en: Pending the time she would finally pack and go, everybody should be content with eating just anything.
yo: Titi di igba ti o maa fi ko eru re lo patapata, ki onikaluku ni itelorun pelu ohunkohun to ba ri je.

en: She knew how best she was going to take care of herself and Tinu.
yo: O mo bi o se ma a toju ara re ati Tinu.

en: Alamu Should learn to look after himself.
yo: Ki Alamu ko bi o se maa toju ara re.

en: His old Mama should not come back again and be given the chance to snap and make any further wicked insinuations.
yo: Ki iya re ma tun pada wa lati maa jagbe ki o si powe ika kankan.

en: Now it was going to be everybody for himself, God for us all.
yo: Bayii, o ti di ki olori dori e mu, ki onikaluku wa fun ra ara re, Olorun wa fun gbogbo wa.

en: "Labake assumed a ""na him sabi"" posture and found herself suddenly in high spirits, she sang in high pitch, her voice rang like a bell."
yo: "Labake n se ise ""oun lo mo"" okan re deede gbe soke lati ko orin re pelu ohun oke, ohun re dun bi i agogo."

en: Her countenance was gay.
yo: Irisi re fi inu didun re han.

en: She told herself she had no problem.
yo: O so fun ara re pe oun ko ni isoro kankan.

en: Nothing to worry about.
yo: Ko ni nnkankan lati daamu fun.

en: No woman on earth in the whole wide world was ever as happy as she was.
yo: Ko si obinrin naa lori ile ni gbogbo aye ti inu re dun to bi inu re se dun.

en: Why should she not be happy?
yo: Ki lo se ti inu re ko ni dun?

en: Her days were numbered in Alamu's house.
yo: Ojo re ti niye ninu ile Alamu.

en: The days of sorrow and tribulations were numbered.
yo: Ojo ibanuje ati wahala re ti niye.

en: The divorce suit was well on the way, she'd almost finished packing her things.
yo: Ejo ikosile ti wa lona, oun naa ti fere e palemo awon nnkan re tan.

en: Tinu gave her no problem, the little girl was full of life and spirit, she herself had been blessed with good health.
yo: Tinu o si fun un ni wahala kankan, omobinrin kekere naa kunfun iye, emi alaafia to peye ni Olorun fi jinki oun fun ara re.

en: In spite of the difficult period at home she'd maintained her pretty look, her elegant posture.
yo: Laduru inira to wa nile o si rewa sibe, iduro re dun sibe.

en: Nobody seeing her would ever think she was a woman with problems.
yo: Ko si eni to ma ri ta so pe obinrin to ni isoro ni.

en: With her present girlish shape and figure, she could go back to England and re-enter the glamorous world of fashion.
yo: Pelu irisi omidan ti o ni lowo lowo yii, o le pada si England ki o si tun pada si aye oge sise e.

en: She would need only three or four months tuning up and reconditioning her body, then catch up finally.
yo: A kan nilo lati tun ara re se fun bi osu meta si merin, a pada sipo.

en: So no regrets, she sang hilariously, she clapped her hands, she danced.
yo: Fun idi eyi, ko si abamo, o rerin-in tariya-tariya, o palemo, o jo.

en: Her soprano voice was throated, and trembling, she wiggle her hips the imaginary rhythm of the brass and the wind instruments, she took measured steps forward backward and jumped up excitedly telling herself again and again that she was a happy woman, happy... h-a-p-p-y! happy... very happy.
yo: Ohun oke re tinrin, o si n gbon riri, o judi si ilu ati orin inu afefe ti o n ro lokan, o ka iwon ese die siwaju-seyin o n fo soke tidunnu-tidunnu, o tun so fun ara re leralera pe obinrin ti o layo ni oun, o layo... l-a-y-o! layo... layo gidi gan.

en: Labake straightened her back and threw out her chest, arms swung freely, her feet marked time left, right, left right, she was sweating!
yo: Labake na eyin, o si ti aya si waju, o jupa laisidiiwo, o n gbe ese sosi sotun-un, sotun-un sosi, o n laagun!

en: But wait... what really was happening?
yo: Sugbon duro na o ... ki gan-an lo n sele?

en: Labake stopped briefly to ask herself.
yo: Labake duro die lati bi ara re ni eyi.

en: She held her breath minute, pondering.
yo: O se eemi fun iseju kan, o n woye.

en: Why all this show of excitement and intoxication?
yo: Kini idi fun gbogbo afihan idunnu ati iyiri yii?

en: Was she going mad? Was she going crazy too?
yo: Se oun ti n ya were? Se oun naa ti n ya were ni?

en: """No, No,"" she answered herself... No."
yo: """Rara, Rara o,"" o da ara re lohun ... Rara."

en: It was Alamu going mad, it was Alamu who had infact, gone mad.
yo: Alamu lo n sinwin, koda, Alamu lo ti ya were.

en: Not her ... Not her!
yo: Kii se oun ...ki i se oun!

en: Before God and man!
yo: Niwaju Olorun ati eniyan!

en: Labake stretched forward her two arms and danced, more enthusiastically, to that imaginary rhythm of music.
yo: Labake na owo re mejeeji siwaju, o si jo pelu itara si ilu afinuro orin naa.

en: No more problem for her.
yo: Ko si isoro fun un mo.

en: She was happy, quite happy. She breezed into the sitting room with her clumsy dancing footsteps, her strange, intricate movement of the hips, slowly towards the standing mirror where she became even more excited
yo: Inu re dun, o dun daadaa. O be wo inu yara igbafe pelu igbese ijo re to lopo, isowojudi re sajeji, o n rin sunmo jigi adaduro diedie nibi ti inu re ti tun bo dun si i.

en: She threw up her two hands into empty air and twisted her body round and round and round several times - until she became dizzy.
yo: O ju owo re mejeeji sinu afefe o si yipoyipo laimoye igba titi ti oyi fi ko o.

en: Then she slumped into the nearby chair, breathing heavily, perspiring profusely.
yo: O si subu sinu aga ti o wa nitosi, o n mi lokeloke.

en: Then the whole building started a momentary journey into space with her as its solitary astronaut...
yo: Leyin eyi ni gbogbo ile bere irinajo ajo pataki sinu ofurufu pelu re gege bi adawako ofurufu ...

en: Why? Why all these? She asked herself again. What's happening? Wasn't she really running out of her mind too?
yo: Kini idi? Kini idifun gbogbo eyi? O tun ara re bi. Ki lo n sele? Se ori tire naa o ti maa yi bayii?

en: Zenabu heaved a heavy sigh from behind the pantry door where she stood watching her madam.
yo: Senabu mi kanle lati eyin ilekun ile ikounjepamo si nibi ti o ti n duro woran madaamu re.

en: She had heard madam's strange songs and now she's seen her dance a strange, off-beat dance.
yo: O ti gbo awon orin ajeji madaamu, o si tun ti ri ijo abami re ti o balu mu.

en: As she tried to get back inside the pantry to avoid her attention, she knocked her head against the wall and tripped over the plates she'd just brought inside the pantry.
yo: Bi o se wa n gbiyanju ati pada sinu ile ounje lati ma je ki won ri i, o seri mo ogiri, o si sise sori awon abo ti o sese ko wo ile ounje naa.

en: There was something about madam now that was always pushing Zenabu away from her.
yo: Nnkankan maa n wa nipa madaamu bayii ti o n le Senabu lara re ni gbogbo igba.

en: Each time she saw her something always told her to run away, or hide.
yo: Nigbakugba ti o ba ri i, nnkankan maa n so fun un pe ki o sa lo, tabi ki o sa pamo.

en: Madam had been so aggressive in recent times.
yo: Madaamu ti n kanra ganan lenu ojo meta yii.

en: It did not appear that she liked her anymore - the way she now looked and talked to her.
yo: Ko fe jo pe o feran re mo isowo wo o ati bi o se n ba soro.

en: Each time madam showed up in the sitting room, therefore, Zenabu would find her way into the toilet to answer nature's call!
yo: Nigbakugba ti Madaamu ba farahan ni yara igbafe, kia ni Senabu maa n wabi gba wo ile igbonse lati lo seyo!

en: But, it did not seem as if that trick would work anymore.
yo: Sugbon ko fe jo pe ogbon yen maa sise mo.

en: Because only yesterday, madam cried out: Zenabu! Zenabu! Where is this mischievous little creature?
yo: Nitori ana alanaa ni madaamu si kigbe pe: Senabu! Senabu! Ibo ni eke kekere yi wa?

en: Here madam! Here madam! Zenabu had answered.
yo: Nibi Madaamu! Nibi Madaamu! Senabu dahun.

en: """Inside the toilet as usual? What the hell is wrong with this little wretch?"
yo: Nile igbonse, bi o se n se? Ki ni o n ba olosi kekere yii ja na?

en: "Always in the toilet 'Nothing madam! Here I am madam!"" Zenabu had stood before her, looking at her pleadingly."
yo: "Gbogbo igba ni ile igbonse ""ko si nnkankan Madaamu, emi re e madaamu"" Senabu duro niwaju re, o n wo pelu oju ebe."

en: Madam's smart fingers caught Zenabis little ears, and as she uttered some obscenities shook her violently, pushing her hither and thither.
yo: Owo madaamu ti yara gba eti Senabu kekere mu o si so awon oro irira si i, o gbo o jigijigi sibi sohun-un.

en: "You will soon go away!' she shouted, ""your job here is almost done, you don't seem to know."
yo: "O pariwo, ""Wa a to lo, ise e ti fere e tan, o dabi i pe o o mo."

en: Soon you'll be returned to your people.
yo: Laipe, won a da e pada fun awon eniyan re.

en: Give me just two or three days.
yo: Funmi lojo meji si meta.

en: Labake let go her hands and Zenabu's body hit the floor with a thump!
yo: Labake tu owo re, Senabu si subu, gba!.

en: There was nobody near to tell all these to.
yo: Ko senikeni nitosi lati so gbogbo eyi fun.

en: Zenabu, very much, longed for somebody to relate her experience to - a trusted person, one who would understand and pity her.
yo: O wu Senabu pupo lati reni so iriri re fun - eni to se e fokan tan, eni ti yoo ye, ti yoo si kaaanu e.

en: Imagine her joy when at last, old Mama again knocking at the door of the house.
yo: E woye bi ayo re se kun to nigbeyin gbeyin ti mama agba tun kan ilekun ile yen.

en: And her all alone in the house too!
yo: Ti o tun ba oun nikan nile!

en: Mama had barely taken her seat when Zenabu's tongue started to wag like the restless tail of a dog on seeing its owner.
yo: Mama o tii jooko taijokoo ti ahon Senabu bere si i gbon bi i ti iru aja ti o n mi ti o ba ri olowo re.

en: Madam has gone mad! Zenabu announced to old Mama.
yo: Madaamu ti ya were! Senabu kede fun mama agba.

en: Gone thoroughly mad! It is a great looks wild like the bush cat.
yo: Won ti ya were gan-an! O ti jo ehanna, bi ologbo-igbo.

en: Her rough bushy hair has dropped carelessly over her neck, stretching to her shoulders making her look like a devil.
yo: Irun re ti o ki bi i igbo yen ti da wale si ejika re, eyi si n je ki jo esu.

en: Her finger nails are now very long and sharp, like the beak of the kingfisher.
yo: Eekanna re ti wa gun gan-an o si mu, a fi bi ti enu eye.

en: There was not a day madam would not deep her long nails inside her cheeks and pull her by the ears.
yo: Ojo kan o le koja ki madaamu ma ti eekanna yen bo o lereke ki o si fa a leti.

en: She showed her blistered ears and swollen cheeks to Mama.
yo: O fi eti ati ereke re wiwu han mama.

en: Madam would one day tear her to pieces, at the rate she was going, with those long, sharp nails of hers or with those snaggy iron teeth because she had become mad.
yo: Madaamu a si ya a si wewe nijo kan pelu bi o se n lo yii, pelu eekanna gigun re ti o mu yen tabi eyin irin re yen nitori o ti ya were.

en: Very mad, Zenabu confessed she was fed up, and would like to go back to her people at home.
yo: Were gidi, Senabu jewo pe o ti su oun, a si wu oun lati pada sodo awon eniyan re nile.

en: Listening to Zenabu relate her story gave Mama great joy.
yo: Mama layo nla bi o se n teti si bi Senabu se n so itan re.

en: She patted the little girl on the back and told her not to worry.
yo: O fi owo lu omo naa jeje leyin, o si so fun un pe ki o ma se daamu.

en: All would be well at last...
yo: Ohun gbogbo a dara nikeyin ...

en: It was good Labake was running mad.
yo: O dara bi Labake se n yi lori.

en: It was expected.
yo: Ohun ti won n reti ni.

en: Mama was not surprised.
yo: Eyi ko si je iyalenu fun mama.

en: Esuniyi had told her Labake would have a bitter taste of her own medicine before long.
yo: Esuniyi ti so fun un pe Labake a je ninu efo ika ti o ti ro ki o to pe.

en: And now, it has started to happen, greater things were soon going to happen.
yo: Ni bayii, o ti wa n sele, nnkan ti o ju eyi a to maa sele.

en: Mama was in town to collect some of Labake's hair and her fingernails.
yo: Irun-ori ati eekanna Labake ni mama wa gba ni igboro.

en: Esuniyi needed them for further action so that Labake's final doom might be sealed.
yo: Esuniyi fe lo o lati fi tunbo ba ti Labake je.

en: It should not surprise anybody, therefore, to see Labake - probably next week or week after - run out to the streets and pitch her home in the market square under the full glare of people who had come to buy and sell.
yo: Ko ni lati ya enikeni lenu leyin eyi lati ri Labake leyin ose kan tabi meji ni awon opopona ki o si duro si gbagede oja nibi ti awon eniyan ti won wa se kara-kata a ti ri iran pipe wo.

en: Esuniyi had said it and Mama knew that was exactly what would happen.
yo: Esuniyi ti so o, mama si mo pe bi o se maa sele gan-an niyen.

en: Finally, Labake would crawl on her knees, in penitence to Esuniyi's lunatic asylum.
yo: Nigbeyin gbeyin, Labake a fi orunkun re rawo ogba Esuniyi pelu ironupiwada.

en: In the case of Alamu, Esuniyi had told Mama there was no cause for alarm anymore.
yo: Ni ti Alamu, Esuniyi ti so fun mama pe ko sewu loko mo.

en: Alamu's condition would start improving henceforth.
yo: Ipo ti Alamu wa a maa yato si daadaa lati isinyi lo.

en: Mama was happy, all what Esuniyi told her had started to come to pass.
yo: Inu mama dun, gbogbo nnkan ti Esuniyi so fun lo ti n wa si i muse.

en: Alamu returned home and met his mother with a gay countenance.
yo: Alamu pada dele, o si ba iya re pelu irisi to fi inu didun han.

en: He greeted the old woman smiling prostrating.
yo: O ki iya naa pelu erin muse lenu ni idobale.

en: He was returning from an important mission to town, the outcome of which greatly cheered his spirit.
yo: O n ti ibi ise kan pataki nigboro bo, eyi ti ayorisi re mu un daraya.

en: For the first time in nine months, Alamu heaved a sigh of relief.
yo: Fun igba akoko ninu osu mesan-an, Alamu mi imi itura.

en: For nine whole months, he had surrounded himself with a mystery that had continued to baffle everybody; a secret that had proved impossible for anybody to decipher - except for that one man who was so dear to him - Adio his only friend.
yo: Fun odidi osu mesan-an gbako ni o ti yi ara re ka pelu adiitu kan ti o ru gbogbo eniyan loju; asiri kan ti ko se e se fun enikeni lati tu - yato si okunrin kan ti o sunmo on pekipeki - Adio ore re kansoso.

en: Now the end of that mystery was in sight.
yo: Nibayii, opin adiitu yen ti wa nitosi.

en: The end of his mental and physical agony was in view, the end of his madness was at hand.
yo: Opin si darudapo opolo ati irora re ti sunmo itosi.

en: He had been told to wait for only two more weeks when all his problems would be practically solved.
yo: Won ti so fun un pe ki o duro fun ose meji si i ti gbogbo isorore a fi yanju patapata.

en: Alamu couldn't believe his ears.
yo: Alamu ko gba eti re gbo.

en: Eagerly, he counted the days one, two, five, ten, fifteen...
yo: Pelu iwanwara ni o fi n ka awon ojo, eni, eji, eta, erin, arun, ewa, meedogun ...

en: Fifteen more days! He counted the hours! The minutes!
yo: Ojo meedogun si i! O n ka wakati! iseju!

en: Adio was amused at Alamu's show of thrill and excitement.
yo: O je iyalenu fun Adio bi Alamu se n se afihan irusoke idunnu re.

en: Well, two weeks more they say and judgment would be delivered?
yo: Bee, ose meji si ni won so, idajo a si waye?

en: That was too short a time compared with the nine months that he'd been waiting.
yo: Iyen kere pupo niye si osu mesan-an ti o ti fi n duro.

en: Was he going to cry or was he going to smile after a fortnight?
yo: Se yoo sunkun ni, tabi yoo rerin-in muse leyin ose meji?

en: He'd been told he would smile.
yo: Won tiso fun un pe a rerin-in muse.

en: Everything pointed to the fact that he would smile.
yo: Gbogbo nnkan lo si toka si i dajudaju pe yoo rerin -in muse.

en: So, it was just proper that he should start smiling from now on, in hope and optimism.
yo: Fun idi eyi, o to ki o kuku bere si i rerin- in muse lati isinyi ninu ireti ati igbagbo pe gbogbo nnkan a sise fun rere.

en: That was why he now met his old mother with a dazzling natural smile...
yo: Idi niyi ti o fi fi erin muse to ri yan-ran yan-ran ko mona pade iya re...

en: Mama watched her son, and her heart sang for joy.
yo: Mama n wo omo re, okan re si korin fayo.

en: Here was her son now smiling at her and responding normally to questions and discussions.
yo: Omo re wa re e to n rerin-in muse si i ti o si n fesi bi o seto si ibeere ati asogba oro won.

en: What was more, Alamu politically took permission from his mother that he had other things doing in town again. He would, therefore, be going back but would not be long.
yo: Kilotun ku, Alamu fi towotowo toro iyonda lowo iya re pe oun si tun ni awon nnkan miiran lati se ni igboro. Fun idi eyi o fe pada jade sugbon ko nii pe.

en: Her son now had the courtesy to take permission! The first part of the job had been accomplished! God bless Esuniyi.
yo: Omo re ti wa ni ibuyi fun un, lati gba aaye! Apa kiini ise naa ti pari! A daa fun Esuniyi.

en: Mama waited patiently for Labake to return.
yo: Mama duro pelu suuru pe ki Labake de.

en: And when she saw her approaching from a distance, she quickly rummaged through the basket she brought from the district and took out a small bottle inside which she kept the herbalist's concoction.
yo: Nigba ti o si ri i ti o n bo loookan, o tete tu apere ti o gbe wa lati igberiko, o si mu igo kekere ti o toju oogun babalawo re si.

en: She'd been properly briefed by Esunivi on how she would apply it.
yo: Esuniyi ti so bi o se maa lo o fun un.

en: So, now, she staggered towards the doorstep of Labake's room and sprinkled the concoction, in a straight line.
yo: Nisinyi, o ta gbon-on gbon-on senu ona yara Labake, o si won oogun naa sile sori ila teere kan.

en: It was important that Labake should walk across it as she entered her so that she might be more violently possessed both mind and body.
yo: O se pataki ki Labake da a koja bi o ba ti n wo yara re ki tie le tubo ba a ni tokan-tara.

en: After sprinkling the preparation, Mama turned round and round five times according to the herbalist's instructions.
yo: Leyin ti o ba ti won oogun naa tan, Mama yipo yipo leemarun-un gegebi babalawo re se la kale.

en: But as she was starting on the fourth round, Labake entered, watching the old woman, mouth agape.
yo: Bi o se wa lori eekerin, Labake wole, o n wo iya agba naa, pelu enu re ni lila sile.

en: Mama stood for a while, nodded in reply to Labake's greetings and then leaned against the wall facing Labake's room, muttering to herself, several times, the short incantatory sentence she'd been asked to recite on first seeing Labake.
yo: Mama duro fun igba die, kanri mole ni esi kiki Labake o si feyinti ogiri ti o koju si ogiri yara Labake, o n so awon ipede ti won ni ko pe ti o ba ti foju gan-an-ni Labake si ara re laimoye igba.

en: At the end of it all, Mama laughed.
yo: Ni opin gbogbo re, mama bu serin-in.

en: Labake's appearance was indeed wild, it was even more terrible than Zenabu had described it.
yo: Irisi Labake jo ti ehanna gidi, o tie tun banileru ju bi Senabu ti sapejuwe re.

en: Labake had really gone mad now - the way she looked like some dreadful monster from inside an old cave poised for rampage!
yo: Labake ti wa ya were gidi bayii - bi o se ri, o dabi i ewele ti o wa lati inu iho apata ti o ti setan ija!

en: Her bushy hair dangled over her neck and shoulders and hid part of her face.
yo: Irun re ti o dabi i igbo da wale sorun ati ejika re, o si bo apa ibikan loju re.

en: The hair... yes, that was one of the items she'd come for.
yo: Irun yen ... bee ni, okan lara awon nnkan ti iya wa wa re e.

en: Before leaving for the district later in the day, she had to ensure that a sizeable lock of that hair was cut and kept away inside her basket.
yo: Ki o to maa lo si igberiko ni irole, o gbodo ri i pe o ri eyi to to won ninu irun naa ge ki o si toju re sinu apere re.

en: Then, Labake's long finger nails, her red, long nails.
yo: Leyin naa ni eekana gigun owo Labake, eekan gigun pupa re.

en: That was one other item she'd come to fetch.
yo: Iyen tun ni nnkan ti o wa mu.

en: Mama's eyes roamed from Labake's black hair to her red nails for some time.
yo: Oju mama n wo lati irun ori Labake dudu de eekana pupa re fun igba die.

en: Finally she looked Labake straight in the face and said;
yo: Nigbeyin, o wo Labake taara o si ni;

en: """Hem... Hem... Hem!"" she cleared her throat, ""Hem... You. You are still here?"""
yo: """Em Em Em!,"" o koko tun ona ofun re se. ""Em....Iwo. Iwo si wa nibi?"""

en: "Labake ignored her and walked towards her room. ""What else are you staying here for?"""
yo: "Labake fi oju paare o si rin lo si ona yara re. ""Ki lo tun n duro nbi fun?"""

en: """Me?,"" Labake asked."
yo: """Se emi?,"" Labake beere."

en: She entered her room crossing Mama's border! Falling into Mama's laid down trap! The herbalist's trap!
yo: O wo yara re lo ni dida ibode mama koja! O ko sinu panpe mama! Panpe babalawo!

en: "And in a minute, she rushed out of her room again and confronted Mama, wearing a murderous look. ""I am now listening!"""
yo: "Ni iseju kan, o ku giri jade lati inu yara re, o dojuko mama pelu iwo ti o le paniyan loju re. ""Mo ti n gbo bayii!"""

en: """She glared. What are you saying, old woman? """
yo: "O wo o. ""Ki ni o n so, iya agba?"""

en: """Asking you... """
yo: """Mo n bi e..."""

en: """Asking me what, old woman!"""
yo: """Bi mi ni ki ni, iya agba?"""

en: """Whether you are ..."""
yo: """Boya o o ..."""

en: """Whether you are what, old woman!"""
yo: """Boya o o se ki ni, iya agba!"""

en: """Not yet gone ..."""
"""Gone where, old woman! ,"" Labake had moved closer to Mama now, pointing her long red finger nails threateningly."
yo: """Lo ibo, iya agba!,"" Labake ti sunmo mama bayii, ti o si n na eekana pupa gigun re tihale-tihale."

en: """You want to beat me?"""
yo: """Se o fe na mi ni?"""

en: Look old woman! My palms are itching to slap the face of an old witch!
yo: Wo o iya! Atelewo n yun mi, o n se mi bi ki n gba oju aje agba kan!

en: See my fingernails moving and moving, anxious now to pluck out the eyes of the hag from their sockets.
yo: Se o ri bi ika owo mi se n sun yii, o n se won bi i ki won fa eyin oju aje mejeeji yo lati inu ako.

en: """Me! Me, Labake?"""
yo: """Emi! Emi, Labake?"""

en: I feel a tingling sensation inside my mouth! I want to test the sharpness of my teeth!
yo: """Mo n ni aibale ninu enu mi! Mo fe danbi eyin enu mi se mu to wo!"

en: Dipping them inside the wrinkled pallor of an old hag!
yo: "Nipa riri won bo inu awo hihunjo agbaya kan"""

en: """Who? It is you old hag! You that is mad! """
yo: """Tani? Iwo agbaya yii ni! Iwo lo ya were!"""
"""Emi? were?"""

en: """Yes, mad! You turned round and round like one in the grip of an epileptic fit."
yo: Beeni, were! O wo yipo yipo bi i eni ti giri warapa gbe.

en: You leaned against the wall like a tired old dog!
yo: O le mo ogiri bi aja gbigbo to re.

en: You whispered like the nanny goat chewing the cud! Mad! Mad! I Say Mad! What else are you but a mad woman!
yo: O n soro kele kele bi ewure alagbato ti o n je apoje lenu! Were! Were! Were ni mo so! Ki tun ni e bi ko se were lobinrin!

en: Labake stood breathing heavily on Mama.
yo: Labake duro, o n mi lokeloke le mama.

en: A sentence more from Mama even a word more, and Labake would have hauled herself on the old woman and sent her grave before the appointed time.
yo: Bi mama ba so gbolohun kan si i, bo ba so eyo oro kan, Labake o ba ti bo iya agba naa, a si ran an lo si saree laito ojo.

en: Mama smiled, and tactfully withdrew.
yo: Mama rerin-in muse, o si fi ogbon ewe jawo.

en: She was not annoyed, not annoyed at all.
yo: Ko binu, ko binu rara.

en: Labake was already under a spell.
yo: Oogun lo n sise lara Labake.

en: Labake had literally dug her own grave now that she had crossed the concoction line across the doorstep of her own room.
yo: Labake ti gbe koto ara re nisinyi ti o ti da ila oogun koja lenu ona yara re.

en: What remained for her to do was to literally put Labake inside the prepared coffin, nail the coffin, and bury it inside the deep earth.
yo: Ohun ti o kan ku fun un ni ki o gbe Labake sinu posi, ki o kan an pa, ki o si sin-in sinu ile ti o gbe.

en: Mama withdrew and allowed Labake to continue raving and raging.
yo: Mama yowo, o si gba Labake laaye lati tesiwaju lati maa soro fitafita pelu irunu.

en: Mind your own business henceforth, old hag! Stop poking your wrinkled nose! You have outlived your usefulness.
yo: Lati isinyi lo, sogba e agbaya! Ye e na imu hihunjo re yen! O ti gbele aye koja iwulo re.

en: Leave me old witch! Leave me alone! Go back to the district to say your last prayers on earth.
yo: Fi mi sile aje agbaya! Fi mi lorun sile! Pada lo si igberiko lati lo se adura ikeyin re lori ile eepe.

en: Your time is up already and your grave is ready.
yo: Asiko re tie tito, sare re si ti wa nile.

en: Never come to town again.
yo: Ma wa si igboro mo lae.

en: You hear that hag!
yo: Soogbo be yen aje!

en: Mama did not utter a word in reply, rather she was smiling, she knew what was happening.
yo: Mama o fesi oro kan, kaka bee n se lo n rerin-in muse, o mo ohun to n sele.

en: Labake was mad now.
yo: Labake ti ya were bayii.

en: Thoroughly mad. Just as Esuniyi had said, so she would not give a single reply, very soon, Labake would pack to her new home in the market square. So, let the tirade continue: Go on!
yo: Were san-un san-un. Gege bi Esuniyi se so fun, idi eyi ko ni esi kankan, laipe, Labake a keru lo si ile re tuntun ni gbagede oja. Fun idi eyi, ki idan ibinu soro naa tesiwaju: Tesiwaju!

en: Yes, go on! Are you tired?
yo: Bee ni, ko tesiwaju! Se o ti re e ni?

en: You couldn't be tired yet! Let the tirade continue by all means!
yo: Ko ti i ye ki o re e! O gbodo je ki o tesiwaju lonakona!

en: After some five minutes, there was quiet Mama winked at Zenabu; silently and knowingly, the little girl nodded her head back.
yo: Idakeroro wa leyin iseju marun-un, mama seju si Senabu; kelekele naa ni omobinrin kekere naa kanri mole pada.

en: She had grown so much used to Mama now that communication between them had become quite easy.
yo: O ti mowo mama to bee ti ibanisoro ti wa rorun laarin won.

en: Labake, after working herself up, setting her own body ablaze went inside the bathroom to have a cold shower and swiftly, Zenabu moved into action.
yo: Leyin ti o ti da ara re laamu, ti o ti gbe emi ara re gbona Labake gbona baluwe lo lati sanra pelu omi tutu, ni kia si ni Senabu bere ise

en: She was not a stranger to madam's bedroom, she knew all the nooks and corners of things included in the room.
yo: Ki i se ajeji si yara madaamu, gbogbo ibi kolofin ati ikorogun yara naa ni o mo.

en: She knew where madam kept all her most private of all her possessions.
yo: O mo gbogbo ibi ti madaamu n toju awon nnkan e si titi mo awon nnkan asiri re.

en: And now that madam had neatly packed, it was all the more easy for Zenabu to locate the two items she was looking for. Under three minutes, she had finished the assignment and she came out of madam's room clutching the two items, neatly wrapped up inside an old paper, and smiling at Mama.
yo: Nisinyi ti madaamu ti fere e ko eru re tan, o rorun fun un lati ri awon nnkan meji ti o wa. Laarin iseju meta, o ti pari ise ti won gbe fun un o si jade lati inu yara madaamu, ti o si di nnkan mejeeji mowo, o fi beba atijo kan we e, ti o si ri tonitoni, o si n rerin-in muse si mama.

en: Mama got the piece of paper and quickly tucked it away inside her basket.
yo: Mama gba a o si tete fi sinu apere re.

en: When finally Labake emerged from inside the bathroom, what she saw was little Zenabu playing with Tinu on the corridor, and Mama bidding Alamu who had just come in goodbye promising to check back on him before the end of that week.
yo: Nigba ti madaamu jade lati inu baluwe, ohun ti o ri nipe Senabu kekere n ba Tinu sere lenu ona, mama si n dagbere fun Alamu to sese n wole de, ti won si n se ileri lati wa wo o ki o to di opin ose naa.

en: The two items were secure inside her basket.
yo: Awon nnkan meji naa wa ni ipamo ninu apere re.

en: Mama had stolen a look at the two items herself, and had been very much pleased: four of Labake's long red nails which she pointed at her a short while ago and which she had removed as she Chtered the room.
yo: Mama ti ji awon nnkan naa wo ninu apere re, o si te e lorun; merin ninu eekanna pupa owo Labake ti o fi nawo si i laipe yii, ti o yo nigba ti o wo yara.

en: Her false nails! Then Labakes Small lock of hair, which some minutes ago had boen dangling over her body and which she had removed as she prepared to go to the bathroom, her wig!
yo: Eekan-na ayederu! Ati die ninu irun Labake ti o da wale sara re laipe yii ti o yo nigba ti o fe wo baluwe, ayederu irun re!

en: These two items now for Esubiyi!
yo: Awon nnkan meji yii ti wa nile fun Esuniyi.

en: The time was near, when Labake would run of the house into the streets naked: when she would pitch her home at the market square, when she would crawl on her knees to Esuniyi's camp in the isolated area of the forest in the district!
yo: Asiko naa ti sunmo, ti Labake a sare jade ninu ile nihooho wo opopona: igba ti o maa so gbagede oja di ile, igbati a rako lori orunkun re wo ogba Esuniyi ti o wa ni agbeegbe iyasoto ninu igbo igberiko.

en: So far so good, that about summed up the radiance on Mama's face as she related the story of her successful visit to town to Esuniyi.
yo: Gbogbo iyen lo yorisi idanmoranto han loju mama bi o se n royin itan aseyori irinajo re si igboro fun Esuniyi.

en: Alamu's condition had improved, Alamu would not suffer the indignity of having his head shaved. He would not suffer the humiliation of being thrown inside the dark room of the mad house with those eccentric inmates velling and hooting.
yo: Ipo Alamu ti yato, ko ni i kan abuku ori fifo mo. Ko ni jiya irenisile ti won a ti ju u si yaradudu ile were pelu awon ogidi asinwin ti won maa n han ti won tun n pariwo gege bi alagbaagbe.

en: "I can still see trouble,' Mama heard Esuniyi say, ""Trouble is not yet over completely."""
yo: """Wahala ni mo si i n ri yii,"" mama gbo ti Esuniyi so eyi ""Ijongbon o ti i pari patapata."

en: "As long as the enemies agent remains with your son at home, anything could still happen."""
yo: Ni won igba ti asoju awon ota ba si wa ninu ile pelu omo re, ohunkohun lo si le sele.

en: "Mama looked at Esuniyi, ""what shall we do now with Labake?"""
yo: "Mama wo Esuniyi, ""Ki la wa fe se pelu Labake bayii?."""

en: Accursed Labake.
yo: Labake eni egun.

en: The enemies' agent.
yo: Asoju awon ota.

en: Mama felt a sharp pin pricking her heart, Labake was that pin!
yo: O n se mama bi igba ti abere to mu gun-un lokan Labake si ni abere naa.

en: "She must be flushed out', Esuniyi continued, ""and very quickly too."""
yo: """A ni lati ti i jade,"" Esuniyi tesiwaju, ""kiakia si ni pelu."""

en: It's only then that we can breathe properly.
yo: Leyin naa ni a to le rimu mi.

en: But with these two things you have brought now.'
yo: Sugbon pelu nnkan meji ti e ti mu wayii ...

en: Esuniyi held out the piece of paper inside which Labake's lock of hair and nails were wrapped.... 'No problem, Mama'
yo: "Esuniyi yo beba ti won di irun ati eekana Labake si yii jade... ""Ko si wahala, Mama."""

en: Mama cleared her throat.
yo: Mama tun ona ofun re se.

en: Well, thank you. What I want you to do now is to... to... to...
yo: Bee, e seun. Ohun ti mo fe ki e se nisinyi ni pe ki..ki ... ki ...

en: They were interrupted by the sound of a deep murmur coming from inside one of the rooms of the mad house.
yo: Ohun ejo wuuru kiki kan lati okan ninu awon yara ile were naa ni o da oro mo won lenu

en: What I will want you to... to... to...
yo: """Ohun ti maa fe ki e ...e ...e ..."""

en: The murmur from the mad house had now developed into a loud noise, splitting listeners'.
yo: Ohun wuuru ti o wa lati inu ile were naa ti wa di ariwo nla, ti o fere di eniyan leti.

en: That was a common feature of Esuniyi's enclave.
yo: Eyi ni abuda ahamo Esuniyi kan.

en: No doubt, his people were at their game their, usual game.
yo: Laisi ani-ani, awon eeyan re ti bere ere ije won bi won se maa n se.

en: The usual physical attack one another had probably started again.
yo: Ija ti won maa n ja fun ti bere niyen.

en: Each time they started it, it was usually like hell itself breaking loose.
yo: Nigbakugba ti won ba si bere, gbegede maa n gbina.

en: They would pounce on one another, like rabies-infected dogs and snap and smack and tear.
yo: Won a bo ara won bi i aja olokunrun, won a lu ara won, won a tun ya ara won je.

en: The lunatics yelling noise drowned Mama's voice.
yo: Ariwo awon were naa mu ohun mama wale.

en: Mama had started appealing passionately to the medicine man to use all his power to eliminate Labake as quickly as possible - today or tomorrow.
yo: Mama ti bere si i be Baba oloogun pelu itara, pe ki o lo gbogbo agbara re lati yanju Labake ni kiakia - lonii sola.

en: Bring her down to her knees.
yo: Ki o mu un wale lori orunkun re.

en: Cause the other invisible enemies of her son to wander naked into the thick jungle where hyenas and leopards would be waiting to launch a fierce attack on them, that was what she wanted.
yo: Ki o je ki awon ota omo re yooku ti o se e foju ri rin lo nihooho sinu igbo kijikiji ti ikoko ati amotekun a ti maa duro lati doju ko won, ohun ti Mama fe niyen.

en: That was what she was telling Esuniyi to do when the noise from the lunatics came on more and more compellingly.
yo: Nnkan ti o n so fun Esuniyi pe ki o se niyen ti ariwo awon were yen fi tun po si i.

en: Esuniyi stood up abruptly, he raced towards the direction of the noise.
yo: Esuniyi dide giri, o sare sona ibi ti ariwo naa ti n wa.

en: In a minute, he ran back again.
yo: Laaarin iseju kan, o ti sare pada.

en: He rushed inside an inner room in his own Apartment.
yo: O sare wo yara kan ninu iyewu tire.

en: He came out circling a long whip over head.
yo: O jade pelu atori kan ti o ka yi ori re.

en: His eyes bulged. The veins stood out in single layers over his strong arms, his lips trembled, his body shook with anger and emotion.
yo: Oju re ran. Isan da duro loto ni owo re lile, ete re n gbon, ara re n gbon pelu ibinu ati imi-edun.

en: At nomal times, Esubiyi would look innocent and calm, talking slowly, quickly, camestly.
yo: Ni awon igba to se gege, Esuniyi maa n tutu, a jo alaise, ara re bale, a maa soro diedie, laipariwo pelu ifokansi.

en: He would smile gently, looking you straight in the face as he spoke.
yo: A rerin-in muse jeje, a maa woju yin bi o se n soro.

en: He was then like any other man, every other man like you and me.
yo: Nigba yen o dabi i gbogbo okunrin, bi okunrin gidi bi iwo ati emi.

en: But on such occasions as this, when this camp was in pandemonium, Esuniyi was a completely different man.
yo: Sugbon leekookan bayii, ti yan-pon-yan-rin ba wa ninu ago yi, Esuniyi maa n di okunrin ara oto.

en: He would bark out orders, his voice roaring like a clap of thunder. He was a man of great strength and physique.
yo: A pariwo ase re, pelu ohun re ti o n buramu-ramu bi atewo aara. O je okunrin ti o kunfun okun nla ati irisi.

en: He would grab his victim with the viciousness of an octopus and the ferocity of a tiger.
yo: A gba eni ti o se mu pelu iwa eeri ati iroro ekun.

en: The strong muscles of his arms would become tense and straighten up.
yo: Isan apa re a yi, a wa le koko.

en: The bones would screech almost cracking.
yo: Egungun re a na, a fere e le kan.

en: His victim would let forth a fearful yelp and recoil immediately in total submission like the trampled millipede.
yo: Eni ti o gba mu naa a pariwo iberu, a si pada seyin pelu ijowo patapata bi i ti ookun ti ati ra mole.

en: Apart from the use of physical force, Esubiyi had other methods.
yo: Yato si ti ipa oju ko-oju, Esuniyi ni awon ilana miiran.

en: You would see him holding his blood-stained antelope horn high up in the air, addressing the four elements - the controllers of human destiny - invoking the invisible spirit of the air to work on the boiling nerves of the lunatics and restore them to order.
yo: Wa a ri i ti o di iwo etu re ti eje ti yi mu soke ninu afefe, a maa ba awon awomo merin aye soro, awon adari kadara eda - o n peri awon emi inu afefe lati sise ninu isan gbigbona awon were naa ki ara won le wale.

en: And it would be so, if only momentarily.
yo: O si maa ri bee, bi o tile je fun igba die.

en: "But now, it was the ""wham-wham-wham! method."
yo: Sugbon nisinyi, ilana wamu-wamu-wamu ni o fe lo.

en: For over five minutes, Mama heard the lashing sound of the whip over human bodies and shrank.
yo: Funbi i iseju marun-un, Mama n gbo ohun atori lara awon eniyan ara re si sunki.

en: This was truly no ordinary place.
yo: Ibi yii ki i se ibi lasan rara.

en: At the end of his punitive step, Esuniyi retumed to Mama with the composure of a normal human being, a serene look, once again, on his face.
yo: Ni opin igbese ifiya-jeniyan re, Esuniyi pada lo ba mama pelu ikorajo eniyan ti o pe, pelu oju omoluabi leekan si i.

en: """It has to be like that,"" he told Mama. ""That's how it should be Mama... otherwise ... otherwise..."" Mama nodded knowingly."
yo: """O ni lati ri bayen,"" o so fun mama, ""Bi o se ye ki o ri ni yen mama ...bi beeko ...bi beeko..."" Mama kanri mole ni idahun."

en: She knew what Esuniyi's 'otherwise' meant...
yo: "O mo ohun ti itumo ""bi beeko"" Esuniyi je..."

en: Otherwise, the Lunatics themselves would take over the control of the mad house.
yo: Bi beeko, awon were funrawon naa agbajoba ile naa.

en: Otherwise, they would turn the place into a battlefield.
yo: Bi beeko, won a so ibe di papa ogun.

en: Otherwise they would attack himself one day and chase him out of his house. They can even kill him.
yo: Bi beeko won a dojuko Esuniyi lojo kan, won a si le e jade kuro ninu ogba re. Won tun le pa a

en: Otherwise, they would burn down all the buildings inside the camp and escape.
yo: Bi beeko, won a dana sun gbogbo ile inu ago naa, won a si na papa bora.

en: There was nothing they would not do once law and order broke down.
yo: Ko si nnkan ti won o le se ti ofin ati ase ba daru.

en: Mama heaved a sigh of relief.
yo: Mama mi imi itura.

en: She had cause to be Thankful to God.
yo: O ni idi lati maa fope fun Eledumare.

en: What would she do if Alamu to be there among these people and be given this harsh, acrimonious treatment?
yo: Ki ni iba se kani pe Alamu wa laarin awon eniyan yii, ti yoo si gba ihuwasi iroro buruku yii?

en: What would she do if it was her son that was now standing, half naked, under that tree, some yards away, pointing at nothing and talking to the empty air?
yo: Ki ni iba se kani omo re ni o duro labe igi okankan yen, ti o ti fere e ja si ihooho tan, ti o n nawo si nnkan ti o si, ti o si n ba afefe ofifo soro?

en: If it was Alamu that was now walking round and round that small building without any motive, and in such endless merry-go-round? What would she do? Nothing.
yo: Bi o ba je Alamu ni o n rin yika ile kekere yen lainidii ninu iru irin layipo yii? Ki ni iba se? Ko si.

en: If it was Alamu that was now clad in rags and urinating on the palm of his outstretched left hand and laughing?
yo: Bi o ba je Alamu ni o wo akisa ti o tun n to si atelewo owo-osi re ti o na siwaju ti o tun n rerin-in?

en: Esuniyi watched Mama and noticed the grim look of concern over her countenance
yo: Esuniyi wo mama, o si sakiyesi ikoro to wa loju re.

en: Mama, there is no cause for fear.
yo: Mama, ko si idi fun iberu.

en: All will be well at last.
yo: Ohun gbogbo a dara nikeyin.

en: The whole job is as good as finished.
yo: Gbogbo ise naa ti fere e pari.

en: But you still have to bring him here.
yo: Sugbon e si ni lati mu u wa sibi

en: """Bring who?"" Mama asked."
yo: """Mu tani wa?"" Mama beere"

en: """Bring your child Mama. Your son?"""
yo: """E mu omo yin wa mama. Omokunrin ti yin?"""

en: You mean that... that... Alamu still has to.. to... come...
yo: """Eyi tumo si pe... pe... Alamu tun ni lati... lati... wa"""

en: Yes, he must be here himself, personally.
yo: Bee ni, o ni lati wa nibi, funrare.

en: To drink from the medicine pot, to swim inside that open whirlpool, and to be incised on the cheeks, chest and the armpits.
yo: A mu lati inu ikoko agbo, a we ninu odo agbo ni gbangba, a a si sin gbere si i lereke, ni igba aya ati abiya re.

en: Your child has to be adequately protected.
yo: Omo yin ni lati ni idaabobo to peye.

en: Nothing must be left to chance.
yo: Nnkankan o gbodo yo o le.

en: Mama looked disturbed.
yo: Iwo idaamu wa loju mama.

en: How easy was it going to be bringing Alamu to the district, and to the asylum? That aspect of the matter had just occurred to her. How was she going to do it?
yo: Bawo ni yoo se rorun fun un lati mu Alamu wa si igberiko, paapaa julo, si ogba Esuniyi? Apa oro yii sese han de si ni. Bawo ni o se maa se e?

en: Should she feign sickness, send a message down to him in town and ask him to come and see her urgently on her sick bed?
yo: Se ki o dogbon aisan, ki o ranse si i nigboro pe ki o wa ri i kiakia ni dubule aisan re?

en: What would she say when finally he arrived?
yo: Ki ni yoo so fun un to ba ti wa de?

en: Should she come out frankly and tell him the truth?
yo: se ki o wa so ooto fun un ni?

en: The bitter truth about his condition?
yo: Otito ti o koro nipa ipo re?

en: The truth that he himself had not been aware of all these days?
yo: Otito ti oun gan alara ko mo lati iye ojo yii?

en: Mama reflected for a minute.
yo: Mama ro o fun iseju kan.

en: Her mind wandered
yo: Okan re sako lo.

en: Well, no choice, no choice, she had to do it.
yo: Bee, ko si ani-ani, ko si ani-ani, o ni lati se e.

en: It was a task she must perform.
yo: O je ise ti o gbodo se.

en: Afterall, Alamu was her son, her only son.
yo: Paripari e, omo re saa ni, omo re kan soso.

en: She was duty-bound to let him know the whole truth however unpalatable it was going to be to him.
yo: Eto re ni lati je ki o mo gbogbo ooto oro naa, bi o ba tie dun mo on.

en: """You are mad!"" She would let her son know point blank - and without mincing words."
yo: """O ti ya were!,"" A je ki omo re mo, a diju so o laideenapenu."

en: It would surely sound unbelievable to him, probably hurt him, probably embarrass him.
yo: Dajudaju ko ni gba eti re gbo, o le dun-un, o le tabuku ba a.

en: But she would not care.
yo: Sugbon ko ni wo iyen.

en: She would say it again, loud and clear.
yo: A tun un so daadaa.

en: """Alamu, you are mad! The way you talk shows you are mad."
yo: """O ti ya were Alamu! Isowosoro re gan-an fi han pe o ya were."

en: The way you behave shows you are mad.
yo: Ihuwasi re fihan pe o ya were.

en: The way you look shows you are mad.
yo: Bi o se n wo gan-an fi han pe o ya were.

en: Yes. You-are-mad-my-son! But Alamu, it is the work of the enemies.
yo: Bee ni. Omo mi o ti ya were! Sugbon Alamu, ise awon ota ni.

en: "It would be important to let him know, ""This is the work of the enemies."
yo: "O maa se pataki lati je ki o mo, ""Ise awon ota ni eyi."""

en: And, at the centre of it all is none but your very wife, Your own very wife. She's the enemies' agent'.
yo: Ati wi pe, pabanbari gbogbo re o seyin iyawo re, iyawo re gan-an. Oun ni asoju awon ota.

en: Whether or not Alamu would believe this was not important to her.
yo: Boya Alamu gba eyi gbo tabi ko gba a ko se pataki si i.

en: She would not care a jot.
yo: Ko kan an bin-in-tin bayii.

en: That was going to be Alamu's own problem.
yo: Wahala ti Alamu niyen.

en: "What was important was to let him know all the details, all the truth. ""But let me tell you, Alamu, that Labake will pay. You don't worry.,"" she would console her son with it."
yo: "Nnkan ti o se pataki ni lati je ki o mo nkan to n sele lekun-un rere, gbogbo otito ibe. ""sugbon je ki n sofun e Alamu, Labake yen a fenu hora. Iwo saa ma seyonu.,"" a tu omo re ninu pelu eyi."

en: You just don't worry.
yo: Iwo saa ma seyonu.

en: """I have tried my best to save the situation and Esubiyi has been assisting us so much."
yo: """Mo ti sa gbogbo ipa mi lati wa ojutuu si i, Esuniyi si ti n ran wa lowo gidi."

en: That's why you are still alive today, that's why you have not gone out onto the streets - you may not know.
yo: Eyi lo fa a ti o fi wa laaye lonii, idi niyi to o se ti i ja si igboro - iwo le ma mo.

en: On your behalf. I have made sacrifices to the gods with billy goats, alligator pepper, bitter kola and red palm-oil.
yo: Nitori tire. Mo ti rubo awon orisa pelu ewure, orogbo, ataare ati epo pupa.

en: Mama knew Alamu would be shocked to hear all these but, could she be bothered?
yo: Mama mo pe gbogbo eyi a ja Alamu laya bi o ba gbo, sugbon se o ye ki iyen tun da oun fun rare laamu?

en: No, she would not even raise her head up to look at her son's face.
yo: Rara, ko ni wule gbe ori soke lati woju omo re.

en: """Now, get prepared Alamu,"" she would finally tell him, we are going together now to see Esuniyi."
yo: """Alamu gbaradi,"" a papa so fun un ""A jo n lo ri Esuniyi nisinyi."""

en: """Me? What for?"" She could imagine her son questioning back, protesting."
yo: """Emi? Fun ki ni?,"" O n ro o bi omo re se n dahun ibeere pada, ti o n tenumo pe."

en: """Not me! Not me!."""
yo: """Emi ko! Emi ko!"""

en: """It's you Alamu!,"" she resolved she would shout back, 'It's you, You, you and me! We'll go together now, to the herbalist."
yo: """Iwo ni Alamu !,"" o pinnu lati pariwo mo on pada, Iwo ni, Iwo, Iwo ati emi! A jo n lo nisinyi ni, sodo onisegun."

en: You will drink from his medicine pot. Take your bath inside the open pool in the centre of his camp and be incised on the body.
yo: Wa a mu lati inu ikoko agbo re. Wa a we ninu ibu omi ti o wa ni aarin ibudo re, won a si sin gbere si o lara.

en: Alamu would probably Laugh at her and walk away, or take to his heels even.
yo: Afaimo ki Alamu ma fi se yeye tabi ki o kan kuro niwaju re, tabi ki o tile ki ere mole.

en: She would pursue him herself.
yo: Mama funrare a le e mu.

en: Mama imagined herself chasing Alamu down the stony crooked forest path.
yo: Mama woye ara re bi o se n le Alamu lo sona igbo olokuuta naa.

en: Chasing him to the bank of river Akokura, appealing to him to come back. begging him, before he would cross that river.
yo: Ti o n le e lo sona eti odo Akokura, ti o bee pe ki o pada, ti o n bee ki o to di wi pe o koja odo naa.

en: Before he would cross the Rubicon.
yo: Ki o to di wi pe o koja ibi ti ko ti ni le pada.

en: Once he crossed river Akokura, there will be no further hope.
yo: Bi o ba file koja odo Akokura, ko ni i si ireti kankan fun un mo.

en: He should not cross any river - or else... She imagined her son still hurrying away.
yo: Ko gbodo koja odo kankan, bi bee ko... O n woye bi omo re se n kanju lo.

en: The mighty power of the enemies was upon him, pushing him, pushing him, making him resist all attempt to bring sanity back. She could hear Alamu snapping back at her.
yo: Owo agbara nla awon ota wa lara re, o n ti i, ti i, o n je ki o maa ko gbogbo igbiyanju lati mu ki ori-re pe. O n gbo bi Alamu se n jagbe mo on.

en: Go back to the village Mama! Go and rest in the village! I would go back to town.
yo: Mama, e pada sabule! E lo sinmi labule! Emi a pada si igboro.

en: Nothing is wrong with me! I have business to do in town, so, I am hurrying away!
yo: Nnkan o se mi! Mo ni ise ti mo fe se ni igboro, mo tete n lo!

en: Mama imagined herself launching a grip, a firm grip on him, a 'kill-me-now, kill-me-now' grip.
yo: Mama tun woye ara re bi o se gba a mu, o gba mu giri-giri, igbamu 'pami-nisinyi, pami nisinyi'.

en: Esuniyi laughed, Mama sat straight, waking up suddenly from her momentary dream.
yo: Esuniyi rerin-in, Mama jokoo sara, o deede taji loju ala asiko ti o n la.

en: Esuniyi had all along been watching her reading her mind.
yo: Esuniyi ti n wo o lateekan ti o n ka nnkan ti o n lo lokan re.

en: It was as if he had seen the picture of what went on inside it.
yo: N se ni o dabi i pe o ti ri aworan nnkan ti o n lo nibe.

en: """Your son will not refuse coming to the district Mama."" Esunyi said, I'll go with you to bring him."
yo: Mama, omo yin o ni ko lati wa si abule'. Esuniyi so, Maa tele yin lo lati mu un wa.

en: He will gladly follow us.
yo: Tayotayo lo maa fi tele wa.

en: Don't worry Mama, I'll just pop into their house for a minute or two.
yo: E ma da ara yin laamu mama, maa kan yo foro sinu ile won fun bi iseju kan si meji.

en: Our eyes would be four, and that's all. I'll rush back to the district and he'll follow later, probably that same day or the following day.
yo: Oju wa a se merin, o de ma tan sibe. Maa sare pada wa si abule, a si tele mi bi o ba ya boya ni oni je lojo naa tabi ojo keji.

en: Mama heaved a heavy sigh again, she had implicit confidence in the powers of the medicine man.
yo: Mama tun mi kanle, o ni igbekele to duro giri ninu agbara baba oloogun.

en: With this man, Esuniyi, nothing seemed impossible.
yo: Pelu okunrin yii, Esuniyi, o fere e le ma si nnkan ti o seese.

en: So, she left for the village with a feeling of relief.
yo: Fun idi eyi, o gbona abule lo, pelu itura lokan re.

en: There was one vacant room inside Mama's mud building in the village where Alamu could put up, if need be, when finally they succeeded in bringing to the district.
yo: Yara ofifo wa ninu ile alamo Mama nibi ti Alamu le duro si, bi o ba nilo, leyin ti o ba ti jaja saseyori ninu mimu un wa si abule.

en: He did not have to return In the same day.
yo: Ko nilo lati pada si igboro ni ojo naa.

en: Esuniyi might want him to stay over.
yo: Esuniyi le fe ki o sun moju.

en: In that case, Alamu could come to the village and stay the night.
yo: Fun idi iyen, Alamu le wa si Abule ki o si sun moju ojo keji.

en: Mama set about putting the vacant room in good order instantly, she brushed down the cobwebs and chased away the geckos and cockroaches.
yo: Mama bere si i tun yara naa se lesekese, o gbon gbogbo jankariwo sile, o si le awon aayan ati omo-onile lo.

en: She sprinkled water on the floor and started sweeping it, she sneezed for the umpteenth time, her head rang like a bell.
yo: O won omi sile, o si bere si i gba a, o n sin laimoye igba, ori re n ro bi agogo.

en: She blew her nose, water came from her eyes and she went deaf for a minute.
yo: O fun imu re, omi jade loju re, eti re di fun iseju kan.

en: Later when she yawned, the doors of her ears flung open and the trapped air rushed out of them, again she sneezed.
yo: Nigba to ya ti o yan, ilekun inu eti re si gbayawu, ategun to ti ha sibe sa jade o tun sin.

en: Life was all suffering.
yo: Ijiya gba a ni aye je.

en: That was even more so with Mama.
yo: Bi o se ri fun mama gan-an re e.

en: She'd suffered, probably like no other woman had ever suffered before.
yo: O ti jiya, iru iya ti obinrin kankan o je ri.

en: Four times in her life, she lost her pregnancy. Two before Alamu and two after him.
yo: Eemerin ni aye re ni oyun ti baje mo on lara. Meji ki o to bi Alamu ati meji miiran leyin Alamu.

en: Then she couldn't become pregnant again, then she reached menopause.
yo: Leyin naa ko le loyun mo, o wo iye ojo ori ti ko ti le sabiyamo mo.

en: Alamu remained her only child.
yo: Alamu nikan lomo kan soso ti o seku fun un.

en: When about ten years ago, her son went to the white man's country, Mama felt she had lost the battle to cure permanent happiness in life.
yo: Nibi i odun mewaa seyin, ti omo re lo si ilu Oyinbo, Mama ro wi pe ogun wiwa ayo ayeraye ti bori re.

en: It was as if Alamu had gone on a jourmey of no return.
yo: N se ni o dabi eni pe Alamu ti rin irinajo aremabo.

en: Mama was virtually left alone in the world.
yo: Mama nikan lo dabi eni pe o ku laye.

en: "Her only ""garment' had been literally stripped off her."
yo: """Aso"" re kansoso ni won ti bo lara re."

en: And she stood naked.
yo: O wa wa ni ogolonto.

en: Life lost its colour and radiance.
yo: Aye ti padanu awo ati ewa re.

en: Alamu's father who could have provided the much-needed support and assurance for her had broken down in health and later died whispering the name of his son, Mama became visibly shaken mentally and emotionally, thereafter.
yo: Baba Alamu ti i ba se alatileyin ati olufo kantan ti dubule aisan ti o si je oruko omo re lenu titi o fi ku, eyi gbo mama de opolo ati imolara leyin igba naa.

en: It was true they often read Alamu's letters to her hearing, letting her know Alamu was alive.
yo: Ooto ni pe won maa n ka leta Alamu si eti igbo re, lati fi je ki o mo pe Alamu si wa laaye.

en: Still Mama would not believe.
yo: Sugbon sibesibe, Mama o gbagbo.

en: She would close her eyes and listen to the soothing words contained in Alamu's letter. He was hale and hearty, doing well in his studies, he was there in the cold land struggling to secure a better future for himself and Mama, very soon he would be coming back home to join her.
yo: A diju re, a si teti si awon oro itura to wa ninu leta Alamu. Ara re a ya, o si mokun, o si n se daadaa ninu eko re, o wa nibe ninu otutu, o n tiraka lati wa ojo iwaju fun ara re ati Mama, laipe a maa pada bo nile lati wa dara po mo on.

en: Mama should take heart, stay alive and continue to pray for him.
yo: Ki Mama mokan, ki o wa laaye ki o si tesiwaju lati maa gbadura fun un.

en: """Your ever loving son - Alamu."""
yo: """Omo yin onifee ooto - Alamu """

en: Mama would open her eyes and muse to herself in disbelief.
yo: Mama a laju re, a si sasaro si ara re ni aigbagbo.

en: Could all these be true really?
yo: Se gbogbo eyi le je otito sa?

en: All these might just be a mere sweet dream.
yo: Gbogbo eyi le je ala didun lasan.

en: Or the trick of some good people who did not want her inside the grave too soon.
yo: Tabiki o je ete awon eeyan daadaa kan ti ko fe ki o wo saree laitojo.

en: Those who did not want her to die of loneliness, who then had to console her with letters allegedly written by her son.
yo: Awon ti ko fe ki o ku iku adagbe, ti won si ni lati tu u lokan pelu leta ti won ni omo re ko.

en: The son she knew, deep down in her heart had gone on a journey of no return.
yo: Omo re ti o mo, lokan ara re ti lo si irinajo aremabo.

en: Lost forever, after waiting eight years in vain for Alamu's return, there was no other conclusion Mama could draw.
yo: O ti sonu titi lae, leyin ti o ti duro iduro asan fun odun mejo fun ipadabo Alamu, ko si ipinnu miiran ti mama le ni.

en: And that explained why the old woman gazed at her son in wonder and incredulity the day he finally arrived back in the country from England.
yo: Iyen ni o si salaye idi ti iya agba naa se wo omo re ni iwo iyanu ati aigbagbo ni ojo ti o jaja pada sile lati ilu England.

en: That explained why, for a whole week after, Mama kept asking herself whether the healthy looking Vivacious young man was really Alamu or his ghost.
yo: Iyen salaye idi, ti mama fi n bi ara re boya omokunrin ti o da sasa yii ni Alamu, tabi oku re ni fun odidi ose kan gbako.

en: And she called him by all his names - all the affectionate names he gave him during childhood, several times each day for one whole week.
yo: O si n pe e ni gbogbo oruko re - gbogbo awon oruko tokunfun ife ti o n pe e nigba kekere, lai moye igba lojo kookan fun odidi ose kan.

en: It was the climax of her joy, such joyous period would came back again to Mama. Life was one long chain of suffering. No end to it.
yo: O je sonso ayo re, iru igba ayo bee o pada de ba Mama mo. Ile aye je sekeseke iya gigun kan. Ti ko lopin.

en: It was a continuous event.
yo: O je igbese ti o n tesiwaju.

en: Mama thought the end of suffering had come with the return of her son.
yo: Mama ro o wi pe opin ijiya oun ti de nigba ti omo re de.

en: But precisely two years after Alamu's retum, a heartache of a different dimension took possession of Mama.
yo: Sugbon kete ti o pe odun meji leyin ti Alamu de, ibanuje ti o gbona aramiiran yo lo tun de ba Mama.

en: A heartache which gave her several sleepless nights, which made her have several dreadful dreams, which made her breasts twitch several times, and which now made her a regular visitor to the herbalist's asylum.
yo: Ibanuje ti o fun un ni opolopo airooorun-sun oru, ti o je ki o maa la aimoye alakalaa, ti o n je ki omu re maa ja pati lai moye igba, ti o wa so o di alejo gbogbo igba si ogba babalawo.

en: All for love of the child.
yo: Gbogbo eyi, fun ife omo.

en: It was not possible to fathom the depth of a mother's suffering over the child.
yo: Ko see se lati mo ijinle iya iya lori omo.

en: That's one reason the mother is the true owner of the child.
yo: Eyi ni idi kan pataki to fi je pe iya ni o lomo loooto.

en: Mama made a desperate resolution, next time she set her eyes on Labake, the story was going to be different.
yo: Mama ni ipinnu lile kan lokan re pe nigba ti o ba tun foju kan Labake, itan naa a yato.

en: She would be downright violent with her, knock her head against Labake's chest, tear at her.
yo: A gbe e gbona fun un, a se ori re mo Labake laya, a ya a je.

en: She would not wait for that slow vengeance of the herbalist anymore.
yo: Koni i duro de esan diedie ti babalawo yen mo.

en: The day she met Labake again, perdition would come down quick and fast on her.
yo: Lojo ti o ba tun pade Labake, a pa a run ni kiakia.

en: Leave Alamu alone! she would shout on the enemies' agent, holding her by the throat, leave my son alone! My only son.
yo: "Fi Alamu sile! A pariwo le asoju awon ota, a di i lofun mu ""Fi omo mi sile! Omo mi kan soso."

en: My garment, leave my only garment alone to enjoy his life Pack and go!
yo: Aso mi, fi aso mi kan soso sile ki o gbadun aye re. Keru e ki o lo!

en: Pack your load and go now!' It is going to be an order.
yo: """Ko eru re ki o lo nisinyi! A je ase."

en: No dialogue anymore with the enemy at home.
yo: Ko si itakuroso pelu ota ti o wa nile mo.

en: She would not give her chance to snap at her like she did the other day, calling her old woman, hag, witch...
yo: Ko ni fun un laye lati da gbon un bi o se se nijosi, ti o n pe e ni iya agba, agbaya, aje...

en: Pack your load and go now! Let's see your back Labake. Never dare look back!
yo: Ko eru e ki o lo nisinyi! Je ka ri eyin re Labake. O o gbodo weyin!

en: Accursed woman! Daughter of a witch! Agent of the devil! Go! Go away!
yo: Obinrin ti won fi n sepe obinrin! Omo iya aje! Asoju Esu! Lo! Maa lo!

en: Mama dropped the broom she was holding and tears started trickling down her wrinkled cheeks
yo: Mama ju igbale ti o dimu sile, omije bere si san wale lereke re ti o ti hunjo.

en: Later, she started to sob violently.
yo: Nigba ti o ya, o bere si i sunkun gidi.

en: Would she have that strength to attack Labake?
yo: Se a le ni okun lati koju Labake?

en: Would her feeble hands not disappoint her that day?
yo: Se owo re ti o lagbara yii o ni doju ti i lojo naa?

en: Would Labake's youthful energy not rumble her tired stomach, send steam rushing down her nostril, throw her tongue out of her mouth?
yo: Se agbara odo to wa lara Labake oni da inu re ti o ti re yii ru, Se ko ni ran eruku jade nimu re, ti a si yo ahon kuro lenu re?

en: Oh! If only she knew how to pull the trigger of a damn gun!
yo: Oh! Bi o ba je pe o mo bi won se n fa irebon ibon ni!

en: But, let Alamu be brought first! Let her son be saved first!
yo: Sugbon, ki o mu Alamu wa na! Ki o gba omo re sile na!

en: Mama was not happy dissipating her energy on an eye for eye, tooth for tooth' venture.
yo: Inu mama ko dun si fifi okun inu re sofo lori wahala oju-fun-oju, eyin-fun-eyin.

en: That would come later.
yo: Iyen a waye bi o ba ya.

en: But now, let Alamu first be rescued.
yo: Sugbon bayii, ki won koko gba Alamu sile na.

en: Esuniyi had promised to follow her.
yo: Esuniyi ti se ileri lati tele e.

en: They were going together to bring him from town.
yo: Won jo maa lo si igboro lati mu un wa ni.

en: For the better part of the night, Mama's eyes refused to close.
yo: Ni gbogbo oru, Mama ko le sun.

en: Alamu would, no doubt, be embarrassed to see her in company of a fetish priest in the dreaded apete garment.
yo: Laisi ani-ani, oju a ti Alamu lati ri i pelu babalawo ti o wo ewu apete ti o kunfun eru.

en: But that was how it should be, he should understand.
yo: Sugbon bi o se ye ki o ri niyen, o ye ki o yee.

en: He should try to understand ... he must understand.
yo: A gbiyanju lati ni oye... O gbodo ye e.

en: Mama's eyes started blinking ... blinking.
yo: Mama bere si i se oju... se oju.

en: Finally the eyes closed up in sleep.
yo: Nigbeyin gbeyin, o sun.

en: The old woman's mind, thereafter, went numb to everything.
yo: Okan iya agbalagba kuro ninu gbogbo nnkan nigba to ya.

en: Numb to the hooting of the owl on the surrounding trees of the forest.
yo: O kuro ninu hiho eye owiwi lori awon igi igbo ayika.

en: Numb to the incessant barking of the dogs in the centre of the village.
yo: O kuro ninu gbigbo awon aja n aarin gungun ilu.

en: It was not anything easy, saying the final goodbye to a home that had been one's own for a long time.
yo: "Ki i se ohun ti o rorun lati se ""o daabo"" si ile ti o ti je ti eni fun igba pipe ."

en: No matter the way such a home had presented itself to the person leaving it.
yo: Laiwo bi ile naa ti se gbe ara re kale, fun eni ti o n fi i le.

en: Labake knew this very well.
yo: Labake mo eyi daadaa.

en: So now, she heaved a heavy sigh and looked round nervously at everything inside the house.
yo: Ni bayii, o mi amikan o si wo gbogbo nnkan inu ile yika tilora tilora.

en: She was probably spending her last day in Alamu's house.
yo: Boya, ojo re ti o keyin, ni o n lo yii nile Alamu.

en: She had dressed up and was about to go out to do some urgent business in town.
yo: O ti mura o si fe jade lati lo se awon owo kia kia kan ni igboro.

en: Already, she had negotiated with a mammy wagon driver.
yo: O ti ba awako oko akeru kan du naa-dura sile.

en: The driver would be around tomorrow with his vehicle, to carry away her things.
yo: Awako naa n bo lola pelu oko re lati wa fi ko awon nnkan re lo.

en: She'd told the driver how she wanted the job done.
yo: O ti so fun dereba naa bi o se fe ki ise naa se ri.

en: She wanted the job completed with dispatch, in not more than, say, two hours.
yo: O fe ki ise naa pari laifakoko sofo, ki o ma ju bi i, kani wakati meji.

en: The neighbours attention should not be attracted at all.
yo: Ko gbodo pe akiyesi awon aladugbo rara.

en: The mammy-wagon driver had promised his Co-operation and assured Labake that the business would not take him and his men more than one hour.
yo: Awako oko-akeru naa ti se ileri ifowosowopo re, o si fi Labake lokan bale pe ise naa ko ni gba oun ati awon eeyan oun ju wakati kan lo.

en: I swear to God Almighty who made me, he said, sucking his forefinger and then pointing it to the sky emphatically.
yo: Mo fi Olorun to dami selerii, awako naa so eyi, o fa ika ilabe re mu, o sinaasi oju orunfun atenumo.

en: Labake was happy.
yo: Inu Labake dun.

en: Final adieu! This had never been anything easy for anyone.
yo: Idagbere ikeyin! Eyi ki i se ohun ti o rorun fun enikeni.

en: And it was not going to be an easy thing for Labake either.
yo: Ko si le je nnkan ti o rorun fun Labake naa.

en: Her heart started beating fast.
yo: Okan re bere si i lu ki ki ki.

en: There were so many things to say goodbye to.
yo: Awon nnkan ti o fe ki pe o di gbose po.

en: She entered the kitchen, muttered something to herself, and came out of it. She entered the bathroom, whispered something to herself and went into the toilet.
yo: Owo ile idana, o soro wuyewuye ara re, o si jade. O wo baluwe, o soro kelekele si ara re, o si wo ile-igbe.

en: In a minute, she came out of the small room, and peeped inside Alamu's room.
yo: Ni iseju kan, o jade kuro ninu yara kekere, o si yoju wo iyara Alamu.

en: She surveyed the empty room briefly.
yo: O wo yara ofifo naa firi...

en: She saw Alamu's dirty clothes piled up on the standing hanger, some of them scattered on the bed.
yo: O ri aso idoti Alamu ti o ko jo sori ibi ifasoko oniduro, ati awon miiran ti o fonka si ori ibusun.

en: A pyramid of files stood on his table.
yo: Atojo faili iwe duro lori tabili re.

en: Then those cob-webs in the corners of the room.
yo: Leyin naa ni awon ja-n-kariwo koro yara.

en: A foul odour permeated the air in Alamu's room.
yo: Oorun buruku kan gba afefe inu yara Alamu.

en: Labake held her nostrils.
yo: Labake fi owo di iho imu re.

en: Everything was topsy-turvy inside the strange room - the room of a mad man! Labake slammed Alamu's door and went inside her own room again.
yo: Gbogbo nnkan ni o dorikodo ninu yara ajoji yii - yara okunrin were kan! Labake jan ilekun naa pade, o si tun wo inu yara tire.

en: In another minute, she came out of it and emerged in the sitting room, her eyes desperately burning red.
yo: Ni iseju miiran, o jade nibe o si wo yara igbafe, oju re pon gidi.

en: That was the end! She rushed out of the flat into the street.
yo: Opin ni yen! O ku giri jade kuro ni ile naa wo opopona.

en: Instinctively, she gazed back at their flat.
yo: Tiye-tiye, o pada wo ile won.

en: What a dreadful picture Alamu's flat now cut in her eyes.
yo: Iru aworan iberu wo ni ile Alamu wa da loju re.

en: When they first moved into the flat shortly after their wedding, it was with the high hope of making the place a paradise.
yo: Nigba ti won kokoko wo inu ile naa ni kete ti won segbeyawo, o wa pelu ireti giga lati so ile naa di paradise.

en: She encouraged Alamu to purchase items that would make the house look exquisite.
yo: O gba Alamu niyanju pe ki o ra awon nnkan ti yoo mu ki ile naa rewa.

en: And she used all her experience as a trained model and designer to make the home look good.
yo: O si lo gbogbo iriri re gege bi ologe ati oludara lati je ki ile naa ri daadaa.

en: She rested flower vases on all the window panes, hung photographs neatly on the wall in the corners of the sitting room and the bedrooms.
yo: O ko awon apoti ododo si oju awon ferese, o fi aworan ko sara ogiri ni koro yara igbafe ati awon iyewu.

en: They purchased special carpets for the sitting room.
yo: Won ra kapeeti ara oto fun yara igbafe.

en: The curtains and window blinds were of air quality.
yo: Awon kotiini ati iboju ferese je gidi.

en: Everything inside the house in order.
yo: Gbogbo nnkan inu ile lo wa leto-leto.

en: Visitors to their house breathed the smell of fresh flowers and were full of for the lady of the house.
yo: Awon alejo to ba wa si ile won maa n gbooorun ododo tutu, won si maa n kan sara si iya-ile naa.

en: Labake was grand style - so it seemed pleased.
yo: Eyi te Labake lorun.

en: The matrimonial home had taken off in.
yo: Ile oko naa ti bere ni ara oto bi o se jo.

en: But was that truly a home?
yo: Sugbon, se ile niyen?

en: Labake was later compelled to begin asking herself.
yo: Labake pada bere si i tun ara re bi.

en: Was she not merely decorating a house, instead of building a home?
yo: Se ki i se pe o kan dara si ile lasan ni, kaka ki o fi ko ile?

en: It did not take Labake a long time to realize that building a good matrimonial home was more than merely furnishing and decorating the rooms of a building.
yo: Ko pe ki o to ye Labake pe kiko ile oko eni ju tito ati didara si awon yara ile lo.

en: The real home was made up of people - husband and wife interacting intimately with each other, loving each other, planning together, looking ahead to the future with hope and optimism.
yo: Ile gidi ni awon eniyan - oko ati iyawo ti won n ba ara won soro timo-timo, ti won nifee ara won, ti won jo n seto, ti won jo n wo ojo iwaju pelu ireti ati igbagbo pe ohun gbogbo a dara.

en: The real matrimonial home was made of human beings with human feelings.
yo: Ile oko gidi kun fun eniyan ati imolara eniyan.

en: Not the building - wall and roof.
yo: Ki i se ile lasan - orule ati ogiri.

en: Not the hypocritical decoration of the rooms, Labake now knew.
yo: Ki i se bi a se dara si awon yara, Labake sese mo.

en: She clutched her small handbag firmly under her and walked out into the street hailing a taxi.
yo: O fi baagi ikopa re sabe apa re o si rin wo opopona naa, ti o n pe kabukabu.

en: It did not take her long, this time, to get to Oke-Ado.
yo: Ko pe e, lasiko yii, ki o to de Oke-Ado.

en: Although the short-cut was still impassable, a of work had been done by the government on the long Agbeni Ogunpa road.
yo: Bi o tile je pe, ona abuja o ti ko se e gba, opolopo ise ni ijoba n se ni titi Agbeni si Ogunpa gigun yen.

en: Some discipline was injected into the danfo and taxi drivers and the war against indiscipline with the street had been waged and won too.
yo: Awon ofin ikoni-nijaanu kan ti wo ara awon awako danfo ati kabukabu, ati ogun ti won dako, aini-ikora-eni-nijaanu awon oloja opopona ti o ti se.

en: They all feared the new decree soon to be enforced by the government.
yo: Gbogbo won ni won beru ofin tuntun ti awon ijoba fe fi lele laipe.

en: Any, driver who parked his vehicle wrongly would be summarily dealt with by the mobile courts; any driver who caused a traffic hold-up' would also be handed over to the courts and for traders who engaged in street trading, stiff penalties awaited them.
yo: "Awako ki awako to ba gbe oko re sona lona aito a foju wina ni awon ile ejo alagbeeka; awako to ba da ""sunkere-fakere"" oko sile, won a fa a le ile-ejo lowo; awon oloja ti o ba taja ni opopona, ijiya ti o le n duro de won."

en: So now, the street was clear and driving on Agbeni Ogunpa road, like every other road of the city, was becoming more and more pleasurable.
yo: Ni bayii, opopona wa mo fefe, wiwako lopoopona Agbeni Ogunpa wa n dun mo bi i ti awon titi miiran niluu nla.

en: Soon Labake was in her lawyers' chambers.
yo: Laipe, Labake ti de iyewu awon agbejoro.

en: The environment in the chambers no longer scared her.
yo: Ayika iyewu naa ki i ba a leru mo.

en: It had become familiar to her now.
yo: O ti mo on lara.

en: The panic and the anxiety which gripped her during her first visit had completely disappeared.
yo: Ipaya ati aibale okan ti o gba a mu nigba akoko ti o maa de ibe ti poora patapata.

en: She felt at ease now as she spoke freely with the friendly receptionist.
yo: Ara re bale bayii bi o se n ba olugbalejo ileese naa soro.

en: """You are lucky today madam', the receptionist said, presenting a smile."
yo: """E soriire lonii madaamu,"" olugbalejo naa soro pelu erin muse lenu,"

en: """Yes, lucky. He's in', ""Really?"
yo: """Bee ni, e mo on rin. Won wa ninu ile."" ""Se loooto?"""

en: "Yes, Then I am lucky, ""You are indeed madam."
yo: """Bee ni,"" ""Mo soriire niyen,"" ""Loooto ni madaamu."

en: But you'll have to wait for a few minutes.
yo: Sugbon e ni lati duro fun bi i iseju die.

en: There's somebody in there with him him'.
yo: "Enikan wa pelu won."""

en: Thank you, I'll wait'.
yo: """E seun, maa duro."""

en: This was Labake's fourth visit to the chambers.
yo: Eyi ni igba eekerin ti Labake ti se abewo si iyewu naa.

en: She had not been lucky since her first visit, to meet any of the two lawyers.
yo: Ko ni anfaani lati ba won, yato si igba akoko, ki o ba ikankan ninu awon agbejoro mejeeji.

en: At various times, she had been told they were out.
yo: Ni opo igba won ti so fun un pe won jade.

en: At one time she was told Lawyer Mustafa had gone on a business trip overseas.
yo: Nigba kan, won so fun un pe agbejoro Mustafa ti lo fun irinajo owo loke-okun.

en: Labake was not surprised to hear that.
yo: Ko ya Labake lenu lati gbo iyen.

en: She remembered he had dropped a hint to that effect the other time.
yo: O ranti pe o ti so nnkan ti o jo eyi ni igbati ori iyen.

en: He said he would make a trip to England or, was it to America?
yo: O ni oun a rin irinajo lo si Englandi, Abi se Amerika ni?

en: During another visit, she was told that Lawyer Mustafa's partner had gone to argue a case in a Lagos Court.
yo: Ni igba abewo miiran, won so fun un pe ikeji agbejoro Mustafa ti lo se awijare ejo kan ni ile-ejo Eko.

en: During Labake's last visit to chambers she met the lawyers' confidential secretary who assured her that action had started on her case.
yo: Nigba abewo igbeyin Labake si ibe, o pade akowe asiri awon agbejoro naa, ti o fi i lokan bale pe iseti bere lori ejo re.

en: The case had been registered, and its strategy mapped out by the lawyers.
yo: Won ti se akosile ejo re, ona ati sise re si ti jade.

en: The wedding album, the marriage ring and the certificate she brought had been inspected and would be tendered in court as exhibits.
yo: Iwe akojopo aworan igbeyawo, oruka igbeyawo, ati iwe-eri igbeyawo ti o mu wa ni won ti yewo finni finni, won a si fi han nile ejo gege bi eri.

en: Labake had listened in rapt attention.
yo: Labake ti teti pelu ifokansi.

en: What remained for her, the secretary said, was to formally meet any of the two lawyers for a brief chat.
yo: Ohun ti o ku fun un ti akowe naa so ni pe, ki o pade okan lara awon agbejoro mejeeji fun itakuroso ranpe.

en: Then they would quickly file the suit, issue a court summons to her husband, and prepare to go to court to argue the case.
yo: Leyin naa ni won a gbe ejo naa lo ile-ejo, ti won a fi iwe ipelejo ranse si oko re, won a si gbaradi lati lo si ile-ejo lati se awijare ejo naa.

en: The confidential secretary had assured her that her case was going to be very easy to prosecute, compared with the other naughty ones the lawyers handled.
yo: Akowe asiri naa fi i lokan bale pe ejo re a rorun lati gba mu, o yato si awon ejo gbe e gbe e, ti awon agbejoro naa ti gba mu.

en: Hers would be quickly disposed of in not more than two proceedings.
yo: Won atete pari tire ni ijokoo eemeji.

en: Now Labake was lucky, She would hear it all from the horse's mouth.
yo: Ni bayii, oriti ba Labake se e, A gbo oro lenu oloro.

en: Lawyer Mustafa's partner was in, and she was shortly going to meet him over the matter.
yo: Ikeji agbejoro Mustafa wa ninu ile, a si lo ba a laipe lori oro naa.

en: She would be meeting this second lawyer for the first time.
yo: A pade agbejoro keji yii fun igba akoko.

en: The friendly receptionist kept her at ease, talking intimately to her.
yo: Olugbalejo to koni mora naa fi i lara bale, o n ba a soro timotimo.

en: """How are the children?"
yo: """Awon omo naa nko?"""

en: """Thank you."
yo: """E seun"""

en: """And their father, madam?"
yo: """Ati baba won, madaamu?"""

en: Fine, thank you', What else would Labake say?
yo: """Won wa daadaa, e seun,"" Ki tun ni ki Labake so?"

en: Her eyes wandered. Everybody with their own problems.
yo: Oju re wo. ra-ra-ra onikaluku pelu isoro tire.

en: Tinu's father was alright, would she say he was not alright?
yo: Baba Tinu wa lalaafia, abi se yoo so pe ko si lalaafia ni?

en: Labake's eyes caught the gold watch twinking on the wrist of the receptionist.
yo: Oju Labake ri aago orun-owo wura ti o n ko mona lorun owo olugbalejo naa.

en: She noted the phosphore scent glow of its tiny hands.
yo: O sakiyesi owo aago naa ti o n tan.

en: This was an opportunity for her to change the topic of discussion over to some general things.
yo: Eyi je anfaani fun un lati yi koko oro won pada si nnkan gbogbo ogbo.

en: """You have a fine wrist-watch', Labake observed. addressing the receptionist, ""Newly purchased, I suppose?"""
yo: """E ni aago orun-owo to rewa,"" Labake so eyi, o n ba olugbalejo naawi, ""Tuntun ni, abi?"""

en: Yes, madam.
yo: """Bee ni, madaamu."

en: Bought only two months ago.
yo: Osu meji seyin la ra a.

en: We got it in Washington during our honeymoon.
yo: Ilu Washington la ti ra a, nigba igbadun asesese igbeyawo.

en: My husband has a similar one.
yo: Oko mi naani iru e.

en: You see, we are always purchasing things together.
yo: See ri i, a jo maa n ra nnkan papo ni.

en: Buy a blouse and he would want a shirt!
yo: Bi mo ba ra bulaosi, oun naa a fe seeti!

en: Buy a shirt and he too would want a pair of trousers.
yo: Bi mo ra seeti kan oun naa a fe sokoto kan.

en: Buy a wig and, oh my God! Dapo would want a hat!
yo: "Bi mo ba ra irun alawosori, Oluwa o! Dapo naaa fe fila."""

en: I see. That's good'.
yo: """Mo ri i. O daa bee"""

en: Thank you madam.
yo: """E seun madaamu."

en: We intend to go back at the end of the year to do some more shopping
yo: A n gbero lati pada lo ni opin odun yii lati lo ra awon nnkan si i.

en: America is so beautiful.
yo: Ilu Amerika ma rewa.

en: Lots and lots of beautiful things to purchase.
yo: Opolopo nnkan to rewa ni o wa lati ra.

en: "Lots of nice, nice people to meet."""
yo: "Opolopo awon eeyan daadaa daadaa lo wa nibe lati pade"""

en: That's right, In happier times, Labake would have told the receptionist that she too was not a stranger to Uncle Sam's country.
yo: """Ooto ni,"" Kani asiko ti inu re dun ni, Labake o ba so fun olugbalejo naa pe oun naa ki i se ajeji si ile alawo funfun."

en: That she had made several visits to America from Britain, and had toured the great cities extensively.
yo: Ko ba so o pe oun ti se aimoye abewo si Amerika lati Briteeni, o si ti de gbogbo ilu nla naa.

en: She was in Philadelphia, Los Angeles and San Francisco, New Orleans and Chicago.
yo: O lo si Philadelphia, Los Angeles ati San Francisco; New Orleans ati Chicago.

en: Yes, during happier times, Labake would have lectured the receptionist, thoroughly, on where to go in America for shopping the shoppers paradise on Madison Avenue in New York the great Neiman Marcus in Washington DC and the mighty Water Tower Complex - the pride of Chicago.
yo: Bee ni, nigba ti inu re n dun, Labake o ba ti se idanilekoo to peye fun olugbalejo naa lori awon ibi ti o le lo ni Amerika tio ba fe ra nnkan - paradise awon onraja ni opopona Madison ni New York, Neiman Marcus nla ni Washington DC ati Tower complex olomi nla - ti o je ewa Chicago.

en: The situation now was quite different.
yo: Oro to wa nile nisinsinyi yato

en: """America is beautiful the receptionist repeated, her eyes shining bright."
yo: """Amerika rewa"" olugbalejo naa tun un so, ti oju re n dan."

en: Labake sized her up quickly. This was one of the travelers to the States who would arrive back at home full of pride at having the rare privilege of visiting civilized America.
yo: "Labake gbe e lewon kiakia. Eyi je okan lara awon arinrinajo lo si ""ilu oba"" ti igberaga maa n wo lewu ti won ba pada de ile nitori won ti jaja ni anfaani atilo si ilu Amerika ti won ti laju."

en: Their two month, or so visit would take them to the state capitals, they would see the glittering street lights and the multiple-carriage highways and then rush back home to talk of beautiful America, mere casual visitors who knew nothing about the ghetto areas in Uncle Sam's country!
yo: "Abewo osu meji abi kinla won maa n mu won lo si olu-ilu; won a ri awon ina opopona ti o n dan ati opopona aimoye, won a wa sare wale lati soro ""ewa Amerika,"" awon alejo lasan lasan ti o mo nnkankan nipa awon adugbo ti o se e foju ri ni ilu oyinbo."

en: Labake's eyes rested on the sparkling ornament on the receptionist's finger - her wedding ring.
yo: Oju Labake lo si ibi ohun osoto n danna ni ika owo olugbalejo naa - oruka igbeyawo re .

en: She was newly- married truly!
yo: O sese se igbeyawo ni loooto!

en: No wonder her face radiated happiness, and she became talkative.
yo: Abajo ti idunnu se kun oju re ti o wa di elejo wewe.

en: No wonder she was so full of life.
yo: Abajo ti iye fi kun inu re.

en: Labake saw a lover's chain dangling from her neck.
yo: Labake ri seeni ololufe ti o n mi lorun re.

en: """You missed seeing my husband, the Receptionist continued, her mouth would not be stopped!"
yo: """Etase riri oko mi,"" olugbalejo naa tesiwaju, enu re ko se e da duro!"

en: You missed him just by a few minutes madam, he just left after teasing me crazy, and promising he would come back to pick me on the dot of three thirty.
