yo: """E tase re fun bi i iseju die madaamu, o lo leyin igba ti o fere e le fife yi mi lori, o si seleri lati wa gbe mi ni aago meta aabo gerege."

en: You see, madam, I have a jealous man for a husband.
yo: Se e ri i, madaamu, ojowu okunrin ni mo ni loko.

en: Dapo can't stand me uing a minute over-time work here.
yo: Dapo o le gba lati ri i pe mo se iseju kan ni asiko ele ise nibi.

en: Won't allow to go out alone.
yo: Ko ni i je ki n dajade.

en: And would always tell me, ok darling, what God has joined together, let no one put asunder'
yo: "A maa so o ni gbogbo igba pe ""wo o ololufe, ohun ti Olorun Oba bati so po, ki enikeni ma se tu u ka"""

en: Then, pull at my cheeks tenderly, cling on to me as if somebody, close at hand, would snatch me from him any minute.
yo: Leyin naa, a fa mi lereke jeje, a wa le mo mi, bi igba ti eniyan kan ba wa nitosi to fe gba mi mo on lowo nigbakugba.

en: Labake looked away, she shifted uncomfortably on the chair.
yo: Labake gboju kuro, o sun pelu inira lori ijokoo.

en: She was already becoming envious of this receptionist in obvious connubial elation.
yo: O ti n jowu olugbalejo yii pelu igberaga ati ayo to farahan.

en: Her what God has joined together jerked her brain to a state of insensibility, and the let no man put asunder pricked her in the mind like a thorn.
yo: "Oro ""Ohun ti Olorun Oba ti so po"" re wo opolo re debi ipo ailopolo, ti ""ki enikeni ma se ya won"" re gun un lokan bi egun."

en: Surely, that was not the first time she would hear the expression, it was a hackneyed expression.
yo: Dajudaju, kii se igba akoko ti yoo gbo oronaa niyen, o je oro ti ko sajeji.

en: She'd heard it a thousand and one times, but to be reminded of it at this point in time was enough to make the heart pound violently as if under the weight of a sledge hammer.
yo: O ti gbo o nigba mokanlelegberun, sugbon ki won ran an leti ninu asiko yii to lati mu ki okan re maa lu ki-ki-ki bi igba ti won folu lu u.

en: Very soon, the inner door of the chambers opened, and a fat man in agbada left the lawyers' office.
yo: Laipe, ilekun inu iyewu naasi sile, okunrin sisanra kan ti o wo agbada kuro ni ofiisi agbejoro.

en: Labake was ushered in and in a minute, found herself face to face with the man who would help her put asunder what God has joined together - Lawyer Mustafa's partner.
yo: Won pe Labake wole ni iseju kan, o si ba ara re niwaju okunrin ti yoo ba a tu ohun ti Olorun ti so po ka - ikeji agbejoro Mustafa.

en: Come right in madam.
yo: """E wole sibi madaamu."

en: Feel free.
yo: Etura ka.

en: Take a chair
yo: E mu ijokoo.

en: You are welcome, the lawyer in grey suit and dark glasses addressed her
yo: "E kaabo,"" agbejoro ti o wo suutu alawo eeru, ti o si kan igo dudu moju, ba a wi."

en: """You are Mrs. Alamu Olaoye?"
yo: """Eyin ni iyaafin Alamu Olaoye?"""

en: Yes... Yes... Yes, At least for now madam?
yo: """Bee ni... bee... bee ni, ""Fun isinyi madaamu?"""

en: Yes. Thank you.
yo: """Bee ni. E seun"""

en: """I am handling your case, is that alright with you?"
yo: """Emi ni ejo yin wa ni ikawo re, se o te e yin lorun?"""

en: """Yes, You want a divorce?"
yo: """Bee ni,"" ""E fe ko oko yin sile?"""

en: """Yes."" My partner has given me all the details."
yo: """Bee ni."" ""Enikeji mi ti fun mi ni ekunrere alaye."

en: Your tape recorded statement is also here.
yo: Ohun yin ti a gba sile naa wa nibi.

en: You have anything more to add to what you've already told
yo: "Se e o ni nnkan ti e fe fi kun awon nnkan tie ti so fun wa?"""

en: No. Nothing. No em...
yo: """Rara. Ko si nnkankan. Rara em ..."""

en: Come madam. Speak up. Well.
yo: """Madaamu e wa. E soro soke. Daadaa."""

en: Except... Except that... that I want the case disposed of as quickly as em.. em.
yo: """Ennn ...yato si pe mo fe ki ejo naa yanju ni kope kope yii em..em."""

en: Can understand your anxiety madam.
yo: """O ye mi bi o se n se yin madaamu."

en: We are ready at our end here.
yo: A ti setan ni odo wa nibi.

en: No problem.
yo: "Ko si isoro."""

en: Thank you, I want the case settled quickly because.
yo: """E seun, mo fe ki ejo naa tete niyanju kiakia nitori pe."""

en: Yes, madam. Feel free... Because?
yo: """Bee ni, madaamu. E tura ka... Nitori pe?"""

en: "Because, this man can harm me any time."""
yo: """Nitori pe okunrin yii le pami lara nigbakuugba"""

en: Is that so?
yo: """Se loooto?"""

en: """Yes, he is now out of his mind. He had gone mad..."
yo: """Bee ni, ori re ti yi. O ti ya were..."""

en: Tell me! OK.
yo: """E so fun mi! o daa."

en: Don't worry madam, tomorrow we go to court.
yo: E ma seyonu madaamu, to ba dola a a lo sile ejo.

en: How about that?
yo: Iyen nko?

en: Do you like it that way?
yo: "Se e fe e bee?"""

en: """Thank you very much."
yo: """E seun gan an ni."

en: "That is what I want."""
yo: "Nnkan ti mo fe niyen."""

en: """You are happy now Mrs. Olaoye?"
yo: """Se inu yin ti dun bayii iyaafin Olaoye?"""

en: """Yes. Yes. Labake could not understand why she felt so shy in the presence of the lawyer."
yo: """Bee ni. Bee ni."" Ko ye Labake idi ti oju fi n ti i to yii niwaju agbejoro naa."

en: It might be because she was meeting him for the first time.
yo: O le je nitori pe o sese n pade re fun igba akoko.

en: It might be because those questions came dropping on her like bombshells. Or that her earlier conversation with the receptionist had weighed on her subconscious mind so much.
yo: O le je pe awon ibeere naa n ba a lojiji bi i ado oloro alugbau. Tabi itakuroso oun pelu olugbalejo eekan lo duro lokan re pupo.

en: Well... Whatever the Reason, she just discovered she couldn't look her lawyer straight in the face.
yo: Ehn... Ohunkohun ti i ba a fa a, o kan sakiyesi pe oun ko le woju agbejoro re taara.

en: She answered all his questions dodging him, looking at the wall over his head, gazing at the fat books on the big shelf or looking down at the soft office rug.
yo: O dahun gbogbo ibeere re laiwoju re, a wo ogiri eyin re, a wo awon iwe nla nla to wa lori pepe nla tabi ki o gboju sile maa wo roogi felefele ofiisi naa.

en: She was not sure the lawyer himself did not notice her nervousness.
yo: Ko da a loju pe agbejoro naa ko sakiyesi aibale ara re.

en: That was probably why he kept telling her to feel free to take things easy, not to worry, that there was no problem.
yo: Boya idi ti o fi n so fun un pe ki o tura ka niyen, ki o se pelepele pe ki o ma seyonu pe ko si isoro.

en: Suddenly, the lawyer raised his voice and said:
yo: Sadeede, ni agbejoro naa gbe ohun re soke, o ni:

en: """Look at me properly."
yo: """Wo mi daadaa."

en: Labake look at me! See my face!
yo: Labake wo mi! Woju mi!

en: Don't you know me?
yo: Se o o mo mi ni?

en: Haven't we met several times before?
yo: "Sa a ti pade laimoye igba ri?"""

en: The lawyer removed his dark glasses and behold, the face that gazed back at Labake was the face of no other person but that of Lawyer Adio, Alamu's bosom friend!
yo: Agbejoro naa yo igo dudu oju re kuro, kiyesi, oju ti o wo Labake ko se oju elomiiran yato si oju agbejoro Adio, ore Alamu timotimo!

en: Labake gazed at him in disbelief, What immediately went on inside her was indescribable.
yo: Labake wo o laigbagbo, nnkan ti o sele ninu re lesekese o se e sapejuwe.

en: For a very long time, she gazed and gazed.
yo: Fun igba pipe, o wo, wo,o wo.

en: Then she started breathing heavily, staring as if she'd seen an apparition.
yo: Leyin naani o bere si i mi loke, o n wo bi i eni ti o ri oku.

en: The two of them sat speechless, regarding each other with utmost wonder and incredulity.
yo: Awon mejeeji jokoo laisoro, won wo ara won pelu iyalenu nla ati aigbagbo.

en: It was a most unexpected meeting which affected Labake like an electric shock
yo: O je ipade airotele ti o kan Labake gbongbon bi igba ti ina ba gbe e.

en: But this was the moment Lawyer Adio had been waiting for ever since.
yo: Sugbon asiko yii ni agbejoro Adio ti n duro de tipe.

en: He'd gone through the file which Lawyer Mustafa created and later transferred to him before he travelled out of the country.
yo: O ti ye faili ti agbejoro mustafa si sile ti o si ta atare re si i ki o to di wi pe o rin irinajo kuro ni orile-ede.

en: With Adio's ears wide open, he'd heard all that Labake had to say concerning her association with his friend.
yo: Pelu eti Adio ni o fi gbo gbogbo nnkan ti Labake ni lati so nipa ibasepo re pelu ore oun.

en: It was a most shocking revelation, he'd seen their wedding album and had inspected their marriage certificate with trembling fingers.
yo: O je isipa yati o mi eeyan titi, o ti ri iwe akojo aworan igbeyawo won, o ti sagbeyewo iwe-eriigbeyawo won pelu ika owoto n gbon riri.

en: And ever since, had been waiting with almost uncontrollable excitement, for this moment to come.
yo: Lati igba naa, ni o ti n duro pelu inu didun fun asiko yii lati waye.

en: Now, here he was, face to face with his friend's wife at last Stance. Strange, isn't it Labake?
yo: Nisinsinyi, nibi ni o wa, lojukoju pelu iyawo ore re nigbeyin gbeyin. O sajeji, abi bee ko Labake?

en: Adio said slowly, Don't worry at all.
yo: """Adio so o jeje. O daa, ma seyonu rara."

en: Let's get talking.
yo: Je ka a soro.

en: Now as lawyer talking to his client, but as the -Wisher of the family talking to the wife of his good friend.
yo: Ki i se bi i oro agbejoro ati onibaara re, sugbon bi i afenifere idile, ti o ba iyawo ore re ti o se e fokan tan soro.

en: Could we do that Labake?
yo: "N je a le se iyen Labake?"""

en: Labake did not answer, obviously, she had not Succeed in extricating herself from the ensuring to readjust her internal confusion.
yo: Labake ko fesi, o han gbangba pe ko ti i saseyori gbigba ara re sile lowo idaamuto n lo ninu re.

en: Adio gave her some more time.
yo: Adio fun un lasiko die lati fi i lara bale.

en: It was in England she last met Adio, at that time Adio maintained a steady association with Alamu.
yo: Englandi ni o ti ri Adio gbeyin, ni asiko yen, Adio se imuduro ibasepo re pelu Alamu.

en: Two people with one soul, they used to call them.
yo: Eniyan meji pelu emi kan, ni won maa n pe won.

en: They fitted like a pair of gloves and together played a tune that never registered a discordant note.
yo: Won ba ara won mu bi idodo efon, oro won kotase ara won ri.

en: Adio was then a law student and Alamu an accountancy student.
yo: Nigba naa, Adio je akekoo imo-ofin, ti Alamu si je akekoo imo-isiro.

en: Both of them attending the same university.
yo: Yunifasiti kan naa ni awon mejeeji si lo.

en: Labake remembered Adio mediating on two occassions in their quarrel over Josephine and Caroline.
yo: Labake ranti eemeji ti Adio da si ija won lori oro Josephine ati Caroline.

en: He remembered their endless trips together to the theatres and the cinema houses with Adio and his girlfriend Lara.
yo: O ranti ode ailopin won papo lo si tiata ati ile sinima pelu Adio ati orebinrin re Lara.

en: Labake remembered their weekend visits to the suburbs whilst in England.
yo: Labake ranti abewo opin-ose won lo si awon igberiko nigbati won si wa ni Englandi.

en: She looked at Adio closely now. She was like a fool really. She was being stupid.
yo: O wo Adio daadaa nisinsinyi. Oun funrare se wa go bayii. O ponu.

en: How could she have forgotten Adio so easily?
yo: Bawo ni o se yara gbagbe Adio kia bee?

en: She was making a fool of herself.
yo: O n fi ara re se yeye.

en: She watched him, speechless.
yo: O n wo o laisoro.

en: When finally she heaved a sign of relief, Adio asked:
yo: Leyin ti o jaja mi imi itura, Adio beere pe:

en: """Would you say now that I am not qualified to discuss this topic with you Labake?"
yo: """Se wa a wa so pe mi o kun oju osunwon lati ba e soro yii Labake?"""

en: """Na... No... Labake answered slowly, meditatively,"
yo: """Rara...rara...,"" Labake rora dahun tironu tironu"

en: """Not that. But. But. em..."
yo: """Ki i se bee. Sugbon. Sugbon. em..."""

en: Look Labake, if you insist on contesting the divorce in court, I won't stop you.
yo: """Wo o Labake, ti o ba si wa lori pe o fe sejo ikosile ni ile-ejo, mi o ni ni ko ma se e."

en: But all I am saying is that we can still talk about the matter...
yo: "Sugbon nnkan ti mo n so ni pe, a si le yanju oro naa..."""

en: You and me...
yo: Emi ati e...

en: """Hum. Yes.' ""Good.., And thank you Labake for that."
yo: """Hun....bee ni"" ""O daa bee.......mo dupe lowo e fun iyen Labake."

en: Did you say Alamu ill-treated you?
yo: Se o ni Alamu fiya je e?

en: """Yes. How? - Probably beating you?"
yo: """Bee ni."" ""Bawo? - se o n na o ni?"

en: No. Hasn't he raised up his hands to beat you once?
yo: """Rara."" ""Se ko ti i gbe owo re soke lati na o leekan ri?"

en: Slap you? Or something?
yo: "Ki o gba o leti? tabi nnkan?"""

en: He has not done that.'
yo: """Ko ti i se iyen"""

en: I see. He must have punished you then - in some other way?
yo: """Mo ri bee. A je pe o ti fiya je e lona miiran niyen?"""

en: """Hum.. Hum... What about provocative utterances?"
yo: """Hun...hun..."" ""Awon idahunsi imunibinu nko?"

en: Like shouting. Yelling on you?
yo: Bi i ko pariwo. Ki o kigbe mo e?

en: Talking angrily, and the rest of it. No.
yo: "Ki o fibinu dahun, ati awon miiran."" ""Rara."""

en: Nothing like that?
yo: """Ko si nnkan ti o jobee?"

en: Adio asked, then smiled.
yo: Adio beere, o si rerin-in muse.

en: """How then has my friend ill-treated you Labake?"
yo: """Bawo ni ore mi se wa fiya je o Labake?"

en: Labake reflected for a minute, she tried to remember some instances of ill-treatment that she'd suffered in the hands of Alamu.
yo: Labake ronu fun iseju kan, o gbiyanju lati ranti apeere awon igba ti o jiya lowo Alamu.

en: She paused, looking up at the ceiling, no example readily came to her mind.
yo: o danu duro, o n wo oke aja, ko si apeere ti o wa si i lokan ni kia.

en: I don't know, but I just know that he ill-treated me.
yo: """Mi o mo, Sugbon mo saa mo pe o fiya je mi."""

en: Adio smiled again.
yo: Adio tun rerin-in muse.

en: "See Labake flopping in an ""under-the-roof cross-examination!"
yo: E wo bi Labake se n kose nibi iforowanilenuwo abele!

en: If it were the rigorous Cross-examination, in court then she would own up that she was wrong and ask for pardon or leniency!
yo: Ti o ba je iforowanilenuwo amunigbon ti ile-ejo ni, a ti jewo pe oun loun se, a toro idariji tabi aanu.

en: Did you say Alamu is mad, Labake?
yo: """Se o ni Alamu ti ya were, Labake?"""

en: Yes, that is clear.
yo: """Bee ni, iyen o runi loju"""

en: What? Could that be true really?
yo: """Eeen? Se iyen le je ooto sa?"

en: How did you know that?
yo: "Bawo ni o se mo iyen?"""

en: He is always laughing.
yo: """Erin ni o maa n rin ni gbogbo igba."

en: Always drinking and smoking.
yo: Oti mimu ati siga fifa ni gbogbo igba.

en: He's carried away all the items in the house.
yo: O ti ko gbogbo ohun eelo inu ile lo tan.

en: Always moody.'
yo: "Ki i turaka rara."""

en: What did you do about all these?
yo: """Ki lo ti se nipa gbogbo eyi?"

en: Have you ever tried to talk him out of it?
yo: "Se o ti gbiyanju ati ba a so o ri?"""

en: """He's always reluctant to talk."
yo: """O maa n lora lati soro"""

en: Do you know whether he has problems?
yo: """Se o mo boya o ni isoro kankan?"""

en: Problem? May be, what type of problem?
yo: """Isoro? Boya, iru isoro wo?"

en: I don't know of any problem.
yo: "Emi o mo siisoro kankan."""

en: """You have not taken time to find out."
yo: """O o ti i samulo asiko lati fi wadii."

en: Well, Labake, let me tell you this, that your husband has problems.
yo: O daa, Labake, je ki n so eyi fun o, pe oko re ni awon isoro.

en: Problems enough to distract his attention - anybody's attention.
yo: Awon isoro ti o to mu okan re kuro - okan enikeni.

en: Problems enough to frustrate any man.
yo: Isoro ti o to lati mu aye su enikeni.

en: As a wife who loves him so well, you should try and talk things over with him.
yo: Gege bi iyawo to feran re daadaa, o ye ki o gbiyanju lati ba a soro.

en: Your husband and I see quite often.
yo: Emi pelu oko re maa n rira daadaa.

en: He is not mad. That much I know.
yo: Ko ya were. Mo mo iyen daju.

en: He may be absent-minded.
yo: O le ma fokan si o.

en: But he is not mad.
yo: Sugbon ko ya were.

en: Alamu is not mad.
yo: Alamu o ya were.

en: My friend is not mad.
yo: Ore mi o ya were.

en: Labake had started perspiring.
yo: Labake ti bere si i laagun.

en: She felt as if she was in dreamland, really she did not bargain for what she saw and heard. She was seized with the urge to jump up from her seat, walk out and snap
yo: O se e bi igba to ba wa ni ilu ala, ko reti nnkan ti o ri ati eyiti o si gbo. Nnkankan de e mole, o n di i mu lati fo soke lati ori ijokoo re, ki o rin jade, ki o si pariwo;

en: Stop! Stop! Lawyer of the honey tongue! Stop persuading me!
yo: Danuduro! Danuduro! Agbejoro alahon oyin! Ma yi mi lokan pada!

en: Stop cajoling me with your sugar tongue! i'll divorce your friend!
yo: "Ma fi enu didun re tan mi mo! Maa ko ore re sile!."""

en: But instead Labake pressed herself more firmly to the chair she sitting on.
yo: Sugbon kaka ki oseeyi, Labake ledi mo aga ti o jokoo le.

en: What Adio was saying had a shoking effect.
yo: Nnkan ti Adio n so n sise amumole.

en: They were things she did not want to hear but which she had no power to stop listening to - for no obvious reason.
yo: Won je nnkan ti ko fe gbo, Sugbon ko ni agbara lati ye gbigbo re - lainidii kankan.

en: But she had to speak up to some of the issues Adio was now raising, otherwise, Adio would heap all the blame on her and declare her guilty through and through.
yo: Sugbon o ni lati fesi si die lara awon oro naa ti Adio n so, bi bee ko, Adio a ko gbogbo ebi le e, a si da a lebi gbogbo re.

en: She was fully prepared, therefore, when Adio said:
yo: O ti gbaradi pipe nigba ti Adio ni;

en: """Labake you did not let my friend's mother know all about these did you?'"
yo: """Labake o o je ki iya ore mi mo nipa gbogbo eyi, abi se o je ki won mo?"""

en: """Mama?"" retorted Labake, ""Mama called me all sorts of names devil, enemies' agent, murderer holding me responsible for her son's plight, threatening to kill me if I did not pack out of her son's house immediately."
yo: """Mama?,"" Labake dahun, ""Ko si oruko ti mama o pe mi tan - esu, asoju ota, apaayan -ti won ni emi ni mo n se omo awon, ti won leri lati pa mi ti mi o ba ko jade ni ile omo awon lesekese."

en: She swore oaths at me and cursed me.
yo: Won sepe, won si gegun-un fun mi.

en: I cannot relate now all I have suffered in the hands of his mother.
yo: Mi o le so gbogbo nnkan toju mi ri lowo iya re tan bayii.

en: I can never forget.
yo: Mi o si le gbagbe.

en: "I don't think I will ever forgive either."""
yo: "Mi o lero pe mo le dari jin in lae pelu."""

en: Labake unburdened her mind, out of anger at what she considered sheer injustice out of the anxiety to exonerate herself. Adio was happy.
yo: Labake tu ero okan re, pelu ibinu sin n kan ti o pe ni aisotito ninu aniyan ati fo ara re mo. Inu Adio si dun.

en: "That's good' he said, ""You have a point Labake."
yo: """Iyen dara,"" o so eyi, ""O ri i so Labake."

en: And you have made it beautifully, but remember, Labake, mama is old.
yo: O si so o daa, Sugbon ranti, Labake, mama ti dagba.

en: She belongs to a different generation, old fashioned, traditional and superstitious.
yo: Owo iran miiran ni won ti wa - ara atijo, alasa ni won, won si tun maa n gbagbo ninu nnkan ti o to nnkan.

en: Come to think of it, Labake, what Mama did is exactly what my own old mother would have done too in similar circumstance.
yo: Tun ro o, Labake, nnkan ti mama se ni iya temi naa i ba se bo ba je awon.

en: You should know all these Labake.
yo: O ye ki o mo gbogbo eyi Labake.

en: My friend couldn't have approved of Mama's stand, did he approve of it?
yo: Ore mi o le fowo si ti mama, abise o fowo si oro mama?

en: I trust my friend. Labake reflected and slowly she said,
yo: Mo je rii ore mi. Labake ro o, o si so o jeje pe,

en: No. No... He did not, he's not aware of it.
yo: """Rara. Rara... Ko se bee, Ko tie gbo si i."

en: There was a time I wanted to let him know of it, but he would not listen.
yo: Igba kan wa ti mo fe so fun un, Sugbon ko ni i gbo.

en: So, I stopped talking about it to him.
yo: Nitori naa, mi o so fun un mo.

en: In other words', Adio interjected, 'my friend did not know anything about Mama's behaviour?'
yo: """Loro kan,"" Adio dahun, ""ore mi o mo nnkankan nipa ihuwasi mama?"""

en: """No, so we cannot blame him... you cannot blame him for something he did not know about."
yo: """Rara,"" fun idi eyi, a ko le da a lebi... O o le daa lebi fun nnkan ti ko mo nipa."

en: Don't let us blame him Labake.
yo: Ma je ki a da a lebi Labake.

en: Adio had scored another point!
yo: Adio tun ti ni ami ayo miiran!

en: Labake was annoyed with herself.
yo: Labake n binu si ara re.

en: If she had not been caught unawares, she probably would have presented her case in a more coherent way.
yo: Bi o base pe o ba a lojiji ni, ko ba ti gbe oro re kale lona ti o daa ju bayii lo.

en: And now she didn't know whether to continue with the discussion or ask Audio to excuse her.
yo: Nisinsinyi, ko mo boya ki o tesiwaju pelu oro naa, tabi ki o toro gafara lowo Adio.

en: But before she ever had the time to reach a resolution, Adio had dealt the final knock-out blow...
yo: Sugbon ki o to raye se ipinnu, Adio ti sooro miiran lu u...

en: """Labake. Labake. There is no doubt about it."
yo: """Labake. Labake. Ko si iyemeji nipa re."

en: You have suffered, I know it.
yo: O ti jiya, mo mo on.

en: It is a pity, but suffering, you know, is part of the test of true love. Don't you agree?
yo: "O seni laaanu, sugbon ijiya, ti o mo yii, je ara adanwo ife otito. Se o gbo?"""

en: "Labake did not say 'yes', she did not say ""no"" either. She was confused."
yo: "Labake ko wi ""bee ni,"" ko si wi ""bee ko."" Iruju ba a."

en: The matter before her was a matter she had to spend days, even weeks, thinking about.
yo: Oro iwaju re yii je oro ti o ni lati lo ojo, ose lati fi ro o.

en: No stand should be taken now.
yo: Ko gbodo so nnkankan bayii.

en: Lawyer Adio had done his best.
yo: Agbejoro Adio ti sa ipa re.

en: He had played his part well.
yo: O ti sise re daadaa.

en: Even as Labake stood up to go, she heard the lawyer promising he would pay them a visit at home, unfailingly, she should expect him.
yo: Bi Labake se dide lati lo, o gbo agbejoro naa ti o n seleri lati be won wo nile, ko ni i ye, ki o maa reti re.

en: Labake closed the door of the chambers gently behind her and was received outside with a sunny cheerful smile by her friend, the receptionist.
yo: Labake pa ilekun iyewu naa de jeje leyin re, erin muse to munudun ni ore re, olugbalejo iyewu naa fi pade re.

en: And downstairs, on the street, Adios drive was waiting, opening the door of his master's car to take Labake back home.
yo: Ni isale, ni opopona, dereba Adio n duro, o si n si ilekun oko ayokele oga re lati fi gbe Labake pada sile.

en: Labake stopped at the motor park. She got out, thanking Adios driver.
yo: Labake duro ni ibudoko. O bo sile, o si n dupe lowo awako Adio.

en: In a minute, the car tuned the roundabout and zoomed off in the direction of Oke-Ado.
yo: Ni iseju kan, oko naa yipo o si tena lo sona Oke-Ado.

en: It was a Mercedes-Benz.
yo: O je oko mesi oloye.

en: Life was no doubt smiling on Adio - a very successful lawyer, enjoying all the wonderful opportunities offered by the city.
yo: Nnkan n dun fun Adio, laisi ani-ani- agbejoro to ni lari ni, o n gbadun gbogbo anfaani ti ilu ni lati fun un.

en: He looked well-fed, and had put on a lot of weight, especially around the neck and the tummy.
yo: O ri bi i eni to jeun kanu, ti o si ti leran leti daadaa, paapaa julo orun re ati ikun re.

en: That was why it was not immediately possible for Labake to recognise him.
yo: Idi niyen ti ko fi seese fun Labake lati da a mo lesekese.

en: Way back in England, Adio was a slim shy-looking man; so indigent - always praying for the quick arrival of his scholarship reimbursement from the High Commission.
yo: Nigba ti won si wa ni Englandi, Adio je okunrin pelebe kan, ti oju maa n ti; o talaka gan an - gbogbo igba ni o fi maa n gbadura pe ki idapada iwe-ofe re otete de lati odo ajo to ga ju.

en: But Nonetheless, struggling and struggling, working very hard. Lucky man...
yo: Sugbon laisi ani-ani, o n gbiyanju gbiyanju, o n sise karakara. Oloriire okunrin...

en: Labake chested and elbowed her way through the surging motor park crowd.
yo: Labake dura koja laaarin awon ero yanturu to wa ni idiko.

en: This was one place she did not always like visiting.
yo: Eyi je ibikan ti ko nifee lati maa de.

en: Apart from the noise everywhere, the motor park was the haven of all sorts of people.
yo: Yato si ti ariwo to wa ni gbogbo ibe, ibudoko je ago ibi ti oniruuru eniyan wa.

en: It was not possible to distinguish honest drivers from the notorious touts and pickpockets.
yo: Ko si seese lati ya awako olododo soto si awon ogbologboo omo ita ati olosa.

en: It was not possible to know genuine hawkers and traders from smugglers and tricksters.
yo: Ko se ese lati daa won ontaja ati oloja gidi mo yato si awon omo ita ati ole.

en: The local magicians and money doublers were allowed to operate freely inside the motor and the sale of second-hand goods flourished at the nooks and corners of the place.
yo: Awon apidan ibile ati awon sogun dogoje naa ni ominira atilo atibo ni ibudoko, itaja ohun aloku si po ni gbogbo kooro ibe.

en: The garage ugh, it was dirty, rowdy and exposed.
yo: Gareeji naa ri jalajala, o doti, ero ti poju, o si ja gbangba.

en: The Council people had tried, without much success to do something about the security of life and property of the people who patronised the place.
yo: Awon ara kansu ti gbiyanju, lai saseyori nipa wiwa nnkan se si oro aabo emi ati ohun ini awon eniyan to n na ibe.

en: If it's not because Labake wanted to report back to her mammy-wagon driver that brought here, nothing on earth could have.
yo: Bi ki i base pe Labake fe jabo fun awako oko akeru re, ko sin nkan tii ba gbe e wa bi.

en: She peered and craned her neck, meandering her way through passengers, hawkers and touts.
yo: O yirun yirun, o narun narun, o n wona laarin awon ero, awon ontaja ati awon agbero.

en: At last she got to him, the mammy-wagon driver.
yo: Ni gbeyin gbeyin, o de odo awon awako oko akeru naa.

en: There he was a little way off, by the side of his vehicle, engrossed in a noisy conversation with three of his mates.
yo: Ibe ni o wa, lowo eyin, legbee oko re, o n rojo alariwo pelu meta ninu awon akegbe re.

en: They were probably discussing with her ... planning the strategy for the evacuation of her belongings.
yo: Boya ise bi won se fe ba a keru ni won n seto re, oun ni won n so.

en: If that was the case, then she was with them at the nick of time, she had come to tell him to drop the matter for some time.
yo: Bi o ba je pe bee ni, o mo on rin niyen, o ti wa so fun won pe ki won si fi ile fun igba die.

en: There was a new development and the proposed evacuation would have to be shelved.
yo: Idagba soke tuntun kan lo de, won yoo si ni lati sun ojo eru kiko siwaju.

en: The mammy-wagon driver shrugged his shoulders when Labake told him about the postponement.
yo: Awako oko-akeru naa mi ejika re nigba Labake so nipa isunsiwaju naa fun un.

en: Till another time... Till another time, Labake said, 'May be next week or week after. But definitely till another time.
yo: """O digba mi in...o digba mi in,"" Labake so eyi, ""Boya lose to n bo tabi eyi to tele e. Sugbon o digba mi in."

en: Sorry. I'll contact you again'.
yo: "E pele. Ma a tun kan si i yin."""

en: Alright madam, no harm done', he answered in a not-too-happy tone.
yo: "O daa madaamu, ko si wahala,"" o fesi pelu ohun ti o fi dunnu han."

en: That was the end of a small business that would have fetched quick money.
yo: Iyen ni opin owo kekere ti o ba mowo kia wole fun un.

en: He'd been unusually hilarious up to that time because he kept the idea of a quick early morning profit at the back of his mind.
yo: Inu re ti sadeede n dun titi di asiko yen, nitori o ti fi ero ere ise kia owuro kutukutu sokan.

en: But now. Well.
yo: Sugbon bayii. O daa.

en: A commercial Peugeot 504 saloon car pulled up a few yards away from them and the owner of the car emerged flashing his teeth and waving to the mammy-wagon. The driver waved back throwing one or two nicknames at him.
yo: Oko pijo 504 kan koja lara won, eni ti o ni i si boyin, o si n juwo si awa kooko-akeru naa. Awako naa juwo si i pada, ti o n pe e ni inagije re bi i meloo kan.

en: Baba o! A je pe aye sir!
yo: """Baba o! Ajepe aye sa."""

en: Then turning back to Labake...
yo: Leyin naa ni o koju si Labake pada...

en: He is the chairman of the Drivers' Union... Our chairman... Very popular with us..', the driver said to Labake,
yo: "Awon ni alaga awon egbe awako... Alaga wa... Maa n ba wa sere gan an...,"" awako naa so fun Labake."

en: Labake looked closely at the man. Her eyes caught the plate number of his car.
yo: Labake wo okunrin naa. Oju re ti gan-an-ni nomba oko naa.

en: What! Labake stared at the car's registration number in frozen stillness.
yo: Eeeen! Labake wo nomba naa pelu igbonriri oju kan.

en: Her heart immediately started pumping hard... Alamu's car! Alamu's former car!
yo: Okan re bere si i sise lemolemo... Oko Alamu! Oko Alamu teletele!

en: Still in very good condition!
yo: Ni o si wa ni ipo to dara yii!

en: Is that em.. the man's car?
yo: """Se em...oko ayokele okunrin naa niyen?"

en: Labake asked, swallowing some saliva.
yo: Labake beere, o dato mi.

en: Yes, his car, he got it second hand. Second hand?
yo: Bee ni, oko ayokele re ni. O ra a ni aloku. Aloku?

en: Yes, second hand, from one man they say was in trouble.
yo: Bee ni, aloku, lowo okunrin kan ti won lo wa ninu isoro.

en: Hem... Madam, there is plenty of trouble in this world you.
yo: Em...madaamu, wahala po laye yii o.

en: So Chairman bought the car cheap cheap from the man - the man in trouble... The mammy-wagon driver held out his two hands - to indicate the bigness of the trouble he was describing. Trouble?
yo: Nitori naa ni alaga wa se ra a lowo re ni gbanjo - lowo okunrin naa - okunrin to wa ninu isoro yen..., awako oko akeru naa yowo re sita lati fi sapejuwe bi isoro ti o n sose tobi to. Isoro?

en: Yes madam, the alakowe man ran into trouble, money trouble.
yo: Bee ni madaamu, okunrin alakowe naa kan ijogbon, ijogbon owo.

en: The man, they say, lost his job, and could no longer feed himself, feed his family.
yo: Won ni okunrin naa padanu ise re, ko si le bo ara re, bo ebi mo.

en: "So he sold the car cheap cheap to Chairman.' You know the man then?."""
yo: "Nitori naa lose ta oko ayokele naa ni gbanjo fun alaga wa. ""E mookunrin naa niyen?"""

en: Hum. Not quite. But one time I saw him walk past here. People say the man's head has turned now. I don't know
yo: Hun. Ko daju. sugbon lasiko kan mo ri i ti o koja nibi. Awon eniyan si so pe ori okunrin naa ti yi bayii. Mi o mo.

en: The hair on Labake's head stood up straight, hair cheeks wrinkled, giving the impression of somebody wanting to laugh if not for her brow which had knitted in several wrinkles at the same time! But, it was no laughter afterall.
yo: Irun ori Labake duro girigiri, ereke re hun po, ose e bi igba ti o ba fe rerin-in, bi ki i base irun oke oju reti o hunpo ni asiko kan naa! Sugbon ki ise erin rara.

en: More than laughter. Better for her in the circumstance, to get away fast.
yo: O ju erin lo. O daa fun un lasikoyii pe, ki o tetekuro.

en: Otherwise, her supreme effort to keep back the tears would prove abortive and the tears already welling up now beneath her eyelids would come streaming down.
yo: Bibee ko, igbiyanju re lati da omi oju naa pada yoo ja sasan, omi oju naa ti o kun si ipenpeju re yii a to san wale.

en: Madam... Madam..., only God can save man from all the troubles of this world o.
yo: Madaamu...madaamu..., Olorun nikan lo le gba eeyan lowo isoro aye yii o.

en: This wicked world in which we are living. Only God can protect man o...
yo: Ile aye ika ti a n gbenu re yii. Olorun nikan lo le gba eeyan o.

en: Yes, They say his wife was the one who turned his head with juju.
yo: Bee ni, won ni iyawo re ni o fi oogun yi i lori.

en: You women are dangerous. You all look fine and beautiful. But to move near you is fire o... 'Fire?
yo: Eyin obinrin lewu gan an. Gbogbo yin le dun un ri te e rewa. sugbon ati sunmo on yin, ina ni o... 'Ina?'

en: "Yes, real fire, madam. How can a wife be so wicked as to turn the husband's head with juju just for fun?"""
yo: "Bee ni, ina gidi madaamu. Bawo ni iyawo kan se le nika debi ki o fi oogun yi ori oko re lai nidii?"""

en: You believe it? Madam, I believe it o.
yo: E gba a gbo? Mo gba a gbo o, madaamu.

en: I am sorry madam, but I don't trust women.
yo: E ma binu o madaamu, sugbon mi o le fokan tan obinrin.

en: My three wives at home know it. But this man's wife must be a witch.
yo: Awon iyawo mi meteeta nile mo. sugbon, aje ni iyawo okunrin yii maa je.

en: I hear that people around them have decided they would stone the woman to death, today or tomorrow. Where?
yo: Mo gbo pe awon eniyan to wa ni ayika won ti pinnu lati soko pa obinrin naa, lonii abi lola. Nibo?

en: I don't know madam, people just say it all about. You women, I fear you. Women are the cause of all men's trouble.
yo: Mi o mo madaamu, awon eniyan kan n so o kaakiri ni. Eyin obinrin, mo beru yin. Awon obinrin ni won maa n fa wahala fun gbogbo okunrin.

en: To have you at home, man must prepare well well.
yo: Lati gbe e yin sile, okunrin ni lati mura daadaa.

en: I am sorry madam, I can see you are not happy with me - the way you are looking. I am sorry indeed, but I know you cannot do that type of thing to your own husband using juju.
yo: E ma binu madaamu, mo ri pe inu yin ko dun si mi bi ese n wo. E mabinu, sugbon mo mo pe eyin o lese iru nnkan bee si oko ti yin, ki e lo oogun.

en: I know you are not that type of woman who... who... who...
yo: Mo mo pe e ki i se iru obinrin ti...ti...ti...

en: The tears had now blurred Labake's vision, five seconds more and she would betray herself. So, she walked quickly away. I will see you again. Another time. Another time. I'll see you.
yo: """Omije naa ti se iran Labake baibai, laarin iseju aaya marun-un, a dale ara re. Nitori naa, o tete rin kuro. Maa maa ri i yin nigba miiran, nigba miiran... ma ari iyin."""

en: Labake walked away across the motor park, wiping her face, looking straight in front of her, refusing to be distracted by the call of the hawkers left and right, inviting her to come and have a look at their second-hand articles.
yo: Labake rin koja ibudoko naa, o n nu oju re, o n wo owo iwaju re taara, o ko lati je ki ipolowo ati ipe awon oloja da a laamu lotun-un losi, pe ki o wa wo oja gbanjo ti won n ta.

en: They jumbled all the articles together in great piles, fridges with their handlebars and locks damaged; television sets with their tuning knobs missing, tape recorders without either the bass tone control or the fast-rewind knobs, record players whose pick-up, armrests and safety catches had gone and standing fans with broken revolving boxes and speed switches. All these the hawkers now invited Labake's attention to, as she sought her way out of the jumble of the motor park.
yo: Won ko awon oja naa po, ero amomitutu ti ifa lowo won ti baje, ero amohun-maworan ti ara re ko pe; ero igbohun si leti awon nnkankan ti yo ninu re; ero akorin ti awon eya ara re ko pe mo; ati awon faanu ada duro ti awon nnkankan ti kuro lara re. Gbogbo awon eyi ni awon oloja naa wa n pe akiyesi Labake si, bi ose n wa ona ati jade ninu rukerudo ibudoko naa.

en: Madam, have a look here.
yo: Madaamu, e wo bi.

en: Madam, how are you?
yo: Madaamu, bawo ni.

en: Thank you for the other day madam
yo: E seun ojo madaamu.

en: How pikin? Hope oga is doing fine?
yo: Omo nko? Se alaafia ni oga wa?

en: Madam, na me o... Na me de greet you so, madam.
yo: Madaamu, emi ni o...emi ni mo n kii yin, madaamu.

en: Labake cast one hateful look after another at the owners of the voice.
yo: Labake fi oju irira wo awon to ni ohun naa.

en: She saw two men close on her heels, flashing their teeth at her - still greeting her, still coming after her, still wanting her to stop and talk.
yo: O ri okunrin meji ti won n tele e, ti won n boyin si i - won si n kii, won n tele e, won fe ki o duro ba won soro.

en: She ignored them and walked faster... there was no length hawkers would not go to attract your attention - petting you, smiling at you, joking with you, calling you sister, auntie', madam all to cajole you into purchasing one item or another...
yo: "O pa won ti, o si rin kia... ko si nnkan ti oloja o lese lati fi pe akiyesi re - won a fowo to o, won a rerin-in muse si o, won a ba o dapaara, won a pe o ni ""sista,"" anti, madaamu - gbogbo re lati ri ipe o ra nnkankan tabi omiran..."

en: Another quick look at the two men and Labake was sure she was not seeing them for the first time. Still, she kept on walking fast.
yo: O sare wo awon okunrin meji naa lee kansi i, o si da Labake loju pe ki ise igba akoko ti yoo ri won re e. Sibe, o si tese morin kia.

en: But.. Wait. Wait... Wait... Labake hesitated for three seconds... Now she knew them.
yo: sugbon... duro... duro... duro... Labake duro fun iseju aaya meta... O ti mo won bayii.

en: The two hefty men who accompanied Alamu home!
yo: Awon okunrin gbangba meji to sin Alamu wale!

en: "The ""repairers' who carried away their refrigerator, television and ceiling fan some months ago - ""for repairs'! Labake's footsteps quickened."
yo: "Awon alatun-unse"" to gbe ero amomitutu, ero amohun-maworan ati faanu oloke won lo ni osu die seyin - fun ""atunse""! Labake yase."

en: She was almost running now, A minute's delay, something told her, and she would see what would make her faint on the spot, from the jumbled mass of those second hand articles inside these men's stalls.
yo: O fere e le maa sare bayii, bi o ba duro iseju kan pe, nnkankan n sofun un pe a ri nnkan to le mu un daku nibe, lati inu oja aloku inu iso awon Okunrin yii.

en: And hadn't she seen enough? Hadn't she heard enough to make her run mad?
yo: Se ko si ti i ri to? Se ko ti i gbo oro ti o le mu un ya were to?

en: "To even make her commit suicide? She added wings to her legs and ""flew"" home."
yo: "To tie le mu un para e? O fi iye kun ese re , o si ""fo"" dele."

en: At home, Labake shouted, Come out! Come out Alamu!
yo: Nile, Labake pariwo, Jade! Jade! Alamu!

en: Come out of your room! Out of your hiding! I must talk to you now. Nothing will stop me!
yo: Jade ninu yara re! Jade nibi to o sa pamo si! Mo gbodo ba osoro bayii. Nnkankan o ni dami duro!

en: Zenabu ran home from one of the houses close by, and entered the sitting room.
yo: Senabu sare lo ile lati okan ninu awon ile to wa nitosi, o si wo yara igbalejo.

en: Tinu stood behind her. They were alone in the house, Zenabu told madam.
yo: Tinu duro leyin re. Awon nikan ni won wa nile, Senabu so fun madaamu.

en: Because master had just gone out with one man. And master said he would soon be back.
yo: Nitori pe oga ti jade pelu okunrin kan. Oga si so pe awon maa too de.

en: He carried plenty of files into the car. The man with him helped carry some of the files too.
yo: Won gbe opolopo iwe sinu oko. Okunrin naa si ba won gbe lara awon iwe naa.

en: Master said they were going to Lagos, master told her to take care of the house well.
yo: Oga ni awon n lo si Eko, oga ni ki o toju ile daadaa.

en: And tell madam they might come back that night, or till tomorrow.
yo: Ki o si so fun madaamu pe awon a de ni ale ojo yen tabi boya o dola.

en: Master said Tinu must not cry. Master also said...
yo: Oga so pe Tinu o gbodo ke. Oga tun so pe...

en: Labake pushed Zenabu out of the way, entered her room and locked the door behind.
yo: Labake ti Senabu kuro lona, o wo yara re, o si ti ilekun leyin.

en: Soon the sharp cry of a soul in torment came from inside the room - lasting for some three minutes, stopping for some two minutes only to pick up again like the slow, on-and-off pain of guinea worm, Ceasing and picking up, picking up and ceasing.
yo: Nigba to ya, igbe ekun okan tii ya n je wa lati inu yara - o pe fun iseju meta kan, o dawo duro fun bi iseju meji kan, o tun bere bi irora so bia, bi ose maa n dun ni, ti a tun rowo.

en: Ceasing temporarily. Then ceasing finally when sleep overtook the eyelids.
yo: A dawo duro die. Leyin naa, o n dawo duro patapata nigba ti oorun ti n kun oju re.

en: I'll not sleep today', she moaned, I'll not close my eyes.
yo: "Mi o ni i sun lonii, o gbin, ""Mi o nii di oju mi."

en: I'll be sitting down like this, he'll meet me sitting down like this.. waiting. Waiting...
yo: Maa jokoo bayii, a ba mi lori ijokoo bayii...mo n duro...mo n duro...

en: And truly, Labake did not close her eyes - even when the night was so far spent.
yo: Loooto, Labake ko diju re - titi mo igba ti ile ti su daadaa.

en: She heard the distant sound of the amplifier, blaring fuji music at some night party in the heart of the town.
yo: O gbo ohun orin fuji lati ona jijin, ni ibi inawo kan ni igboro ilu.

en: Labake listened, after some time, the music seized. The revelling had stopped.
yo: Labake teti, leyin igba die, orin naa ko dun mo. Ariwo re lole.

en: Hundreds of naira - even thousands - had gone down the drain!
yo: Ogoogorun-un naira - titi mo egbeegberun - lo ti sofo.

en: Silence now lay upon the whole city, the air was old and still.
yo: Idake roro wa wa ni gbogbo ilu, afefe naa tutu, o si dake roro.

en: What broke the stillness now was the intermittent sound of the whistle of the night watchmen and the konleogbele sound of their bells.
yo: Nnkan ti o da idake roro naa laamu ni ariwo lemo lemo fere awon olode ati ohun ko-n-le-o-gbe-le agogo won.

en: The wall clock continued ticking away, it was now two o'clock in the morning. The sound of the alarm watch blare's ears, she came to the sitting room and sat down.
yo: Aago n lo, o ti wa di aago meji geerege lowuuro. Ohun aago idagiri de eti Labake, o wa si yara igbalejo o si jokoo.

en: Her eyes gazed intently at the door resolving she would take Alamu up on several issues the very minute he showed his face in the house.
yo: O teju mo ilekun pelu ipinnu pe oun a ba Alamu fa orisiirisii ni iseju ti o ba foju han ninu ile.

en: Alamu had to satisfy her with a concrete explanation on all those things she had heard from people from neighbours, from his friend and from the mammy-wagon driver.
yo: Alamu ni lati te e lorun pelu alaye to dan moran lori gbogbo nnkan ti o gbo lenu awon eeyan - awon aladuugbo, lenu ore re ati awakooko-akeru naa.

en: His life had become one bundle of mystery to her and it was, Alamu alone who could interprete the mystery.
yo: Aye Alamu wa je adiitu si i, Alamu nikan lo si le tu u.

en: His life had become one big knot and it was he alone who could untie it. That he had to do the very moment he stepped into the house.
yo: Aye re ti di koko nla kan ti won so pa ti o si je pe ohun nikan ni o le tu u. Iyen ni o ni lati se ni kete bo base n wole.

en: Labake had seen a lot of things herself - factual and reasonably authentic.
yo: Labake ti ri orisiirisii nnkan fun rare - ti o je koko ti o si je ogidi.

en: What explanation would Alamu give to them all? The explanation must be so convincing, so persuading to satisfy her.
yo: Alaye wo ni Alamu yoo se si gbogbo re? Alaye naa gbodo le yini lokan pada, ki o le te e lorun.

en: She wondered what further role Alamu's friend was going to play in the matter.
yo: O woye iru ipa ti ore Alamu a tun fe ko ninu oro naa.

en: How effectively were they going to handle the matter of the mother-in- law?
yo: Bawo ni won se fe gba oro iya oko re mu?

en: For an immediate query, where had Alamu gone to?
yo: Fun idahun kiakia, nibo ni Alamu lo?

en: Why did he spend the night there?
yo: Ki lo si fa a ti o fi sun ibe moju?

en: Why did he refuse to let her know before hand that he would keep the night outside?
yo: Kini idi ti ko fi so fun un tele pe oun a sunta?

en: It was the early-morning drum signal on a neighbour's radio set which answered her questions.
yo: Ohun ilu owuro kutukutu ori redio aladuugbo kan lo dahun ibeere re.

en: A not too-satisfying answer merely indicating the arrival of dawn.
yo: Idahun ti ko teni lorun to n so pe ile ti mo.

en: Labake's head ached badly, she felt pain all over the body and yawned.
yo: Ori fo Labake gidi, ara n ro o, o si yan.

en: Was this what they called suffering for the sake of love?
yo: Se nnkan ti won n pe ni ijiya ife re e?

en: Love must be a giddy thing indeed to make one suffer so much like this.
yo: Ife wa je nnkan gidi kan to n mu eeyan jiya bayii.

en: The city at dawn! Everything was alive again.
yo: Ilu nla ni daaji! Gbogbo nnkan ti tun ji saye.

en: The sleeping giant has woken up! The hustle and bustle of city life had started as usual.
yo: Omiran to n sun ti ji! Igbokegbodo ilu ti bere bi o se maa n waye.

en: The city people, like frightened ants, hurried away to their various places of work.
yo: Awon ara ilu tete n gbona ibi ise won lo, bi ikokoro teru n ba.

en: It was work, work and work for them all. Work and quench!
yo: Ise ise ise saa ni fun gbogbo won. Ise ati iya.

en: The bus stops were crowded.
yo: Awon ibuso-oko ni ero kun bamu.

en: Getting inside the city buses was a battle - survival of the fittest forty nine sitting, ninety nine standing!
yo: "Riri oko ilu wo wa dogun - eni yara loogun n gbe - ""eeyan mokandinlaaadota ni jokoo, eeyan mokandinlogorun-un niduuro!."""

en: The pregnant women fought it out with the same zeal and energy as the teenage girls rushing to school struggling to beat lateness.
yo: Awon aboyun n jija gbara pelu okun, bee naa lawon omobinrin to n kanju atide ile-iwe ki won ma pe e.

en: And the able-bodied young men demonstrated their agility by crashing inside the city buses through the small windows of the vehicle!
yo: Ati awon odomokunrin to da sasa ti won n fi agbara won han nipa bibe wonu oko lati oju ferese kee-kee-keeoko!

en: In Labake's area of the town, the local hawkers had started advertising their commodities in sing- song, sonorous voices.
yo: Ni apa adugbo Labake niluu naa, awon onikiri n polowo oja won ni ohun orin, ohun didun.

en: A group of young boys and girls had gathered round the small stall in front to purchase the rice and tuwo which had started boiling hot inside the pots on the fire - a look of expectancy on their faces.
yo: Owo awon omokunrin ati omobinrin kee-kee-kee kan ti yi iso kan ka niwaju lati ra iresi ati tuwo ti o ti n ho ninu ikokoori ina - won n reti ko jinna kia.

en: Labake stretched her legs and came out to the verandah of their house.
yo: Labake na ese re, o si jokoo si ita ile won.

en: The local seamstresses were already on their way to their various shops.
yo: Awon aransobinrin ibile naa ti wa lona iso won.

en: They balanced their sewing machines on the head with accustomed ease, chattered all along about this and that topic, connected with their trade...
yo: Won gbe masiini iranso won sori pelu irorun lona to ti mo won lara, ti won si n takuroso lori orisiirisii nnkan ti o jemo owo won...

en: Labake too used to be a good seamstress and very creative too. She could design garments, even now, to match the latest trends in fashion.
yo: Labake naa je ranso-ranso gidi ti o si mose daadaa. O le dara si ewu, paapaa bayii lati ba igba mu.

en: While in England, she took some courses in sewing and designing.
yo: Nigba to si wa ni Englandi, o ko eko ninu iranso ati idarasi.

en: This in addition to her core course which was modelling, it had not been possible for her to practise her trade here in the country, straight away, because of people's general apathy to it.
yo: Eyi kun eko re gan an ti o jemo oge, ko seese fun un lati se owo re ni orile-ede yii lesekese nitori ero gbogbo ogbo awon eniyan nipa re.

en: Otherwise, like these seamstresses, she too would by now have been on her way to her place of work.
yo: Bi bee ko, bi i awon aransobinrin yii, oun naa iba wa lona ibise tire bayii.

en: For now, she was a full time housewife.
yo: Sugbon ni akoko yii, iyawo ile ti ko nise aseje ni.

en: Labake took her eyes away from the seamstresses, who had negotiated the comer of the street.
yo: Labake gboju re kuro lodo awon aransobinrin naa, ti won ti n bo si koro opopona naa.

en: She yawned, she was, understandable, not feeling comfortable, her limbs were stiff, her eyes were drowsy. She felt like that housewife who went through the ordeal of pounding five yam-filled mortars the previous day, all alone, for some late-night visitors.
yo: O yan, ara ko ro orara, apa re yi, ooyi n ko oju re. O n se e bi i ti iyawo ile ti ogun iyan ekun odo marun-un lanaa fun awon alejo alaforuwolu.

en: Her ribs and joints ache like that of a boxer who had just survived twenty gruelling rounds in a fight of the century! She stumbled inside again.
yo: Iha re ati orikeerikee ara n ro o bi i ti ajese ti osese yege ija lona ogun ninu idije ija senturi! O tun be wole.

en: Zenabu was already in the Sitting room, standing at attention by the side of a small mound, something wrapped up inside a blue pillow case, placed in a plastic bucket.
yo: Senabu ti wa ni yara igbafe, o duro sinsin si egbe okiti kekere kan, nnkan ti won di sinu aso irori buluu ti won gbe sinu garawa onike.

en: I am ready to go now ma.
yo: Mo ti fe maa lo nisinsinyi ma.

en: Labake took a cursory look at the small figure in front of her.
yo: Labake wo kini kekere iwaju re lawofin.

en: Yes, it was Zenabu, wanting to go, and taking permission from her.
yo: Bee ni, Senabu ni, o fe maa lo, o si n toro aaye lowo re.

en: Go where, Zenabu? Go home ma.
yo: Ibo lo n lo Senabu? Mo n lo ile ma.

en: Home? Where? In Kwara.
yo: Ile? Nibo? Ni Kwara.

en: Kwara? Yes. Kwara, My home ma.
yo: Kwara? Bee ni, Kwara, ile mi ma.

en: Why? What's wrong with you Zenabu?
yo: "Kilode? Ki lo se o Senabu?"""

en: Nothing madam
yo: Ko si nnkankan Madaamu

en: Come on Zenabu! What is it?
yo: Soro Senabu! Ki lo sele ?

en: Em... em... Nothing... Nothing madam.
yo: Em... em... Ko si... Ko si madaamu.

en: Are you crazy! Are you mad!
yo: O n siere ni! So o ya were ni!

en: Zenabu's cheeks wrinkled, her brows tensed and she closed her eyes.
yo: Ereke Senabu hunjo, irun oju re yi, o si diju re.

en: She soon opened them again and the tears came in beads chasing one another down her little cheeks.
yo: O tun si oju re, omije si bere si i da wa le bi i ileke ni tele-n-tele se reke re kekere.

en: "Madam. Madam, she sobbed out, ""That's what. what they say you are."""
yo: "Madaamu...madaamu, oke jade, ""Nnkan ti won lo n se yin niyen."""

en: """What? They say that em... em.. that.. that you are crazy madam."
yo: Kini? Won so pe em... em... pe... pe e ti ya were madaamu.

en: Me? Who told you that?
yo: Emi? Ta lo so bee fun o?

en: People in the other house.
yo: Awon ara ile keji.

en: Zenabu pointed her finger towards the houses around them.
yo: Senabu na ika owo re si awon ile to wa la yii ka won.

en: They say my madam has gone mad, they say my master has gone mad too, they say my madam has gone crazy, they say I am living inside a mad house. The people there said it... Zenabu pointed her finger again.
yo: Won ni madaamu mi ti ya were, won ni oga mi ti ya were, won ni inu ilewere ni mo n gbe. Awon eeyan ibeyen lo so o... Senabu tun nawo.

en: Neighbours! These illiterate neighbours!
yo: Awon ara adugbo! Awon aladuugbo puruntu yii!

en: Labake lamented, they know nothing but to scandalise, to gossip, to slander, they had said things like these to her own hearing too before.
yo: Labake pohun rere, won o mo nnkankan yato si ki won kan eeyan labuku, ki won seke, ki won sisoro banilorukoje, won ti so irun n kan bee si eti re naa ri.

en: These packs of ignorant, illiterate neighbours.
yo: Awon owo aladuugbo alai mokan-mokan yii.

en: Their stock in trade is to assassinate character.
yo: Awon ti won mo on se o ju ki won ba ti eniyan je.

en: They would not anchor their mouths. If she would still remain with Alamu, she would insist that they leave this illiterate infested area of the city.
yo: Enu won kii gbe jee. Bi o ba si maa wa pelu Alamu, a tenumo on pe ki won kuro ni adugbo aimokan-mokan yii.

en: She would insist that they pack off to a more exclusive section of the city - the G.R.A section - where civilised and well-informed people live in joyful isolation.
yo: A tenumo on pe ki won lo si adugbo to laju niiluu - agbegbe iyasoto ijoba - nibi ti awon eniyan to laju, to mo nnkan to n lo n gbe tayo tayo.

en: Now these awfully detestable neighbours of theirs had started working on their innocent housemaid.
yo: Nisinsinyi, awon aladuugbo buruku wonyi ti n sise lori omo-odo won ti o mo kan.

en: If they had told Zenabu that it was Alamu alone who had gone mad, that would have been better.
yo: Kani pe won so fun Senabu pe Alamu nikan lo ya were, iba daa.

en: Or if they had told the poor girl that old Mama, in addition had gone crazy, it would have been alright too.
yo: Tabi kani pe won so fun omo naa pe Mama naa ya were, iba tun daa.

en: But to say that she, Labake, had also gone mad? What arrant nonsense!
yo: Sugbon ki won so pe oun, Labake naa ti ya were? Iru orokoro wo niyen?

en: Zenabu... Zenabu... tell me, they told you Alamu had gone mad?
yo: Senabu... Senabu... so fun mi, se won so fun o pe Alamu ya were?

en: Yes, madam. But did they really tell you I had gone mad also?
yo: Bee ni madaamu. sugbon se won diidi so fun e pe emi naa ti ya were ni?

en: Yes, they told me you are more mad.
yo: Bee ni, won so fun mi pe were ti yin le ju.

en: Me? Yes, madam
yo: Emi? Bee ni, madaamu.

en: Now, Zenabu, is that why you are crying?
yo: Ni bayii, Senabu, se iyen lo fa a to o fi n sunkun?

en: Is that why you want to return home to Kwara?
yo: Se idi ti o fi fe pada sile ni Kwara ni yen?

en: No, madam. What then?
yo: Rara, madaamu. Ki wa ni?

en: They said you will tear my flesh... with your teeth... in the night.
yo: Won ni e maa fi eyin ya eran ara mi... ni ale.

en: After I am asleep, they said you will not sleep on the day you will do it.
yo: Leyin ti mo ba sun, won ni e o ni i sun lojo ti e ba maase e.

en: But that you will wait until I had slept off well.
yo: Sugbon won ni ema a duro di igba ti mo ba ti sun wora.

en: Then you will grab me. Because you have gone mad.
yo: Leyin naa le e wa gba mi mu. Nitori pe, e ti ya were.

en: They tell me all these things madam. And you believe them, Zenabu?
yo: Won so gbogbo eyi fun mi madaamu. Iwo naa si gba won gbo, Senabu?

en: Madam... Madam... You stayed awake all through last night. Till this morning ma.. I did not close my eyes madam...
yo: "Madaamu... madaamu... e o sun moju lati ale ana. Moju aaro yii ma... Mi o diju mi madaamu."""

en: Yes, I stayed awake Zenabu, but you can't understand. Labake suddenly realised her own position.
yo: Bee ni, mi o sun Senabu, sugbon ko le ye e. Labake deede ranti ipo re.

en: If Zenabu was on the offensive, then, she had to be on the defensive.
yo: Bi Senabu ba ka asese, oun ni lati gba ara re sile.

en: Zenabu... Zenabu. You can't understand why I stayed awake all through the night till this morning. You are too young to know why
yo: Senabu... Senabu. Idi ti mo se laju sile lati ana titi di aaro yii o le ye e. O kere lati mo idi re.

en: Madam, the people told me why. Will you stop!
yo: Madaamu, awon eeyan naa so idi re fun mi. Se wa a dekun!

en: Will you stop listening! Listening to these mad people! Will you stop talking about these crazy people!
yo: "Se wa a dekun ati maa teti si awon were yii! Se wa a dekun lati maa soro nipa awon were eeyan yii!"""

en: Zenabu looked away and defiantly shrugged her little shoulders. It appeared she was with the neighbours, rather than with her.
yo: Senabu gboju kuro, o si gun ejika re. O jo wipe ko gba ti Labake, tawon aladuugbo won lo gba.

en: So, what are you going to do now Zenabu?
yo: Niba yii, ki lo wa fese Senabu?

en: Madam, I have packed my load.
yo: Madaamu, mo ti ko eru mi.

en: And? And I am going back home.
yo: En en? Mo de n pada lo si ile.

en: You are running back home - no doubt - from a mad woman?
yo: O n sa lo ile - laisi ani-ani - o n safun were obinrin abi?

en: No, madam. What then?
yo: Rara, madaamu. Ki wa ni?

en: Just going back home...to my father and mother.
yo: Mo kan fe pada sile ni...mo fe lo ba baba ati iya mi.

en: Ok. Zenabu, go back to your room now! Go and put down your load right now! You hear!
yo: O daa. Senabu, pada si yara re nisinsinyi! Lo gbe eru re sile bayii! Se o gbo!

en: Zenabu once more shrugged her shoulders and shook her little head daringly, rebelliously, the tears inside her eyes had completely dried up.
yo: Senabu tun gun ejika o de miri tafojudi tafojudi, omije oju re ti gbe tan patapata.

en: A look of desperation was now visible on her innocent countenance, she did not move. Instead, she picked up her small load and clutched it firmly in her hands then stood rooted to the ground.
yo: Iwo odaju lo wa han ninu irisi aimokan re, ko mira. Kaka bee, o gbe eru re kekere, o si wa a mora, o si duro tubo fese mule.

en: Labake was a bit scared. Was this little girl mad?
yo: Eru ba Labake die. se omo kekere yii ya were ni?

en: She really must be mad. It would be better to allow this little wretch of a housemaid have her way.
yo: A je pe o ti ya were. A daa ki o je ki omo-odo osi yii rona lo.

en: See her looking impudently. See her pouting her small lips. See fire inside her small eyes.
yo: E wo o bi o se n wo, tafojudi tafojudi. E wo bi ose n su enu po. E wo ina loju re kekere.

en: Alright Zenabu', Labake said piping down, 'You can go to your home town... You are released.
yo: "O daa Senabu, Labake farabale soro, ""O le maa lo si ilu yin... A ti tu o sile."

en: Zenabu put down her small load and stretched out her hands. She wanted the balance of her monthly allowance and, of course, her transport fare, from madam.
yo: Senabu gbe eru re kekere sile, o si nawo re. O fe gba owo-osu re toku, ati owo oko re lowo madaamu.

en: I have no money to give you... No transport fare to give you even since you are going away on your own volition. For money, I'm afraid you have to wait for master to retum.
yo: "Emi o ni owo kankan lati fun o... Mi o ni owo oko lati fun o niwon igba to je pe o n lo ni tie ni. Ti owo, wa a ni lati duro ki oga de."""

en: Alright.. I will wait for master.
yo: O daa... Maa duro de oga.

en: Ok Zenabu, that's right, wait for him, go and stay in your room till master comes back?
yo: O daa Senabu, iyen dara, duro de e, lo duro ninu yara re titi oga a fi pada de?

en: No! No! I will stay here! I will stand here like this, till master will come. He will meet me here.
yo: Rara! Rara! Maa duro nibi! Maa duro bayii, titi oga maa fi de. Won a ba mi nibi.

en: Labake smiles to herself, this girl had thoroughly gone mad... Let her remain standing there, Labake yawned loud. She stood up and staggered towards her own room propping Tinu to her chest, she had become badly spent.
yo: Labake rerin-in si ara re, omo yii ti ya were gidi... Ki o duro sibe, Labake yan yiyan alariwo. O dide, o si ta giegie lo si ona yara re, o gbe Tinu saya.

en: Really intoxicated with sleep. Nature would not be cheated
yo: O ti re e gidi, oorun si n kun un gidi.

en: It did not take Labake's eyes two minutes to close up.
yo: Ko gba oju Labake ni iseju meta lati pade.

en: It did not take her chest three minutes to begin heaving - like a reed in the tide.
yo: Ko gba aya re ni iseju meta lati bere si i mi.

en: Alamu did not travel to Lagos.
yo: Alamu ko ririn ajo lo si Eko.

en: As a matter of fact, he was very much around in town with Adio his friend, their meeting this time was a meeting with a difference.
yo: Koda, o wa niluu pelu Adio, ore re, ipade won lo te yii je ipade to ni iyato.

en: Adio looked at Alamu and smiled, Alamu too smiled back at Adio - a smile of satisfaction and contentment.
yo: Adio wo Alamu , o si rerin-in muse, Alamu naa rerin-in pada si Adio, erin itelorun.

en: How was Alamu going to thank his friend enough for what he had done to assist him these past nine months that he'd been in trouble, burning hell, hell on earth.
yo: Bawo ni Alamu yoo se dupe lowo ore re fun nnkan ti o ti se lati ran an lowo lati osu mesan-an seyin ti o ti wa ninu isoro, orun apaadi to n jo, orun apaadi lorile aye.

en: They shook hands, together their hearts sang the silent song of happiness and gratitude to God, two people with one soul!
yo: Won bo ara won lowo, ajoko ni okan won korin ayo ati idupe sinu lati dupe lowo Olorun, eniyan meji pelu emi kan!

en: Alamu stammered his gratitude, the whole story was long, so long he did not know where exactly to begin relating it.
yo: Alamu kalolo idupe re, gbogbo itan naa gun, to bee ti ko mo ibi ti yoo ti bere re ni siso.

en: "There will be plenty of time later', Adio said, ""to tell the full story, for now, let's celebrate the Victory."
yo: Opo asiko a wa to ba ya', Adio so eyi, 'lati so itan naa ni kikun, sugbon nisinsinyi, je ka a yo ayo isegun.'

en: Two hours ago, Adio was sweating it out in court on behalf of his friend.
yo: Wakati meji seyin, Adio nse awijare ore re nile ejo.

en: That was the third time he would argue Alamu's case.
yo: Iyen ni igba keta ti yoo se awijare ejo Alamu.

en: For over one hour, he stood by Alamu as the barrage of questions came pouring in from the opponent's lawyer, and when at last Adio started his own cross-examination of Alamu's opponent, nobody present in court was in any doubt as to where the axe would fall. The cross examination was rigorous, it was searching, it was through:
yo: Fun wakati kan o le die, oduro ti Alamu girigiri bi ibeerese doju koAlamu lati enu agbejoro alatako re, ko si enikeni to wa nile ejo to mo ibi ti aake oro naa yoo sole si. Agbetungbe ayewo naa le koko, o se finifini, o si pari:

en: Mr. Alamu Olaoye had been in your employment for four years?
yo: "Ogbeni Alamu Olaoye ti wani enu ise yin fun odun marun-un?"""

en: Yes. How many times did you issue queries to him?
yo: Bee ni. Eemeloo ni e ti fiwe pe e lejo ?

en: There were no queries for him. What about warnings?
yo: A ko beere ri. Ikilo nko ?

en: Two times. Where is the evidence?
yo: Eemeji. Eri da?

en: Were they written warnings? No Verbal. Mr. Personnel Manager, did you say you set up a probe panel?
yo: Se e ko won sile? Rara, afenuso ni. Ogbeni alaboojuto osise, se e ni e da igbimo iwadii sile?

en: Yes. To do what? Give us the paper containing its terms of reference.
yo: Bee ni. Lati se kini? E fun wa ni iwe ti i juwe ise won wa.

en: No paper. I just told the panel to... to... to...
yo: Ko si iwe. Mo kan so fun awon ajo naa pe ki...ki...ki...

en: Was the proceeding during the probe tape recorded?
yo: Se e gba ohun sile nigba ti won se pade igbimo iwadii naa?

en: No, it was not. You merely paraphrased evidence at the probe in black and white?
yo: Rara, a ko gba a. Se e kan se agekuru iwadii yin lasan ni?

en: Yes. I put it to you that Alamu's evidence at the probe was taken under duress.
yo: Bee ni. Mo n so pe iwadii yin gba oro lenu Alamu tipatipa.

en: You stage-managed the probe Mr. Personnel Manager - secretly nosing round members of the panel, intimidating them with threats.
yo: E kan se iwadii arumoje ni alakooso osise - ti e kan n fimu ko panti kiri laarin awon omo igbimo asewadii, e si n hale mo won.

en: "You no longer can deny this because we have shown the court evidence to prove this."" Lawyer Adio now turned to the learned Judge."
yo: E o le se eyi tori a ti fi gbogbo eri to gbe eyi lese han nile ejo. Agbejoro Adio si koju si adajo to mose naa:

en: We must not forget, my lord, that the chairman of this kangaroo probe is the Personnel Manager's in-law who works in the Establishment.
yo: A ogbodo gbagbe, oluwa a mi, pe alaga igbimo iwadii arumoje yii ti o n sise nii leese yii je ana alakooso osise ileese yii.

en: The secretary is his cousin, the other two members are relations of the Personnel Manager's friend.
yo: Ibatan re ni akowe, awon omo egbe meji yoo ku si je ibatan ore alaboojuto osise.

en: That was why he found it easy to stage-manage things.
yo: Idi niyi ti o fi rorun fun un latise awuruju yii.

en: Ever since the beginning of this case, my lord, three of the defendant's key witnesses have absconded, the other witnesses are unreliable.
yo: Lati igba ti ejo yii ti bere, Oluwa a mi, meta ninu awon elerii olujejo yii ni o ti na papa bora, awon elerii yooku kose e gbarale.

en: They are the Personnel Manager's praise singers and professional congratulations, we have seen in this court how they fell, like a pack of cards under frank and honest cross-examination.
yo: Awon to n korin yin alakooso osise ati awon to mo epon ati ikiniku-oriire ni won, a si ti ri won nile ejoyii bi won se fidi remi labe agbeyewo taara, ododo ati ibeere iwadii.

en: My client. Mr. Alamu Olaoye has been made to suffer untold hardship and embarrassment as a result of the false allegation of dereliction of duty and financial mis-management levelled against him and the consequent illegal sack letter issued by the Personnel Manager of Bajoks Company Limited'.
yo: Onibaara mi, ogbeni Alamu Olaoye ti jiya aimodi ati itiju latari iro ailese ojuse-eni ati isowo-kumo-kumo ti won pa mo on, ti won si fun un niwee iyonise ti alaboojuto osise ileese Bajoks fun un.

en: The Personnel Manager's move is a calculated attempt to eliminate my client from the Establishment and slot in his own man who had just graduated in Accountancy from the university and whose letter of application and C.V. are now resting in the Personnel Manager's office.
yo: Igbese alaboojuto osise wa latari isiro ipinnu re lati yo onibaara mi nise, ki won si fi eeyan tiwon ti osese ke koo gboye ninu imo isiro owo ni yunifasiti, ti awon leta iwase re ati eri mo-kunju-iwon re n be lofiisi bayii.

en: Conclusively, my lord, the good name of my client has been dragged into the mud, his reputation tamished. He has been painted black in the eyes the Managing Director, the overall boss of company.
yo: Lakootan, Oluwa a mi, won ti wo oruko rere onibaara mi tuurutu ninu erofo, won ti ba a loruko je, won ti ba a je loju a dari alaboojuto, ti o je oga ileese.

en: I therefore pray the court to invoke the law to wrest my client from the vicious grip of his tormentors and oppressors.
yo: Fun idi eyi, mo ro ile-ejo yii ki won fi ofin gba onibaara mi lowo awon ajunilo abatenije yii.

en: Some fifteen minutes later, the learned Judge started reviewing the submissions of both the plaintiff and the defendant, finally pronouncing the verdict: wrongful termination of appointment of the Senior Accountant of Bajoks Company Limited, Mr. Alamu Olaoye. Action of the Personnel Manager, illegal.
yo: Leyin iseju meedogun, adajo naa bere si i satunwo awon eri olupejo ati olujejo, ati gbogbo akosile won, iyonise to lodi ni ti asiro-oro agba ileese Bajoks, Ogbeni Alamu Olaoye, igbese alaboojuto osise, ko bofin mu.

en: The Managing Director of the company was not kept in the true picture of things. He had been deceived by his Personnel Manager.
yo: Won ko si fi aworan tooto bi oro naa se lo han adari alaboojuto ileese. Alabooju too sise re ti tan an.

en: Mr. Alamu Olaoye is therefore to be re-absorbed into the company as the Senior Accountant with immediate effect.
yo: Ki Ogbeni Alamu Olaoye pada sinu ileese naa gege bi i asiro-oro agba ni kia.

en: His nine-month salary is to be paid in arrears with immediate effect by the company, his annual incremental credit to be approved and effected.
yo: Owo-osu re fun osu mesan-an ni ileese gbodo san fun un ni kiakia, afikun owo re odo odun gbodo gba onte, ki o si gba a.

en: A cost of five thousand naira to be paid as damages to Mr. Alamu Olaoye by the defendant.
yo: Egberun marun-un naira ni olujejo gbodo san fun Ogbeni Alamu Olaoye fun ibaje.

en: "The attitude of the Personnel Manager is seen to be inimical to the progress and aspiration of a reputable company of Bajoks standing and the Managing Director is advised to institute a high powered inquiry into the activities of the Personnel Manager..."" That was how it all went."
yo: Ihuwasi alaboojuto osise le di ilosiwaju ati ojo iwaju ileese Bajoks lowo, fun idi eyi, mo gba a dari alaboojuto nii yanju lati se iwadii to mun adoko si gbogbo ise alaboojuto osise naa... Bi o se lo re e.

en: That was how Lawyer Adio fought and finally won the legal battle for his friend. And now, what was left for them was to congratulate each other; then, at leisure, recapitulate the story leading up to this final victory.
yo: Bi agbejoro Adio se ja ajasegun ogun olofin naa fun ore re. Ni bayii, ohun to seku fun won ni lati ki ara won kuoriire, nigba towo ba si dile, won amaase iranti itan titi debi ajasegun re.

en: "There will be plenty of time later', Adio repeated, ""to tell all the story, for now, let's celebrate... and, what a way to begin the celebration! Adio pressed a button on his tape-recorder."
yo: "Asiko a po to ba ya, Adio tun un so,""lati so gbogbo itan naa, ni bayii je ki a sajoyo...ati pe je ki a bere ajoyo naa bayii! Adio te botiini kan lara ero igbohunsile re."

en: Alamu listened... A lady's voice full of complaints and bitterness came out loud. There was another voice - that of a man, occasionally intersecting.
yo: Alamu teti... Ohun obinrin, ti o kun fun ifisun ati ibanuje jade sita. Ohun mii n tun wa - o je ohun okunrin, ti o n ni igbe laaarin.

en: The dialogue between the two peony lasted for about five minutes, the female voice became more and more bitter and severe towards the end of the tape.
yo: Itakuroso laaarin eeyan meji pefun bi iseju marun-un, ohun obinrin naa koro si i, o si le ni opin re.

en: Labake's voice was unmistakable! Alamu instantly recognised the voice of his wife! No mistake about it...it quickly dawned on him that there was a fresh case to contest.
yo: Ohun Labake ose e si mu! Esekese ni Alamu da ohun aya re mo! Ko si asise nipa re...o tete mo pe oun ni ejo miiran lati ro.

en: This time, a matrimonial case, Labake was going to be the complainant, he was going to be the defendant. Anxiously he waited for the time he would come face to face with Labake.
yo: Ni asiko yii, ejo igbeyawo won ni, Labake a je olupejo, oun ni a je olujejo. Ko le duro de asiko ti yoo duro lojukoju pelu Labake.

en: That would be in a matter of five minutes or so from now. Adio's car was waiting outside to take them away.
yo: Iyen a je oro iseju marun-un bi nnkan si isinyi. Oko ayokele Adio n duro nita lati gbe won lo.

en: It was now three o'clock in the afternoon. Everything was quiet in Alamu's house.
yo: Aago meta lo lu bayii losan-an, gbogbo nnkan lo dake roro ni ile Alamu.

en: That was very unusual, the neighbours' curiosity was aroused, on other days the neighbours often listened as Alamu revved the old engine of his jalopy - disturbing their peace.
yo: Eyi sajeji, Okan ofintoto awon ara adugbo won wa loke, ni awon ojo miiran, awon aladuugbo yii maa n teti si bi Alamu se n sana si enjiini oko jalopi re - ti o fi n da won laamu.

en: They often listened to him yell out his strange outlandish laughter, and Labake blaring orders at Zenabu.
yo: Won maa n teti si bi ose n rin erin alaruwo abami re, ati bi Labake se maa n pariwo ase re fun Senabu.

en: Tinu would be crying somewhere inside the house. There used to be movements too; like Labake rushing out to the market; Alamu hurriedly descending the stall case. backing the car out of the garage on his seemingly endless trips out to town; Tinu toddling about on the verandah of the house; Zenabu sneaking out to play with the other girls of her age group in the nearby house.
yo: Tinu a maa sunkun nibi kan ninu ile. Won maa n gbo igbese naa; bi i ki Labake ma lo soja; bi i ki Alamu sare maa bole lori akaso ile. Ki o si feyin oko re rin kuro ninu ogba igbokosi si irinajo alailopin re lo si igboro; Ki Tinu maa sere ni odede ile won; Ki Senabu maa yo jade lati baa won omodebinrin egbe re ni awon ile ayika won.

en: But now, in Alamu's house, there was no noise and there was no movement, it has been like that morning - up till now - three o'clock in the afternoon.
yo: Sugbon nisinsinyi, nile Alamu, ko si ariwo kankan, ko si igbese kankan, o ti ri bee lati aaro -titi di isinyi - aago meta losan-an.

en: That was strange, where was the mad man? Where was his mad wife? Where was that little rat they called their child? And the mischievous creature called Zenabu who used to give them first-hand accounts of what went on inside this mad house?
yo: Iyen sajeji, nibo ni were okunrin wa? Were iyawo re da? Eku kekere ti won pe lomo won da? Ati ika eda ti won n pe ni Senabu, ti o maa n fun won ni iroyin ti o labula nnkan ti o n lo ninu ile were yii?

en: If the neighbours had access to Alamu's house, they would have seen that Zenabu was still deep in sleep - by the side of a small load inside the sitting room of the house.
yo: Bi awon aladuugbo ba ni anfaani si ile Alamu, won a ti ri i pe Senabu si n sun legbee eru kekereninu yara igbafe ninu ile.

en: They would have seen that little Tinu was still in peaceful slumber in her mother's room in the house, the neighbours would have seen that Labake herself had just woken up, yawning and stretching her body after a sleepless night...
yo: Won o ba ti ri i pe Tinu kekere si n sun oorun alaafia ninu yara iya re ninu ile, awon aladuugbo o ba ri i pe Labake fun rare sese ji, o n yan, o n nara leyin ale aisun...

en: As the inquisitive neighbours continued gazing intently and pointing fingers, a white Mercedes-Benz zoomed in and jerked to a stop in front of Alamu's house. Alamu came out of the car, another man following closely after him.
yo: Bi awon eke adugbo se n wo lemo lemo ti won n naka, ni oko ayokele mesi oloye funfun kan wole, ti o si pana niwaju ile Alamu. Alamu jade ninu oko naa, okunrin miiran si tele e peki peki.

en: Together they ascended the stairs talking and nodding excitedly.
yo: Awon mejeeji jo gun akaso ile naa, won n soro, won si n kanri mole ti dunnu ti dunnu.

en: Inside the sitting room, Alamu and his companion met Labake and saw that Zenabu was Just waking up from sleep.
yo: Ninu yara igbalejo, Alamu ati enikeji re pade Labake, won si ri i pe Senabu sese n ji lati oju oorun ni.

en: The little girl scrambled up stretched and rubbed her face several times, she looked round and round - apparently to find out whether or not she was already in Kwara!
yo: Omo kekere naa kora jo, o nara, o si fowo pa oju re laimoye igba, o wo ra ra ra - lati mo boya o ti de Kwara tabi koi debe.

en: In a minute she discovered where she was. Quickly she bent down and clutched her small load firmly in her hands:
yo: Ni iseju kan, o sakiyesi ibi ti o wa. Kia o bere mole o si gbe eru re kekere sowo girigiri:

en: "I am ready to go now ma."" Little Zenabu stretched out her hand in the manner of a creditor asking for money from his debtor."
yo: Mo ti se tan lati maa lo ma, Senabu kekere nawo re bi igba ti asinwo n beere owo lowo Ajigbese re.

en: Get inside your room now Zenabu!' Alamu blurted. His mind was set on a more important issue. And he had no time for a silly, raving little girl...
yo: Wo inu yara re lo bayii Senabu!, Alamu jagbe. Okan re wa ninu oro to pataki ju iyen lo. Ko si raye ti omo onibaje kekere kan....

en: Get you inside quickly now! Zenabu brushed her face again and saw him for the first time, without a word of protest, she stumbled inside the pantry - her little room.
yo: Wole kia nisinyi! Senabu tun nu oju re, o siri i fun igba akoko, laisi oro iyan, o sare wo inu ile ounje - yara re kekere.

en: The three people left in the sitting room now had plenty of time to gaze at one another. For a long time, they regarded one another silently, they stood like three transformed dead bodies now coming together in Hades to settle their age-long, earthly quarrel!
yo: Awon eniyan meta ti o seku si yara igbafe naa wa ni asiko lati wo ara won, Fun igba pipe, won wo ara won ni idake roro, won duro bi i oku meta ti a ti yi pada ti won fe pari ija aye olojo pipe won.

en: Labake's gaze was confrontational and hatred-filled, she seemed to be cursing Alamu under her breath for all the sorrow and tribulations he had unleashed on her these past nine months.
yo: Iwo idojuko ati irira ni o kun oju Labake, o fe jo pe o n sepe fun Alamu lokan re- fun gbogbo osu mesan-an yii.

en: Alamu's own gaze was the apologetic, beg-your-pardon gaze. Pleadingly, his eyes surveyed Labake's angry countenance.
yo: Iwo oju Alamu ni eyi to n bebe; iwo jowo-ma-binu, tebe tebe, oju re wo irisi ibinu Labake.

en: Adio allowed the silent attack and defence to linger on between husband and wife without interruption for some time.
yo: Adio je ki ija idakeroro naa lo laaarin tokotaya won fun igba die laisii diwo.

en: Finally, he broke the silence with, Let's all sit down and talk'.
yo: Nigbeyin gbeyin, o fi oro dekun idakeroro naa, E je ki gbogbo wa jokoo, ki a sisoro.

en: Alamu looked at his friend with eyes twinkling like stars. When he tumed to look at the face of his wife, the tears had actually gathered, her own tears, of course, had started pouring down her cheeks.
yo: Alamu wo ore re pelu oju titan bi irawo. Nigba ti o yi woju iyawo re, omije ti sarajo, omije ti n san wale lereke re.

en: "Let's sit and talk,"" Adio repeated."
yo: E je ki a jokoo soro, Adio tenumo on.

en: Talk about what!' Labake shouted, still sobbing.
yo: Soro nipa kini! Labake pariwo, o si n sunkun.

en: "Can... can... we ever sit down and talk... talk about anything on this earth again?"" She stammered."
yo: Se... se... a le tun jokoo soro nipa nnkankan mo lae?, O kalolo.

en: "We'll sit and talk... We just must sit down and talk,"" Adio pleaded, 'talk things over."""
yo: "A maa jokoo soro... a ni lati jokoo, ki a soro,"" Adio bebe, Ki a so o pari."""

en: I have to explain, Alamu submitted in a voice that seemed to come from another person.
yo: Mo ni lati salaye, Alamu soro pelu ohun ti o jo pe o tenu elomiran jade.

en: There was prolonged silence again. Alamu tried to get himself together, Labake wiped her own face with a handkerchief and blew her nose.
yo: Idakeroro ti o pe tun waye. Alamu gbiyanju lati sarajo, Labake nu oju tire pelu aso inuju, o si fun imu re.

en: "Then she took another look at her husband. Labake bent her head. That strange 'ha ha ha ha"" laughter came to her ears once more, she heard the mocking voices of the neighbours once more, she saw, anew, how the mammy-wagon driver demonstrated the turning of the head."
yo: "Leyin naa ni o tun wo oko re. Labake dorikodo. Erin ""ha ha ha ha"" abami yen tun wa si eti re, o gbo ohun ifiniseyeye awon aladuugbo leekan si i, o tun ri awako oko akeru ti o n sapejuwe bi ori se yi to."

en: Then, she moaned, and fresh tears gathered, those items which you carried away from home Alamu... What happened?
yo: "Leyin naa, o gbin, omije tuntun tun sarajo, awon ohuneelo ti o ko kuro nile Alamu... Ki lo sele ?"""

en: I sold them Labake, so that we would not starve, I sold them to make ends meet... Adio discovered he had to be blunt and tell the truth, that was the only way to restore Labake's confidence which had been badly shaken.
yo: "Mo ta won Labake, kebi ma ba a pa wa, mo ta won lati le je ka a rowo mu lo senu....."" O sakiyesi pe oun ni lati diju, ki o so otito, ona yii ni o le gba lati da ifokan tan Labake ninu re pada."

en: What about your car, Alamu? I sold that one out too Labake... Adio was kind enough to let me have his old Volkswagen.
yo: Oko re nko, Alamu? Mo ta iyen naa Labake... Adio sise daadaa lati le je ki n lo oko bitu aloku re .
