en: Security forces have tear gassed those who defy the ban, and arrested dozens of demonstrators.
yo: Awon eso alaabo ti so tajutaju si aarin awon ti ko gboran lati tu won ka, won si ko aimoye eniyan.

en: Regarding the political situation, the government is delivering conflicting messages: On October 13, President Conde welcomed a dialogue:
yo: Ni ti isele oselu naa, ajo oba naa n kede ise-ije ti o n tako ara won: Ni ojo 13, osu Owara Aare Conde fe isoro-ni-tunbi-n-nubi:

en: Translation Original Quote
yo: Itumo Itunwi-oro Oloro gan-an

en: Alpha Conde has reiterated his call for a responsible dialogue and for a permanent process of discussions in order to iron out differences and answer all the challenges the country is facing.
yo: Alpha Conde ti pe fun isoro ni tunbinnubi o si fe ki ijokoo gege bi tomotiya ti yoo fi peleputu yanju gbonmi-sii-omi-o-too ti o n sele ati ona abayo si awon ipenija ti o n koju orile-ede naa.

en: Yet, Ahmed Tidiane Traore, a presidential counselor, stated the following day on October 12, - two days before the demonstrations started, - to a crowd of RPG youth [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea party]:
yo: Sibe, Ahmed Tidiane Traore, oludamoran ipo aare, so lojo ti o tele e, iyen ni ojo 12 osu Owara, - ojo meji ki ifehonuhan o to bere, - fun awon ero to je odo langba RPG egbe oloseluu [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea]:

en: Translation Original Quote
yo: Itumo Itunwi-oro Oloro gan-an

en: We invite the party's youth to remain vigilant in the districts.
yo: A ro awon odo egbe oselu naa lati kun fun isora ni ojuu popo.

en: They [the opposition activists] have stocked use tires in wholes, we invite young people from the party to get those tires out, prevent them from acting, get those hidden tires, do not attack anyone, do not destroy anything, just defend yourselves.
yo: Awon [ti awon je ajijangbara alatako] ti fa isoro, a pe awon ipeere lati inu egbe naa lati wa ona abayo si isoro to wa nile, amo ki e maa doju ija ko enikeni, ki e maa ba dukia kankan je, ju idaabo bo ara yin lo.

en: All evil-doers will be found and shown to the people.
yo: Gbogbo awon onise-ibi ni o di awari ti a o fi ojuu won han f'araye ri.

en: This double talk amongst those in power has further angered the opposition and civil society, according to the site globalguinee.info:
yo: Enu meji awon ti o n tuko ilu ti tubo mu inu bi egbe alatako ati awon ajafetoo omoniyan, o ni bi itakun globalguinee.info se so:

en: Translation Original Quote
yo: Itumo Itunwi-oro Oloro gan-an

en: October 14, 2019, is a dark Monday, if not black, responding to the call made by the FNDC [National Front for the Defense of the Constitution], Guineans took massively to the streets to oppose the project of constitutional changes.
yo: Ojo 14 osu Owara odun-un 2019 je ojo Aje buruku Esu gbomi mu, ni ti ifesi si ipe ajo FNDC [Awon ti o n le waju n'nu Idaabo bo Iwe-ofin Orile-ede], awon omo Guinea tu yaya tu yaya si ojuu titi lati tako igbese atunse si iwe-ofin.

en: Clashes were reported in different districts of the Guinean capital.
yo: Ikolu waye ni awon agbegbe ti o wa ni aarin olu ilu orile-ede naa.

en: Business in the administrative center of Kalou was almost entirely stopped.
yo: Karakata denu kole ni aarin gbungbun ibi isakoso ilu ni Kalou.

en: Inside the country, people also responded to the call in Middle and Lower Guinea.
yo: Awon ti o wa ni Aarin ati Odo orile ede Guinea naa gbo ipe, won si darapo mo awon omo ilu to ku.

en: In the forest and in Higher Guinea, not so much.
yo: Eniyan die ni o jade ni igberiko ati Okee Guinea.

en: Yet, cities have been paralyzed.
yo: Amo sa, opolopo ilu ti koyin sijoba lori igbese yii.

en: Expressing himself on benbere.org, a Malian platform for youth, Malian blogger Adam Thiam writes:
yo: Ni orii benbere.org, gbagede itakuroso fun awon odo ni Mali, akoroyin buloogu Adam Thiam ko:

en: Translation Original Quote
yo: Itumo Itunwi-oro Oloro gan-an

en: Serious things are now happening in Guinea, with incendiary escalation, almost random dead demonstrators riddles with bullets, blood trails on pavements with barricades and crossroads smoking with tires in flames and tear gas.
yo: Nnkan kayeefi n lo lowo lowo bayii ni Guinea, pelu irogbamu ti o n waye, ota ibon ti fo si ara awon afehonuhan ti o si ti seku pa opolopoo won, eje ni ojuu popo, idigaga ni gbogbo, ina ese okoo sisun ati tajutaju ninu afefe.

en: Netizens have denounced the violence on social media:
yo: Awon omo ilu ori ayelujara fajuro si isele naa lori ero alatagba:

en: Just like Blaise Compaore [Burkinabe politician] Alpha Conde is going straight to the abyss, Will he be able to hear the angry shouting of his compatriots?
yo: Bii ti Blaise Compaore [oloseluu Burkinabe] Alpha Conde n fori le ibi iparun, nje yo lee gbohun inubibi awon araa re bi?

en: The very near future will tell us. Meanwhile, the boat is sinking.
yo: O di ojo iwaju ki a to mo. Ni bayii sa, oko oju omi ti n re.

en: On October 15, Guinean journalist Bhiye Bary wrote:
yo: Lojo 15 osu Owara, akoroyin Guinea Bhiye Bary ko:

en: Hamdallaye pharmacy (#Conakry): certain citizens woken up by the police forces early this morning.
yo: Ile itoogun Hamdallaye (#Conakry): awon olopaa lo ji awon omo ilu kan loju oorun ni owuro yii.

en: According to a local citizen, the police forces are breaking down doors and looting houses.
yo: Gege bi enikan ti se so, awon olopaa n jalekun ti won si n ko eru nile onile.

en: S. Nkola Matamba, a writer and human rights activist from the Democratic Republic of Congo, shared his bitterness:
yo: S. Nkola Matamba, onkowe ati ajafetoo omoniyan ti o je omo Ilu Olominira Ijoba ara wa ti Congo, fi ibanuje okan han:

en: A former member of the opposition, and now devoured by the desire to change the law to allow a third mandate, maybe to remain on the throne till the end, Alpha Conde embodies of of the dark sides of the kind of Africa that keeps taking us down!
yo: Omo egbe alatako igbakan, ti o wa fe yi ofin pada nitori ife ara re ki o ba sejoba fun igba keta, boya ki o ba je gaba titi ti Olojo yoo fi de, Alpha Conde gan-an ni apeere ibi ti o n fa ifaseyin fun Ile-Adulawo !

en: People of Guinea, have courage!
yo: Eyin araa Guinea, e mu okan le!

en: #GUINEE - It's simply appalling. First day of demonstration against a third mandate for Conde and here we are with an outcome of victims and dead people.
yo: #GUINEE - o je ohun iyalenu. Ifehonuhan itako isejoba Conde fun igba keta ojo kan soso ti mu emi awon eniyan lo.

en: This craziness of politicians who want to remain head of state for life Amoulanfe - Cheikh Fall (@cypher007) October 14, 2019
yo: Sisiwin awon oloselu ti o fe ku sori ipo aare yii ti n po ju Amoulanfe - Cheikh Fall (@cypher007) ojo 14, osu Owara 2019

en: Guinean activist Macky Darsalam noted attempts made to manipulate public opinion:
yo: Ajijangbara Guinea Macky Darsalam so ti igbese lati towo bo erongba awon ara ilu loju:

en: The Guinean opposition seems defenseless in the face of such attacks: the deputies of all opposition parties have stopped participating in parliamentary debates since October 11, 2019.
yo: Egbe alatako Guinea naa ko ni aabo ti o le fi bo araa re lasiko ikolu: awon asoju alase egbe alatako gbogbo ko da si ariyanjiyan igbimo ijoba mo lati ojo 11, osu Owara 2019.

en: Violence against these parties has taken on radical forms, as the site mediaguinee.org notes:
yo: Iwa ipa si awon egbe oloselu wonyi ti gba ona ara, bee ni ibudo itakun mediaguinee.org se ko:

en: Translation Original Quote
yo: Itumo Itunwi-oro Oloro gan-an

en: ...at the headquarter of the Union of Republican Forces (URF) of Sidya Toure district, clashes took place between certain members of the opposition and pro-government militants who had taken measures the day before to prevent any unauthorized demonstration in the stronghold of the ruling party.
yo: ...ni olu ileese Union of Republican Forces (URF) ti agbegbe Sidya Toure, ija waye laaarin awon omo egbe alatako kan ati awon ti o n fe ti ijoba ti o ti seto ti ko ni je ki iyide ifehonuhan naa o waye lojo kan si ojo ifehonuhan ni awon agbegbe ti won ti lenu.

en: The clashes ended with a ransacked office of the URF and the arrest of six people whose identity and party affiliation remain yet unknown to the public.
yo: Ikolu naa wa si opin leyin-in ikolo ileese URF naa ti awon eniyan mefa ti ko si eni to mo oruko ati egbe oloselu ti won n ba se di ero atimole.

en: #SexForGrades: A new documentary exposes sexual harassment at West African universities
yo: #SexForGrades: Eto Alalaye-aferihan tu asiiri iwa iyolenu ibalopo ni awon Ifasitii Iwo-oorun Ile-Adulawo

en: Victims fear a backlash and are often unwilling to talk
yo: Itiju mu awon ti isele sele si maa lee so

en: This masked victim was repeatedly sexually abused by Boniface Igbeneghu, a professor in University of Lagos, Nigeria (Screenshot from BBC #SexForGrades video)
yo: Boniface Igbeneghu, ojogbon Ifasitii Eko, Naijiria ti ba eni ti o wo iboju yii se eree gele ni aimoye igba (Aworan lati BBC #SexForGrades)

en: #SexForGrades, a BBC documentary on sexual harassment of female students by university professors in Nigeria and Ghana, has ignited heated online conversation and raises many questions about how to put an end to it:
yo: #SexForGrades, eto alalaye aferihan-an BBC kan ti o da firigbagboo lorii asemase ere ife ti awon ojogbon ifasiti pelu awon akekoobirin ni Naijiria ati Ghana ti ran bii papa inu oye ni ori ayelujara ti o si ti fa awon ibeere olokanojokan nipa ona ti a lee gba dekun asemase ohun lawujo:

en: The groundbreaking investigation, released on October 7, 2019, was anchored by journalist Kiki Mordi, who was forced to abandon her own university degree because she refused to yield to the sexual advances by a university teacher who kept failing her:
yo: Agba ise iwadii naa, ti o di gbigbe jade ni ojo keje osu Owara 2019, ti akoroyin Kiki Mordi ti ko pari ekoo re latarii wipe ko fe se asemase pelu olukoni ifasiti re ti o n fi idii re remi ninu idanwo nitori wipe ko fun un se se atokun-un re:

en: Boniface Igbeneghu, University of Lagos, is caught sexually harassing female students in an undercover investigation by the BBC.
yo: Boniface Igbeneghu, Ifasiti Eko, ti a ka iwa asemase pelu awon akekoobirin ninu iwadii abele ti BBC se.

en: Screenshot from BBC #SexForGrades video.
yo: Aworan lati BBC #SexForGrades.

en: "The nearly one-year investigation revealed the scandal of ""sex for grades"" crises at two West African universities: Nigeria's University of Lagos (UNILAG) and the University of Ghana."
yo: "Iwadii ti o pe wakati kan tu asiiri iwa asemase ti ""ere ife fun oju-ami eko"" ni ifasiti Iwo-oorun Ile Adulawo meji: University of Lagos (UNILAG) ti Naijiria ati University of Ghana."

en: Nigeria's Boniface Igbeneghu, a professor in UNILAG'S faculty of art and an evangelical pastor of local Foursquare Gospel Church, Lagos, was one of the teachers busted by the investigation.
yo: Boniface Igbeneghu, ti i se kofeso ni eka ise ona ti UNILAG, ti o si tun je alufaa Ijo Foursquare Gospel, ni Eko, n be ninu awon oluko ti okete boru mo lowo.

en: Igbenegbu is seen in the BBC video sexually propositioning an undercover BBC reporter who pretended to be a 17-year-old seeking university admission. Igbenegu can be heard saying:
yo: A ri Igbeneghu ninuu etoo BBC naa ti o ko enu ife si omodebinrin ti o dibon gege bi omo olojo ori metadinlogun ti o n wa igbanisile eko lai fura wipe ajabo iroyin ti o n se ise iwadii abele fun BBC ni o n se. Igbeneghu so bayii wipe:

en: Don't you know you are a beautiful girl?
yo: Se o ko mo wipe omobinrin arewa ni o ?

en: Do you know I am a pastor and I am in my 50's but if I want a girl of 17 years, all I need is a sweet tongue and put some money...
yo: Nje o mo wipe alufaa ijo elesin igbagbo ni mo je, ati pe mo to eni aadota odun sugbon bi mo ba fe omo odun metadinlogun oro didun ati owo ni o maa je...

en: In a final meeting between the pair, Igbenegbu switched off the lights, asked her for a kiss and went ahead to hug her in his locked office.
yo: Nibi ipade kan laaarin awon mejeeji, Igbeneghu se ina pa, o si ni ki omodebinrin naa o fenu ko ohun lenu, ti o si tun di mo on gbadigbadi ninuu iyaraa isee re ti o wa ni titi pa.

en: "Foursquare Gospel Church has suspended Igbeneghu ""from all ministerial assignments."""
yo: "Ijo Ajihinrere Foursquare ti da Igbeneghu duro ""lenu ise ihin rere."""

en: "Similarly, the University of Lagos has barred Igbeneghu from the school and also ordered the shutdown of the staff club's ""cold room,"" used by senior staff to hold parties attended by young female students and staff."
yo: "Bakan naa, Ifasiti Eko ti le Igbeneghu kuro ni ile iwe won si ti sun ipere si ehin ilekun ile osise ti won n pe ni ""yara tutu,"" ti awon oga olukoni ti maa n se ariya nibi ti won ti maa n gba awon osoro omoge lalejo."

en: Recounting the trauma of years past
yo: Awon isele ibanuje odun seyin

en: This expose ignited reactions of cataclysmic proportions from Nigerians online with the trending hashtag #SexForGrades on Twitter.
yo: Akara ti o tu sepo yii ti fi gongo fa komookun oro jade lenu ogoro omo orile-edee Naijiria ni ori ayelujara pelu amii #SexForGrades ni orii Twitter.

en: Many female Twitter users recount their own experiences of sexual harassment:
yo: Pupo ninu awon onlo ti o je abo ni orii Twitter fi edun okan-an won han nipa iririi won lorii iwa eree gele ti ibalopo:

en: "Lola Shoneyin, book festival curator and author, recounted the ""terrible shame"" she felt after she was touched inappropriately by a university Deputy Vice-Chancellor (DVC):"
yo: "Lola Soneyin, alatinudaa ajodun iwe ati onkowe, salaye ""itiju nla"" ti ohun ri nigba ti amugbalegbee oga patapata ifasiti kan (DVC) fowo kan ibi ti ko ye ki o fowo kan lara oun:"

en: Philandering university professors have for decades debased female students in Nigerian tertiary institutions.
yo: Awon ojogbon onisina ile eko giga Naijiria ti ba ti awon obinrin je.

en: However, it is usually difficult to prosecute perpetrators because victims are afraid of the backlash and unwilling to talk due to deep trauma associated with these abuses.
yo: Sibesibe, nitori itiju awon ti o fi ara pa ki i lee soro sita eyi ko si je ki o rorun lati da seria fun awon awuwa ibaje.

en: "In 2016, the ""Sexual Harassment in Tertiary Education Institution Prohibition Bill,"" passed by the Nigerian Senate prescribed a 5-year jail term for lecturers and educators convicted of sexually harassing students."
yo: "Ni odun-un 2016, Igbimo Asofin mu aba ewon odun marun-un wa fun olukoni ti ile ejo ba da lebi asemase pelu akekoo ninu ""Iwe abadofin Ifopin si iwa ibaje ibalopo ni Ile Iwe Giga."""

en: However, the Academic Staff Union of Nigerian Universities opposed the bill, claiming that it was discriminatory since it targeted teachers and that it undermined university autonomy.
yo: Sibe, Ajo Olukoni Ifasitii Naijiria ko eyin si iwe aba yii, won ni o ko iyan awon kere, nitori o koju ija si awon oluko ati wipe o yepere ase ati agbara ile eko giga.

en: The opposition to the bill may have led to the death of that legislation - which did not get presidential assent.
yo: Isotasi iwe aba naa pa ofin naa ni apaku fininfinfin - eyi ko si je ki aare o bu owo lu u.

en: Is #SexForGrades another #ChurchToo movement?
yo: Se Ere ife fun oju-ami Eko #SexForGrades ni ijijangbara ile ijosin #ChurchToo tuntun?

en: In July this year, Nigeria's celebrity photographer, Busola Dakolo, accused Biodun Fatoyinbo, the lead pastor of Commonwealth of Zion Assembly (COZA), of forcefully raping her when she was 16.
yo: Ninu osu keje odun yii, gbajugbaja ayaworan-an ni, Busola Dakolo, fi esun kan Biodun Fatoyinbo, alufaa agba ijo Commonwealth of Zion Assembly (COZA), wipe o fi ipa ba oun ni ajosepo nigba ti ohun wa ni omo odun merindinlogun.

en: Read more: Pastor or predator?
yo: Ka siwaju si i: Alufaa tabi apanije bi epa?

en: Nigerian Evangelical preacher embroiled in rape accusations
yo: Ajihinrere Oniwaasu ninuu wahala esun ifipabanilopo

en: Over the past six years, the flamboyant Fatoyinbo has been plagued by allegations of rape and sexual abuse.
yo: Fun odun mefa ti o re koja lo, Fatoyinbo arodede ti ri ifesunkan ifipabanilopo okan-o-jokan.

en: However, the emotional interview during which Dakolo accused Fatoyinbo ignited a national reaction online.
yo: Sibe, iforowanilenuwo ti Dakolo ti fesun kan Fatoyinbo da awuyewuye sile lori ayelukara bi ajere.

en: For days, #ChurchToo - a national iteration of the global #MeToo movement - trended on social media in Nigeria.
yo: Fun ojo die, ile ijosin naa; #ChurchToo - ti i se apeere emi naa ni agbaye #MeToo - gba ayelujara kan ni Naijiria.

en: This agitation soon morphed from online to street protests in major Nigerian cities like Lagos and Abuja.
yo: Esun yii fo fere lati ori ayelujara si ifehonuhan lorii opopona ni awon ilu nla ni Naijiria bii Eko ati Abuja.

en: "The #ChurchToo movement called on the government to take ""the issue of violence against women and girls seriously."""
yo: "Ipesi akiyesi ile ijosin naa #ChurchToo movement ro ijoba lati da ""oran-an ijiya obinrin ati omodebinrin duro."""

en: "The #ChurchToo revealed the silent but ""horrific thriving rape culture, especially within religious circles"" in Nigeria."
yo: "Ile ijosin naa #ChurchToo sipaya idake roro amo ""ibaje asa ifipabanilopo ti o n gberu, paapaa ju lo ni agbo ijosin"" ni Naijiria."

en: It provided an opportunity for women to speak out.
yo: O fun awon obinrin ni anfaani lati wi ti enu won.

en: Like the #ChurchToo movement, the #SexForGrades outcry has again revealed the realities of sexual violence against women and the abuse of power that allows this sexual violence to thrive.
yo: Bii ti #ChurchToo, ike tantan ere ife fun oju-ami eko #SexForGrades ti fe idi ilokulo agbara ti o bi iwa asemase ti ibanilajosepo ti awon obinrin ko fi tokantokan fe sita gbangba.

en: Will this hashtag lead to an offline advocacy movement that pushes for reforms to ensure that universities are safe places for women?
yo: Nje ami ori ayelujara yii yoo se amonaa igbeja eto ti ki i se ti ori ayelujara ti yoo beere fun atunse ti yoo so ile eko giga ifasiti di ibi aabo fun awon obinrin bi?

en: Time will tell.
yo: Igba ati akoko nikan ni yoo so.

en: Zanzibar's one and only music academy on the brink of closure
yo: Ile eko imo orin kiko kan soso ni Zanzibar ti fe di titi pa

en: Dhow Countries Music Academy promotes Swahili culture through music
yo: Ile-eko Orin Kiko Awon Orile-ede Dhow f'orin segbelaruge asaa Swahili

en: Students from the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA) rehearse the qanun, flute, drum and piano at the Old Customs House, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
yo: Awon akekoo lati Ileewe Orin kiko Awon Orile-edee Dhow (DCMA) n fi qanun, fere, ilu ati duru ni Ile Awon Eso Asobode Atijo, ni Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA lo ni aworan.

en: "Thousands of visitors to the historic city of Stone Town, Zanzibar, have followed the sound of music to the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that promotes and preserves the islands"" musical traditions of the Swahili Coast along the Indian Ocean."
yo: Egbeegberun alejo ti o n ro witiwiti wa si ilu Stone Town, Zanzibar ti o kun fun isele ateyinwa, ti tele iro orin Ileewe Orin kiko Awon Orile-edee Dhow (DCMA), ile eko orin kiko ti o n se igbelaruge ati ipamo awon asa orin erekusu naa ti o sun mo Swahili ni ebaa Omi Okun India.

en: Since 2002, the school has promoted and preserved the Zanzibar's unique mix of Arab, Indian and African cultures through music.
yo: Lati odun-un 2002, ile eko naa ti se igbelaruge ati ipamo akojopo orin Larubawa, India ati Ile Adulawo ti ko lelegbe.

en: After 17 years, the school faces a financial crisis that threatens its closure.
yo: Leyin-in odun ketadinlogun, ileewe naa ko ri owo ti o towo ninu apo ikowo si ti o si lee fa ki ileewe naa o di titi pa.

en: Nearly 70% of its 80 full-time students can't afford to pay their tuition, which comes to about $13 USD per month, according to an official DCMA press release.
yo: Ninu iwe igberoyinjade ti awon alase DCMA te jade, ida aadorin ninu awon ogorin akekoo ni ko ri owo ileewe won ti o to bii $13 USD losu san.

en: While the school has received support over the years from international donors and diplomatic missions, they face a gap in funding that may force them to shut their doors at the historic Old Customs House.
yo: Pelu atileyin awon oninuure ti o ti dawo fun ileewe naa, owo ti o ku ni sisan si po to bee ti o fi je wipe, o se e se ki ilekun-un ileewe naa ti o wa ninu Ile Awon Eso Asobode Atijo.

en: Without crucial funds to continue, DCMA students and staff fear that the soulful sounds that flow through the hallways of this iconic institution that make these islands sing - may cease.
yo: Laisi owo ti o towo nile lati tesiwaju, awon akekoo DCMA ati osise n foya ki iro amokanbale ti o n sun jade lati inuu gbongan olokiki ile eko yii ti o mu erekusu yii korin - lee wo okunkun.

en: The school not only teaches and promotes traditional culture and heritage through music, but it's also home to a community of young musicians who seek alternatives to making a living as creatives.
yo: Orin ati igbelaruge asa ati ajogunba nikan ko ni ile eko naa fi gbajumo, amo o je ile fun awon odo ti o n wa ibi ti won yoo ti fi imo kun imo.

en: A DCMA student learns the qanun, a featured instrument in classical taarab songs. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
yo: Akekoo DCMA kan n ko qanun, ohun elo orin ayedaade orin taarab. Aworan lati ileewe DCMA.

en: """We [have started] to face a very challenging financial moment,"" said Alessia Lombardo, managing director of the DCMA, in an official DCMA video."
yo: """A [ti bere] si i ni ri idojuko igba ti o nira,"" alakooso agbaa DCMA, Alessia Lombardo so, ninuu aworan fidio DCMA kan."

en: """From now to the next six months, we are not sure that we can guarantee the salaries to our teachers and staff."""
yo: "Lati isinsinyi lo titi di osu mefa si asiko yii, a ko ri aridaju ti o rinle wipe a o lee san owo osu awon olukoni ati osisee."""

en: At the moment, 19 master teachers and small core staff have gone without salaries for over three months as the school struggles to secure strong funding partnerships and explore sustainable funding models for a school.
yo: Ni akoko ti a wa yii, awon akawe-gboye oluko 19 ati awon osise miiran ti sise fun osu meta gbako lai gba owo lo sile nitori aisi owo ninuu kolo ileewe.

en: While the archipelago is known as a tourist destination for its pristine beaches and luxury hotels, the majority of local people struggle with high unemployment even as poverty has slightly decreased, according to The World Bank.
yo: Gege bi Ile Ifowopamo Agbaye se ti salaye wipe, pelu bi a ti se mo agbegbe ti ileewe naa wa fun ibi irin-ajo igbafe nitori awon etikun atijo ati ile itura olowo nlanla ti o kangun sibe, ogoro awon omo ibile lo n ba ainise lowo po o paapaa bi ise se ti gbe fuke ju ti igba kan lo.

en: For 17 years, the DCMA has worked tirelessly to promote and protect Zanzibar's rich heritage and traditions through music.
yo: Fun odun metadinlogun, DCMA ti sise asekudorogbo nipa lilo orin se igbelaruge toun ipamo oro ajogunba ati asa Zanzibar.

en: The birthplace of legendary taarab singers Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, or Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is home to musical genres that emerged through cultural exchange and collaboration along the Swahili Coast for hundreds of years.
yo: Orirun awon olohun-iyo akorin taarab, Siti Binti Saad ati Fatuma Binti Baraka, ti a tun mo si Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar ni ile eyi-o-joyii orin ti o ti inuu ibasepapo asa ati ajose olodun gbogboro ti o wa laaarin awon adugbo eka Swahili.

en: Today, students can learn traditional musical genres like taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, along with instruments like drums, qanun and oud, as gatekeepers - and interpreters - of culture and tradition.
yo: Laye ode oni, akekoo lee ko orin ibile bii taarab, ngoma ati kidumbak, pelu afikun awon ohun elo ikorin bii ilu ni onirananran, qanun ati oud, gege bi alapamo - ati ongbifo - asa ati ise.

en: Neema Surri, a violin player at the DCMA, has been studying the violin since the age of 9.
yo: Neema Surri, a ta violin ni DCMA, ti n ko bi a ti se n ta ohun eloo violin lati omodun mesan-an menu le oro ninu aworan fidio DCMA naa.

en: """I know many young people who would like to study music but they can't afford the minimal tuition fee because they are poor and unemployed,"" Surri said in the DCMA video."
yo: """Mo mo awon odomode ti o maa nifee si kiko orin sugbon won ko lee san owo imeko ti o je owo ileewe nitori wipe won kusee won ko si ni ise lowo ."""

en: Students at the DCMA rehearse at the Old Customs House, where the school is based, in Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
yo: Awon akekooo DCMA n fi ohun elo ikorin olokun tin-in-rin korin ninu Ile Awon Eso Asobode Atijo, nibiti iileewe naa fi ikale si, ni Stone Town, Zanzibar, lodun-un 2019. Aworan je ti ileewee DCMA.

en: After completing DCMA workshops, certificate and diploma courses, many DCMA students go on to perform on world stages as award-winning bands and solo artists.
yo: Ni ipari awon idanilekooo DCMA, ti won ti gba iwe eri ati ni opin eko olodun kan, pupo ninu awon akekooo DCMA ni o ti di agba oje ti won si i sere lori itage kari aye.

en: "Zanzibar's Amina Omar Juma, a former DCMA student and current DCMA teacher, recently returned from a tour in South Africa with her critically acclaimed, ""Siti and the Band,"" known for ""fusing the roots"" by blending traditional taarab sounds with contemporary, layered rhythms."
yo: "Omo bibii Zanzibar, ti o je akekooo DCMA nigba kan ri, ti o je olukoni ni ileewe kan naa bayii, Amina Omar Juma toun ti ilu mooka egbe akorin re, ti o n ""fi asa iro orin ibile "" taarab papo mo ti igbalodelonigbanlo korin, iyen ""Siti ati Egbe ,"" sese pada wolu lati irinajo orin kiko kan ni orile-edee South Africa."

en: "She and other band members, also former DCMA students, released their first full album, ""Fusing the Roots,"" in 2018, going on to perform at Sauti za Busara, East Africa's largest music festival, that same year."
yo: "Oun, awon die ninu egbe akorin re ati apapo awon akekoo DCMA ni igba kan ri se agbejade awo orin won akoko, ""Fusing the Roots,"" ni odun-un 2018, ti o mu won oi ng o onworan lara ya ni Sauti za Busara, ti i se ajodun orin kiko ti o gbarada ju lo ni Ila-oorun Ile Adulawo."

en: "Here's Siti and the Band's ""Nielewe"" (""Understand Me"") and music video, depicting scenes from Zanzibar while telling the story of a woman who experiences domestic abuse and dreams of life in music, much like Omar Juma's personal story:"
yo: "Hihayin ni orin Siti ati Egbe ""Nielewe"" (""Gbo mi yeke"") ati aworan orin naa, ti o se afihan-an aworan-an, ti o so itan obinrin kan ti o n ri idojuko abe-ile, ti o si n daro ara re. Itan naa jo ti Omar Juma funra re:"

en: Read more: East African women in the music industry sing out against male domination
yo: Ka siwaju si i: Awon akorin lobinrin Ila-Oorun Ile Adulawo korin tako aifaaye gba obinrin awon okunrin.

en: A history of cultural crossroads and collaboration
yo: Itan nipa ayalo asa ati ajosepo

en: Over 15,000 visitors have passed through the academy's iconic building to enjoy live performances, workshops and classes and interact with passionate DCMA musicians who represent the future of Zanzibar culture and heritage, according to the DCMA.
yo: O to egberun meeedogun alejo ni o ti wo ere, gba idanilekoo ati ba awon akorin lorisiirisi ojo ola ni ileewe olokiki naa ni gbolohun ri.

en: "Drawing from a complex history of Indian, Arab and African exchange, the school celebrates the influence of ""dhow countries,"" with inspiration from cultures that converged along the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf."
yo: "Ileewe naa ti se ayalo ati amupapo okan-o-jokan asa ""awon orile-ede dhow,"" ti o wa ni itosii Okun India ati Ogbun-un Persia."

en: "The Omani Sultanate, a ""major maritime force from the 17th to 19th centuries,"" shifted its seat of power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840."
yo: "Agbegbee Omani Sultanate, ti o je "" ibi gboogi awon alagbara atuko ori omi ni ogorun-un Odun-un ketadinlogun si kokandinlogun seyin,"" gbe aga agbara re lati Muscat si Zanzibar ni odun-un 1840."

en: From Stone Town, Omani kings oversaw elaborate systems of maritime trade, including cloves, gold, and textiles, powered by strong winds that set dhows - traditional Arab vessels - sailing across the Indian Ocean, from India to Oman to East Africa.
yo: Lati Stone Town, awon oba Omani n tukoo okowo ori omi igba naa ti o feju, titi kan kanafuru, wura, ati aso , latari awon iji lile ti n tu awon oko ibilee Larubawaa - dhows - ni orii Okun Indian, lati India si Oman titi lo de Ila-Oorun Ile Adulawo.

en: Young Zanzibaris recognize the importance of connecting with the past to determine their future and the music created today expresses that desire to bridge the old with the new.
yo: Awon odo ni Zanzibar mo ririi isele ateyinwa ti o ni ohun nla ni i se fun ojo ola won, ni won fi n se adalu eyi ti a ri ninu awon orin ode oni ti won n gbe jade.

en: "DCMA students and teachers recently formed ""TaraJazz,"" a blend of traditional taarab and modern jazz."
yo: "Awon akekoo ati olukoni DCMA se idasilee ""TaraJazz"" lai pe yii, eyi ti o je adalu orin ibile taarab ati orin Jazz ode oni."

en: Their violinist, Felician Mussa, 20, has only been studying the violin for 3.5 years; TaraJazz is one of the most sought-after bands on the islands, captured here by photographer Aline Coquelle:
yo: Ata violin, Felician Mussa, omo ogun odun, ti n ko ohun elo ikorin olokun tin-in-rin naa fun odun meta ataabo; TaraJazz je okan ninu awon egbe akorin ti o awon eniyan maa n pe si ode ju lo ni awon erekusu naa, ni o wa ninu aworan ti ayaworan ti Aline Coquelle ya:

en: The Swahili coast tells the story of epic cultural exchanges and the DCMA continues this tradition through its musical collaborations.
yo: Agbegbee Swahili so itan pasipaaro asa ibile ti DCMA si n tesiwaju ninuu re pelu ajosepo awon orin-in re .

en: "Every year, the school hosts an initiative called ""Swahili Encounters,"" matching well-known musicians hailing from Africa, the Middle East, Europe and North America with DCMA students to create original musical compositions within a week-long period."
yo: "Lodoodun, ileewe naa maa n gbalejo fun eto ti a pe ni ""Ikolu Swahili,"" ti o mu agbarijopoo agba akorin lati Ile-Adulawo, Ilu Abe-akoso Larubawa, Ile Eroopu ati Ariwa Amerika pelu awon akekoo DCMA lati se orin laaarin ose kan."

en: "At the end of the ""encounter,"" the newly-formed collaboration performs at Sauti za Busara, and many of these collaborations turn into life-time friendships that transcend the boundaries of language and culture, proving music is a universal language."
yo: "Ni igbeyingbeyin ""ikolu"" naa, agbarijopo tuntun naa yoo ta bi elegbe ni Sauti za Busara, ti ajosepo wonyi yoo si di ibasepo olojo pipe ti ko mo iyato ede ati asa, ti o fi han gbangba walia wipe ede kan naa ti gbogbo aye gbo ni orin."

en: "DCMA offers weekly live performances showcasing students"" talents and collaborations with visiting musicians, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of DCMA."
yo: DCMA maa n se agbekale eto orin kiko ti o n se igbelaruge ebun orin kiko awon akekoo ati afihan ajosepo pelu okorin alejo han ni, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA ni o ni aworan.

en: The DCMA recognizes that music empowers and unites people across cultures - and it also employs talented youth living in a struggling economy with limited job opportunities.
yo: DCMA mo riri orin gege bi ohun ti o lee ro awon eniyan lagbara ati gege bi ohun ti o le mu isokan ati irepo ba awon eniyan lai wo ti asa - o si tun n pese anfaani ise fun awon odo ti o ni ebun amo ti o n tiraka lati je.

en: For the 1,800 students who have trained at the DCMA, this is the only musical home they know, where they can learn and grow as professional musicians and artists.
yo: Fun awon akekoo 1,800 ti o ti gba idanilekoo ni DCMA, eyi nikan ni ibi ile orin ti won mo, nibi ti won ti n ko eko ti won si ti n ni alekun imo nipa ise orin kiko ati bi a se n di onkorin.

en: "One traveler from Spain, who recently visited the DCMA, wrote on TripAdvisor: ""Personally, meeting the musicians was the best piece of my time on this island."""
yo: "Arinrin-ajo kan lati Spain, to be DCMA wo ni ko pe yii, ko si orii TripAdvisor: ""Ni temi, isalabaapadee awon akorin ni igba ti o meet ju lo fun mi ni erekusu yii."""

en: As Zanzibar's tourism sector rapidly grows, the DCMA believes that music plays an essential role in the celebration, preservation and promotion of Swahili culture, heritage and history.
yo: Bi eka irin-ajo afee Zanzibar se n gbero si i, DCMA nigbagbo wipe orin ni ipa kan gboogi ni i se ninu ajoyo, ipamo ati igbelaruge toun ipolongo asa, ajogunba ati isele ateyinwaa Swahili.

en: Zanzibar is far more than its beaches and luxury hotels - it's a place bursting with talent that stems from an extraordinary history of cultural connection and collaboration.
yo: Zanzibar ju awon etikun ati ile itura olowo iyebiye re lo - o je ibi ti o kun fun awon eniyan olopolo ti o ni ebun ni poolo ori won latari ajosepo olojo pipe ti o mu agbegbe naa da yato gedegbe.

en: Editor's note: The author of this post has volunteered with DCMA.
yo: Ifiyesi Alakooso Iwe Tite: Onkowe atejade yii ti sise ofe pelu DCMA.

en: Witch-hunting still claims lives in rural India
yo: Isode-aje si n gba emi awon eniyan ni igberiko India

en: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
yo: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India

en: A village near Jamshedpur in Jharkhand. Picture courtesy Anumeha Verma
yo: Ileto kan ni ebaa Jamshedpur ni Jharkhand. Aworan lati owoo Anumeha Verma

en: On 20 July, four elderly people were lynched by a mob in the Gumla District of Jharkhand, India after being accused of practicing witchcraft.
yo: Ni ojo 20 osu Agemo, agbajo awon eniyankeenia gba emi awon agbalagba merin kan lai da won lejo ni agbegbee Gumla ni Jharkhand, India leyin ti a fi esun-un aje kan won.

en: According to reports, the victims were accused of causing a man's death and they were eventually found guilty of witchcraft by a Panchayat (a village assembly).
yo: Gege bi ijabo iroyin, awon agbalagba wonyi se iku pa okunrin kan, ni igbimo abulee Panchayat se da won lebi.

en: The victims were dragged out of their homes and beaten to death by masked men wielding sticks.
yo: Won wo awon agbalagba merin wonyi jade sita ilee won, awon okunrin ti o boju si fi igi lu won titi ti emi fi bo lara won.

en: Eight of the attackers were subsequently arrested by police.
yo: Mejo ninu awon eniyankeenia wonyi ti wa ni akolo olopaa.

en: According to police data published by The Times of India, witch-hunting in Jharkhand has claimed 123 lives from May 2016 to May 2019.
yo: Gege bi akosile olopaa ti Times of India tejade, isode-aje ni Jharkhand ti ran awon eniyan 123 sorun apapandodo ni aarin-in osu Ebibi odun-un 2016 si osu Ebibi odun-un 2019.

en: "Across the country, 134 people were killed for the alleged use of ""black magic"" in 2016, according to the National Crime Records Bureau."
yo: "Jakejado, eniyan 134 di eni ebora-n-ba-jeun latari esun-un lilo ""ogungun"" ni odun-un 2016, iyen gege bi Ajo Asakosile Ese Orile-ede naa se ko o sile."

en: A Perpetual Malady
yo: "Arun T""o N Peleke Si i"

en: """Witch-hunting is not new in Jharkhand,"" says Prem Chand, the Founding Chairman of the Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand, in a telephonic interview."
yo: """Isode-aje ko je tuntun ni Jharkhand,"" Prem Chand, Oludasile ati Alaga Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) ni Jharkhand, so ninuu iforowanilenuwo ori ero-ibanisoro kan."

en: FLAC has been instrumental in bringing about legislation against witch-hunting in Jharkhand.
yo: FLAC ti n se atonaa isofin ti o tako isode-aje ni Jharkhand.

en: The organisation first began working in this area in 1991 when a woman was accused by her neighbour of causing a boy's death.
yo: Ileese naa bere ise ni agbegbe yii ni odun-un 1991 nigba ti awon aladuugbo fi esun kan obinrin kan pe o lowo ninu iku omodekunrin kan.

en: An irate mob attacked her and killed her husband and son.
yo: Agbajo awon eniyankeenia kan digbo lu u, won si pa oko ati omo re okunrin.

en: She sustained injuries.
yo: Oun fi ara pa.

en: When Prem Chand and his colleagues visited the offenders in the prison, they were met with defiance:
yo: Nigbati Prem Chand ati awon elegbee re se ibewo si awon elese wonyi ninuu tubu, won ba ipenija:

en: They told us that they stood by their accusation.
yo: Won so fun won wipe awon duro le orii esun ti won fi kan awon.

en: They also shared a belief that when the blood of a woman branded as a witch falls on the ground, she loses her so-called powers of sorcery.
yo: Won si tun gbagbo wipe bi ejee eni ti a pe ni aje ba kan ile ogere, yoo padanu agbara eleye re.

en: Prem Chand says that it affects specific sectors of the population:
yo: Prem Chand so wipe o kan apa kan ninu awon omo ilu:

en: Usually, it is the women from the weaker sections of the society and economically backward regions that are targeted.
yo: Nigbagbogbo, awon obinrin ti ko lara ti o talaka ni i maa n fi ara kaasa.

en: The victims are mostly Adivasis, Harijans and Dalits.
yo: Awon ti o f'ara kaasa wonyi ni awon Adivasis, Harijans ati Dalits.

en: It is an assault on the dignity of women and a violation of constitutional rights for a dignified life for every human being.
yo: Ifoju iyi awon obinrin ati itase agere si ofin eto si aye iyi fun gbogbo omo eniyan.

en: The Social and Political Realities
yo: Otito Awujo ati Iselu

en: Activists say that deeply rooted superstitions prevalent in the hinterlands are a major cause behind the practice.
yo: Awon ajijangbara so wipe igbagbo-asan ti o rinle ni igberiko ni o n fa iwa palapala naa.

en: A lack of education, poor health facilities and economic backwardness mark the regions where these practices are prevalent.
yo: "Aigbeko, eto ilera ti o poju osuwon ati kolakosagbe ti o n gb""agbegbe ti iwa palapala wonyi ti gbale bi i itakun ni o fi wopo."

en: The cases so far show that often a rumor started by someone is enough to get the ball rolling.
yo: Oran wonyi ti fi han wipe aheso ni o maa fi n bere .

en: Despite the laws enacted by various Indian states which declare witch-hunting to be illegal, participants in these cases see it as a form of self-defense.
yo: Pelu ofin awon ipinle India ti o ka isode-aje si ohun ti o lodi sofin, awon akopa oran wonyi ri i gege bi ona idaaabo-ara-eni.

en: It is also used as an excuse for grabbing resources owned by women, exacting revenge or even exploiting women for sex.
yo: Bakan naa ni won n wi awawi fun gbigba ohun ini awon obinrin, fi agbara gbesan tabi fi ipa ba obinrin lo po.

en: According to Prem Chand:
yo: Gege bi Prem Chand se ti so:

en: The premise is that once you brand a woman as a witch, you can subject her to any treatment.
yo: Ateterotele ni wipe ni kete ti o ba ti pe obinrin ni aje, o le terii re ba fun ilokulo.

en: However, it is important to note that the practice is used as a justification for exploitation and is not a cause behind it per se.
yo: Sibesibe, o se koko lati mo wipe won maa n lo iwa palapala yii fi gba tara awon obinrin, ko si kii se idi ti o n fa a pato.

en: Ironically, the panchayat often provides tacit approval for branding a person a witch even if does not pass ruling on the punishment to be meted out.
yo: Ni ti efe, lai wi to, panchayat naa saba maa n lowo si ipeniyan ni aje paapaa bi ko ba pase ijiya t'o to.

en: In addition to the elected panchayat, there are self-styled caste panchayats with no legal mandate whatsoever that operate in certain parts of the country.
yo: Ni afikun si panchayat ti ibo yan, awon kan nbe ti won pe ara won ni panchayat ipo-isale lai ni ase kankan ti o fun won lagbara nibikibi ni orile-ede.

en: These bodies pass verdicts and mete out punishments and remain largely unchallenged.
yo: Awon egbe yii maa n dajo ati fi iya je eniyan ti ko si si eni ti o ka won lapa ko.

en: An incident in Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported involvement of caste panchayat leading to the death of a 40-year-old woman.
yo: "Isele kan ni agbegbee Ajmer ni Rajasthan lodun-un 2017 jabo ilowosi panchayat ipo-isale ti o s""okunfa iku obinrin ogoji odun kan."

en: Legally, the courts can take action against such verdicts in case of both elected panchayats and caste panchayats.
yo: Gege bi ofin, ile ejo le gbe igbese ti o tako iruu idajo bawonyi yala lati odo awon panchayat ti ibo yan ati panchayat ipo-isale.

en: However, the victims seldom get the opportunity to reach a court of law before they become targets of mobs.
yo: Sibesibe, awon ti o fara kaasa o tile ni anfaani si ile-ejo ofin ki agbajo-awon-eniyankeenia o to kojuu won.

en: Witch-hunting across India
yo: Isode-aje jakejado India

en: Jharkhand has recorded the highest number of crimes committed in the name of witch-hunting but it is not the only state.
yo: Jharkhand ti se akosile iye ese awon eniyan se ti o po ju lo ti o tan mo isode-aje amo ki i se ipinle naa nikan.

en: Cases of witch-hunting have been reported from Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra and Rajasthan too.
yo: "Oran-an isode-aje ti wa l""akosile ni Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra ati Rajasthan pelu."

en: In a chilling incident in 2014, Debjani Bora, an Indian athlete had become a target in Assam.
yo: Nigba isele kan ni 2014, Debjani Bora, elese ehoro omo bibii orile-edee India ti fi ara kaasa ri.

en: According to Debjani's statements, she was accused of being the cause of several deaths in Cherekali village located 180 km from Guwahati, the capital of the eastern state in India.
yo: "Gege bi oroo Debjani, a f""esun-un igbemi eniyan pupo kan an ni abulee Cherekali ti o wa ni kilomita 180 lati Guwahati, olu-iluu India ti apaa ila-oorun."

en: She was allegedly named by a headman of a village prayer hall and brutally assaulted by the villagers.
yo: "Olorii gbogan adura abule l""o daruko re ti awon ara abule si fi iya je e."

en: 2017 witnessed several cases in the state of Rajasthan.
yo: Isele 2017 ni ipinle Rajasthan.

en: Among these, a 40-year-old woman Kanya Devi was attacked and beaten to death after being accused by her family members in Ajmer district of the state.
yo: Lara eyi ni, omobinrin ogoji odun kan Kanya Devi ri ikolu ti a si lu u pa leyin ti molebii re fi esun kan an ni agbegbee Ajmer.

en: Victims and Survivors
yo: Awon Eni-to-fara-kaasa ati Eni-tori-ko-yo

en: People blame accused witches for causing a slew of misfortunes: the death of a person or animal, droughts, crop failures, etc.
yo: "Awon eniyan n f""esun kan awon eleye fun ise-ibi owoo won: iku eniyan tabi eranko, oda ojo, aiso jingbinni irugbin, ati beebee lo."

en: The attacks on these women (and some men) are vicious and inhuman.
yo: Ikolu ti o ko lu awon obinrin wonyi (ati awon okunrin kan) roro bi eranko ehanna.

en: At times, the accusations and punishment are meted out by their families.
yo: Nigba miiran, awon esun naa ati ijiya ese maa wa lati odo molebii won.

en: Some have lived to tell the tale and fight. Chutni Mahato of Saraikela in Jharkhand is one of them.
yo: Awon kan n gbe ti won si n so itan-an won ti won si n ja fun etoo won.

en: "People from the region call her a ""tigress."""
yo: Chutni Mahato ti Saraikela ni Jharkhand je okan lara won.

en: She was accused of practicing witchcraft in 1995.
yo: "Awon eniyan lati agbegbe naa maa n pe e ni ""tigress."""

en: Since then, she has transformed into an activist crusading against the victimization of women in the name of witch-hunting with the help of NGOs working to end the practice.
yo: Won fi esun-un aje kan-an ni odun-un 1995. Lati igba naa, o ti yirapada di ajijangbara olutako ifiyaje awon obinrin pelu atileyin Ile-ise-ti-kii-se-tijoba.

en: Chutni expresses how the lack of resources often makes it a struggle to fight against the practice.
yo: Chutni so bi aisi atileyin to kesejari se mu u nira lati ja tako iwa palapala yii.

en: I wish there was more support from the authorities and government for the work that we are doing here.
yo: Ibajepe atileyin to to wa lati owo awon oniseoba ati ijoba fun ise ti a n se nibi.

en: However, I have suffered because of this practice.
yo: Sibesibe, mo ti jiya nitori iwa palapala yii.

en: When someone comes to me for help, I am always going to stand by them, she said in a telephonic interview.
yo: Bi eniyan ba to mi wa fun iranlowo, mo maa duro ti won gbagbagba, o so ninuu iforowanilenuwo ori ero-ibanisoro kan.

en: Formulating Public Opinion
yo: Dida Ohun Gbogboogbo Si i

en: Both the survivors and activists feel that there is a lack of public opinion in support of ending witch-hunting.
yo: Awon eni-tori-ko-yo ati ajafetoo-eniyan ro wipe awon eniyan gbogbo ko ti ifopin si isode-aje leyin.

en: The activists who were interviewed for this story expressed a paucity of political will and intellectual engagement to provide the momentum required for the campaign against the heinous practice to succeed.
yo: Awon ajafetoo-eniyan ti a foro wa lenu wo lori isele yii je ki a mo wipe abuku iranwo ijoba ati awon onimo ni ko mu iwa aibojumu naa sira kase nle.

en: A silver lining in this dark cloud is that people working against the practice believe that the situation can be turned around.
yo: Ohun ti o dara ju lo ni wipe awon ti o n tako iwa buruku yii gbagbo wipe ayipada le de.

en: According to Prem Chand:
yo: Ni oroo Prem Chand:

en: The efforts for ending witch hunting can be modeled on the same principles that the government has used for promoting other social problems such as the literacy mission.
yo: "Akitiyan lati f""opin si isode-aje le tele ilana ti ijoba fi polongo eto mimoo-ko-ati-mimoo-ka."

en: Also, the intellectuals would have to lend their support to the cause to mold the public opinion.
yo: "Bakan naa, awon onimo ni lati f""owo si i k""awon eniyan o ba f'ohun si i."

en: The sources for the story were interviewed with the assistance of B. Vijay Murty, a journalist and resident editor based out of Jharkhand.
yo: B. Vijay Murty, akoroyin ati olugbe Jharkhand ni o gboro sile lenu awon ti oro kan.

en: Caring for Myanmar's orphaned elephants
yo: Itoju awon erin alailobiii Myanmar

en: A camp staff member bottle-feeds Ayeyar Maung. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy
yo: Osise ago kan n ro Ayeyar Maung ni ounje. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy

en: This article by Aung Kyaw Htet is from The Irrawaddy, an independent news website in Myanmar, and is republished on Global Voices as part of a content-sharing agreement.
yo: Apileko je ti Aung Kyaw Htet ti o ko fun The Irrawaddy, ileese oniroyinin ori ayelujara ni Myanmar, ti Ohun Agbaye se atuntejadee re ni ibamu pelu adehun ibasepo ti o wa laaarin won.

en: When forestry staff found her deep in the jungle of the Irrawaddy Delta, Ayeyar Sein was three months old.
yo: Nigba ti awon osise alaboojuto igbo ri i ninu iju ti o sun mo Eti-omi Irrawaddy, osu meta ni Ayeyar Sein nigba naa.

en: One of her legs was caught in a steel trap laid by poachers.
yo: Esee re kan ti lu pampe awon ajerangbepa.

en: Workers from the government's timber extraction enterprise saved her and sent her to an elephant camp in Bago Region for treatment.
yo: Awon onigedu ijoba lo doola emii re, won si gbe e lo si ago erin kan ni Agbegbee Bago fun itoju.

en: Now she is one of eight calves being sheltered at Wingabaw, Myanmar's only elephant orphanage.
yo: Ohun ni odo erin kejo ti yoo ri aabo ni Wingabaw, ibi aabo fun awon erin Myanmar ti ko lobii.

en: Another calf, Ayeyar Maung, endured a similar ordeal.
yo: Odo erin miiran, Ayeyar Maung naa ri nnkan.

en: Before his arrival at the camp, the six-month-old was snared in a wire trap.
yo: Ki o to di eroo ago naa, erin osu mefa naa ti lu okun.

en: As he was stuck among a group of boulders in the same forest where Ayeyar Sein was found, his herd was forced to leave him behind.
yo: O si ha si aarin awon okuta ninu iju kan naa ti a ti ri Ayeyar Sein, awon owoo re to ku fi i sile lo.

en: However, forest workers were able to free him and he arrived at the camp last year.
yo: Sibe, awon alaboojuto iju tu u sile, o si di araa ago naa ni odun to koja.

en: They are the youngest of the orphans at the camp; the oldest is nearly four years their senior.
yo: Awon mejeeji ni erin alailobiii ti o kere ju lo ninu ago naa; odun merin ni erin ti o dagba ju gba lowoo won.

en: All have tragic backgrounds.
yo: Gbogbo won ni o ni itan kan tabi omiran ti o je mo ijiya lati owo eda omo eniyan adarihununrun.

en: Some were left by their herds, while others were orphaned when their parents were killed by poachers.
yo: Awon kan ko ri owoo won ti won jo n je mo, awon miii di alailobiii leyin ti awon ti o n pa eran ninu igbe nipakupa pa obii won.

en: At Wingabaw Camp, the motherless calves rely on baby formula provided daily by staff.
yo: Ni ago ti o wa ni Wingabaw, awon odo erin ti ko ni obi naa gbekele ounje omo ikoko ti awon alaboojuto iju n pese fun won lojoojumo.

en: They are allowed to roam in the forest in the morning and wash in a nearby stream before returning to the camp.
yo: Aaye gba won lati je ninu iju ni owuro, won yoo si we ninu odo kekere kan nitosi ki won o to pada si ago.

en: Currently, it is believed that Myanmar has nearly 1,500 wild elephants.
yo: Lowo lowo bayii, Myanmar yoo feree ni to erin egan 1,500.

en: But they are under serious threat from poaching, with elephants being killed at the alarming rate of one a week.
yo: Amo o je ohun ti o bani lokan je nitori pe awon ti o n da emii won legbodo ko je ki won o gbe aye, erin kan lose kan ni won n pa.

en: "Tobago's coral bleaching alert makes it clear there is ""no alternative"" to fighting the climate crisis"
yo: Iyun Tobago ti o ti n pawoda fi han gbagadagbagada pe ko si ona miiran ju kikoju ayipada oju-ojo

en: "The island's reefs are on ""Bleaching Alert Level One"""
yo: "The island's reefs are on ""Bleaching Alert Level One"""

en: Bleached stag horn coral. Photo by Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.
yo: Iyun bi iwo agbonrin ti o ti pawoda. Aworan lati owoo Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.

en: Tobago's coral reefs are an integral part of both the island's marine ecosystem and its economy.
yo: Iyun-un abe okuta okun je ohun ti a o lee fowo ro seyin ninu awon amusoro ti o n mu oro Aje Tobago ati awon ayika erekusu naa gbooro.

en: Home to numerous species of marine life (and a main source of fish for local fishermen), they also protect the coastline from wave erosion and the effects of tropical storms.
yo: Ibugbe okan-ojokan eya eda inu omi (ati ibi eja pipa fun awon apeja ibile), ti o si tun n da aabo bo ebute, eyi ti ko mu ki awon iji lile eti omi o po koja ala ni a n so.

en: Popular spots like Buccoo Reef are also popular tourist attractions.
yo: Okuta inu okun Buccoo Reef ti o gbajumo bi isana eleta ti awon arinrin-ajo afe maa n wo tuurutu nibe naa ko gbeyin.

en: "But after a press release issued by the country's Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) on August 22, 2019, in which it warned that - based on findings from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch - Tobago's coral reefs have been placed on a watch for ""Bleaching Alert Level One,"" all eyes are on the island."
yo: "Amo leyin atejade kan si ile iroyin ti Ajo ti o n sakoso Omi orile ede naa (IMA) te jade ni ojo 22, osu Ogun odun-un 2019, eyi ti o kilo wipe - iwadiii National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch so wipe - iyun abe okuta okun Tobago ti bo si abe iso lati se ofintoto ""Ikede Ipawodaa Ipele Ikini,"" gbogbo oju lo n wo erekusu naa."

en: There is a distinct possibility that the bleaching could advance to Level Two within a matter of weeks, which would threatens not only the existence of the reefs themselves, but also the island's marine life and people.
yo: A i i se e mo, ipawoda naa le fo fere si ipele keji laaarin ose die, ti yoo si fa akoba fun iwalaaye awon iyun wonyi, awon eda inu omi miiran ati awon olugbe erekusu naa.

en: What exactly is bleaching?
yo: Ki ni ohun ti n pawoda ni pato?

en: Corals coexist with and become home to symbiotic algae, helping it store nutrients and remove waste.
yo: Alabaagbe ati alajose iyun ni awon ewe inu omi ti o maa n ba a ko ohun asaraloore pamo ati da eeri ara nu.

en: In return, the algae gives the coral the energy it needs to grow, but drastic changes in water temperature can threaten this cooperative relationship.
yo: Ewe wonyi yoo si fun iyun ni okun ti o nilo fun idagbasoke, amo ayipada igbona inu omi n di ajosepo yii lowo.

en: When water becomes too hot (or too cold) the corals expel the algae - and with it, its main source of food.
yo: Bi omi ba gbona ju bi o se ye lo (tabi bi o ba tutu ju) awon iyun yoo le ewe omi - ti yoo si padanu owo ti o n fi ounje nu un.

en: Eventually, the coral starves to death; the most noticeable outward sign of this phenomenon is that the coral loses its colour, going from shades of brown and green to a crisp, brittle, bone white.
yo: Aseyinwa aseyinbo, ebi yoo pa iyun ku; awo ara ti yoo yi pada ni ami ti a o fi mo, ipawoda lati awo olomi-oka ati eweko si funfun egungun.

en: Bleaching Level Alert One means that the corals are extremely likely to start the bleaching process.
yo: Ikede Ipawoda Ipele Kiini n kede wipe bi a ko ba wa nnkan se si i, awon iyun naa yoo bere si i pawoda.

en: The IMA therefore suggests that both biologists and citizens should keep an eye out for signs of bleaching over the next 9-12 weeks.
yo: IMA dabaa wipe ki awon onimo iseda ati omo ilu o maa so awon eda inu omi naa fun awon ami ipawoda ni aarin-in ose mesan-an si mejila ti o n bo.

en: Level Two bleaching would be an indication of widespread coral bleaching and coral mortality.
yo: Ipele ipawoda keji yoo je itoka si ipawoda iyun kari aye ati iku iyun.

en: What causes it?
yo: Ki lo fa sababi?

en: According to local coral reef ecologist Anjani Ganase, the main contributors to coral bleaching in Tobago are the warmer water temperatures - a result of climate change.
yo: Gege bi onimo ayika ibile Anjani Ganase ti se salaye, odada ti o da ipawoda iyun-un Tobago ni iwon igbona omi ti o re oke - ti i se arapa ayipada oju-ojo.

en: Via email, Ganase explained that the ocean absorbs much of the heat in the atmosphere, which in turn causes the water - especially shallower bodies of water, like the Caribbean Sea - to heat up.
yo: Ninu imeeli, Ganase salaye wipe okun maa n fa eyi ti o po ninu ooru inu afefe mu, ti o si n fa ki omi - paapaa ju lo awon ibu omi jinjin gbungbunrungbun bii Osaa Caribbean - o gbona janjan.

en: In fact, NOAA's 12-week outlook extends well past Tobago to the reefs of the Lesser Antilles.
yo: Koda, iso olose mejilaa NOAA Tobago tan pinpin ayipada yii de iyun Lesser Antilles.

en: Other reefs around the region, most notably in parts of the Greater Antilles and Cuba, have already been placed on a Level Two Bleaching Alert:
yo: Awon okuta ti o wa ni agbegbe naa, bii Greater Antilles ati Cuba, ti wa ni Ipele Keji Ikede Ipawoda:

en: What are its effects?
yo: Ki ni arapa re?

en: Coral bleaching is a huge threat.
yo: Ohun ti o lewu ni ipawodaa iyun.

en: Because reefs provide fishes with a habitat that allows them to have access to shelter, food and most importantly, shelter for their young until they are ready to survive in the wider ocean, the proposition of losing them will impact the ability of fish species to survive.
yo: Nitori wipe iyun maa fun eja ni ounje, oun naa ni o duro gege bi ile fun awon eja ati fun awon omo eja ti koi tii le we ninu alagbalugbu omi, nitori idi eyi, bi a ba padanuu won, eja naa yoo ba won lo.

en: It will also negatively affect the livelihoods of local fishermen.
yo: Bi eja ba si tan lomi, ise bo lowo awon apeja niyen.

en: Tobago relies very heavily on its local tourism industry; its reefs reportedly attract around 40 per cent of the island's tourists.
yo: Tobago gbekele ileese irinajo afe ibile; ida 40 awon arinrin-ajo afe erekusu yii ni o maa n wa lati wo awon iyun omi wonyi.

en: Should coral bleaching continue, there will be fewer thriving reefs for people to explore and quite likely, a reduction in tourism dollars, which affects a range of hospitality-related industries: hotels, restaurants, transport services and tour companies.
yo: Bi ipawoda ba tesiwaju, awon eniyan ko ni ri okuta iyun, owo dollar irinajo afe yoo fidi jale, ti yoo si ko ba awon ileese agbalejo bii: ile itura, ile ijeun, ise igbokegbodo oko ati ile ise asakoso irinajo.

en: The great irony is that, as tropical storms intensify as a result of the climate crisis, reefs are needed more than ever to absorb the force of waves and create a buffer between the ocean and the shore - but the reefs are compromised by global heating.
yo: Bi iji lile ba n po si i latari segesege oju-ojo, okuta iyun-un nise pataki ni sise lati fa agbara awon igbe omi ati iduro gege bi alarina laaarin okun ati eti okun - amo igbona agbanla aye n di i lowo lati sisee re.

en: Studies show that coral reefs protect around 90 per cent of Tobago's shoreline from wave-induced erosion.
yo: Iwadii ti fi idii re mule wipe okuta iyun ni n gba ida 90 etido Tobago sile-lowo ogbara ti igbe omi n fa.

en: In a feature address at the International Year of the Reef at the University of the West Indies in 2018, Professor John Agard said that this function will only become more important as storm intensities increase and sea levels rise.
yo: Ni ibi eto Ayajo Odun Okuta iyun ni Ifasiti West Indies ni odun-un 2018, Ojogbon John Agard so wipe ise yii yoo po si i bi iji se n po si i ati bi osa se n kun soke.

en: What can we do to stop it?
yo: Ki ni a le se lati dekun re?

en: Ganase says the lack of proper management that has allowed overfishing and pollution to go unchecked has made Tobago's coral bleaching worse.
yo: Ganase ni pe aimojuto omi wonyi bi o ti to lo fa eja pipa koja ala ati ibaje ayika ni eku eda ti o fa ipawoda iyun-un Tobago.

en: If this continues, she explains, active management and protection will be critical for full recovery and growth:
yo: Bi o ba n ba a lo bee, titempele mo isakoso ati aabo okuta iyun nikan lo le mu ki won o pada bo sipo ati dagba:

en: Ideally, coral reefs should be closed to the public and placed into an intensive recovery programme to ensure healthy fish communities and water quality that will support coral growth and recruitment.
yo: O ye ki okuta iyun o di ohun ti yoo pamo fun awon ero, ki ise irapada o fese mule ki owo eja onilera ati omi ti o dara ti yoo mu ki iyun o dagba o pada.

en: She added:
yo: O so siwaju si i:

en: Individual actions to reduce our carbon footprintare are always warranted but we also need citizens to demand more action from our governments to provide the infrastructure, resources and education for climate conservation and adaptation.
yo: Ojuse onikaluku ni lati din eefin inu ayika ku, bee naa ni omo araye ni eto lati beere fun ise ilosiwaju lati odo awon ijoba ki won o pese ohun ti yoo mu nnkan sun peli, ohun elo ati idanilekoo nipa ipamo ati ifikora.

en: Communities need the support to manage and conserve our natural resources not just from governments but from businesses and corporations that also utilise these resources.
yo: O pon dandan ki a sakoso ati ipamo ohun alumooni wa, boya ijoba ni o tabi ileese nlanla ti o n lo awon alumooni wonyi.

en: There is a pressing need for regional island governments to demand an international effort in tackling the climate crisis.
yo: O ti di sise fun ijoba ti erekusu agbegbe kan naa lati kede nipa ojuse agbaye ni ti igbogunti isoro ayipada oju-ojo.

en: "On September 11, 2019, Barbadian Prime Minister Mia Mottley addressed this issue at the United Nations"" Geneva headquarters, urging larger nations to do better in fighting climate change."
yo: Ni ojo 11, osu Owewe, odun-un 2019, Oludari Barbadia Mia Mottley menu le isoro yii ni olu ileese Ajo Agbaye ni Geneva, o n ro awon orile-ede nla ki won o gbe igbese akin lati kojuu ayipada oju-ojo.

en: "The islands of the Caribbean, she said, ""do not have the luxury of time because [we] are busy trying to survive."""
yo: "O so wipe, erekusu Caribbean, ""ko ni asiko ti o po nitori [a] n sise iye lowo ."""

en: Ganase agrees about the urgency of the matter.
yo: Ganase gba wipe oran naa gba atunse ni kiakia.

en: "Any and all forms of aid in tackling climate change and coral bleaching, she said, especially on political levels, ""requires effort"":"
yo: "Ohun gbogbo ti o ba gba lati gba oromodie oju-ojo lowo ayipada ati idekun ipawoda iyun ni ki a fi fun un, o so wipe, paapaa ju lo ""ise n be"" fun awon ti o n se oselu:"

en: It's not going to be easy as seen internationally, but there is really no alternative.
yo: Bi a se n wo o, ko ni je ohun ti o rorun, amo ona abayo miiran n be.

en: Travel: An extreme sport for Africans
yo: Irin-ajo: Ipekun ere-idaraya fun Omo-adulawo

en: Visa applications can feel like a sacrifice to the gods
yo: Isebeere fun iwe irinna da bii ebo fun awon oosa

en: Africa silhouette image by Natasha Sinegina (CC BY-SA 4.0).
yo: Aworan olojiji lati owoo Natasha Sinegina (CC BY-SA 4.0).

en: Visa page images by Jon Evans (CC BY 2.0).
yo: Aworan oju-ewe iwe irinna latowoo Jon Evans (CC BY 2.0).

en: Image remix by Georgia Popplewell.
yo: Atunto aworan-an latowoo Georgia Popplewell.

en: In 2019, Temitayo Olofinlua, a Nigerian writer and academic, was denied a visa to attend the European Conference on African Studies in Edinburgh, UK.
yo: Ni odun-un 2019, a ko fun Temitayo Olofinlua, onkowe ati omowe omobibi orile-edee Naijiria, ni iwe irinna lati lo si Apero Lori Eko Ile Adulawo ni Eroopu ti o waye ni Edinburgh, UK.

en: "The British High Commission in Nigeria said they were ""not satisfied"" that Olofinlua would leave the UK at the end of her trip."
yo: "Igbimo Agba Sorile-ede Britain ni Naijiria so wipe awon ko ""si aridaju"" ti o te awon lorun wipe Olofinlua yoo fi UK sile leyin ti eto ba pari."

en: The visa refusal was later rescinded by the UK Home Office. Olofinlua went to the conference and has since returned to Nigeria.
yo: Ile-ise UK Nile pe aifuni ni iwe irinna naa pada. Olofinlua lo, o bo pada si Naijiria, ko b'omo je.

en: Others have not been as lucky. In April 2019, the UK visa authorities prevented 24 out of 25 African scientists working on infectious diseases from joining their colleagues at various events taking place as part of the London School of Economics Africa Summit.
yo: Awon miiran ko ri anfaani bayii. Ninuu osuu Igbe odun-un 2019, awon alase iwe irinna UK ko je ki omo adulawo 24 ninuu awon onimo ijinle 25 ti o n sise lorii arun akoran o darapo mo awon akegbee won nibi apero London School of Economics Africa Summit.

en: "The people most invested in and best-positioned to tackle the problem of diseases on their continent, were barred from participating in an event about ""the challenge of pandemic preparedness."""
yo: "Awon onimo ti won lakaki ti won si ni imo pipe lati kojuu arun ti o n ba ile adulawo finra, ko ri iwe irinna ti yoo mu won kopa ninuu apero nipa ""ipenija iponmisile-de-ongbe ajakale arun"" gba."

en: """You won't come back!"""
yo: """O ko ni pada!"""

en: Barring Africans from entry into certain countries is not only humiliating - it also highlights the institutional racism that underpins the notion that African professionals and creatives cannot be trusted to obey the law.
yo: Kekere nikan ko ni idojuti ti aifayegba Omo-adulawo lati wo awon illu kan n mu dani - bee naa ni o n toka si igbekale eleyameya ti o n se atilleyin fun igbagbo wipe awon akosemose Omo-adulawo ati alatinuda o se e fi okan tan lo titi ni ti ibowo fun ofin de.

en: "Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights declares that ""Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country."""
yo: "Abala 13 ti Ikede Kariaye Fun ETo Omoniyan wipe ""Eni kookan lo ni eto lati kuro lorileede yoowu ko je, to fi mo orileede tire, ki o si tun pada si orileede tire nigba to ba wu u."""

en: The reality, however, is that without a passport and valid visa, this right cannot easily be exercised.
yo: Otito ibe, sibesibe, bi ko ba si iwe-ase-omoilu-fun-irinna ati iwe irinna ti o wulo, ko rorun lati lo.

en: And the ease of getting a visa varies according to nationality.
yo: Irorun ni ibeere fun iwe irinna ni awon orile-ede kan, ko si ri bee ni orile-ede miiran.

en: On the 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan and Singapore hold the top spot for access to most countries, while Angola, Egypt and Haiti are at the bottom.
yo: Ni orii 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan ati Singapore ni orile-ede ti o rorun fun ju lo lati riwee gba wolu orisiirisi, nigbati Angola, Egypt ati Haiti wa ni isale.

en: "Read more: ""No Visa Mix': Tanzanian singeli stars denied visas to US music festival"
yo: "Ka siwaju si i: ""Ko Si Apopo Iwe Irinna': Awon irawo olorin orile-ede Tanzania o ri iwe irinna wo ajodun orin ni US"

en: "Kenyan author Ciku Kimeria describes the indignity of living without ""passport privilege."""
yo: "Onkowee omobibii Kenya Ciku Kimeria se alaye gbigbe laisi iyi ""eto si iwe-eri-omoilu-fun-irinna."""

en: "She notes that even a visa does not guarantee entry because ""you still have to deal with the surly immigration official who will suspiciously ask, ""And what are you here to do?"""""
yo: "Obinrin naa so wipe iwe irinna nikan ko gbe eniyan wo orile-ede miiran nitori pe ""o ni lati dahun awon ibeere bii, ""Ki lo wa sibi wa se?"""

en: If the answer to this question isn't to the official's satisfaction, visitors could find themselves being marched back to the departure gate.
yo: ti awon osise ibode yoo beere, bi esi ibeere ko ba te won lorun, arinrin-ajo le ba ara re ni enu iloro alo.

en: For Africans traveling outside the continent, applying for a visa can feel like offering sacrifices to a ravenous god.
yo: Fun awon Omo-adulawo ti o fe se irinajo jade lo si orile-ede ti kii se ti adulawo, ibeere fun iwe irinna iwolu maa n da bii sise ebo fun oosa ti ebi n pa.

en: Adesina Ayeni (Omo Yooba), Global Voices Yoruba translation manager, recounts his recent experience trying to procure a visa to Lisbon, Portugal, for the 2019 Creative Commons Summit:
yo: Adesina Ayeni (Omo Yooba), alakooso Ohun Agbaye ni edee Yoruba, so iririi re nigba ti o se ibeere fun iwe irinna iwoluu Lisbon, Portugal, fun aperoo awon alatinuda 2019 Creative Commons Summit:

en: It was the greatest news of my life when I received a mail to deliver a keynote address at the 2019 CC Summit in Lisbon...
yo: Idunnu nla gba okan-an mi nigba ti mo gba iroyin tel mi lowo wipe n o maa soro akori eto nibi Apero CC odun-un 2019 ni Lisbon. . . .

en: On April 18, 2019, some days to my birthday, I submitted my visa application to attend the Lisbon summit at the VFS Global office in Lekki, Lagos.
yo: Lojo 18 osu Igbe, 2019, ojo die si ayajo ojo ibii mi, mo ko awon ohun ti won beere fun iwe irinna lati woluu Lisbon ki n ba kopa ninuu apero naa sile ni ile-isee VFS Global ni idado Lekki, ni Eko.

en: The summit was slated for May 9-11, 2019, but visa processing takes a minimum 15 days.
yo: Ojo 9 si 11 odun-un 2019 ni apero naa sugbon ojo marunundinlogun ni yo gba fun iwe irinna lati jade fun gbigba.

en: On the day I was to depart for Portugal, I still [hadn't] received my passport...
yo: Lojo ti o ye ki n kuro nile fun Portugal, n koi ti i ri iwe-eri-omoilu-fun-irinna mi gba pada...

en: 11 days after the summit elapsed, I received a text from the VFS for collection of my passport.
yo: ojo mokanla leyin ti apero ti di afiseyin ti eegun alare n fiso, mo gba ise-ije ki n wa gba iwe-eri-omoilu-fun-irinna mi ni VFS.

en: The elders say, you cannot be at your best when sad.
yo: "Awon agba bo, inu didun l""o n mu ori ya."

en: It is one thing that I was not given a visa to attend the summit, another is that the huge scholarship grant to attend the summit went down the drain, wasted.
yo: Isoro kan ni ti airi iwe irinna gba, omiran ni ti owo irinajo ofe goboi ti o wole nitori n ko le e lo si apero.

en: I am miserable because I have not been able to refund the scholarship due to the Central Bank of Nigeria's policy on wire transfers.
yo: Ibanuje gba okan mi poo latarii alaale Ile-Ifowopamo Agba orile-ede Naijiria ti ko mu ifowo ranse si oke okun rorun; n ko le e da owo irinajo ofe ti o pon dandan lati da pada pada fun awon ti o ni owo.

en: It is excruciatingly painful that my right to associate as a free citizen of the global village was violated.
yo: O dun mi wo akinyemi ara wipe won gbese le etoo mi gege bi olominira lati darapo mo awon akegbee mi.

en: I was stripped of my voice!
yo: Won pa ohun mo mi lenu!

en: For Africans traveling within Africa: A painful irony
yo: Isoro: Fun awon Omo-adulawo ti o n se irinajo ninuu Ile-adulawo

en: It's difficult for Africans to travel outside Africa - but it can be equally grim to travel within the continent.
yo: O soro fun omo-adulawo lati se irinajo jade kuro ni Ile-adulawo - sugbon bee naa ni o nira lati se irinajo nile naa.

en: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.
yo: Awon omo oniluu aimoye orile-ede ti o wa ni Ariwa agbanla aye le se irinajo lo si opo orile-ede ni ile-adulawo lai ni iwe irinna, tabi pelu hihamo ti o to nnkan, amo opolopo Omo-adulawo ni o niloo iwe irinna iwolu lati se irinajo si idaji awon orile-ede ti o ku.

en: "Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the ""struggle of Africans traveling within Africa"":"
yo: "Aladaasi Ohun Agbaye omobibi orile-ede Naijiria Rosemary Ajayi se apejuwe ""ilakaka awon omo-adulawo ti o n se irinajo ni aarin ile-adulawo "":"

en: I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.
yo: Inuu mi dun nitori wipe a n gbe oran ohun ti oju awon omo-adulawo maa n ri ni won ba beere fun iwe irinna wo Orile-ede oyinbo ati ohun ti o tan mo on ye wo.

en: This doesn't annoy me as much as the struggles of Africans travelling within Africa.
yo: Eyi ko gbe mi lokan bii ti ilakaka awon omo-adulawo ti o n se irinajo ninuu ile-adulawo.

en: At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I took the time to ask Africans if they had needed visas.
yo: Ni RightsCon ti o waye ni Tunis, ati GlobalFact ti o waye ni Cape Town, mo bi awon Omo-adulawo boya won ti niloo iwe irinna.

en: Just this weekend, I learnt of a Nigerian journalist who was unable to attend GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.
yo: Ni ojo isinmi ti a wa yii, mo gbo wipe onise-iroyin omo Naijiria kan ko le e wa nibi GlobalFact nitori wipe ko ni iwe irinna.

en: Let's not talk about how most of the African delegates at RightsCon had to fly out of Africa first, in order to get to Tunis.
yo: Ki a maa so ti awon omo-adulawo ti o fo kuro nile-adulawo ki won o to le wo Tunis.

en: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to supply the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!
yo: Ni osu ti o koja, mo se alabaapade onise-iroyin ti o wa lati Ila-oorun Ile-adulawo ti o n se ibeere fun iwe irinna wo Naijiria. Won ni ki o pesee iwe-eri iwakoo ti akosemose awako ti yoo wa gbe e bi o ba bale ni papa-oko-ofuurufu!

en: As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.
yo: Bi Rosemary ti so, irinajo ninuu ile-adulawo maa n gba siserinajo kuro ni ile-adulawo ki aserinajo o to le e de ibi ti o n lo ni aarin Ile-adulawo.

en: "At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) regional aviation forum in Accra in June, Ghana's Vice President, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia lamented the fact that ""a business person from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for nearly two days to go to Banjul (often through a third country) for a journey which a straight-line flight would have taken only one hour."""
yo: "Ni ibi apero osise oko-ofuurufu agbegbe ti Ajo Igbokegbodo Oko-ofuurufu Agbaye (IATA) gbe kale ti o waye ni Accra ninuu osu Okudu, Igbakeji Aare Orile-edee Ghana, Onisegun Mahamudu Bawumia pohunrere-ekun latarii wipe ""o ye onisowo lati Freetown [Sierra Leone], fun apeere, lati se irinajo fun ojo meji gbako lati lo si Banjul (nipasee orile-ede keta) fun irinajo ti ko ju wakati kan lo."""

en: The convoluted flight routes are then compounded by the extraordinarily high cost of air travel within the continent.
yo: Ipoyi lori ofuurufu naa gbomo pon pelu owo kanangu fifo loke laaarin Ile-adulawo.

en: Is it true that Africans are unlikely to return home?
yo: Nje otito ni wipe o seese ki Omo-adulawo o maa pada wale?

en: A rescue operation off the Canary Islands in 2006.
yo: Ise idoola-emi ni orii omi Erekusu Canary ni 2006.

en: Photo by Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)
yo: Aworan lati owoo Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)

en: Between 2010-2017, migrants from sub-Saharan African countries accounted for the largest migrant population in the world after Syria.
yo: Ni aarin-n odun-un 2010-2017, awon asipokiri lati awon orile-ede ti o wa labe Ilu Guusu Asale Sahara ni o sepo ti o tele Syria gege bi ilu ti o ni eniyan to po ju ninu awon asipokiri lagbaaye.

en: Many Africans leave the countries fleeing poverty or violent conflict, to seek asylum, refugee status or permanent residence in North America or Europe.
yo: Opolopo Omo-adulawo n sa kuro niluu nitori ebi ati rogbodiyan, lati wabi foripamosieek, didi ogunlemidebi tabi didi agbeluu ni Arewa Amerika tabi ni Eroopu.

en: "A 2018 Pew Research study reports that the number of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa ""grew by 50% or more between 2010 and 2017, significantly more than the 17% worldwide average increase for the same period."""
yo: "Abajade Iwadii Pew odun-un 2018 so wipe iye awon asipokiri lati Ilu Guusu Asale Sahara ""ti fi ida 50 lo soke tabi ju bee lo ni aarin-in odun-un 2010 ati 2017, ju gbogbo re lo won ju ida 17 lo kariaye ni asiko kan naa."""

en: Sub-Saharan Africans are also emigrating to countries far and wide.
yo: Awon omo-adulawo ti o wa lati Ilu Guusu Asale Sahara naa n si kiri orile-ede jakejado agbaye.

en: In 2014, over 170,000 migrants without legal documents ferried across the Mediterranean Sea to Italy.
yo: Ni odun-un 2014, o to asikiri 170,000 ti o ni iwe-ase labe ofin ni o n wo oko gba ori okun Mediterranean lo si orile-ede Italy.

en: Many hailed from sub-Saharan Africa.
yo: Ogoro lo wa lati awon Ilu Guusu Asale Sahara.

en: "In December 2018, Brazilian police rescued 25 sub-Saharan African nationals who had ""been at sea for over a month"" in the Atlantic Ocean."
yo: "Ni osu Ope odun-un 2018, Olopaa Brazil doola emi eeyan 25 omo-adulawo ti o wa lati Ilu Guusu Asale Sahara ""ti o ti wa lori omi okun Atlantic fun osu kan gbako."""

en: "The travelers had paid ""hundreds of dollars apiece"" for the trip from Cape Verde. In June 2019, US Customs and Border Protection in Del Rio, Texas, USA, arrested more than 500 Africans from Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, for trying to cross into the USA via the Rio Grande River."
yo: "Awon arinrinajoo san ""egbelemuku owo lowo enikookan"" fun irinajo lati Cape Verde. Ni osu Okudu odun-un 2019, US Customs Ajo Asobode ati Aabo Ibode US ni Del Rio, Texas, USA, fi owoo sikun ofin mu awon omo-adulawo 500 ti o wa lati Ile-olominira Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, ati Angola, ti won n fe gba omi Odo Rio Grande wo USA."

en: While dominant narratives in the media perpetuate Africa as a continent of mass migration driven by poverty or violent conflict, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, scholars from University of Oxford and University of Amsterdam, respectively, take issue with this stereotype.
yo: Oniruuru iroyin ni o ti ro o wipe Ile-adulawo ni aarin-in gbungun otosi ati ogun, sibesibe, Marie-Laurence Flahaux ati Hein De Haas, awon onimo lati Ifasiti ti Oxford ati Ifasiti ti Amsterdam, ni sisentele, ko gba pe bee ni o ri.

en: "Flahaux and De Haas argue that these narratives are propagated not only by ""media and politicians"" but also by scholars."
yo: "Flahaux ati De Haas jiyan wipe ko ri bi iroyin ti se ro o si etigboo omo araye paapaa ""awon ile ise ati olosolu"" ati awon ologbon naa."

en: "Their research shows that migration from the continent is multi-layered and driven by global ""processes of development and social transformation"" that have increased the ""capabilities and aspirations"" of Africans"" to migrate - similar to migrants from other parts of the world."
yo: "Ise iwadii fi ye wipe awon isipokiri lati Ile-adulawo ko deedee waye, ohun ti o fa a ni ""ilana idagbasoke ati iyipada awujo"" eyi ti o n mu sisikiri lo si awon agbegbe agbaye wu Omo-adulawo - ti ko yato si asipokiri lati ibomiiran lagbaaye."

en: These stereotypical narratives, however, often inform visa policy:
yo: Awon iroyin abanilorukoje wonyi, ni o n fa sababi ilana-ise iwe irinna:

en: "Most countries"" authorities assume that all Africans who travel will not return to their home countries, leaving African visa applicants to bear the burden of proof."
yo: Opolopo orile-ede ni o nigbagbo wipe gbogbo arinrinajo ti o ba je Omo-adulawo ni ko ni pada si orile-edee re, afi bi arinrinajo ba ni eri ti o yanranti to ni o le ri iwe irinna iwolu gba.

en: Getting non-African nations to take a more nuanced approach to visa approvals for African nationals is a long battle.
yo: Ko rorun lati si oju awon ti ki i se omo-adulawo loju nipa oruko buburu ti won ti so orile-ede ti o wa lati Ile-adulawo.

en: Meanwhile, African nations can take action to improve mobility across the continent.
yo: Nibayii, awon orile-ede Ile-adulawo nise lati se si eto lilo-ati-bibo awon omoadulawo. Iwe-eri-omoilu-fun-irinna kan soso fun gbogbo orile-ede ni Ile-adulawo je ona abayo - amo ko to.

en: A common African passport is one step - but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.
yo: Single African Air Transport market naa (SAATM), ati Continental Free Trade Agreement naa, ti a fi lole lodun ti o koja, ti se alaale igbese wonyi, sugbon imuse si ku die kaato.

en: Meanwhile, as an African, to dare to travel is to be subjected to cruel humiliations when travelling outside Africa - or to be jolted out of the fantasy of African unity by the harshness of travelling within the continent.
yo: Lasiko yii, gege bii Omo-adulawo, iyanju lati rinrinajo ni lati ni iriri irenisile ti awon ti o n se irinajo lo si oke-okun n ri - tabi je titaji ninu ala isokan Ile-adulawo ti ko si.

en: Either way the visa gods demand more sacrifices, while remaining adamantly intransigent.
yo: Eyi keyii ti o baa je, oosa iwe irinna n beere ebo si i, ti ko si ye e gbebo.

en: Social media propelled ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during the Nigerian elections
yo: Ero Alatagba ni a fi gbe awon iroyin iro ati oro eleyameya jade lasiko idibo orile-edee Naijiria

en: Ethnic driven falsehoods spiked on social media during the elections
yo: Iro ti o ti ara eleyameya su yo lori ero alatagba lasiko ibo
