yo: Lati odun-un 2011, Boko Haram, ajijangbara esin Imale ni Ila-oorun arewa orile-edee Naijiria, ti fi eru si okan awon eniyan ati bi awon ikolu to roro won ti se fa iku lai ro tele ipi awon eniyan, ti opoo si ti di awati.

en: Read more: Nigeria: A failed state - reality or perception?
yo: Ka siwaju si i: Naijiria: Ilu ti o kuna - ooto tabi iwoye?

en: To further continue to uplift Nigeria, the management of FRCN Lagos Operations put together a series of events to commemorate World Radio Day 2020.
yo: Ni itesiwaju igbesoke orile-edee Naijiria, awon alase FRCN Eka ti Eko se agbekale okanojokan eto lati saami Ayajo Ojo Ero-igbohunsafefe Agbaye odun-un 2020.

en: "It kicked off with an essay contest calling for 1,200 words on ""why I love listening to the radio"" for secondary school students."
yo: "Ere gbogboo bere pelu idije aroko oloro 1,200 ti o da lorii ""idi ti mo fi nifee si lati maa gbo redio"" fun awon akekoo ileewe giga."

en: Students of mass communications also submitted a 5-minute documentary on the importance of radio in achieving sustainable development goals. Two winners emerged from both entries.
yo: Awon akekoo imo ise iroyin naa se eto alalaye oniseeju 5 ti o da firigbagboo lorii patakii ero-igbohunsafefe fun imuse awon ilepa imuduro idagbasoke. Awon akopa meji lo jawe olubori.

en: Essay winner Ilori Ayooluwa of Mater Christi Catholic Girls' High School, Igede Ekiti, Ekiti State, recalls the first time she encountered radio at the age 5:
yo: Olubori idije aroko Ilori Oluwatobi ti ileewe Mater Christi Catholic Girls' High School, Igede Ekiti, Ipinle Ekiti, mu u wa si iranti igba akoko ti oun-un salabaapadee redio nigba ti oun-un wa ni omo odun 5:

en: I think I was 5 years old when I got my first radio.
yo: O da bi eni pe omo odun 5 ni mi nigba ti mo koko ni ero-igbohunsafefee mi.

en: I fiddled with a few buttons and it came on.
yo: Mo te awon ohun-ate-ase ara re, o si tan.

en: "Then I was astonished to hear voices resonating from this ""box"" and thought there were people trapped in it."
yo: "Iyalenu lo je fun mi bi mo se n gbo ohun ti o n ti inuu ""apoti"" yii jade ti mo si ro wipe awon eeyan lo wa ninuu re."

en: I got scared and asked my father what it was and he took his time to explain what a radio was to me.
yo: Eru ba mi mo si beere lowoo babaa mi ohun ti o je, o si salaye ohun ti redio je fun mi.

en: On February 12, secondary school pupils, students of mass communication, ace broadcasters and key personnel from the media industry as well as everyday radio fans converged on the Lekki Coliseum in Lagos for a symposium to talk about the importance of radio for development.
yo: Ni ojo 12 osu Erele, awon akekoo ile eko giga, akekoo imo ise iroyin, oje sorosoro ati awon alenuloro ninu ise iroyin ati awon ololufee redio pejupese si Lekki Coliseum ni Eko fun apero lati jiroro nipa patakii ero-igbohunsafefe fun idagbasoke.

en: On February 12, secondary school pupils, students of mass communication, ace broadcasters and key personnel from the media industry as well as everyday radio fans converged on the Lekki Coliseum in Lagos for a symposium to talk about the importance of radio for development.
yo: Ni ojo 12 osu Erele, awon akekoo ile eko giga, akekoo imo ise iroyin, oje sorosoro ati awon alenuloro ninu ise iroyin ati awon ololufee redio pejupese si Lekki Coliseum ni Eko fun apero lati jiroro nipa patakii ero-igbohunsafefe fun idagbasoke.

en: Photo by Omo Yooba, used with permission.
yo: Aworan lati owoo Omo Yooba, a gba ase lati lo o.

en: When the sun went down, veteran broadcasters, representatives of the Oba of Lagos, Otunba Gani Adams, the Aare Ona Kakanfo of Yoruba-land and other guests and dignitaries mingled at the Lekki Coliseum for the World Radio Day award ceremony and dinner.
yo: Ni igbati ojo ro, awon ogbontarigi sorosoro, awon asoju the Oba Eko, Otunba Gani Adams, Aare Ona Kakanfo ilee Yoruba ati awon alejo miiran pejo si Lekki Coliseum fun apeje ale ati ifamieye danilola Ayajo Ojo Ero-igbohunsafefe Agbaye.

en: Top broadcast professionals like Cordelia Okpei and a host of others graced the event.
yo: Awon agba ojee sorosoro bii Cordelia Okpei ati awon to ku wa si ayeye naa.

en: Some deserving persons were presented with awards of recognition for their contributions to the development of the broadcast industry and service to humanity.
yo: Ami-eyee fun akikanju lenu ise ati isisesinlu lo si odo awon eni ti o to si.

en: "The series of events culminated in an on-air phone-in programme, whereby listeners made phone calls to say ""happy World Radio Day"" in their diverse range of languages and tongues:"
yo: "Okan-o-jokan eto naa wa sopin pelu isoju opo sile lati gba ipe awon olugbo wole sori afefe, nibi ti won ti ni ki awon eniyan o so wipe ""e ku Ayajo Ojo Ero-igbohunsafefe Agbaye"" ni awon oniruuru okan-o-jokan ede ati ahon:"

en: No one was left out of the celebration. Voices of some of the Global Voices Lingua teams were also broadcast on Metro 97.7FM. Some retired broadcasters were invited to read the news or anchor a segment.
yo: Ko seni ti ko kopa ninu ayeye naa. Ohun awon iko Ohun Agbaye naa bo sori afefe ni ori ikanni Metro 97.7FM. Awon sorosoro ti o ti feyinti lo ka iroyin ti won si tokun eto.

en: Radio Nigeria World Radio Day 2020 is the maiden edition of such events but radio practitioners and advocates expect it to become an annual celebration.
yo: "Akoko iru ""e ni Ayajo Ojo Ero-igbohunsafefe Redio Orile-edee Naijiria odun-un 2020 amo awon osise ati ololufee redio lero wipe ayeye naa yoo maa waye lodoodun."

en: This chief hopes Yoruba speakers adopt his newly invented 'talking alphabet'
yo: Oloye yii nireti wi pe awon omo Yoruba yoo tewo gba 'alifabeeti t'o n soro ' ti oun hu imo re

en: Will the new Yoruba orthography become mainstream in the future?
yo: Nje ilana isowoko Yoruba tuntun yoo di lilo lojo iwaju bi?

en: Chief Tolulase Oguntosin stands next to the paramount king of Yorubaland, the Ooni of Ife, seated.
yo: Oloye Tolulase Oguntosin duro legbee oba ile-Yoruba kaafata, Ooni ti Ile-Ife, lori ijokoo.

en: Photo courtesy of Chief Oguntosin.
yo: Oloye Oguntosin lo yanda aworan.

en: In the wake of the International Year of Indigenous Languages in 2019 and the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2022-2032, many Africans have started to take a wide range of actions to advance African languages.
yo: Leyin ipolongo kari aye nipa Odun Ede Ibile Agbaye ni odun 2019 ati ikede Odun mewaa Ede Ibile Agbaye 2022-2032, pupo ninu awon omo Ile-Adulawo lo ti bere okan-o-jokan akanse ise to ni se pelu idagbasoke awon ede Ile-Adulawo.

en: Writing the Yoruba language in the borrowed Latin script may soon become a thing of the past as one Yoruba man, Chief Tolulase Oguntosin, based in Benin, West Africa, has invented a writing system to encode the Yoruba language.
yo: Lilo ayalo ilana Latiini fun kiko ede Yoruba yoo di afiseyin ti eegun alare n fiso lai pe ni eyi ti omo Kaaaro-o-o-ji-ire kan, Oloye Tolulase Oguntosin, eni ti o n gbe ni Ile Olominira Bene, Iwo-oorun Ile-Adulawo, ti hu imo ilana ti a o maa lo fun kiko ede Yoruba.

en: The newly invented Yoruba alphabet is making waves in the hopes that it could replace Latin script used for over 100 years.
yo: Alifabeeti Yoruba tuntun naa ti n gbalu kan pelu ireti wi pe yoo paaro ti Latiini ti o ti je lilo fun ogorun-un odun ati ju bee lo.

en: The distinct alphabet came to him through divine inspiration in his dreams, according to Chief Oguntosin in a Whatsapp interview with Global Voices.
yo: Gege bi Oloye Oguntosin ti se ro fun Ohun Agbaye ninu iforowanilenuwo lori WhatsApp, oju ala ni alifabeeti aramanda wonyi ti f'ara han si oun.

en: "He now travels across Yorubaland - spanning Benin to Nigeria - to promote his ""talking alphabet"" as sent to him by his ancestors."
yo: "Ni bayii, nise ni o maa n se irinajo jakejado Ile-Yoruba - lati Bene titi de Naijiria - lati polongo ""alifabeeti ti o n soro "" re bi awon alale ti se fi ran an."

en: Chief Oguntosin believes that this alphabet was used by Oduduwa, the father of the Yoruba people, in ancient times - but was lost.
yo: Oloye Oguntosin nigbagbo wi pe Oduduwa, ti o je baba-nla iran Yoruba lo alifabeeti naa ni aye atijo - amo o ti di ohun igbagbe.

en: There are 25 symbols in all.
yo: 25 ni gbogbo awon ami wonyi lapapo.

en: African linguists assert that if Africa is to grow, it must have its own orthographies or writing systems.
yo: Awon onimo nipa ede ni Ile-Adulawo so wi pe ki ilosiwaju o to de ba Ile Adulawo, o pon dandan ki o ni ilana isowo ko ede tabi ilana kiko ti o je tire.

en: A civilized and ancient Niger-Congo language like Yoruba should not rely on a borrowed orthography to encode its thoughts and philosophy.
yo: Ede ti o wa labe isori Niger-Congo ti o je ede iran ti o ti wa lojo to ti pe ti o si laju bi ede Yoruba o gbodo gbokan te ilana ayalo fun kiko ero ati imo iriri aye re.

en: Read more: Yoruba loan words: How languages evolve
yo: Ka si i: Oro ayalo ninu ede Yoruba: Bi ede se yi pada

en: In 1843, Reverend Samuel Ajayi Crowther of the Christian Missionary Society developed the Yoruba orthography by adopting Latin script with diacritics - or accent marks.
yo: Ni odun 1843, Alufaa Samueli Ajayi Crowther osise Egbe Ise Iranse Esin Igbagbo (CMS) se agbekale ilana isowoko ede Yoruba nipa yiya ilana Latiini lo pelu afikun awon ami ohun - tabi ami iro oro.

en: Ever since, thousands of books have been published in Yoruba using Latin script instead of Ajami, an Arabic script used before 1843 to write in West African Indigenous languages such as Yoruba and Hausa.
yo: Lati igba naa, egbeegberun iwe ti je tite jade ni ede Yoruba nipase lilo ilana kiko Latiini dipo Ajami, ti i se ilana isowoko Larubawa ti o ti je lilo teletele ri fun kiko ede Iwo-oorun Ile-Adulawo bi i ede Yoruba ati Hausa ki o to di 1843.

en: Some language advocates contend that using Latin, a foreign script, to encode African languages, keeps the continent in an enslaved mindset.
yo: Awon alagbawi ede gba wi pe lilo ilana Latiini, ti o je isowoko lati ile okeere, fun kiko awon ede Ile-Adulawo sile, fi ile naa sinu ipo eru.

en: Instilling this new writing system follows a history of ancient writing systems in Africa, like Egyptian hieroglyphics, the Adrinka collection of the Akan tribe of Ghana, Ethiopian Ge'ez, the Nsibidi ideographic script of West Central Africa which date back to 5000 BC, as well as Vai alphabet scripts are of African origin.
yo: Ipolongo ilana isowoko tuntun yii waye ni ibamu pelu awon isowoko ayebaye Ile-Adulawo, bi i hieroglyphics ti Ijipiti, Akojo Adrinka ti iran Akan ni Ghana, Ge'ez ti Ethiopia, isowoko iyaworan Nsibidi ti Aarin Gbungbun Iwo-oorun Ile-Adulawo ti o ti wa fun bi 5000 odun k'a to bi Jesu, ati alifabeeti Vai ni Ile-Adulawo je orisun won.

en: Divining a 'talking alphabet'
yo: Isayewo 'alifabeeti to n soro '

en: Global Voices Yoruba Lingua Manager Omo Yooba interviewed Chief Oguntosin, via WhatsApp voice note messaging, to learn more about how he discovered this new alphabet.
yo: Alakooso Ohun Agbaye lede Yoruba, Omo Yooba fi oro wa Oloye Oguntosin lenu wo, nipase ise-ije ohun lori ero iitakuroso WhatsApp, lati mo si i nipa bi o ti se ri alifabeeti tuntun yii.

en: Chief Oguntosin, now 43, explained that after the demise of his father in 1997, he had to care for his siblings as the oldest son and could not further his education after completing secondary school.
yo: Oloye Oguntosin, to je omo odun 43 bayii, salaye wi pe oun ko le ka ju ile giga lo leyin ipapoda baba oun ni odun 1997, ti oun si ni lati se ojuse bi baba gege bi akobi lati toju awon aburo re.

en: However, as a Yoruba chief, he focused his cultural work on uniting the seven grandchildren of Oduduwa, serving as a mediator.
yo: Sibe, bi oloye Yoruba ti o je, ise igbelaruge asa re da lori isokan awon omo Oduduwa je ohun ti o gbe e lokan gidi gan-an, ti o si n se bi olulaja laaarin won.

en: As his cultural integration work progressed, however, he wanted to achieve more.
yo: Bi ise igbelaruge asa yii se n gbooro si i, ko te e lorun to bi o se fe.

en: "In 2011, he approached a babalawo or ""diviner"" of Ifa, the Yoruba god of wisdom."
yo: Lodun 2011, o fi eeji kun eeji, o fi eeta kun eeta, o gba oko alawo lo.

en: The diviner, Olokun Awopetu, told him to visit his ancestral shrine within the Farasinmi community in Badagry, Lagos State, Nigeria, and to take whatever he came into contact with at the shrine.
yo: Babalawo naa, Olokun Awopetu, wi fun un pe ki o lo si ojubo idile re ti o wa ni agbegbe Farasinmi ni Agbadarigi (Badagry), Ipinle Eko, orile ede Naijiria, wi pe yoo ri atona ti yoo toka si ohun ti Eledumare ran an wa se laye ni ojubo naa.

en: "There, he found a ""strange object"" that he took with him back to Porto-Novo, Benin."
yo: "Ni ojubo naa, o ri ""nnkan ajeji"" kan ti o mu pada si ile re ni Porto-Novo, Bene."

en: When he arrived, the house was completely dark.
yo: Nigba ti o dele, okunkun bo iyara birimubirimu.

en: With no light bulbs in the living room, he usually relied on light emitted from the rays of the TV screen.
yo: Ko si ina amororo ninu yara igbalejo, imole itansan ero amohunmaworan ni o maa n fi riran.

en: He placed the object on the table and switched on the TV, only to discover, surprisingly, that the object he placed on the table had disappeared.
yo: O gbe nnkan ajeji naa si ori aga igbennkanle, o si tan ero amohunmaworan, kayefi lo je fun un, ohun ti o gbe sori aga di awati.

en: He turned the entire room upside down and finally found it in a corner of the house.
yo: O tu gbogbo ile ki o to wa ri i ni koro ile.

en: That night, he slept with the object under his pillow. He told Global Voices:
yo: Lale ojo yen, o fi nnkan ajeji naa sabe igberi sun. O so fun Ohun Agbaye:

en: I had a dream that I visited the sun.
yo: Mo lalaa wi pe mo lo si inu oorun.

en: When I got to the sun, it was dark and I was shown the alphabet in the form of lightning.
yo: Nigba ti mo debe, o okunkun su bole, a si fi alifabeeti naa han mi ni apeere imole.

en: Every time I slept, I had similar dreams, going from planet to planet, teaching people how to use the script...
yo: Igbakuugba ti mo ba sun, ala yii kan naa ni ni ona ara, mo n lo lati agbegbe kan si agbegbe miiran, ti mo si n ko awon eniyan bi a ti se n lo isowoko tuntun naa...

en: For three years, he kept dreaming about the alphabet, seeing visions consecutively, yet he did nothing about it.
yo: Fun odun meta, ko ye lalaa nipa alifabeeti naa, ko ye riran leralera, sibe ko se nnkankan si i.

en: This time around, in 2016, I went to the sun again, I met a man, Lamurudu, who taught me the sound of the alphabet, he afterward sanctioned me to go all over the globe teaching people the mastery of the symbols.
yo: Lasiko yii, ni odun 2016, mo tun lo si inu oorun, mo salabaapade okunrin kan, Lamurudu, ti o ko mi ni iro alifabeeti naa, ti o si pa a lase fun mi pe ki tan imole imo kiko ati kika ami isowoko naa kari aye.

en: I usually look old in my dreams - and tired - when I wake up from sleep.
yo: Mo maa n jo arugbo loju ala - ti yoo si re mi - bi mo ba ji loju oorun.

en: Things started to become scary for Chief Oguntosin - he began to feel weak, he told Global Voices.
yo: O wa bere si ni di eru fun Oloye Oguntosin - o n re e latinu wa, o wi fun Ohun Agbaye.

en: He decided to narrate his dreams to a close spiritual adviser, Onikoyi, king of Ajase in Port-Novo, who counseled him to do what he was instructed in his dreams.
yo: O pinnu lati ro awon ala naa fun Onikoyi, Alajase ti Ajase ni Port-Novo, eni ti o la a loye pe ki o se bi a ti pa a lase loju ala.

en: For this reason, he now travels from place to place in Yorubaland to pass on his knowledge of the Oduduwa alphabet.
yo: Latari idi eyi, o n se irinajo lati agbegbe kan de omiran ni Ile-Yoruba lati tan imo alifabeeti Oduduwa naa.

en: The following is a short video of teachers instructing students how to write the Oduduwa alphabet in a Benin classroom:
yo: Aworan-atohun awon olukoni ti o ko awon akekoo bi a ti se n ko alifabeeti Oduduwa ni yara-igbeko kan ni Bene:

en: Promoting theYoruba alphabet
yo: Igbelaruge alifabeeti Yoruba naa

en: In 2017, Chief Oguntosin, in the company of prominent traditional rulers in Yorubaland and the diaspora, paid a visit to Rauf Aregbesola, the one-time governor of Nigeria's Osun State, in Osogbo, the state capital, to solicit support for his newly found Oduduwa alphabet.
yo: Lodun 2017, Oloye Oguntosin, pelu awon oba Alase igba-keji orisa Ile-Yoruba nile ati leyin odi, se abewo to si Ogbeni Rauf Aregbesola, eni ti o fi igba kan ri je alakooso Ipinle Osun, ni olu ipinle naa th Osogbo, e one- ede Naijiria, lati beere fun atileyin fun alifabeeti Oduduwa tuntun naa.

en: Aregbesola now serves as the Minister of the Federal Ministry of Interior of Nigeria.
yo: Aregbesola ni Minisita fun Eto Abele fun orile-ede Naijiria ni saa ti a wa yii.

en: A reminder letter was sent to the governor of Osun state after promises made to teach the new alphabet have gone unfulfilled.
yo: Iwe ti a ko ranse si gomina ipinle Osun ni iranti awon ipinnu kiko alifabeeti tuntun naa ti ko tii wa si imuse.

en: Three years later, regrettably, verbal promises made by former governor Aregbesola to teach the discovered alphabet in elementary schools across southwest Nigeria have gone unfulfilled.
yo: Odun meta ti lo, o bani lokan je, ileri ti gomina ana Aregbesola se lati ri daju wi pe alifabeeti tuntun naa je kiko ni awon ileewe ti o n be ni Iwo-oorun guusu ile Naijiria ko tii di mumu se.

en: In a bid to make the Oduduwa alphabet popular, Chief Oguntosin has written a book and produced a documentary on the orthography - with snippets uploaded on the internet for public viewing - as well as an abandoned cartoon project which did not see the light of day due to lack of funds.
yo: Lojuna ki alifabeeti Oduduwa naa o ba di ilumooka, Oloye Oguntosin ti ko iwe kan, o si ti ka aworan-atohun alalaye kan ti o tu perepeere isowoko alifabeeti tuntun naa sile - fun mutumuwa lati wo ni abalaabala lori ayelujara - bakan naa ni epatiri ise akonilogbon katuunu fun awon ewe ti ko s'owo lati pari i re naa o gbeyin.

en: "Chief Oguntosin also uses YouTube, WhatsApp and Facebook Groups: ""Eko Aeebaejiogbe Oduduwa"" and ""Oduduwa Alphabets"" to promote and teach interested language learners."
yo: "Oloye Oguntosin n lo gbagbe YouTube, WhatsApp ati Egbe ori Facebook: ""Eko Aeebaejiogbe Oduduwa"" ati ""Alifabeeti Oduduwa"" fi se igbelaruge ati ko awon akekoo ti o nifee si kiko ilana isowoko naa."

en: He calls on all stakeholders to support the promotion of his linguistic discovery that will checkmate Western writing culture and give the Yoruba people their deserved identity in terms of language development.
yo: O ro gbogbo eni ti oran kan lati dide si ti igbelaruge awari ti yoo gba ilana isowoko Amunisin ti segbee ti yoo si fun iran Yoruba ni idanimo ti o to ti o ni se pelu idagbasoke ede.

en: "A kind-hearted Yoruba man, Sunday Adeniyi, supported the cause by printing 1,000 copies of the ""Aeebaejiogbe Oduduwa Alphabets"" exercise book for primary school pupils."
yo: "Okunrin oninuure kan, Sunday Adeniyi, se agbateru itejade 1,000 eda iwe igbeko ""Alifabeeti Aeebaejiogbe Oduduwa"" fun awon omo ileewe alakoobere."

en: Read more: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yoruba - and other languages - wrong
yo: Ka si i: Sisonu sinu ogbufo: Idi ti Atumo Google se n kuna - ninu titumo ede Yoruba - ati awon ede miiran

en: Copies of the educational pamphlets were printed in Igbo, Hausa, English, and French languages respectively. However, more support is crucial to disseminate the alphabet to a wider audience.
yo: Eda iwe eko alifabeeti naa wa ni ede Igbo, Hausa, English, ati Faranse leseese. Sibesibe, atileyin ki i po ju fun ipinkari alifabeeti naa.

en: The Oduduwa alphabet is a welcome development.
yo: Igbese ti o mu iwuri dani ni alifabeeti Oduduwa naa.

en: Nevertheless, the shift from writing in Latin to the new system will be a major challenge.
yo: Sugbon, sisun lati ilana Latiini si ilana tuntun ni yoo mu ipenija nla lowo.

en: That said, the Oduduwa alphabet is a great step in the right direction toward the development and growth of the Yoruba language - in what Yoruba people will call their own.
yo: Ko je bo se je, ohun ti yoo mu ilosiwaju ati idagbasoke ba ede Yoruba ni alifabeeti Oduduwa - ohun ti iran Yoruba yoo pe ni tiwa-n-tiwa.

en: Yoruba loanwords: How languages evolve
yo: Oro ayalo ninu ede Yoruba: Bi ede se yi pada

en: Do you say akara or bean cake?
yo: Se akara ni o n pe abi bean cake?

en: Akara or Nigerian bean cake is a staple breakfast in Nigeria, July 11, 2013. Photo by Atimukoh via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
yo: Akara tabi beans cake ni Naijiria je ounje aaro ni Naijiria, ojo 11, osu keje, odun 2013. Aworan lati owo Atimukoh lati ori i Wikimedia Commons, ase CC BY 2.0.

en: Relationships between languages have existed for hundreds of years.
yo: Ajosepo laaarin oniruuru ede ti wa lati ayebaye.

en: "Think of the word ""restaurant,"" borrowed from the French language into English."
yo: "Fun akawe, ki a wo gbolohun bi i ""restaurant,"" ti o je oro ti a ya lati inu ede Faranse wa sinu ede Geesi."

en: Today, this loanword - a word adopted from one language into another without translation - circulates in English as if it was never borrowed.
yo: Lode oni, oro-ayalo yii - iyen gbolohun ti a gba lo lati inu ede kan si inu ede miiran lai tu imo re - ko l'onka ninu ede Geesi afi bi eni pe ki i se oro ti a ya lo.

en: These linguistic borrowings can be attributed to immigration, commerce, and trade as people were exposed to a wide range of ethnolinguistic environments.
yo: Awon ede ayalo wonyi waye latari abapade oniruuru eniyan kari aye, bi won se n sikiri, se oro Aje, ati karakata.

en: Through these interactions, people were exposed to various linguistic contexts, and words and phrases were borrowed to accommodate these encounters.
yo: Latari itakuroso ti o waye laaarin awon oniruuru eniyan wonyi, ede wonu ede, gbolohun ati apola oro di ayalo.

en: The Yoruba case is no exception.
yo: Isele yii ko yo iran Yoruba sile.

en: Spoken widely by about 40 million speakers in Nigeria, Yoruba language has been influenced by the English language spoken by the British, who held colonial power in Nigeria from 1914 to 1960.
yo: O to egbeegberun eniyan 40 tio n fo ede Yoruba ni orile ede Naijiria, iru ede Yoruba ti dapo mo sapala ede Geesi, ti i se ede ijoba amunisin ana lati odun 1914 si 1960.

en: "More than half of the vocabulary words used in Yoruba are borrowed from English. Think of the word ""cup,"" it was domesticated as koopu."
yo: "O to idaji gbolohun ede Geesi ti a ya lo ninu ede Yoruba. Ki a wo oro bi i ""cup"" O di koopu."

en: "The word ""phone"" is foonu, ""ball"" is boolu, and ""television"" is telifisoonu, among others."
yo: "A pe ""phone"" ni foonu, ""ball"" di boolu, ""television"" ni telifisoonu, ati bee bee lo."

en: "These English words that were ""loaned"" to Yoruba expanded its vocabulary over time."
yo: "Awon gbolohun ""ayalo"" wonyi mu ede Yoruba feju si i."

en: There are also instances of the Yoruba language borrowing words from the Hausa language, spoken by 44 million people in the northern part of Nigeria.
yo: Bakan naa ni awon oro ayalo inu ede Hausa ti awon egbeegberun 44 eniyan ni Ariwa ile Naijiria n so lo sua.

en: "This language borrows heavily from Arabic, as well, with words like alubarika (""blessing""), alubosa (""onion"") and wahala (""trouble"")."
yo: "Ede yii ya oke aimoye oro lo lati inu ede Larubawa, awon oro bi i alubarika (""ibukun""), albasa (""alubosa"") ati wahala (""iyonu"")."

en: The beauty of Yoruba loanwords is that speakers now use them in their day-to-day conversations as they get absorbed into the language.
yo: Ohun ti o je iwuri ni ti awon oro ayalo ninu ede Yoruba ni bi awon eniyan se n lo won ninu itakuroso lojoojumo bi won se n san wo inu ede naa.

en: "It is not uncommon to hear people say, Ba omo yen mu boolu e or ""Help the child take the ball"" in English."
yo: "Wa a gbo gbolohun bi i, Ba omo yen mu boolu e tabi ""Help the child take the ball"" lede Geesi."

en: Although the underlined word boolu is not native to the Yoruba language, speakers manage to make it fit.
yo: Adi, omo-oro ti a fala si labe boolu je tiwantiwa ninu ede Yoruba, awon asafo mo bi won se n lo o.

en: One of the challenges with the Yoruba language with regard to loanwords is that native speakers themselves love translating Yoruba words into English and using them in sentences instead of the original Yoruba word.
yo: Ipenija kan ti ede Yoruba ni nipa ti oro ayalo o ju ti ogbufo oro wuuru ti awon asafo ede Yoruba maa n se lati tumo awon gbolohun ede Yoruba si ti Geesi ti won maa n lo ninu ipede dipo ojulowo ede Yoruba.

en: An example is the word akara - most Yoruba speakers translate it to bean cake in daily interactions - , especially with foreigners.
yo: Fun apeere, akara - ti awon omo Yoruba ti tumo si bean cake - paapaa ninu iforojomitoro-oro pelu alejo.

en: Using words in their original forms helps ensure that culture - kept alive through language - continues to thrive.
yo: Lilo oro ni ede ponbele maa n mu ki asa - o gbooro - ti yoo si maa je ki ede o di itewogba.

en: For instance, no one calls Japan's sushi by any other name - sushi is sushi.
yo: Bi a ba wo o bayii, ko s'eni je pe sushi Japan loruko miiran - sushi ni sushi n je.

en: If this was the case for many Yoruba words, too, its language and culture could flourish beyond Nigeria and the Yoruba-speaking world.
yo: Bi eyi ba ri bee fun awon oro Yoruba naa, ede ati asa re, yoo gbile koja orile-ede Naijiria ati ibi ti won ti n fo ede Yoruba kari aye.

en: For example, amala is a famous Yoruba food, even in the diaspora.
yo: Fun apeere, amala je ounje ti o ile Yoruba lokiki, paapaa ni oke okun.

en: This word could easily find its way into the lexicon of other languages if Yoruba speakers insisted on it.
yo: Gbolohun yii ti ra pala wonu ilo oro ede miiran bi awon asafo Yoruba ba tenu mo on.

en: "Translating it to ""yam flour"" lessens its status and linguistic root - its ""Yorubaness."""
yo: "Titumo re si ""yam flour"" din agbara ipede naa ku - yoo so ""ipo Yoruba nu."""

en: "Think of the anglicized Yoruba word ""fanimorious,"" which is becoming more popular and appears in the Urban Dictionary."
yo: "Bi a ba wo gbolohun ede Geesi ti a yi pada si ede Yoruba ""fanimorious,"" ti o ti n lokiki ti o si ti wa ninu Iwe Itumo Igbalode."

en: "It means ""appealing,"" or ""beautiful,"" and comes from the word fanimora in Yoruba."
yo: "O tumo si ""bojumu,"" tabi ""rewa,"" ti o suyo lati fanimora ti i se gbolohun Yoruba."

en: This could be phono-morphological: Yoruba language does not allow final word consonants and consonant clusters.
yo: Eyi f'ara pe ibasepo fonoloji ati mofoloji: ede Yoruba ki i faye gba ihunpo konsonanti ati ki oro pari pelu konsonanti.

en: As a result, the English suffix -ious was added to the Yoruba root word.
yo: Tori idi eyi, a fi afomo ipari -ious ede Geesi kun oro ipile Yoruba.

en: However, the fact remains that the word stems from the Yoruba language. This is a win for the Yoruba.
yo: Sibe, otito farahan wipe lati ara ede Yoruba ni o ti su yo. Igbega ni eyi je fun Yor Yoruba.

en: Recently, several other Nigerian English words were added to the Oxford English Dictionary.
yo: Ni ko pe ko pe yii, ogoro ede Geesi bi a ti se n lo o ni Naijiria di afikun ninu iwe itumo ede Geesi ti Oxford.

en: Yoruba will make giant strides only if its speakers contribute to its growth; Its usage in the media is also important as the world becomes increasingly more digitized.
yo: Opon ede Yoruba yoo sun siwaju bi awon to n fo ede naa ba lowo si idagbasoke re; ilo re ninu ise ikoroyin pon dandan ni ibamu pelu bi aye se n lu jara won bi ajere lode oni.

en: Consequently, this will spur further research on the Niger-Congo language.
yo: Ni ipari, eyi yoo tubo mu ki ise iwadii ede Niger-Congo o rinle.

en: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yoruba - and other languages - wrong
yo: Sisonu sinu ogbufo: Idi ti Atumo Google se n kuna - ninu titumo ede Yoruba - ati awon ede miiran

en: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong
yo: Opolopo ogbufo ti ero se ni ko nitumo.

en: Wikimedia User Group Nigeria, October 2018 via Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.
yo: Asamulo Egbe Wikimedia Orile-ede Naijiria, osu Owara odun 2018 lati ori Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.

en: "The English language has dominated online discourse as the ""universal"" language of communication since the inception of the internet."
yo: "Ede Geesi ti je gaba lori ibanisoro ti o n waye ni ori ero ayelukara-bi-ajere gege bi ede ""gbogbo agbaye"" fun itakuroso lati ibere pepe ero ayelujara."

en: As of February 2020, over half of the websites on the internet are in English, according to WebTech3.
yo: Ninu osu Erele odun 2020, gege bi WebTech3 ti se fi han, idaji ibudo itakun agbaye to wa lori ayelujara ni a ko ni ede Geesi.

en: But as more people get online who speak different languages, it has sparked a linguistic digital revolution - immediate access to English translations of multiple languages with the click of a button.
yo: Amo bi opolopo eniyan ti o n so orisiirisii ede agbaye se n bo sori ayelukara-bi-ajere, o se eta ija fun ede eni - iraaye si isogbufo si oniruuru ede ti yoo se ni monawaa.

en: Many tech companies have recently put effort into documenting non-English words on the internet, paving the way for the digitization of multiple languages. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT and ALC are examples of companies and start-ups that have been trying to marry technology with non-English languages.
yo: Opolopo ileese onimo ero ti se ise ribiribi ni ti isakosile awon oro ti ki i se ede Geesi sori ayelujara, ti o n se olulana oniruuru ede lori ero ayarabiasa lona igbalode. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT ati ALC je apeere awon ileese nla ati awon ileese kereje ti o sese bere ti o ti mu imo-ero sise po pelu awon ede ti ki i se ede Geesi.

en: In late February 2020, Google announced that it would add five new languages to its Google Translate services, including Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen and Odia, after a four-year hiatus on adding new languages.
yo: Ki osu Erele odun 2020 o to tenu bepo, Google filo wipe oun yoo fi ede tuntun marun-un kun ise Atumo Google re, awon ede naa ni Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen ati Odia, leyin isinmi odun merin ti won fi ede tuntun kun un keyin.

en: A man looks perplexed while reading a text online. Photo by Oladimeji Ajegbile, open-source via Pexels.
yo: Okunrin kan n wo bi eni ti o nidaamu nigba ti o n ka gbolohun oro lori ayelujara. Aworanllati owo Oladimeji Ajegbile, ase-atunlo lati ori Pexels.

en: But have you ever clicked on the translation option and realized that the English translation is, at best, just OK?
yo: Amo se o ti sira te asayan itumo ri ti o sakiyesi wipe, bakan, lo dara ju lo?

en: And at worst, not accurate at all?
yo: Bakan naa, lo ku die kaato, ko se deedee?

en: There are many controversies and difficulties when it comes to doing this kind of language translation and access work.
yo: Orisiirisii ariyanjiyan ati isoro lo maa n waye bi o ba kan iru itumo ede bayii ati riri i lo.

en: Twitter offers Yoruba language translation into English via Google Translate as much as possible, and usually, the outcome isn't totally bad - perhaps a few words are correct.
yo: Twitter maa n se itumo ede Yoruba si ede Geesi nipase lilo Atumo Google bi o ti se faye gba won, ti abajade re si ku die kaato nigbagbogbo - ti awon oro kookan si se deedee.

en: The reason for these challenges is that tech companies usually collect their linguistic data for English translation sourced from the internet.
yo: Ohun ti o fa awon ipenija wonyi o ju pe ori ayelujara ni awon ileese onimo ero ti maa n se akojo ede won for ti won n fi se ogbufo gbolohun oro.

en: This data may work for some languages, but languages like Yoruba and Igbo, two main languages from Nigeria, are challenging, due to the inadequate or inaccurate accent marks to indicate tones on these words.
yo: Awon akojo gbolohun oro wonyi le sise fun awon ede kan, amo ede bi i Yoruba ati Igbo, je ede meji ni orile-ede Naijiria, ti ipenija yii ba, latari aipoto gbolohun oro ati gbolohun ti a o yan lorilabe daadaa ti yoo toka si iro ohun.

en: In response to why it has taken Google four years to add five new languages, a company spokesperson explained:
yo: Lati fesi si ohun ti o fa sababi ti o fi gba Google ni odun merin ki o to se afikun ede tuntun marun-un kun tile, agbenuso ileese naa se isipaya:

en: Google Translate learns from existing translations found on the web, and when languages don't have an abundance of web content, it's been difficult for our system to support them effectively.
yo: Ori itakun agbaye ni Atumo Google ti maa n sa gbolohun ti a ti tumo jo, amo bi ede ko ba ni gbolohun oro ti o po to lori ayelujara, o nira fun ero wa lati se atileyin ti o lakaaki fun iru awon ede bee

en: However, due to recent advances in our machine learning technology, and active involvement from our Google Translate Community members, we've been able to add support for these languages.
yo: Sibe, latari ilosiwaju abuda kiko ero lekoo wa, ati awon asise Itumo Google lofee, ecent advances in our machine a ti fi atileyin fun awon ede wonyi.

en: Also, most people are not so good with the orthographies - or spellings - in these languages.
yo: Bakan naa, opo eniyan ni ko mo bi a se n ko oro dajudanu - tabi pipe omo-oro - inu awon ede wonyi.

en: As a result, good translations don't compute because these errors are not flagged as inadequate.
yo: Tori naa, ogbufo ti o kunju osuwon ko je akopo nitori ko si bi a se le da awon asise wonyi mo.

en: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong, especially words that are culturally nuanced.
yo: Pupo ninu ogbufo ti ero se ni ko ni itumo, paapaa ju lo awon gbolohun ti o ro mo asa ti o ni ju itumo kan soso lo.

en: For example, Yoruba words ayaba and obabinrin have their meanings situated in a cultural context.
yo: Fun apeere, gbolohun Yoruba bi i ayaba ati obabinrin ni itumo to yato.

en: "Most machines translate both words as ""queen."""
yo: "Opolopo ero ni i maa tu imo gbolohun mejeeji si ""queen."""

en: "However, from a traditional-cum-cultural vantage point, it is essential to note that the meanings of ayaba and obabinrin are different: Obabinrin means ""queen"" in English while ayaba is ""wife of the king."""
yo: "Sibe, ti a ba ti ona ise-ati-asa wo o, o se koko lati so wi pe itumo ayaba and obabinrin yato sira won: Obabinrin tumo si ""queen"" lede Geesi nigba ti ayaba je ""wife of the king."""

en: Even with these translation complications, technology has helped with the advancement of African languages in digital spaces, spurring the coinage of new words.
yo: Pelu awon aisedeedee wonyi, imo-ero ti se iranwo fun idagbasoke awon ede Ile-Adulawo lori awon gbagede ori ayelujara, ti o ti mu iseda oro tuntun waye.

en: African languages have grown with the influx of new gadgets like smartphones and tablets, as new words are coined to name these new technological tools and concepts.
yo: Ede Ile-Adulawo ti goke agba latari awon lilo awon ero igbalode tuntun bi i ero-ilewo ati ero opon ayarabiasa, ti o si n bi awon gbolohun tuntun ti a fi n pe awon irinse imo-ero tuntun wonyi.

en: This process has thus expanded the usage and functionality of these languages.
yo: Eyi si ti fe bi a ti se n lo awon ede wonyi loju.

en: With the emergence of new technologies, the vocabularies of many African languages have become more sophisticated.
yo: Latari awon ero tuntun wonyi, ipede opolopo ede Ile-Adulawo ti le kun si i.

en: "For instance, the Yoruba language has some tech-influenced words such as ero amuletutu (""air conditioner""), ero Ibanisoro (""phone"") and ero Ilota (""grinder"")."
yo: "Fun apeere, ede Yoruba ni awon gbolohun ti o ni se pelu imo-ero bi i ero-amuletutu (""air conditioner""), ero-ibanisoro (""phone"") and ero-ilota (""grinder"")."

en: "Similarly, the Igbo language has words such as ekwe nti (""telephone"") and ugbo ala (""vehicle"")."
yo: "Ewewe, ede Igbo naa ni oro bi i ekwe nti (""telephone"") ati ugbo ala (""vehicle"")."

en: These societies have given these gadgets names based on the functions they perform.
yo: A seda awon oruko yii ni ibamu pelu ise ti won n se.

en: In courses on broadcasting and advertisement in Yoruba, students learn that most people call TV ero Amohunmaworan.
yo: Ninu eko imo igbohunsafefe ati eto ipolowo oja lede Yoruba, awon akekoo ti ko wi pe ero-amohunmaworan ni oopolopo eniyan n pe TV.

en: This coinage generates many questions and opinions - some students argue that video cameras and recorders can also be called ero amohunmaworan based on their functionalities.
yo: Iseda oro yii fa awon oniruuru ibeere ati ero - awon akekoo kan jiyan wi pe a le pe ero-ayaworan naa ni ero-amohunmaworan nitori ise ti won n se.

en: These linguistic challenges in the tech space are healthy for languages - it stimulates critical thinking for both linguistic and tech advancement.
yo: Awon ipenija t'o tara imo-ero wa yii ni yoo mu idagbasoke ba ede - o maa n fa arojinle fun igbega ede ati imo-ero.

en: "In 2019, Google opened its first AI research center in Accra, Ghana, focused on improving ""Google Translate's ability to capture African languages more precisely,"" according to CNN."
yo: "Lodun 2019, gege bi CNN ti se royin, Google si ibise iwadii AI akoko iru e si Accra, Ghana, ti o n lepa lati mu ki ""Atumo Google o gba awon ede Ile-Adulawo jo ki o lo geere."""

en: "Research scientist Moustapha Cisse, who heads Google's AI work in Africa, believes that ""a continent with more than 2,000 dialects deserves to be better served,"" as reported by CNN."
yo: "Onimo ijinle nipa ise iwadii Moustapha Cisse, to je olori ise Google AI ni Ile-Adulawo, nigbagbo wi pe o to si ""ile ti o ni ju eka-ede 2,000 lo lati je anfaani ise,"" - CNN jabo."

en: Mozilla and BMZ recently announced their cooperation to open up voice technology for African languages. With initiatives like this, there is more to show in the future with regards to studies in African languages.
yo: Mozilla ati BMZ kede ajumose won lati se agbateru ise akanse ti o da firigbagboo lori imo-ero alohun fun thei ede Ile-Adulawo. Pelu awon ise atinuda bi eleyii, ojo iwaju iwadii ede Ile-Adulawo dara.

en: Churches in Greece and North Macedonia refuse to modify rituals conducive to the spread of COVID-19
yo: Awon Ileejosin ni Greece ati Ariwa Macedonia ko lati yi owo awon ilana-isin won pada k'o ba ma faye gba ajakale arun COVID-19 t'o n ran ka

en: """Institution of the Eucharist,"" a 1442 painting by Fra Angelico. Public Domain photo via Wikipedia."
yo: """Ajo Ounje Ale Oluwa,"" aworan ti a kun loda ni 1442 lati owo Fra Angelico. Aworan ti ko ni olohun lati ori Wikipedia."

en: While the number of people with COVID-19 steadily increases in the Balkans, a few Christian churches have refused to change liturgical practices that can contribute to the spread of the coronavirus.
yo: Bi awon ti o ti ko arun COVID-19 se n poo si i ni Balkans, awon ile ijosin kan ko yi owo awon ilana isin ti o le mu ki arun Coronavirus o ran bi i papa inu oye pada.

en: The ritual known as the Holy Communion or Eucharist has Orthodox Christian worshipers drinking consecrated wine by a shared spoon, while Catholics eat thin slices of bread directly from the hand of the priest.
yo: Ilana isin ti a mo si Jijeara ati mimu eje Oluwa tabi Ounje Ikeyin ni eyi ti awon omo leyin Kristi ti o n tele ilana isin atijo yoo maa pin waini ti a ti so di mimo mu pelu sibi kan naa, awon Ijo Agudaa maa n je ebe akara felefele ti won fi enu gba lowo alufaa.

en: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding large gatherings and increased levels of personal hygiene and sanitation in order to minimize the spread of the virus by touch, exchange of bodily fluids, and through the air.
yo: Ajo Ilera Agbaye (WHO) ro wa lati jina gbegberegbe si ibi ti awon eroo ba piti si, ki a si karamasiki si ilera ara wa ki a ba din aranka arun eje ti eniyan le ko nipase ifowokan, ifarakan omi to sun lara elomiran, ati lati inu afefe.

en: In an official statement dated March 9, the Greek Orthodox Church said it will not be modifying the ritual to comply with safety measures.
yo: Ninu atejade ojo 9, Ileejosin Atijo Greek so wi pe oun ko ni yi owo ilana-isin pada ki o ba igbese aabo mu.

en: "It also added that the ""coronavirus is not transmitted via Holy Communion, and the faithful should pray against the spread of the deadly virus."""
yo: "Bakan naa ni o so wi pe ""a ko lee ko aarun coronavirus lati ara Jije ara-ati-mimu-eje Oluwa, ati pe ki awon omo Olorun o gbadura gidi nitori aarun apaniyan naa."""

en: GOC bishop Klimis, the Metropolitan of Peristeri, a suburban municipality near Athens, said that those who believe the virus could spread via religious rituals are blasphemers:
yo: Bisoopu ti GOC Klimis, ti Aarin gbungbun Peristeri, labe agbegbe to sun mo Athens, so wi pe oro-odi si Oluwa ni bi enikeni ba so pe ilana esin le mu ki aarun o ran:

en: The Holy Communion is life.
yo: Iye ni Ara-jije ati eje mimu.

en: It is a miracle.
yo: Ise iyanu ni.

en: It is a blasphemy to believe that the virus can be transmitted by receiving Holy Communion.
yo: Oro-odi si Oluwa ni lati ni igbagbo wi pe eniyan le tara Jije ara-ati-mimu-eje Oluwa ko aarun.

en: There have been 89 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Greece, with no deaths so far.
yo: Eniyan 89 lo ti lugbadi COVID-19 ni Greece, laisi eni to ku.

en: Greek authorities, who have recently closed schools and prohibited gatherings in efforts to prevent transmission, urged the Church to reconsider.
yo: Awon alase Greek, ti o ti san awon ileewe pa, ti o si ti f'ofin de apejo loju ona ati dena ajakale, ro Ileejosin naa lati se atunwo.

en: But state officials themselves seem to be ignoring those concerns. On a major religious holiday last Sunday, the president and some government ministers attended a public mass.
yo: Amo awon asoju ijoba tikarawon n tapa si ofin idena aarun yii. Lojo isinmi ajemesin kan lojo Ose to koja, aare ati awon onipo ninu isejoba re lo si isin kan.

en: In neighboring North Macedonia, the Macedonian Orthodox Church - Ohrid Archbishopric seems to be following a similar path.
yo: Ni ilu to mule gbe Greece, o jo pe North Macedonia, Ileejosin Atijo ti Macedonia - Ohrid Archbishopric naa n to ipase kan naa.

en: Although the church has not yet issued any official statement about the outbreak, it has continued to conduct the Holy Communion normally.
yo: Bi o tile je pe Ileejosin naa ko tii se ifilo kankan nipa ajakale naa, o si n fun awon omo ijo ni Ara je ati eje mu bi o ti maa n se.

en: "Alarms were raised when the official website of the Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese published a translated article by Russian website Pravoslavie.ru (meaning ""Orthodox Christianity"") claiming it's ""impossible for believers to be infected during church rituals."""
yo: "Iroyin kan nigba ti ojule ibudo itakun Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese se atejade ogbufo article aroko ibudo itakun to je ti Russia iyen Pravoslavie.ru (itumo ""Esin Igbagbo Atijo "") to n so wi pe ""ko le se e se ki awon onigbagbo o k'arun lati ara ilana-isin ijo."""

en: The text is signed by Russian priest Sergey Adonin, who claims to have knowledge of microbiology and experience working in hospitals.
yo: Alufaa Sergey Adonin ti Russia lo buwo lu apileko naa, eni to so pe oun ni imo nipa iseda eda oniye aifojuri pelu iriri ise ni ileewosan.

en: "He stressed in the article that the rule of using the same spoon instituted in the 7th century Bizantium has so far done no harm, because ""faith in God protects both the parishioners and the priests."""
yo: "O so siwaju si i ninu apileko naa wi pe lilo sibi kan naa bi won ti se fi lole ni ogorun-un odun keje aye Bizantium o fa ipalara, nitori ""igbagbo ninu Olorun n fi iso aabo bo alufaa ati omo ijo."""

en: Also in North Macedonia, right-wing propagandists expressed support to the church.
yo: Ni North Macedonia, awon ti o n mu se ti ilana-isin naa ni ko si aburu ninu ilana ileejosin naa.

en: For instance, one conservative TV host - who in the past promoted anti-vax activists - boasted on Twitter to have participated in risky religious rituals:
yo: Fun apeere, atokun eto lori ero amohunmaworan to je adasa-atijo-mu-sinsin - ajijangbara eni to ti fi igba kan ri se ipolongo itako ibupa - funnu lori Twitter wi pe oun ti kopa ninu awon ilana-isin ajemesin to lewu:

en: Tweet: I received Holy Communion last Sunday in the Church of Holy Annunciation which is part of the Clinical Center in Skopje and will do it again!
yo: Tuwiiti: Mo je Ara Oluwa mu eje Oluwa lojo Aiku to koja ninu Ileejosin Holy Annunciation ti o wa ninu Ileewosan ti Skopje ti n o si tun se e!

en: What's your problem?
yo: Ki ni isoro re?

en: Link title: In spite of the appeal by health authorities: Believers received Holy Communion without fear from the coronavirus.
yo: Akole adari: Pelu gbogbo ebe ajo to n ri si eto ilera: Awon onigbagbo je Ara mu eje Oluwa lai foya fun aarun coronavirus.

en: "Sladjana Velkov, an anti-vax celebrity operating in Serbia and North Macedonia, recently declared that the situation is ""not serious"" and that the new virus is ""just a common cold which, like the other common colds, affects only older people or people with compromised immunity."""
yo: "Sladjana Velkov, eni to gbajumo gege bi alatako-ibupa to n sise ni Serbia ati Ariwa Macedonia, so lai pe yii wi pe nnkan ko ""le toyen"" ati pe ""ofinkin lasan ni, eyi ti ko yato si ofinkin ti a ti mo tele, to maa n se awon agbalagba tabi awon ti ilera ara won ko pe to."""

en: Meanwhile from Italy, where over 631 people have died from the infection and more than 10,000 are affected, this user tweeted:
yo: Ni orile-ede Italy, nibi ti 631 emi eeyan 631 ti bo ti awon ti o to 10,000 ti lugbadi arun naa, asamulo kan tuwiiti:

en: So far there have been seven confirmed cases of COVID-19 in North Macedonia; 25 in Slovenia; 13 in Croatia; six in Albania; five in Serbia; five in Bosnia; and zero in Montenegro.
yo: Bi a ba ka a ni menimeji, o ti to eni meje ti o ti ko arun COVID-19 ni North Macedonia; 25 ni Slovenia; 13 ni Croatia; mefa ni Albania; fi marun-un ni Serbia; marun-un ni Bosnia; odo ni Montenegro.

en: There have been 28 cases in Romania and six in Bulgaria.
yo: O ti to eni 28 to ti ko o ni Romania, mefa ni Bulgaria.

en: Christians elsewhere
yo: Onigbagbo nibi gbogbo

en: The world has already witnessed how the novel coronavirus can spread through religious congregations.
yo: Ile aye ti ri bi coronavirus akoko iru e se le ran nibi ipejo ajemesin.

en: Last month, a majority of 7,400 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in South Korea - a country that until then seemed to have the outbreak under control - were traced to the group Shincheonji Church of Jesus.
yo: Losu to koja, opo eniyan ti o to 7,400 ni a gbo wi pe o ti ni arun apaniyan COVID-19 ni South Korea - orile-ede ti o jo pe o ti n gba arun naa mole - ri arun naa lara Ileejosin egbe Shincheonji ti Jesu.

en: Criminal charges were filed against the sect - often called a cult - and its 88-year-old leader publicly apologized.
yo: A fi esun odaran kan egbe naa - ti won maa n pe ni igbe-imule - olori egbe naa ti i se eni 8-odun wa sita lati se itoro aforiji.

en: Meanwhile, the Orthodox Diocese of Korea announced changes in its liturgical practices in accordance with the recommendations of the Ministry of Health:
yo: Ni tire, Ajo Ilana-isin Atijo ti Korea se ifilo nipa awon ayipada to de ba isin re ni ibamu pelu afilele Ileese Eto Ilera:

en: 1. During the Divine Liturgy all believers will wear masks.
yo: 1. Gbogbo onigbagbo yoo wo ibomubenu lasiko ti isin ba n lo lowo.

en: 2. Before entering the Church, they will disinfect their hands with a disinfectant present at the entrance of the Church.
yo: 2. Ki won o wo Ileejosin, won yoo fi apakokoro to wa lenu abawole Ileejosin ra owo won.

en: 3. They will not shake hands with anyone.
yo: 3. Won ko ni gba enikan lowo.

en: 4. They will not kiss the hand of the Clergy.
yo: 4. Won ko ni f'enu ko Alufaa ijo lowo.

en: 5. They will not kiss the Icons, but they will bow before them.
yo: 5. Won ko ni fenu ko awon Ere, amo won o teriba niwaju won.

en: 6. They will not use the liturgical books at the time of prayer.
yo: 6. Won ko ni lo awon iwe adura nigba isin.

en: 7. They will not receive the Antidoron from the Clergy, but on their own as they leave the church.
yo: 7. Won ko ni gba Akara lowo Alufaa ijo, amo funra won bi won ba n jade kuro ninu ileejosin.

en: 8. The Agape Meal will not be served following the Sunday Liturgy.
yo: 8. Ounje Apeje Ife ko ni je pinpin lojo Aiku.

en: 9. The various group meetings of the Faithful as well as the Catechumens will not take place.
yo: 9. Awon ipade elegbejegbe ati ti awon to n ko isin Olorun ko ni waye.

en: Some churches in Europe have adopted similar measures, such as the Catholic church in Italy.
yo: Awon ile ijosin kan ni Ile Geesi ti n se ayipada si ilana isin won, bi i ijo Aguda ti Italy.

en: The diocese in Croatia have also enacted restrictive rules and, in France, a pilgrimage site in the city of Lourdes has been shut down.
yo: Ajo esin igbagbo Croatia naa en ti s'ofin to da le arun naa, ni France, ibi irinajo mimo kan ni ilu Lourdes ti di titi pa.

en: "The Orthodox Church of Romania issued a decree announcing ""exceptional measures taken only because of the threat of an epidemic"":"
yo: "Ileejosin Ilana-isin Atijo ti Romania fi ofin kan sita ""to je awon igbese ti eniyan yoo tele bi ajakale ba dukoko"":"

en: Believers who are afraid of virus transmission may temporarily refrain from kissing the holy icons in the churches.
yo: Awon onigbagbo tiberubojo arun apaniyan naa ti sojo s'okan won yoo pa ifenuko awon ere inu ile ijosin lara.

en: They can exceptionally ask the priest to use their own spoon for the Holy Communion.
yo: Bi o ba wu won, won lee so fun alufaa wi pe sibi ti won ni awon fe lo fi gba Eje Oluwa mu.

en: After Italy enacted a complete lockdown on national territory, other European states, like the Czech Republic also took more drastic measures on March 10, such as the closure of schools.
yo: Leyin ti Italy pase pe ki gbogbo origun mereerin ilu o di sise pa, awon alamuulegbe, bi i Ile Olominira Czech naa gbe awon agbekale kan lojo 10, osu Erena ti won san awoniileewe pa.

en: The Government of North Macedonia declared a state of emergency and also shut down kindergardens, schools, and universities for two weeks.
yo: Ijoba North Macedonia kede ipo ilu o f'ara ro, o si ti awon jeleosinmi, ileewe, titi kan ileewe giga ju lo Ifasitii pa fun ose meji.

en: "Check out Global Voices"" special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19."
yo: Check Ye awon ise akanse Ohun Agbaye lori arapa COVID-19 lagbaaye.

en: Nigeria enforces travel bans amid sloppy management of COVID-19 cases
yo: Orile-Ede Naijiria fi ofin de irin-ajo lojuna isamojuto awon to ti ko kokoro aifojuri COVID 19

en: Travel ban on 13 countries with over 1,000 cases of COVID-19
yo: Ifofinderinajo awon orile-ede 13 ti eniyan to ti ko COVID-19 ju 1,000 lo

en: Image by Pete Linforth from Pixabay. Used under a Pixabay license, public use.
yo: Aworan lati owo Pete Linforth ni Pixabay. Ilo aworan pelu ase Pixabay, fun ilo gbogboogbo.

en: "Check out Global Voices"" special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19."
yo: Ye akosile akanse Global Voices wo lori ipa COVID-19 lagbaaye.

en: Nigeria has confirmed five new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total number of coronavirus patients to eight, according to the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control.
yo: Gege bi ajo ti o n kapa itankale arun ni Naijiria se so, awon eeyan marun-un miiran ni won ti fidi re mule pe won ti ko kokoro arun COVID-19, aropo iye awon ti won ni arun naa ni Naijiria wa je mejo.

en: "The increase to eight patients came just 48 hours after Dr. E. Osagie Ehanire confirmed the third case of COVID-19, March 16, as a ""Nigerian national in her 30s who returned from a short visit to the United Kingdom on March 13"":"
yo: "Iye awon eni ti o ni kokoro arun naa di mejo ni ojo meji leyin ti dokita E. Osagie Ehanire fidi i re mule ni ojo 16, osu Erena pe won ti ri eni keta ti o ko kokoro aifojuri COVID-19, iyen ""omo orile-ede Naijiria kan ti o le ni eni ogbon ti o sese de lati United Kingdom ni ojo 13, osu Erena."""

en: The patient voluntarily began a 14-day self-isolation in Lagos, during which she developed symptoms of fever and cough.
yo: Alaisan naa ya ara re soto fun ojo 14 ni ilu Eko, laaarin asiko yii ni o bere si i ni ami aisan iba ati iko.

en: The patient is currently admitted to the Infectious Disease Hospital, Yaba, Lagos.
yo: Alaisan naa wa ni ile iwosan ti won ti n setoju Kokoro akoran ni Yaba, ni Ipinle Eko.

en: She is clinically stable and responding to treatment.
yo: Ara re ti n bale, o si n dahun si itoju daadaa.

en: As numbers of COVID-19 cases continue to rise in Nigeria, the government has yielded to public outcry on March 18 by placing travel restrictions on citizens from 13 countries with over 1,000 domestic cases of coronavirus: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, the United States, the United Kingdom, Netherlands and Switzerland.
yo: Bi i iye awon eniyan ti o ko kokoro arun COVID-19 se n po si i ni Naijiria, ijoba apapo ti gbo ohun ti awon araalu so ni ojo 18, osu Erena nipa fifi ofin de awon ti o n rin irin ajo lati orile ede 13 bi i: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, United States, United Kingdom, Netherlands ati Switzerland ti o ni ju eniyan 1000 lo ti o ti ko kokoro arun Korona lati ma wo orile-ede Naijiria.

en: Those who have already entered the country from these countries must go through a 14-day quarantine.
yo: Awon ti won ti wo Naijiria tele lati awon orile ede ti a daruko yii gbodo ya ara won soto fun ojo 14.

en: On February 27, an Italian national visiting Nigeria was confirmed as the index case for COVID-19 in the country.
yo: Ojo 27 ni osu Erele ni a fidi re mule pe omo orile ede Italy kan ti o rin irinajo wa si orile ede Naijiria je eni akoko ti o ni kokoro arun COVID-19.

en: Read more: An Italian national is the index case of COVID-19 disease in Nigeria
yo: Ka si i: Omo orile ede Italy kan ti o rin irinajo wa si orile ede Naijiria ni o koko ni kokoro arun COVID-19

en: The second confirmed case, according to the NCDC, is a contact of the index case who has now tested negative twice.
yo: Eni keji ti a fidi re mule pe o ni kokoro arun yii, gege bi NCDC se so je eni ti o rinna pade eni akoko ti o ko arun naa, ti ara re si ti ya bayii leyin ti ayewo meji ti fi han pe ayewo naa ko si lara re mo.

en: Consequently, the second case was cleared of the virus and was discharged to go home on 13th of March 2020, states the NCDC.
yo: Enikeji yii o ni arun naa mo, won si ti fi i sile ki o maa lo sile ni ojo 13 osu Erena, odun 2020, gege bii ajo NCDC se so.

en: Many Nigerian netizens have not been satisfied with the current response to COVID-19 and have called for tougher measures to prevent the spread of the pandemic in Nigeria.
yo: Bi won se n boju to arun COVID-19 ko te opo araalu lori ayelujara lorun, won si ti n beere fun awon igbese ti o lagbara lati dekun itankale arun naa ni orile ede Naijiria.

en: "Netizen Ayobami decried the slow response of the NCDC. He advised the agency to ""stop the media parade and do some work!"""
yo: "Omo ilu lori ayelujara, Ayobami kede pe igbese NCDC fale. O gba won nimoran pe ""ki won dekun sise asehan lori ayelujara ki won si bere ise!"""

en: "Gideon says it ""should scare all of us"" that COVID-19 testing is slow in Nigeria."
yo: "Gideon so pe ""o ye ki o ba wa leru"" pe sise ayewo fun kokoro arun COVID-19 n fale ni Naijiria."

en: """Restrict travelers coming in especially from countries"" affected by this virus, insists journalist Bayo Olupohunda:"
yo: """E fi ofin de awon arinrin-ajo ti o fe wole lati awon orile ede miiran"" paapaa ju lo awon ti o wa lati awon orile ede ti arun naa ti gbile, akoroyin Bayo Olupohunda naa tenumo:"

en: Dr. Whitewalker insists that a travel ban is a normal epidemiological intervention in order to stem the tide of transmission during a pandemic like this:
yo: Dr. Whitewalker naa tenpele mo on pe ko si ohun ti o buru ninu fifi ofin de awon arinrin-ajo ni akoko ti won sise isadinku itankale arun lati le dekun akoran ni asiko itankale arun bi i iru eyi.

en: "Dr. Chikwe Ihekweazu, head of NCDC, pleaded that they are ""trying VERY hard to meet all urgent needs"":"
yo: "Dr. Chikwe Ihekweazu, olori ajo NCDC, bebe pe awon n ""gbiyanju GIDI lati ri i pe awon se gbogbo ohun ti o ye ki awon se"":"

en: On March 17, the Senate, Nigeria's upper legislative house, initially called for a ban on flights from coronavirus high-risk countries like the United Kingdom and China, before extending the restrictions the following day.
yo: Ni ojo 17 osu Erena, ile igbimo asofin agba ti koko so pe ki won fi ofin de awon oko ofurufu ti o n bo lati awon orile ede ti arun naa ti gbile bi i United Kingdom ati China, ki won to duro di ojo keji ki won to fi ofin naa mule.

en: "All visitors from affected countries will undergo a ""supervised self-isolation and testing for 14 days,"" reports the Cable Nigeria."
yo: Cable Nigeria jabo gbogbo awon ti won wa lati awon orile-ede ti arun naa ti gbile ni won maa ya soto pelu abojuto fun ojo merinla.

en: The government also temporarily suspended visas-on-arrival in Nigeria.
yo: Ijoba apapo si fi ofin de fifun awon eniyan ni visa Naijiria.

en: The travel ban comes into effect on Saturday, March 21, 2020, and will last four weeks, which is open to a possible extension upon review.
yo: Ifofinderinajo naa bere ni abameta ojo 21, osu Erena, odun 2020, yoo si wa fun ose merin ti o se e se ki won sun un siwaju leyin apero.

en: "Read more: COVID-19 in Africa: ""Unprecedented levels of mobilization"" as nations brace for pandemic"
yo: "Ka si i: COVID-19 ni ile Adulawo: ""Igbaradi ti a ko ri iru re ri"" bi awon orile-ede se n mura sile fun itankale arun"

en: Several African countries have been implementing tough protocols to mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
yo: Opo awon orile-ede ni ile Adulawo ti n gbe igbese lati se adinku itankale kokoro arun COVID-19.

en: These stringent measures include placing travel restrictions on nations with high numbers of COVID-19 cases.
yo: Lara awon igbese yii ni fifi ofin de irin-ajo lati awon orile ede ti kokoro arun COVID-19 naa ti gbile lati ma se wo orile ede won.

en: Sloppy management
yo: Isamojuto ti ko peye to

en: There are reports about the inadequate and slipshod response by health officials to the COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria.
yo: Awon ijabo kan wa nipa bi isamojuto awon osise eleto ilera ko se peye to lori awon to ni kokoro arun COVID-19 ni orile-ede Naijiria.

en: A 70-year-old woman who had spent five months in the United Kingdom returned to Nigeria, on March 11.
yo: Obinrin kan ti o je eni odun 70 ti o ti lo osu marun-un ni United Kingdom pada si Naijiria ni ojo 11 osu Erena.

en: Soon after, she presented with COVID-19 symptoms like cold and excessive mucous and on March 13, she was rushed to Enugu State Teaching Hospital (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, in southeast Nigeria.
yo: Leyin igba die ti o de, o bere si ni ami aisan kokoro arun COVID-19 bi i otutu ati ikun ti o po lapoju ni ojo 13, osu Erena, won si sare gbe lo si Teaching Hospital ti ipinle Enugu (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, ni guusu ila-oorun Naijiria.

en: She was isolated in ESUTH Colliery Parklane while her samples were sent to NCDC for diagnosis on March 14.
yo: Won ya a soto ni ESUTH Colliery Parklane, won si fi ayewo ti won se fun un sowo si ajo NCDC ni ojo 14, osu Erena fun ayewo.

en: On March 15, the woman died after the NCDC had reported that she tested negative to COVID-19.
yo: Ni ojo 15, osu Erena, obinrin naa ku leyin ti ajo NCDC jabo pe ko ni kokoro arun COVID-19.

en: "However, in a letter written to Enugu's state governor, the woman's daughter alleged that her mother was ""stigmatized"" by the hospital staff who placed her in a ""dilapidated"" isolation centre overgrown with ""grass and debris."""
yo: "Bee, ninu leta ti won ko si gomina ipinle Enugu, omo obinrin naa fesun kan awon osise ile iwosan naa pe ""tabuku"" iya oun, won gbe e sinu ""ile akoku"" ti o kun fun koriko."

en: Another ill-managed COVID-19 case presented in Lagos, the commercial capital of Nigeria.
yo: Oro enikan ti o ni kokoro arun COVID-19 ti won ko se abojuto to peye fun waye ni ipinle Eko ti o je olu-ilu idokoowo ni orile-ede Naijiria.

en: On March 17, David Hundeyin, a journalist with News Wire, reported the poor handling of a suspected COVID-19 case at Dangote Oil Refinery Company in Ibeju-Lekki, Lagos, which has precipitated panic among workers.
yo: Ni ojo 17, osu Erena, David Hundeyin ti o je akoroyin pelu News Wire, jabo nipa isamojuto ti ko gunrege to lori oro eni ti won furasi pe o ni kokoro arun COVID-19 ni ile ise Dangote ni Ibeju-Lekki, ni Ipinle Eko, ti o si ti n fa ipaya laaarin awon osise ibe.

en: On March 12, an Indian pipefitter from Dangote Refinery flew into Nigeria from Mumbai, after a brief stopover in Cairo, Egypt.
yo: Ni ojo kejila osu Erena, osise ileese Dangote kan ti o je omo ile India ti o n tun opa omi se wa si orile-ede Naijiria lati Mumbai, leyin ti o duro die ni Cairo, ni orile-ede Egypt.

en: "Hudeyin's investigation revealed that the pipefitter developed ""a fever, a dry cough, a sore throat and significant breathing difficulty,"" a day after his return from India."
yo: "Iwadii Hudeyin fi han pe okunrin naa ti o n tun opa omi se bere si i ni ""iba, iko gbigbe, ofun didun ati aile mi dele ,"" ni ojo keji ti o de lati India."

en: "Yet, ""it is unclear whether anyone at Dangote Refinery attempted to establish contact"" with appropriate health officials."
yo: "Sibe, ""ko ti i han boya enikeni ni ileese Dangote ti gbiyanju lati kan si"" awon eleto ilera ti oro naa kan."

en: "Hudeyin further lamented that the firm took advantage of ""the lax regulatory environment"" in Nigeria ""to put its own interests first,"" which puts the life of staff as well as the general public at risk."
yo: "Hudeyin soro siwaju pe ile ise naa n lo anfaani ""ayika ofin ti ko munadoko to"" ni Naijiria ""lati fi ere tire siwaju,"" eyi si n fi emi awon osise re ati gbogbo awujo sinu ewu."

en: This report forced refinery management to release a report stating that the said patient has been moved to the Infectious Disease Hospital in Yaba, Lagos.
yo: Iroyin yii mu ki ileese naa gbe ero won jade pe awon ti gbe alaisan naa lo si ile iwosan ti won ti n setoju kokoro Akoran ni Yaba, ni ipinle Eko.

en: How is COVID-19 reshaping the political and global future of China?
yo: Ona wo ni arun COVID-19 n gba se atunse si eto iselu ati eyin-ola Orile-ede China lagbaaye?

en: "Poster displaying a map of China on the four characters reading  meaning ""Wuhan pneumonia"" (which is still used in Chinese), as the epidemic was initially known, before it was given the name of COVID-19."
yo: "Aworan to n fi aala-ile orile-ede China han lori omo oro merin ti kika re je  ti o tumo si ""arun edoforo Wuhan"" (ti o si je lilo ni ede Chinese), gege bi a ti se mo ajakale naa ni ibere pepe, ki o to yi oruko pada si COVID-19."

en: Image used with permission.
yo: A gba ase lati lo aworan.

en: What started at a seafood market as a local health issue has grown into a national health crisis in China.
yo: Ohun ti o bere ninu oja ounje inu odo, gege bi i oran ailera ibile, ti wa di nnkan to ranka Orile-ede China.

en: After the Wuhan coronavirus was identified in December 2019, a chain reaction was set in motion that has profoundly shaken Chinese society and challenged Beijing's political stability.
yo: Leyin ifesemule ijeyo kokoro aifojuri korona ni Wuhan ninu Osu Kejila Odun 2019, opolopo isele lo se ni sise-n-tele lo su yo to si fi awujo ile Chinese lakalaka ti o si tun doju ipenija ko idurosinsin eto iselu Beijing.

en: Gripped by its obsession with information control, the Chinese government, both local and central, delayed the release of life-saving information for weeks.
yo: Kikundun isakoso iroyin ti fun ijoba lorun, ati ijoba ibile ati ijoba apapo ni aarin gbungbun, lo maa n fa idaduro fun agbejade iroyin ti yoo se ara ilu lanfaani fun ose pipe.

en: When they suddenly announced drastic measures to prevent the spread of the epidemic in late January, for many it was much too late as the Chinese New Year kick-off celebrations had already begun.
yo: Nigba ti won wa so ji lati se ikede lori awon ona ti yoo dekun itanka ajakale naa, o ti bo sori, nitori ayeye odun tuntun iran Chinese olodoodun ti gberaso.

en: Doctors and scientists are still researching and debating the possible origin of the previously unknown Wuhan coronavirus, which causes COVID-2019, a respiratory virus that infects the lungs and can lead to pneumonia.
yo: Awon Dokita ati awon onimo ijinle si n se iwadii ati iforojomitoro-oro lori ohun ti o le je orisun arun ti won mo nigba naa lohun-un gege bi kokoro aifojuri korona ti Wuhan, ti o pada wa se okunfa COVID-19, kokoro aifojuri to n mu ki eniyan ma lee mi sokesodo ti o si n fa arun edoforo.

en: One possible theory is that it comes from snakes or bats that are consumed as a delicacy in China and were sold at the Huanan wet market in Wuhan where the virus is believed to originate.
yo: Idamoran ohun ti o le fa sababi arun naa kan fi ye wi pe kokoro aifojuri korona je yo latari eran ejo tabi eran adan ti awon ara China maa n je l'ounje, ti won n ta ni oja Huanan wet ni agbegbe Wuhan nibi ti opolopo ni ero wi pe ibe ni orisun kokoro aifojuri yii.

en: One of the key questions determining the spread of the virus is its transmissibility: whether it can jump from human to human, and how many people can be infected on average by the same virus carrier.
yo: Ibeere kan ti o nilo idahun ni ti ona itankale arun yii: boya o lee ranka lati ara eeyan kan si ikeji, ati iye eeyan meloo lo lee ko aisan yii latara eni ti o ba ti ni i.

en: The latest medical evidence indicates there is human-to-human transmission, and what is concerning is that it seems to happen before the virus carrier develops symptoms, thus making detection incredibly challenging.
yo: Eri lati imo ilera to fesemule se isipaya arankan lati ara eniyan kan si ikeji, ti o fi je wi pe kokoro naa yoo ti wa lagoo ara fun igba die ki eni ti o ko o o to maa ri awon aami re lara, ti eyi o si mu mimo eni ti o ba ti lu gude arun naa rorun.

en: "As for the rate of transmission, called ""basic reproduction number"" by epidemiologists, it is believed to be between 2 to 3 in late January, meaning one person infects two to three persons, but the numbers are still being discussed and require further research should proper data be made available."
yo: "Ni ti bi arun naa ti n ran, eyi ti awon onimo nipa ajakale arun n pe ni ""onka ipile ibisi,"" gba pe o wa laaarin 2 si 3 ni ipari Osu Kin-in-ni, eni ti o ni i yoo ko o ran eni meji si meta, sugbon ifikunlukun ati iwadii ko duro, iyen bi awon iwifun-alalaye ti o wulo ba wa ni arowoto."

en: As the figure of infected people rises daily, a major health crisis has developed in China's central province of Hubei and its capital Wuhan that have a combined population of nearly 60 million people.
yo: Bi onka awon ti won ti ni kokoro yii se n lo soke si i lojoojumo, aaringbungbun Orile-ede China ti i se Hubei ati Olu-ilu re ti i se Wuhan ti ni idojuko to gogo lori eto ilera, ti apapo awon ti won n gbe lagbegbe yii si je egberun-lona-egberun ni ilopo 60.

en: As cases have been confirmed all over China, all medical staff are on alert, adding pressure on a medical system that is often insufficient for such a large and aging population.
yo: Bi iye awon ti o ti ko arun yii se n po kaakiri Orile-ede China, awon osise eleto ilera ti wa digbi, ti won si tun kona mo eto ilera ti ko suwabo to fun itoju awon oke aimoye arugbo to kun ilu.

en: But the Wuhan coronavirus is not just a health crisis, it is also a major political moment of truth.
yo: Sugbon arun kokoro aifojuri korona Wuhan naa ki i se ikolu eto ilera lasan, o je akoko otito eto iselu ti o lakaaki.

en: Trust in the government that claimed there was nothing to worry about until very late in the game has eroded public confidence significantly, and not just in Hubei province.
yo: Igbekele ijoba ti o so fun awon ara ilu wi pe ko s'ewu l'oko afi giri aparo ni ibere pepe, titi ti epa o fi boro mo, ti awon ara ilu ko si ni ifokantan ninu awon ijoba won mo, ati pe, ki i se ni agbegbe Hubei nikan ni eyi ti sele.

en: Beijing was criticized for the way it mishandled the SARS crisis in 2002-2003 as it concealed information from the World Health Organization (WHO).
yo: Awon ara ilu bu enu ate lu ijoba Beijing fun owo yepere ti won fi mu oro ajakale arun eemi SARS to su yo ni odun 2002 si 2003, bi o ti se fi iroyin to peye lori re pamo fun Ajo Eleto Ilara Lagbaaye (WHO).

en: China's top leader Xi Jinping kept silent on the recent outbreak until January 20 when he recognized the severity of the situation in a public statement - over one month after the first cases had been identified.
yo: Olori Orile-ede China agba Xi Jinping dake roro lori ajakale arun yii ayafi igba ti o di ojo 20, Osu Kin-in-ni Odun, ti o kede fun ara ilu leyin osu kan ti arun naa ti n sose, pe oran naa ti koja afenuso.

en: Control of information remains tight, and as China is experiencing a trade war with the US and an economic slowdown, the handling of the Wuhan coronavirus crisis will determine the course of Chinese society and politics in 2020.
yo: Agbara lori isakoso atejade iroyin fese mule rinrin ni orile-ede China, ati pe, iwoyaaja eto karakata pelu Orile-ede Amerika, ati bi oro-aje won se n denukole, bi won ba se yanju isoro kokoro aifojuri korona ti Wuhan naa ni yoo fori le ni odun 2020.

en: Mozambique and Cape Verde's telcos offer affordable mobile internet as citizens urged to stay home
yo: Awon Ile Ise ero-ibanisoro ni Mozambique ati Cape Verde te pepe eto edinwo fun ayelujara lori ero alagbeeka lati mu ki awon omo-ilu o duro sile

en: Santa Maria Avenue, Cape Verde. Photo by Miccaela, Wikimedia Commons. CC-BY 3.0
yo: Oju ona Santa Maria, Cape Verde. Aworan lati owoo Miccaela, Wikimedia Commons. CC-BY 3.0

en: "Check out Global Voices"" special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19."
yo: "Ye akanse ise ti Ohun Agbaye"" ti se lori ipa ti kokoro aifojuri korona COVID-19 n ko lagbaaye"

en: As more and more Africans are ordered to stay at home amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Mozambique and Cape Verde state-owned telcos are offering significant discounts on mobile data.
yo: Gege bi ase konilegbele se n mule ni ile Adulawo latari ajakale arun COVID-19, awon ile ise ero-ibanisoro ti Ipinle ni Orile-ede Mozambique ati Cape Verde n fun awon ara ilu ni edinwo lori owo-ilo-ayelujara ni ori ero-ibanisoro alagbeeka.

en: To date, Mozambique has registered a total of 10 confirmed cases of COVID-19 and no deaths, while Cape Verde has had six cases and one death.
yo: Di asiko yii, Orile-ede Mozambique ti ni akosile eniyan 10 ti o ti ko arun COVID-19, sugbon ti ko ti i si eni ti o ti ba aisan naa lo, amo eni 6 lo ti ko arun naa ni Cape Verde ti enikan si ti di eni ebora n ba jeun.

en: Last week, both countries have imposed a 30-day state of emergency, with the possibility of extension.
yo: Ni ose ti o koja, Orile-ede mejeeji ti pase ofin pajawiri ilu-o-f'ara-ro olosu kan latari ajakale aisan to gbaye kan, o si se e se ki won se afikun-un re.

en: According to Portugal's news agency Lusa:
yo: Gege bi ile ise oniroyin kan ti Orile-ede Portugal Lusa ti royin:

en: Translation Original Quote
yo: Itumo Itunwi-oro Oloro gan-an

en: The two Cape Verdean mobile telecommunications operators, CV Movel and Unitel T+, announced today a joint campaign that will make available a free package of 2,000 MB of internet to encourage citizens to stay at home, as a form of prevention of COVID-19.
yo: Lonii Ile Ise ero-ibanisoro ti Cape Verde mejeeji, CV Movel ati Unitel T+, se ifilo ipolongo alajumose ti yoo mu ki MB egberun 2 o je ti awon ara ilu fun iwuri lati lee mu won duro sile lojuna idina itanka ajakale arun COVID-19 lawujo.

en: "Titled the ""Fica em Casa"" (""stay home"" in English) package, the promotion was announced by the two operators on social networks in a message that says they have ""joined forces"" so that Cape Verdeans stay ""well at home."""
yo: "Ti akolee re je ""Fica em Casa"" (""ebun iduro sile"" ni ede Yoruba), ipolongo naa ni awon ile ise mejeeji gbe jade sori ero agborokaye ti a ko bayii pe awon ti f'orikori lati ""sise ajamose"" ti yoo mu ki awon ara orile Cape Verde ""o jokoo sile."""

en: The package offers customers of both operators, in addition to the 2,000 MB data package, 15 minutes of calls for all national operators to be used up until April 30.
yo: Ebun pataki yii wa fun onibaara ile ise mejeeji, ati pe ni afikun si MB egberun 2 ti won yoo fun won, owo ipe ofe fun iseju 15 yoo wa lofo fun pipe eyikeyii opo ero ibanisoro orile-ede naa ti o si gbodo je lilo ki o to d'ojo 30, Osu Kerin.

en: COVID-19: Campaign gives 2000 MB of internet to help Cape Verdeans to stay home.
yo: COVID-19: Ipolongo anfaani iranwo MB egberun 2 lati mu ki awon ara ilu Cape Verde o jokoo kale ki ofin konilegbele o ba f'eserinle.

en: A few people have questioned the efficacy of such campaign as many Cape Verdeans don't have regular internet access:
yo: Ogoro ara ilu Cape Verde ti yo suti enu si ipolongo yii, nitori segesege ni afefe ero ayelujara naa maa n se:

en: What a joke !!!
yo: Awada nla ni!!!

en: How many Cape Verdeans have internet?
yo: Eni meloo ninu ara ilu Cape Verde l'o ni afefe ero ayelujara to ja geere?

en: In Cape Verde, an island country of 560,000 people, 57 percent of the population use the internet, according to 2017 data by the World Bank.
yo: Ni Cape Verde, agbegbe erekusu ti o ni eeyan to to egberun 560, ti ida 57 won n lo ero-ayelujara, iyen gege bi iwadii ti Ile Ifowopamo Agbaye se ni odun 2017 ti se fi han.

en: On that year, the world average was 50 percent.
yo: Lodun naa, ida 50 ni ida awon to n lo ayelujara to poju lagbaaye.

en: "In Mozambique, where internet penetration is even lower - the same World Bank report says only 10 percent of its 30 million people are internet users -, state-owned operator TmCel launched a similar promotion, with the same ""stay home"" slogan."
yo: "Ni Mozambique, nibi ti awon eniyan ti o n lo ayelujara o ti to nnkan - Ile Ifowopamo Agbaye kan yii naa fi han ninu iwadii pe ida 10 awon ara ilu ninu eeyan egbeegberun lo ni ero-ayelujara ni arowoto - ile ise ero ibanisoro TmCel ti o je ti omo oniluu naa ti se ifilole ipolongo ""konilegbele"" yii kan naa."

en: The promotion consists of packages ranging from 1 to 5 GB, costing from 25 to 100 meticals (0.37 to 1.50 USD).
yo: Ipolongo naa kun fun awon okan-o-jokan anfaani ebun ofe lati GB 1 si GB 5, ti owoo re je 25 si 100 meticals (0.37 si 1.50 owo US).

en: Activate the #StayAtHome offers from 25 meticals valid for 30 days.
yo: Mu anfaani ebun #StayAtHome yii lo fun 25 meticals laaarin osu kan.

en: Use *219# choose your offer and stay at home with Tmcel. For more information visit the link below:
yo: Te *219# lati se asayan ebun ti o fe, ki o si duro sile pelu TmCel. Fun alaye lekununrere kan si:

en: Although the offer seems to have been well received, a few Twitter users posed questions:
yo: Bi-o-ti-le-je-pe anfaani ebun je ohun atewo gba lawujo, die lara awon onsamulo gbagede Twitter se agbejade awon ibeere kan:

en: Good initiative.
yo: Igbese ti o daa ni.

en: Is the quality good too?
yo: Se o je ojulowo bakan naa?

en: Staying home is not an option for the many informal and daily subsistence workers in Mozambique and Cape Verde. Activist Tomas Queface tweeted:
yo: Diduro sile yii ki i se ohun to ba awon onise owo ati onise igbemiiro ti o n gbe ni Mozambique ati Cape Verde lara mu rara. Ajafetoo omo-eniyan Tomas Queface tuwiiti:

en: The #Coronavirus reveals yet another facet of social inequalities.
yo: Aisan #coronavirus yii ti sipaya iwa aidogba ti o wa lawujo wa.

en: While #StayAtHome is a privilege for few people, for the poor it is a constant dilemma: staying at home without food, or continuing to work and risk your health or endangering the health of others.
yo: Bi ofin konile o gbele #StayAtHome se je oore ofe fun awon kan, nise l'o n mu awon ti o rowohori lawujo fajuro latari fi f'owo mukan: ninuu diduro sile lai ri ounje je, tabi sisise ki alaafia ara o di fiafia tabi fifi ilera awon ara ilu to ku wewu.

en: COVID-19 revives grim history of medical experimentation in Africa
yo: COVID-19 se agbende isele-ateyinwa to buru jai nipa idanwo egbogi ni Ile-Adulawo

en: Africa isn't a testing lab'
yo: Ile-Adulawo ki i se iyara ayewo'

en: Sgt. 1st Class Marites Cabreza, a nurse with 354th Civil Affairs Brigade, Special Functioning Team, Combined Joint Task Force-Horn of Africa, tends to a patient March 29, 2008, during a medical civil action project in Goubetto, Djibouti.
yo: Oloye omo-ogun. 1st Class Marites Cabreza, olutoju omo ti o n sise pelu 354th Civil Affairs Brigade, Special Functioning Team, Combined Joint Task Force-Iho Ile-Adulawo, n toju alaisan lojo 29, osu keta, odun-un 2008, lasiko akanse ise iwosan ilu ni Goubetto, Djibouti.

en: Photo by US Air Force Tech. Sgt. Jeremy T. Lock. Public Domain.
yo: Aworan lati akata Omo-ogun Ofuurufu US Eka imo ero , Jeremy T. Lock. Ilo gbogboogbo.

en: "Check out Global Voices"" special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19."
yo: "Ye akanse iroyin-in ""Ohun Agbaye"" lori ipa ti COVID-19 n ko lagbaaye."

en: The mad rush by scientists and researchers to test potential treatments for COVID-19 in scientific trials has revived a heated debate over the use of humans in critical drug trials in Africa.
yo: Aree panpala bi o o lo o yago ti n sele laaarin awon onimo ijinle ati onise iwadii ko seyin igbese lati se ayewo awon oogun ti won ro pe o le wo arun COVID-19 san lara omo eniyan ti n da gbonmisii-omi-o-too sile ni Ile-Adulawo.

en: On April 1, two French researchers, Dr. Jean-Paul Mira and Camille Locht, suggested on a live television broadcast that trials of a potential vaccine should first take place in Africa, according to Al Jazeera.
yo: Lojo 1, osu kerin, awon onise iwadii omo ile Faranse meji, Onisegun Jean-Paul Mira, ati Camille Locht, da a labaa lori eto kan ni ori ero-amohunmaworan wi pe Ile-Adulawo ni o ye ki won o ti koko dan egbogi ajesara ti yoo ka apa arun kokoro aifojuri korona san wo, gege bi Al-Jazeera ti se jiyin iroyin naa.

en: "Dr. Mira, head of the intensive care unit at Cochin Hospital in Paris, compared the current situation to ""certain AIDS studies, where among prostitutes, we try things because we know that they are highly exposed and don't protect themselves."""
yo: "Onisegun Mira, olori eka itoju afeju ti Cochin Hospital ti o wa ni Paris, fi oro naa we ""awon iwadii ayewo fun Arun Kogboogun EEDI, ti o je wi pe lara awon olowoo nabi ni a ti koko dan an wo, a gbiyanju awon nnkan kan nitori a mo daju wi pe won ki i da aabo bo ara won, ati pe o rorun fun arun ibalopo lati lugo si ara won."""

en: The two researchers made these comments in the context of a discussion of trials in Europe and Australia to see if the BCG tuberculosis vaccine could be effective against the novel coronavirus.
yo: Awon onise iwadii mejeeji menu loro nigba ti asogba oro kan waye lori isayewo egbogi ajesara BCG fun iko-awupeje ni Yuroopu ati Australia lati mo boya yoo sise iwosan fun kokoro aifojuri korona akoko iru e.
