en: In Australia, trials are being conducted on at least 4,000 health care workers.
yo: Ni Australia, ayewo ti n lo lori awon onise ilera egberun 4.

en: The attitude of these researchers echoes a long, grim history of medical experimentation and exploitation in Africa, where African leaders have colluded with pharmaceutical companies - often based in Europe or the United States - to conduct trials on the most vulnerable people in society.
yo: Isesi awon onise iwadii wonyi je gbohungbohun isele-ateyinwa olojo pipe ti o ni se pelu idanwo ati fifowoola gba omo Adulawo ni oju, ti o se wi pe awon adari Ile-Adulawo ti padi-apo-po pelu awon ileese apooogunta - ti o fi Yuroopu tabi ile Amerika se ibugbe - lati wa se ayewo ni ara awon ti ko ri ja je lawujo.

en: "The researchers"" remarks immediately sparked condemnation and outrage, with the trending hashtag phrase, ""Africans are not guinea pigs."""
yo: "Lesekese ni isorosi awon onise iwadii wonyi ri idalebi ati ibinu awon eniyan, ti o mu apola oro kan, ""Omo ile-Adulawo ki i se eku emo."" gbajumo lori ero-agborokaye."

en: Ivorian football star Didier Drogba tweeted:
yo: Irawo agbaboolu omo orile-ede Ivory Coast Didier Drogba tuwiiti:

en: "By April 3, Dr. Mira had apologized for his comments, but only after major pushback and pressure from the France-based anti-racism group SOS Racisme. Dr. Locht's employer, however, dismissed the outrage on Twitter as ""fake news,"" saying that the remarks had been taken out of context."
yo: "Nigba ti o di ojo 3, Osu Kerin, Onisegun Mira ti se itoro aforiji fun awon oro ti o so, amo leyin ti awon egbe SOS Racisme ko eyin si i ni o se eyi. Osisee onisegun Locht, bakan naa, da awon ehonu ori Twitter danu gege bi i ""iroyin eleje ,"" nitori wi pe awon oro naa ko ri bi won ti se n so o."

en: "That same week, Congolese virologist Jean-Jacque Muyembe, who worked on the frontlines of the Ebola epidemic in Democratic Republic of Congo, announced that DR Congo ""is prepared to take part in testing of any future vaccine against the coronavirus,"" according to News 24."
yo: "Ni aarin ose yen kan naa, onimo nipa arun aifojuri omo orile-ede Congo Jean-Jacque Muyembe, ti o n lewaju ninu igbogunti ajakale arun iba ida eje Ebola ni orile-ede Ilu Ijoba Awaarawa Olominira Congo, filo wi pe DR Congo ""ti se tan lati kopa ninu irufe idanwo egbogi ti yoo pa kokoro aifojuri korona ti ko ba a waye lojo iwaju,"" bi News 24 ti jabo."

en: Muyembe, the head of the nation's pandemic task force and national health institute, told a news conference:
yo: Muyembe, olori igbimo amusese lori ajakaye arun naa ati Ileese eto ilera orile-ede naa, so nibi apero awon oniroyin kan:

en: We've been chosen to conduct these tests...
yo: Won ti yan wa lati se awon ayewo wonyi...

en: The vaccine will be produced in the United States, or in Canada, or in China.
yo: Ilu Isokan Amerika tabi Canada tabi ni China ni a o ti se egbogi ajesara naa.

en: We're candidates for doing the testing here.
yo: Awa ni eni ayan fun ise ayewo naa nibi.

en: Once again, the remarks drew ire from Congolese citizens and netizens around the world condemning Dr. Muyembe's openness to hosting clinical trials in DR Congo, where the rates of infection for COVID-19 are still relatively low.
yo: Leekan si i, awon oro wonyi fa irunu awon omo Congo ati awon omo ori ayelujara jakejado ile aye ti won da Onisegun Muyembe ni ebi nitori o faramo isayewo egbogi ni DR Congo, nibi ti iye awon ti o ti ko arun COVID-19 ko ti i fi bee po.

en: Within hours, Dr. Muyembe clarified his statements in a video message, confirming that the vaccine would only be trialed in DR Congo after it had been done in countries such as the US and China:
yo: Laaarin wakati die, Onisegun Muyembe yannana oroo re ninu aworan-atohun kan, ti o fi idii re mule wi pe o di igba ti won ba ti koko ye ise egbogi naa wo ni US ati China ni yoo to je lilo ni DR Congo:

en: A grim history of medical experiment in Africa
yo: Isele-ateyinwa to buru jai nipa idanwo egbogi ni Ile-Adulawo

en: "Medical experimentation in Africa - often conducted under the guise of the ""greater good"" and of finding cures for deadly diseases like meningitis and HIV/AIDS - has sounded ethical and moral alarm bells for years - particularly over informed consent and forced medical procedures."
yo: "Idanwo egbogi ni Ile-Adulawo - ti o saba maa n waye labe etan ""ifee gbogboogbo"" ti o pon dandan ni ojuna ati wa iwosan fun arun asekupani bi i arun yirunyirun ati arun kogboogun HIV/AIDS - ti lu agogo itaniji iwa-omoluwabi fun ainiye odun - paapaa ju lo lori igbase lowo awon eniyan ki won o to se idanwo ati ilana iseto ilera onitulaasi."

en: "These trials are often funded by leading health organizations like the World Health Organization, the United States"" Centers for Disease Control and the National Institute of Health."
yo: Awon ileese ti o je asiwaju ninu eto ilera lagbaaye bi i Ajo Eleto Ilera Agbaye, Ajo Asakoso Arun ti orile-ede Amerika ati Ileese Eto Ilera Ijoba Apapo ni o maa n ko owo sile fun iru awon ise bayii.

en: In Zimbabwe, in the 1990s, over 17,000 HIV-positive women were tested without informed consent in trials for the anti-retroviral drug AZT funded by the CDC, WHO and the NIH.
yo: Ni orile-ede Zimbabwe, ni aarin awon odun ti o re koja ki a to wo Egbaa odun, o le ni 17,000 awon obinrin ti o ni arun kogboogun ni o se idanwo lai fi ase fun awon eleto idanwo wi pe awon fi owo si i ki won o lo awon fun ise iwadii ayewo egbogi-agbogunti itanka arun kogboogun AZT lagoo ara ti CDC, WHO ati NIH ko owo le lori.

en: In the 1990s, the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer tested an experimental drug called Trovan on 200 children in Kano, Nigeria, during an epidemic of bacterial meningitis.
yo: Bakan naa ewe, agba oje ileese apooogunta Pfizer dan oogun kan wo ti a pe ni Trovan ni ara awon ewe 200 ni Ipinle Kano, orile-ede Naijiria, nigba ti ajakale arun yirunyirun se yo.

en: Several families filed and won a lawsuit against Pfizer on the basis of violation of informed consent.
yo: Opolopo idile ni o pe Pfizer ni ejo lori aigbase lowo awon ki won o to lo awon omo awon fun idanwo.

en: Medical experimentation is not only entrenched in the history of racism and colonialism - it also sets a dangerous precedent by eroding the critical trust between citizens and health authorities.
yo: Idanwo egbogi ki i se eyi ti o da lori isele-ateyinwa nipa ti eleyameya ati ifipamunisin nikan - bakan naa ni o n se okunfaa isoro aifokan tan laaarin awon asoju eto ilera ati ara ilu.

en: """Both European colonialism and biomedicine reciprocally extended and strengthened the reach of the other,"" writes Patrick Malloy in an academic paper entitled, ""Research Material and Necromancy: Imagining the Political-Economy of Biomedicine in Colonial Tanganyika."""
yo: "Patrick Malloy ko si inu apileko ajemakada ti a pe akolee re ni, ""Eroja Ise-iwadii ati Ibokuusoro: Igbeyewo ironu nipa eto Iselu-toun Oro-aje ti o ni se pelu isoogun igbalode ni aye ifipamunisin ni Tanganyika"" pe ""Ati ifipamunisin ati isoogun igbalode ni i jo n parapo se, ti ik-in-ni n kin ilosiwaju ikeji leyin."""

en: "From malaria to other ""plague-like"" conditions, colonial authorities often subjected African subjects to the non-consensual practice of specimen-sample collection and ...""African blood was appropriated to feed colonial-era medical research,"" Malloy writes."
yo: "Lati ayee amodi si aye iru awon ""ajakale-arun bawon-onni,"" awon asoju ijoba ifipamunisin saba maa n fi awon Omo Adulawo se ohun elo fun idanwo lai gba ase, Malloy ko pe ...""eje Omo Adulawo ni o dara ju lo lati fi bo ise iwadii egbogi aye ijoba amunisin."""

en: He continues:
yo: O tesiwaju ninu oroo re:

en: In Tanganyika as well as other African colonies, this meant that colonial subjects could be called upon to surrender tissue samples, literally portions of themselves, to the medical authorities.
yo: Ni Tanganyika ati ni apa ibomiran ni Ile-Adulawo, eyi tumo si wi pe ni igbakuugba ni awon amunisin lee ke si awon ti won n je gaba le lori lati yanda awon padi eje, ti o duro fun eya abuda ara won fun asoju eto ilera ti yoo je lilo fun idanwo.

en: "These practices overlapped with horrifying rumors in East Africa about ""gangs"" of people employed by Europeans who would kidnap Africans to withdraw their blood to make a gum-like medicine known as mumiani."
yo: "Awon isele bawonyi ko yato si gboyii-soyii oro ti awon eniyan n je ni enu ni Ila-oorun Ile-Adulawo nipa ""awon egbe "" ti o n sise fun awon Oyinbo ti isee ti won ko ju ki won o maa ji Omo Adulawo gbe lo lati gba eje ti won yoo fi se oogun kan bi ojia ti a pe ni mumiani."

en: "The Swahili term invokes the image of the ""vampire"" or ""bloodletter"" - which has also become synonymous with ""exploitation."""
yo: "Oro iperi ni edee Swahili akawe oogun naa ni ""amuje"" tabi ""agbeje-fun-iwosan"" - ti o ti di ""imori-eni-sabe"" bayii."

en: This grim history has sown seeds of deep mistrust in vaccinations, medical trials and experiments in Africa, and continues to haunt decisions made by health authorities working in sync with government officials and global pharmaceutical companies.
yo: Isele-ateyinwa ti o buru jai yii ti gbin eso aifokan tan ninu awon egbogi ajesara, isayewo ati idan oogun wo ni Ile-Adulawo, ti o si n farahan ninu ise awon asoju eto ilera ti o n sise papo pelu ijoba ati awon ileese alooogunta ni agbaye.

en: That 1990s meningitis trial debacle in Kano, Nigeria, sowed so much distrust that it later made it very difficult to promote critical polio testing. Anti-polio vaccine rumors flourished.
yo: Idanwo oogun arun yirunyirun igbaa nni ni Kano, orile-edee Naijiria, gbin opolopo ainigbagbo ti ko mu ki ipolongo idanwo oogun arun romolaparomolese o rinle.

en: Those rumors got disseminated as news and eventually translated into a regional policy banning the polio vaccine in Nigeria in 2003.
yo: Aheso nipa egbogi ajesara agbogunti arun romolaparomolese fon ka si igboro. Awon aheso oro naa di pinpin ka bi iroyin ti o se atona eto imulo ijoba agbegbe ti o f'ofin de iloo egbogi arun romolaparomolese ni orile-edee Naijiria ni odun-un 2003.

en: Recovering from colonial hangovers
yo: "Imularada leyin ""ori fifo"" ifipamunisin"

en: So, what does this all mean for potential COVID-19 trials in Africa?
yo: Pelu ohun ti a ti so, ki ni gbogbo iwonyi yoo fa fun idanwo egbogi arun COVID-19 ni Ile-Adulawo ?

en: "Netizens and activists have resoundingly expressed the view that ""Africans are not guinea pigs."""
yo: "Awon eniyan ni ori ayelujara ati ajijangbara gbogbo lo ti penupo wi pe ""awon Omo Adulawo ki i se eku emo oyinbo."""

en: "WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has labeled the attitude of the two French doctors a ""hangover"" from a ""colonial mentality"" and declared:"
yo: "Oga agba Ajo Eto Ilera Agbaye (WHO) Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus ti pe ihuwasi awon onisegun mejeeji naa si ""ori fifo "" ti o da lori ""laakaye ifipamunisin,"" o si fi lede:"

en: Africa can't and won't be a testing ground for any vaccine.
yo: Ko lee je Ile Adulawo ati pe ki i se Ile Adulawo ni yoo je ibi idanwo fun eyikeyii irufe egbogi.

en: However, deep-seated fear and distrust of medical experimentation has also turned contact tracing and testing to stem the spread of the highly contagious coronavirus into an uphill battle for health care workers.
yo: Sibe, iberubojo ati aifokan tan idanwo egbogi ti mu ki dida awon eni ti o ti lugbade arun afomo kokoro aifojuri korona mo lawujo ati isayewo o nira fun awon osise eleto ilera.

en: In Cote d'Ivoire on April 6, protesters burned down a COVID-19 testing center, claiming its location in a crowded area was not appropriate.
yo: Ni orile-edee Cote d'Ivoire ni ojo 6, Osu kerin, awon afehonuhan ti ina bo ibi ayewo arun COVID-19 kan, idi ti won fi se bee ni wi pe agbegbe ti ero po si ni won sori ibi ayewo naa si ti ko si bojumu.

en: "The attack was ""reminiscent of attitudes during Ebola outbreaks in West and Central Africa when some people attacked health workers, suspicious that they were bringing the disease to their communities, rather than offering crucial medical care,"" BBC reported."
yo: "Ileese BBC jabo wi pe, ""ikolu naa ""mu ""ni ranti ihuwasi awon eniyan ni asiko ti arun iba Ebola n ja roinroin ni Iwo-oorun ati Aarin gbungbun Ile Adulawo nibi ti awon kan ti ya bo awon onise eto ilera, pelu imufuradani wi pe won n ko arun naa wo adugboo awon, bokanran-an ki won fun awon ni itoju ti o letike."""

en: "Yet, in the throes of the 2018 Ebola outbreak in DR Congo, critical human trials administered to Ebola patients ""under an ethical framework"" - under the medical guidance of Dr. Muyembe and the government of DR Congo - ultimately saved lives."
yo: "Ju bee lo, ninu rogbodiyan ajakale-arun iba Ebola odun-un 2018 ni DR Congo, awon ayewokan ayewokan ti a se ni ara awon eni ti o ti lu gude arun Ebola ""ti o tele alakale iwa-omoluwabi kan"" - labe itonaa Onisegun Muyembe ati ijoba orile-edee DR Congo - doola emi awon eniyan nikeyin."

en: By November 2019, a vaccine had been approved after thousands of Congolese with Ebola were tested.
yo: Nigba ti o maa fi di Osu Kokanla odun-un 2019, ti a ti se ayewo fun omo orile edee Congo ti o ju egberun lo, a fi onte lu egbogi ajesara kan.

en: WHO was expected to declare the DR Congo Ebola-free on April 12, but after more than 50 days without a single case, a 26-year-old man contracted Ebola and died on April 10.
yo: O ye ki WHO o se ikede wi pe arun iba ida eje Ebola ko si ni DR Congo mo ni ojo 12 Osu Kerin, sugbon leyin 50 ojo ti ko si eni ti o lugbadii arun yii, omokunrin ti ojo orii re je odun 26 ko arun iba ida eje Ebola o si file s'aso bora ni ojo 10 Osu Kerin.

en: Now, in addition to Ebola and an ongoing humanitarian crisis, DR Congo must turn its attention to mitigating the spread of the coronavirus.
yo: Ni bayii, ni afikun Ebola ati awuyewuye oro eto omoniyan ti o n m'igboro titi lowolowo, orile-edee DR Congo ni lati ko oju si didekun igbodikan ajakale-arun kokoro aifojuri korona ti o n gbile bi ogede.

en: There are currently 62 efforts underway to find a vaccine for COVID-19. Responsible, ethical vaccine trials take time and attention.
yo: Awon igbese 62 ti o n gbero lati wa egbogi ajesara fun arun COVID-19 lo n lo lowo. Ayewo ati idanwo egbogi ajesara ti yoo sise de gongo ti a gbe se lona ti o ba iwa-omoluwabi mu maa n gba asiko.

en: Will big pharmaceutical companies maintain the same ethical standards in Africa that they usually adhere to in trials conducted in the West?
yo: Nje awon ileese apooogunta nla yoo diro mo awon ofin iwa-omoluwabi ni Ile-Adulawo bi won ti se n se bi won ba n se idanwo ni Ile oyinbo?

en: In Burundi, four journalists jailed for months await appeal
yo: Ni Burundi, awon akoroyin merin ti a fi satimole n duro de ipinnu ejo kotemilorun

en: The journalists were accused of threatening state security
yo: Esun ilowosi idukoko mo aabo ilu ni a fi kan awon akoroyin naa

en: The Press House in Bujumbura, from which independent radios were blocked access. 19 May 2010.
yo: Ileese Oniroyin naa ni Bujumbura, nibi ti a yo awon ile igbohunsafefe kuro lori ila. Ojo 19 osu Ebibi 2010.

en: Four journalists - Agnes Ndirubusa, Christine Kamikazi, Terence Mpozenzi and Egide Harerimana - were charged with attempting to undermine state security and were sentenced in January 2020.
yo: Awon akoroyin merin - Agnes Ndirubusa, Christine Kamikazi, Terence Mpozenzi ati Egide Harerimana - ni a da lejo igbese lati yepere aabo ilu ti a si ran won lo si ewon ninu osu Kin-in-ni odun-un 2020.

en: The four, who all work with Iwacu newspaper, adamantly reject the charges.
yo: Awon mereerin ti o n sise pelu iwe iroyin Iwacu ko fi meni pe meji nise ni won so wi pe awon ko se sofin.

en: They now await an appeal decision on their prison sentence, after their hearing on May 6.
yo: Ni bayii won n duro de ipinnu ejo kotemilorun lori atimole won, leyin igbejo ojo 6 osu Karun-un.

en: Antoine Kaburahe, Iwacu founder who now lives in exile, wrote:
yo: Antoine Kaburahe, oludasile iwe iroyin ti o n gbe ni eyin odi, ko:

en: Breaking: End of court hearing in Bubanza. Iwacu's defence is satisfied.
yo: Ni yajoyajo: Opin igbejo ni Bubanza. Iwacu bori.

en: The accusations against the journalists do not hold up.
yo: Esun ti a ka si awon akoroyin naa lorun ki i se tiwon.

en: The journalists were only doing their job: reporting.
yo: Isee won ni awon akoroyin naa n se: ikoroyinjo.

en: What a relief!
yo: Okan-an bale !

en: The case is under consideration, verdict in max 30 days.
yo: Amo adajo ko tii dajo, abalo-babo oro di leyin osu kan.

en: Stay strong!
yo: E duro sinsin!

en: Detained for reporting
yo: Atimole fun ikoroyinjo

en: On October 22, Burundian security forces battled with an armed anti-government group - reportedly RED-Tabara, based in the Democratic Republic of Congo - around the Kibira forest border area.
yo: Ni ojo 22, osu Owara, awon eso alaabo Burundi wa a ko pelu egbe agbeborin alatako ijoba kan - ti a n pe ni RED-Tabara, ti o fi Democratic Republic of Congo se ile - ni agbegbe ibode igbo Kibira.

en: Armed groups have often used this area to move through the region.
yo: Awon egbe olote agbeborin ti maa n fi ibi yii kiri agbegbe naa.

en: In the battle, 14 insurgents were said to be killed, while security forces suffered about 10 casualties.
yo: Ninu ija akata naa, awon agbeborin 14 ni iku pa, ti eso alaabo 10 si ba a lo.

en: Later that day, police detained the four Iwacu journalists and their driver, Adolphe Masabarakiza, when they went to report at the Musigati commune, Bubanza province, to speak to people who had fled the fighting.
yo: Ni ojo yen naa, awon olopaa fi awon akoroyin Iwacu merin ati awako won Adolphe Masabaakiza si atimole, nigba ti won lo koroyin jo ni adugbo Musigati, ni Bubanza, nibi ti won ti fe ba awon eniyan ti o sa kuro ni adugbo nigba ti ija naa be sile.

en: At first, they were detained without charge, and Christine Kamikazi was reportedly hit when arrested.
yo: Lakooko, a fi won si atimole lai fi esun kan won, ti a si lu Christine Kamikazi nigba ti won mu won.

en: Police confiscated their phones and materials and the intelligence services demanded account passwords in order to search their phones.
yo: Olopaa gba ero-ibanisoro ati awon ohun elo ise won ti awon otelemuye si beere fun gbolohun ifiwole si ori ero won lati ye e wo finnifinni.

en: The journalists were then transferred to other cells with deplorable conditions.
yo: Awon akoroyin naa di eni ti a n gbe kiri lo si tubu miiran ti ko sunwon.

en: "On October 26, in Bubanza province, they were finally charged with ""complicity in threatening state security."""
yo: "Ni ojo 26 osu Kewaa, ni Bubanza, a jaja fesun ""Ilowosi idukoko mo aabo ilu"" kan won."

en: "On October 31, the public prosecutor confirmed this and accused them of having information on the insurgents"" attack."
yo: Ni ojo 31, osu Kewaa, abanirojo naa fi eri eyi lele o si fesun kan won ni pe won mo si ikolu awon koloransi eda naa.

en: "Various organizations promptly called for their release, including Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists"" Federation and the Association Burundaise des Radiodiffuseurs."
yo: "Awon ileese ni eka-o-jeka ni o ti pe fun idasile won, titi kan Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists"" Federation ati Ajo Burundaise des Radiodiffuseurs."

en: However, the National Communications Council said at the time that it could not discuss the matter.
yo: Sibe, Ileese Igbohunsafefe Apapo so wi pe awon ko tii le so si oran naa bayii.

en: Iwacu criticized this reaction, recalling that they were first held without charge and that the council is supposed to support journalists.
yo: Iwacu bu enu ate ohun ti ajo naa so, ni pe won ko fesun kankan kan won nigba ti won mu won ati pe ojuse ajo naa ni lati gbeja awon akoroyin.

en: Many people expressed support online and signed a petition. International media discussed it as a threat to press freedom, while Iwacu continues to follow the situation closely.
yo: Opo awon eniyan ni o gbe leyin awon akoroyinnaa ti won si fi owo bo ifesunkan lori ero-ayelujara. Awon ileese oniroyin rii gege bi ifoju-eto si ominira oniroyin gbole, ti Iwacu si n to okun oran naa lo pekipeki.

en: Journalist Esdras Ndikumana tweeted:
yo: Akoroyin Esdras Ndikumana tuwiiti:

en: "Burundi: 4 Iwacu journalists (and their driver) accused of ""complicity in threatening the interior security of the state"" for having covered a rebel incursion in Bubanza languish in the this province's prisons (Drawing by Yaga) "
yo: "Burundi: awon akoroyin Iwacu merin (ati awako won) ni a fi esun ""ilowosi idukoko mo aabo ilu"" kan nitori won lo ko iroyin ikolu ti o wa saye ti won si di ero ogba ewon Bubanza (Aworan lati owo Yaga) "

en: After appealing the decision on their detention, the date for their court hearing was set for November 18, To their surprise, they were summoned on November 11, to appear before judges for questioning - but without lawyers.
yo: Leyin ti won ti ni ejo ti o fi awon si inu atimole naa ko te awon lorun, a da ojo igbejo won si ojo 18, osu Kokanla, kayefi ni o je fun won nigba ti won gbe won lo sile ejo ni ojo 11, osu Kokanla ki won o wa gbowo ponyin rojo niwaju adajo - lai si awon agbejoro.

en: They refused to answer without legal assistance, asking why their lawyers had not been informed beforehand, and then returned to detention, to be heard on November 18.
yo: Won ko won ko fesi nitori ko si awon agbejoro won nikale, won si da won pada si atimole, ki ojo 18 ti a da fun igbejo o ko.

en: On November 20, the decision came that the four journalists would remain in detention, but the driver was provisionally released.
yo: Ni ojo 20 osu Kokanla, ipinnu de ti wi pe awon akoroyin mereerin yoo pada sinu atimole, amo won da awako sile.

en: The prosecution originally called for a 15-year prison sentence.
yo: Idajo ti a fun won to odun 15 ninu ewon.

en: President Pierre Nkurunziza said during a press conference on December 26 that he wanted a fair trial but he could only intervene as a last resort, even though he could use his power to grant a presidential pardon.
yo: Aare Pierre Nkurunziza so nibi apejo awon akoroyin kan ti o wa saye ni ojo 26 osu Kejila wi pe ohun ohun ko ni fe didiju mori dajo amo o digba ti a ba ti sanpa ti ko se e san mo ni oun yoo to ka a leri, pelu pe o le fi ase ti o n be ni ikawo re da ejo naa nu.

en: On January 30, in Bubanza, the four journalists were sentenced to two and a half years in prison and a fine of a million francs each ($521 United States dollars) under article 16 of the Penal Code, while the driver was acquitted.
yo: Lojo 30, osu Kin-in-in ni Bubanza, a ran to awon akoroyin mereerin naa lo si ewon odun meji ati abo pelu ki enikookan o sanwo itanran egbeegberun owo francs ($521 owo orile ede Amerika) labe ofin 16 ti Ofin Odaran, ti awako si gba ile-e re lai sanwo itanran.

en: "The prosecution could not prove any actual link or contact with the rebels, so the charge was changed to ""impossible attempt at the complicity in undermining state security,"" that is - that they intended to threaten state security but it was not possible."
yo: "Idajo naa ko fi han ni pato wi pe awon akoroyin naa mo ohunkohun nipa isele naa, latari eyi esun naa yira pada di ""igbese ilowosi idukoko mo aabo ilu ti ko se e se,"" iyen ni pe - won pete lati dunmorurumoruru mo aabo ilu amo o soro lati gbe se."

en: Iwacu pointed out that the reporters went to the area after authorities had publicly mentioned the incident, were accredited, and there were no restrictions on the area.
yo: Iwacu salaye wi pe awon akoroyin naa lo sibi isele naa leyin ti awon alase ti fi lede, won gba iwe ase ko si si ofin ti o ni kenikan o maa de agbegbe isele naa.

en: "The key element used as evidence against the journalists was a WhatsApp message sent by one of the reporters to a friend, which said they were going to ""help the rebels."""
yo: "Eri kan soso ti won ri dimu ti o ko awon akoroyin naa si yawuyawu ni atejise ori WhatsApp ti okan lara awon akoroyin naa fi sowo si oree re kan, ti o so wi pe awon fe lo ""ran awon olote ijoba naa lowo ."""

en: They argued it was clearly a dry joke - the government has often conflated critics, political opponents, and armed groups to justify generalized crackdowns. But the text was taken literally as evidence against them.
yo: Amo efe lasan ni won fi se - ijoba ti maa n saba ko awon alatako, egbe oloselu ati awon agbebonrin papo lati jare iru igbese bayii. the atejise naa ni a fi kan won mole.

en: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) said the journalists should be able to report on sensitive topics without fear of reprisals, particularly ahead of Burundi's May 20 election.
yo: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) so wi pe awon akoroyin naa letoo lati jabo iroyin ti o kan gbogbo ilu gbongbon lai foya igbesan, papaa ni igbaradi ibo orile-edee Burundi ojo 20 osu karun-un ti o n bo lona.

en: They made a petition calling for their release, which had almost 7,000 signatures in early May.
yo: Won ko iwe ifesunkanni kan ti o n pe fun idasile won, eyi ti eniyan ti o to 7,000 towobo ni ibere osu Karun-un.

en: European Union deputies, the European Parliament, and UN human rights experts are among those who called for their release.
yo: Awon igba-keji ajo European Union, Igbimo ijoba Yuroopu, ati awon agba UN nipa eto omoniyan wa lara awon ti o ti pe fun idasile won.

en: On February 20, the journalists appealed, questioning the quality of the legal process, including the change to the original charge without proper notification.
yo: Lojo 20 osu Keji, awon akoroyin naa ni idajo naa ko-te awon lorun, ti won so wi pe alaise ni won n fiya je, ati ayipada pajawiri ti o deedee ba esun ti won koko fi kan won.

en: On May 6, the journalists appeared at an appeal hearing, after approximately six months in jail.
yo: Lojo 6, osu karun-un, awon akoroyin naa foju han nile ejo kotemilorun kan, leyin ti won ti fi ewon osu mefa jura.

en: "Responding to the accusation based on the WhatsApp message, the defense noted that in another message, one journalist said the rebels were coming to ""threaten the peace."""
yo: "Ni ifesipada si esun naa latari ise-ije ori WhatsApp, ni eyi ti akoroyin kan so wi pe awon olote naa n bo wa ""di alaafia lowo ."""

en: RFI quoted their defense lawyer, Clement Retirakiza, saying there was an absence of evidence against them, and they wanted to show it was a purely professional trip.
yo: RFI tun oro agbejoro won, Clement Retirakiza wi, wipe kko si eri ti daju nipa esun ti a fi kan awon akoroyin naa, won kan fe fi owo ola gba alaise loju ni.

en: Iwacu has long been an independent voice that criticizes politicized violence - it is one of the last independent media outlets following the 2015 crackdown.
yo: Ojo ti pe ti Iwacu ti wa gedegbe gege bi ohun ti o fajuro si jagidijagan iselu - oun ni ileese oniroyin ti o keyin leyin igbesele odun-un 2015.

en: A history of violence against journalists
yo: Isele ateyinwa nipa ijiya akoroyin

en: After controversial 2015 elections - in which Nkurunziza returned for a third term that many argued as unconstitutional - there was a failed putsch. The media environment quickly deteriorated.
yo: Leyin eto idibo ti o da wahala sile ti odun-un After 2015 - eyi ti o gbe Nkurunziza pada sipo fun igba keta ti awon eniyan so wi pe o tase agbere sofin - ifipagbajoba ti ko yori si re. Ise awon akoroyin de polukumusu.

en: Several radios stations - the most relied upon for information in Burundi - were closed and some were attacked. Dozens of journalists fled and some suffered torture, such as Esdras Ndikumana.
yo: Opolopo ileese agbohunsafefe - ti awon eniyan feran fun ekunrere iroyin ti ko figbakanbokan ni Burundi - ni a san pa. Opolopo akoroyin llo juba ehoro ti awon miiran bii Esdras Ndikumana je mo-yo-iya

en: "Numerous journalists have also experienced violence from security forces, particularly when reporting on topics deemed ""sensitive"" by the state."
yo: "Ogoro awon akoroyin ni o ti ni iriri iya lowo awon eso agbofinro ilu, paapaa ju lo bi won n ba ko iroyin ti o ""pon dandan"" jo."

en: In late 2015, cameraman Christophe Nkezabahizi was killed by police along with three family members, in an operation against protests after the contentious election.
yo: Ni ipari odun 2015, olopaa pa onyaworan Christophe Nkezabahizi pelu awon omo-lebi meta, ni asiko ibo ti ifehonu wa saye.

en: In July 2016, Jean Bigirimana was forcibly disappeared, reportedly arrested by intelligence services (SNR), with a limited police investigation.
yo: Ninu osu Keje odun 2016, Jean Bigirimana di awati, o se e se ki o je wi pe ileese otelemuye (SNR) lo gbe e, lai je ki awon olopaa o se iwadii ifinidiikoko bo se ye.

en: This year, on January 16, reporter Blaise-Pascal Kararumiye with Radio Isanganiro (Meeting Point Radio) was arrested following a report on local government finances. On April 28, journalist Jackson Bahati was hit by a police officer while reporting.
yo: Lodun yii, ni ojo 16 osu Kin-in-ni, akoroyin Blaise-Pascal Kararumiye pelu Radio Isanganiro (Meeting Point Radio) di ero akanran olopaa leyin iroyin kan nipa owo ijoba ibile kan. Lojo 28, osu kerin, olopaa kan na akoroyin Jackson Bahati nibi ti o ti n sise ikoroyin jo.

en: International media have not been spared, with BBC and VOA banned in 2019. RSF ranked Burundi 160 of 180 countries for press freedom - down 15 from 2015.
yo: Awon ileese oniroyin agbaye naa o gbeyin, a gbese le ise BBC ati VOA ni 2019. RSF to Burundi si ipo 160 ninu orileede 180 fun ominira oniroyin - o fi 15 lati 2015.

en: Women in Nigeria face a caustic landmine of political advocacy online
yo: Awon obinrin ni Naijiria koju ado-oloro agbeselero agbawi oro iselu lori ero-ayelujara

en: #BringBackOurGirls and #ArewaMeToo reshaped political activism in Nigeria
yo: #BringBackOurGirls ati #ArewaMeToo se atunto si igbawi eto iselu ni orile ede Naijiria

en: Members of the Mother's Savings Club, Nigeria. Image by Karen Kasmauski / USAID in Africa via United States government work, public domain.
yo: Awon omo egbe Mother's Savings Club, Naijiria. I'm Aworan lati owo Karen Kasmauski / USAID ni Ile-Adulawo ni ori United States government work, public domain.

en: In Nigeria, the political advocacy sphere is a caustic landmine.
yo: Ni Naijiria, ado-oloro agbeselero ni gbagede agbawi oro oselu.

en: Politics and advocacy usually get filtered through a religious and ethnocentric prism.
yo: Agbawi ati oro iselu saba maa n fi ti oro esin ati eleyameya se.

en: "Advocates with a strong social media presence - especially on Twitter - have to develop a tough skin to deal with the avalanche of gbas gbos (Nigerian Pidgin for ""throwing punches"") in digital spaces."
yo: "Awon alagbawi ti o gbajumo lori ero-alatagba - paapaa ju lo lori Twitter - ni lati le fi ara gba opolopo gbas gbos (ede adalu-mo-Geesi Naijiria fun ""ikanse"") ni ori ero-ayarabiasa."

en: Nigerian female advocates - in addition to weathering this identity-driven harmful content - also face the added reality of gender-driven attacks.
yo: Awon alagbawi ti o je obinrin - ni afikun si tite awon ohun idanimo ti o n mu ipalara wa mole - bakan naa ni won n koju ikolu ti o ti ara ikoriira tegbintegbin eya je yo.

en: How do female advocates in Nigeria cope with the bitter online terrain such as trolling, hate speech and targeted misalignment of their messages?
yo: Bawo ni awon alagbawi l'obinrin ni Naijiria se n farada ikoro ori ero-ayelujara bii isoro alufansa sini, oro ikoriira tegbintegbin ati imoomo yi-oro won da?

en: How do they forge ahead to make sure that these attacks do not simmer their resolve or eclipse the message of their movement?
yo: Bawo ni won se n tesiwaju ninu ise won tabi fonrere ise won?

en: Two online social media movements in Nigeria lend powerful insights into the experiences of advocacy and gender: The #BringBackOurGirls movement, led by Dr. Oby Ezekwesili; and #ArewaMeToo, led by Fakhriyyah Hashim, both experienced gendered political hatred that greatly affected the integrity of their messages.
yo: Awon ajijagbara ori ero alatagba meji ni Naijiria fi iriri awon agbawi ati ikoriira iwa abo han: #BringBackOurGirls, ti Dokita Oby Ezekwesili je asiwaju; ati #ArewaMeToo, ti Fakhriyyah Hashim je agbateru, gbogbo won ni won ni iriri ikoriira tegbintegbin abo ninu agbo oselu ti o n fa ilosiwaju won seyin.

en: #BringBackOurGirls (#BBOG) movement
yo: Ijagbara #BringBackOurGirls (#BBOG)

en: Six years ago, on April 15, 2014, about 200 school girls between the ages of 15 and 18, were forcefully abducted by Boko Haram, an Islamist terrorist group, from Government Girls Secondary School in Chibok near Maiduguri, in northeast Nigeria.
yo: Odun mefa seyin, ni ojo 15, Osu Igbe odun 2014, o to 200 awon omodebinrin ti ojo ori won o ju odun 15 ati 18 lo, lati ileewe Giga Ijoba Obinrin ni Chibok eba Maidiguri, ni ariwa-ila-oorun Naijiria ni egbe afemisofo elesin Musulumi Boko Haram so di eni ti a fi tulaasi mu si igbesin.

en: The kidnapping of the Chibok girls ignited an international outcry.
yo: Ijinigbe awon omodebinrin Chibok naa se okunfa ilowosi awon orile ede kari agba nla aye.

en: The BBC reported that in April 2014, the #BringBackOurGirls trended on Twitter with over 3.3 million tweets, 27 percent of the tweets came from Nigeria, 26 percent from the United States and 11 percent from the United Kingdom.
yo: Ileese oniroyin BBC jabo wi pe ninu osu Igbe odun 2014, #BringBackOurGirls naa gbajumo ni ori Twitter pelu nnkan bii awon eniyan egbeegberun 3.3 ti o tun tuwiiti naa tuwiiti, ida 27 awon tuwiiti wonyi ni o wa lati Naijiria, ida 26 lati orile ede Amerika ati ida 11 lati Ile Geesi.

en: Dr. Oby Ezekwesili answering a question during a UN Women event with #BringBackOurGirls Campaign Coordinators.
yo: Dokita Oby Ezekwesili n dahun ibeere nibi eto awon obinrin ajo UN pelu awon alakooso ipolongo #BringBackOurGirls.

en: Image by UN Women/Ryan Brown, September 14, 2014. (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0)
yo: Aworan lati owo UN Women/Ryan Brown, ojo 14, osu Owewe odun 2014. (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0)

en: Dr. Obiageli (Oby) Ezekwesili, a former vice president of the World Bank, and one-time minister of education in Nigeria, started tweeting about the Chibok girls the day they were kidnapped.
yo: Dokita Obiageli (Oby) Ezekwesili, igba-keji aare Ile ifowopamo Agbaye igba kan, ati minisita eto eko orile ede Naijiria nigba kan ri, bere si tuwiiti nipa awon omodebinrin Chibok ni ojo ti won ji won gbe gan-an gan-an.

en: She was motivated to take action due to a previous attack on schoolboys at the Federal Government College of Buni Yadi in Yobe State, northeastern Nigeria on February 25, 2014.
yo: Isele kan ti o ti sele ti awon ajinigbe ji awon omodekunrin gbe ni ileewe Koleji ijoba Apapo ti Buni Yadi ni Ipinle Yobe, ariwa-ila-oorun Naijiria lojo 25, osu Erele odun 2014 lo si i loju si ipolongo yii.

en: Fifty-nine boys died from gunshots or knife wounds, while the others were burnt to death.
yo: Awon omodekunrin kankandinlogota ni o ti ara ota ibon ati ogbe obe ku, nigba ti ina si jo awon miiran pa.

en: However, it was not until April 23, when, as a guest at a UNESCO event in Port Harcourt, in the oil-rich Niger Delta region, did her cry for the release of the schoolgirls grab national and international attention:
yo: Sibesibe, afi igba ti o di ojo 23, osu Igbe, nigba ti ajo UNESCO gba a lalejo ni Port Harcourt, ibi ti o kun fun epo-robi ni agbegbe Niger Delta, ni o ti ke gbajare fun idasile awon omodebinrin ti o fi di ohun ti gbogbo orile ede agbaye gba bi igba oti:

en: And on May 7, 2014, former American first lady Michelle Obama posted an image of herself on Twitter holding a sign with the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls.
yo: "Ni ojo 7 osu Ebibi odun 2014, aya aare orile-ede Amerika ogabinrin Michelle Obama se atejade aworan kan ti o ti mu ami ""E da awon omodebinrin wa pada"" #BringBackOurGirls lowo."

en: She also released a video a few days later from the White House - making it a global sensation.
yo: Bakan naa ni o tari aworan-olohun kan lati inu Ile Funfun sita - ti igbese yii si so isele ijinigbe naa di oran ti gbogbo agbaye fe ri abalo-babo re.

en: It would take two years before the Nigerian army rescued one girl, in May 2016.
yo: Odun meji ni o gba awon omo ogun orile ede Naijiria lati gba omodebinrin kan sile, ninu osu Okudu odun-un 2016.

en: By October 2016, 21 girls were reunited with their families. And by May 2017, Boko Haram militants released 82 girls from captivity.
yo: Nigba ti o maa fi di osu Owara odun-un 2016, awon omodebinrin 21 darapo mo awon molebi won. Ni osu Ebibi 2017, iko Boko Haram da awon omodebinrin 82 sile ninu igbesin.

en: However, about 112 girls remain missing and 13 are presumed dead, according to a 2018 report.
yo: Sibesibe, o to omodebinrin 112 ti o di awati bi abere ti o si jo pe awon 13 ti segbe, iyen gege bi iwadii odun 2018 kan se to pinpin.

en: Ezekwesili co-founded the #BBOG movement that mobilized a global protest for the release of the Chibok girls.
yo: Ezekwesili ati ajosepo awon eniyan kan ni o da igbese ija fun eto awon omodebinrin #BBOG ti o ko awon eniyan jo lagbaaye fun idasile awon omodebinrin Chibok.

en: The movement later transformed into a formidable social movement organisation that has withstood the harsh Nigerian civic space.
yo: Nigba ti o se, igbese naa yirapada di igi araba ti enikan ko lee si nidii ti o fi ara da igbagede eto ilu Naijiria t'o roro.

en: But the success of this movement occurred at great personal cost to Ezekwesili.
yo: Amo sa o, aseyori akitiyan yii ko seyin-in inawonara Ezekwesili.

en: The kidnapping of the Chibok girls occurred on the threshold of the 2015 presidential election, and Ezekwesili's online advocacy was viewed through the prism of partisan politics by some.
yo: Ni were ki eto idibo aare odun 2015 o wa saye ni isele ijinigbe awon omodebinrin Chibok se, ti eyi si mu ki awon kan o maa fi oju igbeleyin egbe oloselu kan wo igbawi ti Ezekwesili n ba ka lori ayelujara.

en: Her personal integrity was not only questioned but shredded.
yo: Bi won ti fi oju otito inu re gbole ni won fa gbogbo aso iyii re ya perepere.

en: Some alleged that her #BBOG was merely a front to gain political capital.
yo: Awon miiran so wipe gbogbo kukugege akitiyan #BBOG re ko ju ki o ba lenu ninu iselu lo.

en: "Reno Omokri, a former presidential aide, accused Ezekwesili of being used by the then-opposition party, the All Progressive Congress (APC), to ""undermine"" the government of President Jonathan, thereby paving the way for APC's ""rise to power."""
yo: "Reno Omokri, oluranlowo aare ana, fi esun kan Ezekwesili wi pe egbe oloselu APC ni o n lo o fi ba ijoba ti o wa lori apere je ati lati ""yepere"" ijoba Aare Jonathan, nipa eyi naa ni o fi lana fun APC lati ""gba opa ase."""

en: "Supporters of former President Jonathan and the Peoples"" Democratic Party spread ""all manners of falsehoods"" online against Ezekwesili in 2014: ""I was actually being insulted, maligned..."" said Ezekwesili in a live Twitter video broadcast on April 14, to mark the sixth anniversary of the abduction."
yo: "Ni odun-un 2014 awon alatileyin Aare ana aare Jonathan ati egbe oloselu Peoples"" Democratic Party (PDP) fi ""awon okan-o-jokan iro "" lede ni ori ero-ayelujara lati tako Ezekwesili. Dokita naa so ninu atejade aworan-olohun Twitter kan ti ojo 14, osu Igbe ni isaami odun mefa ti awon omodebinrin naa ti di awati wi pe: ""ki a ma puro won tabuku mi, won si se keeta."

en: Ezekwesili was falsely accused of being bitter for not gaining a ministerial appointment under Jonathan.
yo: Awon elenu eke so wi pe igbonara ai ri ipo ninu ijoba Jonathan lo n mu Ezekwesili tepele mo igbaruku ti oran awon omo ti ajinigbe ji gbe.

en: "According to her, some of her online attackers thought ""that the reason we kept on with the advocacy of Chibok girls was that I wanted to be made a minister."""
yo: "Bi o ti se so, awon ti o ko enu egbin si i lori ayelukara-bi-ajere lero ""wi pe tori ki won ba fi oun j'oye minisita ni oun o fi menu kuro loran awon omodebinrin Chibok."""

en: How could I want to be made a minister when I rejected the request to be a minister way before the Chibok girls were abducted three years later?
yo: Bawo ni yo se je bee leyin ti mo ko ipo minisita ni odun meta seyin ki awon omodebinrin Chibok o to di igbesin?

en: Ezekwesili said in the live Twitter video broadcast.
yo: Ezekwesili wi ninu aworan-olohun Twitter naa.

en: She became a 2018 presidential contender, but later withdrew from the race.
yo: O di okan ninu awon ondije si ipo aare odun-un 2018, sugbon o ju owo sile nigba o ya.

en: Live on Twitter, Ezekwesili recalled her grief: It was a very sad thing for me to bear the thought that children who went to school were so killed and brutally murdered to the point where parents could not recognise their children.
yo: "Ni ori Twitter, Ezekwesili mu ibanuje re wa si iranti: ""Edun okan ni fun mi pe awon omode ti a ran nile iwe di pipa bi eran de ibi wi pe awon obi won ko le da awon omo won mo ."""

en: But her grief and rage was eclipsed by the political maligning she endured to get the #BBOG message out.
yo: Amo isaata ti oloselu nipa igbese ipolongo #BBOG ti gbe ibinu toun t'ibanuje re mi.

en: #ArewaMeToo and NorthNormal
yo: #ArewaMeToo ati NorthNormal

en: On February 3, 2019, a young woman named Khadijah Adamua found the courage to tweet about the physical abuse inflicted by her ex-boyfriend.
yo: Ni ojo 3, osu Erele odun-un 2019, odobinrin kan ti oruko re n je Khadijah Adamua gbojugboya lati tuwiiti nipa ilokulo ajemara ti orekunrin re igba kan lo oun.

en: Adamua, who lives in Kano state in northwest Nigeria, had previously blogged about her horrific experiences.
yo: Adamua, eni ti o n gbe ni ipinle Kano ti i se ariwa-ila-oorun orile ede Naijiria, ti saaju ko buloogu nipa iriri re ti o banileru.

en: Fellow Nigerian Fakhriyyah Hashim tweeted her support for Adamua with the hashtag #ArewaMeToo:
yo: Omo Naijiria rere Fakhriyyah Hashim tuwiiti atileyin re fun Adamua pelu lilo ami #ArewaMeToo:

en: "#ArewaMeToo became northern Nigeria's version of the global #MeToo movement. (Arewa is the Hausa word for ""North"") - igniting a storm of online discussion on rape and other forms of gender-based violence."
yo: "#ArewaMeToo di eda igbese Emi Naa agbaye #MeToo ni ariwa Naijiria. (Arewa ni ede-iperi fun ""Ariwa"" ni ede Hausa) - ti o tan iji asogba oro lori ifipabanilopo ati iru awon iwa-ipa si awon obinrin ni ori ero ayelukara-won-bi-ajere."

en: Violence against women is rampant throughout Nigeria. However, Relief Web asserts that between November 2014 and January 2015, northeastern Nigeria, especially Borno State, recorded the most violence against women.
yo: Iwa-ipa si obinrin wopo jakejado orile-edee Naijiria. Sibe, Relief Web so wi pe ni aarin osu Belu odun-un 2014 ati osu Seere odun un 2015, ariwa-ila-oorun Naijiria, paapaa ju lo Ipinle Borno, ni akosile iwa-ipa si obinrin ti po jojo.

en: In the Muslim-majority north, discussions about these taboo topics are difficult, often forcing victims into silence.
yo: Ni agbegbe ariwa ti awon Musulumi po si ju lo, asogba nipa ori oro eewo wonyi soro, ti o maa papa so awon ti o n jiya ipalara si ipa keke.

en: The online rage of #ArewaMeToo propelled the NorthNormal offline protests in Bauchi, Kano, Niger.
yo: Ibinu #ArewaMeToo ni ori ero-ayelujara se atona iyide ifehonuhan ita gbangba NorthNormal ni Bauchi, Kano, ati Niger.

en: Sixteen days of NorthNormal protests occurred in November last year across eight northern Nigerian states and Abuja.
yo: Iyide olojo meeedogun ti NorthNormal wa saye ninu osu Belu odun t'o koja ni awon ipinle mejo ni oke Oya ati ni Abuja.

en: "They were largely positive and state legislators ""were receptive of young indigenes"" for taking ""the baton to push for the VAPP,"" Hashim said."
yo: "Won ri ipa rere latari iyide ti awon asofin ""si ri idi ti o fi ye ki awon gbo si awon odo ibile "" lenu tori won n ""le iwaju ninu ija fun VAPP,"" Hashim salaye oro."

en: "However, in Sokoto State, ""government played a role in harassing and arresting NorthNormal campaigners,"" Hashim said."
yo: "Hashim tesiwaju wi pe,"" sibe, ni Ipinle Sokoto, ijoba n ko awon ti o n yide NorthNormal."""

en: The police manhandled a local leader of the movement.
yo: Awon olopaa se okan lara awon olori ibile ti i se alagbeekale iyide naa sibasibo.

en: Thereafter, protests were banned by the Sultan of Sokoto, head of Nigerian Muslims.
yo: Leyin wa, oba Sokoto, ti i se olori awon Musulumi orile ede Naijiria fagile iwode.

en: "According to Hashim, NorthNormal grew out of the #ArewaMeToo hashtag, and has two objectives: advocating for ""the domestication of the Violence against Persons Prohibition Act (VAPP),"" and championing the conversation on ""various forms of gender-based violence and rape culture across northern Nigeria."""
yo: "Gege bi Hashim ti se wi, NorthNormal suyo lati ara ami #ArewaMeToo, ti o si ni eta meji: igbawi fun ""isamulo Ifofinde Iwa-ipa si awon Eniyan (VAPP),"" ati ilewaju ninu itakuroso ""oniruuru iwa-ipa si obinrin ati asa ifipabanilopo jakejado ariwa Naijiria."""

en: The Violence Against Persons (Prohibition) Act 2015 was signed into law on May 23, 2015.
yo: Aba Ofin Iwa-ipa si Awon Eniyan (Ifofinde) odun-un 2015 di titowobo lojo 23, osu Ebibi, odun-un 2015.

en: Under the VAPP Act - an improvement on the provisions of Nigeria's penal code - acts of violence against women are punishable offences.
yo: Labe Aba VAPP - ilosiwaju ofin ijiya ese orile ede Naijiria - aba iwa-ipa si awon obinrin je ese labe ofin.

en: This includes rape, spousal battery, forceful home ejections, forced financial dependence or economic abuse, harmful widowhood practices, female circumcision or genital mutilation, and/or child abandonment.
yo: Lara re ni ifipabanilopo, nina aya, ifipale aya jade nile, ifipa so obinrin di adabukata gbo tabi ijiya ti oro-aje, asa opo ti o n fa ipalara, didabe fun obinrin tabi gige ida, ati/tabi ikosile omo.

en: In Nigeria, rape is punishable with life imprisonment. A minor can face up to 14 years in prison.
yo: Ni Naijiria, ewon gbere ni ijiya ifipabanilopo. Omode le fi ara gba ewon odun 14.

en: In cases of gang rape, offenders are jointly liable to 20 years imprisonment without the option of a fine.
yo: Bi o ba je oran ifipabanilopo eni pupo, ewon odun 20 ni awon elese yoo fi gbara lai san owo itanran.

en: However, Section 47 of the VAPP Act stipulates that this legislation applies only in Abuja, Nigeria's capital. NorthNormal and other organisations have been campaigning for all 36 state legislative assemblies to domesticate this act.
yo: Sibe, Abala 47 ti Aba ofin VAPP fi lele wi pe Abuja, olu ilu orile ede Naijiria nikan ni ofin yii ti f'ese rinle. NorthNormal ati awon ileese miiran ti n polongo ki gbogbo igbimo asofin ipinle 36 o so aba yii d'ofin.

en: Backlash against advocates
yo: Atako awon alagbawi

en: "One year after sparking the #ArewaMeToo movement, Hashim told Global Voices that although their advocacy exposed the ""rot within society,"" it also took its toll."
yo: "Odun kan leyin ti #ArewaMeToo gba igboro, Hashim so fun Ohun Agbaye wi pe adi igbawi won ti o tu ""ibaje awujo jade,"" o si tun ni arapa tire."

en: "Hashim experienced major online harassment when her group confronted ""an alleged serial abuser of minors"" who works at the finance ministry as part of their online advocacy."
yo: "Hashim ni iriri iyolenu lori ayelujara nigba ti egbe re koju ""enikan ti o maa ba awon omode lo ni sisentele kiri adugbo"" eni ti o n sise ni ileese isuna-owo gege bi igbawi ori ayelujara won."

en: She told Global Voices:
yo: O so fun Ohun Agbaye:

en: We launched a campaign against him [the serial abuser], demanding that he be sacked by the minister; some people did not like that so they orchestrated an online targeted harassment campaign to delegitimise ArewaMeToo.
yo: A se ifilole ipolongo tako re [abomode sun], ki o ba gba iwe iyoninise lati owo minisita; awon kan ko fe bee tori idi eyi ni won se gbe igbese ipolongo iyolenu ori ayelujara lati so #ArewaMeToo di eyi ti o lodi si ofin.

en: According to Hashim, harassers attempted to delegitimise ArewaMeToo by associating ArewaMeToo with LGBTQ [lesbians, gay, bisexual transgender and queer people] and their strategy worked as online harassment gained momentum, Hashim said.
yo: Gege bi Hashim se so, awon ayonilenu gbero lati so ArewaMeToo di ohun ti o tase agere si ofin nipa siso ArewaMeToo po mo LGBTQ [obinrin-to-n-fe-obinrin, okunrin-ti-o-n-fe-okunrin, awon abo ati ako ti o yira pada di ako tabi abo ati awon eniyan ti o se ajeji ti ko si ni ibamu] ati ete won sise bi iyolenu ori ayelujara se n lekun si i.

en: In Nigeria, gay marriage is illegal and under Sharia and penal legal codes, sodomy and lesbianism are punishable in some states.
yo: Ni orile ede Naijiria, igbeyawo laaarin okunrin ati okunrin lodi sofin bee naa ni abe ofin Seria ati ofin ifiyaje elese, ibalopo iho idi ati ibalopo laaarin obinrin ati obinrin ni ijiya ni awon ipinle kan.

en: By associating Haashim's movement with LGBTQ rights, online trolls distorted their message and framed #ArewaToo and NorthNormal as illegitimate.
yo: Nipase dida igbese ipolongo Hashim papo mo eto LGBTQ, awon eniyan ni ori ero-ayelujara lo ipolongo won po won si pe #ArewaToo ati NorthNormal ni ohun ti ko to.

en: However, Global Voices was not able to independently verify tweets that pinned Hashim's movement to LGBTQ rights.
yo: Bi-o-ti-wu-ki-o-ri, Ohun Agbaye ko ri aye si awon tuwiiti ti o so igbese ipolongo Hashim ni ija fun eto LGBTQ.

en: Still, Hashim posts messages of hope on Twitter:
yo: Sibe, Hashim se atejade awon oro ireti si ori Twitter:

en: Fakhriyyah Hashim, co-founder of #ArewaToo and NorthNormal (Image used with her permission).
yo: Fakhriyyah Hashim, okan lara awon oludasile #ArewaToo ati NorthNormal (a gba ase lati lo aworan re.

en: "She said all these experiences helped her grow a ""really thick skin"":"
yo: "O so wi pe gbogbo iriri yii ran oun lowo lati ""ni ifarada ti o po"":"

en: In my experience of being loud on political Twitter for good governance, I've grown a really thick skin, but even that didn't prepare me for the amount of backlash we got through ArewaMeToo and NorthNormal.
yo: Iriri mi nipa igbohunsoke lori oro oselu ni ori Twitter fun isejoba ti o dara, ti ko mi ni ifarada, amo iyen ko mu mi gbaradi fun okan-o-jokan itako ti a foju ri latari ipolongo ArewaMeToo ati NorthNormal.

en: Though I mustered all of that and did not retreat to any cave, I did begin feeling demoralised about Northern Nigeria's governanace and response to sexual violence...
yo: Amope mo fi gbogbo re se osun mo fi para n o si je ki o fa mi seyin, mo bere si ni i ni irewesiokan nipa isejoba Ariwa orile ede Naijiria ati bi won se fi owo mu iwa ifipabanilo...

en: After every episode of attacks, we did gather more strength and energy to push back because the backlash made us see how society enforced the culture of silence and if we allowed our lips to be sealed then that would be the real tragedy.
yo: Leyin ikolu kookan, a maa n ni okun ati agbara lati tesiwaju nitori itako mu wa ri bi asa idake roro ti se rinle to ni awujo ati pe bi a ba fi aye gba ipanumo, a je wi pe oko iparun ni a n fi ori le.

en: "Sadly, Hashim and Ezekwesili still struggle with the excruciating ""lack of empathy"" that characterises discourse about gender-based violence on- and offline."
yo: "O seni laaanu, Hashim ati Ezekwesili si n janpata pelu iya ""aisi aanu omolakeji"" ti o diro mo oran iwa ijiya awon obinrin lori ayelujara ati loju aye tooto."

en: "According to Hashim, this ""deliberate maligning of a cause that only seeks better for victims of sexual violence"" is incredibly difficult to grasp."
yo: "Ni ti Hashim, ""imoomo saata igbese ti o n gbero lati fi ohun fun awon ti o n jiya ifarapa"" nira lati gba mu."

en: "This article is part of the project, ""the identity matrix: platform regulation of online threats to expression in Africa."""
yo: "Aroko yii je okan lara akanse ise, ""Orisun idanimo: ofin gbagede ori ero-ayelujara bi ajere ti n gbegi dina idagbasoke oro siso ni Ile Adulawo."""

en: These posts interrogate identity-driven online hate speech or discrimination based on language or geographic origin, misinformation and harassment (particularly against female activists and journalists) prevalent in the digital spaces of seven African countries: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia and Uganda.
yo: Atejade yii se ibeere ipa idanimo oro ikoriira tegbintegbin tabi iyasotooto ti o da firigbagboo lori ede tabi agbegbe ile aye, asiwifun ati iyolenu (paapaa ju lo iyolenu awon ajafetoo omoniyan ati akoroyin l'obinrin) lori ero ayelujara bi ajere ti o wopo ni orile ede Ile Adulawo meje: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia ati Uganda.

en: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
yo: Africa Digital Rights Fund ti Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni o kowo fun a kanse ise yii.

en: "In Assad-controlled Syria, the official narrative is ""no COVID-19 cases"""
yo: "Ni awon ilu ti o wa labe isakoso Assad ni ile Syria, awon alakooso so bayii pe ""ko si isele aarun korona kankan"""

en: After nine years of a deadly civil war, the health system in Syria is barely functional.
yo: Leyin odun mesan-an ogun abele to gbona girigiri, eto ilera ni orile-ede Syria o se bee gbopon mo.

en: In territories controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, authorities deny the presence of COVID-19.
yo: Ni awon ilu ti o wa labe isakoso Aare Bashar al-Assad, awon Alase won ti tako isele aarun COVID-19.

en: According to Johns Hopkins University, the country has confirmed 439 cases and 21 deaths as of July 15.
yo: Gege bi Fafiti John Hopkins  so, Orile-ede ohun ti sawari isele Ojilenirinwo-dinkan pelu iku eniyan mokanlelogun titi di ojo keeedogun osu Agemo.

en: But narratives on the ground reveal the ways in which the state has denied and repressed the realities of COVID-19.
yo: Sugbon awon iroyin ti o wa nile bayii ti se afihan bi ile naa se taku wonle ti won si n se idaniloju pe aarun COVID-19 wa loooto.

en: Walid Abdullah, 23, says the state has even gone so far as to suggest terminating the lives of suspected COVID-19 patients.
yo: Walid Abdullah omo odun metalelogun, so o di mimo pe ile yii tile se e debi pe won n daba gbigba emi awon alaaare ti won ba funra si pe won ni COVID-19.

en: Global Voices is using a pseudonym upon request to protect his identity.
yo: Ohun Agbaye n lo orukokoruko lati daabo bo.

en: Speaking to Global Voices by phone, Abdullah explained that on May 13, he called Daraa National Hospital, in southern Syria, to inform them about a suspected case of coronavirus.
yo: Ninu itakuroso pelu Ohun Agbaye lori ago, Abdullah se e ni alaye pe ni ojo ketala osu ebibi, oun pe Ile iwosan Apapo ti Daraa ni iha Guusu ile Syria lati fi isele aarun korona kan to won leti.

en: "When he asked what steps should be taken, the government hospital employee who answered the phone said: ""Shoot him - we have no cure for him,"" according to Abdullah."
yo: "Gege bi Abdullah se so, nigba ti o beere igbese ti o ye ni gbigbe, osise ijoba ti o gbe ipe naa so pe "" Yinbon pa a, a ko ni iwosan fun"""

en: He quickly ended the call.
yo: O yara fi opin si ipe naa.

en: Obviously, the idea of shooting a suspected COVID-19 patient was out of the question.
yo: Daju, ko si oro ninu yiyin ibon pa eni ti a fura si pe o ni arun COVID-19.

en: """Death by COVID-19 is more honorable than to set foot in any public hospital,"" Abdullah told Global Voices."
yo: "Abdullah so fun Ohun Agbaye ""Iku nipase COVID-19 san ju dida ese wo ile iwosan ijoba lo"""

en: This harrowing testimony is corroborated by other sources.
yo: Eri ibanilokanje eleyii tun kin in leyin lati awon orisun miiran.

en: "In a March 10 report published in The Voice of the Capital, an independent Syrian newspaper, medical personnel from the Syrian Ministry of Health claimed that ""deliberate termination operations are taking place at the al-Mujtahid government hospital in the capital, Damascus, for those who are believed to be carrying the virus, through giving them additional doses of the drug [anesthetic]."""
yo: "Atejade ojo kewaa, osu Erena kan ti The Voice of the Capital, Iwe iroyin Olominira kan ni ile Syria so di mimo, pe awon eleto ilera lati Ile-ise Eto Ilera ile Syria so pe ""Ise Imo-on-mosekupani n waye ni ile iwosan ijoba Al-Mujtahid ni olu ilu ile naa, Damascus, fun awon ti won ni igbagbo pe won ni arun ohun ni tooto, nipa fifun won ni apoju oogun ti o maa n rani niy""e."

en: This claim also appeared on social media:
yo: Eyi pelu fi ara han ni ori ikanni alatagba:

en: Another person from al-Mouwasat Hospital in Damascus was also quoted in the same article confirming this claim:
yo: Elomiiran lati ile iwosan Mouwasat ni Damascus ni oro re tun je didi mo owo ninu atejade kan naa ti o so pe:

en: """These terminations are conducted in complete secrecy and are carried out by doctors dedicated to following up on cases of suspected virus infection."""
yo: """Ise Imo-on-mosekupani n waye ni ibi kolofin patapata, awon dokita ti won se ise itopinpin arun ohun ni won si n se e."""

en: The Assad regime's desperate approach to dealing with COVID-19 parallels callous strategies used in Assad's war, which left 586,100 people dead, nearly 100,000 detained and forcibly disappeared, and 5.6 million refugees around the world.
yo: Igbese saa isejoba Assad si idekun arun COVID-19 yii buru jai, o fi ara jo ete ti won lo nigba Ogun abele Assad ti o gba emi eniyan ti o le die ni milionu, ti Egberun lona ogorun-un ti o wa latimole pare sibe, ti milionu marun-un abo-o-le si di ogunlende kaakiri awon orile-ede agbaye.

en: Virus outbreak and regime survival
yo: Ibesile Ajakale Arun ati Itesiwaju Isejoba

en: The Assad regime owes its survival to its key allies, including Iran. With few allies in the region, Iran has leaned on Syria as well.
yo: Saa isejoba Assad yii ti so opolopo awon ilu ti o yi i ka sinu idaamu ti o fi mo orile-ede Iran naa, pelu bi o se je pe ile Syria ni opolopo awon ilu ti o yi i ka fi n mi.

en: In February, Iran became one of the world's most COVID-19 affected countries and is a likely source of infection in Lebanon, Iraq and Syria, where Iranian troops have had physical contact through military cooperation.
yo: Ni osu Erele, Orile-ede Iran di okan ninu awon orile-ede ti Covid-19 ti sose julo, ibi ti aarun naa gba wo ile won ni o seese ki o je Lebanon, Iraq ati Syria, nibi ti ifarayira ti sele nipase ajosepo awon Ologun.

en: Additionally, Iranian pilgrims and religious tourists, continued to visit Damascus-based shrines up until the first week of March, as reported by Zaki Mehchy, co-author of a March study published by the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE).
yo: Ni afikun, awon Arinrinajo-esin ati awon Arinrinajo-igbafe lati Iran naa tesiwaju lati maa se abewo si awon ojubo ni Damascus titi di ose kini osu erena (march) gege bi Zaki Mechy ti o je ara awon Onkowe March Study ti London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) se so.

en: However, the Assad regime has pursued a policy of misinformation, prevarication and denial in terms of the number of COVID-19 casualties.
yo: Sibe, Isejoba Assad n tepele mo siso ofege iroyin ati iro lorisirisi bee ni o tun se adinku iye awon eniyan ti won ti ni COVID-19.

en: In a March 13 interview with the official Syrian News Channel, Minister of Health Nizar Al-Yaziji insisted on denying the existence of any COVID-19 cases in Syria, saying:
yo: Ni iforowanilenuwo pelu eka iroyin ijoba ile Syria ni ojo ketala Osu Erena, Minisita eto ilera ile naa Nizar Al-Yaziji kojale lori pe ko si isele COVID-19 ni ile Syria, o so pe:

en: """Thank God that the Syrian Arab Army has cleansed the Syrian soil from many germs:"""
yo: """A dupe lowo Olorun pe awon Eka Ologun ti fo ile Syria mo kuro lowo arunkarun:"""

en: The Syrian Ministry of Health did not announce its first case of COVID-19 until March 22, causing resentment and anger among Syrians who noted that the Assad regime lied and pursued a policy of denial.
yo: Minisita eto ilera ile Syria ko tile kede isele aarun COVID-19 akoko ile naa titi di ojo kejilelogun Osu Erena (March 22), eyi si n fa ibinu ati itutosoke foju gba a ni aarin awon omo ile Syria ti won se akiyesi pe isejoba Assad n paro, o si n tako iroyin ododo.

en: "In an article published on an independent Syria 24 news site in response to Yaziji's claims, one citizen poignantly asked, ""didn't you say in your statement that all germs have been eliminated?"""
yo: "Ninu iwe apileko ti won fi si ori ero alatagba-oniroyin kan ni ile naa, okan ninu awon ara ilu fesi si oro Yaziri, o so pe ""se o ko so ninu oro re tele pe gbogbo arun ni o ti je fifo kuro ni"""

en: However, the regime has continued to report implausibly low numbers.
yo: Sibe naa isejoba yii ti bere si ni si se adiku onka iye awon ti won ni arun naa ninu atejade won.

en: In a statement dated April 1, the Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces called on the international community to put pressure on the regime to disclose verified data regarding COVID-19 cases.
yo: Ninu atejade kan ti ojo kini osu Igbe Ajo ti o pe fun Atunse Isejoba Syria ati awon Egbe Alatako kesi awon orile-ede agbaye lati fina mo isejoba ohun, pe ki won o gbe ooto onka iye awon ti won ni arun COVID-19 jade.

en: Stressing the assumed existence of a large number of casualties, the coalition wrote:
yo: O gbe ero re jade lori iye ti o ye ki o je ooto, ajo naa ko bayii pe:

en: A broken health care system
yo: Eto ilera ti o ti denu kole

en: Recognizing the pandemic is embarrassing for the Assad regime because it forces authorities to admit that the health system is non-existent.
yo: Gbigba pe ajakale aarun yii wa loooto bu isejoba Assad ku nitori pe ohun ni yoo je ki awon alase won o fi tipa gba looto pe won ko ni eka eto ilera.

en: According to the LSE study, the maximum number of COVID-19 infections that can be treated in the Syrian health sector is estimated to be only 6,500 in a nation of 17.5 million inhabitants.
yo: Gege bi London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) se so, apapo iye awon alaaare COVID-19 ti won le wo ni ile naa ko ju egberun mefa aabo lo (6500) ninu ogoro eniyan ti o to milionu metadinlogun abo ti o n gbe ni ile naa.

en: If casualties exceed this capacity, the health system, already worn out by the war, is likely to collapse.
yo: O ni bi iye awon alaare ba ti ju iye yii lo, ipa orile-ede naa ti pin niyen, omi si le teyin wogbin lenu.

en: Throughout the war, military attacks have caused widespread damage to the health sector.
yo: Ni asiko ogun abele naa, awon ologun ti se ikolu ti o lagbara si eka eto ilera won.

en: Data from the World Health Organization and the Syrian Ministry of Health show that only 58 hospitals are fully operational among the country's 111 public hospitals.
yo: Akosile lati odo Ajo WHO ati Ile-ise eto ilera ile Syria so o di mimo pe mejidinlogota nikan ni eto ise re pe ninu ile iwosan ijoba okanlelaaadofa ti o wa ni ile naa.

en: The data also noted that up to 70 percent of health workers have left the country as migrants or refugees, while the rest are often subjected to restrictions, including military and political interference.
yo: Akosile yii tun fi han pe o to ida aadorin ninu ogorun-un awon osise eleto ilera ile naa ti won ti kuro lati di atipo ati ogunlende si ile ibomiiran.

en: COVID-19 amid ongoing humanitarian disaster
yo: COVID-19 wa lara ajalu ti o n kuju omoniyan

en: Perhaps the biggest challenge many Syrians face is the accumulation of disasters: war, a pandemic, and famine.
yo: O seese ki o je pe ohun ti o je idojuko awon omo ile Syria julo ni bi awon ajalu yii se ro lu ara won; ogun, ajakale-arun ati iyan.

en: "The United Nations warned on June 26 that Syria is now facing an ""unprecedented"" hunger crisis, with urgent action still needed to prevent the spread of COVID-19."
yo: Ajo Isokan Agbaye se ikilo ni ojo kerindinlogbon osu Okudu pe Syria n foju wina ebi apafeeeku, igbese nikia si nilo lati deena itankale COVID-19

en: According to the World Food Program, food prices rose by 11 percent in May compared to April, and 133 percent when compared to the same period in 2019.
yo: Gege bi Ajo Eleto Ounje Agbaaye se so, owongogo ba ounje pelu ida mokanla iye re tele ni osu Ebibi yato si ti osu Igbe, o si won si i ni iwon metalelaaadoje nigba ti won gbe e wo si ti odun 2019.

en: "As the economic situation deteriorates, 28-year-old Ali al-Ahmed (also a pseudonym upon request to protect his identity) from Daraa city told Global Voices in a phone interview that ""the situation is bad, regardless of how much you work, even if you make 10,000 SYP a day [between $1 and $5 USD] it will not be enough."""
yo: "Gege bi eto oro aje won se denukole. Ali al-Ahmed (orukokoruko ni eyi naa, gege bi eni yii se beere fun idaabobo oruko re) lati ilu Daraa so fun Ohun Agbaye ni ori ago pe ""nnkan buru jai, ko si iru ise ti o le se, koda ki won o maa san Egberun mewaa owo ile Syria (laarin Dola kan si marun-un) fun eniyan, ko le too na."""

en: Ahmed said most people have been forced to forgo many basic goods due to exorbitant costs.
yo: Ahmed ni opo awon eru ni awon eniyan ti ko sile laigba latari owongogo owo igberu.

en: Between a health care system shattered by years of war and an economic situation that has left many Syrians impoverished, the ongoing pandemic has pushed the country toward uncharted, catastrophic territory.
yo: Lasiko ti eto ilera won ti denikole yii lataari ewu ogun ti o wu won ti eto oro aje ti o fori sanpon si ti so opo omo ile Syria di Akusee, Ajakale aarun ti o ja kiri yii tun ti ti ilu yii sinu ewu aikasi ati idibaje.

en: YKS, with 2.5 million students, is taking place despite all the warnings: social distancing disappeared
yo: Idanowo YKS n lo lowo pelu milionu meji abo akekoo laduruu gbogbo ikilo: Ijinasira-eni lawujo gan-an di awati.

en: A new YKS controversy: morality
yo: Aigboraeniye Idanwo YKS tuntun: iwa rere

en: COVID-19 is not the only debate surrounding YKS in 2020.
yo: Ki i se COVID-19 nikan ni faminfa ti o yi Idanowo YKS ka ni odun 2020.

en: An even more impassioned discussion started in early July in relation to a text selected for the Turkish language exam.
yo: Opolopo awon oro lo ti n ja ranhinranhin lati ibeere osu keje eyi ti o niise pelu iwe ayoka fun idanwo ede Turkish.

en: One of the questions referred to the song by pop singer Mabel Matiz, a member of the LGBTQ.
yo: "Okan ninu awon ibeere abe re toka si ""Frtnadaym, (mo wa ninu iji), orin olorin taka-n-sufee kan Mabel Matiz omo egbe LGBTQ."

en: "The question about the meaning of ""Gozumun gordugu, gogsumun bildigi ile bir degil"" (which can be translated as ""what my eyes see is not what my heart feels"") has left its mark on social media because of Mabel's popularity among young people (some of his videos have 50 million views) and his sexual orientation."
yo: "Ibeere lori itumo ""Gozumun gordugu, gogsumun bildigi ile bir degil"" (ti a le tu si ohun ti oju mi ri ko ni ohun ti aya mi mo) ti n da awon ikanni awujo ru gudugudu nitori Mabel je eni ti awon odo mo bi eni mo owo (Opo awon fonran re ni o maa n ni oluwo ti o to aadota milionu) ati ise re lori awon ohun ti o jemo ako ati abo."

en: Following growing debates on Twitter, Halis Aygun, the president of the Center for Measurement, Selection and Placement (OSYM), the government body responsible for preparing the exam, gave an interview to far-right conservative media Yeni Akit in which he said the matter would be investigated and that those responsible for including the text would be fired:
yo: Ni ibamu pelu faminfa ori ikanni Twitter, Halis Aygun Aare Center for Measurement, Selection and Placement (OSYM), eka ijoba ti o boju to iseto idanwo so ninu iforowanilenuwo pelu agba osise iroyin kan, Yeni Akit. Nibe ni o ti so pe won yoo se iwadii oro naa, gbogbo awon ti won ba si lowo ninu fifi iwe naa si abe idanwo ohun ni won yoo le kuro lenu ise.

en: The 2020 YKS was completed safely and successfully in 188 exam centers in three sessions with the participation of approximately two and a half million candidates.
yo: Idanwo YKS odun 2020 kese jari kakakiri awon ibudo idanwo mejidinnigba (188) ni isi eemeta, ti awon akopa ninu re si n lo bii milionu meji abo.

en: The question pool is created with the participation of thousands of academicians from different universities of our country.
yo: Awon idanwo re je eyi ti awon onimo akada kaakiri awon fafiti orile-ede wa seto.

en: The sensitivity of the management of our institution about our national, moral values and social value judgments is clear.
yo: Ikiyesi awon eko ile ati ogbon ibagbepo lawujo fun awon ile-iwe giga wa maa n je kikiyesi.

en: An investigation has been launched into the content of the relevant question in the Turkish area of the 2020 YKS's TYT [this refers to one portion of the YKS exam] session.
yo: Won ti fi idi iwadii lole lori akoonu awon ibeere ti o niise pelu idanwo ede Turkish ti idanwo YKS odun 2020 [eyi ka okan ninu awon abala idanwo YKS].

en: The members of staff responsible will be discharged from the process of question preparation.
yo: Awon osise ti eyi ba si mo lori ni won yoo di gbigbon danu kuro ninu iseto idanwo.

en: For some Twitter users, those measures aren't enough:
yo: Fun awon asamulo ikanni Twitter kan, idajo yii ko to:

en: [Top] OSYM President spoke for the first time after the exam!
yo: "[Oke] Aare OSYM soro fun igba akoko leyin idanwo! """

en: """An investigation has been launched into the content of the problem."
yo: Won ti fi idi iwadii lole lati wo ibi ti isoro naa ti wowa.

en: "Responsible persons will be removed from the question preparation processes. """
yo: "Awon ti won ba lowo ninu re yoo di gbigbon danu kuro ninu iseto idanwo."""

en: [Bottom] It is not enough [to remove him], the neglecting president must be removed from the management process so that he is properly done with.
yo: [Isale] Ko to [la ti yo o] nikan, Aare ti ko ka nnkan si naa gbodo je yiyo kuro ninu isakoso gbogbo ki oju re le wale.

en: Conservative segments of society also question the intention behind the choice of that question:
yo: Owo awon alenuloro lawujo naa tun ri wi si ipinnu ati seto iru ibeere bayii:

en: In today's YKS2020 exam, couldn't you find anyone else to show to teenagers other than the gay and LGBT advocate Mabel Matiz?
yo: Ninu idanwo YKS2020 ti o waye lonii, e ko ri elomiiran fi se apejuwe fun awon omode wonyi afi okunrin onibalopo-akosiako nni Mabel Matiz

en: " (The one who carries a banner saying ""we are faggots"") What are you trying to do?"
yo: " (Eniyan ti o gbe akole ti o fi n polongo pe ""Onibalopo-akosiako ni awa"" Ki ni e n gbiyanju lati se?"

en: Public opinion remains largely divided as other Twitter users point out the success and popularity of Mabel Matiz:
yo: Ero awon asamulo ikanni Twitter ko sokan pelu bi awon miiran se n toka si awon aseyori Mabel Matiz ati bi o se lokiki si:

en: "Dear investigative board members, I recommend that you watch Mabel Matiz's clips. Because we have no other artists who have embraced our culture this way for many years. That's why mabelmatiz is the treasure of our land. He is a unique ""artist"""
yo: Eyin omo igbimo asewadii. Mo fe ki e wo awon fonran Mabel Matiz. Nitori pe a ko ni elere miiran ti o ti se amulo asa wa to bayii ni opo odun seyin. Idi niyen ti mabelmatiz se je isura wa.

en: This netizen draws attention to the fact that by focusing on a gay singer politicians avoid addressing real issues:
yo: Awon netizen pe akiyesi si i pe fifi oju sun olorin ti o je onibalopo-akosiako, awon oloselu yoo pa awon oro ti o se koko ti:

en: Nobody makes any noise about rapists, yet Mabel Matiz question becomes the subject of an investigation.
yo: Ko si eni ti o figbe ta lori awon afipabanilopo, sibe iwadii Mabel Matiz ni won n gba bi eni n gba igba oti.

en: "You say ""our social value judgments"" but Mabel Matiz is the best reflector of our culture."
yo: "E so pe ""idaabo bo ise wa"" sugbon Mabel Matiz ni eni ti o se igbejade asa wa julo."

en: Thus investigation should be about the ones who insult Mabel Matiz and discriminate against him.
yo: O wa ye ki iwadii o da le awon eyi ti o tabuku Mabel Matiz ti won si seleyameya re.

en: Mabel Matiz's response to the controversy.
yo: Esi Mabel Matiz si aigboraeniye naa.

en: On July 3, as the debate became more heated, Matiz finally broke his silence:
yo: Ni ojo keta osu keje, bi faminfa naa se n gbona si i, Matiz pada la ohun:

en: Hi:) I was very happy that my music was be the subject of such an important exam.
yo: E nle o:) Inu mi dun pe orin mi je lilo fun iru idanwo pataki bi eyi.

en: Now I am amazed at how my personal values are subject of the same exam.
yo: Ni bayii, iyalenu loje fun mi bi igbeaye mi se di ohun ti o kan idanwo ti a n so yii.

en: Look what I was tested with, while the geographical sign logo was about placed next to my name.
yo: E wo ohun ti a fi dan mi wo..bi a se gbe aami kan ni ifegbekegbe pelu oruko mi.

en: Well, I say that life's exams never end:) Another roll call came from here.
yo: Ko buru, Idanwo aye ko lopin:) Iyan tun di atungun wayi.

en: I read your intense messages of support.
yo: Mo ka opolopo awon atejade ti o segbe leyin mi.

en: I understand what I want to say with my music, I sense that you understand me, and I feel even stronger now.
yo: Ohun ti mo fe so ninu orin yen yemi, mo nimo pe o ye eyin naa, ara mi si tun ya gaga si i.

en: I will continue to make my music, tell stories, and be part of this country.
yo: N o tesiwaju lati maa ko orin si i, lati maa so itan ati lati je omo orile-ede yii.

en: See you in another exam...
yo: Ka tun pade ninu idanwo miiran...

en: Matiz remains very popular: Just one day after Aygun's statement.
yo: Matiz si lokiki sibe: leyin ojo kan ti Aygun soro safefe.

en: He received two awards in a competition based on the popular vote.
yo: O gba ami-eye meji ninu idije ami-eye kan nipase ibo ti o poju.

en: He won in two categories.
yo: O gba ami-eye ipele meji.

en: """Best Clip"" and ""Best Male Singer"" at the 46th Pantene Golden Butterfly Awards."
yo: """Orin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ati ""Olorin okunrin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ni idije amieye Pantene Golden Butterfly eleekerindinlaaadota iru re."

en: This seems to indicate that very large numbers of people support him against the homophobia expressed by the government and conservative citizens.
yo: Eyi fi han pe opo eniyan ni won wa leyin re tako oro ibalopo-akosiako ti ijoba ati awon alenuloro ti ijoba n so.

en: On July 5, Mabel Matiz tweeted again:
yo: Ni ojo karun osu keje, Mabel Matix tun tuwiiti:

en: "I received the ""Best Male Artist"" and ""Best Video Clip"" awards at the 46th Golden Butterfly Awards, I am happy!"
yo: "Mo gba ami-eye ""Fonran orin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ati ""Olorin okunrin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ninu idije ami-eye Pantene Golden Butterfly eleekerindinlaaadota iru re"

en: "Thanks to all my dear listeners! I would like to extend my thanks to Erhan Ark and DOP Meryem Yavuz, the precious directors of [my song] ""I Have a Red in My Wipe"" clip."
yo: ". Inu mi dun! E se gan eyin olugbo mi gbogbo. Maa fe lati dupe lowo Erhan Arik ati DOP Meryem Yavuz. Awon ti won dari fonran [orin mi] ""I Have a Red in My Wipe"" tele."

en: In Turkey, 2.5m students sit university entry exam despite COVID-19 outbreak
yo: Ni orile-ede Turkey, egbeegberun meji abo awon akekoo ni won jokoo se idanwo igbaniwole si Ifasiti

en: This year's exam was embroiled in controversy - and not just because of the pandemic
yo: Idanwo odun yii waye ninu aigboraeniye - ati pe ki i se nitori ajakale

en: Posted 17 July 2020 12:54 GMT
yo: Atejade itumo 15 Ogun 2020 8:07 GMT

en: Screenshot of the YouTube video featuring a song by Mabel Matiz including the lyrics at the heart of the current controversy around the Higher Education Institutions Exam (YKS):
yo: Aworan oju iwo aworan-olohun ori YouTube ti orin kan lati owo Mabel Matiz pelu oro orin naa ni aarin aigboraeniye ti o suyo latari Idanwo Igbaniwole si Ile Eko Giga (YKS):

en: """Gozumun gordugu, gogsumun bildigi ile bir degil"" (""what my eyes see is not what my heart feels"") "
yo: """Gozumun gordugu, gogsumun bildigi ile bir degil"" (ohun ti oju mi ri ko ni okan mi mo "") "

en: In Turkey, a country of over 83 million people, one needs to pass an entry test, the Higher Education Institution Exam, called Yuksekogretim Kurumlar Snav in Turkish (YKS) to enter university.
yo: Ni orile-ede Turkey, orile-ede ti o le ni egbeegberun metalelogorin eniyan (83 million), eniyan ni lati peregede ninu idanwo igbaniwole ti won n pe ni Yuksekogretim Kurumlar Snav ni ede ile Turkey lati wole si Fafiti.

en: This year, the multiple-choice questionnaire was taken in physical spaces by 2.5 million people, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.
yo: Pelu bi ajakele COVID-19 se n ja ranhin ranhin, idanwo yii si je sise lojutaye, egbeegberun meji abo eniyan (2.5 million) ni won jokoo se idanwo naa.

en: On March 26, the Council of Higher Education announced the dates for YKS as July 25-26.
yo: Ni ojo 26 osu Keta, ajo awon ile-iwe giga ile naa kede ojo idanwo YKS yii gege bi ojo 25 si ojo 26 osu Keje.

en: On May 4, Turkish President Recep Erdogan changed them to June 27 and 28.
yo: Sugbon ni ojo 4 osu karun-un, Aare ile Turkey Recep Erdogan yi ojo naa si ojo 27 si ojo 28 osu Keje.

en: The changes and the uncertainties around the exam amid the COVID-19 pandemic launched countless discussions in Turkish society and on social media:
yo: Ayipada yii ati aidaju idanwo yii ti n ko awon eniyan ile Turkey lominu, ni aarin igboro ilu ati ni ori awon ero alatagba lori pe:

en: How do date changes affect the psychology of students, given the level of stress associated to YKS for which candidates prepare for months?
yo: Bawo ni ojo yiyi se ni ipa lori ironu awon akekoo ti won n mura sile de idanwo lati bi osu meloo kan?

en: How would COVID-19 prevention measures be applied and respected (social distancing, temperature measurements, the use of masks) when bringing together 2.5 million people?
yo: Bawo ni awon alakale ati ofi ideena itankale COVID-19 yoo se di titele (Jijinna sira eni lawujo, iwon igbona/tutu, ilo aso ibomu) bi a ba n ko eniyan ti o to milionu meji abo papo.

en: In 2019, 74.16 percent of the candidates passed the first part of YKS, and only 39.4 percent succeeded in the second part of the exam.
yo: Ni odun 2019, ida merinlelaaadorin o le die ni awon olusedanwo ti won pegede ninu idanwo naa, nigba ti ida mokandinlogoji pegede si ipele ikeji idanwo naa.

en: Turkey registered its first confirmed COVID-19 case on March 11, and by July 15, around 5,500 people infected with the virus have died, while there have been more than 200,000 confirmed cases of the disease in the country.
yo: Orile-ede Turkey se akosile isele COVID-19 akoko won ni ojo 11 osu keta odun, ni igba ti o fi maa di ojo 15 osu keje eniyan egberun marun-un abo ti padanu emi won si owo aarun naa bee si ni iye eniyan ti o ti ni aarun naa ti le ni igba egberun.

en: On July 1, the government enforced special normalization measures:
yo: Ni ojo 1 osu keje, Ijoba gunle awon igbese idekun lorisirisi:

en: Businesses such as restaurants, cafes, cinemas and wedding halls that had been closed for about three months reopened with social distancing restrictions.
