yo: Awon ile oko-owo bi ile ounje, awon oko owo ero ayelujara, ile isafihan ere, gbongan ayeye igbeyawo ti won ti pa fun bii osu meta ni won ti tun si pada bayii, amo sa pelu atele ijijina sira eni lawujo.

en: Patrons are now required to wear masks and will have their temperature taken as well.
yo: Awon olubewo bayii nilo lati maa bo imu wo, won yoo si maa se ayewo igbona/tutu won.

en: While students and opposition parties called for a further postponement of the YKS, the government went ahead with its plans:
yo: Bi awon akekoo tile fi ipe sita pe ki idanwo YKS o di sisun siwaju, ijoba o teti ninu alakale re:

en: In late June, 2.5 million people took the exam.
yo: Ni ipari osu keje milionu meji abo ni o jokoo se idanwo naa..

en: As can be seen in this tweet, concerns over enforcement of social distancing in this context proved to be legitimate:
yo: Gege bi a se ri i ni inu tuwiiti yii, ti o niise pelu asuju lori imunitele ijinna si ara eni lawujo:

en: YKS, with 2.5 million students, is taking place despite all the warnings: social distancing disappeared
yo: Idanowo YKS n lo lowo pelu milionu meji abo akekoo laduruu gbogbo ikilo: Ijinasira-eni lawujo gan-an di awati.

en: A new YKS controversy: morality
yo: Aigboraeniye Idanwo YKS tuntun: iwa rere

en: COVID-19 is not the only debate surrounding YKS in 2020.
yo: Ki i se COVID-19 nikan ni faminfa ti o yi Idanowo YKS ka ni odun 2020.

en: An even more impassioned discussion started in early July in relation to a text selected for the Turkish language exam.
yo: Opolopo awon oro lo ti n ja ranhinranhin lati ibeere osu keje eyi ti o niise pelu iwe ayoka fun idanwo ede Turkish.

en: "One of the questions referred to the song by pop singer Mabel Matiz, a member of the LGBTQ+ community, ""Frtnadaym"" (""I am in the storm""):"
yo: "Okan ninu awon ibeere abe re toka si ""Frtnadaym, (mo wa ninu iji), orin olorin taka-n-sufee kan Mabel Matiz ti i se LGBTQ ""Frtnadaym"" (""I am in the storm""):"

en: "The question about the meaning of ""Gozumun gordugu, gogsumun bildigi ile bir degil"" (which can be translated as ""what my eyes see is not what my heart feels"") has left its mark on social media because of Mabel's popularity among young people (some of his videos have 50 million views) and his sexual orientation."
yo: "Ibeere lori itumo ""Gozumun gordugu, gogsumun bildigi ile bir degil"" (ti a le tu si ohun ti oju mi ri ko ni ohun ti aya mi mo) ti n da awon ikanni awujo ru gudugudu nitori Mabel je eni ti awon odo mo bi eni mo owo (opo awon aworan-atohun re ni o maa n ni iwo ti o to aadota milionu) ati ise re lori awon ohun ti o jemo akosebiabo."

en: Following growing debates on Twitter, Halis Aygun, the president of the Center for Measurement, Selection and Placement (OSYM), the government body responsible for preparing the exam, gave an interview to far-right conservative media Yeni Akit.
yo: Ni ibamu pelu faminfa ori ikanni Twitter, Halis Aygun Aare Center for Measurement, Selection and Placement (OSYM), eka ijoba ti o boju to iseto idanwo so ninu iforowanilenuwo pelu agba osise iroyin kan, Yeni Akit.

en: In which he said the matter would be investigated and that those responsible for including the text would be fired:
yo: Nibe ni o ti so pe won yoo se iwadii oro naa, gbogbo awon ti won ba si lowo ninu fifi iwe naa si abe idanwo ohun ni won yoo le kuro lenu ise:

en: The 2020 YKS was completed safely and successfully in 188 exam centers in three sessions with the participation of approximately two and a half million candidates.
yo: Idanwo YKS odun 2020 kese jari kakakiri awon ibudo idanwo mejidinnigba (188) ni isi eemeta, ti awon akopa ninu re si n lo bii milionu meji abo.

en: The question pool is created with the participation of thousands of academicians from different universities of our country.
yo: Awon idanwo re je eyi ti awon onimo akada kaakiri awon fafiti orile-ede wa seto.

en: The sensitivity of the management of our institution about our national, moral values and social value judgments is clear.
yo: Ikiyesi awon eko ile ati ogbon ibagbepo lawujo fun awon ile-iwe giga wa maa n je kikiyesi.

en: The members of staff responsible will be discharged from the process of question preparation.
yo: Awon osise ti eyi ba si mo lori ni won yoo di gbigbon danu kuro ninu iseto idanwo.

en: For some Twitter users, those measures aren't enough:
yo: Fun awon asamulo ikanni Twitter kan, idajo yii ko to:

en: [Top] OSYM President spoke for the first time after the exam!
yo: [Oke] Aare OSYM soro fun igba akoko leyin idanwo!

en: """An investigation has been launched into the content of the problem. Responsible persons will be removed from the question preparation processes. """
yo: """Won ti fi idi iwadii lole lati wo ibi ti isoro naa ti wowa. Awon ti won ba lowo ninu re yoo di gbigbon danu kuro ninu iseto idanwo."""

en: [Bottom] It is not enough [to remove him], the neglecting president must be removed from the management process so that he is properly done with.
yo: [Isale] Ko to [la ti yo o] nikan, Aare ti ko ka nnkan si naa gbodo je yiyo kuro ninu isakoso gbogbo ki oju re le wale.

en: Conservative segments of society also question the intention behind the choice of that question:
yo: Owo awon alenuloro lawujo naa tun ri wi si ipinnu ati seto iru ibeere bayii:

en: In today's #YKS2020 exam, couldn't you find anyone else to show to teenagers other than the gay and LGBT advocate Mabel Matiz?
yo: Ninu idanwo #YKS2020 ti o waye lonii, e ko ri elomiiran fi se apejuwe fun awon omode wonyi afi okunrin onibalopo-akosiako nni Mabel Matiz?

en: " (The one who carries a banner saying ""we are faggots"") "
yo: " (Eniyan ti o gbe akole ti o fi n polongo pe ""Onibalopo-akosiako ni awa"""

en: What are you trying to do?
yo: Ki ni e n gbiyanju lati se?

en: Public opinion remains largely divided as other Twitter users point out the success and popularity of Mabel Matiz:
yo: Ero awon asamulo ikanni Twitter ko sokan pelu bi awon miiran se n toka si awon aseyori Mabel Matiz ati bi o se lokiki si:

en: Dear investigative board members, I recommend that you watch Mabel Matiz's clips.
yo: Eyin omo igbimo asewadii. Mo fe ki e wo awon fonran Mabel Matiz.

en: Because we have no other artists who have embraced our culture this way for many years.
yo: Nitori pe a ko ni elere miiran ti o ti se amulo asa wa to bayii ni opo odun seyin.

en: "That's why #mabelmatiz is the treasure of our land. He is a unique ""artist"""
yo: Idi niyen ti mabelmatiz se je isura wa.

en: This netizen draws attention to the fact that by focusing on a gay singer politicians avoid addressing real issues:
yo: Awon eeyan lori ayelujara pe akiyesi si i pe fifi oju sun olorin ti o je onibalopo-akosiako, awon oloselu yoo pa awon oro ti o se koko ti:

en: Nobody makes any noise about rapists, yet Mabel Matiz question becomes the subject of an investigation.
yo: Ko si eni ti o figbe ta lori awon afipabanilopo, sibe iwadii Mabel Matiz ni won n gba bi eni n gba igba oti.

en: And this one concludes:
yo: Eleyii ko gbogbo re nile:

en: "You say ""our social value judgments"" but Mabel Matiz is the best reflector of our culture."
yo: "E so pe ""idaabo bo ise wa"" sugbon Mabel Matiz ni eni ti o se igbejade asa wa julo."

en: Thus investigation should be about the ones who insult Mabel Matiz and discriminate against him. #MabelMatizisnotalone [Top of post]
yo: O wa ye ki iwadii o da le awon eyi ti o tabuku Mabel Matiz ti won si seleyameya re. #MabelMatizisnotalone [Atejade oke]

en: Mabel Matiz's response to the controversy
yo: Esi Mabel Matiz si aigboraeniye naa

en: On July 3, as the debate became more heated, Matiz finally broke his silence:
yo: Ni ojo 3 osu Keje, bi faminfa naa se n gbona si i, Matiz pada la ohun:

en: Hi:) I was very happy that my music was be the subject of such an important exam.
yo: E nle o:) Inu mi dun pe orin mi je lilo fun iru idanwo pataki bi eyi.

en: Now I am amazed at how my personal values are subject of the same exam.
yo: Ni bayii, iyalenu loje fun mi bi igbeaye mi se di ohun ti o kan idanwo ti a n so yii.

en: Look what I was tested with, while the geographical sign logo was about placed next to my name.
yo: E wo ohun ti a fi dan mi wo..bi a se gbe aami kan ni ifegbekegbe pelu oruko mi.

en: Well, I say that life's exams never end:)
yo: Ko buru, Idanwo aye ko lopin:)

en: Another roll call came from here.
yo: Iyan tun di atungun wayi.

en: I read your intense messages of support.
yo: Mo ka opolopo awon atejade ti o segbe leyin mi.

en: I understand what I want to say with my music, I sense that you understand me, and I feel even stronger now.
yo: Ohun ti mo fe so ninu orin yen yemi, mo nimo pe o ye eyin naa, ara mi si tun ya gaga si i.

en: I will continue to make my music, tell stories, and be part of this country.
yo: N o tesiwaju lati maa ko orin si i, lati maa so itan ati lati je omo orile-ede yii.

en: See you in another exam...
yo: Ka tun pade ninu idanwo miiran...

en: Matiz remains very popular: Just one day after Aygun's statement, he received two awards in a competition based on the popular vote.
yo: Matiz si lokiki sibe: leyin ojo kan ti Aygun soro safefe, o gba ami-eye meji ninu idije ami-eye kan nipase ibo ti o poju.

en: "He won in two categories, ""Best Clip"" and ""Best Male Singer"" at the 46th Pantene Golden Butterfly Awards."
yo: "O gba ami-eye ipele meji, ""Orin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ati ""Olorin okunrin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ni idije amieye Pantene Golden Butterfly eleekerindinlaaadota iru re."

en: This seems to indicate that very large numbers of people support him against the homophobia expressed by the government and conservative citizens.
yo: Eyi fi han pe opo eniyan ni won wa leyin re tako oro ibalopo-akosiako ti ijoba ati awon alenuloro ti ijoba n so.

en: On July 5, Mabel Matiz tweeted again:
yo: Ni ojo 5 osu Keje, Mabel Matix tun tuwiiti:

en: "I received the ""Best Male Artist"" and ""Best Video Clip"" awards at the 46th Golden Butterfly Awards, I am happy!"
yo: "Mo gba ami-eye ""aworan-atohun orin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ati ""Olorin okunrin ti musemuse re da muse julo"" ninu idije ami-eye Pantene Golden Butterfly eleekerindinlaaadota iru re, Inu mi dun!"

en: Thanks to all my dear listeners!
yo: E se gan eyin olugbo mi gbogbo.

en: I would like to extend my thanks to Erhan Ark and DOP Meryem Yavuz, the precious directors of [my song]
yo: Maa fe lati dupe lowo Erhan Arik ati DOP Meryem Yavuz, awon ti won dari aworan-atohun [orin mi]

en: """I Have a Red in My Wipe"" clip."
yo: """I Have a Red in My Wipe"" clip tele."

en: "When a courtier seeks disgrace, he asks, ""What can the king do?"""
yo: Bi ilari ba fe te, a ni ki loba o se?

en: If the fire gets at the stew, the stew will burst into speech.
yo: Bi ina ba dun obe, a da oro so.

en: Were it not for the fact that they were brought transported together, what would a goat want in the chicken's stall?
yo: Bi ko si akopo, ki lewure wa de iso adie?

en: But for a person of filthy habits, who would wake in the morning and not wash his or her face clean?
yo: Bi ko si tobun eeyan, ta ni iba ji lowuuro ti ko boju sasa?

en: If I die on account of a farm, I will lay my case before the hut; if I die on account of bananas, I will lay my case before the river; if I die on account of the famous woman with facial scarification, I will lay my case before my head.
yo: Bi mo ba tori oko ku n o ro fahere; bi mo ba tori ogede ku n o ro fodo; bi mo ba tori alabaja okiki ku, n o ro forii mi.

en: If it has been three years since the leopard took ill, is it a monkey that one sends to ask its condition?
yo: Bi o di odun meta ti ekun-un ti n se ojojo, olugbe la o ha ran lo be e wo?

en: It is by its flight that the parrot proves itself a formidable bird.
yo: Bi ofe ti n fo la ti n mo o lako eye.

en: Whether the corpse is distended or is not, one should ask the heir of the dead.
yo: Bi oku fe, bi ko fe, ka bi omo olokuu leere.

en: When the eyes see, the mouth remains quiet.
yo: Bi oju ba ri, enu a dake.

en: If the eye does not see, the mouth says nothing.
yo: Bi oju ko ba ri, enu ki i so nnkan.

en: If the thief feels no shame, members of his household should.
yo: Bi oju ko ba ti ole, a ti ara ile e.

en: Even though the host's eyes are tiny, and the guest's eyes are huge, it is the host who holds sway over the guest.
yo: Bi oju onile ba mo tintin, ti oju alejoo to gbongbo, onile ni n se oko alejo.

en: If the owner of a yard does not die, his yard is not overgrown with wild grass.
yo: Bi olode o ku, odee re ki i hu gbegi.

en: If the owner of the food is reluctant to share, one disgraces him by refusing to eat.
yo: Bi olounje ba roju a fi aije te e.

en: When the year is done, the bonnobonnon tree changes its color.
yo: Bi odun ba dun, bonnonbonnon a pawo da.

en: When the market disperses, only the head of the market women remains; only the venerable elders remain; when Ifa has had his say, the genius that consults him arises.
yo: Bi ojaa ba tu tan, a ku olorii patepate, a ku agbaagba sa-nko sa-nko loja; bIfa ba pedi tan, iwo-n-wo a dide.

en: "When a goat's day ""to die"" arrives, it says there is nothing a butcher can do to it."
yo: Bi ojo ewure ba pe, a ni ko si ohun ti alapata le fi oun se.

en: If a lazy man cannot fight, he should be able to die disgracefully.
yo: Bi ole o le ja, a le ku tue.

en: If God does not make one a father, one strives to act like an elder.
yo: Bi Olorun o se eni ni baba, a fi iyanju se bi agba.

en: If a youth attempts to act like an elder, his age will stop him.
yo: Bi omode ba fe sise agba, ojo orii re o nii je.

en: If a child ascends the height of maturity, he/she must become wise.
yo: Bi omode ba gun oke agba, o nilati gbon.

en: When a child is being a child, an elder must remain an elder.
yo: Bi omode ba n se omode, agba a maa se bi agba.

en: If a child brags a great deal, but has no father, one acts the part of a father.
yo: Bi omode n leri bebe, ti ko ni baba, ti baba la n se.

en: Even if the goddess Oya sings in heaven and the god Sango sings on earth, matters cannot be so bad for the father that he will say it is all up to his dead child in heaven.
yo: Bi Oya n ko lorun, bi Sango n jo laye, ko nii buru fun baba ko ni o dowo omo oun lorun.

en: The mad dog, and the person who behaves like a mad dog, both make it impossible for one to know the real dog.
yo: Digbolugi-digboluuyan o je ka mo aja tooto.

en: The elephant has only chosen to remain silent; to the elephant belongs the forest.
yo: Didake lerin dake; ajanaku lo legan.

en: Some masqueraders are greater than others; some gods are greater than others; the masquerader Paaka chases the Sango worshipper into the bush.
yo: Eegun ju eegun; orisa ju orisa; Paaka le onisango wogbe.

en: The masquerader did not hit a woman with his shroud, but the woman unwraps her home-woven wrapper and hits the masquerader with it.
yo: Eegun o na obinrin lago; obinrin tu kijipa idii re, o fi na eegun.

en: "The masquerader stayed too long on parade and is reduced to speaking with his upper lip. They said, ""Welcome, father,"" and he responded, ""He-e-e-e."""
yo: "Eegun pe lode, o fete oke dahun; won ni, ""Baba ku abo,"" o ni, ""Hi ii."""

en: "The masquerader enters a house and claims he did not see Ejonto; Ejonto asked, ""Is that a rag that entered the house, or what?"""
yo: "Eegun wole, o ni oun o ri Ejonto; Ejonto ni, ""Akisa ni, abi kini wole?"""

en: An elephant's bone: it sticks in the wolf's mouth.
yo: Eegun ajanaku: o ha ikoko lenu.

en: A tick fastens on a fox's mouth and a chicken is asked to peck it off; the chicken, though, knows that it itself is food for a fox.
yo: Eegbon so mo ayinrin lenu, a ni ki adie wa yan an je; adie mo pe oun naa ounje ayinrin.

en: A snake does not escape over the fence while a warrior watches.
yo: Ejo ki i ti oju Aare gun ogba lo.

en: I bought twenty cowries worth of corn pap and you bought twenty cowries worth of corn pap, and you call me a corn pap addict.
yo: Emi dako okoo, iwo dako okoo, o n pemi ni muko-muko.

en: I am a pawn, you are a pawn, and you tell me the creditor sent you to collect his money; have you repaid yours?
yo: Emi iwofa, iwo iwofa, o ni baba ni ka gbowo wa; o da tire sile na?

en: It is palm oil that I am carrying; sandman, do not ruin my fortune.
yo: Epo ni mo ru; oniyangi ma ba temi je.

en: An elephant's trumpeting is never answered by its young's trumpeting.
yo: Erin ki i fon komoo re o fon.

en: It is people who use the path that will spread the word about mature corn.
yo: Ero ona ni yo royin oka to gbo.

en: Esuru yam forgets itself and loses favor with the maker of pounded yams; the lizard forgets itself and falls into disfavor with the wall; tortoise-like He-who-will-remain-nameless forgets himself and loses all regard with me.
yo: Esuru se fuja o te lowo oniyan; alangba se fuja o te lowo ogiri; Olamonrin ajapa se fuja o te lowo-o mi.

en: It is only with the ears that a woman hears the voice of Oro.
yo: Eti lobinrin fi n gbo ohun oro.

en: Which among the leaves of the locust-bean tree is adequate to receive corn-loaf?
yo: Ewo lo to ekoo gba ninu ewe irugbaa?

en: What business does Sikirat have in the town of Iwo?
yo: Ewo ni ti Sikira niluu Iwo.

en: The cane-rat that attempts to uproot a palm-tree will lose all its teeth in the attempt.
yo: Ewuju ti yoo tu ope: gbogbo eyin e ni yoo kan tan.

en: The goat did not say it was not sired by the sheep; it was the sheep that said it was not sired by the goat.
yo: Ewure o wi pe oun o somo aguntan; aguntan lo wi pe oun o somo ewure.

en: If sired by a goat, one does not go foraging in the realm of sheep.
yo: Ewure ki i bini ka lo siso aguntan lo je.

en: Only people like monkeys have their clothing torn by monkeys.
yo: Eeyan bi obo lobo n ya laso.

en: Humans have no place to sleep, and a dog is snoring.
yo: Eeyan o ribi sun, aja n hanrun.

en: A shameless person deserves to have only one eye, that one as large as a horse's.
yo: Eeyan ti o nitiju oju kan ni iba ni; a gborin a to tesin.

en: """Lead it into the stable"" is what becomes a horseman."
yo: """E fa a wole"" lo ye elesin."

en: Let us breathe, leave us in peace; the fashion is for people to sit on their behinds; were humans in the position of God they would not permit people to breathe.
yo: E je ka mi, e je ka simi; eeyan ni n fidi eeyan jokoo; eeyan iba se bi Olorun ko nii je ka mi.

en: """Greetings to you, house-bound ones"" is improper for the house-bound to utter; ""Welcome home"" is not proper for the person arriving from a trip; whoever fails to give ""welcome"" to the person returning does himself or herself out of ""greetings, house-bound."""
yo: """E kuule"" o ye ara ile; ""E ku atiba"" o yeni ti n tajo bo; eni ti o ki eni, ""Ku atiba""-a padanu ""E kuule."""

en: The mouth-trap never misses.
yo: Ebiti enu o tase.

en: It is for one's peers that one makes pounded yam with ewura yams.
yo: Egbe eni la n gunyan ewura de.

en: The novice does not know that a good-looking person does not wear a masquerade; all his perfectly white teeth are concealed beneath the cloth.
yo: Egberi o mo pe arewa ki i gbe eku; gbogbo eyin kin-kin-kin labe aso.

en: The elder walks in front, a loincloth draped over his shoulder; the younger walks behind, wearing a garment; if people cannot tell which one is shiftless, does he not know himself?
yo: Egbon siwaju o so aso ko; aburo keyin o wewu; bi a o mole, ole o mo araa re?

en: A person says he has lost an unspecified amount of money, and you ask if the amount is five hundred cowries or eleven hundred cowries; which amount did you steal?
yo: "Eleeede n lo eede, o ni ""Eedegbeta ni abi eedegbefa?""; ewo lo gbe nibe?"

en: The pig wallows in mud, but thinks it is being a dandy.
yo: Elede n pafo, o ro pe oun n soge.

en: A pig does not know what is becoming.
yo: Elede o meye.

en: When a person proclaims the loss of six articles, one does not respond by saying one has not eaten in six days.
yo: Eleefa ki i lo eefaa re ka so pe o di ijefa ti a ti jeun.

en: The person one would leave on the farm hoping he would become a partridge boasts that he is the indispensable presence of the household.
yo: Eni a ba fi soko ko daparo, o ni oun eni ile.

en: A person who should be sold for money to purchase a machete bemoans his lack of a machete.
yo: Eni a ba ta ka fowoo re ra ada: o ni iya ada n je oun.

en: A person who should be sold for money to purchase a lamp boasts that he is one-people-light-lamps-to-admire-at-night.
yo: Eni a ba ta ka fowoo re ra atupa: o ni oun a-ji-tanna-wo-loru.

en: A person one would sell for money to purchase quartered yams for planting: he claims that he has enough earnings to buy three hundred yam pieces.
yo: Eni a ba ta ka fowoo re ra ebu: o ni ele oun ko oodunrun.

en: It is the person who is revered that will disgrace himself or herself.
yo: Eni a n gbe gege ni yo ba araa re je.

en: Whoever gazes downwards with will see his or her nose.
yo: Eni ba de ojuu re sile a rimuu re.

en: The person who wears a crown has outgrown childhood.
yo: Eni dade ti kuro lomode.

en: The person who is clothed by others does not list what he will not wear.
yo: Eni ti a ba n daso fun ki i ka eewo.

en: A person one loves is different from a person who says there is no one like him/herself.
yo: Eni ti a fe yato si eni to ni ko si iru oun.

en: The person whom people have seated on a pig should moderate his or her strutting; even a horse rider will eventually come down to earth.
yo: Eni ti a gbe gun elede, iwon ni ko yo mo; eni to gesin, ile lo n bo.

en: A person who can be lifted does not hang limp.
yo: Eni ti a le gbe ki i dawo.

en: A person whose appearance moves one to tears is moved to laughter by his own appearance.
yo: Eni ti a n wo lawo-sunkun n wo araa re lawo-rerin-in.

en: A person whose company is not desired gets no turn at riddling.
yo: Eni ti a o fe, alo o kan an.

en: A person not welcome in the town does not take a turn in the dancing circle.
yo: Eni ti a o fe niluu ki i jo loju agbo.

en: The person one would expect to be reckless is not reckless; the person one would expect to be cautious is not cautious; the millipede with two hundred arms and two hundred legs behaves very gently.
yo: Eni ti iba huwa ipa o huwa ipa; eni ti iba huwa ele o hu ele; okun to nigba owo, to nigba ese n huwa pele.

en: A person who lacks the strength to lift an ant but rushes forward to lift an elephant ends in disgrace.
yo: Eni ti ko le gbe eera, ti n kusa si erin, tite ni n te.

en: It is a person with limited experience of life who thinks there is none as wise as he.
yo: Eni ti ko ri aye ri ni n so pe ko seni to gbon bi oun.

en: It is the person who deceives himself that the gods above deceive: a bachelor who has no wife at home but implores the gods to grant him children.
yo: Eni to tan araa re lorisa oke n tan: apon ti o laya nile, to ni ki orisa o bun un lomo.

en: A person who is not huge in stature does not breathe heavily.
yo: Eni ti ko to gelete ki i mi fin-in.

en: The person who is self-aware protects his or her own reputation thereby.
yo: Eni to tiju ti i fun araa re.

en: "Nobody is entitled to say, ""Here we come."""
yo: "Enikan ki i je ""Awa de."""

en: What sort of meat is it, the likes of which one has never tasted? A toad comes upon one at the swamp and cowers in fright.
yo: Eran ki la o je ri? Opolo bani labata o ba buruburu.

en: The haft of the hoe is behaving like a hoe.
yo: Eruko n se bi oko.

en: A palace guard does not receive arrows on his back; he suffers wounds only on his front.
yo: Eso ki i gba ofa leyin; iwaju gangan ni n fii gba ogbe.

en: A chain as thick as a palm-tree cannot stop an elephant; the vine that proposes to stop the elephant from going to the grassland will go with the elephant.
yo: Ewon to to ope o too da erin duro; itakun to ni ki erin ma roke odan, toun terin ni n lo.

en: I was born of a monkey; I was raised by a leopard, I was adopted by a cat; if there is no meat in the stew I will not eat it.
yo: Eya lo bi mi, ekun lo wo mi dagba, ologinni gba mi to; bi ko seran lobe n ko je.

en: The woodpecker boasts that it can carve a mortar; who ever used a mortar carved by the woodpecker to make pounded yam?
yo: Eye akokoo ni oun le gbe odo; ta ni je fi odo akoko gunyan je?

en: A bird cannot get at the liquid inside a coconut to drink.
yo: Eye o le ri omi inu agbon bu mu.

en: Whatever bird emulates the vulture will find itself behind the cooking hearth.
yo: Eye to fi ara we igun, eyin adiro ni n sun.

en: Falana, look to your own affairs; one's attention should be focused first on one's own affairs.
yo: Falana gbo tire, tara eni la n gbo.

en: The monkey's showing off is limited to the confines of the forest.
yo: Faaari obo o ju inu igbe lo.

en: Unrestrained and thoughtless behavior does not befit a well-born person.
yo: Ganran-ganran o ye eni a biire.

en: """Take this and eat it"" does not become an elder."
yo: """Gba je"" o ye agba."

en: """Save me, save me!"" does not become an elder; an elder should not do something that will make him the object of pursuit."
yo: """Gba mi, gba mi!"" o ye agba; agba ki i se ohun alemu."

en: """Save me, save me!"" does not befit a masquerader; ""An animal is chasing me!"" does not befit a hunter."
yo: """Gba mi, gba mi!"" o ye eegun; ""eran n lemi bo"" o ye ode."

en: """Accept imputation of imbecility,"" ""I will accept no imputation of imbecility"" is the explanation for market noise."
yo: """Gba were,"" ""N o gba were"" loja fi n ho."

en: Everybody laments Banjo's fate, but Banjo does not lament his own fate.
yo: Gbogbo eeyan ni n sunkun-un Banjo; sugbon Banjo o sunkun ara e.

en: Everybody is taking the title Mayeloye (May-you-never-lose-the-title), but the title you receive is Sare-pegbe (Run-and-assemble-the-associations' members; in other words, Courier or Messenger).
yo: Gbogbo egbe n je Ma-ye-loye, o n je Sare-pegbe.

en: The busybody is privy to all matters.
yo: Gbogbo oro ni n soju eke.

en: There is no cause for staggering about, except for the person pushing himself/herself.
yo: Gbon-on-gbon-on kan o si, afi eni to ba n ti ara e.

en: The disgrace one incurs in one day does not disappear that soon.
yo: Ibaje ojo kan o tan boro.

en: Whatever one names as the head, one does not tread the floor with it.
yo: Ibi ti a ba pe lori, a ki i fi tele.

en: Wherever one situates the body, there it inhabits.
yo: Ibi ti a fi ara si lara n gbe.

en: Salt dampens only the place where it is placed.
yo: Ibi ti a fi iyo si lo n somi si.

en: The part one names the head is the one that grows hair.
yo: Ibi ti a pe lori ni n hurun.

en: The place where a lazy person was apprehended bears no marks; the place where a powerful man was apprehended is broad enough to plant a farm.
yo: Ibi ti a ti mu ole o kunna; ibi ti a ti mu alagbaraa to okoo ro.

en: Where one must recite genealogies in order to establish one's claim to inheritance, one should know that one really has no claim to patrimony there.
yo: Ibi ti a ti n pitan ka to jogun, ka mo pe ogun ibe o kanni.

en: Where life catches up with one, there one lives it.
yo: Ibi ti aye ba eni ni a ti n je e.

en: It is the master's engaging in silly antics that affords the pawn the opportunity to laugh so hard that he tosses his cutlass away.
yo: Ibon dida olowo lo ni kiwofa rin rin rin ko so ada nu.

en: It is with its own sword that one kills the tortoise.
yo: Ida ahun la fi n pa ahun.

en: The sword is destroying its own home, and it says it is ruining the scabbard.
yo: Ida n wo ile ara e o ni oun n ba ako je.

en: The two buttocks are sufficient for their owner to sit on.
yo: Idi mejeeji to oluwaa re jokoo.

en: The vulture perches on the roof; its eyes see the homestead as well as the farm.
yo: Igunnugun ba le orule; oju to ile o to oko.

en: When the clay statue hankers for disgrace it asks to be placed in the rain.
yo: Igba ti sigidii ba fe se ere ete a ni ki won gbe oun sojo.

en: When will (or how can) Maku avoid the danger of dying? Maku does not know the mysteries of the cult yet he joins in its vows; Maku does not know how to swim and yet he jumps into the river.
yo: Igba wo ni Makuu o nii ku? Makuu o mo awo o n bu opa; Makuu o mo o we o n bo sodo.

en: What sort of hole does the rat live in that makes him say that household work preoccupied it?
yo: Iho wo lekute n gbe to ni ise ile n diwo?

en: The wild cat never roams in daylight; a well-bred person does not wander around in the night time.
yo: Ijakumo ki i rin osan, eni a biire ki i rin oru.

en: The brown ant cannot lift a boulder.
yo: Ijalo o le gbe okuta.

en: How one sits causes one to carry the leaves used to wrap corn-meal to the dump.
yo: Ijokoo eni ni n muni da ewe eko nu.

en: The government summons you and you say you are busy eating cassava grains soaked in water; who owns you, and who owns the water with which you are eating the cassava?
yo: Ijoba n pe o o ni o n mu gaari lowo; ta ni ni o, ta ni ni omi ti o fi n mu gaari?

en: """I-was-in-my-home"" is never the guilty party in a dispute."
yo: Ile-ni-mo-wa ki i jebi ejo.

en: A house does not burn while the landlord lounges with indifference.
yo: Ile ki i jo ki baale ile takaka.

en: A house does not burn and fill the eyes with sleep.
yo: Ile ki i jo ki oorun kun oju.

en: One drum is not enough for an Egun person to dance to; if one drums for him he too will play a rhythm on his chest.
yo: Ilu kan o to Egun jo; bi a ba lu fun un a maa lu aya.

en: Fire burns and the wall does not run from it; now it moves threateningly towards water.
yo: Ina n jo ogiri o sa, o wa n gba geere geere somi.

en: An unpleasant inside is what a venerable elder should have; a venerable elder should not have an unpleasant mien.
yo: Inu buruku lagba n ni, agba ki i ni oju buruku.

en: The wound left by a cutlass may heal, but the wound left by speech does not heal.
yo: Ipa ogbe ni n san; ipa ohun ki i san.

en: One sees only other peoples' occiputs; only others can see one's own.
yo: Ipako onipako la n ri; enieleni ni n ri teni.

en: The eyelashes do not make dew; a venerable old beard does not behave like an ingenue.
yo: Ipenpeju o ni enini; agbalagba irungbon o se oloo.

en: There is no cheating in photography; it is just as you sit that you will find your image.
yo: Ireje o si ninuu foto; bi o ba se jokoo ni o o ba araa re.

en: The likeness of a particular type of cloth is not lacking among those in fashion.
yo: Iru aso o tan ninu asa.

en: The likeness of an elephant is not scarce in Alo.
yo: Iru erin o tan ni Alo.

en: The horse-tail whisk does not shun Ifa; high-fashion maiden, pause awhile and give me a greeting.
yo: Irukere ki i yan Ifa lodi; oge, duro o ki mi.

en: "The fugitive does not stop to pull a thorn ""from his/her feet""; the fugitive does not stop to clear dinner dishes."
yo: Isansa o yo egun; isansa ki i kawo obe.

en: Destitution does not attach to one at a particular place; suffering does not attack a person at a particular place; if one walks like a wretch into a town, if one looks like a loser when one enters a town, it is with a miserable calabash that the people will offer one water to drink.
yo: Ise o ti ibikan mu eni; iya o tibikan je eeyan; bi o ba rinrin osi, bi o ba oju ise wolu, igbakugba ni won o fi bu omi fun e mu.

en: A vine as thick as a palm-tree trunk will not stop an elephant; whatever vine attempts to stop an elephant from going to Alo will go with the elephant instead.
yo: Itakun to to ope ko to pe kerin ma lo; itakun to pe kerin ma lo Alo, toun terin ni n lo.

en: Character is always remarkable (or good) in the opinion of its owner.
yo: Iwa ni n jo oniwa loju.

en: A pawned person always dances with a pawned person.
yo: Iwofa ni n mu iwofa jo.

en: The measure of the rat is the measure of the nest; a robin does not live on a cushion.
yo: Iwon eku niwon ite; olongo ki i gbe timutimu.

en: Trading insults brings ruin to an elder's home.
yo: Iwosi ni i ba ile agba je.

en: The wife who whips a relative of her husband is asking for stern rebuke.
yo: Iyawo to na omo obakan, oro lo fe gbo.

en: Sedately is the way an elderly masquerader dances.
yo: Jeje leegun agba n jo.

en: The jokumo plant looks like the indigo plant; it is the indigo dye, though, we have use for.
yo: Jokumoo se bi elu, aro la be lowe.

en: To see a person in the streets is not the same as going home with the person.
yo: Ka rini lode o dabii ka bani dele.

en: Having people to advise one is nothing like knowing how to take advice.
yo: Ka rini soro funni o dabii ka soro funni ka gba.

en: If one is spoken to one should listen; if one is advised one should heed the advice; one should seek direction from straggling wayfarers in order than one's life might be pleasant.
yo: Ka wi fun eni ka gbo; ka soro funni ka gba; ka bere ona lowo ero to ku leyin kaye baa le yeni.

en: If one is spoken to one should listen; if one is advised one should accept the advice; refusal to listen to speech and refusal to accept advice leads to using the calabash of deprivation as a drinking cup.
yo: Ka wi funni ka gbo; ka soro funni ka gba; a-wi-igbo, a-gbo-igba ni n fi igba adanu bu omi mu.

en: To heed advice is what best becomes a human being.
yo: Ka wi ka gba lo ye omo eeyan.

en: "Whether one speaks twenty times or speaks thirty times, ""I do not like it, and I will not accept it"" is how the imbecile ends the discussion."
yo: "Ka wi ogun, ka wi ogbon, ""N o fe, n o gba"" lasiwere fi n pekun oran."

en: Rather than prostrate oneself in homage or obeisance to a Hausa person, one should rather die.
yo: Kaka ka dobale fun Gambari, ka roju ka ku.

en: Rather than cry out, the ram will die.
yo: Kaka ki agbo ke, agbo a ku.

en: Rather than the father carrying the son's cutlass home from the farm, each will carry his own.
yo: Kaka ki baba ran omo ni ada bo oko, onikaluku a gbe tie.

en: Rather than bend backwards, the crab's claws will break.
yo: Kaka ki iga akan o pada seyin, a kan.

en: Rather than the lion serving as carrier for the leopard, each will hunt separately.
yo: Kaka ki kiniun se akapo ekun, olode a mu ode e se.

en: The toad is only slightly taller than the earth.
yo: Kekere lopolo fi ga ju ile lo.

en: Let the slave know him/herself as a slave; let the pawn know him/herself as a pawn; let the well born person know him/herself as the child of God.
yo: Ki eru mo ara e leru; ki iwofa mo ara e niwofa; ki omoluwabi mo ara e leru Olorun oba.

en: Responsibility does not devolve on the father only for him to say it is his son's duty.
yo: Ki i dowoo baba ko lo di owo omo.

en: What is the point of bragging on account of an ass which when one rides on it one's feet drag on the ground?
yo: Ki ni anfani ketekete lara ketekete a-gun-fese-wole?

en: What does a bald man want in the stall of the barber?
yo: Ki ni apari n wa ni iso onigbajamo?

en: What did Daaro own before he claimed he was robbed?
yo: Ki ni Daaro ni ko to so pe olee ko oun?

en: What is it that the seller of gbegbe leaves has to sell that she complains that the market is slow?
yo: Ki ni elewee gbegbe n ta ti o n so pe oja o ta?

en: What would take the vulture to the stall of the hair dresser?
yo: Ki ni iba mu igun de odoo onidiri?

en: "What has the bachelor to feel superior about, such that while he is roasting yams he is whistling the song, ""What one does fills them with jealousy""?"
yo: "Ki ni o ya apon lori to fisu sina to n sufee pe ""bi a ti n se ni inu n bi won""?"

en: What is the calabash owner doing that the china plate owner cannot do?
yo: Ki ni onigba n se ti alawo o le se?

en: What can the head do that the shoulder cannot do? The shoulder carried a load and earned three hundred cowries; the head sold its own for two hundred and twenty cowries.
yo: Ki ni ori n se ti ejika o le se? Ejika ru eru o gba oodunrun; ori ta tie ni ogunlugba.

en: What use do the people of Ilorin have for Ahmadu? Even goats are so named.
yo: Ki ni won ti n se Amodu nIlorin? Ewure n je bee.

en: Durable hand-woven cloth is the material for shiftless people; loom-woven cloth is the material for the elders; whichever elder cannot afford loom-woven cloth should strive for durable hand-woven cloth.
yo: Kijipa laso ole; ofi laso agba; agba ti o ni tofi a roju ra kijipa.

en: He does not buy, he has no money, yet he sits sulkily before the seller of bean fritters.
yo: Ko ra, ko lowo lowo, o n wu tutu niwaju onitumpulu.

en: "There is no one pleased ""by one's success"" except one's head."
yo: Ko si eni to dun mo afi ori eni.

en: Without-me-in-an-assembly-the-assembly-is-not-complete deceives only himself/herself.
yo: Ko si mi lajo ajo o kun: ara e lo tan je.

en: There is nothing Sango can do to enable itself to rage in a drought.
yo: Ko si ohun ti Sango le se ko ja leerun.

en: He-was-not-at-home never fails to prove his valor with his mouth.
yo: Ko-si-nile ki i jagun enu ti.

en: Swiftly-consumed-swiftly-consumed is the way a dog laps up water.
yo: Ko-tan-ko-tan laja n la omi.

en: The butterfly likens itself to a bird, but it cannot do what a bird can do.
yo: Labalaba fi ara e weye, ko le se ise eye.

en: Ash mixed with water likens itself to indigo dye, but it cannot do what the dye can do; the large red bean likens itself to corn.
yo: Labulabu fara we aro, ko le se bi aro; popondo fara we agbado.

en: Were So-and-So alive he would transform himself into a brown monkey; did the person who preceded him ever transform himself into any kind of monkey?
yo: Lagbaja iba wa a di ijimere; eni to ba niwaju di oloyo?

en: A limp is no great asset for a person wishing to stop a fight; a masquerader's child is no easy playmate.
yo: Laka-n-laka o see fi laja; omo eegun o see gbe sere.

en: One does not wear etu cap as a matter of course; only certain people have heads suited for such a cap.
yo: Lasan ko la n de etu; o ni eni tori e n ba etu mu.

en: Cattle egrets never lay black eggs; only white eggs do they lay.
yo: Lekeelekee o ye eyin dudu; funfun ni won ny e eyin won.

en: Save face with members of your household and save face with complete strangers, such a person loses face with himself/herself.
yo: Ma tee lowo onile, ma tee lowo alejo; lowo ara eni la ti n te.

en: A cow may not boast in the presence of a horse.
yo: Maluu o le leri niwaju esin.

en: Lightning is no good for roasting yams.
yo: Manamana o see sun isu.

en: """Were I at Oyo I would own a horse by now"": he should have numerous sheep to his name in this town."
yo: """Mba wa lOyoo ma ti so esin""; aguntan-an re a niye nileyi."

en: "How large a community is Ejigbo that one of its settlements is named Ayegbogbo ""The whole world""?"
yo: Meloo lEjigbo ti okan e n je Aye-gbogbo?

en: I have become old and wise, but childish play has not ceased to appeal to me.
yo: Mo dagba mo dago, are omode o tan lojuu mi.

en: Having grown old I miss youthfulness.
yo: Mo dagba tan ewee wu mi.

en: """I am beautiful, I am beautiful!"" has ugliness as its conclusion."
yo: """Mo dara, mo dara,"" aidara ni n pekun e."

en: """I am all-wise, I am all-knowing"" kept the wasp from having as much venom as the bee."
yo: """Mo gbon tan, mo moran tan"" ki i je ki agbon loro bi oyin."

en: "and also ""Mo mo-o gun,"" . . ."
yo: "Compare ""Mo mo-o gun"" . . ."

en: """Mo mo-o tan,."" . ."
yo: "Compare ""Mo gbon tan, . . . """

en: "also ""Mo gbon tan, . . . """
yo: Compare the preceding entry,

en: "and ""Mo mObara..."""
yo: "Compare ""Mo gbon tan, . . . """

en: """Mo mo-o gun, . . ."""
yo: "Compare ""Mo gbon tan, . . . """

en: """I am full"" means ""I am full""; ""I decline"" means ""I decline""; eating with abandon, that is the father of all greediness."
yo: """Mo yo"" n je ""mo yo,"" ""mo ko"" n je ""mo ko""; jeun nso, agba okanjuwa ni."

en: """I will get my money's worth out of these trousers""; the grown man only winds up exposing his bare buttocks to the world."
yo: """N oo gba owoo mi lara sokoto yii""; idi lagbalagba n si sile."

en: "The humpback's child has presented a formidable dilemma: he cries, ""Mother, mother, carry me on your back!"""
yo: "Nlanla lomo abuke n da: o ni ""Iya, iya, oun o pon."""

en: Where did you discard all other names and picked for yourself the name Lamboroki?
yo: Nibo lo foruko si ti o n je Lamboroki?

en: When we were stacking the corn we did not stack some for the brown rat.
yo: Nigba ti a n to oka a o to ti emo si.

en: Since you claim to be a seasoned rider, how come your horse has gone lame?
yo: Nigba ti o mo o gun, esin e e se se orokun?

en: Since when did a tiger-hide sac become a thing a child uses to harvest okro?
yo: Nigba wo lapo ekun-un di ikala fomode?

en: Salt loses its good quality and becomes like saltpeter.
yo: O bo lowo iyo o dobu.

en: The moon loses its esteem and shines all night long.
yo: O bo lowo osu o daran-moju.

en: Your eyes flinch not and your mouth is unstoppable, but you do not know nine times nine.
yo: O daju danu, o o mo esan mesan-an.

en: Not until the gathering of trousers will Ladugbo know itself as a miscreant.
yo: O di awujo sokoto ki ladugbo to mo ara re Labese.

en: It will not be until the end of days before the humpback realizes that a hump is not a child.
yo: O di ojo ale kabuke to mo pe ike ki i somo.

en: You do not know what black eyed peas are like for dinner.
yo: O ko mo ewa lonje a-je-sun.

en: You are reduced to eating last year's antelope in your stew, and yet you claim to have attained the height of good fortune.
yo: O n jagbonrin esin lobe, o ni o ti to tan.

en: Because you are carrying a huge pot you strut; what would one say to the person carrying the divinity Yemoja?
yo: O ru ladugbo o n rera; ki ni ka so feni to ru Orisaa Yemoja?

en: It might be seemly for a masquerader to chase one off a corn farm, but it is not seemly for Pakoko to chase one in the middle of town.
yo: O to ki eegun leni loko agbado, ewo ni ti Pakoko laarin ilu?

en: Everybody has a right to say the yams are not well cooked, but not the bata drummer.
yo: O ye eni gbogbo ko so pe isu o jina, ko ye alubata.

en: It is fitting for everybody to bargain to reduce the cost of dyeing clothes, but not the bed wetter.
yo: O ye eni gbogbo ko dinwo aro, ko ye atoole.

en: "Everyone can justifiably say, ""God, who has left nothing undone,"" but not a eunuch."
yo: "O ye eni gbogbo ko so pe ""Olorun a-sekan-ma-ku,"" ko ye akuko."

en: It is only in a small stream that the crab can make its oil; when it becomes huge and swift the river sweeps the crab away.
yo: Odo kekere lalakan-an ti le fo epo; bo ba di agadamgba tan, odo a gbe alakan lo.

en: "The law will assert itself, ""as in the case of"" a junior wife flogging the child of the senior wife."
yo: Ofin ni yo so ara e; iyawo ti n na omo iyaale.

en: The war that the two-eyed person saw and fled is the same the one-eyed person vows he will join.
yo: Ogun ti oloju meji ri sa ni oloju kan ni oun n lo ja.

en: Only two things are proper for a warrior: the warrior goes to war and drives the enemy off; the warrior goes to war and dies in battle.
yo: Ohun meji lo ye Eso: Eso ja, o le ogun; Eso ja o ku sogun.

en: What one sells is what one eats; that does not apply to the kerosene seller.
yo: Ohun ti a n ta la n je; ki i se oro oni-kerosiini.

en: Whatever the ant is able to carry is what it says is its full measure.
yo: Ohun ti eera ba le gbe ni n pe ni iganniko.

en: That which the cricket attempted and broke a thigh, the alaantete asks to be permitted to attempt.
yo: Ohun ti iree se to fi kan lapa, alaantete ni ki won je ki oun o se e.

en: A thing that is not worth the least amount of money should not prove a hardship for an elder.
yo: Ohun ti ko to okoo ki i je agba niya.

en: What the imbecile does to himself is far worse than what he does to others.
yo: Ohun ti were fi n se ara e, o po ju ohun to fi n se omo elomiran lo.

en: "One boasts only about things proper to boast about; whoever heard of the boast, ""By this time yesterday I had given my parent-in-law the beating of his life.""?"
yo: "Ohun to see faga la n faga si; ewo ni,""Iwoyi ana mo ti na anaa mi faga-faga""?"

en: It is in a visitor's presence that one gets into debt; it is in her absence that one repays the debt.
yo: Oju alejo la ti n je gbese; eyin-in e la n san an.

en: The eye, father of the body; nothing is as valuable as the eye; nothing is as difficult to achieve as the status of elder.
yo: Oju baba ara; awon bi oju; asoro da bi agba.

en: It is not in the presence of the flame that water-yam grows hair.
yo: Oju ina ko lewura n hurun.

en: The colobus monkey is never so reduced in circumstances that it becomes a land-hugging creature; the vulture is never so badly off that it becomes the equal of a chicken.
yo: Oju ki i pon edun ko deni ile; ise ki i se igun ko di ojugba adie.

en: A head of a household is never so hard up that he sweeps his compound with his bare hands.
yo: Oju ki i pon baale ile ko fowo gbale ile e.

en: An Ifa diviner-priest is never so hard up that he asks for yesterday's sacrifice.
yo: Oju ki i pon babalawo ko beere ebo ana.

en: A dead person cannot be so desperate as to appeal to a living person for deliverance.
yo: Oju ki i pon oku orun ko ni ki ara aye gba oun.

en: One should not become so desperate that one takes one's younger sister as wife.
yo: Oju ki i ponni ka faburo eni saya.

en: One should never be so benighted that one covers oneself in rags.
yo: Oju ki i ponni ka fakisa bora.

en: One's circumstances do not so deteriorate that one becomes red in teeth.
yo: Oju ki i ponni ka pon leyin.

en: A person only newly acquainted with wealth; he has a son and names him Olaniyonu.
yo: Oju o rola ri; o bimo e o so o ni Olaniyonu.

en: The medicine man lacks all shame, he announces that his parent-in-law is dying.
yo: Oju o ti onisegun, o ni ana oun n ku lo.

en: Shame upon the wasp; the wasp has a nest but no honey.
yo: Oju ti agbon agbon lafa ko lero.

en: The giant bush rat and its child become equals in their hole; the mother cracks palm-nuts with its teeth, and the child does the same thing.
yo: Okete pelu omo ee di ogboogba sinu iho; nigba ti iya n feyin pakuro, omo naa n feyin pa a pelu.

en: "Darkness does not know who deserves deference; it consulted the oracle Ifa for ""Who might you be?"""
yo: "Okunkun o meni owo; o dIfa fun ""Iwo ta niyen""?"

en: A person who has only one wife does not form a circle for a fight.
yo: Olobinrin kan ki i pagbo ija.

en: A one-eyed person does not attempt standing somersaults.
yo: Olojukan ki i takiti oro.

en: The omele drummer does not vow that there will be an earth-shaking performance on the morrow.
yo: Olomele ki i so pe igi yo daa lode lola.

en: The rich man eats slowly and at leisure; the poor person eats fast and with anxiety; the poor man who keeps company with a wealthy man is exceeding his station.
yo: Olowo jeun jeje; otosi jeun tipa-tijan; otosi ti n ba oloro rin, ako oju lo n ya.

en: It is a rich person that keeps company with a wealthy person; only people of equal standing play together.
yo: Olowo ni n ba oloroo rin; egbe ni n ba egbe sere.

en: It is a rich person that eats pounded yams worth two thousand cowries.
yo: Olowo ni n je iyan egbaa.

en: A minor chief should not act garrulously in the presence of a king.
yo: Oloye kekere ki i se faaari niwaju oba.

en: Today, the antelope falls into the ditch; tomorrow, the antelope falls into the ditch; is the antelope the only animal in the forest?
yo: Oni, etu jinfin, ola, etu jinfin; etu nikan leran to wa nigbo?

en: The shameless person does not know what is fitting; the shameless person is off to raid a farm, and he takes his wife along; the husband steals staple yams, the wife steals wateryams.
yo: Onibaje o mora; onibaje n lo soko ole o mu obinrin lo; oko ko akosu, iyawo ko ewura.

en: "The bata drummer does not enter a mosque and ask ""Where is the Imam?"""
yo: "Onibata ki i wo mosalasi ko ni ""Lemamu nko?"""

en: "The excessively attentive visitor ""who"" extends hospitality greetings to the host."
yo: Onifunra alejo ti n tete se onile pele.

en: The person with goitre offers a ridiculously low price for beads; were the beads seller to accept her offer she would have no neck to string the beads around.
yo: Onigege fileke dopo; onileke iba gbowo, ko rorun fileke so.

en: The host is eating the fruits of the gbingbindo tree; the visitor asks to be treated to some black-eyed peas.
yo: Onile n je eso gbingbindo; alejoo ni ki won se oun lowo kan ewa.

en: The Sango worshipper who dances and does not shake his skirt: he does not disgrace Sango but himself.
yo: OniSango to jo ti ko gbon yeri: abukuu Sango ko; abuku ara e ni.

en: Facebook's role in Brexit - and the threat to democracy.
yo: Ipa Facebook ninu Brexit - ati ideruba re si ijoba awarawa.

en: "So, on the day after the Brexit vote, in June 2016, when Britain woke up to the shock of discovering that we're leaving the European Union, my editor at the ""Observer"" newspaper in the UK asked me to go back to South Wales, where I grew up, and to write a report."
yo: "Nitori naa, ni ojo keji leyin ibo Brexit, ni osu Okudu odun 2016, nigba ti orile-ede Britain ji si ijaya mimo wi pe a n kuro Ajo-Igbimo Ile-Europe sile, olootu mi ni iwe-iroyin ""Observer"" ni orile-ede UK so fun mi wi pe ki n pada si South Wales, nibi ti mo ti se kekere, ki n si ko ijabo."

en: And so I went to a town called Ebbw Vale.
yo: Mo ba lo si ilu kan ti won n pe ni Ebbw Vale.

en: Here it is.
yo: Oun re e.

en: It's in the South Wales Valleys, which is this quite special place.
yo: "O wa ni South Wales Valleys, t""o je ibi akanse ti o pa lowo bayii."

en: So it's had this very, sort of rich, working-class culture, and it's famous for its Welsh male voice choirs and rugby and its coal.
yo: Nitori naa o ti ni asa owo-osise, ibi oro, o si gbajumo fun ohun awon egbe akorin olohun okunrin Welsh ati boolu alafowo-fese gba ati eedu re.

en: But when I was a teenager, the coal mines and the steelworks closed, and the entire area was devastated.
yo: Sugbon nigba ti mo wa ni ogoso, iwakusa eedu ati ise-ona irinlilo di titipa, ti gbogbo agbegbe naa si ti baje.

en: "And I went there because it had one of the highest ""Leave"" votes in the country."
yo: "Nigba ti mo si lo sibe nitori o ni okan lara ibo ""Kuro"" to poju lo ni orile-ede naa."

en: Sixty-two percent of the people here voted to leave the European Union.
yo: "Ida meji-le-logota awon eniyan nibi l""o dibo lati fi Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe sile."

en: And I wanted to know why.
yo: Mo si fe mo idi re.

en: When I got there, I was just a bit taken aback, because the last time I went to Ebbw Vale, it looked like this.
yo: Nigba ti mo debe, o ya mi lenu die, nitori igba ti mo lo si Ebbw Vale keyin, o ri bayii.

en: And now, it looks like this.
yo: Sugbon nisinyii, o ri bayii.

en: This is a new 33-million-pound college of further education that was mostly funded by the European Union.
yo: Ile-eko giga oni owo poun aadota-oke 33 tuntun fun itesiwaju eto-eko ti pupo ninu owo yen wa lati owo Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe.

en: And this is the new sports center that's at the middle of 350-million-pound regeneration project that's being funded by the European Union.
yo: Ibi ere-idaraya tuntun re e ti o wa laaarin ise akanse isodotun oni aadota-oke 350 owo poun ti Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe n se onigbowo re.

en: And this is the new 77-million-pound road-improvement scheme, and there's a new train line, a new railway station, and they're all being funded by the European Union.
yo: Eyi ni eto atunse ona tuntun oni owo poun aadota-oke 77, oju ona oko-oju-irin tuntun naa wa, ibudoko awon oko ojuurin tuntun, ti o je wi pe Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe lo n se onigbowo gbogbo re.

en: And it's not as if any of this is a secret, because there's big signs like this everywhere.
yo: Ki i si se wi pe ikankan ninu awon wonyii je asiiri, nitori awon apeere nla bi eyi wa kaakiri.

en: [EU Funds: Investing in Wales]
yo: [Owo Igbowo EU: idokowo ninu Wales].

en: I had this sort of weird sense of unreality, walking around the town.
yo: Mo ti ni imolara ajoji yii nipa aijoooto bi mo se n rin kaakiri ilu naa.

en: And it came to a head when I met this young man in front of the sports center.
yo: O wa simi lori nigba ti mo pade odomokunrin kan niwaju ibi ere idaraya naa.

en: And he told me that he had voted to leave, because the European Union had done nothing for him.
yo: O so fun mi wi pe oun ti dibo lati kuro, nitori Ajo-igbimo Ile Europe o se nnkankan fun oun.

en: He was fed up with it.
yo: O ti su u.

en: And all around town, people told me the same thing.
yo: Yika gbogbo ilu, oun kan naa ni awon eniyan n so fun mi.

en: They said that they wanted to take back control, which was one of the slogans in the campaign.
yo: "Won ni awon fe gba isakoso pada, eyi t""o je okan lara ipede ninu ipolongo naa."

en: And they told me that they were most fed up with the immigrants and with the refugees.
yo: Won so fun mi wi pe ti awon asikiri ati awon ogunlende ni o toju su awon ju.

en: They'd had enough.
yo: Awon ti ri to.

en: Which was odd.
yo: Leyii to sajoji.

en: Because walking around, I didn't meet any immigrants or refugees.
yo: Tori bi mo se rin kaakiri, mi o ri asikiri tabi ogunlende kankan.

en: I met one Polish woman who told me she was practically the only foreigner in town.
yo: Mo pade arabinrin omo Poland kan ti o so fun mi wi pe oun nikan ni ajoji to wa ninu ilu naa.

en: And when I checked the figures, I discovered that Ebbw Vale actually has one of the lowest rates of immigration in the country.
yo: "Nigba ti mo wo iye re, mo ri i wi pe Ebbw Vale ni okan lara igbelewon isilo-si-ilu-okeere-miiran t""o kere julo ni orile-ede naa."

en: And so I was just a bit baffled, because I couldn't really understand where people were getting their information from.
yo: O fa iporuru okan die fun mi, nitori mi o ni o ye ibi ti awon eniyan ti n gba ifitonileti won.

en: Because it was the right-wing tabloid newspapers which printed all these stories about immigration.
yo: "Nitori iwe-iroyin apa-otun l""o se atejade gbogbo iroyin nipa isilo-si-ilu-okeere-miiran wonyi."

en: And this is a very much left-wing Labour stronghold.
yo: Ti eyi si fi pupo wa ni sakani apa-osi Ise-sise.

en: But then after the article came out, this woman got in touch with me.
yo: Sugbon leyin ti apileko naa jade, obinrin yii kan si mi.

en: And she was from Ebbw Vale, and she told me about all this stuff that she'd seen on Facebook.
yo: "O wa lati Ebbw Vale, o so fun mi nipa gbogbo awon nnkan yii t""o ti ri lori Facebook."

en: "I was like, ""What stuff?"
yo: "Mo beere wi pe, ""nnkan wo?"

en: """ And she said it was all this quite scary stuff about immigration, and especially about Turkey."
yo: """O so wi pe gbogbo awon nnkan abanileru yii nipa isilo-si-ilu-okeere-miiran, paapaa julo nipa orile-edeTurkey."

en: So I tried to find it.
yo: Tori naa mo gbiyanju lati sawari re.

en: But there was nothing there.
yo: Sugbon ko si nnkankan nibe.

en: Because there's no archive of ads that people had seen or what had been pushed into their news feeds.
yo: Nitori ko si aka ti ipolowo ti awon eniyan ti ri tabi nnkan ti won ti ti si ikanni afunni niroyin won.

en: No trace of anything, gone completely dark.
yo: Ko si itose nnkankan, o ti dudu patapata.

en: And this referendum that will have this profound effect forever on Britain -- it's already had a profound effect: the Japanese car manufacturers that came to Wales and the north east to replace the mining jobs -- they are already going because of Brexit.
yo: Ibo yii ti yoo nipa nla lara Britain titi-laye -- o wule ti nipa nla: awon ara Japan ti won n se oko ile ta ti won wa si orile-ede Wales ati ariwa ila-oorun lati ropo ise iwakusa -- won ti n lo nitori Brexit.

en: And this entire referendum took place in darkness, because it took place on Facebook.
yo: Gbogbo ibo yii waye ninu okunkun, nitori o waye lori Facebook.

en: And what happens on Facebook stays on Facebook, because only you see your news feed, and then it vanishes, so it's impossible to research anything.
yo: Nnkan to ba si sele lori Facebook yoo duro sori Facebook, nitori iwo nikan lo n ri afunni niroyin re, yoo si di ofo, nitori naa ko se e se lati sewadii nnkankan.

en: So we have no idea who saw what ads or what impact they had, or what data was used to target these people.
yo: Tori naa a o mo eni ti o ri iru ipolowo tabi ipa ti won ni, tabi iwifun-alalaye ti o je lilo lati dari ipolowo si awon eniyan wonyi.

en: Or even who placed the ads, or how much money was spent, or even what nationality they were.
yo: "Tabi ta ni eni t""o fi ipolowo naa sibe, tabi eeloo lowo ti won na, tabi omo orile-ede ti won je."

en: But Facebook does.
yo: Sugbon Facebook mo.

en: Facebook has these answers, and it's refused to give them to us.
yo: Facebook ni awon idahun wonyi, o si ko lati ko won fun wa.

en: Our parliament has asked Mark Zuckerberg multiple times to come to Britain and to give us these answers.
yo: Awon asofin wa ti so fun Mark Zuckerberg lopo igba pe ko wa si orile-ede Britain lati wa fun wa ni awon idahun wonyi.

en: And every single time, he's refused.
yo: Ni asiko kookan, o ko jale.

en: And you have to wonder why.
yo: "Ti eniyan si ni lati woye oun t""o fa sababi"

en: Because what I and other journalists have uncovered is that multiple crimes took place during the referendum.
yo: Nitori nnkan ti emi ati awon akoroyin miiran ti wu jade ni wi pe oke aimoye iwa-odaran lo waye lasiko ibo naa.

en: And they took place on Facebook.
yo: Won si waye lori Facebook.

en: It's because in Britain, we limit the amount of money that you can spend in an election.
yo: Idi ni wi pe ni ile Britain, a fi gbedeke si iye owo ti eniyan le na ninu ibo.

en: And it's because in the 19th century, people would walk around with literally wheelbarrows of cash and just buy voters.
yo: "Idi si ni wi pe ni orun-odun 19, lawomo litireso awon eniyan maa n rin kaakiri pelu keke-akeru-elese-kan t""o kun fun owo lati ra awon oludibo."

en: So we passed these strict laws to stop that from happening.
yo: "Tori naa a se awon ofin t""o muna wonyi lati dekun iyen ki o ma waye."

en: But those laws don't work anymore.
yo: Sugbon awon ofin wonyen ko sise mo.

en: This referendum took place almost entirely online.
yo: Ibo yii waye lapapo lori ero ayelukara-bi-ajere.

en: And you can spend any amount of money on Facebook or on Google or on YouTube ads and nobody will know, because they're black boxes.
yo: Eniyan si le na owo iye-ki-ye lori Facebook tabi lori Google tabi ipolowo lori YouTube ti enikeni o ni mo, nitori awon ohun ti o fara sin ni won.

en: And this is what happened.
yo: "Ohun t""o sele re e."

en: We've actually got no idea of the full extent of it.
yo: A o ni imo kankan nipa bo se to ni kikun.

en: "But we do know that in the last days before the Brexit vote, the official ""Vote Leave"" campaign laundered nearly three quarters of a million pounds through another campaign entity that our electoral commission has ruled was illegal, and it's referred it to the police."
yo: "Sugbon a mo wi pe ni awon ojo t""o keyin ki ibo Brexit o to bere, ipolongo gangan ""Dibo Kuro"" feree ko ida meta aadota-oke owo poun kan mi nipase ipolongo miiran ti ajo eleto idibo wa ti pase pe ko bofinmu, ti o si tari re si akoto awon olopaa."

en: "And with this illegal cash, ""Vote Leave"" unleashed a fire hose of disinformation."
yo: "Pelu owo ti o bofinmu yii, ""Dibo Kuro"" se itusile opa ipana ifitonileti-asinilona."

en: Ads like this.
yo: Awon ipolowo bi eyi.

en: [Turkey's 76m people joining the EU]
yo: [Aadota-Oke 76 awon eniyan orile-ede Turkey ti won n darapo mo EU].

en: This is a lie, it's a total lie.
yo: Iro ni eyi, iro patapata ni.

en: Turkey is not joining the European Union.
yo: Orile-ede Turkey o darapo mo Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe.

en: There's not even any discussions of it joining the European Union.
yo: Ko ti e si ijiroro kankan nipa re pe o fe darapo mo Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe.

en: And most of us, we never saw these ads, because we were not the target of them.
yo: Opolopo wa, a o ri ipolowo yii rara, nitori awa ko ni won n dari re si.

en: """Vote Leave"" identified a tiny sliver of people who it identified as persuadable, and they saw them."
yo: """Dibo Kuro"" sedamo awon eniyan die t""o sedamo won gege bi eni ti a le yi-lokan-pada, won si ri won."

en: And the only reason we are seeing these now is because parliament forced Facebook to hand them over.
yo: Idi kan pato ti a se n ri awon wonyi nisisiyi ni wi pe awon asofin ti fipa mu Facebook lati ko won sile.

en: "And maybe you think, ""Well, it was just a bit of overspending."
yo: "Boya o ro wi pe, "" Daradara, inakunaa die ni o je."

en: It's a few lies.
yo: Iro die ni.

en: """ But this was the biggest electoral fraud in Britain for 100 years."
yo: """ Sugbon eyi ni ibo jibiti t""o tobi ju nile Britain laaarin 100 odun."

en: In a once-in-a-generation vote that hinged upon just one percent of the electorate.
yo: Ni ibo ekan-laarin-iran-kan to gbara le ida kan soso awon oludibo.

en: And it was just one of the crimes that took place in the referendum.
yo: "O je okan lara awon iwa-odaran t""o waye ninu idibo naa."

en: There was another group, which was headed by this man, Nigel Farage, the one to the right of Trump.
yo: Egbe kan tun wa, ti okunrin yii je olori won, Nigel Farage, eyi to wa lapa otun Trump.

en: "And his group, ""Leave."
yo: "Egbe re, ""Kuro ni EU"" -- oun naa rufin bakan naa."

en: "EU"" -- it also broke the law."
yo: O rufin eto-idibo ile Britain ati iwifun-alalaye ofin Britain, won si n se itokasi re fun awon olopa.

en: It broke British electoral laws and British data laws, and it's also being referred to the police.
yo: Okunrin yii, Arron Banks, oun lo se onigbowo ipolongo yii.

en: And this man, Arron Banks, he funded this campaign.
yo: Ni oro to yato gedengbe, won n se itokasi re fun awon Ajo to n ri si Iwa-odaran Apapo wa, todo tiwa to se deedee FBI, nitori ajo eleto idibo wa ti so wi pe awon o mo ibi ti owo re ti wa.

en: And in a completely separate case, he's being referred to our National Crime Agency, our equivalent of the FBI, because our electoral commission has concluded they don't know where his money came from.
yo: Tabi to ba se wi pe omo ile Britain ni.

en: Or if it was even British.
yo: Mi o ti e ni menu ba awon iro ti Arron Banks ti so nipa ajosepo ikoko re pelu ijoba orile-ede Russia.

en: And I'm not even going to go into the lies that Arron Banks has told about his covert relationship with the Russian government.
yo: Abi asiko ajoji ipade Farage pelu Julian Assange ati pelu ore Trump, Roger Stone, ti won ti fesun kan, lesekese siwaju ki Wikileak to se agbejade meji sanko-sanko, leyii ti mejeeji se anfaani fun Trump.

en: Or the weird timing of Nigel Farage's meetings with Julian Assange and with Trump's buddy, Roger Stone, now indicted, immediately before two massive WikiLeaks dumps, both of which happened to benefit Donald Trump.
yo: Sugbon ma a so fun o wi pe Brexit ati Trump jo wonu arawon ni.

en: But I will tell you that Brexit and Trump were intimately entwined.
yo: Okunrin yii so funmi wi pe Brexit ni awokoto-isayewo fun Trump.

en: This man told me that Brexit was the petri dish for Trump.
yo: A si mo wi pe awon eniyan yii kan naa, awon ile-ise kan naa, iwifun-alalaye kan naa, ilana-ise kan naa, isamulo ikorira ati iberu kan naa ni.

en: And we know it's the same people, the same companies, the same data, the same techniques, the same use of hate and fear.
yo: Nnkan ti won n fi sori Facebook niyi.

en: This is what they were posting on Facebook.
yo: Mi o si fe pe eyi gan-an niro.

en: And I don't even want to call this a lie, [Immigration without assimilation equals invasion] because it feels more like a hate crime to me.
yo: [isilo-si-ilu-okeere-miiran laisi igbaniwole tumo si idoti] Nitori o jo iwa-odaran ju ikorira lo si mi.

en: I don't have to tell you that hate and fear are being sown online all across the world.
yo: Mi o ni lati so fun yin wi pe ikorira ati iberu ni won n gbin sori ero ayelukara kaakiri aye.

en: Not just in Britain and America, but in France and in Hungary and Brazil and Myanmar and New Zealand.
yo: Ki i se ni orile-ede Britain ati America nikan, sugbon ni orile-ede France ati Hungary ati Brazil ati Myanmar ati New Zealand.

en: And we know there is this dark undertow which is connecting us all globally.
yo: A si mo pe omi dudu to n san kan wa to n so gbogbo wa po lagbaye.

en: And it is flowing via the technology platforms.
yo: O si n san lori awon gbagede imo-ero.

en: But we only see a tiny amount of what's going on on the surface.
yo: Sugbon die ninu nnkan to n lo loke la n ri.

en: And I only found out anything about this dark underbelly because I started looking into Trump's relationship to Farage, into a company called Cambridge Analytica.
yo: "Mo ri nnkankan nipa okunkun to wa labe-inu yii tori mo sese bere si i wo ajosepo t""o wa laaarin Trump ati Farage ni, sinu ile-ise kan ti won n pe ni Cambrige Analytica."

en: And I spent months tracking down an ex-employee, Christopher Wiley.
yo: Mo lo aimoye osu ti mo n topa osise-feyinti kan, Christopher Wiley.

en: And he told me how this company, that worked for both Trump and Brexit, had profiled people politically in order to understand their individual fears, to better target them with Facebook ads.
yo: "O si so fun mi bi ile-ise yii, t""o sise fun Trump ati Brexit, ti se akosile awon eniyan ni ti oselu lati le loye iberu enikookan won, lati le dari ipolowo Facebook si won."

en: And it did this by illicitly harvesting the profiles of 87 million people from Facebook.
yo: O si se eyi nipase kikore isofunni awon eniyan aadota-oke 87 lori Facebook ni ona aibofinmu.

en: It took an entire year's work to get Christopher on the record.
yo: O gba ise odidi odun kan gbako lati le mu Christopher sori akosile.

en: And I had to turn myself from a feature writer into an investigative reporter to do it.
yo: Mo si ni lati so ara mi di olujabo iwadii itopinpin lati akoroyin lati le se e.

en: And he was extraordinarily brave, because the company is owned by Robert Mercer, the billionaire who bankrolled Trump, and he threatened to sue us multiple times, to stop us from publishing.
yo: "Oun naa si ni igboya alailegbe, nitori Robert Mercer ni o ni ile-ise naa, oloro t""o se onigbowo fun Trump, o si dukoko lati pe wa lejo ni opo igba, lati da atejade wa duro."

en: But we finally got there, and we were one day ahead of publication.
yo: Sugbon a papa de ibe, o ku ojo kan ki a se atejade.

en: We got another legal threat.
yo: A gba idukoko ipelejo miiran.

en: Not from Cambridge Analytica this time, but from Facebook.
yo: Ki i se lati Cambridge Analytica lasiko yii, sugbon lati Facebook.

en: It told us that if we publish, they would sue us.
yo: O so fun wa wi pe ti a ba se atejade, won maa pe wa ni ejo.

en: We did it anyway.
yo: A saa se e sa.

en: Facebook, you were on the wrong side of history in that.
yo: Facebook, iha ti o dara ninu itan ni o wa ninu iyen.

en: And you were on the wrong side of history in this -- in refusing to give us the answers that we need.
yo: O si wa ni iha ti o dara ninu itan eyi -- latari kiko jale lati fun wa ni awon idahun ti a nilo.

en: And that is why I am here.
yo: Idi niyen ti mo fi wa nibi.

en: To address you directly, the gods of Silicon Valley.
yo: Lati baa yin soro taara, awon oosa ti Silicon Valley.

en: Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg and Larry Page and Sergey Brin and Jack Dorsey, and your employees and your investors, too.
yo: Mark Zuckerberg ati Sheryl Sandberg ati Larry Page ati Sergy Brin ati Jack Dorsey, ati awon osise yin ati awon oludokoowo yin, bakan naa.

en: Because 100 years ago, the biggest danger in the South Wales coal mines was gas.
yo: "Nitori 100 odun seyin, ewu t""o tobi ju ni awon iwa eedu ni South Wales ni afefe idana."

en: Silent and deadly and invisible.
yo: Dake roro ati ti-n-seku-pani ti a ko le ri soju.

en: It's why they sent the canaries down first to check the air.
yo: Idi niyi ti won fi ran awon eye ibaka lo sinu ile lati koko lo ye afefe naa wo.

en: And in this massive, global, online experiment that we are all living through, we in Britain are the canary.
yo: Ninu ayewo ori ero ayelukara ti agbaye ti o tobi ti a n la koja lowo yii, awa ti a wa ni orile-ede Britain ni eye ibaka.

en: We are what happens to a western democracy when a hundred years of electoral laws are disrupted by technology.
yo: "Awa ni ohun t""o sele si ijoba awarawa ni iha-iwo-oorun nigba ti imo-ero ti se idiwo fun ofin eto-idibo ogorun odun."

en: Our democracy is broken, our laws don't work anymore, and it's not me saying this, it's our parliament published a report saying this.
yo: "Ijoba awarawa ti fo yanga, awon ofin wa o sise mo, emi ko ni mo n so eyi, awon asofin wa ni won te atejade ihin t""o n so eyi."

en: This technology that you have invented has been amazing.
yo: Imo-ero ti o ti sapilese re yii yanilenu.

en: But now, it's a crime scene.
yo: Sugbon bayii, ogangan-ibi-isele iwa-odaran ni.

en: And you have the evidence.
yo: O si ni eri.

en: And it is not enough to say that you will do better in the future.
yo: Ko si to lati so wi pe o o se daadaa lojo iwaju.

en: Because to have any hope of stopping this from happening again, we have to know the truth.
yo: Tori lati ni ireti kankan nipa didawo eyi duro lati ma sele mo, a ni lati mo otito.

en: "And maybe you think, ""Well, it was just a few ads."
yo: "Boya o si n ro, ""O daa, awon ipolowo die naa ni."

en: And people are smarter than that, right?
yo: Awon eniyan si gbon ju iyen lo, abi?

en: """ To which I would say, ""Good luck with that."
yo: "Ni eyi ti mo maa so wi pe, ""konge ire pelu iyen."

en: """ Because what the Brexit vote demonstrates is that liberal democracy is broken."
yo: Nitori nnkan ti ibo Brexit sapejuwe re ni wi pe eto ijoba awarawa ti fo.

en: And you broke it.
yo: Eyin le si si fo o.

en: This is not democracy -- spreading lies in darkness, paid for with illegal cash, from God knows where.
yo: "Eyi ki i se ijoba awarawa -- fifon iro ka ninu okunkun, ti won fi owo ti o bofinmu san, lati ibi t""o je pe Olorun lo mo."

en: It's subversion, and you are accessories to it.
yo: Iyipo ni, eyin le si se atileyin fun un.

en: Our parliament has been the first in the world to try to hold you to account, and it's failed.
yo: "Ile asofin wa je akoko ni gbogbo agbaye t""o gbiyanju lati mu u o salaye nnkan ti e se, o si kuna."

en: You are literally beyond the reach of British law -- not just British laws, this is nine parliaments, nine countries are represented here, who Mark Zuckerberg refused to come and give evidence to.
yo: E ti koja arowoto ofin ile Britain - ki i se ofin Britain nikan, owo asofin mesan-an re e, orile-ede mesan-an ni o ni asoju nibi, ti Mark Zukerberg ko jale lati wa fi eri fun.

en: And what you don't seem to understand is that this is bigger than you.
yo: Nnkan ti o si ye e yin ni wi pe eyi tobi ju eyin gan-an lo.

en: And it's bigger than any of us.
yo: O si tobi ju enikankan wa lo.

en: "And it is not about left or right or ""Leave"" or ""Remain"" or Trump or not."
yo: "Ki i se nipa osi tabi otun tabi ""Kuro"" tabi ""Duro"" tabi Trump tabi elomiran."

en: It's about whether it's actually possible to have a free and fair election ever again.
yo: O je nipa boya o se e se lati ni eto-idibo ti yoo lo ni irowo-rose mo.

en: Because as it stands, I don't think it is.
yo: Tori bo se ri yii, mi o ro bee.

en: And so my question to you is, is this what you want?
yo: Ibeere mi sii yin ni, se nnkan ti e fe ree?

en: Is this how you want history to remember you: as the handmaidens to authoritarianism that is on the rise all across the world?
yo: Se bi e se fe ki itan o rantii yin re e: gege bi oluranlowo fun ijoba apase waa to n dide kaakiri gbogbo agbaye?

en: Because you set out to connect people.
yo: Nitori e bere lati so awon eniyan po ni.

en: And you are refusing to acknowledge that the same technology is now driving us apart.
yo: E si n ko lati gba pe imo-ero yii kan naa n pin wa niya.

en: And my question to everybody else is, is this what we want: to let them get away with it, and to sit back and play with our phones, as this darkness falls?
yo: Ibeere mi si gbogbo eniyan toku ni pe, se nnkan ti a fe re e: lati je ki won mu u je, ka si jokoo ka maa fi ero-ibanisoro wa sere, bi okunkun yii se n ku?

en: The history of the South Wales Valleys is of a fight for rights.
yo: Itan South Wales Valleys je ti ija fun eto.

en: And this is not a drill -- it's a point of inflection.
yo: Eyi kii se ibawi -- koko ayipada ni.

en: Democracy is not guaranteed, and it is not inevitable, and we have to fight and we have to win and we cannot let these tech companies have this unchecked power.
yo: Ijoba awarawa o daju, ko si se e feku, a ni lati ja a si ni lati bori a o le je ki awon ile-ise imo-ero ni agbara ti o se e ye lowo wo yii.

en: It's up to us -- you, me and all of us.
yo: O dowoo wa -- iwo, emi ati gbogbo wa.

en: We are the ones who have to take back control.
yo: Awa la ni lati gba isakoso pada.

en: How we can make energy more affordable for low-income families.
yo: Bi a se le je ki agbara roju fun awon ebi ti owo ti ipawo wole won kere.

en: So, as a child, I used to spend all of my time at my great-grandmother's house.
yo: Gege bi omode, mo maa n lo gbogbo asiko mi ni ile iya-agba iya mi.

en: On hot, humid, summer days, I would dash across the floor and stick my face in front of her only air conditioner.
yo: Ni awon ojo to ba gbona, lasiko ooru, mo maa sare koja nile ma si gboju mi siwaju ero amuletutu won kan soso.

en: But I didn't realize that that simple experience, though brief, was a privileged one in our community.
yo: Sugbon mi o mo pe iriri kekere yen, bo tile je perete, je anfaani kan ni awujo wa.

en: Growing up, stories of next-door neighbors having to set up fake energy accounts or having to steal energy seemed normal to me.
yo: "Nigba ti mo n dagba, itan awon aladugbo nile-keji ti won se agbekale ayederu apo asuwon agbara tabi ti won ni lati ji agbara je nnkan t""o to si mi."

en: During the winter, struggling to get warm, my neighbors would have no choice but to bypass the meter after their heat was shut off, just to keep their family comfortable for one more day.
yo: Lasiko otutu, titiraka lati je ki ara lo, awon aladugbo mi o ni anfaani kankan ju wi pe ki won pe mita koja leyin ti won ba ti pa oru won, lati le fi ara de ebi won fun ojo kan si i.

en: These kinds of dangerous incidents can take root when people are faced with impossible choices.
yo: Iru awon isele to lewu wonyi le gbile nigba ti awon eniyan ba n koju awon anfaani yiyan ti o se e se.

en: In the US, the average American spends three percent of their income on energy.
yo: Ni orile-ede US, ogbo omo ile America maa n na ida meta owo ti won n gba lori agbara.

en: In contrast, low-income and rural populations can spend 20, even 30 percent of their income on energy.
yo: Ni idakeji, ipawo wole to kere ati iye awon eniyan nigberiko le na ida ogun, koda ogbon ninu owo ti won n gba lori agbara.

en: In 2015, this caused over 25 million people to skip meals to provide power to their homes.
yo: Ni odun 2015, eyi je ki aadota-oke meedogbon eniyan fi ebi panu lati pese agbara ni ile won.

en: This is when energy becomes a burden.
yo: Asiko yii ni agbara di isoro.

en: But energy burdens are so much more than just a number.
yo: Sugbon awon isoro agbara po gan-an ju iye kan lo.

en: They present impossible and perilous choices: Do you take your child to get her flu medicine, or do you feed her?
yo: Won maa n se agbekale awon eyan ti o se e se to je abewude: Se waa mu omoo re lo gba oogun arun-oloje-ona-eemi re, abi ki o bo o?

en: Or do you keep her warm?
yo: Abi se ki o je ki ara re maa lo?

en: It's an impossible choice, and nearly every month, seven million people choose between medicine and energy.
yo: Eyan ti o se e se ni, o si feree je pe losoosu, aadota-oke meje eniyan maa n yan laaarin oogun ati agbara.

en: This exposes a much larger and systemic issue.
yo: "Eyi n tu asiiri oro t""o tobi to si gba eto."

en: Families with high energy burdens are disproportionately people of color, who spend more per square foot than their white counterparts.
yo: Awon ebi ti won ni isoro agbara to ga ni awon eniyan alawo dudu, ti won maa n nawo ju iwon ese kan yato si awon akegbe won ti won je alawo funfun.

en: But it's also nurses, veterans and even schoolteachers who fall into the mass of 37 million people a year who are unable to afford energy for their most basic needs.
yo: Sugbon awon oluto-ile-iwosan, awon agba-oje ati awon oluko nile-eko wa ninu awon aadota-oke meta-din-logoji eniyan lodun ti won o nikapa agbara fun awon ohun elo kose e ma nii julo won.

en: As a result, those with high energy burdens have a greater likelihood of conditions like heart disease and asthma.
yo: Nitori eyi, awon ti won ni isora agbara to ga se e se ki won ni awon arun bi arun okan ati arun seeemi-seeemi.

en: Look -- given our rockets to Mars and our pocket-sized AI, we have the tools to address these systemic inequities.
yo: E woo - pelu balu ayarafefe wa to lo si maasi ati AI ti o ju apo lo, a ni awon irinse lati yanju awon kudie-kudie eto wonyi.

en: The technology is here.
yo: Imo-ero naa wa debi.

en: Cost of renewables, insulation, microgrids and smart home technology are all decreasing.
yo: Iye owo isodotun, bibo oru, akojopo agbara ati imo-ero agbara inu-ile gbogbo ti n dinku.

en: However, even as we approach cost parity, the majority of those who own solar earn much more than the average American.
yo: Sibe, pelu bi a se n sumo idogba iye owo, opolopo awon ti won ni agbara itosan-oorun n pawo ju opo omo ile America lo.

en: This is why, when I was 22, I founded the nonprofit RETI.
yo: Idi niyi, nigba ti mo wa lomodun meji-le-logun, mo da ile-ise aijere RETI sile.

en: Our mission is to alleviate energy burdens by working with communities, utilities and government agencies alike to provide equitable access to clean energy, energy efficiency and energy technology.
yo: Afojusun wa ni lati so isoro agbara di fufuye nipa isise pelu awon awujo, awon ile-ise to n pese agbara ati awon asoju ijoba bakan naa lati pese anfaani adogba si agbara alailewu, adinku agbara ati imo-ero agbara.

en: But there's no one way to solve this.
yo: Sugbon ko si ona kan soso lati yanju eyi.

en: I believe in the power of local communities, in the transforming effect of relationships.
yo: Mo nigbagbo ninu agbara ni awon awujo agbegbe, ninu ayipada ipa ajosepo.

en: So we start by working directly with the communities that have the highest energy burdens.
yo: A bere pelu sise ise taara pelu awon awujo ti won ni isoro agbara to gaju.

en: We host workshops and events for communities to learn about energy poverty, and how making even small updates to their homes like better insulation for windows and water heaters can go a long way to maximize efficiency.
yo: A se ipade akanse-ise ati awon eto fun awon awujo lati ko nipa osi agbara, ati bi sise isodotun kekere si ile-won bii bibo-oru fun oju ferese ati amomi-gbona se le se pupo lati samulo adinku agbara.

en: We're connecting neighborhoods to community solar and spearheading community-led smart home research and installation programs to help families bring down their energy bills.
yo: A n so awon agbegbe mo agbara itosan-orun awujo a si n lewaju iwadii igbese-awujo lori ile aladase ati awon eto sise ato lati le ba awon ebi mu owo agbara wale.

en: We're even working directly with elected officials, advocating for more equitable pricing, because to see this vision of energy equity and resilience succeed, we have to work together sustainably.
yo: A tun sise taara pelu awon asoju ti won fibo yan, ti a n ja fun owo adogba, nitori lati je ki iran agbara adogba ati alailewu kesejari, a ni lati sise papo pelu ifowosowopo.

en: Now, the US spends over three billion a year on energy bill payment assistance.
