yo: Ni bayii, orile-ede US n na ju bilionu meta lodun lori iranlowo sisan owo agbara.

en: And these programs do help millions of people, but they're only able to help a fraction of those in need.
yo: Awon eto wonyi maa n ran aadota-oke eniyan lowo, sugbon apa kan ninu awon alaini ni won le pese iranlowo fun.

en: In fact, there is a 47-billion-dollar home-energy affordability gap, so assistance alone is not sustainable.
yo: Loooto, bilionu meta-din-laadota alafo inikapa agbara-ile lo wa, nitori naa iranlowo nikan o to.

en: But by building energy equity and resilience into our communities, we can assure fair and impartial access to energy that is clean, reliable and affordable.
yo: Sugbon pelu iseda agbara adogba ati alailewu ninu awujo wa, a le se idaniloju anfaani adogba ati alaisegbe si agbara ti o lewu, to se e gbarale to si roju.

en: At scale, microgrid technology, clean technology and energy efficiency dramatically improve public health.
yo: Lori iwon, imo-ero akojopo agbara, imo-ero alailewu ati adinku agbara maa n mu idagbasoke ba ilera gbogbogbo bi ere.

en: And for those with high energy burdens, it can help them reclaim 20 percent of their income -- 20 percent of a person's income who's struggling to make ends meet.
yo: Fun awon ti won ni isoro agbara to ga, o le ba won gba ida ogun owo ti won n gba pada -- ida ogun owo ti eniyan n gba to n tiraka lati wa ounje ojo.

en: This is life-changing.
yo: Eyi n yi igbesiaye pada.

en: This is an opportunity for families to use their energy savings to sponsor their future.
yo: Anfaani ree fun awon ebi lati lo adinku owo-agbara lati se igbowo ojo-iwaju won.

en: I think back to my great-grandmother and her neighbors, the impossible choices that they had to make and the effect it had on our whole community.
yo: Mo maa n ronu pada si iya agba iya mi ati awon alajogbe won, awon anfaani yiyan ti o se e se ti won ni lati se ati ipa to ni lori gbogbo awujo.

en: But this is not just about them.
yo: Sugbon eyi kii se nipa won nikan.

en: There are millions nationwide having to make the same impossible choices today.
yo: Aadota-oke lagbaye ni won n se iru anfaani yiyan ti o se e se yii kan naa loni.

en: And I know high energy burdens are a tremendous barrier to overcome, but through relationships with communities and technology, we have the paths to overcome them.
yo: Mo mo pe isoro agbara nla je wahala kan to po lati bori, sugbon nipase ajosepo pelu awon awujo ati imo-ero, a ni awon ona lati bori won.

en: And when we do, we will all be more resilient.
yo: Nigba ti a ba si se bee, gbogbo wa ni ara wa maa tubo le si i

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: Can we stop climate change by removing CO2 from the air?
yo: Nje a le da ayipada oju ojo duro pelu yiyo CO2 kuro ninu afefe?

en: To avoid dangerous climate change, we're going to need to cut emissions rapidly.
yo: Lati dena ayipada oju ojo to lewu, a maa nilo lati ge itusile ku kiakia.

en: That should be a pretty uncontentious statement, certainly with this audience.
yo: Iyen gbodo je oro ti o mu awuyewuye dani, ni idaniloju pelu awon olugbo yii.

en: But here's something that's slightly more contentious: it's not going to be enough.
yo: Sugbon nnkankan ree to le fa awuyewuye die lowo: ko ni to.

en: We will munch our way through our remaining carbon budget for one and a half degrees in a few short years, and the two degree budget in about two decades.
yo: A maa rapala waye koja isuna eedu toku fun alefa kan atabo ni odun to kere die, ati isuna alefa meji ni bii ewa-odun meji.

en: We need to not only cut emissions extremely rapidly, we also need to take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere.
yo: A o nilo lati ge itusile ku kiakia nikan, a tun nilo lati mu oyi-eedu kuro ni oyi oju-aye.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: I work assessing a whole range of these proposed techniques to see if they can work.
yo: Mo sise pelu sise ayewo opolopo awon ilana ti won dalabaa wonyi lati wo o boya won le sise.

en: We could use plants to take CO2 out, and then store it in trees, in the soil, deep underground or in the oceans.
yo: A le lo awon nnkan ogbin lati mu CO2 kuro, ka si toju won sinu igi, inu iyepe, labe ile tabi inu omi-okun.

en: We could build large machines, so-called artificial trees, that will scrub CO2 from the air.
yo: A le seda awon ero nla-nla, awon ti won n pe ni igi atowoda, ti yoo nu CO2 kuro ninu afefe.

en: For these ideas to be feasible, we need to understand whether they can be applied at a vast scale in a way that is safe, economic and socially acceptable.
yo: Ki awon ero wonyi le se e se, a nilo lati mo boya a le samulo won lori iwon nla lona ti o fi ni sewu, ti yoo si je gbigba fun oro-aje ati awujo.

en: All of these ideas come with tradeoffs.
yo: Gbogbo ero wonyi lo wa pelu kudiekudie.

en: None of them are perfect, but many have potential.
yo: Ko si ikankan ninu won to pe tan, sugbon opolopo ninu won lo se e se.

en: It's unlikely that any one of them will solve it on its own.
yo: Ko daju pe ikakan ninu won le yanju re loun nikan.

en: There is no silver bullet, but potentially together, they may form the silver buckshot that we need to stop climate change in its tracks.
yo: Ko si idan Kankan, sugbon boya lapapo, won le pidan ti a nilo lati da ayipada oju-ojo duro ni oripa re.

en: I'm working independently on one particular idea which uses natural gas to generate electricity in a way that takes carbon dioxide out of the air.
yo: Mo n sise adase lori ero kan to n lo oyi-atiletu lati pese ina-manamana ni ona ti yoo mu oyi-eedu kuro ninu afefe.

en: How does that work?
yo: Bawo ni iyen se n sise?

en: So the Origen Power Process feeds natural gas into a fuel cell.
yo: Igbese Agbara Ina-manamana Origen maa n fi afefe-idana atiletu sinu padi epo-robi.

en: About half the chemical energy is converted into electricity, and the remainder into heat, which is used to break down limestone into lime and carbon dioxide.
yo: Bii abo agbara kemika ni yoo yipada di ina-manamana, awon iyoku yoo si di ooru, ti won n lo lati so okuta-efun di efun ati oyi-eedu.

en: Now at this point, you're probably thinking that I'm nuts.
yo: Nibi ti a de yii, boya e n ro o wi pe ori mi o pe.

en: It's actually generating carbon dioxide.
yo: O n seda oyi-eedu loooto.

en: But the key point is, all of the carbon dioxide generated, both from the fuel cell and from the lime kiln, is pure, and that's really important, because it means you can either use that carbon dioxide or you can store it away deep underground at low cost.
yo: Sugbon Koko ibe ni wi pe, gbogbo oyi-eedu to n seda, lati inu padi epo-robi ati aaro efun, lo mo gaara, iyen si se pataki, nitori o tumo si wi pe e le lo yala oyi-eedu yen tabi ki e ko o pamo sabe ile lowo kekere.

en: And then the lime that you produce can be used in industrial processes, and in being used, it scrubs CO2 out of the air.
yo: Leyin naa efun ti e ti seda yen le di lilo fun ipese nnkan nile-ise, ati lilo o, o maa n nu CO2 kuro ninu afefe.

en: Overall, the process is carbon negative.
yo: Lapapo, igbese naa ki i pese oyi-eedu.

en: It removes carbon dioxide from the air.
yo: O maa n yo oyi-eedu kuro ninu afefe ni.

en: If you normally generate electricity from natural gas, you emit about 400 grams of CO2 into the air for every kilowatt-hour.
yo: Bi e ba n seda ina manamana latara oyi-atiletu daadaa, bii irinwo giramu CO2 ni e n gbe jade sinu afefe fun gbogbo wakati kilowaati kookan.

en: With this process, that figure is minus 600.
yo: Pelu igbese yii, figo yen je pelu ayokuro egbeta.

en: At the moment, power generation is responsible for about a quarter of all carbon dioxide emissions.
yo: Lowolowo yii, ipese agbara lo n se okunfa bii ida kan ninu ida merin gbogbo itusile oyi-eedu.

en: Hypothetically, if you replaced all power generation with this process, then you would not only eliminate all of the emissions from power generation but you would start removing emissions from other sectors as well, potentially cutting 60 percent of overall carbon emissions.
yo: Ni aba, ti e ba ropo gbogbo ipese agbara pelu igbese yii, e o ni yo gbogbo awon itusile latara ipese agbara nikan sugbon e o bere si yo awon itusile ni awon eka miiran bakan naa, gige ida ogota gbogbo itusile eedu.

en: You could even use the lime to add it directly to seawater to counteract ocean acidification, one of the other issues that is caused by CO2 in the atmosphere.
yo: E le tun lo efun naa lati daapo mo omi-osa taara lati mu adinku ba ekan omi-okun, okan ninu awon wahala miiran ti CO2 n fa ninu oyi oju-aye.

en: In fact, you get more bang for your buck.
yo: Loooto, e o gba ju iye ti e fi sile lo.

en: You absorb about twice as much carbon dioxide when you add it to seawater as when you use it industrially.
yo: E maa gba bii ilopo meji oyi-eedu sara nigba ti e ba daapo mo omi-osa ju ti e ba lo o nile-ise lo.

en: But this is where it gets really complicated.
yo: Sugbon ibi yii lo ti maa n di amudiju gidi gan-an.

en: While counteracting ocean acidification is a good thing, we don't fully understand what the environmental consequences are, and so we need to assess whether this treatment is actually better than the disease that it is seeking to cure.
yo: Nigba ti mimu adinku ba ekan omi-okun je nnkan to dara, a o nimo kikun nipa nnkan ti abajade re lawujo je, nitori naa a nilo lati sayewo boya itoju yii dara loooto ju arun to fe wosan lo.

en: We need to put in place step-by-step governance for experiments to assess this safely.
yo: A nilo lati seto idari leseese fun awon idanwo lati se ayewo yii laisewu.

en: And the scale: to avoid dangerous climate change, we are going to need to remove trillions -- and yes, that's trillions with a T -- trillions of tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere in the decades ahead.
yo: Iwon re: lati dena ayipada oju-ojo to lewu, a maa nilo lati yo tirilionu - beeni, tirilionu niyen pelu T --tirilionu toonu oyi-eedu kuro ninu oyi-oju-aye ni ewa-odun to wa niwaju.

en: It will cost a few percent of GDP -- think defense-sized expenditure, lots of industrial activity and inevitably harmful side effects.
yo: O maa na wa ni ida GDP die -- boya owo-naa ologun, opolopo amuse-ise awon ile-ise ati awon ayorisi miiran to lewu ta o le feku.

en: But if the scale seems enormous, it is only because of the scale of the problem that we are seeking to solve.
yo: Sugbon ti iwon naa ba tobi, nitori iwon isoro ti a n wa lati yanju nikan ni.

en: It's enormous as well.
yo: O si tobi bakan naa.

en: We can no longer avoid these thorny issues.
yo: A o le ma pe awon isoro to lagbara wonyi mo

en: We face risks whichever way we turn: a world changed by climate change or a world changed by climate change and our efforts to counter climate change.
yo: A n koju ewu ni gbogbo ibi ti a ba yiju si: ile-aye ti ayipada oju-ojo ti yi pada tabi ile-aye ti ayipada oju-oju ti yi pada ati igbiyanju wa lati tako ayipada oju-ojo.

en: Would that it were not so, but we can no longer afford to close our eyes, block our ears, and say la-la-la.
yo: O wun mi ki o ma ri i bee, sugbon a o le dijuu wa, di eti wa, ki a ma so la-la-la mo.

en: We need to grow up and face the consequences of our actions.
yo: A nilo lati dagba soke ka si koju abajade awon iwa wa.

en: Does talk of curing climate change undermine the will to cut emissions?
yo: Se oro nipa iwosan ayipada oju ojo n dena ipinnu lati ge itusile ni?

en: This is a real concern, so we need to emphasize the paramount importance of reducing emissions and how speculative these ideas are.
yo: Edun okan tooto ni eyi, nitori naa a nilo lati tenu mo pataki mimu adinku ba itusile ati bi awon ero wonyi se je aheso-oro.

en: But having done so, we still need to examine them.
yo: Sugbon leyin ti a ti se bee, a si nilo lati se ayewo won.

en: Can we cure climate change?
yo: Nje a le se iwosan ayipada oju-ojo?

en: I don't know, but we certainly can't if we don't try.
yo: Mi o mo, sugbon a o le mo ti a o ba gbiyanju.

en: We need ambition without arrogance.
yo: A nilo ipinnu laisi igberaga.

en: We need the ambition to restore the atmosphere, to draw down carbon dioxide back to a level that is compatible with a stable climate and healthy oceans.
yo: A nilo ipinnu lati se adapada oyi-oju-aye, lati fa oyi-eedu wale pada si ipele ti o wa ni ibamu pelu oju-ojo ti ko yi pada ati omi-okun to lalaafia.

en: This will be an enormous undertaking.
yo: Ise to po ni eleyii maa je.

en: You could describe it as a cathedral project.
yo: E le sapejuwe re gege bi ise-akanse ojo-iwaju.

en: Those involved at the outset may draft the plans and dig the foundations, but they will not raise the spire to its full height.
yo: Awon ti won lowo ninu re lati ibere le ya aworan re ki won si se ifilole re, sugbon won o ni gbe e de oke tente.

en: That task, that privilege, belongs to our descendants.
yo: Ise yen, anfaani yen, awon ti a se sile ni won ni i.

en: None of us will see that day, but we must start in the hope that future generations will be able to finish the job.
yo: Ko si enikeni ninu wa ti yoo ri ojo naa, sugbon a gbodo bere pelu ireti pe awon iran ojo-iwaju maa le pari ise naa.

en: So, do you want to change the world?
yo: Nitori naa, se e fe mu ayipada ba ile-aye?

en: I don't.
yo: Mi o fe.

en: I do not seek the change the world, but rather keep it as it's meant to be.
yo: Mi o wa lati mu ayipada ba ile-aye, sugbon lati fi si bo se ye ko wa.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: Chris Anderson: Thanks.
yo: Chris Anderson: E seun.

en: I just want to ask you a couple of other questions.
yo: Mo ko fe bi yin ni awon ibeere miiran bi meloo kan ni.

en: Tell us a bit more about this idea of putting lime in the ocean.
yo: E so die si funwa nipa ero fifi efun sinu omi-okun.

en: I mean, on the face of it, it's pretty compelling -- anti-ocean acidification -- and it absorbs more CO2.
yo: Mo n so nipa pe, bose ri loju, o n fanimora -- atako ekan omi okun -- to si n gba opo CO2 mora.

en: You talked about, we need to do an experiment on this.
yo: E soro nipa pe, a nilo lati se idanwo lori eyi.

en: What would a responsible experiment look like?
yo: Bawo ni idanwo to se e gbarale se maa ri?

en: Tim Kruger: So I think you need to do a series of experiments, but you need to do them just very small stage-by-stage.
yo: Tim Kruger: mo ro wi pe e nilo lati se opolopo idanwo, sugbon e nilo lati se won ni kekere nipele-ipele.

en: In the same way, when you're trialing a new drug, you wouldn't just go into human trials straight off.
yo: Ni ilana kan naa, nigba ti e ba n se ayewo oogun tuntun, e o ko ni lo si ayewo lara eniyan taara.

en: You would do a small experiment.
yo: E o se idanwo kekere.

en: And so the first things to do are experiments entirely on land, in special containers, away from the environment.
yo: Nitori naa nnkan akoko lati se ni idanwo lori ile, ninu abo akanse, kuro laaarin agbegbe.

en: And then once you are confident that that can be done safely, you move to the next stage.
yo: Nigba to ba ti daa yin loju pe eyi se e se laisewu, e o si tesiwaju si ipele to kan.

en: If you're not confident, you don't.
yo: Bi ko ba daa yin loju, e o ni se bee.

en: But step by step.
yo: Sugbon ni ipele-ipele.

en: CA: And who would fund such experiments?
yo: CA: tani yoo se onigbowo iru idanwo bee?

en: Because they kind of impact the whole planet at some level.
yo: Nitori won nipa lara gbogbo agbaye ni awon ipele kan.

en: Is that why nothing is happening on this?
yo: Se idi niyen ti nnkankan o se tii sele nipa eleyii?

en: TK: So I think you can do small-scale experiments in national waters, and then it's probably the requirement of national funders to do that.
yo: TK: mo ro wi pe e le se idanwo oniwon-kekere ninu awon omi orile-ede, nigba naa boya awon onigbowo orile-ede nikan ni yoo nilo lati se iyen.

en: But ultimately, if you wanted to counter ocean acidification in this way on a global scale, you would need to do it in international waters, and then you would need to have an international community working on it.
yo: Sugbon nigbeyin, ti e ba fe tako ekan omi-okun lori iwon agbaye lona yii, e maa nilo lati se e ninu omi ile okeere, e o si nilo lati ni awon orile-ede agbaye lati sise lori re.

en: CA: Even in national waters, you know, the ocean's all connected.
yo: CA: koda ninu awon omi orile-ede, e mo, awon omi-okun naa japo.

en: That lime is going to get out there.
yo: Efun yen maa jade sita yen.

en: And people feel outraged about doing experiments on the planet, as we've heard.
yo: Awon eniyan si maa n binu gan-an nipa sise idanwo ninu aye, bi a se ti gbo.

en: How do you counter that?
yo: Bawo le o se tako iyen?

en: TK: I think you touch on something which is really important.
yo: TK: mo ro wi pe e menu ba nnkankan to se pataki pupo

en: It's about a social license to operate.
yo: Nipa ifayegba awujo lati sise ni.

en: And I think it may be that it is impossible to do, but we need to have the courage to try, to move this forward, to see what we can do, and to engage openly.
yo: Mo ro pe o le je wi pe ko se e se lati se e, sugbon a nilo lati ni igboya lati gbiyanju, lati sun eyi siwaju, lati ri nnkan ti a le se, ka si soro ni gbangba.

en: And we need to engage with people in a transparent way.
yo: A si nilo lati ba awon eniyan soro lona to han kedere.

en: We need to ask them beforehand.
yo: A nilo lati bi won siwaju.

en: "And I think if we ask them, we have to be open to the possibility that the answer will come back, ""No, don't do it."
yo: "Mo si ro wi pe ti a ba bi won, a ni lati si okan wa sile pe o se e se ki idahun naa maa pada wa ni, ""Rara, ma se e."

en: CA: Thanks so much.
yo: CA: E seun pupo.

en: That was really fascinating.
yo: Iyen fanimora gigi gan-an.

en: TK: Thank you.
yo: TK: E seun.

en: A comprehensive, neighborhood-based response to COVID-19
yo: Ekunrere, idahun ajemo agbegbe si COVID-19.

en: Good evening.
yo: E kaale.

en: It is such a blessing to work at the Harlem Children's Zone, an African-American-led organization that has pioneered the field of comprehensive place-based services, from cradle to career.
yo: "Ibukun ni o je lati sise ni Harlem Children's Zone, ile-ise ti awon Omo Ile-Adulawo ati America n lewaju t""o ti sina eka ekunrere ise ajemo-aye, lati omo-owo debi ise."

en: "And that word, ""comprehensive,"" is so key to what we do."
yo: "Oro yen, ""ekunrere"" se pataki si nnkan ti a n se."

en: You know, most interventions focus on one piece of a complicated, giant puzzle.
yo: E mo, opo awon idasi maa n koju mo ayo amudiju, nla kan ni.

en: But that's not enough to solve the puzzle.
yo: Sugbon iyen o to lati wa iyanju si ayo naa.

en: You don't solve education without understanding the home context or the home environment of our young scholar.
yo: E o le yanju eto-eko lainimo nipa ogangan-ipo ile tabi ayika ile awon akekoo kekeeke.

en: Or the broader context of health, nutrition or criminal justice.
yo: Tabi ogangan-ipo ilera to feju, isaraloore tabi idajo iwa-odaran.

en: The unit of change for us is not the individual child, it's the entire neighborhood.
yo: Iwon ayipada fun wa ki i se omo kookan, gbogbo adugbo ni.

en: You have to do multiple things at the same time.
yo: E ni lati se opolopo nnkan leekan naa.

en: And we have 20 years of data to prove that this works.
yo: A ni data ogun odun lati fi seri pe eyi n sise.

en: We've had 7,000 graduates of our baby college, we've eliminated the Black-white achievement gap in our schools.
yo: A ti ni egberun meje awon akekoojade ni ile-eko ikoko wa, a ti pana alafo aseyori dudu ati funfun ni ile-eko wa.

en: We've reduced obesity rates in our health programs and have close to 1,000 students enrolled in college.
yo: A ti mu adinku ba isowo-sanra ninu awon eto ilera wa si ni to egberun kan awon akekoo ti won ti forukosile ni ile-eko wa.

en: We weave together a net of services so tightly, so that no one will fall through the cracks.
yo: A hun awon ise papo doindoin, ki enikeni ma ba a jabo nibi to ti lanu.

en: And we've inspired global practitioners.
yo: A ti se iwuri fun awon to n se e lagbaaye.

en: We've had over 500-plus communities across the US and 70-plus countries come and visit us to learn our model.
yo: A ti ni awon awujo to le laadota kaakiri orile-ede US awon orile-ede to le laadorin ni won maa n wa yoju siwa lati ko awose wa.

en: You see, the problems of the globe, and the problems of the world are not neatly siloed into buckets.
yo: Se e ri i, awon isoro agbaye, ati awon isoro ile-aye ni won o bomi rin daadaa.

en: So therefore the solutions must be comprehensive, they must be holistic.
yo: Nitori naa awon iyanju naa gbodo je ekunrere, won gbodo je lapapo.

en: And now we're in the midst of a global pandemic.
yo: Nisisiyi a wa ninu ajakale arun kariaye.

en: COVID-19 has revealed to us what we always knew to be true.
yo: COVID-19 ti fi awon nnkan ti a ti mo tele pe ooto ni han wa.

en: The poorest among us pay the highest price with their lives and their livelihood.
yo: Awon ti won kuse julo laaarin wa ni won n san eje to poju pelu emi won ati ona iwa ije-imu won.

en: And that's playing out every day in the African American community, where we're 3.6 times more likely to die of COVID than our white counterparts.
yo: Iyen si n sele lojoojumo ni awujo awon omo ile Adulawo ni orile-ede America, nibi to ti se e se ki COVID pa wa ni ilopo merin-din-logbon ju awon akegbe wa ti won je alawo funfun lo.

en: We're seeing those health disparities on the ground in New York City, our nation's epicenter.
yo: A n ri awon iyato ilera wonyen lopolopo ni New York City, nibi to ti arun yii ti wopo julo lorile-ede wa.

en: And to compound the impact of the health disparities, there's significant economic devastation, where one in four of our families in Harlem report food insecurity, and 57 percent report a loss of income or a loss of their job.
yo: Lati so ipa iyato ilera naa di pupo, ipalara oro aje to foju han wa, nibi ti okan ninu merin awon ebii wa ni Harlem ti n jabo airounje je, ti ida meta-din-logota n jabo ipadanu owo-osu tabi ipadanu ise won.

en: But to better understand the work of the Harlem Children's Zone, I want to share a story with you, about a second-grade scholar named Sean.
yo: Sugbon lati tubo ni imo nipa ise ti Harlem Children Zone n se, mo fe so itan kan fun yin, nipa akekoo ile-iwe alakoobere keji ti oruko re nje Sean.

en: Sean is a beautiful Black boy whose smile would light up any room that he's in.
yo: Sean je omodekunrin alawo-dudu to rewa ti erin re maa n mu idunnu wo inu yara to ba wa ni.

en: And when quarantine began in March, we noticed that Sean wasn't attending virtual school.
yo: Nigba ti iyasoto bere ni osu Erena, a sakiyesi wi pe Sean o kin wa si ile-eko ori ero ayelukara.

en: And after some investigation, we've come to learn that Sean's mom was hospitalized due to COVID.
yo: Leyin iwadii die, a wa mo wi pe iya Sean wa nile-iwosan nitori COVID.

en: So he was at home with grandma and his baby sibling, who was his only viable support system, since Sean's father is incarcerated.
yo: Oun wa nile pelu iya-agba re ati aburo re kekere, to se pe oun nikan naa ni alatileyin fun, nigba to je wi pe won ti fi baba Sean sewon.

en: Grandma was struggling.
yo: Iya-agba n tiraka ni.

en: There wasn't much food in the household, limited diapers, and Sean didn't even have a computer.
yo: Ko si ounje pupo ni ile naa, iledi die, Sean naa o wule ni ero-ayarabiasa kankan.

en: When mom was released from the hospital, their challenges deepened, because they could no longer stay with grandma, due to her preexisting health conditions.
yo: Nigba ti won tu iya re sile nile-iwosan, idojuko won tubo feju sii, nitori won o le gbepo pelu iya-agba won mo, nitori ipo-ilere ateyinwa re.

en: So Sean, his baby sibling and his mom had to go to a shelter.
yo: Nitori naa Sean, aburo re kekere ati iya re ni lati lo sile awon alaini.

en: Sean's story is not atypical at the Harlem Children's Zone.
yo: Itan Sean kii se ni Harlem Children's Zone nikan.

en: We know Sean and millions like him all across the country deserve to have everything that this world has to offer, without inequality robbing them of that opportunity.
yo: A mo wi pe Sean ati awon aadota-oke bii tie kaakiri orile-ede naa letoo lati ni gbogbo nnkan ti aye yii ni lati funni, laijepe aidogda yoo ma jawon lole iru anfaani yen.

en: All the result of racism and historical and systemic underinvestment are now compounded by COVID-19.
yo: Gbogbo esi eleyameya itan ati eto aidokowo ti wa papo mo COVID-19.

en: Our comprehensive model uniquely positions the Harlem Children's Zone in the fight of COVID.
yo: Ekunrere awose wa gbe Harlem Children's Zone sinu ijagudu COVID lona oto.

en: The success that we have on the ground in Harlem makes it imperative, and it is our responsibility to share what we know works with the country.
yo: Aseyori ti a ni lopo ni Harlem so o di pataki, ojuse wa si ni lati so ohun ti a mo pe o sise fun orile-ede.

en: We have developed a comprehensive COVID-19 relief and recovery response for our community, that was surfaced from our community, focused on five primary areas of need, and already servicing families like Sean's.
yo: A ti se agbekale ekunrere idahun si iderun ati ipadabo-sipo COVID-19 fun awujo wa, ti o jeyo ni awujo wa, to dale awon koko nnkan koseemanii marun-un, a si n se atileyin fun awon ebi bii ti Sean.

en: They are the following.
yo: Awon naa re e.

en: One, emergency relief funds.
yo: Akoko, owo iderun pajawiri.

en: We know that our families need cash in their hands right now.
yo: A mo wi pe awon ebi wa nilo owo lowo won lasiko yii.

en: Two, protecting our most vulnerable.
yo: Ikeji, didaaabo bo awon akogun-sewuju wa.

en: We know our families need access to essential goods and information.
yo: A mo wi pe awon ebi wa nilo anfaani si awon ohun-elo-koseemani ati ifitonileti.

en: So that is food, that's masks, that's a curated resource list and public health campaigns.
yo: Ounje niyen, ibomu niyen, akojopo ohun-elo ati ipolongo ilera gbogbogbo.

en: Three, bridging the digital divide.
yo: Iketa, didi alafo aidogba arowoto ero- ayelukara.

en: We believe that internet is a fundamental right.
yo: A nigbagbo wi pe eto koseemani ni ero-ayelukara je.

en: So we need to ensure our families have connectivity, and also all school-age children in a household have the proper learning devices.
yo: A ni lati rii daju wi pe awon ebi wa ni isopo mo ero-ayelukara, bakan naa gbogbo awon omo ti ojo-ori won wa labe ikekoo ni ile kan ni won ni ohun-elo ikekoo to to.

en: Four, zero learning loss.
yo: Ikerin, aipadanu ikekoo.

en: We know that there's a generation of students at risk of losing an entire year of their education.
yo: A mo wi pe awon iran akekoo kan wa ti won wa ninu ewu ipadanu gbogbo odun ikekoo won.

en: We need to make sure that we are providing high-quality virtual programing, in addition to having safe reentry planned for school reentry.
yo: A nilo lati rii wi pe a n pese eto ikekoo ero-ayelukara to lagbara, ni afikun si sise eto ipadawole alailewu fun ipadawole ile-eko.

en: And five, mitigating the mental health crisis.
yo: Ikarun-un, mimu adinku ba arun opolo.

en: There's a generation at risk of having PTSD, due to the massive amounts of toxic stress.
yo: Awon iran kan wa ninu ewu nini PTSD, nitori apoju majele ti laalaa.

en: We need to ensure that our families have access to telehealth and other virtual supports.
yo: A nilo lati rii daju pe awon ebi wa ni anfaani si eto-ilera ori ero ayelukara ati awon iranlowo ori ero-ayelukara miiran.

en: We have six amazing partners across six cities in the United States that are adopting our model for their own context in their community.
yo: A ni awon alajosepo to danto mefa kaakiri awon ileto mefa ni orile-ede United States ti won n tele awose wa fun ogangan-ipo tiwon ni awujo won.

en: They are Oakland, Minneapolis, Chicago, Detroit, Newark and Atlanta.
yo: Awon naa ni Oakland, Minneapolis, Chicago, Detroit, Newark ati Atlanta.

en: In addition to those partners, we have three national partners, who will be sharing our model and sharing our strategies through their network, in addition to amplifying our impact by policy advocacy.
yo: Ni afikun si awon alajosepo wonyen, a ni awon alajosepo orile-ede meta, ti won yoo ma pin awose wa ati awon eto wa lori ikani won, ni afikun si pipariwo ipa wa pelu atileyin ipinnu.

en: We will have impact on three levels.
yo: A maa ni ipa ni ipele meta.

en: Individual impact on the ground in Harlem, across a number of outcomes in education, in health, in economics, reaching 30,000 people.
yo: Ipa enikookan lopo ni Harlem, kaakiri iye awon abajade ninu eto-eko, ninu eto-ilera, ninu oro-aje, kikansi egberun-lona 30 awon eniyan.

en: There's community-level impact across six cities, again through our amazing partners, that will reach an additional 70,000 people.
yo: Ipa ipele awujo naa wa kaakiri awon ileto mefa, bakan naa nipase awon alajosepo wa to danto, ti won yoo kan si afikun egberun-lona 70 awon eniyan.

en: And then national impact, not only through policy advocacy, but through capacity building at scale.
yo: Leyin naa ipa lori orile ede, ki i se nipa igbawi ilana-ise nikan, sugbon nipase mim ironilagbara de oju iwon.

en: Our answer to COVID-19, the despair and inequities plaguing our communities, is targeting neighborhoods with comprehensive services.
yo: Idahun wa si COVID-19, ainireti ati aidogba to n ba awujo wa ja, n doju ko awon adugbo pelu ekunrere ise.

en: We have certainly not lost hope.
yo: A o tii so ireti nu rara.

en: And we invite you to join us on the front lines of this war.
yo: A si n pe yin lati darapo mo wa niwaju ogun yii.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: Why civilians suffer more once a war is over
yo: Idi ti iya se maa n je awon ara-ilu gan-an nigba ti ogun ba ti pari.

en: So have you ever wondered what it would be like to live in a place with no rules?
yo: Nje o ti ro o tele ri pe bawo lo se maa ri ti eniyan ba n gbe nibi ti ko si ofin.

en: That sounds pretty cool.
yo: Iyen dun gbo.

en: You wake up one morning, however, and you discover that the reason there are no rules is because there's no government, and there are no laws.
yo: O ji laaro ojo kan, ewe, e wa ri i wi pe idi ti ko fi si ofin ni wi pe ko si ijoba, ko si si ofin.

en: In fact, all social institutions have disappeared.
yo: Loooto, gbogbo ile-ise awujo ti poora.

en: So there's no schools, there's no hospitals, there's no police, there's no banks, there's no athletic clubs, there's no utilities.
yo: Nitori naa Ko si ile-eko, ko si ile-iwosan, ko si olopaa, ko si ile-ifowopamo, ko si awon egbe elere-idaraya, ko si ohun-elo.

en: Well, I know a little bit about what this is like, because when I was a medical student in 1999, I worked in a refugee camp in the Balkans during the Kosovo War.
yo: O daa. Mo mo die nipa bi eyi se ri, tori nigba ti mo je akekoo imo-isegun ni odun 1999, mo sise ni ipago awon atipo ni Balkans lasiko ogun Kosovo.

en: When the war was over, I got permission -- unbelievably -- from my medical school to take some time off and follow some of the families that I had befriended in the camp back to their village in Kosovo, and understand how they navigated life in this postwar setting.
yo: Nigba ti ogun naa pari, mo gba iyanda -- si iyalenu -- lati ile-eko imo-isegun mi lati lo sinmi ki n si tele awon ebi ti mo ti ba doree ni ipago naa pada si abule won ni Kosovo, ki n mo bi won yoo se lo igbesi-aye ni ibudo leyin ogun yii.

en: Postwar Kosovo was a very interesting place because NATO troops were there, mostly to make sure the war didn't break out again.
yo: Kosovo leyin ogun je ibikan to dun nitori awon omo-ogun NATO wa nibe, lati ri i pe ogun o tun seyo mo.

en: But other than that, it was actually a lawless place, and almost every social institution, both public and private, had been destroyed.
yo: "Sugbon yato si iyen, aye ti o l""ofin ni, o fere je pe gbogbo ile-ise awujo, ti ijoba ati aladani, ni won ti baje."

en: So I can tell you that when you go into one of these situations and settings, it is absolutely thrilling for about 30 minutes, because that's about how long it takes before you run into a situation where you realize how incredibly vulnerable you are.
yo: Nitori naa mo le so fun yin wi pe ti e ba wo okan ninu awon ipo ati ibudo yii, o maa n panilerin-in fun bii ogbon iseju, tori bo se maa n pe to niyen ki e to wa ni ipo ti e o fi mo bi e se kangun-sewu si.

en: For me, that moment came when I had to cross the first checkpoint, and I realized as I drove up that I would be negotiating passage through this checkpoint with a heavily armed individual who, if he decided to shoot me right then and there, actually wouldn't be doing anything illegal.
yo: Fun emi, akoko naa wa nigba ti mo ni lati koja enu-ibode akoko, bi mo se wa oko siwaju ni mo ti mo wi pe mo maa se idunaadura kikoja enu-ibode yii pelu enikan to diha ogun to se pe, to ba pinnu lati yinbo momi lasiko yen ati nibe yen, ko ni tii se nnkan ti o bofinmu.

en: But the sense of vulnerability that I had was absolutely nothing in comparison to the vulnerability of the families that I got to know over that year.
yo: Sugbon oye ikangun-sewu ti mo ni ko to nnkan si ikangun-sewu awon ebi ti mo mo ni odun yen.

en: "You see, life in a society where there are no social institutions is riddled with danger and uncertainty, and simple questions like, ""What are we going to eat tonight?"" are very complicated to answer."
yo: "Se e ri i, igbe-aye lawujo ti ko si awon ile-ise awujo n koju ewu ati aidaju, ati awon ibeere to rorun bii, ""ki la maa je lale yii? ""je amudiju lati dahun."

en: Questions about security, when you don't have any security systems, are terrifying.
yo: Awon ibeere nipa aabo, nigba ti ko ba si eto aabo, maa n bani leru.

en: Is that altercation I had with the neighbor down the block going to turn into a violent episode that will end my life or my family's life?
yo: Se ede-aiyede yen ti mo ni pelu araale mi to wa nisale o ni di rogbodiyan ti yoo gba emi mi tabi emi ebi mi?

en: Health concerns when there is no health system are also terrifying.
yo: Ironu nipa ilere nigba ti ko ba si eto-ilera naa n bani leru.

en: "I listened as many families had to sort through questions like, ""My infant has a fever."
yo: "Mo n teti bi opolopo awon ebi se ni lati yanju awon ibeere bi, ""ikoko mi ni aarun iba."

en: What am I going to do?
yo: Kini mo fe se?

en: """ ""My sister, who is pregnant, is bleeding."
yo: """ ""Aburo mi lobirin, to loyun, n da eje."

en: What should I do?
yo: Kini ki n se?

en: Who should I turn to?
yo: Tani ki n koju si?

en: """ ""Where are the doctors, where are the nurses?"
yo: """ ""Awon onisegun-oyinbo da, awon oluto-ile-iwosan da?"

en: If I could find one, are they trustworthy?
yo: Ti mo ba le ri okan, se won se e gbagbo?

en: How will I pay them?
yo: Bawo ni maa se sanwo fun won?

en: In what currency will I pay them?
yo: Iru owo wo ni maa fi sanwo fun won?

en: """ ""If I need medications, where will I find them?"
yo: """ ""Ti mo ba nilo oogun, nibo ni maa ti ri won?"

en: If I take those medications, are they actually counterfeits?
yo: Bi mo ba lo awon oogun wonyen, se ayederu niwon loooto?

en: """ And on and on."
yo: """ Ati bee ati bee."

en: So for life in these settings, the dominant theme, the dominant feature of life, is the incredible vulnerability that people have to manage day in and day out, because of the lack of social systems.
yo: Fun igbe-aye ni awon ibudo wonyi, koko oro to gbajumo ju, awomo igbeaye to gbajumo ju, ni ikangun-sewu ti awon eniyan ni lati mojuto lojoojumo, tori aisi awon eto awujo.

en: And it actually turns out that this feature of life is incredibly difficult to explain and be understood by people who are living outside of it.
yo: O pada jeyo wi pe awomo igbe-aye yii soro pupo lati salaye ati lati mo fun awon eniyan ti won n gbe nita re.

en: I discovered this when I left Kosovo.
yo: Mo mo eyi nigba ti mo kuro ni Kosovo.

en: I came back to Boston, I became a physician, I became a global public health policy researcher.
yo: Mo pada wa si Boston, mo di alagbawo, mo di onise iwadii ipinnu ilera gbogbogbo lagbaye.

en: I joined the Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital Division of Global Health.
yo: Mo darapo mo ile-eko isegun Havard ati Brigham ati eka ile-iwosan awon obinrin ti ilera agbaye.

en: And I, as a researcher, really wanted to get started on this problem right away.
yo: Emi, gege bi onise iwadii, fe bere ise lori isoro yii lesekese.

en: "I was like, ""How do we reduce the crushing vulnerability of people living in these types of fragile settings?"
yo: "Mo n ro o wi pe, ""Bawo ni a se le mu adinku ba ikangun-sewu awon eniyan ti won n gbe ni awon ibudo elege wonyi?"

en: Is there any way we can start to think about how to protect and quickly recover the institutions that are critical to survival, like the health system?
yo: Nje ona kankan wa ti a le bere sini ronu nipa bi a se le pese idaaabobo ati ipadabosipo logan awon ile-ise ti won se pataki fun imoribo, bi eto ilera?

en: """ And I have to say, I had amazing colleagues."
yo: """ Mo si gbodo so wi pe, mo ni awon akegbe to danto."

en: But one interesting thing about it was, this was sort of an unusual question for them.
yo: Sugbon nnkan kan to panilerin nipa re ni wi pe, awon ibeere ajoji ni eyi je fun won.

en: "They were kind of like, ""Oh, if you work in war, doesn't that mean you work on refugee camps, and you work on documenting mass atrocities?"" -- which is, by the way, very, very, very important."
yo: """ Won ro o wi pe, ""Oh, ti e ba sise ninu ogun, se iyen o tumo si wi pe e sise ni ipago awon atipo ni, e si n sise lori akosile opo awon iwa-ibaje?"" -- to se wi pe, lapa kan, o se pataki gigi gaan."

en: So it took me a while to explain why I was so passionate about this issue, until about six years ago.
yo: O gbami lasiko die lati salaye idi ti mo fi nife si oro yii, titi di bi odun mefa seyin.

en: That's when this landmark study that looked at and described the public health consequences of war was published.
yo: Nigba naa ni iwadii alailegbe yii to se ibojuwo ati apejuwe et o ilera gbogbogbo abajade ogun di tite jade.

en: They came to an incredible, provocative conclusion.
yo: "Won se ifenuko to yani lenu t""o si bini ninu."

en: These researchers concluded that the vast majority of death and disability from war happens after the cessation of conflict.
yo: Awon onise iwadii wonyi fenuko pe opolopo iku ati isonidalaaabo-ara latara ogun maa n sele leyin ti ikolura ba ti dopin.

en: So the most dangerous time to be a person living in a conflict-affected state is after the cessation of hostilities; it's after the peace deal has been signed.
yo: "Asiko t""o lewu ju lati je eniyan to n gbe ni orile-ede to ni isele-ikolura ni leyin ti ogun ba ti dopin; leyin ti adehun alaafia ba ti di bibuwolu ni."

en: It's when that political solution has been achieved.
yo: Igba ti ona-abayo oselu yen ba ti di sise.

en: That seems so puzzling, but of course it's not, because war kills people by robbing them of their clinics, of their hospitals, of their supply chains.
yo: Iyen dabi eni ruju, sugbon bee ni ko ri bee, nitori ogun maa n pa awon eniyan nipa jija won lole awon ile-iwosan alaboode won, awon ile-iwosan won, ati ipinkari awon eru-oja won.

en: Their doctors are targeted, are killed; they're on the run.
yo: Won maa n dajuso awon onisegun-oyinbo won, won n gba emii won; won ti sa lo.

en: And more invisible and yet more deadly is the destruction of the health governance institutions and their finances.
yo: Eyi aihan daadaa ti o tun si n seku pani ju ni iparun awon ile-ise to n dari eto ilera ati awon isuna owo won.

en: So this is really not surprising at all to me.
yo: Tori naa eyi ko fi bee ya mi lenu rara.

en: But what is surprising and somewhat dismaying, is how little impact this insight has had, in terms of how we think about human suffering and war.
yo: Sugbon nnkan to yani lenu to si bani lokan je, ni ipa kekere ti oye yii ni, nipa bi a se n ronu nipa inira awon eniyan ati ogun.

en: Let me give you a couple examples.
yo: E je ki n fun yin ni awon apeere bii meloo kan.

en: Last year, you may remember, Ebola hit the West African country of Liberia.
yo: Lodun to koja, e le ranti, Ebola kolu orile-ede Liberia ti Iwo-oorun Ile-Adulawo.

en: There was a lot of reporting about this group, Doctors Without Borders, sounding the alarm and calling for aid and assistance.
yo: "Opolopo iroyin l""o wa nipa egbe yii, Awon Onisegun-Oyinbo Laisi Aala, ti won n kebosi ti won si n pe fun iranlowo ati atileyin."

en: But not a lot of that reporting answered the question: Why is Doctors Without Borders even in Liberia?
yo: Sugbon ki i se gbogbo ijabo iroyin yen ni o dahun ibeere naa: kin ni idi ti Awon Onisegun-Oyinbo Laisi Aala se wa ni orile-ede Liberia?

en: Doctors Without Borders is an amazing organization, dedicated and designed to provide emergency care in war zones.
yo: "Awon Onisegun-Oyinbo Laisi Aala je ile-ise alaraagbaida, ti gbekale t""o si ni ifokansin lati pese itojuu pajawiri ni awon agbegbe ogun."

en: Liberia's civil war had ended in 2003 -- that was 11 years before Ebola even struck.
yo: Ogun abele orile-ede Liberia ti dopin ni odun 2003 - iyen je odun 11 ki arun Ebola o to be sile.

en: When Ebola struck Liberia, there were less than 50 doctors in the entire country of 4.5 million people.
yo: Nigba ti Ebola be sile ni orile-ede Liberia, awon onisegun-oyinbo to din ni 50 ni won wa ni gbogbo orile-ede ti o ni awon eniyan bi egberun-lona-egberun 4.5.

en: Doctors Without Borders is in Liberia because Liberia still doesn't really have a functioning health system, 11 years later.
yo: "Awon Onisegun-Oyinbo Laisi Aala wa ni orile-ede Liberia nitori Liberia o tii fi bee ni eto ilera to n sise b""o se ye, leyin odun 11."

en: When the earthquake hit Haiti in 2010, the outpouring of international aid was phenomenal.
yo: Nigba ti isele kolu Haiti ni odun 2010, awon atileyin to n wole lati ile-okeere kamama.

en: But did you know that only two percent of that funding went to rebuild Haitian public institutions, including its health sector?
yo: Sugbon se e mo wi pe ida meji igbowo yen lo lo si kiko awon ile-ise ijoba gbogbogbo Haiti, to fi mo eka ilera re?

en: From that perspective, Haitians continue to die from the earthquake even today.
yo: Lati oju-iwoye yen, awon Omo Haiti si n tesiwaju lati ku nitori iji-ile paapaa doni.

en: I recently met this gentleman.
yo: Mo pade arakunrin yii laipe yii.

en: This is Dr. Nezar Ismet.
yo: Onimo-isegun Nezar Ismet re e.

en: He's the Minister of Health in the northern autonomous region of Iraq, in Kurdistan.
yo: Oun ni Alakoso fun Eto-Ilera ni agbegbe olominira ariwa orile-ede Iraq, ni Kurdistan.

en: Here he is announcing that in the last nine months, his country, his region, has increased from four million people to five million people.
yo: Oun re e to n kede pe ni osu mesan seyin, orile-ede re, agbegbe re, ti lekun lati egberun-lona-egberun merin eniyan si egberun-lona-egberun marun-un eniyan.

en: That's a 25 percent increase.
yo: Afikun ida 15 niyen.

en: Thousands of these new arrivals have experienced incredible trauma.
yo: Aimoye egberun ninu awon sesede wonyi ni won ti ni iriri iporuru-okan ti-ko-se-e-gbagbo.

en: His doctors are working 16-hour days without pay.
yo: Awon onisegun-oyinbo re n sise fun wakati 16 lojumo laigbowo.

en: His budget has not increased by 25 percent; it has decreased by 20 percent, as funding has flowed to security concerns and to short-term relief efforts.
yo: Isuna re o tii lekun pelu ida 25; o ti dinku pelu ida 20, gege bi igbowo se ti san si ironu nipa eto-aabo ati igbiyanju iralowo onigba kukuru.

en: When his health sector fails -- and if history is any guide, it will -- how do you think that's going to influence the decision making of the five million people in his region as they think about whether they should flee that type of vulnerable living situation?
yo: Nigba ti eka-ilera re ba kuna -- ti itan ba se e tele, yoo ri bee -- bawo ni e se ro wi pe iyen se le nipa lori sise ipinnu fun egberun-lona-egberun marun-un awon eniyan to wa ni agbegbe re bi won se n ronu nipa boya ki awon sa fun iru ipo igbeaye ikagun-sewu bee?

en: So as you can see, this is a frustrating topic for me, and I really try to understand: Why the reluctance to protect and support indigenous health systems and security systems?
yo: Gege bi e se ri i, koko-oro to n dani laamu ni eyi je fun mi, mo si gbiyanju gan-an lati ni oye pe: ki lo n fa isun-seyin lati pese idaaabobo ati sise atileyin eto-ilera eni ati eto aabo?

en: I usually tier two concerns, two arguments.
yo: Mo maa n ni aniyan meji, ariyanjiyan meji.

en: The first concern is about corruption, and the concern that people in these settings are corrupt and they are untrustworthy.
yo: Aniyan akoko ni nipa iwa-ibaje, ati aniyan wi pe awon eniyan ti won wa ni awon ibudo wonyi niwa ibaje won o si se e gbagbo.

en: And I will admit that I have met unsavory characters working in health sectors in these situations.
yo: Mo maa gba wi pe mo ti pade awon oniwa-ibaje ti won n sise ni eka-ilera ni awon ipo wonyi.

en: But I will tell you that the opposite is absolutely true in every case I have worked on, from Afghanistan to Libya, to Kosovo, to Haiti, to Liberia -- I have met inspiring people, who, when the chips were down for their country, they risked everything to save their health institutions.
yo: Sugbon mo maa so fun-un yin pe ooto ni idakeji je ninu gbogbo nnkan ti mo ti sise le lori, lati orile-ede Afganistan de Libya, de Kosovo, de Haiti, de Liberia -- mo ti pade awon eniyan to n funni ni imisi, to se wi pe, nigba ti isoro to lagbara ba sele si orile-ede won, won maa n se gbogbo nnkan lati doola awon ile-ise ilera won.

en: The trick for the outsider who wants to help is identifying who those individuals are, and building a pathway for them to lead.
yo: Ogbon fun awon araata ti won fe se iranlowo ni lati toka eni ti awon eniyan wonyen n se, ki won si pese oju-ona fun won lati siwaju.

en: That is exactly what happened in Afghanistan.
yo: Nnkan to sele ni orile-ede Afganistan gaan niyen.

en: One of the unsung and untold success stories of our nation-building effort in Afghanistan involved the World Bank in 2002 investing heavily in identifying, training and promoting Afghani health sector leaders.
yo: Okan lara awon itan aseyori igbiyanju kiko-orile-ede Afganistan wa ti won o si gboriyin nipa re ni ti idokowo nla Ile-ifowopamo Agbaye ni odun 2002 lati sedamo, sise ikoni ati agbega awon adari eka eto-ilera Afgani.

en: These health sector leaders have pulled off an incredible feat in Afghanistan.
yo: Awon adari eka eto-ilera wonyi ti se aseyori to po ni Afganistan.

en: They have aggressively increased access to health care for the majority of the population.
yo: Won ti fi ikanra se afikun anfaani si itoju ilera fun opo awon ara-ilu.

en: They are rapidly improving the health status of the Afghan population, which used to be the worst in the world.
yo: Won mu iyato to daa ba ipo ilera awon eniyan Afghan, to je wi pe oun lo buru julo lagbaaye tele.

en: In fact, the Afghan Ministry of Health does things that I wish we would do in America.
yo: Loooto, ile-ise to n ri si eto-ilera ni Afghan n se awon nnkan ti yoo wun mi ka se e ni orile-ede America.

en: They use things like data to make policy.
yo: Won n lo awon nnkan bi iwifuni-alalaye lati se ipinnu.

en: It's incredible.
yo: O lagbara.

en: "The other concern I hear a lot about is: ""We just can't afford it, we just don't have the money."
yo: "Aniyan keji ti mo maa n gbo nipa re gan-an ni: ""O ti ga ju ara lo, a o ni owo re."

en: It's just unsustainable.
yo: Ko se e tesiwaju.

en: """ I would submit to you that the current situation and the current system we have is the most expensive, inefficient system we could possibly conceive of."
yo: """ Mo maa jabo fun yin pe nnkan to n sele lowo ati eto ti a ni lowolowo lo won ju, ohun si ni eto ti o sise ti a le ronu re lo."

en: The current situation is that when governments like the US -- or, let's say, the collection of governments that make up the European Commission -- every year, they spend 15 billion dollars on just humanitarian and emergency and disaster relief worldwide.
yo: Nnkan to n sele lowolowo ni wi pe nigba ti awon ijoba bii ti orile-ede US -- tabi, ka so wi pe, akojopo awon ijoba ti won jo parapo di Ajo-Igbimo Ile Europe -- lodoodun, won n na bilionu meedogun dola lori iderun aanu omoniyan ati pajawiri ati ajalu jake-jako agbanla-aye.

en: That's nothing about foreign aid, that's just disaster relief.
yo: Iyen kii se nnkankan nipa iranwo ile-okeere, iderun ajalu nikan niyen o.

en: Ninety-five percent of it goes to international relief agencies, that then have to import resources into these areas, and knit together some type of temporary health system, let's say, which they then dismantle and send away when they run out of money.
yo: Ida marun-le-laadorun ninu re ni o n lo si awon Ajo iderun ile okeere, ti won ni lati ko awon ohun-elo wole si awon agbegbe yii, ti won o si hun awon eto ilera onigba die papo, ka so wi pe, ti won yoo wa tu u ka ti won yoo si le won danu nigba ti owo ba tan.

en: So our job, it turns out, is very clear.
yo: Nitori naa ise wa, bo se ri, han kedere.

en: We, as the global health community policy experts, our first job is to become experts in how to monitor the strengths and vulnerabilities of health systems in threatened situations.
yo: Awa, gege bi agba-oje ninu ipinnu awujo ilera agbaye, akoko ise wa ni lati di agba-oje ninu bi a se n mojuto okun ati ikogun-sewu eto ilera ni ipo ewu.

en: And that's when we see doctors fleeing, when we see health resources drying up, when we see institutions crumbling -- that's the emergency.
yo: Nigba naa ni a n ri awon onisegun-oyinbo ti won n salo, nigba ti a n ri awon ohun-elo ilera to n gbe, nigba ti a n ri awon ile-ise ti won n wo -- pajawiri naa niyen.

en: That's when we need to sound the alarm and wave our arms.
yo: Nigba naa ni a gbodo kebosi ki a si juwo wa.

en: Not now.
yo: Ki i se nisiyii.

en: Everyone can see that's an emergency, they don't need us to tell them that.
yo: Gbogbo eniyan lo le ri wi pe pajawiri niyen, won o nilo wa lati so iyen fun won.

en: Number two: places like where I work at Harvard need to take their cue from the World Bank experience in Afghanistan, and we need to -- and we will -- build robust platforms to support health sector leaders like these.
yo: Eleekeji: awon ibi ti mo ti sise bii ni Havard nilo lati ko eko latara iriri Ile-Ifowopamo Agbaye ni orile-ede Afganistan, a si ni lati -- a si maa -- ko awon igbagede lati se iranwo fun awon adari eka eto-ilera bi awon wonyi.

en: These people risk their lives.
yo: Awon eniyan wonyi n fi emi ara won wewu.

en: I think we can match their courage with some support.
yo: Mo ro wi pe a le ba akinkanju won dogba pelu awon iranlowo kookan.

en: Number three: we need to reach out and make new partnerships.
yo: "Eleeketa: a nilo lati jade sita k""a si se awon ajosepo tuntun."

en: At our global health center, we have launched a new initiative with NATO and other security policy makers to explore with them what they can do to protect health system institutions during deployments.
yo: Ni awon ibi ilera agbaye wa, a ti se ikojade eto tuntun pelu NATO ati awon asepinnu eto-abo miiran lati rinrin ajo peluu won ohun ti won le se lati daaabobo awon ile-ise eto ilera lasiko isise.

en: We want them to see that protecting health systems and other critical social institutions is an integral part of their mission.
yo: A fe ki won ri i wi pe didaaabo bo eto ilera ati awon ile-ise awujo miiran je okan pataki lara ise won.

en: It's not just about avoiding collateral damage; it's about winning the peace.
yo: Ki i se ki eniyan maa sa fun iba nnkan je awon ologun nikan; o je lati bori pelu alaafia.

en: But the most important partner we need to engage is you, the American public, and indeed, the world public.
yo: Sugbon alajose to se pataki julo ti a nilo lati ba soro ni eyin, eyin eniyan ile America, ati loooto, eyin eniyan agbaye.

en: Because unless you understand the value of social institutions, like health systems in these fragile settings, you won't support efforts to save them.
yo: Nitori ayafi ti e ba ni oye iwulo awon ile-ise awujo, bi eto ilera ni awon ibudo elege wonyi, e o ni se atileyin fun igbiyanju lati doola won.

en: "You won't click on that article that talks about ""Hey, all those doctors are on the run in country X."
yo: "E o ni gbowole atiku yen to n so nipa ""Hey, gbogbo awon onisegun-oyinbo yen ti n sa kuro ni orile-ede X."

en: I wonder what that means.
yo: Mo woye ohun ti eyi tumo si.

en: I wonder what that means for that health system's ability to, let's say, detect influenza.
yo: Mo woye nnkan ti iyen tumo si fun ikapa eto ilera yen lati, ka so wi pe, kefin arun-oloje-opona-eemi.

en: """ ""Hmm, it's probably not good."
yo: """ ""Hmm, boya ko dara."

en: """ That's what I'd tell you."
yo: """ Nnkan ti maa so fun yin niyen."

en: Up on the screen, I've put up my three favorite American institution defenders and builders.
yo: Loke loju agboji, mo ti fi awon awon aayo mi meta ti won je alaabo ti won si ko awon ile-ise ile America.

en: Over here is George C. Marshall, he was the guy that proposed the Marshall Plan to save all of Europe's economic institutions after World War II.
yo: Nibi yii ni George C. Marshall, oun ni okunrin to dabaa ipinnu Marshall lati doola gbogbo ile-ise oro-aje ile Europe leyin Ogun Agbaye II.

en: And this Eleanor Roosevelt.
yo: Eleanor Roosevelt niyi.

en: Her work on human rights really serves as the foundation for all of our international human rights organizations.
yo: Ise re lori eto omo-eniyan sise gege bi ipile fun gbogbo awon ile-ise eto omo-eniyan wa lagbaye.

en: Then my big favorite is Ben Franklin, who did many things in terms of creating institutions, but was the midwife of our constitution.
yo: Ben Franklin ni aayo mi to tobi ju, ti o se orisirisi nnkan nipa sise idasile awon ile-ise, sugbon to je agbebi ninu iwe-ofin wa.

en: And I would say to you that these are folks who, when our country was threatened, or our world was threatened, they didn't retreat.
yo: Ma a si so fun yin wi pe awon wonyi ni awon ti, nigba ti orile-ede wa wa ninu ewu, tabi ti ile-aye wa wa ninu ewu, won o sa.

en: They didn't talk about building walls.
yo: Won o so nipa kiko awon ogiri.

en: They talked about building institutions to protect human security, for their generation and also for ours.
yo: Won soro nipa kiko awon ile-ise lati daaabo bo eto-abo omo eniyan, fun iran won ati fun tiwa.

en: And I think our generation should do the same.
yo: Mo si ro wi pe iran tiwa naa gbodo se bee.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: Lessons from the 1918 flu
yo: Awon eko latara arun-oloje-ona-eemi odun 1918.

en: So the first question is, why do we need to even worry about a pandemic threat?
yo: Ibeere akoko ni, kini idi ti a fi nilo lati ronu nipa ewu ajakale arun kariaye?

en: What is it that we're concerned about?
yo: Kini nnkan naa ti a n ronu nipa re?

en: "When I say ""we,"" I'm at the Council on Foreign Relations."
yo: "Bi mo ba so wi pe ""awa,"" mo wa ni Ajo-igbimo to n ri si ajosepo ile-okeere."

en: We're concerned in the national security community, and of course in the biology community and the public health community.
yo: A da lori awujo eto-aabo orile-ede, bee ni awujo eko nipa eda ati awujo ilera gbogbogbo.

en: While globalization has increased travel, it's made it necessary that everybody be everywhere, all the time, all over the world.
yo: Nigba ti kari-aye ti se afikun si irinajo, o ti je ko rorun pe ki gbogbo eniyan wa nibi gbogbo, nigba gbogbo, kaakiri agbaye.

en: And that means that your microbial hitchhikers are moving with you.
yo: Iyen tumo si wi pe aarun wiwa oko-ofee re ti n tele e.

en: So a plague outbreak in Surat, India becomes not an obscure event, but a globalized event -- a globalized concern that has changed the risk equation.
yo: Ajakale arun kan ni Surat, India ko ni je isele airi, sugbon isele kariaye -- ironu kariaye to ti se ayipada iye ewu.

en: Katrina showed us that we cannot completely depend on government to have readiness in hand, to be capable of handling things.
yo: Katrina fi han wa wi pe a o le gbokan le ijoba patapata lati wa ni imurasile logan, lati le ni ikapa isakoso nnkan.

en: Indeed, an outbreak would be multiple Katrinas at once.
yo: Loooto, ajakale arun kan yoo di opolopo Katrina leekan soso.

en: Our big concern at the moment is a virus called H5N1 flu -- some of you call it bird flu -- which first emerged in southern China, in the mid-1990s, but we didn't know about it until 1997.
yo: Ironu wa to tobi ju lowolowo yii ni kokoro kan ti won n pe ni arun-oloje-ona-eemi H5N1 -- awon kan ninu yin maa n pe e ni kooli -- ti o koko seyo ni guusu orile-ede China, ni aarin 1990, sugbon a o gbo nipa re afi odun 1997.

en: At the end of last Christmas only 13 countries had seen H5N1.
yo: Ni ipari odun Keresi to koja awon orile-ede metala nikan ni won ti ri H5N1.

en: But we're now up to 55 countries in the world, have had this virus emerge, in either birds, or people or both.
yo: Sugbon a ti to orile-ede marun-un-le-laadota ni agbaye bayii, ti kokoro yi ti seyo, yala lara eranko-abiye, tabi eniyan tabi mejeeji.

en: In the bird outbreaks we now can see that pretty much the whole world has seen this virus except the Americas.
yo: "Ninu ajakale arun eranko-abiye naa a le ri bayii pe o feree je gbogbo agbaye l""o ti ri kokoro yii ayafi awon ara ile America nikan."

en: And I'll get into why we've so far been spared in a moment.
yo: Maa si wonu idi re to fi dawasi laipe.

en: In domestic birds, especially chickens, it's 100 percent lethal.
yo: Lara awon ohun-osin abiye, paapaa julo adiye, ida ogorun ni isekupani re.

en: It's one of the most lethal things we've seen in circulation in the world in any recent centuries.
yo: O je okan lara awon nnkan to le sekupani ti a ti ri to wa kaakiri agbaye ni awon orun-odun laipe yii.

en: And we've dealt with it by killing off lots and lots and lots of chickens, and unfortunately often not reimbursing the peasant farmers with the result that there's cover-up.
yo: A ti koju re pelu pipa opolopo awon adiye, o si seni laanu pe lopo igba won kii sanwo re pada fun awon agbe olokoowo kekeke pelu esi wi pe iboju wa nibe.

en: It's also carried on migration patterns of wild migratory aquatic birds.
yo: Won tun gbe e lori batani asikiri awon eye omi igbe ti won maa n si kiri.

en: There has been this centralized event in a place called Lake Chenghai, China.
yo: Iru isele igbakoso yii ti waye ni aye kan ti won n pe ni Lake Chenghai, ni orile-ede China.

en: Two years ago the migrating birds had a multiple event where thousands died because of a mutation occurring in the virus, which made the species range broaden dramatically.
yo: Ni odun meji seyin awon eye asikiri ni opolopo isele nibi ti awon egberun ti ku nitori ayipada to n sele si kokoro naa, to je ki odiwon owo won tobi si i bi ere.

en: So that birds going to Siberia, to Europe, and to Africa carried the virus, which had not previously been possible.
yo: Ki awon eye ti won n lo si Siberia, si Europe ati si ile Adulawo gbe kokoro naa, eyi ti o se e se tele.

en: We're now seeing outbreaks in human populations -- so far, fortunately, small events, tiny outbreaks, occasional clusters.
yo: A wa n ri ajakake arun naa laaarin awon omo-eniyan nisiyin -- lowolowo, ori bawa se, awon isele kekeeke, awon ajakale arun to kere, isupo leekookan.

en: The virus has mutated dramatically in the last two years to form two distinct families, if you will, of the H5N1 viral tree with branches in them, and with different attributes that are worrying.
yo: Kokoro naa ti yi pada bi ere laaarin odun meji seyin lati di ebi meji otooto, ti e ba maa se bee, ti igi kokoro H5N1 pelu awon eka ninu won, pelu awon awomo otooto ti o fini lokan bale.

en: So what's concerning us?
yo: Tori naa ki lo n mu wa ronu?

en: Well, first of all, at no time in history have we succeeded in making in a timely fashion, a specific vaccine for more than 260 million people.
yo: O daa, akoko na, ko si igba kankan ninu itan ti a saseyori nibi sise akanse oogun ajesara lasiko fun ota-le-nigba eniyan le.

en: It's not going to do us very much good in a global pandemic.
yo: Ko ni sewa ni anfaani to po nigba ti ajakale arun kariaye ba se.

en: You've heard about the vaccine we're stockpiling.
yo: E ti gbo nipa oogun ajesara ti a n ko pamo lopo.

en: But nobody believes it will actually be particularly effective if we have a real outbreak.
yo: Sugbon ko seni to gbagbo wi pe yoo sise ti a ba ni ajakale arun tooto.

en: So one thought is: after 9/11, when the airports closed, our flu season was delayed by two weeks.
yo: Ironu kan ni wi pe: leyin 9/11, nigba ti won ti papako ofuurufu, asiko arun-oloje-ona-eemi wa ni idaduro fun ose meji.

en: So the thought is, hey, maybe what we should do is just immediately -- we hear there is H5N1 spreading from human to human, the virus has mutated to be a human-to-human transmitter -- let's shut down the airports.
yo: Ironu naa ni wi pe, hey, boya nnkan to ye ka se maa je lesekese -- a gbo pe H5N1 kan wa to n ran latara eniyan si eniyan, kokoro naa ti yipada lati di akoran eniyan si eniyan -- e je ka ti papako ofuurufu pa.

en: However, huge supercomputer analyses, done of the likely effectiveness of this, show that it won't buy us much time at all.
yo: Ewe, itupale ero-ayarabiasa alagbara nla, ti won se nipa bi eyi se lagbara si, fi han pe ko ni fun wa ni asiko pupo rara.

en: And of course it will be hugely disruptive in preparation plans.
yo: Bee ni yoo se idiwo nla fun awon eto imurasile.

en: For example, all masks are made in China.
yo: Fun apeere, China ni won ti n se gbogbo ibomu.

en: How do you get them mobilized around the world if you've shut all the airports down?
yo: Bawo le se fe pin won kaakiri agbaye ti e ba ti gbe gbogbo papako ofuurufu tipa.

en: How do you get the vaccines moved around the world and the drugs moved, and whatever may or not be available that would work.
yo: Bawo le se fe gbe awon oogun ajesara naa kaakiri agbaye ati gbigbe awon oogun naa, ati awon nnkan to ba wa tabi ti o si ti yoo sise.

en: So it turns out that shutting down the airports is counterproductive.
yo: O pada je wi pe gbigbe awon papako ofuurufu tipa o fun wa lesi ti a fe.

en: We're worried because this virus, unlike any other flu we've ever studied, can be transmitted by eating raw meat of the infected animals.
yo: Okan wa o bale nitori kokoro yii, yato si awon arun-oloje-ona-eemi miiran ti a ti se iwadii re, le di akoran pelu jije eran tutu awon eranko ti won ti ko o.

en: We've seen transmission to wild cats and domestic cats, and now also domestic pet dogs.
yo: A ti ri akoran si awon ologbo igbe ati awon ologbo osin, lowolowo yii bakan naa awon osin aja.

en: And in experimental feedings to rodents and ferrets, we found that the animals exhibit symptoms never seen with flu: seizures, central nervous system disorders, partial paralysis.
yo: Ninu idanwo bibo eku ati ehoro, a ri i wi pe awon eranko naa n safihan awon ami aisan ti a o riri pelu arun-oloje-ona-eemi: giri, aisedede gbungbun isakoso ara, irolapa-rolese die.

en: This is not your normal garden-variety flu.
yo: "Eyi ki i se iru arun-oloje-ona-eemi t""o wa ninu ogba yin."

en: It mimics what we now understand about reconstructing the 1918 flu virus, the last great pandemic, in that it also jumped directly from birds to people.
yo: O n sin nnkan ti a ti wa mo nipa sise atunko kokoro afaafe odun 1918, ajakale arun kariaye to lagbara gbeyin, ti ohun naa fo taara latara eranko abiye si eniyan.

en: We had evolution over time, and this unbelievable mortality rate in human beings: 55 percent of people who have become infected with H5N1 have, in fact, succumbed.
yo: A ni itiranya bi igba se n gori igba, ati isowo ku awon omo-eniyan to yanilenu yii: ida marun-un-din-laadota awon eniyan ti won ti ko H5N1 ti, loooto, juwoole.

en: And we don't have a huge number of people who got infected and never developed disease.
yo: A o si ni opolopo awon eniyan ti won ko o ti won o ni arun rara.

en: In experimental feeding in monkeys you can see that it actually downregulates a specific immune system modulator.
yo: Ninu idanwo bibo awon obo e le ri i wi pe o n yi asakoso eto ajesara kan sile.

en: "The result is that what kills you is not the virus directly, but your own immune system overreacting, saying, ""Whatever this is so foreign I'm going berserk."
yo: "Esi naa ni wi pe nnkan t""o n pa yin ki i se kokoro naa taara, sugbon eto ajesara re t""o n se aseju, ti o n so wi pe ""nnkan-ki-nnkan ti ajoji yii i ba a je ma a binu."

en: """ The result: most of the deaths have been in people under 30 years of age, robustly healthy young adults."
yo: """Esi re: opolopo awon iku ti o ti waye ti je ninu awon eniyan labe ogbon odun, awon odo onilera pipe."

en: We have seen human-to-human transmission in at least three clusters -- fortunately involving very intimate contact, still not putting the world at large at any kind of risk.
yo: A ti ri akoran eniyan si eniyan ni o kere ju isupo meta -- ori bawa se o ni se pelu akoran timotimo, ti ko fi gbogbo aye lapapo sinu ewu kankan.

en: Alright, so I've got you nervous.
yo: O dara, mo ti deru bayin.

en: Now you probably assume, well the governments are going to do something.
yo: Bayi e n ro o, ijoba maa se nnkan si i.

en: And we have spent a lot of money.
yo: A si ti nawo to po.

en: Most of the spending in the Bush administration has actually been more related to the anthrax results and bio-terrorism threat.
yo: Opolopo inawo ninu isakoso Bush tan mo esi kokoro antiraasi ati ewu lilo kemika gege bi ohun-ija.

en: But a lot of money has been thrown out at the local level and at the federal level to look at infectious diseases.
yo: Sugbon opolopo owo ni won ti gbe jade ni ipele ijoba ibile ati ipele ijoba apapo lati wo awon arun riran.

en: End result: only 15 states have been certified to be able to do mass distribution of vaccine and drugs in a pandemic.
yo: Esi igbeyin: ipinle meedogun ti gba idaniloju lati le se ipin oogun ajesara ati awon oogun lopo lasiko ajakale arun kariaye.

en: Half the states would run out of hospital beds in the first week, maybe two weeks.
yo: Abo awon ipinle ni ko ni ni aye nile-iwosan ni ose akoko, boya ose meji.

en: And 40 states already have an acute nursing shortage.
yo: Ipinle ogoji ti ni adinku awon oluto-ile-iwosan gidi.

en: Add on pandemic threat, you're in big trouble.
yo: Ninu ewu ajakale arun kariaye, e ti wo wahala nla.

en: So what have people been doing with this money?
yo: Ki wa ni awon eniyan ti n fowo se?

en: Exercises, drills, all over the world.
yo: Ere-idaraya, gbigbaniyan sise, kaakiri agbaye.

en: Let's pretend there's a pandemic.
yo: E je ka dogbon pe ajakale arun kariaye wa.

en: Let's everybody run around and play your role.
yo: E je ki gbogbo eniyan sare kaakiri ki e si ko ipa yin.

en: Main result is that there is tremendous confusion.
yo: Esi gangan ni wi pe iporuru-okan ti wa.

en: Most of these people don't actually know what their job will be.
yo: Opolopo awon eniyan wonyi o mo nnkan ti ise won yoo je.

en: And the bottom line, major thing that has come through in every single drill: nobody knows who's in charge.
yo: Koko ibe ni wi pe, koko nnkan to ti sele ninu gbogbo igbanisise kookan ni wi pe: ko seni to mo eni to wa nidi re.

en: Nobody knows the chain of command.
yo: Ko seni ti mo okun ase.

en: If it were Los Angeles, is it the mayor, the governor, the President of the United States, the head of Homeland Security?
yo: To ba je Los Angeles ni, se olori agbegbe ni, gomina, Aare orile-ede United States, olori eka eto-aabo labele?

en: In fact, the federal government says it's a guy called the Principle Federal Officer, who happens to be with TSA.
yo: Loooto, ijoba apapo so wi pe okunrin kan ti won n pe ni Asoju Ilana Ijoba Apaponi, to wa pelu TSA.

en: The government says the federal responsibility will basically be about trying to keep the virus out, which we all know is impossible, and then to mitigate the impact primarily on our economy.
yo: Ijoba so wi pe ojuse apapo ni pataki julo yoo je nipa igbiyanju lati dena kokoro naa, ti gbogbo wa mo wi pe ko se e se, ati lati dena koko ipa re lori oro-aje wa.

en: The rest is up to your local community.
yo: Eyi toku dowo awujo ibile yin.

en: Everything is about your town, where you live.
yo: Gbogbo re je nipa agbegbe yin, ti e n gbe.

en: Well how good a city council you have, how good a mayor you have -- that's who's going to be in charge.
yo: Bi ajo-igbimo agbegbe ti e ni se dara si, bi olori-agegbe ti e ni se dara si -- eni ti yoo wa ni isakoso niyen.

en: Most local facilities would all be competing to try and get their hands on their piece of the federal stockpile of a drug called Tamiflu, which may or may not be helpful -- I'll get into that -- of available vaccines, and any other treatments, and masks, and anything that's been stockpiled.
yo: Opolopo awon ohun-elo agbegbe maa jijagudu lati gbiyanju ati dawo won le okan ninu akojo oogun apapo ti won n pe ni Tamiflu, to le tabi ko ma se iranlowo -- maa so nipa iyen -- awon oogun ajesara to wa, ati awon itoju miiran, ati iboju, ati eyikeyi nnkan ti won ti toju pamo.

en: And you'll have massive competition.
yo: "E o si ni ifigagbaga t""o po."

en: Now we did purchase a vaccine, you've probably all heard about it, made by Sanofi-Aventis.
yo: Bayii a ra oogun ajesara loooto, gbogbo yin le le ti gbo nipa e, ti Sanofi-Aventis se.

en: Unfortunately it's made against the current form of H5N1.
yo: O seni laaanu pe won se e tako irisi H5N1 lowolowo yii ni.

en: We know the virus will mutate.
yo: A mo wi pe kokoro naa yoo yi pada.

en: It will be a different virus.
yo: O maa di kokoro to yato.

en: The vaccine will probably be useless.
yo: Oogun ajesara naa le ma wulo.

en: So here's where the decisions come in.
yo: Ibi ni ipinnu naa ti maa wole.

en: You're the mayor of your local town.
yo: Iwo ni olori agbegbe ibile re.

en: Let's see, should we order that all pets be kept indoors?
yo: E je ka wo o, se ka pase wi pe ki a toju gbogbo awon eranko sinu ile ni?

en: Germany did that when H5N1 appeared in Germany last year, in order to minimize the spread between households by household cats, dogs and so on.
yo: Orile-ede Germany se eyi nigba ti H5N1 seyo ni Germany lodun ti o koja, lati le mu adinku ba itanka re laaarin awon ologbo ile si ile, aja ati beebee lo.

en: What do we do when we don't have any containment rooms with reverse air that will allow the healthcare workers to take care of patients?
yo: Ki la fe se nigba ti a o ba ni yara iko nnkan si pelu ategun afeyinrin ti yoo je ki awon osise ilera se itoju awon alaisan?

en: These are in Hong Kong; we have nothing like that here.
yo: Awon wonyi wa ni Hong Kong; a o ni nnkan to jo bee nibi.

en: What about quarantine?
yo: Iyasoto nko?

en: During the SARS epidemic in Beijing quarantine did seem to help.
yo: Lasiko ajakale aarun SARS ni Beijing iyasoto dabi eni se iranlowo.

en: We have no uniform policies regarding quarantine across the United States.
yo: A o ni ipinnu to dogba nipa iyasoto ni orile-ede United States.

en: And some states have differential policies, county by county.
yo: Awon ipinle kan ni ipinnu oto, orile-ede si orile-ede.

en: But what about the no-brainer things?
yo: Sugbon awon nnkan ti o mu opolo dani nko?

en: Should we close all the schools?
yo: "Se k""a ti gbogbo ile-eko pa ni?"

en: Well then what about all the workers?
yo: Awon osise nko nigba naa?

en: They won't go to work if their kids aren't in school.
yo: Won o ni lo sibi ise ti awon omo won o ba si nile-eko.

en: Encouraging telecommuting?
yo: Sise atileyin fun ero-ibaraenisoro?

en: What works?
yo: Ki lo n sise?

en: Well the British government did a model of telecommuting.
yo: Ijoba ile Britain se awose ero-ibaraenisoro kan.

en: Six weeks they had all people in the banking industry pretend a pandemic was underway.
yo: Ose mefa ni won fi ni ki awon eniyan ni eka ifowopamo dibon pe ajakale arun ti n bo.

en: What they found was, the core functions -- you know you still sort of had banks, but you couldn't get people to put money in the ATM machines.
yo: Nnkan ti won ri ni wi pe, awon ise pataki -- e mo pe e si ni ile-ifowopamo, sugbon e o le ri awon eniyan ti yoo fi owo sinu ero ATM.

en: Nobody was processing the credit cards.
yo: "Ko seni t""o n se ike-pelebe-isanwo-si-lori."

en: Your insurance payments didn't go through.
yo: Sisan owo idojutofo re o lo.

en: And basically the economy would be in a disaster state of affairs.
yo: Pataki julo oro-aje yoo wa ninu ajalu nla.

en: And that's just office workers, bankers.
yo: Awon onisee ofisi nikan niyen o, awon osise ile-ifowopamo.

en: We don't know how important hand washing is for flu -- shocking.
yo: A o mo bi owo fifo se se pataki si arun ayokele si -- lejaa fuu.

en: One assumes it's a good idea to wash your hands a lot.
yo: A gba pe ero to dara ni lati maa fowo wa lopolopo.

en: But actually in scientific community there is great debate about what percentage of flu transmission between people is from sneezing and coughing and what percentage is on your hands.
yo: Sugbon ni awujo awon onimo-ijile ariyanjiyan wa nipa kini ida iye akoran arun ayokele laaarin awon eniyan lati ara sinsin ati iko ki si ni ida to wa lowoo re.

en: The Institute of Medicine tried to look at the masking question.
yo: Ile-eko imo-isegun gbiyanju lati wo ibeere ibomu.

en: Can we figure out a way, since we know we won't have enough masks because we don't make them in America anymore, they're all made in China -- do we need N95?
yo: Nje a le wa ona kan, nigba ti a o mo wi pe a o ni ibomu to to nitori a o kin se e ni ile America mo, orile-ede China ni won ti n se gbogbo re -- nje a nilo N95?

en: A state-of-the-art, top-of-the-line, must-be-fitted-to-your-face mask?
yo: Ibomu to ba igba mu, to n lewaju, ti yoo ba ojuu re mu?

en: Or can we get away with some different kinds of masks?
yo: Abi se a le lo orisirisi ibomu?

en: In the SARS epidemic, we learned in Hong Kong that most of transmission was because people were removing their masks improperly.
yo: Lasiko ajakale arun SARS, a kekoo ni Hong Kong pe opolopo akoran waye nitori pe awon eniyan n yo iboju won lona ti o to.

en: And their hand got contaminated with the outside of the mask, and then they rubbed their nose.
yo: Owoo won maa n ni akoran pelu ita ibomu naa, won si n ra imu won.

en: Bingo! They got SARS.
yo: Yegede! Won ti ni SARS.

en: It wasn't flying microbes.
yo: Ki i se awon kokoro aifojuri to n fo.

en: If you go online right now, you'll get so much phony-baloney information.
yo: Bi e ba lo sori ero-ayelukara nisiyii, e o ri opolopo afitoni asinilona.

en: You'll end up buying -- this is called an N95 mask.
yo: E o si pada ra a -- eyi ni won n pe ni iboju N95.

en: We don't actually have a standard for what should be the protective gear for the first responders, the people who will actually be there on the front lines.
yo: A o ni awokose fun nnkan to ye ko je ohun-elo idaaabobo fun awon alewaju isele pajawiri, awon eniyan ti won yoo siwaju ogun.

en: And Tamiflu.
yo: Ati Tamiflu.

en: You've probably heard of this drug, made by Hoffmann-La Roche, patented drug.
yo: Boya e ti gbo nipa oogun yii, ti Hoffmann-La Roche se, oogun to gba iwe-ase ni.

en: There is some indication that it may buy you some time in the midst of an outbreak.
yo: Awon itokasi kan wa pe o le ra asiko die fun yin laaarin ajakale arun.

en: Should you take Tamiflu for a long period of time, well, one of the side effects is suicidal ideations.
yo: Se ki e lo Tamiflu fun igba pipe, o daa, okan ninu awon ayorisi miiran ni ero igbemi ara eni.

en: A public health survey analyzed the effect that large-scale Tamiflu use would have, actually shows it counteractive to public health measures, making matters worse.
yo: Itopinpin ilera gbogbogbo se itupale ayorisi ti lilo Tamiflu lopolopo le ni, fi han pe o sise tako osuwon ilera gbogbogbo, to je ki oro tubo buru si i.

en: And here is the other interesting thing: when a human being ingests Tamiflu, only 20 percent is metabolized appropriately to be an active compound in the human being.
yo: Nnkan miiran to tun panilerin ni pe: nigba ti omo eniyan ba lo Tamiflu, ida ogun ni yoo yoro daadaa lati sise ninu omo eniyan.

en: The rest turns into a stable compound, which survives filtration into the water systems, thereby exposing the very aquatic birds that would carry flu and providing them a chance to breed resistant strains.
yo: Awon toku yoo pada di nnkan ti o yipada, ti yoo moribo nibi sise sinu eto omi, ti yoo si se agbejade eye omi gan-an ti yoo gbe arun-oloje-ona-eemi naa ti yoo si fun won ni anfaani lati se itoju awon eya arun-oloje-ona-eemi atako.

en: And we now have seen Tamiflu-resistant strains in both Vietnam in person-to-person transmission, and in Egypt in person-to-person transmission.
yo: Ni bayii a ti ri eya atako-Tamiflu bayii ninu akoran eniyan si eniyan ni Vietnam, ati ni orile-ede Egypt akoran eniyan si eniyan.

en: So I personally think that our life expectancy for Tamiflu as an effective drug is very limited -- very limited indeed.
yo: Mo n ro o lokan ara mi pe okun emi Tamiflu gege bi oogun to n sise ni gbedeke -- o ni gbedeke loooto.

en: Nevertheless most of the governments have based their whole flu policies on building stockpiles of Tamiflu.
yo: Sibesibe opolopo awon ijoba ti gbe gbogbo awon ilana-ise arun-oloje-ona-eemi won lori ikojo oogun Tamiflu.

en: Russia has actually stockpiled enough for 95 percent of all Russians.
yo: Orile-ede Russia ti se ikojo eyi ti yoo to fun ida 95 gbogbo awon omo orile-ede Russia.

en: We've stockpiled enough for 30 percent.
yo: A ti se ikojo eyi ti yoo to fun ida 30.

en: When I say enough, that's two weeks worth.
yo: Bi mo ba so wi pe eyi to to, eyi ti yoo to fun ose meji ni.

en: And then you're on your own because the pandemic is going to last for 18 to 24 months.
yo: O ti ku iwo nikan o tori ajakale arun naa yoo to bi osu 18 si osu 24.

en: Some of the poorer countries that have had the most experience with H5N1 have built up stockpiles; they're already expired.
yo: Awon kan ninu awon orile-ede ti won ti ni iriri to poju pelu H5N1 ti se akojo oogun; won si ti baje.

en: They are already out of date.
yo: Won ti koja igba won.

en: What do we know from 1918, the last great pandemic?
yo: Ki la mo lati odun 1918, ajakale arun alagbara to sele gbeyin?

en: The federal government abdicated most responsibility.
yo: Ijoba apapo ti gbe opolopo ojuse re ju sile.

en: And so we ended up with this wild patchwork of regulations all over America.
yo: Nitori naa a papa wa ni alelu-ise ofin yii kaakiri ile America.

en: Every city, county, state did their own thing.
yo: Gbogbo agbegbe, orile-ede, ati ipinle n se nnkan tiwon.

en: And the rules and the belief systems were wildly disparate.
yo: Awon ofin ati eto igbagbo ni won o jora won.

en: In some cases all schools, all churches, all public venues were closed.
yo: Ni awon oran kookan gbogbo ile-eko, gbogbo ile-ijosin awon kiristeni, awon agbegbe ilu ni won gbeti.

en: The pandemic circulated three times in 18 months in the absence of commercial air travel.
yo: Ajakale arun naa tan-yika nigba meta ni osu 18 laisi irina oko ofuurufu ajere.

en: The second wave was the mutated, super-killer wave.
yo: Iji keji yipada, iji asekupani-nla.

en: And in the first wave we had enough healthcare workers.
yo: Ni iji akoko a ni awon osise ilera ti o to.
