en: But by the time the second wave hit it took such a toll among the healthcare workers that we lost most of our doctors and nurses that were on the front lines.
yo: Sugbon nigba ti iji keji fi ja o mu pupo lara awon osise ilera lo ti a padanu awon onisegun-oyinbo ati awon oluto-ile-iwosan wa ti won lewaju naa.

en: Overall we lost 700,000 people.
yo: Lapapo a padanu egberun-lona 700 awon eniyan.

en: The virus was 100 percent lethal to pregnant women and we don't actually know why.
yo: Kokoro naa fi ida 100 sekupa awon obinrin alaboyun a o si mo idi re.

en: Most of the death toll was 15 to 40 year-olds -- robustly healthy young adults.
yo: Opolopo akosile iku je eni odun 15 si 40 odun -- awon odo ti ilera won peye.

en: It was likened to the plague.
yo: Won fi-we ajakale arun naa.

en: We don't actually know how many people died.
yo: "A o mo iye eniyan t""o ku pato."

en: The low-ball estimate is 35 million.
yo: Idiyele naa ti o se e gbojule je aadota-oke 35.

en: This was based on European and North American data.
yo: Eyi wa lati ara iwifuni-alalaye ti ile Europe ati North America.

en: A new study by Chris Murray at Harvard shows that if you look at the databases that were kept by the Brits in India, there was a 31-fold greater death rate among the Indians.
yo: Iwadii tuntun ti Chris Murray se ni Havard fi han pe ti e ba wo aka-iwifuni-alalaye ti awon Brits ni orile-ede India toju, ilopo 31 odiwon iku laaarin awon omo orile-ede India lo wa.

en: So there is a strong belief that in places of poverty the death toll was far higher.
yo: Igbagbo to lagbara wa wi pe ni awon agbegbe olosi akosile iku tun po pupo.

en: And that a more likely toll is somewhere in the neighborhood of 80 to 100 million people before we had commercial air travel.
yo: "Ati wi pe opolopo akosile to se e se wa laaarin adugbo aadota-oke 80 si aadota-oke 100 eniyan k""a to ni eto irinajo oko-ofuurufu ti i se ti owo."

en: So are we ready?
yo: Se a ti setan?

en: As a nation, no we're not.
yo: Gege bi orile-ede, a o se tan.

en: And I think even those in the leadership would say that is the case, that we still have a long ways to go.
yo: Mo si ro o wi pe awon to wa nipo asiwaju maa so wi pe bo se ri niyen, pe ona wa si jin.

en: So what does that mean for you?
yo: Kini iyen tumo si fun yin?

en: Well the first thing is, I wouldn't start building up personal stockpiles of anything -- for yourself, your family, or your employees -- unless you've really done your homework.
yo: "Nnkan akoko ni wi pe, mi o ni bere sini se ikojo adani ohunkohun - tikaraare, ebii re, tabi awon osise ""e-- ayafi ti e ba ti se ise asetilewaa yin."

en: What mask works, what mask doesn't work.
yo: Ibomu wo lo n sise, ibomu wo ni o sise.

en: How many masks do you need?
yo: Ibomu meloo la nilo?

en: The Institute of Medicine study felt that you could not recycle masks.
yo: iwadii ile-eko imo-isegun ro o wi pe e o le se atunse ibomu.

en: Well if you think it's going to last 18 months, are you going to buy 18 months worth of masks for every single person in your family?
yo: Bi e ba ro wi pe yoo to osu 18, se e o ra ibomu ti yoo to osu 18 fun eniyan kookan ninu ebii yin ni?

en: We don't know -- again with Tamiflu, the number one side effect of Tamiflu is flu-like symptoms.
yo: A o mo -- pelu Tamiflu leekan sii, ayorisi miiran akoko ti Tamiflu ni ni ami aisan afarajo-arun-oloje-ona-eemi.

en: So then how can you tell who in your family has the flu if everybody is taking Tamiflu?
yo: "Bawo le se le mo eniyan naa ninu ebii yin t""o ni arun-oloje-ona-eemi ti gbogbo won ba n lo Tamiflu?"

en: If you expand that out to think of a whole community, or all your employees in your company, you begin to realize how limited the Tamiflu option might be.
yo: Bi e ba feju iyen sita lati ronu nipa gbogbo awujo, tabi gbogbo awon osise ni ile-ise yin, e o bere sini mo gbedeke bi eyan Tamiflu se le ri.

en: Everybody has come up to me and said, well I'll stockpile water or, I'll stockpile food, or what have you.
yo: Gbogbo eniyan ti wa ba mi ti won si so wi pe, a maa se ikopamo omi tabi, maa se ikopamo ounje, tabi nnkan miiran.

en: But really?
yo: Sugbon se loooto?

en: Do you really have a place to stockpile 18 months worth of food?
yo: Nje e ni aye lati se ikopamoo ounje fun osu meji-din-logun?

en: Twenty-four months worth of food?
yo: Ounje to to osu merin-din-logun?

en: Do you want to view the pandemic threat the way back in the 1950s people viewed the civil defense issue, and build your own little bomb shelter for pandemic flu?
yo: Se e fe foju wo ewu ajakale arun bi awon eniyan ni asiko 1950 se foju wo oro aabo ara-eni, ki e si ko iboji ado-oloro kekere fun ajakale arun-oloje-ona-eemi?

en: I don't think that's rational.
yo: Mi o ro wi pe iyen ba ironu mu.

en: I think it's about having to be prepared as communities, not as individuals -- being prepared as nation, being prepared as state, being prepared as town.
yo: Mo ro wi pe o nise pelu igbaradi gege bi awujo, kii se gege bi eniyan -- wiwa nigbaradi gege bi orile-ede, wiwa nigbaradi gege bi ipinle, wiwa nigbaradi gege bi agbegbe.

en: And right now most of the preparedness is deeply flawed.
yo: "Lowolowo bayii opolopo igbaradi l""o ni akude t""o feju."

en: "And I hope I've convinced you of that, which means that the real job is go out and say to your local leaders, and your national leaders, ""Why haven't you solved these problems?"
yo: "Mo si lero wi pe mo ti yii yin lokan pada, to tumo si wi pe oju ise gangan ni ki e jade ki e si so fun awon adari ibile yin, ati awon adari apapo yin, ""ki lo de ti e o se tii yanju awon isoro wonyi?"

en: Why are you still thinking that the lessons of Katrina do not apply to flu?
yo: Ki lo de ti e si n ronu pe awon eko nipa Katrina o wulo fun arun-oloje-ona-eemi?

en: """ And put the pressure where the pressure needs to be put."
yo: """ ki e si gbe agbara le ibi to ye ki e gbe agbara le."

en: But I guess the other thing to add is, if you do have employees, and you do have a company, I think you have certain responsibilities to demonstrate that you are thinking ahead for them, and you are trying to plan.
yo: Sugbon mo ro wi pe nnkan miiran to ye ka fi kun-un ni pe, ti e ba ni awon osise loooto, ti e si ni ile-ise loooto, mo ro wi pe e ni awon ojuse kookan lati safihan wi pe e n ronu siwaju fun won, e si n gbiyanju lati seto.

en: At a minimum the British banking plan showed that telecommuting can be helpful.
yo: Ni akerepin eto ifowopamo Britain fi han pe ibaraeni-soro le se iranlowo.

en: It probably does reduce exposure because people are not coming into the office and coughing on each other, or touching common objects and sharing things via their hands.
yo: O le se adinku agbejade nitori awon eniyan o wonu ibi-ise ki won maa wuko sira won lara, tabi fowo kan nnkan ajoni ati pinpin-in nipase owo won.

en: But can you sustain your company that way?
yo: Sugbon se e le se itesiwaju ile-ise yin bayen?

en: Well if you have a dot-com, maybe you can.
yo: Ti e ba ni ero-ayelukara, boya e le se bee.

en: Otherwise you're in trouble.
yo: Yato si iyen e ti wo wahala.

en: Happy to take your questions.
yo: Imu mi dun lati gba ibeere yin.

en: Audience member: What factors determine the duration of a pandemic?
yo: Okan lara onworan: Awon nnkan wo lo le so iye akoko ajakale arun kan?

en: Laurie Garret: What factors determine the duration of a pandemic, we don't really know.
yo: Laurie Garret: awon nnkan wo lo le so iye akoko ajakale arun kan, a o fi bee mo.

en: I could give you a bunch of flip, this, that, and the other.
yo: Mo le fun yin ni akojopo isi, eyi, iyen, ati omiran.

en: But I would say that honestly we don't know.
yo: Sugbon maa so wi pe lododo a o mo.

en: Clearly the bottom line is the virus eventually attenuates, and ceases to be a lethal virus to humanity, and finds other hosts.
yo: Koko ibe ni wi pe kokoro naa maa n ni adinku okun, o si maa n dekun lati di kokoro asekupani fun eniyan, o si maa n wa agbarun miiran.

en: But we don't really know how and why that happens.
yo: Sugbon a o fi bee mo bo se n sele ati idi to fi n sele.

en: It's a very complicated ecology.
yo: Eko nipa ajosepo laaarin eniyan ati awujo to je amudiju ni.

en: Audience member: What kind of triggers are you looking for?
yo: Okan lara onworan: iru asokunfa wo le n wa?

en: You know way more than any of us.
yo: E nimo ju enikan kan wa lo.

en: To say ahh, if this happens then we are going to have a pandemic?
yo: Lati so pe ahh, ti eyi ba sele a maa ni ajakale arun?

en: LG: The moment that you see any evidence of serious human-to-human to transmission.
yo: LG: igba ti e ba ti n ri eri akoran eniyan si eniyan to lagbara.

en: Not just intimately between family members who took care of an ailing sister or brother, but a community infected -- spread within a school, spread within a dormitory, something of that nature.
yo: Kii se timotimo laaarin molebi ti won n se itoju aburo lobinrin tabi aburo lokunrin to n saisan nikan, sugbon akoran laaarin awujo -- ifonka laaarin ile-eko, akoran laaarin odede, iru nnkan bayen.

en: Then I think that there is universal agreement now, at WHO all the way down: Send out the alert.
yo: Mo si ronu wi pe adehun agbaye ti wa bayii, ni WHO titi de isale: e fi ifitoni ranse sita.

en: Audience member: Some research has indicated that statins can be helpful.
yo: Okan lara onworan: awon iwadii kan ti fi han pe awon oogun ora inu eje n le se iranlowo.

en: Can you talk about that?
yo: Nje e le soro nipa iyen?

en: LG: Yeah.
yo: LG: beeni.

en: There is some evidence that taking Lipitor and other common statins for cholesterol control may decrease your vulnerability to influenza.
yo: Awon eri kan wa pe Lipitor ati awon oogun ora inu eje toku le se adinku ikangun-sewu arun-oloje-opona-eemi.

en: But we do not completely understand why.
yo: Sugbon a o mo idi re rara.

en: The mechanism isn't clear.
yo: Eto naa o han kedere.

en: And I don't know that there is any way responsibly for someone to start medicating their children with their personal supply of Lipitor or something of that nature.
yo: Mi o si mo wi pe ona kankan wa to to fun eniyan lati bere sini fun awon omo won logun pelu Lipitor adani tabi nnkan to jo bee.

en: We have absolutely no idea what that would do.
yo: A o nimo Kankan nipa nnkan ti iyen maa se.

en: You might be causing some very dangerous outcomes in your children, doing such a thing.
yo: E le maa fa abajade abewude si omo yin lara, pelu sise nnkan bee.

en: Audience member: How far along are we in being able to determine whether someone is actually carrying, whether somebody has this before the symptoms are full-blown?
yo: Okan lara onworan: bawo la se sumo mimo boya enikan n gbe e kiri, boya enikan ni eyi ki awon ami aisan naa to foju-han.

en: LG: Right.
yo: LG: o daa.

en: So I have for a long time said that what we really needed was a rapid diagnostic.
yo: Mo ti so nigba pipe pe nnkan ti a nilo ni idamo aisan kankan.

en: And our Centers for Disease Control has labeled a test they developed a rapid diagnostic.
yo: Awon aye fun idena arun wa ti sami si ayewo kan ti won se idamo aisan kankan.

en: It takes 24 hours in a very highly developed laboratory, in highly skilled hands.
yo: O maa n gba to wakati merin-le-logun ni aye fun imo-ijinle to ti dagbasoke gan-an, ni owo awon ti won moo se gan-an.

en: I'm thinking dipstick.
yo: Mo n ronu jinle.

en: You could do it to your own kid.
yo: E le se e fun awon omo yin.

en: It changes color.
yo: O maa n pa awo da.

en: It tells you if you have H5N1.
yo: O maa so fun yin boya e ni H5N1.

en: In terms of where we are in science with DNA identification capacities and so on, it's not that far off.
yo: Nipa ibi ti a wa ninu imo-ijinle pelu ikapaa idanimo DNA ati beebee lo, a o jina pupo.

en: But we're not there.
yo: Sugbon a o tii debe.

en: And there hasn't been the kind of investment to get us there.
yo: Ko si tii si iru idokowo to le gbe wa debe.

en: Audience member: In the 1918 flu I understand that they theorized that there was some attenuation of the virus when it made the leap into humans.
yo: Okan lara onworan: Ni afaafe odun 1918 o yemi wi pe won pese tiori pe awon adinku okun kokoro naa sele nigba to fo wonu eniyan.

en: Is that likely, do you think, here?
yo: Se iyen se e se, se e ro bee, nibi?

en: I mean 100 percent death rate is pretty severe.
yo: Mo n so nipa pe ida ogorun apapo iku po pupo.

en: LG: Um yeah.
yo: LG: Um beeni.

en: So we don't actually know what the lethality was of the 1918 strain to wild birds before it jumped from birds to humans.
yo: A o mo bi isekupani kokoro odun 1918 se to si awon eye igbo ko to fo latara eye si eniyan.

en: It's curious that there is no evidence of mass die-offs of chickens or household birds across America before the human pandemic happened.
yo: O sajoji pe ko si eri iku lopo nipa awon adiye tabi awon eye inu-ile kaakiri ile America ki ajakale arun naa to sele si eniyan.

en: That may be because those events were occurring on the other side of the world where nobody was paying attention.
yo: Iyen le je nitori awon isele yen n sele ni odi keji agbaye nibi ti enikankan o ti fokan si.

en: But the virus clearly went through one round around the world in a mild enough form that the British army in World War I actually certified that it was not a threat and would not affect the outcome of the war.
yo: Sugbon kokoro naa ni kedere lo leekan kaakiri agbaye ni eda to le ti awonn omo-ogun Britain ninu ogun agbaye akoko fi owo re soya pe kii se ewu ko si ni se idiwo fu abajade ogun.

en: And after circulating around the world came back in a form that was tremendously lethal.
yo: Nigba to si lo yipo agbaye o pada wa ni eda asekupani to le.

en: What percentage of infected people were killed by it?
yo: Kini ida awon eniyan to ko o ti o pawon?

en: Again we don't really know for sure.
yo: Leekan si i a o mo loooto.

en: It's clear that if you were malnourished to begin with, you had a weakened immune system, you lived in poverty in India or Africa, your likelihood of dying was far greater.
yo: O foju han pe ti e ba lokun fun ibeere, e ni eto ajesara to le, e n gbe ninu ise ni orile-ede India tabi ile Adulawo, ise e se yin lati ku po gidi gan-an.

en: But we don't really know.
yo: Sugbon a o fi bee mo.

en: Audience member: One of the things I've heard is that the real death cause when you get a flu is the associated pneumonia, and that a pneumonia vaccine may offer you 50 percent better chance of survival.
yo: Okan lara omworan: okan lara awon nnkan ti mo ti gbo ni wi pe okunfa iku gangan nigba ti eniyan ba ni arun-oloje-ona-eemi ni otutu aya to ro mo, ati wi pe oogun ajesara otutu-egbe le fun yin ni ida aadota anfaani arula.

en: LG: For a long time, researchers in emerging diseases were kind of dismissive of the pandemic flu threat on the grounds that back in 1918 they didn't have antibiotics.
yo: LG: fun igba pipe, awon onise iwadii ninu arun tuntun o kobiara si ewu ajakale arun-oloje-opona-eemi pelu awijare wi pe ni odun 1918 won o ni oogun apa kokoro aifojuri.

en: And that most people who die of regular flu -- which in regular flu years is about 360,000 people worldwide, most of them senior citizens -- and they die not of the flu but because the flu gives an assault to their immune system.
yo: Ati wi pe opolopo awon eniyan ti won ku iku arun-oloje-ona-eemi ojoojumo -- to se wi pe ni odun afaafe ojoojumo bii egberun lona ota-le-loodunrun eniyan kaakiri agbanla-aye, opolopo awon agbalagba -- won si ku kii se nitori afaafe sugbon nitori arun-oloje-ona-eemi naa ti fa ewu si eto ajesara aifaragbaisan-laaye won ni.

en: And along comes pneumococcus or another bacteria, streptococcus and boom, they get a bacterial pneumonia.
yo: Pelu re ni otutu-egbe tabi kokoro-aifojuri miiran, kokoro amunkandobu, o fon ka, won ti ni kokoro-aifojuri otutu-egbe.

en: But it turns out that in 1918 that was not the case at all.
yo: Sugbon o sele wi pe ni odun 1918 bi oro se ri ko niyen rara.

en: And so far in the H5N1 cases in people, similarly bacterial infection has not been an issue at all.
yo: Di asiko yii ni ti oro H5N1 ninu eniyan, iru akoran kokoro-aifojuri bee ko ni wahala rara.

en: It's this absolutely phenomenal disruption of the immune system that is the key to why people die of this virus.
yo: Nnkan asediwo fun eto ajesara aifaragbaisan-laaye to yato patapata yii ni kokoro si idi ti awon eniyan fi n ku latara kokoro yii.

en: And I would just add we saw the same thing with SARS.
yo: Mo si ma se afikun pe a ri nnkan kan naa pelu SARS.

en: "So what's going on here is your body says, your immune system sends out all its sentinels and says, ""I don't know what the heck this is."
yo: "Nnkan to n sele nibi ni wi pe ara yin n so wi pe, ki eto ajesara aifaragbaisan-laaye yin n ran gbogbo asafihan arun re ko si so wi pe, ""mi o mo ohun ti eyi je."

en: We've never seen anything even remotely like this before.
yo: A o tii ri nnkankan koda die to dabi eyi ri tele.

en: """ It won't do any good to bring in the sharpshooters because those antibodies aren't here."
yo: Ko ni se anfaani kankan lati mu awon atamatase wole nitori awon agbogunti-arun ara yen o si nibi.

en: And it won't do any good to bring in the tanks and the artillery because those T-cells don't recognize it either.
yo: Ko si ni se anfaani kankan lati mu awon oko-ijagun ati ibon nla wole nitori awon padi-T o da mo pelu.

en: So we're going to have to go all-out thermonuclear response, stimulate the total cytokine cascade.
yo: A maa nilo lati jade tan pelu idahun ago gbigbona, igun ni kese gbogbo atopo amu-ilera ara-sedeede.

en: The whole immune system swarms into the lungs.
yo: Gbogbo eto ajesara aifaragbaisan-laaye ti luwe wonu edofooro.

en: And yes they die, drowning in their own fluids, of pneumonia.
yo: Bee ni won ku, won ri sinu oje ara won, ti otutu-egbe.

en: But it's not bacterial pneumonia.
yo: Sugbon ki i se kokoro-aifojuri otutu-egbe.

en: And it's not a pneumonia that would respond to a vaccine.
yo: Ki i se otutu-egbe ni yoo dahun si oogun ibupa.

en: And I think my time is up.
yo: Mo ro wi pe akoko mi ti to.

en: I thank you all for your attention.
yo: Mo dupe lowo gbogbo yin fun akiyesi yin.

en: Refugees have the right to be protected
yo: Awon ogunlende ni eto si idaaabobo.

en: Bruno Giussani: Commissioner, thank you for coming to TED.
yo: Bruno Giusani: komisona, e seun ti e wa si TED.

en: Antonio Guterres: Pleasure.
yo: Antonio Guterres: idunnu mi ni.

en: BG: Let's start with a figure.
yo: BG: e je ka bere pelu onka.

en: During 2015, almost one million refugees and migrants arrived in Europe from many different countries, of course, from Syria and Iraq, but also from Afghanistan and Bangladesh and Eritrea and elsewhere.
yo: Lasiko odun 2015, o feree to aadota-oke kan awon atipo ati awon asikiri ti won de sile Europe lati orile-ede lorisiirisi, bee ni, lati Syria ati Iraq, sugbon bakan naa lati Afghanistan ati Bangladesh ati Eritrea ati ibomiran.

en: And there have been reactions of two different kinds: welcoming parties and border fences.
yo: Irufe awon esi meji otooto lo ti wa: awon ti won n gba alejo wole ati awon ogiri enubode.

en: But I want to look at it a little bit from the short-term and the long-term perspective.
yo: Sugbon mo fe wo o die pelu oju-iwoye igba-die ati igba-pipe.

en: And the first question is very simple: Why has the movement of refugees spiked so fast in the last six months?
yo: Ibeere akoko si rorun gidi gan-an: kilode ti irinajo awon atipo se lekun sii lati bi osu mefa seyin?

en: AG: Well, I think, basically, what triggered this huge increase was the Syrian refugee group.
yo: AG: O daa, mo ro o, ni pataki julo, pe nnkan to sokunfa afikun nla yii ni egbe awon atipo orile-ede Syria.

en: There has been an increased movement into Europe from Africa, from Asia, but slowly growing, and all of a sudden we had this massive increase in the first months of this year.
yo: Alekun ti wa ninu irnajo lo sile Europe lati ile Adulawo, lati Asia, sugbon to n dagba diedie, lojiji a ni afikun to po ni osu akoko odun yii.

en: I think there are three reasons, two long-term ones and the trigger.
yo: Okunfa meta ni mo ro wi pe o fa a, awon tigba-pipe meji ati okunfa e.

en: The long-term ones, in relation to Syrians, is that hope is less and less clear for people.
yo: Awon tigba-pipe, ni ibatan pelu awon omo ile Syria, ni wi pe ireti kere ko si hande pupo fun awon eniyan.

en: I mean, they look at their own country and they don't see much hope to go back home, because there is no political solution, so there is no light at the end of the tunnel.
yo: Mo n so nipa pe, won n wo orile-ede won won o si ri ireti pupo lati pada sile, nitori ko si ona-abayo oselu, tori naa ko si imole leyin okunkun.

en: Second, the living conditions of the Syrians in the neighboring countries have been deteriorating.
yo: Eleekeji, igbesi aye awon omo orile-ede Syria ti won wa ni awon orile-ede to sumo ti n poluku-musu.

en: We just had research with the World Bank, and 87 percent of the Syrians in Jordan and 93 percent of the Syrians in Lebanon live below the national poverty lines.
yo: A se se iwadii pelu Ile-ifowopamo Agbaye ni, ida meta-din-laadorun awon omo orile-ede Syria ni Jordan ati ida meta-le-laadorun awon omo orile-ede Syria ni Lebanon ni won n gbe labe ila osi apapo.

en: Only half of the children go to school, which means that people are living very badly.
yo: Idaji ninu awon omo ni won n lo ile-eko, to tumo si wi pe awon eniyan n gbe igbeaye ti o da.

en: Not only are they refugees, out of home, not only have they suffered what they have suffered, but they are living in very, very dramatic conditions.
yo: Kii se wi pe won je atipo nikan, ti won o nile, kii se wi pe won ti jiya ti won je nikan, sugbon won n gbe ni ipo to bani ninu je.

en: And then the trigger was when all of a sudden, international aid decreased.
yo: Okunfa naa ni igba to je wi pe lojiji, iranwo latokere dinku.

en: The World Food Programme was forced, for lack of resources, to cut by 30 percent food support to the Syrian refugees.
yo: Won pon-on ni dandan fun Eto Ounje Agbaye, fun aisi ohun-elo, lati ge ida ogbon iranwo ounje fun awon atipo omo orile-ede Syria.

en: "They're not allowed to work, so they are totally dependent on international support, and they felt, ""The world is abandoning us."
yo: "Won o gba won laaye lati sise, nitori naa won gbarale iranwo lati ile-okeere patapata, won de n ro o wi pe, ""gbogbo aye ti n pawa ti."

en: """ And that, in my opinion, was the trigger."
yo: Iyen, ni erongba temi, ni okunfa re.

en: All of a sudden, there was a rush, and people started to move in large numbers and, to be absolutely honest, if I had been in the same situation and I would have been brave enough to do it, I think I would have done the same.
yo: Lojiji, irogiri wa, awon eniyan de bere sini gbera niye won ati, ki so ododo, ti mo ba wa ni iru ipo bee ti mo si ni igboya lati se e, mo ro wi pe emi naa i ba se bee.

en: BG: But I think what surprised many people is it's not only sudden, but it wasn't supposed to be sudden.
yo: BG: sugbon mo ro wi pe nnkan to ya opolopo eniyan lenu ni wi pe se ko tii ya ju, sugbon ko ye ki o ya.

en: The war in Syria has been happening for five years.
yo: Ogun to wa ni orile-ede Syria ti n sele fun odun marun-un.

en: Millions of refugees are in camps and villages and towns around Syria.
yo: Aadota-oke awon atipo wa ni ipago ati awon abule ati awon agbegbe to yi orile-ede Syria.

en: You have yourself warned about the situation and about the consequences of a breakdown of Libya, for example, and yet Europe looked totally unprepared.
yo: Won ti kilo fun yin nipa isele naa ati apadabo idarudapo ni orile-ede Libya, fun apeere, sibe ile Europe dabi eni ti o tii setan.

en: AG: Well, unprepared because divided, and when you are divided, you don't want to recognize the reality.
yo: AG: O daa, aimurasile nitori ipinya, ti e ba d si e ti pinya, e o ni fe ri ooto.

en: You prefer to postpone decisions, because you do not have the capacity to make them.
yo: O maa te e yin lorun lati sun ipinnu siwaju, nitori e o ni ikapa lati sewon.

en: And the proof is that even when the spike occurred, Europe remained divided and was unable to put in place a mechanism to manage the situation.
yo: Eri ni wi pe koda nigba ti alekun naa sele, ile Europe si pin sibe won o si ni anfanni lati seto ti yoo moju to isele naa.

en: You talk about one million people.
yo: E soro nipa egberun-lona-egberun kan eniyan.

en: It looks enormous, but the population of the European Union is 550 million people, which means we are talking about one per every [550] Europeans.
yo: O jo bi eni po, sugbon apapo eniyan ni Ajo-igbimo Ile Europe je egberun-lona-egberun ota-din-lewa-din-legbeta awon eniyan, to tumo si wi pe a n soro nipa okan ninu gbogbo [ota-din-lewa-din-legbeta] awon omo ile Europe.

en: Now, in Lebanon, we have one refugee per three Lebanese.
yo: Bayii, ni Lebanon, a ni atipo kan ninu omo orile ede Lebanon meta.

en: And Lebanon?
yo: Orile-ede Lebanon nko?

en: Struggling, of course, but it's managing.
yo: O n tiraka, bee ni, sugbon o n gbiyanju.

en: So, the question is: is this something that could have been managed if -- not mentioning the most important thing, which would have been addressing the root causes, but forgetting about root causes for now, looking at the phenomenon as it is -- if Europe were able to come together in solidarity to create an adequate reception capacity of entry points?
yo: Nitori naa, ibeere naa ni wi pe: nnkan yii ni won o ba ti samojuto re to ba se wi pe -- laimenu ba nnkan to se pataki julo, ti o ba ti yanju okunfa ipile re, sugbon ka gbagbe nipa okunfa ipile re bayi, bi a se n wo nnkan naa bo se ri yii -- ti ile Europe ba le parapo ni isokan lati pese aye igbalejo to peye ni awon ona abawole nko?

en: But for that, the countries at entry points need to be massively supported, and then screening the people with security checks and all the other mechanisms, distributing those that are coming into all European countries, according to the possibilities of each country.
yo: Sugbo fun iyen, awon orile-ede to wa ni awon ona abawole nilo iralowo to po, ati sise ayewo fun awon eniyan naa pelu ayewo ajemo-aabo ati gbogbo awon eto miran, pinpin awon ti won n wo gbogbo orile-ede Europe, gege bi ase e se orile-ede kookan.

en: I mean, if you look at the relocation program that was approved by the Commission, always too little too late, or by the Council, too little too late --
yo: Mo n so nipa pe, ti e ba wo eto isipopada ti Ajo naa fowosi, o n kere ju o n pe ju ni gbogbo igba, tabi latodo Ajo naa, o n kere ju o n pe ju.

en: BG: It's already breaking down.
yo: BG: O ti n denukole.

en: AG: My country is supposed to receive four thousand.
yo: AG: o ye ki orile-ede mi gba egberun merin.

en: Four thousand in Portugal means nothing.
yo: Egberun merin ni orile-ede Portugal o tumo si nnkankan.

en: So this is perfectly manageable if it is managed, but in the present circumstances, the pressure is at the point of entry, and then, as people move in this chaotic way through the Balkans, then they come to Germany, Sweden, basically, and Austria.
yo: Eyi se e mojuto daadaa ti won ba mojuto, sugbon pelu nnkan to n sele lowo, ona abawole ni isoro wa, leyin naa, bi awon eniyan se n rin lona idarudapo si Balkan, ti won si wa si orile-ede Germany, Sweden, ni pataki julo, ati Austria.

en: They are the three countries that are, in the end, receiving the refugees.
yo: Awon ni orile-ede meta ti, nigbeyin, won n gba awon atipo naa.

en: The rest of Europe is looking without doing much.
yo: Awon ara ile Europe toku n wo laise nnkankan.

en: BG: Let me try to bring up three questions, playing a bit devil's advocate.
yo: BG: e je ki n bere ibeere meta, ki n se ise alatako.

en: I'll try to ask them, make them blunt.
yo: Maa gbiyanju lati bere won, lati so oju abe niko.

en: But I think the questions are very present in the minds of many people in Europe right now, the first, of course, is about numbers.
yo: Sugbon mo ro wi pe awon ibeere naa wa ni okan opolopo awon eniyan nile Europe lowolowo bayii, akoko, bee ni, nipa iye won.

en: You say 550 million versus one million is not much, but realistically, how many people can Europe take?
yo: E ni ota-din-lewa-din-legbeta koju egberun-lona-egberun kan ti poju, sugbon loooto, eniyan meloo ni ile Europe le gba?

en: AG: Well, that is a question that has no answer, because refugees have the right to be protected.
yo: AG: O dara, ibeere ti o ni idahun niyen, nitori awon atipo ni eto si idaaabobo.

en: "And there is such a thing as international law, so there is no way you can say, ""I take 10,000 and that's finished."
yo: "Nnkan to jo bi ofin ile okere wa, nitori naa ko si ona ti e le fi so wi pe, ""Mo mu egberun mewa iyen si ti tan."

en: """ I remind you of one thing: in Turkey, at the beginning of the crisis, I remember one minister saying, ""Turkey will be able to receive up to 100,000 people."
yo: """ Mo ran-an yin leti nnkankan: ni orile-ede Turkey, ni ibere rogbodiyan naa, mo ranti alakoso kan to n so wi pe, ""orile-ede Turkey maa le gba to egberun lona ogorun eniyan."

en: """ Turkey has now two million three-hundred thousand or something of the sort, if you count all refugees."
yo: """ Orile-ede Turkey ti ni egberun-lona-egberun meta ati egberun lona orin-din-nirinwo tabi nnkan to jo bee, ti e ba ka gbogbo awon atipo naa."

en: So I don't think it's fair to say how many we can take.
yo: Tori naa mi o ro wi pe o bojumu lati so wi pe meloo ni a le gba.

en: What it is fair to say is: how we can we organize ourselves to assume our international responsibilities?
yo: Nnkan to bojumu lati so ni wi pe: bawo la sele seto arawa lati gba ojuse ile-okere wa?

en: And Europe has not been able to do so, because basically, Europe is divided because there is no solidarity in the European project.
yo: Ile Europe ko tii ri iyen se, nitori ni pataki, ile Europe ti pin nitori ko si isokan ninu ise-akase ile Europe.

en: And it's not only about refugees; there are many other areas.
yo: Ki i se nipa awon atipo nikan; awon aye miran tun wa.

en: And let's be honest, this is the moment in which we need more Europe instead of less Europe.
yo: E je ka so ododo, asiko naa re e to se wi pe a nilo opo Europe yato si die Europe.

en: But as the public less and less believes in European institutions, it is also each time more difficult to convince the public that we need more Europe to solve these problems.
yo: Sugbon bi awon ara ilu se n ni igbagbo to kere ninu awon ile-ise ile Europe, ni asiko kookan yii naa lo maa n nira lati yi awon ara-ilu lokan pada pe a nilo opo ile-europe lati yanju awon isoro wonyii.

en: BG: We seem to be at the point where the numbers turn into political shifts, particularly domestically.
yo: BG: O jo bi eni wi pe a ti de ibi ti nomba naa ti yi pada di ayipada oselu, paapaa julo labele.

en: We saw it again this weekend in France, but we have seen it over and over in many countries: in Poland and in Denmark and in Switzerland and elsewhere, where the mood changes radically because of the numbers, although they are not very significant in absolute numbers.
yo: A tun ri i lopin ose yii lorile-ede France, sugbon a ti ri i laimoye igba ni opolopo awon orile-ede: ni Poland ati ni Denmark ati ni Switzerland ati ibomiran, nibi ti imulara ti yipada nitori nomba, bo tile je wi pe won o fi bee se pataki ninu gbogbo onka.

en: The Prime Minister of --
yo: Olori igbimo ijoba ti --

en: AG: But, if I may, on these: I mean, what does a European see at home in a village where there are no migrants?
yo: AG: sugbon, ti mo ba le, lori awon wonyi: mo n so nipa pe, kini omo ile Europe n ri nile ni abule nibi ti ko si awon asikiri?

en: What a European sees is, on television, every single day, a few months ago, opening the news every single day, a crowd coming, uncontrolled, moving from border to border, and the images on television were of hundreds or thousands of people moving.
yo: Nnkan ti omo ile Europe n ri ni, lori ero amohun-maworan, lojoojumo, ni osu die seyin, sisi iroyin ni ojo kookan, awon ero to n bo, lai ni idari, ti won n lo lati ibode si ibode, awon aworan lori ero amohun-maworan je ti awon egberun lona ogorun awon eniyan ti won n lo.

en: And the idea is that nobody is taking care of it -- this is happening without any kind of management.
yo: Ero wa ni wi pe ko si eni to n se amojuto re -- eyi n sele laisi amojuto kankan.

en: "And so their idea was, ""They are coming to my village."
yo: "Nitori naa ero won ni wi pe, ""Won n bo wa si abule mi."

en: """ So there was this completely false idea that Europe was being invaded and our way of life is going to change, and everything will -- And the problem is that if this had been properly managed, if people had been properly received, welcomed, sheltered at point of entry, screened at point of entry, and the moved by plane to different European countries, this would not have scared people."
yo: """ Ero iro patapata yii wa wi pe won n kogun ja ile Europe ati wi pe asa wa maa yi pada, gbogbo nnkan naa lo maa ri bee -- isoro naa ni wi pe ti won ba ti mojuto o daadaa ni, ti won ba gba alejo awon eniyan bo se to ni, ti won gba won, ti won fun won lorule ni enu abawole, ti won se ayewo won ni enu abawole, ti won si fi oko ofuurufu gbe won lo si orisirisi orile-ede ile Europe, eyi o ba ti ma deruba awon eniyan."

en: But, unfortunately, we have a lot of people scared, just because Europe was not able to do the job properly.
yo: Sugbon, o seni laanu, a deruba opolopo awon eniyan, nitori ile Europe o ni anfaani lati sise naa bo se ye.

en: BG: But there are villages in Germany with 300 inhabitants and 1,000 refugees.
yo: BG: sugbon awon abule kan wa ni orile-ede Germany pelu orin-din-nirinwo awon olugbe ati egberun kan awon ogunlende.

en: So, what's your position?
yo: Nitori naa, kini ipo yin?

en: How do you imagine these people reacting?
yo: Bawo le se ro wi pe awon eniyan yii se n huwa?

en: AG: If there would be a proper management of the situation and the proper distribution of people all over Europe, you would always have the percentage that I mentioned: one per each 2,000.
yo: AG: Ti amojuto to bojumu ba wa fun isele naa ati pinpin awon eniyan kaakiri ile Europe lona to bojumu, e o maa ni ida ti mo menuba ni gbogbo igba: eyokan ninu egberun meji.

en: It is because things are not properly managed that in the end we have situations that are totally impossible to live with, and of course if you have a village -- in Lebanon, there are many villages that have more Syrians than Lebanese; Lebanon has been living with that.
yo: Nitori pe won o samojuto nnkan lona to ye nigbeyin lafi ni isele ti ko se e se lati gbe pelu rara, bee si ni ti e ba ni abule kan -- ni orile-ede Lebanon, opolopo awon abule lo wa ti won ni opo awon omo orile-ede Syria ju omo orile-ede Lebanon lo; orile-ede Lebanon ti n gbe pelu iyen.

en: I'm not asking for the same to happen in Europe, for all European villages to have more refugees than inhabitants.
yo: Mi o so wi pe ki iru re sele ni ile Europe, fun gbogbo awon abule nile Europe lati ni atipo ju awon olugbe lo.

en: What I am asking is for Europe to do the job properly, and to be able to organize itself to receive people as other countries in the world were forced to do in the past.
yo: Nnkan ti mo n bere ni ki ile Europe se ise naa bo se to, lati le se atunto ara re lati gba awon eniyan gege bi won se fipa mu awon orile-ede miran lagbaye lati se e seyin.

en: BG: So, if you look at the global situation not only at Europe --
yo: BG: nitori naa, ti e ba wo isele naa lagbaye ti kii se ile Europe nikan --

en: BG: Yes!
yo: BG: bee ni!

en: BG: If you look at the global situation, so, not only at Europe, I know you can make a long list of countries that are not really stepping up, but I'm more interested in the other part -- is there somebody who's doing the right thing?
yo: BG: Ti e ba wo isele naa lagbaye, nitori, kii se ni ile Europe nikan, mo mo wi pe e le se akojopo awon orile-ede ti won o gbera so, sugbon mo nife ninu apa keji -- nje enikan wa to n se nnkan to ye?

en: AG: Well, 86 percent of the refugees in the world are in the developing world.
yo: AG: O dara, ida 86 awon ogunlende to wa lagbaye ni won wa ni awon orile-ede to n dagba soke.

en: And if you look at countries like Ethiopia -- Ethiopia has received more than 600,000 refugees.
yo: Bi e ba wo awon orile-ede bi Ethiopia -- Ethiopia ti gba awon ogunlende to ju egberun-lona 600 lo.

en: All the borders in Ethiopia are open.
yo: Gbogbo ibode Ethiopia lo wa ni sisi sile.

en: "And they have, as a policy, they call the ""people to people"" policy that every refugee should be received."
yo: "Won si ni, gege bi ipinnu, ti won n pe ni ipinnu ""eniyan si eniyan"" wi pe gbogbo ogunlende gbodo di gbigba wole."

en: And they have South Sudanese, they have Sudanese, they have Somalis.
yo: Won si ni awon omo orile-ede South Sudan, won ni awon omo orile-ede Sudan, won ni awon omo orile-ede Somalia.

en: They have all the neighbors.
yo: Won ni gbogbo awon alajogbe.

en: They have Eritreans.
yo: Won ni awon omo orile-ede Eritrea.

en: And, in general, African countries are extremely welcoming of refugees coming, and I would say that in the Middle East and in Asia, we have seen a tendency for borders to be open.
yo: Lapapo, awon orile-ede Adulawo n gba awon atipo to n bo gidi gan-an, ma a si so wi pe ni Aarin Gbungbun Ila Oorun ati ni Asia, a ti ri ase e se fun ibode lati di sisi sile.

en: Now we see some problems with the Syrian situation, as the Syrian situation evolved into also a major security crisis, but the truth is that for a large period, all borders in the Middle East were open.
yo: Bayii a ri awon isoro kookan pelu isele orile-ede Syria, bi isele orile-ede Syria se yipada di rogbodiyan eto-aabo nla, sugbon ooto ibe ni wi pe fun igba pipe, gbogbo ibode to wa ni Aarin Gbungbun Ila Oorun wa lo wa ni sisi sile.

en: The truth is that for Afghans, the borders of Pakistan and Iran were open for, at the time, six million Afghans that came.
yo: Otito ibe ni wi pe fun awon omo orile-ede Afghan, awon ibode Pakistan ati Iran wa ni sisi fun, ni gbogbo igba, aadota-oke mefa omo orile-ede Afghan to ba wa.

en: So I would say that even today, the trend in the developing world has been for borders to be open.
yo: Ma a so wi pe koda lonii, isesi ni awon orile-ede to n dagbasoke ni lati je ki awon ibode wa ni sisi sile.

en: The trend in the developed world is for these questions to become more and more complex, especially when there is, in the public opinion, a mixture of discussions between refugee protections on one side and security questions -- in my opinion, misinterpreted -- on the other side.
yo: Ona tuntun naa ni awon orile-ede to ti dagbasoke ni fun awon ibeere wonyi lati tubo diju sii, paapaa julo nigba ti, ni ipinnu awon ara ilu, adapo ijiroro laaarin aabo ogunlende ni apa kan ati awon ibeere aabo -- ni temi, asitu imo -- ni apa keji.

en: BG: We'll come back to that too, but you mentioned the cutting of funding and the vouchers from the World Food Programme.
yo: BG: A maa pada si iyen naa, sugbon e menuba gige igbowo ati iwe-igba-nnkan-ofe lati Eto Ounje Agbaye.

en: That reflects the general underfunding of the organizations working on these issues.
yo: Iyen se agbejade airigbowo apapo awon ajo to n sise lori awon oro wonyi.

en: Now that the world seems to have woken up, are you getting more funding and more support, or it's still the same?
yo: Bayii todabi wi pegbogbo agbaye ti ji, se n n ri igbowo ati atileyin si i, abi bakan naa ni?

en: AG: We are getting more support.
yo: AG: a n ri altileyin si.

en: I would say that we are coming close to the levels of last year.
yo: Maa so wi pe a n sun mo ipele odun to koja.

en: We were much worse during the summer.
yo: O buru jai lasiko ooru.

en: But that is clearly insufficient to address the needs of the people and address the needs of the countries that are supporting the people.
yo: Sugbon iyen o to lati yanju ohun-elo awon eniyan naa ati lati yanju ohun-elo awon orile-ede ti won n se atileyin fun awon eniyan naa.

en: And here we have a basic review of the criteria, the objectives, the priorities of development cooperation that is required.
yo: Nibi a ni atunyewo ipile fun osuwon, erongba, ati pataki idagbasoke ifowosowopo ti a fe.

en: For instance, Lebanon and Jordan are middle-income countries.
yo: Fun apeere, orile-ede Lebanon ati Jordan je awon orile-ede ti ipawowole won wa lagbede meji.

en: Because they are middle-income countries, they cannot receive soft loans or grants from the World Bank.
yo: Nitori won je orile-ede ti ipawowole won wa lagbede meji, won o le gba eyawo tabi owo-iranwo lati ile-ifowopamo agbaye.

en: Now, today this doesn't make any sense, because they are providing a global public good.
yo: Ni bayii, loni eyi o mopolo dani, nitori won n se ipese daadaa gbogbogbo agbaye.

en: They have millions of refugees there, and to be honest, they are pillars of stability in the region, with all the difficulties they face, and the first line of defense of our collective security.
yo: Won ni egberun-lona-egberun awon ogunlende nibe, ka so ododo, awon ni opo iduro sinsin ni ekun naa, pelu gbogbo idojuko ti won n koju, ati alewaju atileyin eto-aabo ajoni wa.

en: So it doesn't make sense that these countries are not a first priority in development cooperation policies.
yo: Tori naa ko mopolo dani wi pe awon orile-ede wonyi ko ni pataki akoko ninu awon ipinnu ifowosowopo idagbasoke.

en: And they are not.
yo: Awon ko.

en: And not only do the refugees live in very dramatic circumstances inside those countries, but the local communities themselves are suffering, because salaries went down, because there are more unemployed, because prices and rents went up.
yo: Kii se pe awon ogunlende n gbe ni ipo to bani ninuje ninu awon orile-ede wonyi nikan, sugbon awon awujo ibile funra won naa n jiya, nitori owo-osu ti wale, nitori awon ti o nise ti po, nitori owo-nnkan ati owo-ile ti lo soke.

en: And, of course, if you look at today's situation of the indicators in these countries, it is clear that, especially their poor groups of the population, are living worse and worse because of the crisis they are facing.
yo: Bee ni, ti e ba wo isele toni nipa awon atoka ni awon orile-ede wonyi, o han kedere pe, paapaa julo awon egbe won to kusee ninu awon eniyan, n gbe igbeaye to buru jai nitori awon rogbodiyan ti won n koju.

en: BG: Who should be providing this support?
yo: BG: Ta lo ye ko maa pese iranlowo yii?

en: Country by country, international organizations, the European Union?
yo: Orile-ede si orile-ede, ajo ile okeere, Ajo-igbimo Ile Europe?

en: Who should be coming up with this support?
yo: Ta lo ye ko maa mu iranlowo yii wa?

en: AG: We need to join all efforts.
yo: AG: A nilo lati so gbogbo igbiyanju papo.

en: It's clear that bilateral cooperation is essential.
yo: O han gbangba wi pe ifowosowopo asemeji se pakaki.

en: It's clear that multilateral cooperation is essential.
yo: O han gbangba wi pe ifowosowopo olopo se pakaki.

en: It's clear that international financial institutions should have flexibility in order to be able to invest more massively in support to these countries.
yo: O han gbangba wi pe awon ile-ise owo ile-okeere gbodo ni ase e yipada lati le dokowo to po ni iranlowo fun awon orile-ede wonyi.

en: We need to combine all the instruments and to understand that today, in protracted situations, at a certain moment, that it doesn't make sense anymore to make a distinction between humanitarian aid and development aid or development processes.
yo: A nilo lati ko gbogbo irinse naa jo ka si ni oye pe lonii, ni isele ti yoo pe, ni asiko kan, pe ko mopolo dani mo lati se iyato laaarin iranwo eleyinju-aanu ati iranwo idagbasoke tabi eto-igbese idagbasoke.

en: Because you are talking about children in school, you are talking about health, you are talking about infrastructure that is overcrowded.
yo: Nitori e n soro nipa awon omo ni ile-eko, e n soro nipa ilera, e n soro nipa ohun-amayederun to ti kun akun ya.

en: You are talking about things that require a long-term perspective, a development perspective and not only an emergency humanitarian aid perspective.
yo: E n soro nipa awon nnkan to gba oju-iwoye igba pipe, oju-iwoye idagbasoke ki i se oju-iwoye iranwo eyinju-aanu pajawiri nikan.

en: BG: I would like your comment on something that was in newspapers this morning.
yo: BG: mo fe se ariwisi yin lori nnkankan to wa ninu iwe iroyin ni owuro yii.

en: It is a statement made by the current front-runner for the Republican nomination for US President, Donald Trump.
yo: Oro kan ti eni to n lewaju lowolowo fun ifakale Republican fun Aare ile US, Donald Trump so.

en: Yesterday, he said this.
yo: lanaa, o so eyi.

en: No, listen to this.
yo: Rara, e teti si eyi.

en: It's interesting.
yo: O pani lerin.

en: "I quote: ""I am calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the US, until our country's representatives can figure out what's going on."
yo: "Mo yoo lo ""Mo n pe fun igbetipa lapapo ati patapata awon musulumi ti won n wo orile-ede US, titi ti awon asoju orile-ede wa yoo fi sawari nnkan to n sele."

en: """ How do you react to that?"
yo: """ Kini esi ti e o fi si iyen?"

en: AG: Well, it's not only Donald Trump.
yo: AG: O daa, kii se Donald Trump nikan.

en: We have seen several people around the world with political responsibility saying, for instance, that Muslims refugees should not be received.
yo: A ti ri opolopo awon eniyan kaakiri agbaye pelu ojuse oselu ti won n so, fun apeere, pe awon ogunlende Musulumi o gbodo di gbigba wole.

en: And the reason why they say this is because they think that by doing or saying this, they are protecting the security of their countries.
yo: Idi ti won fi n so eyi ni wi pe won ro wi pe pelu sise tabi siso eyi, awon n daaabo bo eto-aabo orile-ede won ni.

en: Now, I've been in government.
yo: Ni bayii, mo ti wa ninu ijoba ri.

en: I am very keen on the need for governments to protect the security of their countries and their people.
yo: Mo tera mo pataki fun ijoba lati daaabo bo eto-aabo orile-ede won ati awon eniyan won.

en: "But if you say, like that, in the US or in any European country, ""We are going to close our doors to Muslim refugees,"" what you are saying is the best possible help for the propaganda of terrorist organizations."
yo: "Sugbon ti e ba so wi pe, bi iyen, ni orile-ede US tabi ni orile-ede ile Europe Kankan, ""a maa ti ilekun wa mo awon musulumi ogunlende,"" nnkan ti e n so ni iranlowo ase e se to dara ju fun aheso ijo awon agbesumomi."

en: Because what you are saying --
yo: Tori nnkan ti e n so --

en: What you are saying will be heard by all the Muslims in your own country, and it will pave the way for the recruitment and the mechanisms that, through technology, Daesh and al-Nusra, al-Qaeda, and all those other groups are today penetrating in our societies.
yo: Nnkan ti e n so maa di gbigbo fun gbogbo awon musulumi ni orile-ede tiyin, yoo si sina fun igbaniwole ati awon eto ti, nipase imo-ero, Daesh ati al-Ausra, al-Qaeda, ati gbogbo awon egbe miiran wonyen ti won n wo awujo wa loni.

en: "And it's just telling them, ""You are right, we are against you."
yo: "O kan n so fun won pe, ""ooto le so, a n tako yin."

en: """ So obviously, this is creating in societies that are all multiethnic, multi-religious, multicultural, this is creating a situation in which, really, it is much easier for the propaganda of these terrorist organizations to be effective in recruiting people for terror acts within the countries where these kinds of sentences are expressed."
yo: """ O foju han, eyi n se idasile ni awon awujo ti won je oniran-pupo, elesin-pupo, alasa-pupo, eyi n seidasile awon isele to se wi pe, loooto, o maa rorun fun aheso awon ijo agbesumomi wonyi lati fesemule ninu igbaniwole awon eniyan fun iwa igbesunmomi laaarin orile-ede nibi ti won ba ti n so iru awon gbolohun wonyi."

en: BG: Have the recent attacks in Paris and the reactions to them made your job more difficult?
yo: BG: Nje awon ikolu to sele ni Paris laipe yii ati idahun si won ti je ki ise yin o nira si i?

en: AG: Undoubtedly.
yo: AG: laisi aniani.

en: BG: In what sense?
yo: BG: lona wo?

en: AG: In the sense that, I mean, for many people the first reaction in relation to these kinds of terrorist attacks is: close all borders -- not understanding that the terrorist problem in Europe is largely homegrown.
yo: AG: lona to je wi pe, mo n so nipa pe, fun opolopo awon eniyan idahun akoko ni ibatan si iru awon ikolu igbesumomi wonyi ni: e ti gbogbo enu ibode - laini imo wi pe isoro awon agbesumomi ni ile Europe je ti abele lopolopo igba.

en: We have thousands and thousands of European fighters in Syria and in Iraq, so this is not something that you solve by just not allowing Syrians to come in.
yo: A ni egberun ati egberun awon omo-ogun ile Europe ni orile-ede Syria ati ni orile-ede Iraq, nitori naa eyi kii se nnkan ti e le yanju pelu aigba awon omo orile-ede Syria laye lati wole.

en: And I must say, I am convinced that the passport that appeared, I believe, was put by the person who has blown -- himself up, yeah.
yo: Mo si gbodo so wi pe, mo ni idaniloju pe iwe-irina to han, mo nigbagbo, eni to fi ado oloro para re naa lo fi sibe, bee ni --.

en: AG: [I believe] it was on purpose, because part of the strategies of Daesh is against refugees, because they see refugees as people that should be with the caliphate and are fleeing to the crusaders.
yo: AG: [Mo gbagbo] won moomo se e ni, nitori lara ogbon atinudaa Daesh tako ogunlende, nitori won ri awon ogunlende gege bi eniyan to ye ko wa pelu awon musulumi ti won wa n sa lo ba awon oniwasuu.

en: And I think that is part of Daesh's strategy to make Europe react, closing its doors to Muslim refugees and having an hostility towards Muslims inside Europe, exactly to facilitate Daesh's work.
yo: Mo si ro wi pe lara ogbon atinuda Daesh lati je ki ile Europe o fesi, titi ilekun mo awon musulumi ogunlende ati sise atako si awon musulumi to wa ninu Europe, bee gele lati se atileyin fun ise Daesh.

en: And my deep belief is that it was not the refugee movement that triggered terrorism.
yo: Igbagbo mi to jinle ni wi pe kii se isikiri awon ogunlende ni o se okunfa igbesumomi.

en: I think, as I said, essentially terrorism in Europe is today a homegrown movement in relation to the global situation that we are facing, and what we need is exactly to prove these groups wrong, by welcoming and integrating effectively those that are coming from that part of the world.
yo: Mo lero, gege bi mo se so, ni pataki julo igbesumomi ni ile Europe lonii je ipolongo labele ni ibatan pelu isele agbaye ti a n koju, nnkan ti a si nilo ni lati dojuti awon egbe yii, pelu gbigba won wole ka si da awon ti won n bo lati apa orile-ede yen po daadaa.

en: And another thing that I believe is that to a large extent, what we are today paying for in Europe is the failures of integration models that didn't work in the '60s, in the '70s, in the '80s, in relation to big migration flows that took place at that time and generated what is today in many of the people, for instance, of the second generation of communities, a situation of feeling marginalized, having no jobs, having improper education, living in some of the neighborhoods that are not adequately provided by public infrastructure.
yo: Nnkan miiran ti mo gbagbo wi pe lona to po, nnkan ti a n jiya re nile Europe loni ni ikuna lati se afibo awose ti ko sise ni awon 60s, ni 70s, ni 80s, ni ibatan pelu iyipada asikiri nla to sele ni igba yen to di nnkan to da lonii ninu opo eniyan, fun apeere, ninu awon iran keji awujo, nini imolara ipati, lainise, laini eto eko to ye koro, gbigbe ni awon adugbo ti won o pese ohun amayederun gbogbogbo fun.

en: And this kind of uneasiness, sometimes even anger, that exists in this second generation is largely due to the failure of integration policies, to the failure of what should have been a much stronger investment in creating the conditions for people to live together and respect each other.
yo: Iru inira yii, nigba miran ibinu, to maa n wa ni iran keji yii maa n je nitori ikuna lati se afibo ipinnu, si ikuna nnkan to ye ko je idokowo to lagbara ninu ipese aye fun awon eniyan lati gbe papo ki won si bowo fun ara won.

en: For me it is clear.
yo: Ni temi o han kedere.

en: For me it is clear that all societies will be multiethnic, multicultural, multi-religious in the future.
yo: Ni temi o han kedere pe gbogbo awujo yoo di, oniran-pupo, alasa-pupo, elesinpupo lojo iwaju.

en: To try to avoid it is, in my opinion, impossible.
yo: Lati gbiyanju lati dena re je, ni iwoye temi, ko se e se.

en: And for me it's a good thing that they will be like that, but I also recognize that, for that to work properly, you need a huge investment in the social cohesion of your own societies.
yo: Fun emi nnkan to dara ni pe ki won rii bayen, sugbon mom o wi pe, fun iyen lati sise daadaha, a nilo idokowo nla ninu agboye awujo ti awujo tiyin.

en: And Europe, to a large extent, failed in that investment in the past few decades.
yo: ile Europe, ni opo igba, kuna ninu idokowo yen ni bii ewa odun die seyin.

en: BG: Question: You are stepping down from your job at the end of the year, after 10 years.
yo: BG: e o fi ise yin sile nigbeyin odun yii, leyin odun mewa.

en: If you look back at 2005, when you entered that office for the first time, what do you see?
yo: Bi e ba weyin wo odun 2005, nigba ti e wo ibi-ise yen fun igba akoko, ki le ri?

en: AG: Well, look: In 2005, we were helping one million people go back home in safety and dignity, because conflicts had ended.
yo: AG: o daa, E wo o: Ni odun 2005, a n pese iranlowo fun egberun-lona-egberun kan awon eniyan lati pada sile laisewu ati ninu aponle, nitori ija ti pari.

en: Last year, we helped 124,000.
yo: Lodun to koja, a pese iranlowo fun egberun-lona 124.

en: In 2005, we had about 38 million people displaced by conflict in the world.
yo: Ni odun 2005, a ni bii aadota-oke 38 awon eniyan ti won di alainile nipase rogbodiyan lagbaaye.

en: Today, we have more than 60 million.
yo: Lonii, a ni ju egberun-lona-egberun 60 lo.

en: At that time, we had had, recently, some conflicts that were solved.
yo: Ni igba yen, a ti ni, awon rogbodiyan kan ti won yanju.

en: Now, we see a multiplication of new conflicts and the old conflicts never died: Afghanistan, Somalia, Democratic Republic of Congo.
yo: Ni bayii, a n ri aropo awon rogbodiyan tuntun awon rogbodiyan atijo o si kin ku: orile-ede Afghanistan, Somalia, Ile-olominira ti Congo.

en: It is clear that the world today is much more dangerous than it was.
yo: O foju han pe orile-ede agbaye loni tun lewu lopolopo ju bo se wa tele lo.

en: It is clear that the capacity of the international community to prevent conflicts and to timely solve them, is, unfortunately, much worse than what it was 10 years ago.
yo: O han kedere pe ikapa awujo ile-okeere lati dena rogbodiyan ki won si yanju won lasiko, je, o seni laaanu, nnkan to buru ju bo se wa ni odun 10 seyin lo.

en: There are no clear power relations in the world, no global governance mechanisms that work, which means that we live in a situation where impunity and unpredictability tend to prevail, and that means that more and more people suffer, namely those that are displaced by conflicts.
yo: Ko si ajosepo agbara to han ni agbaye, ko si awon eto idari to n sise, to tumo si wi pe a n gbe ni aye to se wi pe iwa-ibaje ati aileso asotele n rese wale, iyen si tumo si wi pe opo awon eniyan n jiya, kadaruko awon ti won di alainile latara rogbodiyan.

en: BG: It's a tradition in American politics that when a President leaves the Oval Office for the last time, he leaves a handwritten note on the desk for his successor that walks in a couple of hours later.
yo: BG: asa lo je ninu oselu ile America pe nigba ti Aare kan ba fi Ibi-ise Oval sile fun igba ikeyin, o maa fi iwe afowoko sile lori tabili fun adele re ti yoo wole ni wakati bi meloo kan.

en: If you had to write such a note to your successor, Filippo Grandi, what would you write?
yo: Bi e ba ni lati ko iru iwe yen si adele yin, Filippo Grandi, ki le maa ko?

en: AG: Well, I don't think I would write any message.
yo: AG: mi o ro wi pe mo ma ko iwe kankan.

en: You know, one of the terrible things when one leaves an office is to try to become the backseat driver, always telling the new one what to do.
yo: E mo, okan ninu awon nnkan to buru ju nigba ti eniyan ba fi ipo sile ni igbiyanju lati di ero to n dari awako, to maa n so nnkan ti awako tuntun naa yoo se fun-un.

en: So that, I will not do.
yo: iyen, emi o ni se e.

en: "If I had to say something to him, it would be, ""Be yourself, and do your best."
yo: "Bi mo ba ni lati so nnkankan fun-un, yoo je, ""Jewo araa re, ki o si se iwon to le se."

en: BG: Commissioner, thank you for the job you do.
yo: BG: komisona, e seun fun ise ti e se.

en: Thank you for coming to TED.
yo: E seun ti e wa si TED.

en: The beautiful future of solar power
yo: Ojo-iwaju agbara itansan-oorun to rewa.

en: Last summer, I was hiking through the Austrian mountains.
yo: Lasiko oru to koja, mo n rin irinajo afe kiri awon oke orile-ede Austria.

en: And there, on top, I saw this beautiful, stone, remote hut, and it had solar panels on it.
yo: "Nibe, lori oke tente, mo ri ahere to rewa, olokuta, to dawa, t""o si ni patako-igun-merin agbara itansan oorun lori re."

en: And every time I see solar panels, I get very enthusiastic.
yo: Gbogbo igba ti mo ba ri patako-igun-merin agbara itansan-oorun, inu mi maa n dun ni.

en: It's this technology that takes sunlight, which is free and available, and turns that into electricity.
yo: "Imo-ero yii ni o maa n gba oorun, to je ofe to si wa, t""o si maa n yi iyen pada di ina manamana."

en: So this hut, in the middle of nowhere, on a beautiful location, was self-sufficient.
yo: Ahere yii, to wa laaarin ibikan, ni aye to rewa, to ti to tan.

en: But why do solar panels always have to be so ugly?
yo: Sugbon ki lo de ti patako-igun-merin agbara itansan-oorun se gbodo se maa burewa ni gbogbo igba?

en: My name is Marjan Van Aubel and I'm a solar designer.
yo: Oruko mi ni Marjan Van Aubel mo de oluselojo agbara itansan oorun.

en: I work in the triangle of design, sustainability and technology.
yo: Mo n sise ninu iselojo onigun meta, alalope ati imo-ero.

en: I strive for extreme efficiency, meaning that I develop materials that expand in size or work with solar cells that use the properties of colors to generate electricity.
yo: Mo n tiraka fun isedede to yato, to tumo si wi pe mo n pese awon ohun-elo to n fe ni iwon tabi to n sise pelu padi itansan-oorun to maa n lo awomo awo lati pese ina manamana.

en: My work is in museums all over the world, such as MoMA.
yo: Ise ni wa ni awon ile-ona kaakiri agbaye, bii MoMA.

en: And, I mean, it all went quite well, but it always felt that something was missing.
yo: Mo n so nipa pe, gbogbo re lo lo daadaa, sugbon o maa n jo bi eni wi pe nnkankan ti sonu.

en: "And it was, until I read the book called the ""Solar Revolution,"" where it says that within one hour we receive enough sunlight to provide the world with enough electricity for an entire year."
yo: "Ayafi igba ti mo ka iwe ti won n pe ni ""Iyipoda si Itansan-oorun,"" nibi ti o ti so wi pe laaarin wakati kan a n gba agbara oorun ti o to lati pese ina manamana to se deede fun gbogbo agbaye fun odidin odun kan."

en: One hour.
yo: Wakati kan.

en: And since then, I realized I just want to focus on solar.
yo: Lati igba naa, mo mo wi pe mo ko fe gbajumo agbara itansan oorun ni.

en: Scientists all over the world have been focusing on making solar panels more efficient and cheaper.
yo: "Awon onimo-ijinle kaakiri agbaye ti n gbajumo sise patako-igun-merin agbara itansan oorun to peye t""o si roju."

en: So the price of solar has dropped enormously.
yo: Iye-owo agbara itansan oorun ti wale gan-an.

en: And this is because China started producing them on a large scale.
yo: Idi ni wi pe orile-ede China ti bere sini pese won lopo yanturu.

en: And also their efficiency has increased a lot.
yo: Bakan naa agbara won ti lekun gidi gan-an.

en: They now even have an efficiency of 44.5 percent.
yo: Won ti ni ida 44 atabo agbara bayii.

en: But if you think about the image of solar cells, it's kind of stayed the same for the last 60 years.
yo: Sugbon ti e ba ronu nipa aworan awon padi agbara itansan-oorun, o da bi eni pe bakan naa lo se wa lati bi 60 odun.

en: It's still this technology just stacked onto something.
yo: Imo ero yii ko gbara le nnkan.

en: And solar cells need to be much better integrated into our environment.
yo: Padi agbara itansan-oorun nilo lati di gbigbe wonu awujo wa daadaa sii.

en: Climate change is the biggest problem of our time.
yo: Ayipada oju-ojo ni isoro to tobi ju lasiko tiwa.

en: And we can't rely on the others -- the government, the engineers -- to make positive changes.
yo: A o de le gbara le awon toku -- ijoba, awon onimo-ero -- lati pese ayipada gidi.

en: We all can contribute towards change.
yo: Gbogbo wa la le lowo si ayipada.

en: Like I said, I'm a designer and I would like to change things through design.
yo: Gege bi mo se so, mo je oluselojo yoo si wunmi lati mu ayipada ba nnkan nipase iselojo.

en: Let me give you some examples of my work.
yo: E je ki n fun yin ni apeere die nipa ise mi.

en: I'm collaborating with Swarovski, the crystal company.
yo: Mo n se ajosepo pelu Swarovski, ile-ise okuta-mimo-gaara.

en: And if you cut crystals in a certain way, you are able to bend and direct the light onto a certain place.
yo: Bi e ba ge okuta-mimo-gaara ni awon ona kan, yoo se e te lati dari ina naa si awon aye kan.

en: So I use these crystals to focus the light onto a solar panel, making them more efficient, but using aesthetics.
yo: Tori naa mo ma n lo awon okuta-mimo-gaara wonyi lati dari ina si patako-igun-merin agbara itansan-oorun, ki won le gba agbara sii, sugbon pelu fifi ti ewa se.

en: So you take the solar crystal with you in the light, there's a battery in the solar cell, you put it in a docking station and you are able to power these chandeliers.
yo: E maa mu okuta-mimo-gaara agbagbara itansan-oorun pelu yin ninu imole, okuta-agbagbara-ina-sara kan wa ninu padi agbara itansan oorun, e o fi sinu afi-agbara-sori-ero, e maa le fi gbe agbara sori awon ina-alagbeko-soke-aja wonyi.

en: So you're literally bringing the light indoors.
yo: E n mu ina wonu ile niyen.

en: I got completely hooked on solar when I came across this technology called dye-sensitized solar cells, colored solar cells, and they are based on photosynthesis in plants.
yo: Mi o lee se lai ma lo agbara itasan oorun nigba ti mo rina pade imo-ero yii ti won n pe ni padi ero agbara itansan oorun oni fonran tinrin, padi ero agbara itansan oorun alawoojawo, ti won si gbarale itansan-di-okun-fun-nnkan-ogbin.

en: Where the green chlorophyl converts light into sugar for plants, these cells convert light into electricity.
yo: Nibi ti awo-obedo ti eweko ti n so itansan suga fun nnkan ogbin, awon padi wonyi maa n so ina di ina mana-mana.

en: The best thing is, they even work indoors.
yo: Nnkan to dara ju ni wi pe, won tun n sise ninu ile.

en: So different colors have different efficiency, depending on their place on the color spectrum.
yo: Orisirisi awo lo ni agbara lati sise otooto, o ni i se pelu ibi ti won wa lori ibilu awo.

en: So, for example, red is more efficient than blue.
yo: Nitori naa, fun apeere, awo pupa lagbara ju awo aro lo.

en: So if I hear this as a designer: a colored surface, a glass colored surface, color that's mostly just used for esthetics, now gets an extra function and is able to harvest electricity, I think, where can we apply this, then?
yo: Ti mo ba gbo eyi gege bi oluselojo: oju-aye to je alawo, oju-ibi to je awojiji alawo, awo ti won ko n lo fun iselosoo, ti wa ni afikun ise o si le gba agbara ina manamana si ara, mo gbero, nje, nibo ni a ti le samulo eleyii?

en: This is Current Table, where the whole tabletop consists of these colored solar cells.
yo: Tabili Isan-oyi-manamana niyi, nibi ti gbogbo ori tabili ti je apapo awon padi agbara itansan oorun alawo wonyi.

en: There are batteries in the legs where you can charge your phone through USB ports.
yo: Awon okuta-agbagbara-ina-sara wa ni ese re nibi ti e le gbanasori ero ibanisoro yin nipase oju USB.

en: And in my work, it's always very important, the balance between efficiency and aesthetics.
yo: Ninu ise mi, o se pataki pupo, isogboogba laaarin agbara-lati-sise ati iselosoo.

en: So that's why the table is orange, because it is a very stable color for indoors.
yo: Idi niyi ti tabili naa fi je awo olomi osan, nitori o je awo to duro-digbi fun ilo ninu ile.

en: "And this is always the most asked question I get: ""OK, great, but how many phones can I charge from this, then?"
yo: "Eyi si ni ibeere ti mo maa n gba ju: ""O je b""o ti je, sugbon iye ero ibanisoro meloo ni mo le gbagbara-ina-sori re latara eyi, nigba naa?"

en: """ And before I go to this complicated answer of like, ""Well, where is the table, does it have enough light, is it next to a window?"
yo: "Ki n to lo sibi idahun iruniloju bi eyi, ""o dara, tabili naa da, se o ni ina ti o to, so sunmo ferese?"

en: """ The table now has sensors that read the light intensity of the room."
yo: Tabili naa ti ni iye bayii ti o maa n kiyesi ipojojo agbara ina ninu yara naa.

en: So through an app we developed you can literally follow how much light it's getting, and how full the battery is.
yo: Tori naa lati ara ohun-amulo-ori-ero-ayarabiasa kan ti a seda re le mo iye ina ti o n gba, ati bi okuta-agbagbara-ina-sara naa se gbagbara to.

en: I'm actually proud, because yesterday we installed a table at Stichting Doen's offices in Amsterdam and, right at this moment, our Queen Maxima is charging a phone from this table.
yo: Mo ni igberaga, nitori lanaa a se agbelele tabili kan si ibi-ise ti Stichting Deon ni Amsterdam ati, lowolowo bayii, Obabinrin wa Maxima n gbanasori ero-ibanisoro kan latara tabili yii.

en: It's cool.
yo: O rewa.

en: So the more surface you have, the more energy you can harvest.
yo: Bi oju-ibi-igbennkanle ba se po to, ni iye agbara-ina ti e le gbajo.

en: These are Current Windows, where we replaced all windows in a gallery in London, in Soho, with this modern version of stained glass.
yo: Awon ferese Isan-oyi-manamana yii, nibi ti a ti paaro gbogbo ferese nibi isafihan aworan ni London, ni Soho, pelu eya awojiji alabawon igbalode yii.

en: So people from the street could come and charge their phones through the window ledges.
yo: Awon eniyan lati adugbo le wa gbanasori ero- ibanisoro won latara oju to wa lara ferese naa.

en: So I'm giving extra functions to objects.
yo: Mo n se afikun ise si nnkan naa.

en: A window doesn't have to be just a window anymore.
yo: Ferese o ni lati je ferese lasan mo.

en: It can also function as a little power station.
yo: O tun le sise gege bi ile-ise agbara kekere.

en: So, here I am, talking about how much I love solar, but I don't have solar panels on my roof.
yo: Emi re e, ti mo n soro nipa bi mo se feran agbara itansan oorun, sugbon mi o ni patako-igun-merin agbara itansan oorun lori orule mi.

en: I live in the center of Amsterdam, I don't own the house and it's a monument, so it's not possible and not allowed.
yo: Mo n gbe ni aringbungbun Amsterdam, emi ko ni mo ni ile naa aye iranti ni, nitori naa ko se e se ko si si igbalaaye re.

en: So how can you make solar cells more accessible and for everyone, and not only for the people that can afford a sustainable lifestyle?
yo: Bawo la se le je ki gbogbo eniyan ni anfaani si padi agbara itansan oorun, ti ki i se fun awon eniyan ti won nikapa lati igbeaye alaiyipada?

en: We now have the opportunity to integrate solar on the place where we directly need it.
yo: A ti wa ni anfaani lati gbe agbara itansan oorun si aye ti a ti nilo re taara.

en: And there are so many amazing technologies out there.
yo: Awon imo-ero to yanilenu wa nita nibe yen.

en: If I look around now, I see every surface as an opportunity.
yo: Bi mo ba wo yika nisiyii, mo maa n ri gbogbo aye gege bi anfaani.

en: For example, I was driving in the train through the Westland, the area in the Netherlands with all the greenhouses.
yo: Fun apeere, nigba ti mo wa ninu oko oju-irin lona Westland, agbegbe kan ni Netherlands to ni gbogbo ile agbara.

en: There I saw all this glass and thought, what if we integrate those with transparent solar glass?
yo: Nibe ni mo ti ri gbogbo awon awojiji yii ti mo si wa ro o pe, ti a ba se afikun awon wonyi si awojiji agbara itansan oorun to han kedere nko?

en: What if we integrate traditional farming that requires a lot of energy together with high-tech and combine those?
yo: Bi a ba se afikun ise-agbe atijo to gba agbaara to po papo pelu imo-ero to ga kawa pa a po pelu awon yii nko?

en: With this idea in mind, I created Power Plant.
yo: Pelu ero yii lokan mi, mo seda ero amunawa.

en: I had a team of architects and engineers, but let me first explain how it works.
yo: Mo ni iko awon ayaworan-ile ati awon onimo-ero, sugbon e je ki n koko salaye bo se n sise.

en: We use transparent solar glass to power its indoor climate.
yo: A lo awojiji agbaara itansan oorun to han kedere lati tan oju-ojo inu ile re.

en: We use hydroponics that pumps around nutrified water, saving 90 percent of water usage.
yo: A lo eto gbingbin-ohun-ogbin-ninu-omi ti o n fa omi ti a f'okunfun kaakiri, to n se adinku ida 90 omi lilo.

en: By stacking up in layers, you are able to grow more yield per square meter.
yo: Pelu titopo ni ipele-ipele, e le gbin ire-oko to po sori iwo onirinmeji lopo si.

en: Extra light, besides sunlight, coming from these colored LED lights also enhances plant growth.
yo: Afikun ina, yato si imole oorun, to n wa lati awon ina alawo LED wonyi tun se iranwo fun idagbasoke nnkan ogbin.

en: As more and more people will live in big cities, by placing Power Plants on the rooftops you don't have to fly it in from the other side of the world, you are able to grow it on the location itself.
yo: Pelu bose je wi pe opolopo awon eniyan lo maa gbe ni awon ilu nla, pelu gbigbe awon Ero Amunawa sori orule e o nilo lati ko o wole lati odi-keji aye, e le gbin-in si aye naa fun ra re.

en: Well, the big dream is to build these in off-grid places -- where there's no access to water, electricity -- as an independent ecosystem.
yo: O daa, ala nla naa ni lati ko awon wonyi ni awon aye ti won o ni ohun amayederun ijoba -- nibi ti won o ti ni anfaani si omi, ina mana-mana -- gege bi eto ojo-eda olominira.

en: For this year's Design Biennial, I created the first four-meter high model of the power plant, so you could come in and experience how plants grow.
yo: Fun iselojo daadaa odun yii, mo seda awose ero amunawa to ga to mita-merin akoko, ki e le wole wa lati ni iriri bi nnkan ogbin se n hu.

en: So it's a double harvest of sunlight, so both for the solar cells and for the plants.
yo: Ikore itansan-oorun onibeji ni, fun apapo padi agbara itansan-oorun ati fun nnkan ogbin.

en: It's like a future botanical garden, where we celebrate all these modern technologies.
yo: O dabi ogba ajara ojo iwaju, nibi ti ati n sajoyo awon imo-ero igbalode wonyi.

en: "And the biggest compliment I got was, ""But where are the solar panels?"
yo: "Ikini to tobi ju ti mo gba ni, ""Sugbon awon patako-igun-merin ero agbara itansan oorun da?"

en: """ And that's when I think design really works, when it becomes invisible and you don't notice it."
yo: """ Nigba naa ni mo ro wi pe iselojo naa sise gidi gan-an, to ba di afeeri ti e o si sakiyesi re."

en: I believe in solar democracy: solar energy for everyone, everywhere.
yo: Mo nigbagbo ninu agbara itansan oorun awarawa: agbara itansan oorun fun gbogbo eniyan, nibi gbogbo.

en: My aim is to make all surfaces productive.
yo: Erongba mi ni lati je ki gbogbo aye o wulo.

en: I want to build houses where all the windows, curtains, walls, even floors are harvesting electricity.
yo: Mo fe ko awon ile nibi ti gbogbo ferese, aso oju ferese, ogiri, koda gbogbo ile ti n gba ina manamana.

en: Think about this on a big scale: in cities, there are so many surfaces.
yo: E ronu nipa eyi lori osuwon nla: ni awon ilu-nla, orisirisi aye lo wa.

en: The sun is still available for everyone.
yo: Oorun si wa fun gbogbo eniyan.

en: And by integrating solar on the place where we need it, we now have the opportunity to make solar cells accessible for everyone.
yo: Pelu gbigbe agbara itansan oorun si aye ti a ti nilo re, a ti ni anfaani lati se padi agbara itansan oorun to se e lo fun gbogbo eniyan.

en: I want to bring solar close to the people with you, but beautiful and well designed.
yo: Mo fe mu ero agbara itansan oorun sumo awon eniyan pelu yin, sugbon ti yoo rewa ti yoo ni oso daadaa.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: How bees can keep the peace between elephants and humans
yo: Bi kokoro oyin se le je ki alaafia o wa laaarin erin ati omo eniyan.

en: Ever since I can remember, African elephants have filled me with a sense of complete awe.
yo: Lati igba ti mo le ranti, awon erin ile Adulawo ti fun mi ni oye inibowo to pe.

en: They are the largest land mammal alive today on planet Earth, weighing up to seven tons, standing three and a half meters tall at the shoulder.
yo: Awon ni eranko afomolomu to tobi ju ti won wa laye loni lori ile agbaye, ti won won to toonu meje, ti won n duro ni mita meta ataabo ni ejika.

en: They can eat up to 400 kilos of food in a day, and they disperse vital plant seeds across thousands of kilometers during their 50-to-60-year life span.
yo: Won le je to 400 kilo ounje lojo kan, won si n pin awon eso nnkan ogbin to se pataki kaakiri egberun kilomita lasiko 50-si-60 odun igbesi aye won.

en: Central to their compassionate and complex society are the matriarchs.
yo: Ni pataki si awujo aanu ati amudiju won ni awon obinrin olori ile.

en: These female, strong leaders nurture the young and navigate their way through the challenges of the African bush to find food, water and security.
yo: Awon abo wonyi, awon adari alagbara ni won n re awon odo ti won si n dari ona won ninu idojuko igbe ile Adulawo lati wa ounje, omi ati aabo.

en: Their societies are so complex, we're yet to still fully tease apart how they communicate, how they verbalize to each other, how their dialects work.
yo: Awujo won diju gan-an, a o tii sawari bi won se n bara won soro tan, bi won se bara won rojo, bi eka-ede won se n sise.

en: And we don't really understand yet how they navigate the landscape, remembering the safest places to cross a river.
yo: A o si fi bee ni oye bi won se n dari aworan ile, iranti awon aye ti o lewu pupo lati la odo koja.

en: I'm pretty sure that like me, most of you in this room have a similar positive emotional response to these most magnificent of all animals.
yo: O dami loju pe gegebi emi naa, opolopo eyin ti e wa ninu yara yii ni idahun padi-aye kan naa si eranko to tobi ju ninu gbogbo awon eranko yii.

en: It's really hard not to have watched a documentary, learned about their intelligence or, if you've been lucky, to see them for yourselves on safari in the wild.
yo: O nira pe ki eniyan o ma ti wo itan aroso adalori isele gidi kan, to n ko nipa ogbon won tabi, ti e ba ti ni anfaani, lati ri won funra yin ni ibugbe won ninu igbe.

en: But I wonder how many of you have been truly, utterly terrified by them.
yo: Sugbon mo n wo o pe meloo ninu yin ni won ti deruba loooto.

en: I was lucky to be brought up in Southern Africa by two teacher parents who had long holidays but very short budgets.
yo: Mo lori lowo pe won tomi dagba ni guusu ile Adulawo lodo awon obi oluko meji ti won maa n ni isinmi olojo gigun sugbon ti isuno won kere jojo.

en: And so we used to take our old Ford Cortina Estate, and with my sister, we'd pile in the back, take our tents and go camping in the different game reserves in Southern Africa.
yo: A maa n gbe Ford Cortina Estate atijo wa lo, pelu omo iya mi lobirin, a o korawa jo seyin, gbe agboji wa a o si lo pago si awujo eranko lorisirisi ni guusu ile Adulawo.

en: It really was heaven for a young, budding zoologist like myself.
yo: Orun lo je fun odo, olubere ekoo nipa eranko bii temi.

en: But I remember even at that young age that I found the tall electric fences blocking off the game parks quite divisive.
yo: Sugbon mo ranti wi pe koda ni ojo ori kekere yen mo ri gbogbo ogba onina giga to n di gaga awon eranko naa gege bi ipinya.

en: Sure, they were keeping elephants out of the communities, but they also kept communities out of their wild spaces.
yo: Bee ni, won n le awon erin jade kuro ni awujo, sugbon won tun n le awujo kuro ni aye won ninu igbe.

en: It really was quite a challenge to me at that young age.
yo: It really was quite a challenge to me at that young age. Idojuko nla lo je fun mi ni ojo ori kekere yen.

en: It was only when I moved to Kenya at the age of 14, when I got to connect to the vast, wild open spaces of East Africa.
yo: Igba ti mo ko lo si orile ede Kenya ni omodun merinla nikan, nigba ti mo ni lati sopo pelu awon aye nla to si sile ni ila oorun ile Adulawo.

en: And it is here now that I feel truly, instinctively, really at home.
yo: Ibi yii ni mo ti ni imolara loooto, pe ile ni mo wa.

en: I spent many, many happy years studying elephant behavior in a tent, in Samburu National Reserve, under the guideship of professor Fritz Vollrath and Iain Douglas-Hamilton, studying for my PhD and understanding the complexities of elephant societies.
yo: Mo lo aimoye odun alayo ti mo n ko nipa isesi erin ninu atibaba kan, nibi ifipamo apapo Samburu, labe itosona ojogbon Fritz Vollrath ati Lain Douglas-Hamilton, ti mo n kekoo fun oye owowe ti mo si n mo awon amudiju awujo erin.

en: But now, in my role as head of the human-elephant coexistence program for Save the Elephants, we're seeing so much change happening so fast that it's urged a change in some of our research programs.
yo: Sugbon nisinyii, ninu ojuse mi gege bi olori eto igbayepo eniyan ati erin fun Gba Awon Erin La, a n ri ayipada pupo to n sele were-were ti o ti bebe ayipada ninu awon eto iwadii wa.

en: No longer can we just sit and understand elephant societies or study just how to stop the ivory trade, which is horrific and still ongoing.
yo: A o ko le jokoo ka wa ni oye awujo erin tabi ka ko kekoo bi a se le da owo eyin erin duro, to je iberu to si n lo lowo.

en: We're having to change our resources more and more to look at this rising problem of human-elephant conflict, as people and pachyderms compete for space and resources.
yo: "A ni lati se ayipada awon ohun-elo wa lopo lati wo isoro rogbodiyan eniyan ati erin t""o n suyo, bi awon eniyan ati awon eranko-nla se n jija gudu fun aye ati ohun-elo."

en: It was only as recently as the 1970s that we used to have 1.2 million elephants roaming across Africa.
yo: Laipe yii bii asiko odun 1970 ni a ni egberun-lona-egberun kan ati egberun lona igba awon erin ti won n kaakiri ile adulawo.

en: Today, we're edging closer to only having 400,000 left.
yo: Loni, a n sumo nini egberun lona erinwo.

en: And at the same time period, the human population has quadrupled, and the land is being fragmented at such a pace that it's really hard to keep up with.
yo: Ni asiko kan naa, iye apapo awon eniyan ti di ilopo merin, ile naa si n dinku ni ere to nira lati ba dogba.

en: Too often, these migrating elephants end up stuck inside communities, looking for food and water but ending up breaking open water tanks, breaking pipes and, of course, breaking into food stores for food.
