yo: Lopo igba, awon erin ti won si kiri wonyi maa n ha nigbeyin sinu awon awujo, won n wa ounje ati omi sugbon nigbeyin won maa n fo awon kokondoro omi, fifo awon opa ati, beeni, fifo awon ile itaja ounje fun ounje.

en: It's really a huge challenge.
yo: Idojuko to tobi gan-an ni.

en: Can you imagine the terror of an elephant literally ripping the roof off your mud hut in the middle of the night and having to hold your children away as the trunk reaches in, looking for food in the pitch dark?
yo: Nje e le ronu iwa igbesumomi erin to n fa orule ahere yin ya laaarin oru ti e ni lati di awon omo yin mu kuro nibi arowoto eyin erin, to n wa ounje ninu okunkun?

en: These elephants also trample and eat crops, and this is traditionally eroding away that tolerance that people used to have for elephants.
yo: Awon erin wonyi tun maa n te won si maa n je nnkan ogbin, eyi si n ba ifarada ti awon eniyan maa n ni fun awon erin je.

en: And sadly, we're losing these animals by the day and, in some countries, by the hour -- to not only ivory poaching but this rapid rise in human-elephant conflict as they compete for space and resources.
yo: O bani ninu je, a n se afeku awon eranko wonyi lojoojumo, ni awon orile-ede kookan, ni wakati wakati -- kii se si awon to n pa eranko lona aito nikan sugbon isuyo rogbodiyan laaarin eniyan ati erin bi won se n jija-gudu fun aye ati ohun-elo.

en: It's a massive challenge.
yo: Idojuko to tobi ni.

en: I mean, how do you keep seven-ton pachyderms, that often come in groups of 10 or 12, out of these very small rural farms when you're dealing with people who are living on the very edge of poverty?
yo: Mo n so nipa pe, bawo le se le toju toonu meje awon eranko nla, ti won maa wa ni iko eleni mewa tabi mejila ni gbogbo igba, ninu awon oko agegbe kekeke wonyi nigba ti e ba n lajose pelu awon eniyan ti won n gbe ni ikogun osi?

en: They don't have big budgets.
yo: Won o ni isuna to tobi.

en: How do you resolve this issue?
yo: Bawo le sele yanju oro yii?

en: Well, one issue is, you can just start to build electric fences, and this is happening across Africa, we're seeing this more and more.
yo: O daa, isoro kan ni wi pe, e le bere sini ko awon ogba onina, eyi si n sele kaakiri ile Adulawo, a n ri eyi lopolopo.

en: But they are dividing up areas and blocking corridors.
yo: Sugbon won n pin awon agbegbe won si n di awon enu ona.

en: And I'm telling you, these elephants don't think much of it either, particularly if they're blocking a really special water hole where they need water, or if there's a very attractive female on the other side.
yo: Mo si n so fun yin, awon erin wonyi o ronu pupo nipa re pelu, paapaa julo ti won ba n di iho omi to yato nibi ti won ti nilo omi, tabi ti abo to woju gidi gan-an ba wa lodi keji.

en: It doesn't take long to knock down one of these poles.
yo: Kii pe ti won o fi n wo okan ninu awon opo wonyi lule.

en: And as soon as there's a gap in the fence, they go back, talk to their mates and suddenly they're all through, and now you have 12 elephants on the community side of the fence.
yo: Ni kete ti alafo ba ti wa ninu ogba naa, won yoo pada, lati ba awon akegbe won soro lojiji gbogbo won ki koja, bayii a ni erin mejila ni odi keji ogba awujo.

en: And now you're really in trouble.
yo: Bayii e ti wo wahala.

en: People keep trying to come up with new designs for electric fences.
yo: Awon eniyan tubo n gbiyanju lati wa apere tuntun fun ogba onino.

en: Well, these elephants don't think much of those either.
yo: O daa, awon erin wonyi o ronu pupo nipa awon wonyen pelu.

en: So rather than having these hard-line, straight, electric, really divisive migratory-blocking fences, there must be other ways to look at this challenge.
yo: Dipo nini awon ogba gbooro, onino, to n se ipinya to si n dena isikiri, ona miiran gbodo wa lati wo idojuko yii.

en: I'm much more interested in holistic and natural methods to keep elephants and people apart where necessary.
yo: Mo nife pupo si ilana apapo ati adamo lati ya erin ati eniyan soto nibi to ba ye.

en: Simply talking to people, talking to rural pastoralists in northern Kenya who have so much knowledge about the bush, we discovered this story that they had that elephants would not feed on trees that had wild beehives in them.
yo: Biba awon eniyan soro, biba awon adaranje agbegbe ni ariwa orile-ede Kenya ti won ni imo to po nipa igbe soro, a sawari itan yii ti won gbo pe awon erin o ni je igi ti afara-oyin ba wa ninu re.

en: Now this was an interesting story.
yo: Itan to panilerin leyii.

en: As the elephants were foraging on the tree, they would break branches and perhaps break open a wild beehive.
yo: Bi awon erin se n wa ounje kiri lara igi, won maa ge eka ati boya won a ge afara oyin to buru.

en: And those bees would fly out of their natural nests and sting the elephants.
yo: Awon oyin yii maa fo jade kuro ninu ile adamo won won o si ta erin naa.

en: Now if the elephants got stung, perhaps they would remember that this tree was dangerous and they wouldn't come back to that same site.
yo: Bi won ba ta erin naa, boya won maa ranti pe igi yii lewu won o si ni pada si agbegbe yen mo.

en: It seems impossible that they could be stung through their thick skin -- elephant skin is around two centimeters thick.
yo: O jo bi eni wi pe ko se e se pe won le tawon nibi awo won to nipon -- awo erin nipon to sentimita meji.

en: But it seems that they sting them around the watery areas, around the eyes, behind the ears, in the mouth, up the trunk.
yo: Sugbon o dabi eni pe won maa n ta won ni awon aye to lomi, nibi oju, leyin eti, ni enu, ati ni oke owoja won.

en: You can imagine they would remember that very quickly.
yo: E le woye wi pe won maa ranti iyen kiakia.

en: And it's not really one sting that they're scared of.
yo: Kii se tita ekan soso lo n bawon leru.

en: African bees have a phenomenal ability: when they sting in one site, they release a pheromone that triggers the rest of the bees to come and sting the same site.
yo: Awon oyin ile Adulawo ni ipa toyato: ti won ba ta nnkan ni aye kan, won yoo tu kemika ti yoo se okunfa ki awon oyin toku wa ta nnkan naa ni aye kan naa.

en: So it's not one beesting that they're scared of -- it's perhaps thousands of beestings, coming to sting in the same area -- that they're afraid of.
yo: Nitori naa kii se tita oyin lo n ba won leru -- boya tita egberun oyin, ti won n bo wa ta a ni aye kan naa -- lo n ba won leru.

en: And of course, a good matriarch would always keep her young away from such a threat.
yo: Loooto, obinrin olori ile to dara yoo mu awon omo re kuro nibi iru ewu bee.

en: Young calves have much thinner skins, and it's potential that they could be stung through their thinner skins.
yo: Awon omo erin maa n ni awo to tirin die, o si se e se pe ki won tawon ni awon awo to tinrin yii.

en: So for my PhD, I had this unusual challenge of trying to work out how African elephants and African bees would interact, when the theory was that they wouldn't interact at all.
yo: Fun oye omowe mi, mo ni idojuko to sowon ninu igbiyanju lati wa ona abayo si bi awon erin nile Adulawo ati awon oyin ile Adulawo se le ni ajosepo, nigba ti tiori naa je wi pe won o le ni ajosepo rara.

en: How was I going to study this?
yo: Bawo ni mo se fe sewadi eleyii?

en: Well, what I did was I took the sound of disturbed African honey bees, and I played it back to elephants resting under trees through a wireless speaker system, so I could understand how they would react as if there were wild bees in the area.
yo: O daa, nnkan ti mo se ni pe mo mu ohun awon oyin ile Adulawo to n damu, mo wa pile re pada fun awon erin ti won n simi labe igi ninu ero-gbohungbohun ti o ni waya, kin le mo bi won o se se to ba se wi pe oyin to buru ba wa ni agbegbe naa.

en: And it turns out that they react quite dramatically to the sound of African wild bees.
yo: Abajade re ni wi pe won huwa to jo bi ere si ohun awon oyin ile Adulawo to buru.

en: Here we are, playing the bee sounds back to this amazing group of elephants.
yo: Awa re e, ti a n pile ohun oyin pada fun egbe awon oyin ti won yanilenu yii.

en: You can see the ears going up, going out, they're turning their heads from side to side, one elephant is flicking her trunk to try and smell.
yo: E ri bi eti won se n lo soke, to n jade, ti won n yi ori won lati apakan si ikeji, erin kan n fi owoja re lati gbiyanju lati gboorun.

en: There's another elephant that kicks one of calves on the ground to tell it to get up as if there is a threat.
yo: Erin miiran wa to n ta okan ninu awon omo re to wa nile nipa lati so fun-un wi pe ko dide bi eni pe ewu wa.

en: And one elephant triggers a retreat, and soon the whole family of elephants are running after her across the savannah in a cloud of dust.
yo: Erin kan n gbiyanju lati sa seyin, laipe gbogbo ebi erin ti n sa tele fona ninu esu eruku.

en: (Sound of bees buzzing)
yo: (ohun oyin to n kun).

en: (Sound of bees ends)
yo: (ohun oyin ti pari).

en: Now I've done this experiment many, many times, and the elephants almost always flee.
yo: Mo ti se idanwo yii laimoye igba, awon erin naa fere le salo ni gbogbo igba.

en: Not only do they run away, but they dust themselves as they're running, as if to knock bees out of the air.
yo: Kii se pe won salo nikan, sugbon won maa n gbonra bi won se nsalo, bi eni pe won n gbon oyin danu.

en: And we placed infrasonic microphones around the elephants as we did these experiments.
yo: A gbe awon ero agbohun kelekele si orun awon erin naa bi a se n se ayewo wonyi.

en: And it turns out they're communicating to each other in infrasonic rumbles to warn each other of the threat of bees and to stay away from the area.
yo: Abajade re ni wi pe won n ba ara won soro pelu ikun kelekele lati kira won nilo nipa ewu oyin ati jijina si agbegbe naa.

en: So these behavioral discoveries really helped us understand how elephants would react should they hear or see bee sounds.
yo: Awon awari isesi wonyi ranwa lowo gan-an lati ni oye bi awon erin se n huwa ti won ba fi le gbo ohun oyin.

en: This led me to invent a novel design for a beehive fence, which we are now building around small, one-to-two-acre farms on the most vulnerable frontline areas of Africa where humans and elephants are competing for space.
yo: Eyi lo dari mi lati seda iselojo ogba afara oyin akokose, ti a n ko nisinyii kaakiri awon saare ile kan si meji oko kekeeke, ni awon aye ti won lewaju ikangun-sewu nile Adulawo nibi ti awon eniyan ati erin ti n jijagudu fun aye.

en: These beehive fences are very, very simple.
yo: Awon ogba afara oyin wonyi rorun gidi gaan.

en: We use 12 beehives and 12 dummy hives to protect one acre of farmland.
yo: A lo afara oyin mejila ati eda afara oyin mejila lati daaabobo saare ile-oko kan.

en: Now a dummy hive is simply a piece of plywood which we cut into squares, paint yellow and hang in between the hives.
yo: Bayii igi pilaiwudu kan ti a ge si igun merin ni eda afara oyin, ti a kun ni awo ayinrin ti a fi ha saarin afara-oyin naa.

en: We're basically tricking the elephants into thinking there are more beehives than there really are.
yo: A n tan awon erin naa lati ro wi pe ile oyin po nibe ju bo se ye lo.

en: And of course, it literally halves the cost of the fence.
yo: Bee si ni, o so iye owo ogba naa di abo.

en: So there's a hive and a dummy hive and a beehive and now dummy hive, every 10 meters around the outside boundary.
yo: Afara kan ati eda afara ati afara-oyin ati eda afara lo wa, ni gbogbo mita mewa yika aala ita.

en: They're held up by posts with a shade roof to protect the bees, and they're interconnected with a simple piece of plain wire, which goes all the way around, connecting the hives.
yo: Awon igi lo gbe won duro pelu orule aboji lati daaabobo awon oyin, won si sopo pelu ogidi waya kekere kan, to lo yika, to so awon afara oyin naa papo.

en: So if an elephant tries to enter the farm, he will avoid the beehive at all cost, but he might try and push through between the hive and the dummy hive, causing all the beehives to swing as the wire hits his chest.
yo: Bi erin kan ba gbiyanju lati wo oko naa, yoo sa fun afara oyin naa lona kona, sugbon o le gbiyanju lati koja laaarin afara oyin ati eda afara oyin naa, ti yoo mu ki awon ile oyin naa o sun bi waya naa ba se n ba aya re.

en: And as we know from our research work, this will cause the elephants to flee and run away -- and hopefully remember not to come back to that risky area.
yo: Bi a se mo latara ise iwadii wa, eyi maa je ki erin naa sa ko si fere ge - pelu ireti wi pe yoo ranti lati ma pada wa si agbegbe ewu yen.

en: The bees swarm out of the hive, and they really scare the elephants away.
yo: Awon oyin naa maa suru jade ninu afara naa, won o si le erin naa lo.

en: These beehive fences we're studying using things like camera traps to help us understand how elephants are responding to them at night time, which is when most of the crop raiding occurs.
yo: Awon ogba afara oyin ti a n se iwadii re pelu lilo awon nnkan bii panpe ayaworan lati je ka ni oye bi awon erin se n huwa si won lale, to je asiko ti jije nnkan ogbin maa n sele ju.

en: And we found in our study farms that we're keeping up to 80 percent of elephants outside of the boundaries of these farms.
yo: A ri i ninu awon oko iwadii wa wi pe a n le to ida ogorin erin sita aala awon oko wonyi.

en: And the bees and the beehive fences are also pollinating the fields.
yo: Awon oyin ati ogba afara oyin naa n gbon iyerin sori ile naa.

en: So we're having a great reduction both in elephant crop raids and a boost in yield through the pollination services that the bees are giving to the crops themselves.
yo: A n ni adinku to po ninu ijeko erin ati alekun ninu ire oko nipase ise gbibon iyerin ti awon oyin naa n fun awon nnkan ogbin funra won.

en: The strength of the beehive fences is really important -- the colonies have to be very strong.
yo: Agbara ogba afara oyin naa se pataki gidi gan-an -- awon ile naa ni lati lagbara gidi gan-an.

en: So we're trying to help farmers grow pollinator-friendly crops to boost their hives, boost the strength of their bees and, of course, produce the most amazing honey.
yo: A n gbiyanju lati ba awon agbe gbin awon ire-oko ti won ba iyerin re lati salekun agbara afara won, loooto, pese oyin to dara ju.

en: This honey is so valuable as an extra livelihood income for the farmers.
yo: Oyin yii lowo lori gidi gan-an gege bi afikun ipawowole fun awon agbe.

en: It's a healthy alternative to sugar, and in our community, it's a very valuable present to give a mother-in-law, which makes it almost priceless.
yo: Aropo to dara lo je fun suga, ni awujo wa, ebun to joju lo je lati fun iya-iyawo wa, to feree so o di nnkan olowo iye-biye.

en: We now bottle up this honey, and we've called this wild beautiful honey Elephant-Friendly Honey.
yo: A ti n pon oyin yii sinu igo, a si ti pe oyin buburu to rewa yii ni Oyin Aberin Sore.

en: It is a fun name, but it also attracts attention to our project and helps people understand what we're trying to do to save elephants.
yo: Oruko to panilerin ni, sugbon o tun pe akiyesi si ise akanse wa o de n ran awon eniyan lowo lati ni oye nnkan ti a n gbiyanju lati se lati doola awon erin.

en: We're working now with so many women in over 60 human-elephant conflict sites in 19 countries in Africa and Asia to build these beehive fences, working very, very closely with so many farmers but particularly now with women farmers, helping them to live better in harmony with elephants.
yo: A n sise po pelu opolopo awon obinrin ni awon aye rogbodiyan eniyan ati eranko to le ni ogota ni orile-ede mokan-din-logun nile Adulawo ati Asia lati ko awon ogba afara oyin wonyi, a n sise papo pelu opolopo awon agbe sugbon ni paapaah julo bayii pelu awon agbe lobinrin, riran won lowo lati gbe ni irepo pelu awon erin.

en: One of the things we're trying to do is develop a toolbox of options to live in better harmony with these massive pachyderms.
yo: Okan ninu awon nnkan ti a n gbiyanju lati se ni lati pese apoti-irinse oni yiyan kan lati tubo gbe ni irepo pelu awon eranko nla wonyi.

en: One of those issues is to try and get farmers, and women in particular, to think different about what they're planting inside their farms as well.
yo: Okan ninu isoro yen ni lati ri awon agbe, ni pataki julo awon obinrin, lati ni ironu to yato nipa nnkan ti won n gbin sinu oko won bakan naa.

en: So we're looking at planting crops that elephants don't particularly want to eat, like chillies, ginger, Moringa, sunflowers.
yo: A n wo sise ogbin awon ire oko ti awon erin ni pataki julo o fe je, bii ata, ata ile, moringa, ati ododo-oorun.

en: And of course, the bees and the beehive fences love these crops too, because they have beautiful flowers.
yo: Loooto ni, awon oyin ati awon ogba afara oyin feran awon ire-oko wonyii pelu, nitori pe won ni awon ododo to rewa.

en: One of these plants is a spiky plant called sisal -- you may know this here as jute.
yo: Okan ninu awon nkan ogbin wonyi je awon nnkan-ogbin to maa n po ti won n pe ni sisun -- e le mo eyi si juuti nibi yii.

en: And this amazing plant can be stripped down and turned into a weaving product.
yo: Nnkan ogbin to dara yii le di bibo si hoho ka si yi pada si eroja hihun.

en: We're working with these amazing women now who live daily with the challenges of elephants to use this plant to weave into baskets to provide an alternative income for them.
yo: A n sise pelu awon obinrin ti won dara bayii ti won n gbe pelu idojuko awon erin eda afara oyin je lati lo awon nnkan ogbin yii lati hun apere lati pese apaaro ipawowole fun won.

en: We've just started construction only three weeks ago on a women's enterprise center where we're going to be working with these women not only as expert beekeepers but as amazing basket weavers; they're going to be processing chili oils, sunflower oils, making lip balms and honey, and we're somewhere on our way to helping these participating farmers live with better eco-generating projects that live and work better with living with elephants.
yo: A se bere sini ko o ni bii ose meta seyin si aye ile-ise awon obinrin nibi ti a o ti maa sise pelu awon obinrin wonyi ti kii se gege bi ojini olutoju-oyin nikan sugbon gege bi onise ona apere; won yoo ma pese ororo sili, ororo ododo-oorun, sise ipara ete ati oyin, a wa nibikan loju ona lati ran awon agbe ti won n kopa wonyi lowo lati ni igbeaye to dara pelu awon ise-akanse to n pese ojo to dara ti yoo ma gbe ti yoo si ma sise pelu igbepo pelu awon erin.

en: So whether it's matriarchs or mothers or researchers like myself, I do see more women coming to the forefront now to think differently and more boldly about the challenges that we face.
yo: Tori naa boya awon obinrin olori ile ni tabi awon abiyamo tabi awon onise iwadii bii temi, mo maa n ri opolopo awon obinrin ti won n lewaju bayii lati ronu lona oto ti won si ni igboya si nipa awon idojuko ti a n koju.

en: With more innovation, and perhaps with some more empathy towards each other, I do believe we can move from a state of conflict with elephants to true coexistence.
yo: Pelu iseda lopo, ati boya pelu aanu fun arawa, mo nigbagbo pe a le sun lati rogbodiyan pelu erin si ajogbepo tooto.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: Will automation take away all our jobs?
yo: Nje adase le gba gbogbo ise wa lo?

en: Here's a startling fact: in the 45 years since the introduction of the automated teller machine, those vending machines that dispense cash, the number of human bank tellers employed in the United States has roughly doubled, from about a quarter of a million to a half a million.
yo: Ododo-oro to yanilenu re e: ni bii odun marun-le-logoji latigba ti won ti safihan ero to n powo, awon ero to maa n powo jade wonyi, iye awon eniyan ti won n gba lati maa kawo ni orile-ede United State ti di ilopo meji, lati bi ida merin egberun-lona-egberun di idaji aadota-oke.

en: A quarter of a million in 1970 to about a half a million today, with 100,000 added since the year 2000.
yo: Ida 4 aadota-oke ni odun 1970 si bii idaji egberun-lona-egberun lonii, pelu afikun egberun lona ogorun lati odun 2000.

en: These facts, revealed in a recent book by Boston University economist James Bessen, raise an intriguing question: what are all those tellers doing, and why hasn't automation eliminated their employment by now?
yo: "Awon ododo wonyi, ti won yoju re sita ninu iwe onimo nipa oro-aje ni fasiti Boston James Bassen, beere ibeere t""o ba mi leru: kini awon ti won n sanwo wonyen n se, ki l""o fa a ti imo-ero-adasise o se tii gbase lowo won lasiko yii?"

en: If you think about it, many of the great inventions of the last 200 years were designed to replace human labor.
yo: Bi e ba ronu nipa re, opolopo awon iseda nla lati bii igba odun seyin ni won se lati ropo ise omo eniyan.

en: Tractors were developed to substitute mechanical power for human physical toil.
yo: A seda oko katakata idako lati fi agbara ero ropo laalaa agbara kikan omo eniyan.

en: Assembly lines were engineered to replace inconsistent human handiwork with machine perfection.
yo: A seda ibi-itoko-papo lati fi isedeedee ero ropo aisedeedee ise-owo omo eniyan.

en: Computers were programmed to swap out error-prone, inconsistent human calculation with digital perfection.
yo: A ko-ede-isise ero-ayarabiasa lati paaro asise, aisedeedee isiro omo eniyan pelu aisedeedee ero-ayarabiasa igbalode.

en: These inventions have worked.
yo: Awon ogbon ipilese wonyi ti sise.

en: We no longer dig ditches by hand, pound tools out of wrought iron or do bookkeeping using actual books.
yo: "A o fi owo gbe koto mo, k""a lu irinse jade latara ako irin tabi k""a fi awon iwe gangan se ifiwepamo."

en: And yet, the fraction of US adults employed in the labor market is higher now in 2016 than it was 125 years ago, in 1890, and it's risen in just about every decade in the intervening 125 years.
yo: Sibe, apa kan awon agbalagba ti won n gba ni oja osise ti ga bayii ni odun 2016 ju bi o se wa ni odun marun-un-le-logofa seyin, ni odun 1890, o si n lekun ni gbogbo ewa odun laaarin odun marun-un-le-logofa naa.

en: This poses a paradox.
yo: Eyi n se afihan ajoro-sooto.

en: Our machines increasingly do our work for us.
yo: Awon ero wa n se alekun ise wa fun wa.

en: Why doesn't this make our labor redundant and our skills obsolete?
yo: Ki lo de ti eyi o se je ki awon osise o leele ki imose wa o si ma wulo mo?

en: Why are there still so many jobs?
yo: Ki lo de ti ise si se po?

en: I'm going to try to answer that question tonight, and along the way, I'm going to tell you what this means for the future of work and the challenges that automation does and does not pose for our society.
yo: Ma a gbiyanju lati dahun ibeere yen lale yii, bi a ba se n se eyi, maa so nnkan ti eyi tumo si fun ojo-iwaju ise ati idojuko ti idase n se ati awon ti ko si fun awujo wa.

en: Why are there so many jobs?
yo: Ki lo de ti ise se po.

en: There are actually two fundamental economic principles at stake.
yo: Ilana oro-aje to se pataki meji lo wa ninu ewu.

en: One has to do with human genius and creativity.
yo: Okan ni se pelu opolo omo eniyan ati ogbon atinuda.

en: The other has to do with human insatiability, or greed, if you like.
yo: Ikeji nise pelu ailayo-okan omo eniyan, okanjua, ti e ba fe.

en: I'm going to call the first of these the O-ring principle, and it determines the type of work that we do.
yo: Maa pe akoko ninu awon yii ni ilana oruka-O, o si maa n se okunfa iru ise ti a n se.

en: The second principle is the never-get-enough principle, and it determines how many jobs there actually are.
yo: Ilana keji ni ilana koto, o si maa n se okunfa iye ise to wa.

en: Let's start with the O-ring.
yo: E je ka bere pelu oruka-O.

en: ATMs, automated teller machines, had two countervailing effects on bank teller employment.
yo: Awon ATM, ero to n da powo, ni ipa alagbara meji lara igbanisise awon osise ile-ifowopamo ti won n funi lowo.

en: As you would expect, they replaced a lot of teller tasks.
yo: Bi e se n reti re, won ropo opolopo ise awon ti won n funi lowo.

en: The number of tellers per branch fell by about a third.
yo: Iye awon ti won n funni lowo ni eka kookan dinku pelu ida meta.

en: But banks quickly discovered that it also was cheaper to open new branches, and the number of bank branches increased by about 40 percent in the same time period.
yo: Sugbon awon ile-ifowopamo pada ri wi pe o roju lati si eka tuntun, iye eka ile-ifowopamo lekun pelu bii ida ogoji ni asiko kan naa.

en: The net result was more branches and more tellers.
yo: Esi apapo ni wi pe bi eka se n po si ni awon ti won n funi lowo naa n po si.

en: But those tellers were doing somewhat different work.
yo: Sugbon awon ti won n funi lowo yii n sise oto.

en: As their routine, cash-handling tasks receded, they became less like checkout clerks and more like salespeople, forging relationships with customers, solving problems and introducing them to new products like credit cards, loans and investments: more tellers doing a more cognitively demanding job.
yo: Gege bi ojuse won, ise gbigba-owo dinku, won o yato si agbowo won si jo abanitaja, nini ajosepo pelu awon onibaraa, yiyanju awon isoro ati sise afihan awon ohun-elo otun bii ike-igbawo, owo-iya ati idokowo: opo awon afuni lowo ti won n se awon ise to gba opolo.

en: There's a general principle here.
yo: Ilana apapo wa nibi.

en: Most of the work that we do requires a multiplicity of skills, and brains and brawn, technical expertise and intuitive mastery, perspiration and inspiration in the words of Thomas Edison.
yo: Opolopo ise ti a n se lo gba imoose lopo, ati opolo ati agbara, ojini onimo-ero ati opolo imoose, ilaagun ati imisi ninu oro Thomas Edison.

en: In general, automating some subset of those tasks doesn't make the other ones unnecessary.
yo: Lapapo, idase awon atunpin seeti awon ise wonyen o ni so awon toku di alaise pataki.

en: In fact, it makes them more important.
yo: Ni tooto, o maa n je ki won se pataki si ni.

en: It increases their economic value.
yo: O maa n se afikun iwulo oro-aje won ni.

en: Let me give you a stark example.
yo: E je kin fun-un yin ni apeere kan to foju han.

en: In 1986, the space shuttle Challenger exploded and crashed back down to Earth less than two minutes after takeoff.
yo: Ni odun 1986, oko ofuurufu onija gbina o si ja pada si aye leyin bi iseju meji to gbera.

en: The cause of that crash, it turned out, was an inexpensive rubber O-ring in the booster rocket that had frozen on the launchpad the night before and failed catastrophically moments after takeoff.
yo: Nnkan to sokunfa jija yen, abajade re, je roba oruka-O ti kii ran ninu afun roketi lagbara to ti di sori paadi-igbera lalee o kola to si kose lona to lewu ni asiko die leyin to gbera.

en: In this multibillion dollar enterprise that simple rubber O-ring made the difference between mission success and the calamitous death of seven astronauts.
yo: Ni ile-ise olopo bilionu dola ti roba oruka-O lasan ti se iyato laaarin ise to yege ati ajalu iku awon aredumare meje.

en: An ingenious metaphor for this tragic setting is the O-ring production function, named by Harvard economist Michael Kremer after the Challenger disaster.
yo: Ojulowo afiwe eleloo fun ibudo isele buruku yii ni ojuse iseda oruka-O, ti onimo nipa oro-aje Michael Kremer fun loruko leyin ajalu buruku awon onija.

en: The O-ring production function conceives of the work as a series of interlocking steps, links in a chain.
yo: Ise ipese oruka-O fa irori ise naa gege bi orisirisi igbese to wonu ara won, ti won sopo ninu okun kan.

en: Every one of those links must hold for the mission to succeed.
yo: Ikookan ninu awon isopo wonyen gbodo sele ki ise naa le di aseyori.

en: If any of them fails, the mission, or the product or the service, comes crashing down.
yo: Bi ikankan ninu won ba kuna, ise naa, tabi ohun-elo tabi ise naa, yoo ja lule.

en: This precarious situation has a surprisingly positive implication, which is that improvements in the reliability of any one link in the chain increases the value of improving any of the other links.
yo: Isele ase e se yii ni apadabo rere to yani lenu, to se wi pe atunse ninu igbarale ikookan ninu awon isopo naa maa se afikun iwulo atunse ikankan awon isopo yoku.

en: Concretely, if most of the links are brittle and prone to breakage, the fact that your link is not that reliable is not that important.
yo: Ni aridimu, ti opolopo awon isopo naa ba le ti won si le kan, paapaa pe isopo yin o se gbarale o fi bee se pataki.

en: Probably something else will break anyway.
yo: Boya nnkan miiran lo maa kan bayen.

en: But as all the other links become robust and reliable, the importance of your link becomes more essential.
yo: Sugbon bi awon isopo toku se n tobi sii ti won si se e gbarale, pataki isopo yin yoo tubo wulo si.

en: In the limit, everything depends upon it.
yo: Ni gbedeke, gbogbo nnkan lo gbara le e.

en: The reason the O-ring was critical to space shuttle Challenger is because everything else worked perfectly.
yo: Idi ti oruka-O se se pataki si awon oko ofuurufu onija ni wi pe gbogbo nnkan toku lo sise daadaa.

en: If the Challenger were kind of the space era equivalent of Microsoft Windows 2000 --the reliability of the O-ring wouldn't have mattered because the machine would have crashed.
yo: Bi awon onija naa ba je adogba pelu Microsoft Window odun 2000 -- igbarale oruka-O o ni kan won nitori ero naa yoo ti ja lule.

en: Here's the broader point.
yo: Koko-oro to tun feju re e.

en: In much of the work that we do, we are the O-rings.
yo: Ninu opolo po ise ti a n se, awa ni oruka-O.

en: Yes, ATMs could do certain cash-handling tasks faster and better than tellers, but that didn't make tellers superfluous.
yo: Bee ni, awon ero ATM le yara se awon ise ju awon ti won n fun ni lowo lo, sugbon iyen o so awon ti won n fun ni lowo di alaiwulo.

en: It increased the importance of their problem-solving skills and their relationships with customers.
yo: O n se afikun si pataki imoose iyanju-isoro won ati ajosepo won pelu awon onibaara.

en: The same principle applies if we're building a building, if we're diagnosing and caring for a patient, or if we are teaching a class to a roomful of high schoolers.
yo: Iru ilana bee la maa lo ti a ba n ko ile kan, ti a ba n se ayewo ti a si n se itoju awon alaisan, tabi ti a ba n ko kilasi awon akekoo ni ile-iwe girama to kun denu.

en: As our tools improve, technology magnifies our leverage and increases the importance of our expertise and our judgment and our creativity.
yo: Bi irinse se n dagba soke, imo-ero ti se afikun agbara wa o si ti se afikun si pataki imo-ojini wa ati idajo wa ati ogbon atinuda wa.

en: And that brings me to the second principle: never get enough.
yo: Eyi lo mu mi lo sibi ilana keji: koto.

en: You may be thinking, OK, O-ring, got it, that says the jobs that people do will be important.
yo: E le maa ro wi pe, o dara, oruka-O, o yemi, to so wi pe awon ise ti awon eniyan n se maa se pataki.

en: They can't be done by machines, but they still need to be done.
yo: Awon ero o le se won, sugbon won si gbodo di sise.

en: But that doesn't tell me how many jobs there will need to be.
yo: Sugbon iyen o so fun mi iye ise ti yoo wa.

en: If you think about it, isn't it kind of self-evident that once we get sufficiently productive at something, we've basically worked our way out of a job?
yo: Ti e ba ronu nipa e, se ko foju han pe ti a ba ti ri nnkan se, a ti wa ona wa jade kuro nibi ise yen?

en: In 1900, 40 percent of all US employment was on farms.
yo: Ni odun 1900, ida ogoji gbogbo igbanisise ni orile-ede US je lori oko.

en: Today, it's less than two percent.
yo: Loni, o ti dinku ni ida meji.

en: Why are there so few farmers today?
yo: Ki lo de ti awon agbe se kere loni?

en: It's not because we're eating less.
yo: Kii se nitori pe a o jeun pupo.

en: A century of productivity growth in farming means that now, a couple of million farmers can feed a nation of 320 million.
yo: Orun odun idagbasoke ninu ise-agbe tumo si wi pe ni bayii, ilopo egberun-lona-egberun awon agbe le bo orile-ede to ni egberun-lona-egberun orin-din-nirinwo le logun eniyan.

en: That's amazing progress, but it also means there are only so many O-ring jobs left in farming.
yo: Itesiwaju to yanilenu niyen, sugbon o tun tumo si wi pe awon ise oruka-O to po lo ku ninu ise agbe.

en: So clearly, technology can eliminate jobs.
yo: O foju han kedere, imo-ero le pa ise.

en: Farming is only one example.
yo: Apeere kan soso ni ise-agbe je.

en: There are many others like it.
yo: Awon miiran bi iru re tun wa.

en: But what's true about a single product or service or industry has never been true about the economy as a whole.
yo: Sugbon nnkan to je otito nipa ohun-elo kan soso tabi ise tabi ile-ise ko figba kan je otito nipa oro-aje lapapo.

en: Many of the industries in which we now work -- health and medicine, finance and insurance, electronics and computing -- were tiny or barely existent a century ago.
yo: Opolopo awon ile-ise ti a ti n sise bayii -- ilera ati oogun, isuna ati idojutofo, ohun-elo to n lona ati ero-ayarabiasa -- kere tabi won o fere si rara bi orun odun seyin.

en: Many of the products that we spend a lot of our money on -- air conditioners, sport utility vehicles, computers and mobile devices -- were unattainably expensive, or just hadn't been invented a century ago.
yo: Opolopo ninu awon eroja ti a n na opo owo wa le lori -- ero amuletutu, awon oko obokun oloye, ero-ayarabiasa ati awon ero ibanisoro -- gbowo lori gidi gan-an, tabi won o tii seda won bi orun odun seyin.

en: As automation frees our time, increases the scope of what is possible, we invent new products, new ideas, new services that command our attention, occupy our time and spur consumption.
yo: "Bi adase se n se itusile asiko wa, to n se alekun oju-iwoye nnkan to se e se, a seda awon eroja tuntun, ero tuntun, ise tuntun t""o n pase fun akiyesi wa, t""o n gba akoko ati ilo wa."

en: You may think some of these things are frivolous -- extreme yoga, adventure tourism, Pokemon GO -- and I might agree with you.
yo: E le ro boya awon nnkan wonyi je ina apa -- ipekun yoga, irin-ajo afe, Pokemon GO -- mo si le gba pelu yin.

en: But people desire these things, and they're willing to work hard for them.
yo: Sugbon awon eniyan nife si awon nnkan wonyi, won si setan lati sise karakara fun won.

en: The average worker in 2015 wanting to attain the average living standard in 1915 could do so by working just 17 weeks a year, one third of the time.
yo: Aropin awon osise ni odun 2015 ti won duro lati de ipo aropin igbeaye awokose ni odun 1915 le se bee pelu sise ise fun ose meta-din-logun pere ninu odun kan, ida meta asiko naa.

en: But most people don't choose to do that.
yo: Sugbon opolopo eniyan kii fe se iyen.

en: They are willing to work hard to harvest the technological bounty that is available to them.
yo: Won setan lati sise karakara lati kore imo-ero lopo bo se wa fun won.

en: Material abundance has never eliminated perceived scarcity.
yo: Wiwa lopo awon ohun-elo ko tii pa owon ti a kefin.

en: In the words of economist Thorstein Veblen, invention is the mother of necessity.
yo: Ninu oro onimo nipa oro-aje Thorstein Veblen, iseda ni iya fun ko se e ma ni.

en: Now. So if you accept these two principles, the O-ring principle and the never-get-enough principle, then you agree with me.
yo: Nitori naa ti e ba gba awon ilana meji wonyi, ilana oruka-O ati ilana koto, e o gba pelu mi nigba naa.

en: There will be jobs.
yo: Ise yoo wa.

en: Does that mean there's nothing to worry about?
yo: Se iyen tumo si wi pe ko si nnkankan lati beru?

en: Automation, employment, robots and jobs -- it'll all take care of itself?
yo: Idase, igbanisise, sigidi-oyinbo ati ise -- gbogbo won maa mojuto ara won?

en: That is not my argument.
yo: Ki i se ariyanjiyan mi niyen.

en: Automation creates wealth by allowing us to do more work in less time.
yo: Idase n pese oro pelu fifun wa ni anfaani lati sise to po ni akoko perete.

en: There is no economic law that says that we will use that wealth well, and that is worth worrying about.
yo: Ko si ofin oro-aje to so wi pe a maa lo oro yen daadaa, iyen si to nnkan to ye ka ronu nipa re.

en: Consider two countries, Norway and Saudi Arabia.
yo: E wo orile-ede meji, Norway ati Saudi Arabia.

en: Both oil-rich nations, it's like they have money spurting out of a hole in the ground.
yo: Awon mejeeji ni won ni epo, o da bi eni pe won ni owo to n jade lati inu iho kan ninu ile ni.

en: But they haven't used that wealth equally well to foster human prosperity, human prospering.
yo: Sugbon won o lo oro naa dogba daadaa lati se atileyin fun aseyori omo eniyan, awon eniyan to n saseyori.

en: Norway is a thriving democracy.
yo: Norway je oselu awarawa to n dagba.

en: By and large, its citizens work and play well together.
yo: Lapapo, awon omo-ilu re n se ise ati ere papo.

en: It's typically numbered between first and fourth in rankings of national happiness.
yo: O wa laaarin ipo akoko si ikerin ni ato idunu orile-ede.

en: Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy in which many citizens lack a path for personal advancement.
yo: Saudi Arabia je ilu oloba ti awon omo-ilu re o ni ona si itesiwaju araeni.

en: It's typically ranked 35th among nations in happiness, which is low for such a wealthy nation.
yo: O wa nipo karun-le-logbon ninu awon orile-ede ti won wa ninu idunnu, ti o kere fun iru orile-ede to loro bee.

en: Just by way of comparison, the US is typically ranked around 12th or 13th.
yo: Pelu sise afiwe lasan, orile ede US wa nipo kejila tabi iketala.

en: The difference between these two countries is not their wealth and it's not their technology.
yo: Iyato to wa laaarin awon orile-ede meji yii ki i se oro won ki i si i se imo-ero won.

en: It's their institutions.
yo: Awon ile ise won ni.

en: Norway has invested to build a society with opportunity and economic mobility.
yo: Norway ti dokowo lati ko awujo to ni anfaani ati agbekiri oro-aje.

en: Saudi Arabia has raised living standards while frustrating many other human strivings.
yo: Saudi Arabia ti se afikun si afisodiwon igbeaye nigba ti won n wahala opo igbiyanju awon eniyan miiran.

en: Two countries, both wealthy, not equally well off.
yo: Orile-ede meji, ti won loro, ti oro won o dogba.

en: And this brings me to the challenge that we face today, the challenge that automation poses for us.
yo: Eyi lo mu mi wa sibi idojuko ti a n koju loni, idojuko ti adase n se fun wa.

en: The challenge is not that we're running out of work.
yo: Idojuko naa kii se wi pe ko si ise.

en: The US has added 14 million jobs since the depths of the Great Recession.
yo: Orile-ede US ti se afikun aadota-oke merinla ise lati igba opin ojojo oro-aje to lagbara.

en: The challenge is that many of those jobs are not good jobs, and many citizens cannot qualify for the good jobs that are being created.
yo: Idojuko ibe ni wi pe opolopo awon ise wonyen kii se ise rere, opolopo awon ara ilu o si peregede fun ise gidi ti won pese.

en: Employment growth in the United States and in much of the developed world looks something like a barbell with increasing poundage on either end of the bar.
yo: Idagbasoke igbanisise ni orile-ede United States ati ni opolopo awon orile ede ti won ti goke agba da bi irin ti won n se afikun igberin ni ipekun irin mejeeji.

en: On the one hand, you have high-education, high-wage jobs like doctors and nurses, programmers and engineers, marketing and sales managers.
yo: Ni apa kan, e ni eko giga, awon ise ti owo-ise won ga bii onisegun oyinbo ati awon oluto-ile-iwosan, awon onimo nipa komputa ati awon onimo-ero, itaja ati awon alamojuto itaja.

en: Employment is robust in these jobs, employment growth.
yo: Igbanisise po ninu awon ise yii, idagbasoke igbanisise.

en: Similarly, employment growth is robust in many low-skill, low-education jobs like food service, cleaning, security, home health aids.
yo: Bakan naa, idagbasoke igbanisise po ninu awon ise oni imoose-kekere, ati eko kekere bii ise ounje, agbale, eleto aabo, iralnwo ilera inu-ile.

en: Simultaneously, employment is shrinking in many middle-education, middle-wage, middle-class jobs, like blue-collar production and operative positions and white-collar clerical and sales positions.
yo: Lasiko kan naa, igbanisise n ru ni opo awon eko to wa lagbede meji, owo-ise agbedemeji, awon ise-agbedemeji, bi isise amoju-ero ati ise alakowe ati itaja.

en: The reasons behind this contracting middle are not mysterious.
yo: Idi ti aarin yii fi n ha yii kii semo.

en: Many of those middle-skill jobs use well-understood rules and procedures that can increasingly be codified in software and executed by computers.
yo: Opolopo awon ise imoose agbedemeji maa n lo awon ofin ati ilana ti o yeni yeke ti won le gbe sinu ohun-elo ero-ayarabiasa ti o se e fowo kan ti won le lo lori ero-ayarabiasa.

en: The challenge that this phenomenon creates, what economists call employment polarization, is that it knocks out rungs in the economic ladder, shrinks the size of the middle class and threatens to make us a more stratified society.
yo: Idojuko ti nnkan yii n dasile, nnkan ti awon onimo nipa oro-aje n pe ni ipin si meji igbanisise, ni wi pe o maa n ja awon akaso ninu akaba oro-aje, o maa n joro iwon awon ti won wa lagbedemeji o si n dukoko lati so awujo wa di onipele.

en: On the one hand, a set of highly paid, highly educated professionals doing interesting work, on the other, a large number of citizens in low-paid jobs whose primary responsibility is to see to the comfort and health of the affluent.
yo: Ni apa kan, owo awon ti won n gbowo geere, awon akosemose ti won kawe ti won n se ise to rorun, lapa keji, ogunlogbon awon ara-ilu ti won n sise ti owo ise won kere ti ojuse won gangan je lati ri si iderun ati ilera awon oloro.

en: That is not my vision of progress, and I doubt that it is yours.
yo: Eyi kii se afojusun ilosiwaju mi, mo si n seye meji pe tiyin niyen.

en: But here is some encouraging news.
yo: Sugbon awon iroyin to wunilori niyi.

en: We have faced equally momentous economic transformations in the past, and we have come through them successfully.
yo: A ti koju awon asiko ayipada oro-aje seyin, a si ti ri ona abayo kuro ninu won laseyori.

en: In the late 1800s and early 1900s, when automation was eliminating vast numbers of agricultural jobs -- remember that tractor?-- the farm states faced a threat of mass unemployment, a generation of youth no longer needed on the farm but not prepared for industry.
yo: Ni ipekun asiko 1800 ati ibere asiko 1900, nigba ti idasise n pa opo awon ise agbe -- e ranti oko-katakata-idako? ipo awon oko naa koju ewu ainiselowo to po, iran awon odo ti a o nilo lori oko sugbon ti won o setan fun ile-ise.

en: Rising to this challenge, they took the radical step of requiring that their entire youth population remain in school and continue their education to the ripe old age of 16.
yo: Kikoju awon idojuko yii, won gbe igbese akin fun pipe fun gbogbo awon odo lati duro si ile-eko ki won si tesiwaju eko won titi ti won o fi balaga di omo odun merin-din-logun.

en: This was called the high school movement, and it was a radically expensive thing to do.
yo: Eyi ni won pe ni itesiwaju ile-eko giga, o si je nkan to won lati se.

en: Not only did they have to invest in the schools, but those kids couldn't work at their jobs.
yo: Kii se pe won ni lati dokowo ninu awon ile-eko nikan, sugbon awon omo wonyen o le se ise won.

en: It also turned out to be one of the best investments the US made in the 20th century.
yo: "O pada di okan ninu awon idokowo t""o dara ju ti orile-ede US ti se ni orun odun ogun."

en: It gave us the most skilled, the most flexible and the most productive workforce in the world.
yo: O fun wa ni imoose to po ju, awon osise ti won le yipada ju ti won si n sise ju lagbaaye.

en: To see how well this worked, imagine taking the labor force of 1899 and bringing them into the present.
yo: Lati le ri bi eyi se sise si, e woye mimu awon osise odun 1899 ka mu won wa si asiko lowolowo yii.

en: Despite their strong backs and good characters, many of them would lack the basic literacy and numeracy skills to do all but the most mundane jobs.
yo: Pelu eyin lile ati iwa rere won, opolopo won o ni imo ipile ati imoose onka lati se gbogbo re sugbon awon ise ti o munu eni dun.

en: Many of them would be unemployable.
yo: Opo ninu won ni o ni se e gba sise.

en: What this example highlights is the primacy of our institutions, most especially our schools, in allowing us to reap the harvest of our technological prosperity.
yo: Nnkan ti apeere yii toka si ni pataki awon ile-ise wa, paapaa julo awon ile-eko wa, lati gbawa laye lati kore ilosiwaju imo-ero wa.

en: It's foolish to say there's nothing to worry about.
yo: Iwa oponu ni lati so wi pe ko si nnkankan lati beru.

en: Clearly we can get this wrong.
yo: O han gbangba pe a le si eleyi.

en: If the US had not invested in its schools and in its skills a century ago with the high school movement, we would be a less prosperous, a less mobile and probably a lot less happy society.
yo: Bi orile-ede US ba ti dokowo ninu awon ile-eko re ati imoose re lati bii orun odun seyin pelu itesiwaju ile-eko giga ni, a o ni lamilaka pupo, a o ni sun kaakiri pupo ati boya awujo ti o ni idunnu pupo.

en: But it's equally foolish to say that our fates are sealed.
yo: Sugbon iwa oponu tun ni bakan naa lati so wi pe won ti pari kadara wa.

en: That's not decided by the machines.
yo: Ki i se awon ero ni yoo se iyen.

en: It's not even decided by the market.
yo: Ki i se oja gan-an ni yoo se e.

en: It's decided by us and by our institutions.
yo: Awa ati awon ile-ise wa la maa se iyen.

en: Now, I started this talk with a paradox.
yo: Ni bayii, mo bere atotonu yii pelu ajoro-sooto.

en: Our machines increasingly do our work for us.
yo: Awon ero wa n se ise wa fun wa lopolopo.

en: Why doesn't that make our labor superfluous, our skills redundant?
yo: Ki lo de ti iyen o se so awon osise wa di alaiwulo, ki imoose wa si lele?

en: Isn't it obvious that the road to our economic and social hell is paved with our own great inventions?
yo: Se ko foju han pe oju ona si apadi oro-aje ati awujo wa ti di sisi latara iseda nla wa?

en: History has repeatedly offered an answer to that paradox.
yo: Itan ti n fun wa ni idahun si ajoro-sooto yen ni tele-n-tele.

en: The first part of the answer is that technology magnifies our leverage, increases the importance, the added value of our expertise, our judgment and our creativity.
yo: Abala akoko idahun naa ni wi pe imo-ero ti se afikun agbara wa, ti se afikun si iwulo awon agba-oje wa, idajo wa ati ogbon atinuda wa.

en: That's the O-ring.
yo: Oruka-O naa niyen.

en: The second part of the answer is our endless inventiveness and bottomless desires means that we never get enough, never get enough.
yo: Apa keji idahun naa ni pe iseda ailopin wa ati ife ti o nipekun tumo si wi pe koto, koto.

en: There's always new work to do.
yo: Gbogbo igba ni ise tuntun maa n wa lati se.

en: Adjusting to the rapid pace of technological change creates real challenges, seen most clearly in our polarized labor market and the threat that it poses to economic mobility.
yo: Isuraki si opo ere ayipada imo ero ti pese idojuko tooto sile, ti a n ri kedere lopo ninu isodi meji oja awon osise wa ati ewu to n fa fun ilosiwaju oro-aje.

en: Rising to this challenge is not automatic.
yo: Idide si idojuko yii kii se adase.

en: It's not costless.
yo: Kii se pe ko ni nani lowo.

en: It's not easy.
yo: Ko rorun.

en: But it is feasible.
yo: Sugbon o se e se.

en: And here is some encouraging news.
yo: Awon iroyin to n fun ni ni iwuri ree.

en: Because of our amazing productivity, we're rich.
yo: Nitori isise wa, a ti dolowo.

en: Of course we can afford to invest in ourselves and in our children as America did a hundred years ago with the high school movement.
yo: Loooto a lowo lati dokowo ninu ara wa ati awon omo wa gege bi orile-ede America se se ni ogorun odun seyin pelu itesiwaju awon ile-eko giga.

en: Arguably, we can't afford not to.
yo: O se e jiyan, a o le teti lati ma se e.

en: Now, you may be thinking, Professor Autor has told us a heartwarming tale about the distant past, the recent past, maybe the present, but probably not the future.
yo: Ni bayii, e le maa ro o wi pe, ojogbon Autor ti so itan atunilara fun wa nipa igba pipe, igba ti o tii pe, boya lowolowo yii, sugbon boya ki i se nipa ojo iwaju.

en: Because everybody knows that this time is different.
yo: Nitori gbogbo eniyan lo mo wi pe asiko yii yato.

en: Is this time different?
yo: Nje asiko yii yato?

en: Of course this time is different.
yo: Bee ni asiko yii yato.

en: Every time is different.
yo: Gbogbo asiko lo yato.

en: On numerous occasions in the last 200 years, scholars and activists have raised the alarm that we are running out of work and making ourselves obsolete: for example, the Luddites in the early 1800s; US Secretary of Labor James Davis in the mid-1920s; Nobel Prize-winning economist Wassily Leontief in 1982; and of course, many scholars, pundits, technologists and media figures today.
yo: Lopo igba ni igba odun seyin, awon omowe ati awon ajafeto ti kebosi pe a o ni ise mo a si n so ara wa di alaiwulo: fun apeere, awon onimo-ero ni ibere asiko 1800; akowe awon osise fun orile-ede US james Davis ni aarin asiko 1920; onimo nipa oro-aje to tun gba ebun Wassily Leontief ni odun 1982; bee si ni, opolopo awon omowe, ayanana, awon onimo-ero ati awon agbohun-safefe lonii.

en: These predictions strike me as arrogant.
yo: Awon asotele wonyi bami bi onigberaga.

en: "These self-proclaimed oracles are in effect saying, ""If I can't think of what people will do for work in the future, then you, me and our kids aren't going to think of it either."
yo: "Awon ti won sora won di oosa wonyi ti won n so wi pe, ""ti mi o ba le ronu nipa nnkan ti awon eniyan maa se lati rise lojo iwaju, iwo, emi ati awon omo wa o ni ronu nipa re pelu."

en: """ I don't have the guts to take that bet against human ingenuity."
yo: """ Mi o lokan lati ta tete yen tako ogbon inu omo eniyan."

en: Look, I can't tell you what people are going to do for work a hundred years from now.
yo: E wo o, mi o le so nnkan ti awon eniyan maa se lati rise ni ogorun odun si asiko yii fun yin.

en: But the future doesn't hinge on my imagination.
yo: Sugbon ojo iwaju o gbara le ironu mi.

en: "If I were a farmer in Iowa in the year 1900, and an economist from the 21st century teleported down to my field and said, ""Hey, guess what, farmer Autor, in the next hundred years, agricultural employment is going to fall from 40 percent of all jobs to two percent purely due to rising productivity."
yo: "Bi mo ba je agbe ni lowa ni odun 1900, ti awon onimo nipa oro-aje orun odun kankan-le-logun wa jade sori ile mi to wa so pe, ""iwo, se o mo nnkan, agbe Autor, ni ogorun odun to n bo, igbanisise agbe maa dinku lati ida ogoji gbogbo ise si ogere ida meji nitori isise to n lo soke."

en: What do you think the other 38 percent of workers are going to do?
yo: Ki le ro wi pe ida meji-din-logoji awon osise yoo maa se?

en: """ I would not have said, ""Oh, we got this."
yo: """ mi o ba ma so pe, ""Oh, a mo eyi."

en: We'll do app development, radiological medicine, yoga instruction, Bitmoji.
yo: A maa se ipese awon ohun-elo, awon ero ayaworan-ara fun isegun, ikoni ni yoga, Bitmoji.

en: I wouldn't have had a clue.
yo: Mi o ba ti ma ni imo kankan.

en: "But I hope I would have had the wisdom to say, ""Wow, a 95 percent reduction in farm employment with no shortage of food."
yo: "Sugbon mo lero wi pe maa ni ogbon lati so wi pe, ""Wow, adinku ida marun-un-le laadorun ninu igbanisise oko laisi adinku ounje."

en: That's an amazing amount of progress.
yo: Itesiwaju to yanilenu niyen.

en: I hope that humanity finds something remarkable to do with all of that prosperity.
yo: Mo lero wi pe awon omo eniyan yoo ri nnkan gidi lati se pelu gbogbo ilamilaka yen.

en: And by and large, I would say that it has.
yo: Lapapo, maa so wi pe o ti ri bee.

en: Thank you very much.
yo: E seun pupo.

en: A celebration of natural hair
yo: Ajodun irun amutorun wa.

en: I am from the South Side of Chicago, and in seventh grade, I had a best friend named Jenny who lived on the Southwest Side of Chicago.
yo: Mo wa lati Apa Guusu orile-ede Chicago, mo si wa ni ipele keje, mo ni oredenu kan ti oruko re n je Jenny to n gbe ni Apa Guusu-iwo-oorun orile-ede Chicago.

en: Jenny was white, and if you know anything about the segregated demographics of Chicago, you know that there are not too many black people who live on the Southwest Side of Chicago.
yo: Jenny je alawo funfun, ti e ba si mo nnkankan nipa awon aye ti won ya soto ni orile-ede Chicago, e mo wi pe awon eniyan dudu o fi bee gbe ni Apa Guusu-iwo-oorun orile-ede Chicago.

en: But Jenny was my girl and so we would hang out every so often after school and on the weekends.
yo: Sugbon Jenny ni arabinrin mi nitori naa a maa n jade papo lopo igba leyin ti a ba jade ni ile-eko ati ni opin ose.

en: And so one day we were hanging out in her living room, talking about 13-year-old things, and Jenny's little sister Rosie was in the room with us, and she was sitting behind me just kind of playing in my hair, and I wasn't thinking too much about what she was doing.
yo: Ni ojo kan a jo wa ni yara igbalejo won, ti a n soro nipa awon nnkan omo odun metala, aburo Jenny lobinrin Rosie wa ninu yara naa pelu wa, o jokoo leyin mi ti o n fi irun mi sere, mi o si ronu pupo nipa nnkan ti o n se.

en: But at a pause in the conversation, Rosie tapped me on the shoulder.
yo: Sugbon nigba ti a danu duro die ninu iforojomitoro naa, Rosie fowo tomi lejika.

en: "She said, ""Can I ask you a question?"
yo: "O wi pe. ""Nje mo le bi o ni ibeere kan."

en: "I said, ""Yeah, Rosie."
yo: "Mo ni, ""bee ni, Rosie."

en: """Are you black?"
yo: """Se alawo dudu ni o ni?"

en: The room froze.
yo: Yara naa tutu.

en: Jenny and Rosie's mom was not too far away.
yo: Iya Jenny ati Rosie o fi bee jino si wa.

en: She was in the kitchen and she overheard the conversation, and she was mortified.
yo: Won wa ninu ile-idana won si n gbo oro wa, oju tiwon.

en: "She said, ""Rosie! You can't ask people questions like that."
yo: "Won ni, ""Rosie! O o le ma bere iru ibeere bayen lowo awon eniyan."

en: """ And Jenny was my friend, and I know she was really embarrassed."
yo: """ Jenny je ore mi, mo si mo wi pe oju tii gidi gan-an."

en: I felt kind of bad for her, but actually I was not offended.
yo: Inu mi baje nitori tie, sugbon ko semi.

en: I figured it wasn't Rosie's fault that in her 10 short years on this earth, living on the Southwest Side of Chicago, she wasn't 100 percent sure what a black person looked like.
yo: "Mo ri I wi pe kii se ejoo Rosie pe ni odun kekere re bii mewa t""o ti lo laye, t""o si n gbe ni Apa Guusu-iwo-oorun orile-ede Chicago, ko ni idaniloju to pe ida ogorun bi eniyan dudu se ri."

en: That's fair.
yo: Iyen dara.

en: But what was more surprising to me was, in all of this time I had spent with Jenny and Rosie's family -- hanging out with them, playing with them, even physically interacting with them -- it was not until Rosie put her hands in my hair that she thought to ask me if I was black.
yo: "Sugbon nnkan t""o jomi loju ju ni pe, ni gbogbo asiko ti mo ti lo pelu ebi Jenny ati Rosie -- ti mo n jade pelu won, ti mo n bawon sere, ti mo si n ba won soro lojukoju -- afi igba ti Rosie fi owo kan irun mi ni o to beere boya alawo dudu ni mi."

en: That was the first time I would realize how big of a role the texture of my hair played in confirming my ethnicity, but also that it would play a key role in how I'm viewed by others in society.
yo: "Igba akoko niyen ti mo maa mo ipa nla ti irisi irun mi le ko lati so iran mi, pe o tun le ko ipa to se pataki si bi awon eniyan t""o ku lawujo se n wo mi."

en: Garrett A.Morgan and Madame CJ Walker were pioneers of the black hair-care and beauty industry in the early 1900s.
yo: Garrett A. Morgan ati Madame CJ Walker ni won se idasile itoju-irun dudu ati ile-ise isaralooge ni ibere asiko odun 1900.

en: They're best known as the inventors of chemically-based hair creams and heat straightening tools designed to permanently, or semipermanently, alter the texture of black hair.
yo: A mo won si oluseda awon iparun oni kemika ati awon irinse iforu na nnkan ti won se lati se ayida irisi irun dudu fun gbere tabi fungba die.

en: "Oftentimes when we think about the history of blacks in America, we think about the heinous acts and numerous injustices that we experienced as people of color because of the color of our skin, when in fact, in post-Civil War America, it was the hair of an African-American male or female that was known as the most ""telling feature"" of Negro status, more so than the color of the skin."
yo: "Nigba miran nigba ti a ba ronu nipa itan awon alawo dudu ni ile America, a maa n ronu nipa awon iwa buruku ati opolopo aisedede ti a koju gege bi alawo dudu nitori awo ara wa, nigba to si je pe loooto, leyin ogun abele ile America, irun omo ile America alawo-dulawo lokunrin tabi lobinrin ni won mo gege bi ""awomo asoro"" ije alawo dudu, ju awo ara lo."

en: And so before they were staples of the multibillion-dollar hair-care industry, our dependency on tools and products, like the hair relaxer and the pressing comb, were more about our survival and advancement as a race in postslavery America.
yo: Nitori naa ki won to di asopo ile-ise aserun loge olopo egberun-lona-egberun dola, agbokan le wa lori awon irinse ati ohun-elo, bii ose-irun ati iyarun, ni a n lo fun imoribo ati ilosiwaju gege bi iran kan leyin ikonileru nile America.

en: Over the years, we grew accustomed to this idea that straighter and longer hair meant better and more beautiful.
yo: Lati bi aimoye odun, a n dagba si mimo ero yii pe irun to na to si gun tumo si didara o si maa n rewa si.

en: "We became culturally obsessed with this idea of having what we like to call ""good hair."
yo: "A so ero yii di asa nini nnkan ti a feran lati maa pe ni ""irun gidi."

en: """ This essentially means: the looser the curl pattern, the better the hair."
yo: """ Ni pataki eyi tumo si wi pe: bi batani lilo ba se si si, ni irun se maa dara si."

en: And we let these institutionalized ideas form a false sense of hierarchy that would determine what was considered a good grade of hair and what was not.
yo: A je ki awon iwoye awujo wonyi di opolo ipele agbeka ti o ye ti yoo maa so ohun ti a mo si isori irun gidi ati eyi ti o se.

en: What's worse is that we let these false ideologies invade our perception of ourselves, and they still continue to infect our cultural identity as African-American women today.
yo: "Nnkan t""o tun buru ju ni wi pe a je ki awon ero bayeseri ti o ye wonyi n kogun ja ero wa nipa ara wa, won si n tesiwaju lati koba asa idanimo wa gege bi obinrin Omo-ile America Adulawo lonii."

en: So what did we do?
yo: Tori naa ki la se?

en: We went to the hair salon every six to eight weeks, without fail, to subject our scalps to harsh straightening chemicals beginning at a very young age -- sometimes eight, 10 -- that would result in hair loss, bald spots, sometimes even burns on the scalp.
yo: A lo si ile iserunloge ni ose mefa-mefa si mejo-mejo, laiye, lati jowo awo-ori wa fun awon eroja ti ki i se ti eda amurunna ti o lagbara bere lati ojo ori kekere -- nigba miiran odun mejo, 10 -- eyi yoo yori si irun jija, pipari, nigba miiran egbo le wa lori awo-ori.

en: We fry our hair at temperatures of 450 degrees Fahrenheit or higher almost daily, to maintain the straight look.
yo: "A n yan irun wa pelu oru ti odiwon re t""o 450 tabi ju bee lo lojoojumo, lati je k""o na sibe."

en: Or we simply cover our hair up with wigs and weaves, only to let our roots breathe in private where no one knows what's really going on under there.
yo: "Tabi ki a kan bo irun wa pelu irun-adabori ati ehun, lati le je ki gbongbo ori wa le mi nibi ti enikankan o ti ni mo nnkan t""o n sele nisale nbe."

en: We adopted these practices in our own communities, and so it's no wonder why today the typical ideal vision of a professional black woman, especially in corporate America, tends to look like this, rather than like this.
yo: "A gba awon isesi yii ni awujo tiwa, ko yani lenu idi t""o fi je pe lonii afojusun akosemose obinrin alawo dudu, paapaa julo ni America awon alakowe, le ri bayii, yato si bayii."

en: And she certainly doesn't look like this.
yo: O daju pe ko ri bayii.

en: In September of this year, a federal court ruled it lawful for a company to discriminate against hiring an employee based on if she or he wears dreadlocks.
yo: Ni osu Owewe odun yii, ile ejo apapo kan pa a lase fun ile-ise kan lati ma se eleyameya nipa igbanisise lori boya eni naa lokurin tabi lobinrin serun dada.

en: "In the case, the hiring manager in Mobile, Alabama is on record as saying, ""I'm not saying yours are messy, but you know what I'm talking about."
yo: "Ni ti oro naa, gbigba alamojuto si ile-ise ero-ibaraeni-soro, won gba ohun Alabama sile to n so wi pe, ""mi o so wi pe tiyin doti, sugbon e mo nnkan ti mo n so nipa e."

en: """ Well, what was she talking about?"
yo: """ O daa, kinni nnkan t""o n so nipa e?"

en: Did she think that they were ugly?
yo: Se o ro wi pe won burewa ni?

en: Or maybe they were just a little too Afrocentric and pro-black-looking for her taste.
yo: Abi boya won n se bi omo ile adulawo die ni ti won dabi alawo dudu ju bo se fe lo.

en: "Or maybe it's not about Afrocentricity, and it's more just about it being a little too ""urban"" for the professional setting."
yo: "Tabi boya ki i se nipa Ise-bi-omo-adulawo, t""o si je nitori won je ""igboro"" die fun awujo awon akosemose."

en: "Perhaps she had a genuine concern in that they looked ""scary"" and that they would intimidate the clients and their customer base."
yo: "Boya o ni ironu t""o to nipa pe irisi won ""banileru"" won o si maa deruba awon alajose ati egbe awon onibaraa won."

en: All of these words are ones that are too often associated with the stigma attached to natural hairstyles.
yo: "Gbogbo awon oro wonyi je awon t""o jo mo ideyesi ti o sopo mo asa irun amutorunwa."

en: And this has got to change.
yo: Eyi si ni lati yipada.

en: In 2013, a white paper published by the Deloitte Leadership Center for Inclusion, studied 3,000 individuals in executive leadership roles on the concept of covering in the workplace based on appearance, advocacy, affiliation and association.
yo: Ni odun 2013, iwe apileko ijoba ti Deloitte Leadership Center for Inclusion te jade, se ayewo egberun 3 awon eniyan ti won wa nipo adari ijoba lori ero bibori nibi ise lori irisi, igbawi, ile-ise ti won wa ati egbe.

en: When thinking about appearance-based covering, the study showed that 67 percent of women of color cover in the workplace based on their appearance.
yo: Nigba ti e ba n ronu nipa bibori to nise pelu irisi, iwadii naa fi han pe ida meta-din-laadorin awon obinrin ti won je alawo dudu ni won n bori nibi ise nitori irisi won.

en: Of the total respondents who admitted to appearance-based covering, 82 percent said that it was somewhat to extremely important for them to do so for their professional advancement.
yo: Ninu apapo awon abena-imo ti won gba fun ibori nipa irisi, ida meji-le-logorin so wi pe o se pataki pupo fun won lati se bee nitori ilosiwaju ikosemose won.

en: Now, this is Ursula Burns.
yo: Ni bayii, Ursula Burns re e

en: She is the first African-American female CEO of a Fortune 500 company -- of Xerox.
yo: Oun ni alase ati oludari omo ile America to je obinrin adulawo fun ile-ise Fortune 500 -- ti Xerox

en: She's known by her signature look, the one that you see here.
yo: Awon eniyan mo o fun irisi re, eyi ti e ri nibi.

en: A short, nicely trimmed, well-manicured Afro.
yo: Irun ile Adulawo to kere, ti won ge dogba daadaa, to ri itoju gidi.

en: "Burns is what we like to call a ""natural girl."
yo: "Burns ni a feran lati ma ape ""omobinrin to je abinibi."

en: """ And she is paving the way and showing what's possible for African-American women seeking to climb the corporate ladder, but still wishing to wear natural hairstyles."
yo: """ O n lana o si n safihan nnkan to se e se fun awon obinrin omo ile America to je adulawo ti won n wa lati gun akaba alakowe, sugbon to wun won lati gbe irun abinibi won."

en: But today the majority of African-American women who we still look to as leaders, icons and role models, still opt for a straight-hair look.
yo: Sugbon leni pupo ninu awon obinrin omo ile America to je adulawo ti a si n wo gege bi asiwaju, akoni ati awokose, si n lo fun irun nina.

en: Now, maybe it's because they want to -- this is authentically how they feel best -- but maybe -- and I bet -- a part of them felt like they had to in order to reach the level of success that they have attained today.
yo: Nisinyii, boya nitori pe won fe e bee ni -- bo se wun won julo niyi -- sugbon boya -- mo si mo -- apa kan ninu won yoo dabi wi pe won ni lati se e lati de ipele aseyori ti won ti de loni.

en: There is a natural hair movement that is sweeping the country and also in some places in Europe.
yo: Itesiwaju irun amutorunwa kan wa to n lo kaakiri orile-ede naa ati ni awon aye kookan nile Europe.

en: Millions of women are exploring what it means to transition to natural hair, and they're cutting off years and years of dry, damaged ends in order to restore their natural curl pattern.
yo: Egberun-lona-egberun awon obinrin ni won wo nnkan to jo lati ta koso si irun amutorunwa, won si n ge irun atodun-modun to ti gbe, ti owo re ti baje lati se adapada batani lilo amutorunwa

en: I know because I have been an advocate and an ambassador for this movement for roughly the last three years.
yo: Mo mo nitori pe mo ti je agbenuso ati asoju fun itesiwaju yii fun apapo odun meta.

en: After 27 years of excessive heat and harsh chemicals, my hair was beginning to show extreme signs of wear and tear.
yo: Leyin odun meta-din-logbon opo oru ati kemika to lagbara, irun mi ti bere sini safihan bibaje ati jija.

en: It was breaking off, it was thinning, looking just extremely dry and brittle.
yo: O n ja danu, o n tu, o gbe o si le gidi gan-an.

en: All those years of chasing that conventional image of beauty that we saw earlier was finally beginning to take its toll.
yo: Gbogbo odun ti a fi n le aworan ewa ojoojumo ti a ri nibere ti bere sini ni ipadabo.

en: "I wanted to do something about it, and so I started what I called the ""No Heat Challenge,"" where I would refrain from using heat styling tools on my hair for six months."
yo: "Mo fe se nnkan nipa re, nitori naa ni mo se bere nnkan ti mop e ni ""ipenija ko si oru,"" nibi ti mo ti maa jawo ninu lilo awon irinse oru si irun mi fun osu mefa."

en: And like a good millennial, I documented it on social media.
yo: Bii egberun odun to dara, mo se akojopo re sori ero ayelukara

en: I documented as I reluctantly cut off three to four inches of my beloved hair.
yo: Mo se akojopo re bi mo se n lo tiko lati ge insi meta si merin irun mi ti mo feran.

en: I documented as I struggled to master these natural hairstyles, and also as I struggled to embrace them and think that they actually looked good.
yo: Mo se akojopo bi mo se n tiraka lati mo awon isowo serun amutorunwa wonyi, ati bi mo se n tiraka lati gbawon mora ati lati ronu wi pe won dara

en: And I documented as my hair texture slowly began to change.
yo: Mo si se akojopo bi irisi irun mi se bere sini yi pada.

en: By sharing this journey openly, I learned that I was not the only woman going through this and that in fact there were thousands and thousands of other women who were longing to do the same.
yo: Pelu siso irinajo yi sita, mo kekoo wi pe emi nikan ko ni obinrin to n la eyi koja ati wi pe loooto egberun ati egberun awon obinrin miiran ni won wa ti won n foju sona lati se bee.

en: "So they would reach out to me and they would say, ""Cheyenne, how did you do that natural hairstyle that I saw you with the other day?"
yo: "Won maa n kan simi won a si so wi pe, ""Cheyenne, bawo lose se isowo serun ti mo ri pelu re lojosi yen?"

en: What new products have you started using that might be a little better for my hair texture as it begins to change?
yo: Eroja tuntun wo lo ti bere sini lo to le tun dara fun irisi irun mi bo ba se n yipada?

en: """ Or, ""What are some of the natural hair routines that I should begin to adopt to slowly restore the health of my hair?"
yo: """ Tabi, ""kini awon igbese irun amutorunwa ti mo gbodo bere sini se lati se adapada ilera irun mi diedie?"

en: """ But I also found that there were a large number of women who were extremely hesitant to take that first step because they were paralyzed by fear."
yo: """ Sugbon mo tun ri i wi pe opolopo awon obinrin lo wa ti won n kojale lati gbe igbese akoko yen nitori pe iberu ti sowon di alaile dide."

en: Fear of the unknown -- what would they now look like?
yo: Iberu ohun to le sele -- bawo ni awon se fe ri?

en: How would they feel about themselves with these natural hairstyles?
yo: Bawo ni awon se maa ri ara awon pelu isowo serun amutorun wa wonyi?

en: And most importantly to them, how would others view them?
yo: Nnkan to se pataki si won ju, iru oju wo ni awon toku yoo ma fi wo won?

en: Over the last three years of having numerous conversations with friends of mine and also complete strangers from around the world, I learned some really important things about how African-American women identify with their hair.
yo: Lati bi odun meta ti mo ti n ni asogba to po pelu awon ore mi ati awon araata jakejado agbaye, mo ti ko awon nnkan to se pataki pupo nipa bi awon obinrin omo ile America to je adulawo se n di mimo pelu irun won.

en: "And so when I think back to that hiring manager in Mobile, Alabama, I'd say, ""Actually, no."
yo: "Nigba ti mo ba ronu pada si gbigba alamojuto si Mobile, Alabama, maa so wi pe, ""ni pataki, rara."

en: We don't know what you're talking about.
yo: A o mo nnkan ti e n so.

en: """ But here are some things that we do know."
yo: """ Sugbon awon nnkan ti a mo ree."

en: We know that when black women embrace their love for their natural hair, it helps to undo generations of teaching that black in its natural state is not beautiful, or something to be hidden or covered up.
yo: A mo wi pe ti awon obinrin adulawo ba gba ife won fun irun amutorunwa won, o maa se iranwo lati se ayokuro iran ikekoo wi pe alawo dudu nipo abinibi o rewa, tabi nnkan to ye ko fi pamo tabi ki won bo.

en: We know that black women express their individuality and experience feelings of empowerment by experimenting with different hairstyles regularly.
yo: A mo wi pe awon obinrin adulawo n safihan imolara adani ati iriri nipa ironilagbara pelu sise ayewo pelu orisirisi isowo serun ni gbogbo igba.

en: And we also know that when we're invited to wear our natural hair in the workplace, it reinforces that we are uniquely valued and thus helps us to flourish and advance professionally.
yo: A si mo wi pe nigba ti won ba pe wa lati gbe irun amutorunwa wa wa sibi ise, o maa n se iwuri wi pe won moyi wa gan-an yoo si ran wa lowo lati dagbasoke ati lati tesiwaju gege bi akosemose.

en: I leave you with this.
yo: Maa fiyin sile pelu eyi.

en: In a time of racial and social tension, embracing this movement and others like this help us to rise above the confines of the status quo.
yo: Lasiko eleyameya ati ainifokanbale awujo, gbigba itesiwaju yii ati ati awon miiran bi eyi maa n ranwa lowo lati gori ifunpinpin bi a se wa.

en: So when you see a woman with braids or locks draping down her back, or you notice your colleague who has stopped straightening her hair to work, do not simply approach her and admire and ask her if you can touch it -- Really appreciate her.
yo: Nitori naa ti e ba ri obinrin kan pelu irun kiko tabi dada to gun de eyin re, tabi e se akiyesi akegbe yin to ti dawo nina irun re wa sibi ise duro, e ma kan lo ba a ki e ma yin in ati ki e beere boya e le fowo kan-an nikan -- E mo riri re.

en: Applaud her.
yo: E sa a ni atewo.

en: Heck, even high-five her if that's what you feel so inclined to do.
yo: Kasaa, koda e bo o lowo ti o ba se wi pe nnkan ti emi dari yin lati se niyen.

en: Because this -- this is more than about a hairstyle.
yo: Nitori eyi -- eyi ju nipa isowo serun lo.

en: It's about self-love and self-worth.
yo: Nipa iferan ara eni ati imoyi ara eni ni.

en: It's about being brave enough not to fold under the pressure of others' expectations.
yo: Nipa nini igboya lati ma kaa sabe ipa ireti awon toku ni.

en: And about knowing that making the decision to stray from the norm does not define who we are, but it simply reveals who we are.
yo: Nipa mimo pe sise ipinnu lati yabara lati asa naa o sapejuwe iru eni ti a je, sugbon yoo safihan iru eni ti a je.

en: And finally, being brave is easier when we can count on the compassion of others.
yo: Ni ipari, nini igboya rorun nigba ti a ba le gbarale ikaaanu awon to ku.

en: So after today, I certainly hope that we can count on you.
yo: Nitori naa leyin onii, mo lero wi pe a le gbarale e yin.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: Your fingerprints reveal more than you think
yo: Onte-ika yin n safihan nnkan ju bi e se lero lo

en: "Do you ever stop and think, during a romantic dinner, ""I've just left my fingerprints all over my wine glass."
yo: "Nje e ti e ti duro ki e si ronu, lasiko ounje-ale ipekinreki-ololufe kan, ""mo sese fi onte-ika mi si gbogbo ara ife-alawojiji oti mi ni."

en: Or do you ever worry, when you visit a friend, about leaving a little piece of you behind on every surface that you touch?
yo: Abi se e ro o ri, nigba ti e ba lo ki ore yin kan, nipa fifi orike die lara yin sile ni gbogbo aye ti e ti fowo kan?

en: And even this evening, have you paid any attention to sit without touching anything?
yo: Koda lale yii, nje e ti se akiyesi jijoko lai fi owo kan nnkankan?

en: Well, you're not alone.
yo: O daa, e o da wa.

en: Thankfully, criminals underestimate the power of fingerprints, too.
yo: Ikunfunope, awon odaran n safojudi agbara onte-ika, bakan naa.

en: And I'm not just talking about the twisted parting of lines that make our fingerprint unique.
yo: Mi o so nipa awon ila lilopo ti won je ki onte-ika wa yato gedengbe nikan.

en: I'm talking about an entire world of information hiding in a small, often invisible thing.
yo: "Mo n so nipa odidi agbaramuramu ifitoni t""o sa pamo sara nnkan kekere, ti o se e foju ri lopo igba."

en: In fact, fingerprints are made up of molecules that belong to three classes: sweat molecules that we all produce in very different amounts molecules that we introduce into our body and then we sweat out and molecules that we may contaminate our fingertips with when we come across substances like blood, paint, grease, but also invisible substances.
yo: Ni ooto, onte-ika je apapo awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po ti won wa ni eka meta: ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po aagun ti a n se ni iye ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po to yato ti a n lo sinu ara wa ti a ba si laagun sita ati awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po ti o n sakoba eti omo-ika wa ti a ba se alabapade awon nnkan bi eje, oda, girisi, ati awon nnkan aifojuri.

en: And molecules are the storytellers of who we are and what we've been up to.
yo: Ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po je asotan nipa iru eni ti a n se ati ati nnkan ti a ti se.

en: We just need to have the right technology to make them talk.
yo: A ko nilo lati ni imo-ero to to lati je ki won soro ni.

en: So let me take you on a journey of unthinkable capabilities.
yo: E je ki n muu yin rin irinajo ikapa alailero kan.

en: Katie has been raped and her lifeless body has been found in the woods three days later, after her disappearance.
yo: Won ti fipa ba Katie lajosepo won si ti ri oku re ninu igbo, leyin ojo meta ti o poora.

en: The police is targeting three suspects, having narrowed down the search from over 20 men who had been seen in that area on the same day.
yo: Awon olopaa n topa awon afurasi meta, leyin igba ti won mu itopa iwadii awon afurasi won wale lati 20 okunrin ti won ti ri ni agbegbe naa lojo yen naa.

en: The only piece of evidence is two very faint, overlapping fingerprints on the tape that was found wrapped around Katie's neck.
yo: Eri kan soso ni onte-ika meji ti ko han rere, agbelerawon lori ajabule ti won we mo orun Katie ti won ri.

en: Often, faint and overlapping fingerprints cannot help the police to make an identification.
yo: "Lopo igba, onte-ika ti ko han rere, t""o wa lori ara won ko le ran awon olopaa lowo lati se idanimo."

en: And until recently, this might have been the end of the road, but this is where we can make the difference.
yo: Afi laipe yii, eyi o ba ti je opin ona, sugbon ibi ti a ti le se atunse niyi.

en: The tape is sent to our labs, where we're asked to use our cutting-edge technology to help with the investigation.
yo: "Won fi ajabule naa ranse si aye fun imo-ijinle wa, nibi ti won ti ni k""a lo imo-ero alailegbe wa lati se iranlowo fun itopinpin naa."

en: And here, we use an existing form of mass spectrometry imaging technology that we have further developed and adapted specifically for the molecular and imaging analysis of fingerprints.
yo: Nibi, a lo eda imo-ero asaworan ero igbon agbon nla to wa nile ti a ti se idagbasoke re siwaju sii ti a se ni adayanri fun iyanana ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po ati aworan onte-ika.

en: In essence, we fire a UV laser at the print, and we cause the desorption of the molecules from the print, ready to be captured by the mass spectrometer.
yo: "Ni pataki, a bena itansan UV si onte naa, a si mu ki ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po naa o yo kuro lara onte naa, t""o ti se tan lati di yiya pelu ero odiwon-ibilu akopo."

en: Mass spectrometry measures the weight of the molecules -- or as we say, the mass -- and those numbers that you see there, they indicate that mass.
yo: Ero odiwon-ibilu akopo maa diwon iwuwo ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po naa -- tabi bi a se so, iwon akopo -- ati awon onka ti e n wo nibe yen, won n safihan iwon akopo yen.

en: But more crucially, they indicate who those molecules are -- whether I'm seeing paracetamol or something more sinister, forensically speaking.
yo: Sugbon ni pataki julo, won n safihan eni ti awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po wonyi je -- boya mo n ri paracetamol tabi nnkan to tun lewu ju bee lo, ti a ba n soro nilana imo-ijinle.

en: We applied this technology to the evidence that we have and we found the presence of condom lubricants.
yo: A samulo imo-ero yii si eri ti a ni a de ri iduro imudiyiyo roba idaaabobo.

en: In fact, we've developed protocols that enable us to even suggest what brand of condom might have been used.
yo: Loooto, a ti se idagbasoke ilana-aatele ti yoo fun wa ni anfaani lati dabaa iru roba idaaabobo ti won lo.

en: So we pass this information to the police, who, meanwhile, have obtained a search warrant and they found the same brand of condom in Dalton's premises.
yo: A fi afitoni yii ranse si awon olopaa, ti won, laimo, ti gba ase lati tule won si ti ri iru roba idaaabobo yii kan naa ni ayika ile Dalton.

en: And with Dalton and Thomson also having records for sexual assaults, then it is Chapman that may become the less likely suspect.
yo: Pelu pe Dalton ati Thomson tun ni akosile ifipabanilopo, a je wi pe Chapman lo le di eni ti a le ma furasi pupo

en: But is this information enough to make an arrest?
yo: Sugbon se afitoni yii to lati fi ase oba mu?

en: Of course not, and we are asked to delve deeper with our investigation.
yo: Rara, won si so fun wa pe ka tusu desale ikoko pelu iwadii wa.

en: So we found out, also, the presence of other two very interesting molecules.
yo: A sawari re, bakan naa, iduro awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po meji to yanilenu.
