en: One is an antidepressant, and one is a very special molecule.
yo: Okan je apa-irewesi-okan, okan si je ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po molecule to yato gidi gan-an.

en: It only forms in your body if you drink alcohol and consume cocaine at the same time.
yo: O maa n di sara nigba ti e ba mu oti tabi lo oogun-oloro lasiko kan naa.

en: And alcohol is known to potentiate the effects of cocaine, so here, we now have a hint on the state of mind of the individual whilst perpetrating the crime.
yo: "A si mo oti pe o maa n se irolagbara fun ipa oogun-oloro, nitori naa nibi, a ti ni afitoni nipa ipo emi eni naa nigba t""o n hu iwa odaran naa."

en: We passed this information to the police, and they found out that, actually, Thomson is a drug addict, and he also has a medical record for psychotic episodes, for which presumably the antidepressant was prescribed.
yo: A fi afitoni yii ranse si awon olopaa, won sawari re pe, loooto, Thomson kundun oogun-oloro, o si ni akosile iwosan agana, fun eyi to se wi pe boya tori re ni won se se asayan apa-irewesi-okan.

en: So now Thomson becomes the more likely suspect.
yo: Ni bayii Thomson ti di afurasi to se e se.

en: But the reality is that I still don't know where these molecules are coming from, from which fingerprint, and who those two fingerprints belong to.
yo: Sugbon ododo ibe ni wi pe mi o tii mo ibi ti awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po wonyi ti n wa, lati onte-ika wo, ati eni ti awon onte-ika meji yii je tire.

en: Fear not.
yo: E ma beru.

en: Mass spectrometry imaging can help us further.
yo: Ero igbon agbon nla le ran wa lowo siwaju sii.

en: In fact, the technology is so powerful that we can see where these molecules are on a fingerprint.
yo: Lododo, imo-ero naa lagbara gidi gan-an debi wi pe a le ri ibi ti awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po wonyi wa lori onte-ika.

en: Like you see in this video, every single one of those peaks corresponds to a mass, every mass to a molecule, and we can interrogate the software, by selecting each of those molecules, as to where they are present on a fingermark.
yo: Gege bi e se ri i ninu foran yii, okookan awon ti won gaju wonyen tumo si iwon-okun, iwon-okun kookan si ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po kan, a si le fi oro wa ohun-elo ero-ayarabiasa ti o se e fowo kan naa lenu wo, pelu mimu ikookan awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po wonyen, nipa ibi ti won wa lori apa-ika naa.

en: And some images are not very revealing, some are better, some are really good.
yo: Awon aworan kan o ki n f'ara han daadaa, awon kan dara, awon kan dara gidi gan-an.

en: And we can create multiple images of the same mark -- in theory, hundreds of images of the same fingerprint -- for as many of the molecules that we have detected.
yo: A seda opo aworan apa kan naa -- ni tiori, ogorun aworan onte-ika kan naa -- fun gbogbo iye ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po ti a ti ri.

en: So step one for overlapping fingerprints, chances are, especially if they come from different individuals, that the molecular composition is not identical, so let's ask the software to visualize those unique molecules just present in one fingermark and not in the other one.
yo: "Igbese akoko fun onte-ika to gori ara won, anfaani ni pe, paapaa julo ti won ba wa latara orisirisi eniyan, pe iseda ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po naa ko jora won, nitori naa e je k""a beere lowo ohun-elo ero-ayarabiasa ti o se e fowo kan lati wo awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po aseyato to wa ninu onte-ika kan ti o si ni ikeji."

en: By doing so, that's how we can separate the two ridge patterns.
yo: Pelu sise bee, bi a se le se iyasoto batani etii mejeeji niyen.

en: And this is really important because the police now are able to identify one of the two fingerprints, which actually corresponds to Katie.
yo: Eyi si se pataki nitori awon olopaa le toka si okan ninu onte-ika mejeeji bayii, to ba ti Katie mu.

en: And they've been able to say so because they've compared the two separate images with one taken posthumously from Katie.
yo: Won ti le so bee nitori pe won ti fi awora meji otooto naa wera won pelu ikan ti won mu latara oku Katie.

en: So now, we can concentrate on one fingerprint only -- that of the killer's.
yo: Ni bayii, a le gbajumo onte-ika kan soso -- to je ti asekupani yen.

en: So then, step two where are these three molecules that I've seen?
yo: Leyin naa, igbese keji awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po meta wonyi ti mo ti ri yii da?

en: Well, let's interrogate the software -- show me where they are.
yo: "O daa, e je k""a fi oro wa ohun-elo ero-ayarabiasa ti o se e fowo kan naa lenu wo -- fi ibi ti won wa han mi."

en: And by doing this, only portions of the image of the killer's fingerprint show up.
yo: "Pelu sise eyi, apa kan aworan onte-ika asekupani naa nikan l""o han."

en: In other words, those substances are only present in the killer's print.
yo: Iyen ni wi pe, awon nnkan wonyen wa ninu onte asekupani naa nikan ni.

en: So now our molecular findings start matching very nicely the police intelligence about Thomson, should that fingerprint belong to him.
yo: Ni bayii asawari ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po wa bere sini ba iwadii awon olopa nipa Thomson mu daadaa, ti o ba je wi pe oun lo ni onte-ika yen.

en: But the reality is that that print is still not good enough to make an identification.
yo: Sugbon otito ibe ni wi pe onte yen o tii dara to lati se idanimo.

en: Step three: since we can generate hundreds of images of the same fingerprint, why don't we superimpose them, and by doing so, try to improve the rich pattern of continuity and clarity?
yo: Igbese keta: nigba to je wi pe a le seda ogorun aworan onte ika kan naa, ki lo de ti a o gbe won sori ara won, ti a ba se bee, ka gbiyanju lati se afikun batani itesiwaju ati ifojuhan to kun?

en: That's the result.
yo: Esi naa niyen.

en: We now have a very clear image of the fingerprint and the police can run it through the database.
yo: A ti wa ni aworan onte-ika to han kedere awon olopaa si le lo o lori aka-iwifun-alalaye.

en: The match comes out to Thomson.
yo: Ibamu naa jade si ti Thomson.

en: Thomson is our killer.
yo: Thomson ni asekupani wa.

en: Katie, the suspects and the circumstances of the crime aren't real, but the story contains elements of the real police casework we've been confronted with, and is a composite of the intelligence that we can provide -- that we have been able to provide the police.
yo: Katie, afurasi naa ati awon nnkan to ro mo iwa-odaran naa kii se tooto, sugbon itan naa ni awon omole ise-iwadii olopaa tooto ti a ti koju re, o si je eka iwadii ti a le pese -- ti a ti pese fun awon olopaa.

en: And I'm really, really thrilled that after nine years of intense research, as of 2017, we are able to contribute to police investigations.
yo: Inu mi si n dun gidi gan-an pe leyin odun mesan iwadii alagbara, ni odun 2017, a ni anfaani lati dasi itopinpin awon olopaa.

en: Mine is no longer a dream; it's a goal.
yo: Temi kii se ala mo; ipinnu ni.

en: We're going to do this wider and wider, bigger and bigger, and we're going to know more about the suspect, and we're going to build an identikit.
yo: A maa se eyi ni fife ati fife, nla ati nla, a si ma nimo si nipa afurasi naa, a si ma seda ero-idanimo.

en: I believe this is also a new era for criminal profiling.
yo: Mo nigbagbo pe igba otun ni eyi fun sise akosile iwa-odaran.

en: The work of the criminologist draws on the expert recognition of behavioral patterns that have been observed before to belong to a certain type, to a certain profile.
yo: Ise iwadii iwa odaran maa n lo idamo agba-oje nipa batani ihuwasi ti won ti sakiyesi tele pe o je ti eya kan, si akosile kan.

en: As opposed to this expert but subjective evaluation, we're trying to do the same thing, but from the molecular makeup of the fingerprint, and the two can work together.
yo: Ni atako si agba-oje yii sugbon ni asegbe igbelewon, a n gbiyanju lati se nnkan kan naa, sugbon latara ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po to papo di onte-ika, mejeei si le sise papo.

en: I did say that molecules are storytellers, so information on your health, your actions, your lifestyle, your routines, they're all there, accessible in a fingerprint.
yo: Mo so wi pe awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po je asotan, nitori naa awon afitoni nipa ilera yin, isesi yin, igbeaye yin, ise yin, gbogbo won lo wa nibe, to se e wo ninu onte-ika kan.

en: And molecules are the storytellers of our secrets in just a touch.
yo: Awon ida-kekeeke-nnkan-ti-o-su-po je asotan nipa asiri wa pelu ifowokan kan.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: (Audience) Wow.
yo: (Awon onworan) Wow.

en: Our immigration conversation is broken - here's how to have a better one
yo: Asogba iwole latokere wa ti fo - bi a se le ni eyi to dara re e.

en: We often hear these days that the immigration system is broken.
yo: A maa n gbo lopo igba lasiko yii pe eto iwole latokeere ti fo.

en: I want to make the case today that our immigration conversation is broken and to suggest some ways that, together, we might build a better one.
yo: Mo fe se ipejo loni pe asogba iwole latokeere wa ti fo ati lati dabaa awon ona ti, lapapo, a le pese eyi to dara.

en: In order to do that, I'm going to propose some new questions about immigration, the United States and the world, questions that might move the borders of the immigration debate.
yo: Lati le se iyen, maa dabaa awon ibeere tuntun nipa iwole latokeere, orile-ede United States ati agbaye, awon ibeere ti o le sun ariyanjiyan ibode iwole latokere.

en: I'm not going to begin with the feverish argument that we're currently having, even as the lives and well-being of immigrants are being put at risk at the US border and far beyond it.
yo: Mi o ni bere pelu ariyanjiyan to n sojojo ti a n ni lowolowo yii, koda bi igbeaye ati igbayegbadun awon asikiri se n wa ninu ewu ni enu-ibode orile-ede US ati ju bee lo.

en: Instead, I'm going to begin with me in graduate school in New Jersey in the mid-1990s, earnestly studying US history, which is what I currently teach as a professor at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee.
yo: Dipo bee, maa bere pelu ara mi ni ile-eko akekoo-jade ni New Jersey ni arin asiko 1990, ti mo n kekoo nipa itan orile-ede US, to je nnkan ti mo n ko lowolowo gege bi ojogbon ni fasiti Vanderbilt ni Nashville, Tennessee.

en: And when I wasn't studying, sometimes to avoid writing my dissertation, my friends and I would go into town to hand out neon-colored flyers, protesting legislation that was threatening to take away immigrants' rights.
yo: Nigba ti mi o ba kekoo, nigba miran lati sa fun kiko apileko abo iwadii mi, emi ati awon ore mi maa wo igboro lo lati lo fun awon eniyan ni iwe-ilewo alara-n-bara awo, to n fi ehonu han si ofin to n dukoko lati gba eto awon asikiri.

en: Our flyers were sincere, they were well-meaning, they were factually accurate.
yo: Awon iwe ilewo wa sooto, won nitumo gidi, won peye ni otito.

en: But I realize now, they were also kind of a problem.
yo: Sugbon o wa yemi bayii, won tun fee je orisi wahala kan.

en: "Here's what they said: ""Don't take away immigrant rights to public education, to medical services, to the social safety net."
yo: "Nnkan ti won so re e: ""e ma gba eto awon asikiri si eko gbogbogbo, si eto ilere, si awon aabo awujo."

en: They work hard.
yo: Won n sise karakara.

en: They pay taxes.
yo: Won n sanwo-ori.

en: They're law-abiding.
yo: Won n tele ofin.

en: They use social services less than Americans do.
yo: Won o lo awon ile-ise awujo to bi awon omo ile America se n lo o.

en: They're eager to learn English, and their children serve in the US military all over the world.
yo: Won nife lati ko ede geesi, awon omo won si n sinru-ilu ninu iko omo-ogun orile-ede US kaakiri agbaye.

en: """ Now, these are, of course, arguments that we hear every day."
yo: """ Bayii, awon wonyi ni, bee ni, awon ariyanjiyan ti a n gbo lojoojumo."

en: Immigrants and their advocates use them as they confront those who would deny immigrants their rights or even exclude them from society.
yo: Awon asikiri ati awon agbenuso won n lo won lati fi koju awon ti won yoo fi eto awon asikiri du won tabi ti won fe yo won kuro ninu awujo.

en: And up to a certain point, it makes perfect sense that these would be the kinds of claims that immigrants' defenders would turn to.
yo: De ipele kan, o mu opolo dani pe awon wonyi yoo je iru awijare ti awon ti won n gbe leyin awon asikiri maa koju si.

en: But in the long term, and maybe even in the short term, I think these arguments can be counterproductive.
yo: Sugbon nigba pipe, ati boya lasiko die, mo ro wi pe awon ariyanjiyan wonyi le dira won lowo.

en: Because it's always an uphill battle to defend yourself on your opponent's terrain.
yo: Tori ogun to lagbara lo maa n je lati gbeja ara yin ni agbegbe alatako yin.

en: And, unwittingly, the handouts my friends and I were handing out and the versions of these arguments that we hear today were actually playing the anti-immigrants game.
yo: pelu aimokan, iwe-ilewo ti emi ati awon ore mi n fun awon eniyan ati eda awon ariyanjiyan wonyi ti a n gbo loni n tayo atako-asikiri ni.

en: We were playing that game in part by envisioning that immigrants were outsiders, rather than, as I'm hoping to suggest in a few minutes, people that are already, in important ways, on the inside.
yo: A n ta ayo yen lorike pelu oju-iwoye pe araata ni awon asikiri, yato si pe, bi mo se n lero lati da laba ni iseju die, awon eniyan ti won ti, ni awon ona to se pataki, wa ninu ile tele.

en: It's those who are hostile to immigrants, the nativists, who have succeeded in framing the immigration debate around three main questions.
yo: Awon ti won n deyesi awon asikiri, awon alatileyin omo-ilu, ti won ti saseyori nibi siso ariyanjiyan iwole latokere mo koko ibeere meta.

en: First, there's the question of whether immigrants can be useful tools.
yo: Akoko, ibeere kan wa nipa boya awon asikiri le di irinse to wulo.

en: How can we use immigrants?
yo: Bawo la se le lo awon asikiri?

en: Will they make us richer and stronger?
yo: Se won maa je ka lowo ka si tun lagbara sii?

en: The nativist answer to this question is no, immigrants have little or nothing to offer.
yo: Idahun awon alatileyin omo ilu si ibeere yii ni rara, awon asikiri ni die tabi won o ni nnkankan lati fun wa.

en: The second question is whether immigrants are others.
yo: Ibeere keji ni wi pe boya awon asikiri je awon toku.

en: Can immigrants become more like us?
yo: Nje awon asikiri le di ara wa?

en: Are they capable of becoming more like us?
yo: Se won nikapa lati dabi wa?

en: Are they capable of assimilating?
yo: Se won nikapa lati farajowa?

en: Are they willing to assimilate?
yo: Se won se tan lati farajowa?

en: Here, again, the nativist answer is no, immigrants are permanently different from us and inferior to us.
yo: Nibi, leekan sii, idahun awon alatileyin omo-ilu ni rara, awon asikiri yato patapata si wa won si kere siwa.

en: And the third question is whether immigrants are parasites.
yo: Ibeere keta ni boya awon asikiri je ajofe.

en: Are they dangerous to us?
yo: Se won lewu fun wa?

en: And will they drain our resources?
yo: Se won maa gbon ohun-alumoni wa gbe?

en: Here, the nativist answer is yes and yes, immigrants pose a threat and they sap our wealth.
yo: Nibi, idahun awon omo ilu ni bee ni ati bee ni, awon asikiri le fa ewu won si n gbon oroo wa gbe.

en: I would suggest that these three questions and the nativist animus behind them have succeeded in framing the larger contours of the immigration debate.
yo: Maa da a laba wi pe awon ibeere meta wonyi ati ipinnu awon alatileyin omo-ilu to wa leyin won ti se aseyori nibi sise awon igun nla nipa ariyanjiyan iwole latokere.

en: These questions are anti-immigrant and nativist at their core, built around a kind of hierarchical division of insiders and outsiders, us and them, in which only we matter, and they don't.
yo: Awon ibeere wonyi je atako-awon asikiri ati awon alatileyin omo ilu paraku, ti won sopo mo ipin onipele agbeka awon arale ati araata, awa ati awon, to je wi pe awa la se pataki julo, ti awon o si ri bee.

en: And what gives these questions traction and power beyond the circle of committed nativists is the way they tap into an everyday, seemingly harmless sense of national belonging and activate it, heighten it and inflame it.
yo: Nnkan to n fun awon ibeere wonyi ni okiki ati agbara tayo egbe awon alatileyin omo-ilu ti won ni afokansin ni bi won se n pin ninu oye ajogbepo apapo ojoojumo ti o lewu ti won si n samulo re, ti won n gbe e soke ti won si n fun-un lagbara.

en: Nativists commit themselves to making stark distinctions between insiders and outsiders.
yo: Awon alatileyin omo-ilu ti jowo ara won fun sise iyato to foju han laaarin araale ati araata.

en: But the distinction itself is at the heart of the way nations define themselves.
yo: Sugbon iyato naa fun ra re wa ni gbungun ona ti awon orile-ede n gba se apejuwe ara won.

en: The fissures between inside and outside, which often run deepest along lines of race and religion, are always there to be deepened and exploited.
yo: Iyato to wa laaarin inu ati ita, to se wi pe lopo igba o maa n sa wo oju ona iran ati esin, maa n wa nibe lati jinu ati lati di amulo.

en: And that potentially gives nativist approaches resonance far beyond those who consider themselves anti-immigrant, and remarkably, even among some who consider themselves pro-immigrant.
yo: Iyen si n fun awon alatileyin omo ilu ni ona-imuse alatapada tayo awon ti won rira won bii atako awon asikiri, ati lilu logo-enu, koda laaarin awon kan ti won rira won gege bi alatileyin awon asikiri.

en: So, for example, when Immigrants Act allies answer these questions the nativists are posing, they take them seriously.
yo: Fun apeere, nigba ti awon alatileyin iwe-ofin awon asikiri dahun awon ibeere ti awon alatileyin omo-ilu n gbe jade wonyi, won mu won lokukudun.

en: They legitimate those questions and, to some extent, the anti-immigrant assumptions that are behind them.
yo: Won so awon ibeere wonyi di ofin ati, de awon aye kan, imoonu awon atako-asikiri ti won wa leyin won.

en: When we take these questions seriously without even knowing it, we're reinforcing the closed, exclusionary borders of the immigration conversation.
yo: Bi a ba mu awon ibeere wonyi lokunkundun lainimo nipa e, a n se iwuri fun titi, ayokuro asogba ibode iwole latokere.

en: So how did we get here?
yo: Tori naa bawo la se debi?

en: How did these become the leading ways that we talk about immigration?
yo: Bawo ni awon wonyi se di ona to n lewaju ti a fi n soro nipa iwole latokere?

en: Here, we need some backstory, which is where my history training comes in.
yo: Nibi, a nilo awon itan-ipile, to je ibi ti idanileko itan mi yoo ti wole.

en: During the first century of the US's status as an independent nation, it did very little to restrict immigration at the national level.
yo: Lasiko orun odun akoko ipo orile-ede US gege bi orile-ede olominira, o se die lati se idiwo iwole latokere ni ipele orile-ede.

en: In fact, many policymakers and employers worked hard to recruit immigrants to build up industry and to serve as settlers, to seize the continent.
yo: Ni tooto, opolopo awon asofin ati awon osise n sise karakara lati gba awon asikiri lati seda ile-ise ati lati sise gege bi atedo, lati gba ekun naa.

en: But after the Civil War, nativist voices rose in volume and in power.
yo: Sugbon leyin ogun abele, ohun awon alatileyin omo-ilu goke ni yiyi ati ni agbara

en: The Asian, Latin American, Caribbean and European immigrants who dug Americans' canals, cooked their dinners, fought their wars and put their children to bed at night were met with a new and intense xenophobia, which cast immigrants as permanent outsiders who should never be allowed to become insiders.
yo: Awon ile Asia, Latin America, Caribbean ati awon asikiri ile-Europe ti won gbe koto-idaminu awon omo-ile America, ti won n dana ale won, ti won n jagun won ti won si n re awon omo won te lale ni won se alabaapade iberu araata tuntun to le, to pin awon asikiri gege bi araata patapata ti won o gbodo gba laye lati di araale.

en: By the mid-1920s, the nativists had won, erecting racist laws that closed out untold numbers of vulnerable immigrants and refugees.
yo: Nigba ti yo fi di arin asiko 1920, awon alatileyin omo-ilu ti bori, gbigbe ofin eleyameya dide se agbetisita iye awon asikiri to kogun-sewu ati awon ogunlende ti won o so sita.

en: Immigrants and their allies did their best to fight back, but they found themselves on the defensive, caught in some ways in the nativists' frames.
yo: Awon asikiri ati awon alatileyin won sapa won lati ja pada, sugbon won bara won leni to n se atileyin, won kawon ni awon ona kookan ninu ise atileyin fun awon alatileyin omo-ilu.

en: When nativists said that immigrants weren't useful, their allies said yes, they are.
yo: Nigba ti awon alatileyin omo-ilu so wi pe awon asikiri o wulo, awon alatileyin won ni bee ni, won wulo.

en: When nativists accused immigrants of being others, their allies promised that they would assimilate.
yo: Nigba ti awon alatileyin omo-ilu fi esun kan awon asikiri wi pe awon toku niwon, awon alatileyin won se adehun pe won maa fara jowon.

en: When nativists charged that immigrants were dangerous parasites, their allies emphasized their loyalty, their obedience, their hard work and their thrift.
yo: Nigba ti awon alatileyin omo-ilu fesun kan won pe awon asikiri je ajofe to lewu, awon alatileyin won se ifirinle ijoloooto won, igboran won, isise kara won ati ainawo-ninakuna won.

en: Even as advocates welcomed immigrants, many still regarded immigrants as outsiders to be pitied, to be rescued, to be uplifted and to be tolerated, but never fully brought inside as equals in rights and respect.
yo: Koda bi awon agbenuso se n gba awon asikiri mora, opo si n ka awon asikiri si araata to ye ki won kaanu, to ye ki won doola, to ye ki won gbega ki won si gba mora, sugbon ti won o ni mu wole gege bi adogba ni eto ati owo.

en: After World War II, and especially from the mid-1960s until really recently, immigrants and their allies turned the tide, overthrowing mid-20th century restriction and winning instead a new system that prioritized family reunification, the admission of refugees and the admission of those with special skills.
yo: Leyin ogun agbaye keji, paapaa julo lati arin asiko 1960 yatosi aipe yii, awon asikiri ati awon alatileyin won n fa isele pada seyin, ti won fe ti idiwo orun odun arin-ogun subu ati ibori dipo eto tuntun ti yoo gbajumo ikojopo awon ebi, gbigba awon ogunlende ati gbigba awon ti won ni imoose to yato.

en: But even then, they didn't succeed in fundamentally changing the terms of the debate, and so that framework endured, ready to be taken up again in our own convulsive moment.
yo: Sugbon nigba naa, won o saseyori ninu sise ayipada ipile awon adehun ariyanjiyan naa, nitori naa eto-igbese ise naa duro, to setan lati di lilo pada ni asiko ipari titi wa.

en: That conversation is broken.
yo: Asogba yen ti fo.

en: The old questions are harmful and divisive.
yo: Awon ibeere atijo naa lewu ati ipinya.

en: So how do we get from that conversation to one that's more likely to get us closer to a world that is fairer, that is more just, that's more secure?
yo: Bawo la se fe kuro lati asogba yen si eyi to le muwa sumo ile-agbaye kan to je oni deede, to je adogba, ti o lewu pupo?

en: I want to suggest that what we have to do is one of the hardest things that any society can do: to redraw the boundaries of who counts, of whose life, whose rights and whose thriving matters.
yo: Mo fe dabaa wi pe nnkan ti a ni lati se je okan ninu awon nnkan to le ti awujo kankan le se: lati se atunya awon enu-ala eni to se pataki, ti igbesi aye re, ti eto re ati idagbasoke se pataki.

en: We need to redraw the boundaries.
yo: A nilo lati se atunya awon enu-ala naa

en: We need to redraw the borders of us.
yo: A nilo lati se atunya awon ibode wa.

en: In order to do that, we need to first take on a worldview that's widely held but also seriously flawed.
yo: Lati le se iyen, a nilo lati koko gbajumo oju-iwoye ti awon eniyan ni sugbon ti won ti ni akude gidi gan-an.

en: According to that worldview, there's the inside of the national boundaries, inside the nation, which is where we live, work and mind our own business.
yo: Gege bi oju-iwoye yen, inu awon enu-ala apapo wa, ninu orile-ede naa, to je ibi ti a n gbe, ti a ti n sise ti a si n mowon arawa.

en: And then there's the outside; there's everywhere else.
yo: Ita re naa wa; ibi gbogbo naa wa.

en: According to this worldview, when immigrants cross into the nation, they're moving from the outside to the inside, but they remain outsiders.
yo: Gege bi oju-iwoye yii, nigba ti awon asikiri ba ta koso si orile-ede naa, won n gbera lati ita sinu ile, sugbon won o si je araata.

en: Any power or resources they receive are gifts from us rather than rights.
yo: Eyikeyii agbara tabi ohun-elo ti won ba gba gege bi ebun latodo wa yatosi awon eto won

en: Now, it's not hard to see why this is such a commonly held worldview.
yo: Ni bayii, ko soro lati ri eredi ti eyi fi je iru oju-iwoye ti awon eniyan ni to wopo.

en: It's reinforced in everyday ways that we talk and act and behave, down to the bordered maps that we hang up in our schoolrooms.
yo: Won se iwuri fun-un ni awon ona ojoojumo bi a se n soro ati bi a se n se ati bi a se n huwa, debi aworan enubode ti a fi ko soke ninu awon yara-ile-eko wa.

en: The problem with this worldview is that it just doesn't correspond to the way the world actually works, and the way it has worked in the past.
yo: Isoro to wa pelu oju-iwoye yii ni wi pe ko papo mo ona ti ile agbaye n gba sise, ati ona ti o ti gba sise seyin.

en: Of course, American workers have built up wealth in society.
yo: Bee ni, awon osise ile America ti pese oro ni awujo.

en: But so have immigrants, particularly in parts of the American economy that are indispensable and where few Americans work, like agriculture.
yo: Bee naa ni awon asikiri, pataki julo ni apa kan oro-aje ile America ti o se e feku ati ibi ti die ninu awon omo ile America ti n sise, bii ise agbe.

en: Since the nation's founding, Americans have been inside the American workforce.
yo: Latigba ti won ti da orile-ede naa sile, ni awon omo ile America ti wa ninu egbe-osise ile America.

en: Of course, Americans have built up institutions in society that guarantee rights.
yo: Bee ni, awon omo ile America ti ko awon ile-ise sinu awujo to n se idaniloju eto.

en: But so have immigrants.
yo: Bee naa ni awon asikiri.

en: They've been there during every major social movement, like civil rights and organized labor, that have fought to expand rights in society for everyone.
yo: Won ti wa nibe lasiko koko itesiwaju awujo, bii eto ara-ilu ati egbe awon osise, ti a ti ja lati fe eto loju ninu awujo fun gbogbo eniyan.

en: So immigrants are already inside the struggle for rights, democracy and freedom.
yo: Nitori naa awon asikiri ti wa ninu ija fun eto, ijoba awarawa ati ominira

en: And finally, Americans and other citizens of the Global North haven't minded their own business, and they haven't stayed within their own borders.
yo: Lakotan, awon omo ile America ati awon awon omo-ilu toku ni Global North o mowon ara won, won o si tii duro saarin ibode tiwon.

en: They haven't respected other nations' borders.
yo: Won o tii ni ibowo fun enubode awon orile-ede toku.

en: They've gone out into the world with their armies, they've taken over territories and resources, and they've extracted enormous profits from many of the countries that immigrants are from.
yo: Won ti jade lo sinu aye pelu awon omo-ogun won, won ti gba isakoso awon ile ati ohun alumoni, won si ti yo ere to po lara orile-ede pupo ti awon asikiri ti wa.

en: In this sense, many immigrants are actually already inside American power.
yo: Ni ti eyi, opolopo awon asikiri kule ti wa ninu agbara ile America tele.

en: With this different map of inside and outside in mind, the question isn't whether receiving countries are going to let immigrants in.
yo: Pelu aworan inu ati ita orile-ede lemi won, ibeere naa kii se wi pe boya gbigba awon orile-ede wonyi yoo je ki awon asikiri o wole.

en: They're already in.
yo: Won kule ti wole.

en: The question is whether the United States and other countries are going to give immigrants access to the rights and resources that their work, their activism and their home countries have already played a fundamental role in creating.
yo: Ibeere naa ni pe boya orile-ede United States ati awon orile-ede toku maa fun awon asikiri ni an anfaani fani si awon eto ati ohun alumoni ti ise won, ijafetoo won ati awon orile-ede won ti ko ipa pataki ninu iseda re.

en: With this new map in mind, we can turn to a set of tough, new, urgently needed questions, radically different from the ones we've asked before -- questions that might change the borders of the immigration debate.
yo: Pelu aworan orile-ede tuntun yii lokan, a le koju si seeti awon ibeere lile, tuntun, ti a nilo kiakia, to yato gedengbe si awon ti a ti bere tele -- awon ibeere to le se ayipada ariyanjiyan enubode iwole latokere.

en: Our three questions are about workers' rights, about responsibility and about equality.
yo: Awon ibeere meta wa je nipa eto awon osise, nipa ojuse ati nipa idogba.

en: First, we need to be asking about workers' rights.
yo: Akoko, a nilo lati maa bere nipa eto awon osise.

en: How do existing policies make it harder for immigrants to defend themselves and easier for them to be exploited, driving down wages, rights and protections for everyone?
yo: Bawo ni awon ipinnu to wa nile se n je ko le fun awon asikiri lati gbeja arawon ko si rorun fun won lati lo won nilo-kulo, wiwa owo-ise wale, eto ati idaaabobo fun gbogbo eniyan?

en: I have learned that if we focus on women's education, we improve their life positively as well as the well-being of their community.
yo: Mo ti kekoo pe ti a ba gbajumo eko awon obinrin, a maa mu iyato ba igbeaye won gidi gan, bakan naa ni alaafia awujo won.

en: This is why now I dedicate my life to education.
yo: Idi niyi ti mo fi jowo aye mi fun eto-eko.

en: And this is totally aligned with my sense of equity and my pursuit of social justice, because if you want to increase access to health services, you need first to increase access to health education.
yo: Eyi wa ni isokan pelu ironu mi nipa idogba ati lile dede awujo, nitori ti e ba fe se afikun anfani si eto-ilera, e nilo lati koko se afikun anfani si imo ilera.

en: So with friends and partners, we are building a beautiful university in the rural north of Rwanda.
yo: Pelu awon ore ati awon alajose, a n ko fasiti to rewa ni igberiko ariwa orile-ede Rwanda.

en: We educate our students to provide quality, equitable, holistic care to everyone, leaving no one out, focusing on the vulnerable, especially women and children, who are historically the last to be served.
yo: A n ko awon akekoo wa lati pese ojulowo, adogba, itoju apapo fun gbogbo eniyan, laiyo enikeni sile, gbigbajumo awon to kogun sewu, paapaa julo awon obinrin ati awon omode, to se pe ninu itan awon ni eni igbeyin lati gba itoju.

en: We transform them into leaders and give them managerial skills and advocacy skills for them to be smooth changemakers in the society where they will be, so that they can build health systems that allow them to care about the vulnerable where they are.
yo: A se ayipada won si asiwaju a si fun won ni imoose isamojuto ati imoose ije agbenuso ki won le se ayipada to dan moran ni awujo ti won maa wa, ki won le pese eto ilera ti yoo gba won laye lati setoju awon to kogun sewu nibi ti won wa.

en: And it's really transformative.
yo: O si ti mu ayipada wa.

en: Because currently, medical education, for example, is given in institutions based in cities, focused on quality health services and skills, clinical skills, to be given in institutions.
yo: Tori lowolowo yii, eto-eko imo-isegun, fun apeere, ni won n ko ni awon ile-eko to wa nigboro, to gbajumo ojulowo eto-ilera ati imoose, imoose ajemo-itoju, ti yoo di gbigba ni awon ile-eko.

en: We also focus on quality clinical skills but with biosocial approach to the condition of patient, for care to be given in communities where the people live, with hospitalization only when necessary.
yo: A tun gbajumo ojulowo imoose ajemo-itoju sugbon pelu ona-imuse ajosepo iwa ati awujo si ipo-ilera awon alaisan, lati le se itoju ni awujo ti awon eniyan n gbe, pelu gbigbe lo si ile iwosan nigba to ba pon dandan nikan.

en: And also, after four to seven years of clinical education in cities, young graduates don't want to go back to rural area.
yo: Bakan naa, leyin odun merin si meje eto-eko ajemo-iwosan nigboro, awon odo akekoo jade o fe pada si awon igberiko.

en: So this is why we have built the University of Global Health Equity, an initiative of Partners in Health, called UGHE, in the rural north of Rwanda.
yo: Idi niyi ti a fi ko Fasiti Idogba Eto-Ilera Agbaye, igbese awon alajosepo ninu eto-ilera, ti won pe ni UGHE, ni igberiko ariwa orile-ede Rwanda.

en: Our students are meant to go and change the world.
yo: Awon akekoo wa wa lati mu ayipada ba agbaye.

en: They will come from all over -- it's a global university -- and will get the medical education for free at one condition: they have to serve the vulnerable across the world during six to nine years.
yo: Won yoo wa lati ibi gbogbo -- fasiti agbaye ni -- won yoo si gba eto-eko imo-isegun lofee labe adehun kan: won ni lati se itoju awon to kogun sewu jakejado agbaye laarin odun mefa si mesan-an.

en: They will keep the salary for themselves and their families but turn the education we give in quality clinical services, especially for the vulnerable.
yo: Won yoo toju owo ise naa fun ara won ati awon ebi won sugbon won yoo yi eko ti a fun won pada si ojulowo ise ajemo-iwosan, paapaa julo fun awon akogun-sewu.

en: And doing so, they sign an agreement at the start that they will do that, a binding agreement.
yo: Sise eyi, won yoo towo bo iwe adehun ni ibeere pepe pe won yoo se iyen, adehun ofin ni.

en: We don't want money.
yo: A o fe owo.

en: We have to go and mobilize the money.
yo: A ni lati lo pin owo naa yika.

en: But they will turn this in quality service delivery for all.
yo: Sugbon won yoo so eyi di ijabo ise fun gbogbo eniyan.

en: For this, of course, we need a strong gender equity agenda.
yo: Fun eyi, bee ni, a nilo eto idogba laarin okunrin ati obinrin to lagbara.

en: And in all our classes, master's course, minimum of 50 percent of women.
yo: Ni gbogbo yara ikekoo wa, abala eko oye ijinle, o kere ju ida adota awon obinrin.

en: And I'm proud to say that for the medical school that started five months ago, we have enrolled 70 percent girls.
yo: Inu mi dun lati so pe fun ile-eko imo-isegun to bere ni osu marun-un seyin, a ti gba ida adorin awon omodebinrin.

en: This is a statement against the current inequity for women to access medical education in our continent.
yo: Eyi je esi tako aidogba lowolowo fun awon obinrin lati ni anfani si eto-eko imo-isegun ni ekun wa.

en: I believe in women's education.
yo: Mo nigbagbo ninu eto-eko awon obinrin.

en: This is why I applaud African ladies who go all over the world to increase their education, their skills and their knowledge.
yo: Idi niyi ti mo fi gboriyin fun awon obinrin nile Adulawo ti won n lo kaakiri agbaye lati se afikun si eko won, imoose won ati imo won.

en: But I hope they will bring that back to Africa to build the continent and make the continent a strong continent, because I'm sure a stronger Africa will make the world stronger.
yo: Sugbon mo lero wi pe won yoo mu iyen pada wa sile Adulawo lati je ki ekun naa gbooro ki won si so ekun naa di agbegbe alagbara, nitori o dami loju pe ile Adulawo to lagbara yoo so orile-ede agbaye di alagbara.

en: Twenty-three years ago, I went back to Rwanda, to a broken Rwanda, that now is still a poor country but shining with a bright future.
yo: Odun meta-le-logun seyin, mo pada lo si orile-ede Rwanda, si orile-ede Rwanda to ti tuka, to si je orile-ede to kusee sugbon to n tan pelu ojo-iwaju rere.

en: And I am full of joy to have come back, even if some days were very difficult, and even if some days I was depressed, because I didn't find a solution and people were dying, or things were not moving enough.
yo: Mo kun fun ayo lati pada wa, koda ti awon ojo kan ba le koko, to si je wi pe awon ojo kan mo ni irewesi, nitori mi o ri ona abayo awon eniyan si n ku, tabi nkan o lo daadaa.

en: But I'm so proud to have contributed to improve my community.
yo: Sugbon inu mi dun lati lowo si ayipada awujo mi.

en: And this makes me full of joy.
yo: Eyi si n je ki n kun fayo.

en: So, African women from the diaspora, if you hear me, never forget your homeland.
yo: Nitori naa, awon obinrin ile Adulawo lati ile-okere, ti e ba n gbomi, ma gbagbe ilee re.

en: And when you are ready, come back home.
yo: Ti e ba ti setan, e pada wale.

en: I did so.
yo: Mo se bee.

en: It has fulfilled my life.
yo: O ti je ki aye mi ni aseyori.

en: So, come back home.
yo: Nitori naa, e pada wale.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: How community-led conservation can save wildlife
yo: Bi ikopamo ti awujo lewaju re se le doola awon eranko igbo.

en: I'm a lion conservationist.
yo: Mo je olukopamo kinihun.

en: Sounds cool, doesn't it?
yo: O dun-un gbo, abi bee ko?

en: Some people may have no idea what that means.
yo: Awon eniyan kan le ma ni oye nkan ti eyi tumo si.

en: But I'm sure you've all heard about Cecil the lion.
yo: Sugbon o dami loju wi pe gbogbo yin le ti gbo nipa Cecil kinihun naa.

en: [Cecil the Lion (2002-2015) ]
yo: [Cecil kinihun naa (2002-2015) ].

en: (Lion roaring)
yo: (kinihun to n bu ramu-ramu).

en: He roars no more.
yo: Ko bu ramu-ramu mo

en: On the second of July, 2015, his life was cut short when he was killed by a trophy hunter.
yo: Ni ojo keji osu Agemo, odun 2015, won da emi re legbodo nigba ti ode aperanko igbo kan pa a.

en: They say that you can become attached to the animals you study.
yo: Won so wi pe e le feran eranko ti e n ko nipa re.

en: That was the case for me with Cecil the lion, having known him and studied him for three years in Hwange National Park.
yo: Bi o se ri funmi ati Cecil kinihun naa niyen, leyin ti mo ti mo o ti mo si ti mowa re fun odun meta ni aaye-igbafe apapo Hwange.

en: I was heartbroken at his death.
yo: Ikuu re bami lokan je.

en: But the good thing to come out of this tragedy is the attention that the story brought towards the plight of threatened wild animals.
yo: Sugbon nkan rere kan to jade lati ibi ajalu buruku yii ni akiyesi ti itan yii muwa nipa ehonu awon eranko igbo ti won wa ninu ewu.

en: After Cecil's death, I began to ask myself these questions: What if the community that lived next to Cecil the lion was involved in protecting him?
yo: Leyin iku Cecil, mo bere sini bi ara mi ni awon ibeere wonyi: ti o ba je wi pe awujo ti won n gbe legbe kinihun naa lowo si aabo re nko?

en: What if I had met Cecil when I was 10 years old, instead of 29?
yo: To ba se wi pe mo ti mo Cecil nigba ti mo wa ni omo odun mewa, yato si omo odun mokan-din-logbon nko?

en: Could I or my classmates have changed his fate?
yo: Nje emi tabi awon akegbee mi ni yara ikekoo iba ti yi ayanmo re pada bi?

en: Many people are working to stop lions from disappearing, but very few of these people are native to these countries or from the communities most affected.
yo: Opo awon eniyan n sise lati dekun ki kinihun o ma poora mo, sugbon die ninu awon eniyan wonyi ni won je omo onilu si awon orile-ede wonyi tabi lati awujo ti oro kan ju.

en: But the communities that live with the lions are the ones best positioned to help lions the most.
yo: Sugbon awon awujo ti won n gbe pelu awon kinihun naa ni won wa ni ipo to dara ju lati ran awon kinihun naa lowo.

en: Local people should be at the forefront of the solutions to the challenges facing their wildlife.
yo: Awon omo onilu lo ye ki won lewajuu wiwa iyanju si awon ipenija to n koju awon eranko igbo.

en: Sometimes, change can only come when the people most affected and impacted take charge.
yo: Nigba miran, ayipada yoo waye nigba ti awon eniyan ti oro kan to si nipa lara won julo ba gba a.

en: Local communities play an important role in fighting poaching and illegal wildlife trade, which are major threats affecting lions and other wildlife.
yo: Awon awujo igberiko n kopa pataki lati koju pipa ati owo eranko igbo lona aibofinmu, ti won je olori ewu to n damu awon kinihun ati awon eranko igbo miiran.

en: Being a black African woman in the sciences, the people I meet are always curious to know if I've always wanted to be a conservationist, because they don't meet a lot of conservationists who look like me.
yo: Pe mo je obinrin alawo-dudu omo ile Adulawo ninu imo-ijinle, awon eniyan ti mo maa n pada maa n nife lati mo boya o wunmi lati je oluko pamo ni, nitori won kii pade awon olukopamo ti won jomi lopolopo.

en: When I was growing up, I didn't even know that wildlife conservation was a career.
yo: Nigba ti mo n dagba, mi o tie mo wi pe ise-ise ni ikopamo awon eranko igbo.

en: The first time I saw a wild animal in my home country was when I was 25 years old, even though lions and African wild dogs lived just a few miles away from my home.
yo: Igba akoko ti mo ri eranko igbo ni orile-ede mi nigba ti mo wa lomo odun meedogbon, bo tile je wi pe kinihun ati awon aja igbo ile Adulawo n gbe ni ibuso die si ile mi.

en: This is quite common in Zimbabwe, as many people are not exposed to wildlife, even though it's part of our heritage.
yo: Eyi wopo ni orile-ede Zimbabwe, nitori opolopo awon eniyan o laju si eranko igbo, bo tile je wi pe o wa lara asa wa.

en: When I was growing up, I didn't even know that lions lived in my backyard.
yo: Nigba ti mo n dagba, mi o tile mo wi pe kinihun n gbe leyin ile mi.

en: When I stepped into Sav Valley Conservancy on a cold winter morning 10 years ago to study African wild dogs for my master's research project, I was mesmerized by the beauty and the tranquility that surrounded me.
yo: Nigba ti mo dase wo Save Valley Conservancy ni aaro ologiniti kan ni odun mewa seyin lati kekoo nipa awon aja igbo ile Adulawo fun ise iwadi oye ijinle mi, ewa ati idakeroro to yimi ka fami mora.

en: I felt like I had found my passion and my purpose in life.
yo: O dabi eni pe mo ti ri ohun ti mo nife si ati ayanmo mi nile aye.

en: I made a commitment that day that I was going to dedicate my life to protecting animals.
yo: Mo se ipinnu lojo naa pe maa fi gbogbo aye mi daabo bo awon eranko.

en: I think of my childhood school days in Zimbabwe and the other kids I was in school with.
yo: Mo ronu nipa awon igba ti mo wa ni ile-eko ewe ni orile-ede Zimbabwe ati awon omo toku ti a jo wa ni ile-eko.

en: Perhaps if we had a chance to interact with wildlife, more of my classmates would be working alongside me now.
yo: Boya ti a ba ti ni anfani lati farakinra pelu eranko igbo ni, opo ninu awon akegbe mi ni yara ikekoo ni a o jo maa sise bayii.

en: Unless the local communities want to protect and coexist with wildlife, all conservation efforts might be in vain.
yo: Ayafi ti awon awujo igberiko ba fe daabobo ti won si fe gbe pelu eranko igbo, gbogbo igbiyanju olukopamo le ja sasan.

en: These are the communities that live with the wild animals in the same ecosystem and bear the cost of doing so.
yo: Awon wonyi ni awujo ti won n gbe pelu awon eranko igbo naa ni ayika kan naa ti won si n fara gba sise bee.

en: If they don't have a direct connection or benefit from the animals, they have no reason to want to protect them.
yo: Ti won o ba ni ajosepo taara tabi anfani latara awon eranko naa, won o ni idi kankan lati daabo bo won.

en: And if local communities don't protect their wildlife, no amount of outside intervention will work.
yo: Ti awon awujo igberiko o ba daabo bo eranko igbo won, ko si iye idasi lati ita ti yoo sise.

en: So what needs to be done?
yo: Nitori naa ki la nilo lati se?

en: Conservationists must prioritize environmental education and help expand the community's skills to conserve their wildlife.
yo: Awon olukopamo gbodo mu eto-eko agbegbe lokukudun ki won si se iranlowo lati gbooro imoose awujo lati se ipamo awon eranko igbo won.

en: Schoolchildren and communities must be taken to national parks, so they get a chance to connect with the wildlife.
yo: Awon omo ile-eko ati awujo gbodo di mimu lo si awon aye-igbafe apapo, ki won le ni anfani lati ni ibasepo pelu eranko igbo.

en: At every effort and every level, conservation must include the economies of the people who share the land with the wild animals.
yo: Fun gbogbo igbiyanju ati gbogbo ipele, ikopamo gbodo pelu oro-aje awon eniyan ti won jijo n pin ile lo pelu awon eranko igbo.

en: It is also critical that local conservationists be part of every conservation effort, if we are to build trust and really embed conservation into communities.
yo: O tun se pataki pe ki awon olukopamo agbegbe wa lara gbogbo igbiyanju ikopamo, ti a ba fe ki won gba wa gbo ti a si fe fi ikopamo rinle si awujo looto.

en: As local conservationists, we face many hurdles, from outright discrimination to barriers because of cultural norms.
yo: Gege bi olukopamo agbegbe, a maa n koju isoro to po, lati ibi eleyameya si awon isoro nitori asa ati ise.

en: But I will not give up my efforts to bring indigenous communities to this fight for the survival of our planet.
yo: Sugbon mi o ni jawo igbiyanju mi lati mu awon eniyan awujo wole lati ja ija yii fun imoribo agbaye wa.

en: I'm asking you to come and stand together with me.
yo: Mo n pe yin lati wa darapo pelu mi.

en: We must actively dismantle the hurdles we have created, which are leaving indigenous populations out of conservation efforts.
yo: A gbodo jo tu awon isoro ti a ti seda ka, to n yowo awon omo-ilu kuro ninu igbiyanju ikopamo.

en: I've dedicated my life to protecting lions.
yo: Mo ti jowo aye mi fun idaabo bo kinihun.

en: And I know my neighbor would, too, if only they knew the animals that lived next door to them.
yo: Mo de mo pe awon alajogbe mi yoo se bee, bakan naa, iba se wi pe won mo awon eranko ti o n gbe ni egbe won ni.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: How cancer cells communicate - and how we can slow them down
yo: Bi awon horo aisan jejere se n soro - ati bi a sele mu won wale.

en: It's a devastating disease that takes an enormous emotional toll.
yo: Aarun to n bani laye je ni to si n bani lokan je.

en: Not only on the patient, but the patient's loved ones, as well.
yo: Kii se fun alaisan nikan, sugbon awon ololufe alaisan naa, bakan naa.

en: It is a battle that the human race has been fighting for centuries.
yo: Ogun ti iran omo eniyan ti n ja fun aimoye orun-odun ni.

en: And while we've made some advancements, we still haven't beaten it.
yo: Nigba ti a ti se awon itesiwaju kan, a o tii segun re.

en: Two out of five people in the US will develop cancer in their lifetime.
yo: Meji ninu eniyan marun-un ni orile-ede US ni yoo ni aisan jejere ni isemi won.

en: Of those, 90 percent will succumb to the disease due to metastases.
yo: Ninu awon wonyi, ida adorun (90%) yoo juwole fun aarun yii nitori itanka re.

en: Metastasis is a spread of cancer from a primary site to a distal site, through the circulatory or the lymphatic system.
yo: Itanka je ifonka aisan jejere lati aye ipile si aye miran, nipase eto isan-eje tabi eto omi-ara.

en: For instance, a female patient with breast cancer doesn't succumb to the disease simply because she has a mass on her breast.
yo: Fun apeere, obinrin alaisan pelu aisan jejere oyan kii juwole fun aarun naa nitori o po lori oyan re.

en: She succumbs to the disease because it spreads to the lungs, liver, lymph nodes, brain, bone, where it becomes unresectable or untreatable.
yo: O juwole fun aarun naa nitori o n tan lo si edo-foro, edo, ase omi-ara, opolo, egungun, nibi ti ko ni se e fi ise abe yo tabi see toju.

en: Metastasis is a complicated process.
yo: Itanka je igbese amudiju.

en: One that I've studied for several years now.
yo: Eyi ti mo ti n ko nipa re fun aimoye odun bayii.

en: And something that my team and I discovered recently was that cancer cells are able to communicate with each other and coordinate their movement, based on how closely packed they are in the tumor microenvironment.
yo: Nkan ti emi ati iko mi sawari laipe yii ni wi pe awon horo aisan jejere maa n ba ara won soro won si maa n dari eto igbese won, lori bi won se sunmora won ninu agbegbe-aifojuri koko.

en: They communicate with each other through two signaling molecules called Interleukin-6 and Interleukin-8.
yo: Won maa n bara won soro nipase moleku afunilowo meji ti won n pe ni Interleukin-6 ati Interleukin-8.

en: Now, like anything else in nature, when things get a little too tight, the signal is enhanced, causing the cancer cells to move away faster from the primary site and spread to a new site.
yo: Ni bayii, bi nkan miiran ninu eda, ti nkan ba fun die, o maa n ran ami naa lowo, ti yoo si mu ki awon horo aisan jejere naa yara sun kuro lati aye-ipile ki won si fonka si aye tuntun.

en: So, if we block this signal, using a drug cocktail that we developed, we can stop the communication between cancer cells and slow down the spread of cancer.
yo: Nitori naa, ti a ba di ami yii, pelu lilo ogun kan ti a pese, a le da ibanisoro laarin awon horo aisan jejere duro ka si mu adinku ba ifonka aisan jejere.

en: Let me pause here for a second and take you back to when this all began for me in 2010, when I was just a sophomore in college.
yo: E je ki n danu duro die fun iseju aya kan ki n si mu yin pada si igba ti gbogbo eyi bere fun mi ni odun 2010, nigba ti mo je akekoo odun keji ni ile-iwe giga.

en: I had just started working in Dr Danny Wirtz's lab at Johns Hopkins University.
yo: Mo se bere sini sise ni aye fun ayewo imo-ijinle omimo isegun Danny Wirtz ni fasiti John Hopkins ni.

en: And I'll be honest: I was a young, naive, Sri Lankan girl, who had no previous research experience.
yo: Maa de se ooto: mo je odo, alaimokan, omodebinrin Sri Lankan, ti o ni iriri iwadii ateyinwa Kankan.

en: And I was tasked to look at how cancer cells move in a 3D collagen I matrix that recapsulated, in a dish, the conditions that cancer cells are exposed to in our bodies.
yo: Ise ti won gbe fun mi ni lati wo bi awon horo aarun jejere se n rin ni 3D collagen I matrix to maa n safihan, ninu abo kan, ipo ti awon horo aarun jejere n koju lara wa.

en: This was new and exciting for me, because previous work had been done on 2D, flat, plastic dishes that really weren't representative of what the cancer cells are exposed to in our bodies.
yo: Eyi je tuntun o si n fun mi layo, nitori awon ise ateyinwa ni won ti se lori 2D, pelebe, abo onike ti won kii fi bee se agbejade nkan ti awon horo aarun jejere n koju lara wa.

en: Because, let's face it, the cancer cells in our bodies aren't stuck onto plastic dishes.
yo: Nitori, e je ka doju ko o, awon horo aarun jejere ninu ara wa kii duro lori awon abo onike.

en: It was during this time that I attended a seminar conducted by Dr Bonnie Bassler from Princeton University, where she talked about how bacteria cells communicate with each other, based on their population density, and perform a specific action.
yo: Ni asiko yii ni mo lo si semina ti Onisegun-oyinbo Bonnie Bassler lati fasiti Princeton gbe kale, nibi to ti soro nipa bi awon horo alamo se n bara won soro, lori iye agbarijopo won, ti won si n se awon ise kan pato.

en: "It was at this moment that a light bulb went off in my head, and I thought, ""Wow, I see this in my cancer cells every day, when it comes to their movement."
yo: "Asiko yii ni ina kan dede ku lori mi, mo wa ro o, ""Wow, mo maa n ri eyi ninu horo aarun jejere mi lojoojumo, ti a ba n so nipa igbese won."

en: The idea for my project was thus born.
yo: Ero ise-akanse mi ba di bibi.

en: I hypothesized that cancer cells are able to communicate with each other and coordinate their movement, based on how closely packed they are in the tumor microenvironment.
yo: Mo se aroso pe awon horo aarun jejere maa n bara won soro won si maa n dari igbese won, lori bi won se jo wa papo ni awujo-aifojuri koko.

en: I became obsessed with pursuing this hypothesis.
yo: Mo bere sini ronu pelu isise to aroso yii.

en: And fortunately, I work for someone who is open to running with my crazy ideas.
yo: Ori bami se, mo n sise fun enikan to setan lati sise pelu ero to n sin mi niwin.

en: So, I threw myself into this project.
yo: Nitori naa, mo jura mi sinu ise-akanse yii.

en: However, I couldn't do it by myself.
yo: Sibe, mi o le dase e funra mi.

en: I needed help.
yo: Mo nilo iranlowo.

en: I definitely needed help.
yo: Mo nilo iranlowo looto.

en: So we recruited undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and professors from different institutions and multiple disciplines to come together and work on this idea that I conceived as a sophomore in college.
yo: A gba awon akekoo ti won o tii kekoo jade, awon akekoo-jade, awon omowe ati awon ojogbon lati ile-eko lorisirisi ati orisirisi eka lati parapo sise lori ero yii ti mo loyun re gege bi akekeo odun keji nile-eko giga.

en: After years of conducting experiments together and merging different ideas and perspectives, we discovered a new signaling pathway that controls how cancer cells communicate with each other and move, based on their cell density.
yo: Leyin aimoye odun ti a ti n se idanwo papo ti a si n pa orisirisi ero ati oye po, a sawari oripa isami tuntun to n darii bi awon ho

en: Some of you might have heard this, because most of social media knows it as the Hasini effect.
yo: Awon kan ninu yin le ti gbo eyi, nitori opo awon ikani ibanidore mo o si ipa Hasini.

en: And we weren't done yet.
yo: A o de tii setan.

en: We then decided that we wanted to block this signaling pathway and see if we could slow down the spread of cancer.
yo: A wa pinnu wi pe a fe di oripa isami ka wa wo o boya a le mu adinku ba ifonka aarun jejere.

en: Which we did, in preclinical animal models.
yo: Ti a de se, ni awose itoju siwaju ayewo lara eranko.

en: We came up with a drug cocktail consisting of tocilizumab, which is currently used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, and reparixin, which is currently in clinical trials against breast cancer.
yo: A pese oogun aladalu kan to ni tocilizumab, ti a n lo lowolowo lati toju lakuregbe, ati reparixin, ti a n lo lowolowo fun iwadii ajemo-itoju aarun jejere oyan.

en: And interestingly, what we found was that this cocktail of drugs really had no effect on tumor growth, but directly targeted metastases.
yo: Pelu idunu, nkan ti a ri ni wi pe oogun aladalu yii ko fi bee nipa lara idagbasoke koko, sugbon o dojuko itanka taara.

en: This was a significant finding, because currently, there aren't any FDA-approved therapeutics that directly target the spread of cancer.
yo: Eyi je abajade to se pataki, tori lowolowo yii, ko si oogun FDA kankan to gbase to n koju itanka aarun jejere taara.

en: In fact, the spread of cancer, metastasis, is thought of as a byproduct of tumor growth.
yo: Looto, itanka aarun jejere, titanka, ni won n ri gege bi eroja idagbasoke koko.

en: Where the idea is, if we can stop the tumor from growing, we can stop the tumor from spreading.
yo: Nibi ti ero naa wa, ti a ba le dena idagbasoke koko, a le dena itanka koko.

en: However, most of us know that this is not true.
yo: Sibe, opolopo wa mo wi pe eyi kii se ooto.

en: We, on the other hand, came up with the drug cocktail that targets metastasis not by targeting tumor growth, but by targeting the complex mechanisms that govern it, through the targeting of the Hasini effect.
yo: Awa, nida keji, pese ogun olomi kan to n koju itanka ti kii se pelu idojuko idagbasoke koko, sugbon pelu idojuko iseda to gbooro to n dari re, nipase kikoju ipa Hasini.

en: "This work was recently published in ""Nature Communications,"" and my team and I received an overwhelming response from around the world."
yo: "Won se atejade ise yii laipe yii ninu ""Nature Communications,"" emi ati awon iko mi de gba esi to po kaakiri agbaye."

en: Nobody on my team could have predicted this sort of response.
yo: Ko si enikeni ninu iko mi to le so asotele iru awon esi yii.

en: We seem to have struck a nerve.
yo: O jo bi eni pe a ti kan nkan.

en: Looking back, I am extremely grateful for the positive response that I received, not only from academia, but also patients, and people around the world affected by this terrible disease.
yo: Wiwo eyin, mo n dupe gidi gan fun awon esi gidi ti mo ri gba, kii se lati eka eto-eko nikan, sugbon lati odo awon alaisan, ati awon eniyan kaakiri agbaye ti aarun buruku yii n baja.

en: As I reflect on this success I've encountered with the Hasini effect, I keep coming back to the people that I was fortunate enough to work with.
yo: Bi mo se n nipa lori aseyori ti mo ba pade pelu ipa Hasini, mo tun pada wa ba awon eniyan ti mo ni anfani lati sise pelu.

en: The undergraduate students who demonstrated superhuman powers through their hard work and dedication.
yo: Awon akekoo ti won o tii kekoo jade ti won fi agbara akanda eniyan han nipase ise takun-takun ati ifokansin won.

en: The graduate students and the postdoctoral fellows, my fellow Avengers, who taught me new techniques and always made sure I stayed on track.
yo: Awon akekoo-jade ati awon omowe, awon akegbe mi olukoya, ti won ko mi ni awon ogbon tuntun ti won si rii daju pe mo wa loju ona.

en: The professors, my Yodas and my Obi-Wan Kenobis, who brought their expertise into making this work into what it is today.
yo: Awon ojogon, awon Yoda ati Obi-Wan Kenobid mi, ti won mu imo ojini won wa lati je ki ise yii di nkan to da loni.

en: The support staff, the friends and family, people who lifted our spirits, and never let us give up on our ambitious endeavors.
yo: Awon osise alatileyin, awon ore ati ebi, awon eniyan ti won gbe ori mi soke, ti won o je ka jakan lori igbiyanju ipinnu wa.

en: The best kind of sidekicks we could have asked for.
yo: Awon kese to dara ju ti a le bere fun.

en: It took a village to help me study metastasis.
yo: O gba abule kan lati ba mi sayewo itanka.

en: And believe me, without my village, I wouldn't be here.
yo: E gbamigbo, laisi abule mi, mi o ni si nibi.

en: Today, our team has grown, and we are using the Hasini effect to develop combination therapies that will effectively target tumor growth and metastases.
yo: Loni, iko wa ti dagba, a si n lo ipa Hasini lati pese akojopo oogun to maa koju idagbasoke koko ati itanka.

en: We are engineering new anticancer therapeutics, to limit toxicity and to reduce drug resistance.
yo: A n se eto oogun atako-jejere, lati se adinku oro ati lati mu adinku ba itako oogun.

en: And we are developing groundbreaking systems that will help for the development of better human clinical trials.
yo: A n se awon eto ti yoo nipa ti yoo si se iranwo fun idagbasoke iwadii ajemo-itoju lara eniyan daadaa.

en: It blows my mind to think that all this, the incredible work that I'm pursuing -- and the fact that I'm standing here, talking to you today -- all came from this tiny idea that I had when I was sitting at the back of a seminar when I was just 20 years old.
yo: O munu mi dun lati ronu wi pe gbogbo eyi, ise alailegbe ti mo n sise to - ati ije ooto pe mo duro nibi, baa yin soro loni -- gbogbo re wa latara ero kekere ti mo ni nigba ti mo joko leyin ni semina nigba ti mo wa lomo ogun odun.

en: I recognize that right now, I am on this incredible journey that allows me to pursue work that I am extremely passionate about, and something that feeds my curiosity on a daily basis.
yo: Mo mo iyen nisinyii, mo wa lori irin-ajo alailegbe yii to fun mi ni anfani lati sise to ise ti mo nife si, ati nkan to maa n bo imo mi lojoojumo.

en: But I have to say, my favorite part of all of this -- other than, of course, being here, talking to you, today -- is the fact that I get to work with a diverse group of people, who make my work stronger, better and just so much more fun.
yo: Sugbon mo gbodo so pe, eyi ti mo feran ju ninu gbogbo eyii -- yato si, bee ni, wiwa nibi, bi baa yin soro, loni -- ni pe mo sise pelu orisirisi eya eniyan, ti won je ki ise mi lagbara, ko dara ko si rorun pupo.

en: And because of this, I have to say that collaboration is my favorite superhuman power.
yo: Tori eleyii, mo ni lati so wi pe ajosepo ni agbara akanda-eniyan ti mo feran ju.

en: And what I love about this power is that it's not unique to me.
yo: Nkan ti mo si feran nipa agbara yii ni wi pe emi nikan ko ni mo ni i.

en: It's within all of us.
yo: O wa ninu gbogbo wa.

en: My work shows that even cancer cells use collaboration to invade our bodies and spread their wrath.
yo: Ise mi fi han pe koda awon horo aarun jejere ma n lo ajosepo lati kogun ja ago-ara wa ati lati fon ibinu won ka.

en: For us humans, it is a superpower that has produced incredible discoveries in the medical and scientific field.
yo: Fun awa eniyan, agbara-akanda naa ti pese awon awari alailegbe ni eka imo-isegun ati imo-ijinle.

en: And it is the superpower that we can all turn to to inspire us to create something bigger than ourselves, that will help make the world a better place.
yo: Agbara-akanda naa ni gbogbo wa le koju si lati se koriya fun wa lati se nkan to tobi ju awa funra wa lo, iyen yoo si ran wa lowo lati so ile-aye di aye to dara.

en: Collaboration is the superpower that I turn to, to help me fight cancer.
yo: Ajosepo ni agbara-akanda ti mo koju si, lati ba mi jagun aarun jejere.

en: And I am confident that with the right collaborations, we will beat this terrible disease.
yo: Mo de ni idaniloju pe pelu ajosepo to to, a maa segun aarun buruku yii.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: You may be accidentally investing in cigarette companies
yo: E le maa dokowo si awon ile-ise siga laimo.

en: In 2001, I was a brand new, shiny doctor, planning to save the world.
yo: Ni odun 2001, mo je onisegun-oyinbo tuntun ayoran, to n dan, to n gbero lati gba aye la.

en: My first job was working for three months on a lung cancer unit.
yo: Ise mi akoko ni sise ise fun osu meta ni eka aarun jejere edoforo.

en: Nearly all of my patients were smokers or ex-smokers, and most of them had started smoking when they were children or in their early teens.
yo: O fere je wi pe gbogbo alaisan mi ni won n mu siga tabi ti mu siga ri, opo won si ti bere si mu siga nigba ti won wa lomode tabi lati bii omodun metala.

en: And despite living in a beautiful, wealthy country, with access to the most sophisticated medicines, nearly every single one of my patients died.
yo: Pelu pe won n gbe ni orile-ede to rewa, to roro, pelu anfani si awon oogun to lagbara ju, o fere je wi pe ikankan gbogbo awon alaisan mi ni won ku tan.

en: Everyone knows tobacco is bad, but when you see the impact firsthand, day-by-day, it leaves a very deep impression.
yo: Gbogbo eniyan lo mo wi pe kukuye o dara, sugbon ti e ba ri ipa re taara, tojo n gori ojo, o maa n fi ipa to kenu sile.

en: Ten years later, I'm a radiation oncologist, fully aware of the suffering caused by tobacco.
yo: Leyin odun mewa, onimo nipa itan ikoko ni mi, to mo nipa inira ti kukuye n fa.

en: I'm sitting at the hospital cafeteria, having my first ever meeting with a representative from my superannuation fund.
yo: Mo jokoo si ile-ounje ile-iwosan, mo n se ipade mi akoko pelu asoju kan lati ile-ise owo-ifeyinti mi.

en: It was thrilling, I'm sure you can imagine.
yo: O munu mi dun, o dami loju pe e le woye re.

en: He tells me I'm in the default option.
yo: O so fun mi pe mo wa ni eyan ipile.

en: "And I said, ""Option?"
yo: "Mo ni, ""Eyan?"

en: Does that mean there are other options?
yo: Se iyen tumo si wi pe awon anfani yiyan miran tun wa?

en: "He looked at me, rolled his eyes, and said, ""Well, there is this one greenie option for people who have a problem with investing in mining, alcohol or tobacco."
yo: "O wo mi, o yi oju re, o si wi pe, ""yiyan idaabo bo awujo kan bayii wa fun awon eniyan ti won ni isoro idokowo ninu iwa-kusa, oti-lile tabi kukuye."

en: "I said, ""Did you just say tobacco?"
yo: "Mo ni, ""Nje o daruko kukuye?"

en: "He said, ""Yes."
yo: O ni, bee ni.

en: "I said, ""So, are you telling me I'm currently investing in tobacco?"
yo: "Mo ni, ""bayii, se o n so funmi wi pe mo n dokowo ninu kukuye lowolowo yii?"

en: "And he said, ""Oh, yes, everyone is."
yo: "O ni, ""oh, bee ni, gbogbo eniyan si ni."

en: When you invest in a company, you own part of that company.
yo: Ti o ba dokowo ni ile-ise kan, o ti ni die lara ile-ise yen.

en: You want that company to grow and succeed and thrive.
yo: O fe ki ile-ise yen gbooro ko se aseyori ko si gberu.

en: You want that company to attract new customers, you want that company to sell more of its products.
yo: O fe ki ile-ise yen fa oju awon onibaara tuntun mora, o fe ki ile-ise yen ta opo ninu awon eroja re.

en: And when it comes to tobacco, I couldn't think of anything that I wanted less.
yo: Ti o ba si je ti kukuye, mi o le ronu nkankan ti mo fe to yato.

en: Now, I know you can only see one person standing here on this big red dot, on this enormous stage.
yo: Ni bayii, mo mo wi pe enikan to duro lori ami pupa yii nikan ni e n ri, lori itage nla yii.

en: But instead, I would like you to imagine that you're looking at seven million people crammed up here beside me today.
yo: Sugbon dipo bee, maa fe ki e ro o wi pe e n wo milionu meje eniyan ti won funpo ni egbe mi nibi loni.

en: Seven million people across the world have died as a result of tobacco in the past year alone.
yo: Milionu meje eniyan kaakiri agbaye ti ku nitori kukuye ni odun to koja nikan.

en: Just imagine, if a brand new industry were launched today, and by the end of next June, that industry's products had killed seven million people.
yo: E ko ro o wo, ti won ba se ifilole ile-ise tuntun ayanran kan loni, ni ipari osu Okudu to n bo, awon eroja ile-ise yen ti pa milionu meje eniyan.

en: Would any of us invest in that new, deadly industry?
yo: Se ikankan ninu wa maa dokowo ni ile-ise tuntun, asekupani yen?

en: Tobacco is one of the most pressing global issues of our time, and most of us are far more complicit in the problem than we may realize.
yo: Kukuye je okan ninu awon oro to n fe amojuto ju ni asiko wa, opolopo wa si lowo ninu wahala naa ju bose yewa lo.

en: So, the super fund representative explained to me that tobacco companies would be found in the international shares portion of my portfolio.
yo: Nitori naa, asoju owo nla salaye fun mi wi pe maa ri awon ile-ise kukuye ni aye ipin-idokowo ile-okere mi.

en: "So I asked him, ""Well, which international shares do I have?"
yo: "Mo bi i leere, ""o daa, ipin-ikokowo ile-okere wo ni mo ni?"

en: He got back to me two weeks later with this list: my number one holding in international shares was British American Tobacco.
yo: """ O kan si mi leyin ose meji pelu iwe yii: idokowo mi akoko ninu ipin idokowo ile-okere je ti British America Tobacco."

en: Number two, Imperial Tobacco.
yo: Eleekeji, Imperial Tobacco.

en: Number four, Philip Morris.
yo: Eleekerin, Philip Morris.

en: And number five, the Swedish Match company.
yo: Eleekarun, ile-ise Swedish Match.

en: Four of the top five companies were tobacco companies, my investments, an oncologist.
yo: Merin ninu awon ile-ise marun to wa loke tente je ile-ise kukuye, idokowo temi, onimo nipa aarun jejere.

en: And then I realized it wasn't just me.
yo: Nigba naa ni mo mo wi pe kii se emi nikan.

en: It was all members of my super fund.
yo: Gbogbo awon omo egbe owo nla mi ni.

en: And then I realized it wasn't just my super fund, it was all of them.
yo: Nigba naa ni mo mo wi pe kii se owo nla mi nikan, gbogbo won ni.

en: And then I realized, it wasn't just superannuation funds, it was banks, insurers and fund managers.
yo: Nigba naa ni mo mo, kii se ile-ise owo ifeyinti nikan, awon ile-ifowopamo, abanidojutofo ati awon alamojuto owo.

en: And then I realized it wasn't just Australia.
yo: Mo wa mo wi pe kii se orile-ede Australia nikan.

en: It was the entire global finance sector, completely tangled up with the tobacco industry.
yo: Gbogbo eka owo lagbaye ni, won sopo patapata mo ile-ise kukuye.

en: The industry that makes products that kill seven million people every year.
yo: Ile-ise to n pese eroja to n pa milionu meje eniyan lodoodun.

en: So I started discussing the issue with my superannuation fund, and I've been discussing it ever since.
yo: Mo bere sini jiroro nipa oro naa pelu ile-ise owo-ifeyinti mi, mo de ti n so o latigba naa.

en: Finance leaders have many challenging issues to deal with, these days.
yo: Awon adari owo ni orisirisi ipenija lati koju, lasiko yii.

en: So I suggest they adopt a framework that clearly articulates why it is reasonable to take a strong position on tobacco.
yo: Mo da a laba pe ki won lo eto-igbese kan ti yoo so idi ti o fi ba ironu mu lati gbe igbese to le lori kukuye.

en: I suggest finance leaders ask a suite of three questions of any company in which they might invest our money.
yo: Mo da a laba pe ki awon adari bere apapo ibeere meta nipa awon ile-ise ti won le ti ko owoo wa si.

en: Question one: Can the product made by the company be used safely?
yo: Ibeere akoko: Nje eroja ti ile-ise naa n pese le di lilo laisewu?

en: No is the answer for tobacco companies.
yo: """Rara"" ni idahun fun awon ile-ise kukuye."

en: Zero is the only safe number of cigarettes for a human being.
yo: Odo nikan ni iye ailewu siga fun omo eniyan.

en: It could not be more black and white.
yo: Ko le ju dudu ati funfun lo.

en: Question two: Is the problem caused by the company so significant on a global level that it is subject to a UN treaty or convention?
yo: Ibeere keji: Nje wahala ti awon ile-ise naa n da sile nipa ni ipele agbaye debi pe o wa labe adehun tabi apero UN?

en: Yes is the answer for tobacco.
yo: """Bee ni"" ni idahun fun kukuye."

en: Indeed there is a UN tobacco treaty that has been ratified by 180 countries.
yo: Looto adehun kukuye UN kan wa ti awon orile-ede bi ogosan ti fowo si.

en: The treaty was created because of the catastrophic global impact of tobacco.
yo: Won seda adehun naa nitori ipa ewu kukuye lagbaye.

en: The current forecast is that the world is on track for one billion tobacco-related deaths this century.
yo: Asotele lowo ni wi pe orile-ede agbaye n wa loju ona fun bilionu kan iku to tan mo kukuye ni orun odun yii.

en: One billion deaths.
yo: Bilionu iku kan.

en: There's only seven billion of us.
yo: Bilionu meje pere niwa.

en: Question three relates to the concept of engagement.
yo: Ibeere keta tan mo ero isoro-papo.

en: Many financial organizations genuinely want to be good corporate citizens.
yo: Opo awon ile-ise owo ni won fe di omo-ilu gidi looto.

en: They want to use their shareholder power to sit down with companies, engage with them, and encourage them to do better things.
yo: Won fe lo agbara ipin-idokowo won lati jokoo pelu aown ile-ise, ba won soro, ki won si se iwuri fun won lati se nkan gidi.

en: So the question is: Can engagement with the company be an effective lever for change?
yo: Ibeere naa ni wi pe: Nje sisoro papo pelu ile-ise naa le je ategun fun ayipada?

en: No is the answer for tobacco companies.
yo: """Rara"" ni idahun fun awon ile-ise kukuye."

en: Engagement with the tobacco industry is futile.
yo: Sisoro papo pelu ile-ise kukuye o le so eso rere.

en: The only acceptable outcome would be if tobacco companies ceased their primary business.
yo: Abajade to se e gba ni ti awon ile-ise kukuye ba dawo owo ipile won gangan duro.

en: In fact, engagement with the tobacco industry has never led to less human death.
yo: Looto, sisoro papo pelu ile-ise kukuye o tii yori si adinku iku omo eniyan ri.

en: When we consider that framework, three simple questions, we can see that is reasonable and defensible to take a strong position and exclude investment in the tobacco industry.
yo: Ti a ba wo eto-igbese yen, ibeere to rorun meta, a le ri wi pe o ba ironu mu o si se e duro ti lati gbe igbese alagbara ka si yo idokowo ninu ile-ise kukuye kuro.

en: In addition to the UN tobacco treaty, there is, in fact, another global treaty that demands that we act on tobacco.
yo: Ni afikun si adehun kukuye UN, looto, adehun agbaye miiran wa to pe fun gbigbe igbese lori kukuye.

en: In 2015, the UN adopted the Sustainable Development Goals.
yo: Ni odun 2015, UN gba awon ipinnu idagbasoke alalope wole.

en: Now, we're talking about tobacco, and I know you're going to jump straight to number three: good health and well-being.
yo: Ni bayii, a n soro nipa kukuye, mo de mo pe e maa fo taara si eleeketa ni: ilera to dara ati wiwa lalaafia.

en: And indeed, ramping up tobacco control regulation is essential if we're going to achieve that goal.
yo: Looto, irolagbara ofin to n dari kukuye se pataki ti a ba fe ki ipinnu yen di sise.

en: However, look a bit more deeply, and you will find that 13 of the 17 goals cannot be achieved unless there is a major shake-up of the tobacco industry.
yo: Sibe, e fi oju inu wo o die si, e o si ri wi pe ipinnu metala ninu meta-din-logun o le di sise ayafi ti atunto to lagbara ba deba ile-ise kukuye.

en: Personally, my favorite goal is number 17: partnerships for the goals.
yo: Fun emi, ipinnu keta-din-logun ni mo feran ju: ajosepo fun ipinnu naa.

en: At present, we have the entire global health sector doing everything it can to help the tidal wave of patients suffering as a result of tobacco.
yo: Lowolowo yii, a ni gbogbo eka ilera agbaye ti won n se gbogbo nkan ti won le se lati se iranlowo fun opo awon alaisan ti won nje rora ipadabo kukuye.

en: But that said, in the past year alone, seven million people have died, so clearly, that is not enough.
yo: Sugbon leyin ti a ti so eyi, ni odun to lo nikan, milionu meje eniyan ti ku, kedere ni, iyen o to.

en: We also have governments aligned on tobacco, 180 of them, busily trying to implement the provisions of the UN tobacco treaty.
yo: A ni awon ijoba ti won to seyin kukuye, ogosan ninu won, ti won n gbiyanju lati samulo ipese adehun kukuye UN.

en: But that, too, is not enough.
yo: Sugbon iyen, bakan naa, ko to.

en: If the global finance sector continues to lend money to tobacco companies, to invest in tobacco companies, and to strive to profit from tobacco companies, we are working against each other.
yo: Ti eka owo lagbaye ba tesiwaju lati maa ya awon ile-ise kukuye lowo, lati dokowo ninu kukuye, to si n gbiyanju lati jere lara ile-ise kukuye, a n sise tako arawa ni.

en: "Now, if we are going to disrupt what doctors call ""the global tobacco epidemic,"" we need every sector of society to stand side by side and be part of the solution."
yo: "Ni bayii, ti a ba fe se idiwo fun nkan ti awon onisegun-oyinbo pe ni ""ajakale aarun kukuye lagbaye,"" a nilo ki gbogbo eka lawujo duro fegbe-kegbe ki won wa lara iyanju naa."

en: So I call on finance leaders to implement a framework to deal with sensitive issues.
yo: Mo n pe gbogbo adari eka owo lati se amulo eto-igbese kan lati gbogun ti oro nla yii.

en: And I call on them to uphold global conventions.
yo: Mo de n kesi won lati sise to awon apero agbaye.

en: But in addition, there are business risks.
yo: Sugbon ni afikun, ewu isowo wa nibe.

en: Pure financial risks, associated with being invested in the tobacco industry over the long term, and I ask finance leaders to consider them.
yo: Awon ewu owo alailabula, to nise pelu idokowo ni ile-ise kukuye fun igba pipe, mo si n ro awon adari eka-owo lati boju wo won.

en: The first risk is that fewer and fewer people will smoke, as a result of increasing tobacco regulation.
yo: Ewu akoko ni wi pe awon eniyan diedie ni yoo ma mu siga, gege bi abajade sise afikun ofin kukuye.

en: Regulation gets noticed, regulation reduces consumption, and we have 180 countries committed to more regulation.
yo: Won maa n kefin ofin, ofin maa n se adinku ilo re, a si ni ogosan (180) orile-ede ti won setan lati se opolopo ofin.

en: Let's talk about litigation and the risk that presents.
yo: E je ka so nipa igbese ofin ati ewu to le fa.

en: At present, it's the business model of the tobacco industry that is being challenged.
yo: Lowolowo yii, ato owo ile-ise kukuye ni a n tako.

en: Currently, the tobacco industry externalizes all of the health costs associated with tobacco.
yo: Lowolowo yii, ile-ise kukuye n se ayokuro gbogbo ewu ilera to tan mo kukuye.

en: Governments pay, communities pay, you pay, I pay.
yo: Ijoba n san, awujo n san, iwo n san, emi n san.

en: The tobacco industry externalizes all those costs, with an estimated one trillion US dollars per year.
yo: Ile-ise kukuye n se ayokuro gbogbo inawo yii, pelu apapo tirilionu kan dola orile-ede US lodun kankan.

en: Yet they internalize and privatize the profits.
yo: Sibe won n se apasile ati adani awon ere.

en: In 2015, in Quebec province, the courts determined that the tobacco industry was indeed responsible for those health costs, and ordered them to pay 15 billion US dollars.
yo: Ni odun 2015, ni agbegbe Quebec, ile-ejo pinnu pe ile-ise kukuye ni won se okunfa awon inawo ilera wonyen, won si pase fun won lati san bilionu meedogun dola orile-ede US.

en: That case is under appeal.
yo: Ejo yen wa ni ile-ejo ko temilorun.

en: But it begs the question, why should any of us, in any country, be paying for the costs of the tobacco industry?
yo: Sugbon o n bere ibere pe, ki lo de ti ikankan ninu wa, ni eyikeyii orile-ede, maa sanwo fun ewu ile-ise kukuye?

en: Let's move on to supply chain and the risk there.
yo: E je ka tesiwaju lo si okun itaja ati ewu to wa nibe.

en: It is not well known that the tobacco industry significantly relies on child labor.
yo: Ko fi bee je mimo wi pe ile-ise kukuye gbara le fifi omo sowo eru.

en: "In March 2017, the International Labour Organization issued a report which stated: ""In tobacco-growing communities, child labor is rampant."
yo: "Ni osu Erena odun 2017, Ajo awon Osise Lagbaye se agbejade ijabo kan to so wi pe: ""Ni awon agbegbe ti won ti n gbin kukuye, fifi omo sowo eru wopo."

en: The US Department of Labor currently lists 16 countries that use children to produce tobacco leaf.
yo: """ Eka osise orile-ede US lowolowo yii ti ka awon orile-ede merin-din-logun ti won n lo awon omode lati pese ewe kukuye."

en: Scrutiny of supply chains is intensifying, and that cannot continue to escape public attention.
yo: Sise ayewo okun itaja finifini lagbara, iyen o si le tesiwaju lati maa fo akiyesi gbogbogbo.

en: Finally, there is also reputation risk to consider for individuals and organizations that continue to maintain an affiliation with the tobacco industry.
yo: Lakotan, ewu ije-omoluwabi wa nibe lati bojuwo fun awon eniyan ati ile-ise ti won n tesiwaju lati maa ni ajosepo pelu awon ile-ise kukuye.

en: In countless surveys, the tobacco industry ranks as the world's least reputable industry.
yo: Ninu aimoye ise-iwadi, ile-ise kukuye lo gba ipo gege bi ile-ise ti ije-omoluwabi re kere julo.

en: Let's just look at the impact on children.
yo: E je ka ko wo ipa re lara awon omode.

en: Globally, every single day, it is estimated that 100,000 children start smoking.
yo: Kaakiri agbaye, ni ojo kankan, won se e wi pe egberun lona ogorun omo ni won maa n bere si mu kukuye.

en: That's enough children to fit inside the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
yo: Iyen je iye omo ti yoo kun inu papa-isere boolu alafigigba Melbourne.

en: And most of those children are from the poorest communities on earth.
yo: Opolopo awon omo wonyen ni won wa lati awon awujo to kusee julo lori ile-eepe.

en: Here in Australia, the average age that people start smoking is 16 years and two months.
yo: Ni orile-ede Australia nibi, aropin ojo-ori ti awon eniyan ti bere sini mu kukuye ni odun merin-din-logun ati osu meji.
