en: They look pretty young to me, but the worst thing here is that while we don't have data from every country on earth, we believe that is the oldest age.
yo: Won kere pupo loju mi, sugbon nkan to buru ju nibi ni wi pe a o ni data lati gbogbo orile-ede to wa lori ile-eepe, a gbagbo wi pe ojo-ori to dagba julo niyen.

en: Everywhere else is younger.
yo: Ni gbogbo aye miiran o kere.

en: Now for the good news.
yo: Nibayi fun iroyin ayo.

en: Things are changing.
yo: Nkan ti n yato.

en: The finance sector is coming to the party.
yo: Eka owo naa ti n darapo.

en: After around 2,000 meetings with finance leaders, primarily in the cafs of Melbourne and Sydney and London and Paris and New York and all across the globe, momentum, moving away from investment in the tobacco industry, is starting to snowball.
yo: Leyin bi egberun meji ipade pelu awon adari eka-owo, ni ile-ijeun Melbourne ati Sydney ati London ati Paris ati New York ati kaakiri agbaye, agbara, yiye kuro nibi idokowo ninu ile-ise kukuye, ti bere sini gbera.

en: Finance leaders are alarmed when they're presented with the facts, and overwhelmingly, they want to be part of the solution.
yo: Awon adari eka-owo ti mo nigba ti won pese eri fun won, ati lopo, won fe darapo mo ona-abayo naa.

en: Here, in Australia, we now have 10,636,101 superannuation accounts that are tobacco-free.
yo: Nibi, ni orile-ede Australia, a ti ni milionu mewa le awon apo ifowopamo owo-ifeyinti ti ko ni kukuye.

en: That one is mine, by the way.
yo: Iyen ni temi, lapa kan.

en: "There is still a lot of work to be done, but I've watched the conversation go from ""Should we go tobacco-free? to Why haven't we done it yet?"
yo: "Ise si po lati se, sugbon mo ti ri bi oro naa se n lo lati ""se ki o ma si kukuye mo ni? ""si ""ki lo de ti a o se tii se e?"

en: In the past year alone, major tobacco-free moves have been made by leading financial organizations in eight different countries.
yo: """ Ni odun to koja nikan, awon igbese kosi-kukuye ti di sise ni awon ile-ise owo ti won n lewaju ni awon orile-ede mejo otooto."

en: In Australia, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, France, Ireland and the USA.
yo: Ni orile-ede Australia, New Zealand, Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, France, Ireland ati USA.

en: By sovereign wealth funds, fund managers, pension funds, banks, insurers and reinsurers.
yo: Latodo awon olominira owo iranwo, awon alamojuto owo, awon owo-ifeyinti, ile-ifowopamo, abani-dojutofo ati atun-bani-dojutofo.

en: Since tobacco-free portfolios began, more than six billion dollars has been redirected away from investment in the tobacco industry.
yo: Lati igba ti apo-ifowopamo ti ko ni kukuye ti bere, o le ni bilionu mefa dola ni won ti dari kuro ninu idokowo ni ile-ise kukuye.

en: The case study is well and truly proven.
yo: Agbeyewo naa dara won si jewo re looto.

en: "When making the tobacco-free announcement in March this year, the CEO of AMP Capital said, ""We are not prepared to deliver investment returns at any cost to society."
yo: "Nigba ti a n se ikede kosi-kukuye ni osu Erena odun yii, alase ati oludari AMP Capital so wi pe, ""a o setan lati se agbekale adapada ere idokowo ti yoo pa awujo lara lona kona."

en: And that is the question we need to ask ourselves.
yo: Ibeere ti a ni lati bi ara wa niyen.

en: Is there no baseline standard below which we will not sink to make profit?
yo: Se ko si gbedeke awokose to je wi pe a o ni koja re lati jere ni?

en: Along the way, I've had a lot of help and incredible support.
yo: Loju ona naa, mo ti ni opolopo iranlowo ati atileyin alagbara.

en: Now, if you're trying to do something, I highly recommend that you have a princess on your team.
yo: Ni bayii, ti o ba n gbiyanju lati se nkan, mo ro yin pe ki e ni omoba-binrin ninu ikoo yin.

en: Her Royal Highness, Princess Dina Mired, is the global ambassador for this work.
yo: Alayeluwa, omoba-binrin Dina Mired, ni asoju wa kaakiri agbaye fun ise yii.

en: We also have a lord, a knight, a former premier, a former federal minister and a stack of CEOs.
yo: A tun ni oluwa, onibiniran, olori orile-ede nigba kan ri, alakoso ijoba apapo nigbakan ri ati agbarijopo awon alase ati oludari ile-ise.

en: But the capacity to change things does not rest exclusively with these highly influential people.
yo: Sugbon ikapa lati yi nkan pada ko si lori awon eniyan pataki wonyii nikan.

en: The power to do that is with all of us.
yo: Agbara lati se iyen wa lodo gbogbo wa.

en: Everyone here can be part of the solution.
yo: Gbogbo wa nibi le darapo mo iyanju yii.

en: In fact, everyone here must be part of the solution.
yo: Looto, gbogbo wa nibi ni a gbodo darapo mo iyanju naa.

en: Most people in this room own companies via their superannuation funds, their banks and their insurers.
yo: Opolopo eniyan ninu yara yii ni o ni ile-ise nipase owo-ifeyinti won, ile-ifowopamo won ati abanidojutofo won.

en: And it is time for us to ask them: Are they investing our money in companies that make products that kill seven million people every year?
yo: Asiko ti to lati bi won: se won n fi owoo wa dokowo ni awon ile-ise ti won n se eroja to n pa milionu meje eniyan lodoodun?

en: It's your money.
yo: Owoo yin ni.

en: It's my money, it's our money.
yo: Owo mi ni, owoo wa ni.

en: And that is a very reasonable question.
yo: Ibeere to si mu opolo dani niyen.

en: Pretty cramped up here, with seven million people beside me today.
yo: Mo fun po nibi, pelu milionu meje eniyan ni egbe mi loni.

en: But if we don't act now, and act together, we'll need to make way for one billion people before the end of this century.
yo: Sugbon ti a o ba gbe igbese nisinyii, ka si jo sise papo, a maa nilo lati sina fun bilionu kan eniyan ki orun odun yii to pari.

en: And this is a very big stage.
yo: Itage to tobi gan ni eyi.

en: But there is no more room.
yo: Sugbon ko si aye mo.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: How deepfakes undermine truth and threaten democracy
yo: Bi foran ayederu se n se idiwo fun otito to si n dukoko mo ijoba awarawa.

en: [This talk contains mature content]
yo: [ijiroro yii kun fun awon akoonu fun agbalagba].

en: Rana Ayyub is a journalist in India whose work has exposed government corruption and human rights violations.
yo: Rana Ayyub je akoroyin ni orile-ede India ti ise re ti tu asiri iwa-ibaje ijoba ati tite eto omo eniyan loju mole.

en: And over the years, she's gotten used to vitriol and controversy around her work.
yo: Fun aimoye odun, awon eebu ati awuyewuye ti o yi ise re ka ti mo o lara.

en: But none of it could have prepared her for what she faced in April 2018.
yo: Sugbon ko si ikankan ninu re to se igbaradi re fun nkan ti ojuu re kan ni osu Igbe odun 2018.

en: She was sitting in a cafe with a friend when she first saw it: a two-minute, 20-second video of her engaged in a sex act.
yo: O jokoo ni ile-ijeun pelu ore re kan nigba ti o koko ri i: foran oniseju meji ati ogun iseju aaya ara re to n ni ibalopo.

en: And she couldn't believe her eyes.
yo: Ko le gbagbo ohun ti oju re ri.

en: She had never made a sex video.
yo: Ko se foran ibalopo kankan ri.

en: But unfortunately, thousands upon thousands of people would believe it was her.
yo: Sugbon o seni laanu, egberun lona egberun awon eniyan yoo gbagbo pe oun ni.

en: I interviewed Ms. Ayyub about three months ago, in connection with my book on sexual privacy.
yo: Mo se iforowanilenuwo fun Ms. Ayyub ni bii osu meta seyin, ni isopo pelu iwe mi lori koko ibalopo.

en: I'm a law professor, lawyer and civil rights advocate.
yo: Ojogbon nipa ofin nimi, agbejoro ati ajafeto omo eniyan.

en: So it's incredibly frustrating knowing that right now, law could do very little to help her.
yo: O n bini ninu lati mo wi pe lowolowo yii, die ni ofin le se lati ran-an lowo.

en: And as we talked, she explained that she should have seen the fake sex video coming.
yo: Bi a se n soro, o salaye wi pe o ye ki oun ti ri i wi pe foran ibalopo ayederu naa n bo.

en: "She said, ""After all, sex is so often used to demean and to shame women, especially minority women, and especially minority women who dare to challenge powerful men,"" as she had in her work."
yo: "O ni, ""Fekan tele naa, ibalopo ni won maa n lo lopo igba lati sa obinrin mere ati lati dojuti obinrin, paapaa julo awon obinrin kekeke, ati paapaa awon obinrin kekeke ti won ba ni igboya lati koju awon okunrin alagbara,"" bo se wa ninu ise re."

en: The fake sex video went viral in 48 hours.
yo: Foran ibalopo ayederu naa lo kaakiri fun wakati meji-din-laadota (48).

en: All of her online accounts were flooded with screenshots of the video, with graphic rape and death threats and with slurs about her Muslim faith.
yo: Gbogbo ikani ayelukara re lo kun fun aworan foran naa, pelu aworan ifipabanilopo ati idukoko iku pelu eebu nipa igbagbo musulumi re.

en: "Online posts suggested that she was ""available"" for sex."
yo: "Awon atejade lori ero ayelukara da a laba wi pe o ""si sile"" fun ibalopo."

en: And she was doxed, which means that her home address and her cell phone number were spread across the internet.
yo: Won wonu aka re, eyi to tumo si wi pe adiresi ilee re ati nomba ero ibanisoro re ni won fonka ori ikani alatagba.

en: The video was shared more than 40,000 times.
yo: Won se atagba foran naa ju igba ogoji egberun (40,000) lo.

en: Now, when someone is targeted with this kind of cybermob attack, the harm is profound.
yo: Ni bayii, ti won ba doju ko enikan pelu iru awon eebu ikani ayelukara yii, akoba re maa n po gan.

en: Rana Ayyub's life was turned upside down.
yo: Won da igbesiaye Ranna Ayyub kodo.

en: For weeks, she could hardly eat or speak.
yo: Fun aimoye ose, tipa-tipa lo fi n jeun tabi soro.

en: She stopped writing and closed all of her social media accounts, which is, you know, a tough thing to do when you're a journalist.
yo: O dawo kiko duro o si ti gbogbo ikani ibanidore re pa, to je, e mo, nkan to lagbara lati se ti o ba je akoroyin.

en: And she was afraid to go outside her family's home.
yo: Eru si n ba a lati jade kuro ni ile awon molebii re.

en: What if the posters made good on their threats?
yo: Ti awon ti won n dukoko ba mu ileri won se nko?

en: The UN Council on Human Rights confirmed that she wasn't being crazy.
yo: Ajo-igbimo UN to n ri si eto omo eniyan fese re mule wi pe orii re o daru.

en: It issued a public statement saying that they were worried about her safety.
yo: Won fi ohun lede wi pe okan awon o bale nipa aabo re.

en: What Rana Ayyub faced was a deepfake: machine-learning technology that manipulates or fabricates audio and video recordings to show people doing and saying things that they never did or said.
yo: Nkan ti Rana Ayyub koju ni foran ayederu: imo-ero ikekoo-ero to maa n se ayederu tabi ayida akale ohun ati aworan lati safihan awon eniyan to n se to si n so ohun ti won o se tabi so.

en: Deepfakes appear authentic and realistic, but they're not; they're total falsehoods.
yo: Foran ayederu ma n dabi asegbarale o de maa n jo tooto, sugbon won o ri bee; iro patapata niwon.

en: Although the technology is still developing in its sophistication, it is widely available.
yo: Bo tile je wi pe imo-ero si n dagba soke ninu imo re, o wa kaakiri.

en: Now, the most recent attention to deepfakes arose, as so many things do online, with pornography.
yo: Ni bayii, akiyesi si foran ayederu dide laipe yii, bi orisirisi nkan se n se lori ikani ayelukara, pelu sinima ibalopo.

en: In early 2018, someone posted a tool on Reddit to allow users to insert faces into porn videos.
yo: Ni ibere odun 2018, enikan fi irinse kan lede lori Reddit lati fun awon asamulo re ni anfani lati gbe oju si foran ibalopo.

en: And what followed was a cascade of fake porn videos featuring people's favorite female celebrities.
yo: Nkan to tele eyi ni opolopo awon foran ibalopo ayederu to n safihan awon eni-iyi lobinrin ti won je aayo awon eniyan.

en: And today, you can go on YouTube and pull up countless tutorials with step-by-step instructions on how to make a deepfake on your desktop application.
yo: Loni, e le lo sori YouTube ki e wo awon eko ti ko se e ka pelu ikoni leseese lori bi o sele se foran ayederu lori komputa alapo tii re.

en: And soon we may be even able to make them on our cell phones.
yo: Laipe a le ma sewon lori awon ero-ibanisoro wa.

en: Now, it's the interaction of some of our most basic human frailties and network tools that can turn deepfakes into weapons.
yo: Ni bayii, ajosepo lairin awon kudie-kudie omo eniyan ati awon irinse oju-opo ayelukara ni o le so foran ayederu di ohun-ija.

en: So let me explain.
yo: E je ki n salaye.

en: As human beings, we have a visceral reaction to audio and video.
yo: Gege bi omo eniyan, a maa n fi eran-ara fesi si ohun ati aworan.

en: We believe they're true, on the notion that of course you can believe what your eyes and ears are telling you.
yo: A gbagbo pe ooto ni won, pelu igbagbo wi pe bee ni e le nigbagbo ninu nkan ti oju ati eti yin ba n so fun yin.

en: And it's that mechanism that might undermine our shared sense of reality.
yo: Eya ara yen naa ni o le se idiwo fun igbagbo wa nipa ooto.

en: Although we believe deepfakes to be true, they're not.
yo: Bo tile je wi pe a gbagbo pe ooto ni foran ayederu, won ko ri bee.

en: And we're attracted to the salacious, the provocative.
yo: A maa n fa si ibaje, abini-ninu.

en: We tend to believe and to share information that's negative and novel.
yo: A maa n gbagbo a de maa n se atagba awon afitoni ti o da ati aroso.

en: And researchers have found that online hoaxes spread 10 times faster than accurate stories.
yo: Awon onise-iwadii ti ri i pe iro maa n yara fonka nigba mewaa ju awon itan to peye lo.

en: Now, we're also drawn to information that aligns with our viewpoints.
yo: Ni bayii, a maa n fa si awon afitoni to papo mo ero wa.

en: "Psychologists call that tendency ""confirmation bias."
yo: "Awon onimo ise-okan pe iwa yen ni ""ifesemule asegbe."

en: And social media platforms supercharge that tendency, by allowing us to instantly and widely share information that accords with our viewpoints.
yo: Awon ikani ibanidore ayelukara n se afikun iwa yen, pelu anfani lati se atagba awon afitoni to ba oju-iwoye wa mu lesekese ati kariaye.

en: Now, deepfakes have the potential to cause grave individual and societal harm.
yo: Ni bayii, foran ayederu ni anfani lati fa ewu to lagbara fun eniyan ati awujo.

en: So, imagine a deepfake that shows American soldiers in Afganistan burning a Koran.
yo: E woye foran ayederu to n safihan omo ogun ile America ni orile-ede Afganistan to n dana sun omo orile-ede korea.

en: You can imagine that that deepfake would provoke violence against those soldiers.
yo: E le woye pe foran ayederu yen maa fa rogbodiyan tako awon omo ogun wonyen.

en: And what if the very next day there's another deepfake that drops, that shows a well-known imam based in London praising the attack on those soldiers?
yo: To ba se wi pe lojo keji gangan foran ayederu miiran tun jade, to n safihan imaamu ilu-mooka kan to n gbe ni London to wa n gboriyin fun ikolu awon omo ogun woyen nko?

en: We might see violence and civil unrest, not only in Afganistan and the United Kingdom, but across the globe.
yo: A le ri rogbodiyan ati ifehonuhan, kii se ni orile-ede Afganistan ati United kingdom nikan, sugbon kaakiri gbogbo agbaye.

en: "And you might say to me, ""Come on, Danielle, that's far-fetched."
yo: "E de le so funmi wi pe, ""wa, Danielle, iyen o se e se."

en: But it's not.
yo: Sugbon ko ri bee.

en: We've seen falsehoods spread on WhatsApp and other online message services lead to violence against ethnic minorities.
yo: A ti ri bi iro se n tanka lori ikani WhatsApp ati awon ikani atejise miiran lori ero ayelukara se n yori si rogbodiyan tako awon iran kekeke.

en: And that was just text -- imagine if it were video.
yo: Atejise lasan niyen -- e woye pe to ba je wi pe foran alaworan ni.

en: Now, deepfakes have the potential to corrode the trust that we have in democratic institutions.
yo: Ni bayii, foran ayederu ni anfani lati ba igbagbo ti a ni ninu orile-ede olominira je.

en: So, imagine the night before an election.
yo: Nitori naa, e woye ale ibo kola.

en: There's a deepfake showing one of the major party candidates gravely sick.
yo: Ti foran ayederu kan wa n safihan ikan ninu awon adije-dupo labe egbe oselu nla kan ti ara re o ya gidi gan.

en: The deepfake could tip the election and shake our sense that elections are legitimate.
yo: Foran ayederu naa le sun ibo naa ko si gbo opolo wa pe idibo bofin mu.

en: Imagine if the night before an initial public offering of a major global bank, there was a deepfake showing the bank's CEO drunkenly spouting conspiracy theories.
yo: E woye to ba je wi pe alee o kola ti ile-ifowopamo agbaye nla kan fe ta ipin idokowo sita, foran ayederu kan wa n safihan alase ati oludari ile-ifowopamo naa to n so awon tiori agbelero leyin to ti yo.

en: The deepfake could tank the IPO, and worse, shake our sense that financial markets are stable.
yo: Foran ayederu naa le bo tita ipin idokowo naa mole, to tun buru, gbo opolo wa pe awon oja owo naa duro sisin.

en: So deepfakes can exploit and magnify the deep distrust that we already have in politicians, business leaders and other influential leaders.
yo: Foran ayederu le samulo ko si so ainigbagbo ti a ti ni tele ninu awon oloselu, awon adari owo ati awon adari miran to nifon di nla.

en: They find an audience primed to believe them.
yo: Won maa n wa awon onworan ti won ti duro lati gba won gbo.

en: And the pursuit of truth is on the line as well.
yo: Isise to otito naa wa ninu ewu bakan naa.

en: Technologists expect that with advances in AI, soon it may be difficult if not impossible to tell the difference between a real video and a fake one.
yo: Awon onimo-ero n reti wi pe pelu itesiwaju ninu AI, laipe o le soro tabi ko ma se e se lati so iyato laarin foran alaworan gidi ati ayederu.

en: So how can the truth emerge in a deepfake-ridden marketplace of ideas?
yo: Bawo ni otito se le jeyo ni oja oye ti foran ayederu n da laamu?

en: Will we just proceed along the path of least resistance and believe what we want to believe, truth be damned?
yo: Se a o ko tesiwaju ni ona aise e gbarale ati igbagbo ohun ti a fe gbagbo, ka sepe fun otito?

en: And not only might we believe the fakery, we might start disbelieving the truth.
yo: Kii se wi pe a le gba ayederu gbo nikan, a le bere si so igbagbo nu ninu otito.

en: We've already seen people invoke the phenomenon of deepfakes to cast doubt on real evidence of their wrongdoing.
yo: A ti ri awon eniyan ti won lo foran ayederu lati so ariyanjiyan si eri gidi nipa asise won.

en: "We've heard politicians say of audio of their disturbing comments, ""Come on, that's fake news."
yo: "A ti gbo ti awon oloselu so nipa foran oro won to bani lokan je, ""E wa, iroyin ayederu niyen."

en: You can't believe what your eyes and ears are telling you.
yo: E o le gba nkan ti oju ati eti yin n so fun yin gbo.

en: "And it's that risk that professor Robert Chesney and I call the liar's dividend"": the risk that liars will invoke deepfakes to escape accountability for their wrongdoing."
yo: """ Ewu yen ni emi ati ojogbon Robert Chesney pe ni ""ere oniro"": ewu pe awon oniro le lo foran ayederu lati sa fun ijiyin asise won."

en: So we've got our work cut out for us, there's no doubt about it.
yo: Won ti pin ise wa fun wa, ko si iyemeji nipa re.

en: And we're going to need a proactive solution from tech companies, from lawmakers, law enforcers and the media.
yo: A maa nilo ona abayo latodo awon ile-ise imo-ero, awon asofin, awon agbofinro ati ile-ise iroyin.

en: And we're going to need a healthy dose of societal resilience.
yo: A maa nilo ifarada awujo ni iwon alailewu.

en: So now, we're right now engaged in a very public conversation about the responsibility of tech companies.
yo: Ni bayii, a ti wa ninu apero gbogbogbo nipa ojuse awon ile-ise imo-ero.

en: And my advice to social media platforms has been to change their terms of service and community guidelines to ban deepfakes that cause harm.
yo: Imoran mi fun awon ikani ibanidore ni lati se ayipada adehun ise won ati ilana itosona awujo lati fi ofin de foran ayederu to le fa ewu.

en: That determination, that's going to require human judgment, and it's expensive.
yo: Ipinnu yen, yoo gba idajo omo eniyan, o de won.

en: But we need human beings to look at the content and context of a deepfake to figure out if it is a harmful impersonation or instead, if it's valuable satire, art or education.
yo: Sugbon a nilo ki awon eniyan wo akonu ati ogangan ipoo foran ayederu lati sawari re boya ayederu eniyan to lewu ni tabi dipo bee, ti o ba je pe eebu to niye lori ni, ogbon atinuda tabi eko.

en: So now, what about the law?
yo: Ni bayii, ofin nko?

en: Law is our educator.
yo: Oludanileko wa ni ofin je.

en: It teaches us about what's harmful and what's wrong.
yo: O maa n kowa nipa nkan to lewu ati nkan ti o to.

en: And it shapes behavior it deters by punishing perpetrators and securing remedies for victims.
yo: O maa n satunse iwa o maa n dena iwa-ibaje pelu fifi iya je oniwa ibaje ati wiwa atunse fun awon toro sele si.

en: Right now, law is not up to the challenge of deepfakes.
yo: Ni bayii, ofin o kapa foran ayederu.

en: Across the globe, we lack well-tailored laws that would be designed to tackle digital impersonations that invade sexual privacy, that damage reputations and that cause emotional distress.
yo: Kaakiri agbaye, a o ni ofin to duroo re ti won yoo se lojo lati tako ayederu eniyan dijita to n tu ikoko ibalopo, to n ba omoluwabi eniyan je to si n fa inira inu opolo.

en: What happened to Rana Ayyub is increasingly commonplace.
yo: Nkan ti o sele si Ranna Ayyub tubo n sele si lemo-lemo.

en: Yet, when she went to law enforcement in Delhi, she was told nothing could be done.
yo: Sibe, nigba to lo si odo awon agbofinro ni Delhi, won so fun un wi pe ko si nkan ti won le se.

en: And the sad truth is that the same would be true in the United States and in Europe.
yo: Ooto to bani lokan je ni wi pe nkan kan naa ni yoo sele ni Amerika ati ile Yuroopu.

en: So we have a legal vacuum that needs to be filled.
yo: A ni alafo ofin to nilo didi.

en: My colleague Dr. Mary Anne Franks and I are working with US lawmakers to devise legislation that would ban harmful digital impersonations that are tantamount to identity theft.
yo: Emi ati akegbe mi Dr. Mary Anne Franks n sise pelu awon asofin orile-ede US lati se ofin ti yoo fofin de ayederu eniyan dijita to lewu to dogba pelu jiji idanimo.

en: And we've seen similar moves in Iceland, the UK and Australia.
yo: A si ti ri iru awon igbese bee ni orile-ede Iceland, UK ati Australia.

en: But of course, that's just a small piece of the regulatory puzzle.
yo: Sugbon bee ni, orike kekere niyen ninu ayo ofin naa.

en: Now, I know law is not a cure-all.
yo: Ni bayii, mo mo wi pe ofin kii se gbogbo nise.

en: It's a blunt instrument.
yo: Irinse to kunu ni.

en: And we've got to use it wisely.
yo: A de ni lati fi ogbon lo o.

en: It also has some practical impediments.
yo: O tun ni awon idiwo aseemulo kankan.

en: You can't leverage law against people you can't identify and find.
yo: E o le lo agbara ofin tako awon eniyan ti e o damo ti e o le ri.

en: And if a perpetrator lives outside the country where a victim lives, then you may not be able to insist that the perpetrator come into local courts to face justice.
yo: Ti oniwa-ibaje kan ba n gbe ni ita orile-ede nibi ti eni toro sele si n gbe, e le ma le taku wi pe ki oniwa-ibaje naa wa si ile-ejo agbegbe lati koju ofin.

en: And so we're going to need a coordinated international response.
yo: A maa nilo idahun lati ile-okere to leto.

en: Education has to be part of our response as well.
yo: Eto-eko ni lati wa lara idahun wa bakan naa.

en: Law enforcers are not going to enforce laws they don't know about and proffer problems they don't understand.
yo: Awon agbofinro o ni lo ofin ti won o mo nipa re ko si gba awon wahala ti o ye won.

en: In my research on cyberstalking, I found that law enforcement lacked the training to understand the laws available to them and the problem of online abuse.
yo: Ninu ise-iwadii mi lori idukoko lori ero ayelukara, mo ri i wi pe igbofinro o ni ikoni lati mo awon ofin to wa nile fun won ati wahala eebu lori ero ayelukara.

en: "And so often they told victims, ""Just turn your computer off."
yo: "Ni opo igba won maa n so fun awon to lugbadi pe, ""ko pa ero komputa re."

en: Ignore it.
yo: Moju kuro nibe.

en: It'll go away.
yo: O maa lo.

en: And we saw that in Rana Ayyub's case.
yo: A de ri iyen ninu igbejoo Rana Ayyub.

en: "She was told, ""Come on, you're making such a big deal about this."
yo: "Won so fun-un pe, ""Wa, o n so nkan yii di babara."

en: It's boys being boys.
yo: Awon omokunrin ni won n sise omokunrin.

en: And so we need to pair new legislation with efforts at training.
yo: A nilo lati se asopo ofin tuntun pelu igbiyanju ifikora.

en: And education has to be aimed on the media as well.
yo: A gbodo doju eto-eko ko awon ile-ise iroyin bakan naa.

en: Journalists need educating about the phenomenon of deepfakes so they don't amplify and spread them.
yo: Awon akoroyin naa nilo eko nipa ilana foran ayederu ki won ma baa pariwo re ko si ma fonka.

en: And this is the part where we're all involved.
yo: Ibi yii ni o ti kan gbogbo wa.

en: Each and every one of us needs educating.
yo: Enikankan ninu wa nilo kiko.

en: We click, we share, we like, and we don't even think about it.
yo: A maa n te, a maa n se atagba, a maa n feran, a o de kin ronu nipa re.

en: We need to do better.
yo: A nilo lati se ju bayii lo.

en: We need far better radar for fakery.
yo: A nilo irinse asawari gidi fun ayederu.

en: So as we're working through these solutions, there's going to be a lot of suffering to go around.
yo: A n sise lori awon ona-abayo wonyi, opolopo iya ni yoo wa ti yoo si kari.

en: Rana Ayyub is still wrestling with the fallout.
yo: Ranna Ayyub si n jija gudu pelu ipadabo re.

en: She still doesn't feel free to express herself on- and offline.
yo: Ara re o tii bale lati soro lori ati kuro lori ero ayelukara.

en: And as she told me, she still feels like there are thousands of eyes on her naked body, even though, intellectually, she knows it wasn't her body.
yo: Bo se so fun mi, o si n dabi eni pe egberun oju lo n wo ihoho oun, bo tile je wi pe, ninu opolo, o mo wi pe ara oun ko.

en: And she has frequent panic attacks, especially when someone she doesn't know tries to take her picture.
yo: O maa n ni iberu lemolemo, paapaa julo ti enikan ti ko mo ri ba gbiyanju lati ya aworan re.

en: What if they're going to make another deepfake? she thinks to herself.
yo: """To ba je wi pe won fe se foran ayederu miran nko? "" o maa n roo lokan ara re."

en: And so for the sake of individuals like Rana Ayyub and the sake of our democracy, we need to do something right now.
yo: Fun anfani awon eniyan bi Rana Ayyub ati fun anfani ijoba awarawa, a nilo lati se nkan nisinyii.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.

en: What tech companies know about your kids
yo: Nkan ti awon ile-ise imo-ero mo nipa awon omoo yin.

en: Every day, every week, we agree to terms and conditions.
yo: Lojoojumo, losoose, a maa n gba awon adehun ati asotele.

en: And when we do this, we provide companies with the lawful right to do whatever they want with our data and with the data of our children.
yo: Ti a ba si se eyi, a n fun awon ile-ise ni eto labe ofin lati se ohun-kohun to ba wun won pelu data wa ati data awon omo wa.

en: Which makes us wonder: how much data are we giving away of children, and what are its implications?
yo: To maa n je ka bere: data ni a n fi sile nipa awon omo wa, ki de ni ipadabo re?

en: I'm an anthropologist, and I'm also the mother of two little girls.
yo: Onimo nipa ajosepo eniyan lawujo ni mi, mo de tun je iya awon omodebinrin meji.

en: And I started to become interested in this question in 2015 when I suddenly realized that there were vast -- almost unimaginable amounts of data traces that are being produced and collected about children.
yo: Mo bere si nife ninu ibeere yii ni odun 2015 nigba ti mo mo pe opo -- ni iye itopa data ti eniyan o lero ti won n pese ti won si ngba nipa awon omo.

en: So I launched a research project, which is called Child Data Citizen, and I aimed at filling in the blank.
yo: Mo bere akanse ise-iwadii, ti won n pe ni Data Omo onilu, mo si pinnu lati di alafo naa.

en: Now you may think that I'm here to blame you for posting photos of your children on social media, but that's not really the point.
yo: Ni bayii e le maa ro o wi pe mo wa sibi lati daa yin lebi fun fifi aworan awon omo yin sori ikani ayelukara, sugbon koko oro ibe ko niyen.

en: "The problem is way bigger than so-called ""sharenting."
yo: "Wahala yii tobi ju nkan ti won n pe ni ""fifi aworan omo sori ikani ayelukara lo."

en: This is about systems, not individuals.
yo: Eyi je nipa eto, kii se awon eniyan.

en: You and your habits are not to blame.
yo: Iwo ati iwa re o lebi.

en: For the very first time in history, we are tracking the individual data of children from long before they're born -- sometimes from the moment of conception, and then throughout their lives.
yo: Fun igba akoko ninu itan, a n topa data omo kankan lati igba pipe ka to biwon -- nigba miiran lati igba ti won ba ti loyun won, ati ni gbogbo igbesi aye won.

en: "You see, when parents decide to conceive, they go online to look for ""ways to get pregnant,"" or they download ovulation-tracking apps."
yo: "Se e ri i, ti awon obi ba pinnu lati loyun, won maa lo sori ero ayelukara lati wa ""ona ti a le gba loyun,"" tabi ki won gba awon irinse atopa-iroyin."

en: And then, when the baby is born, they track every nap, every feed, every life event on different technologies.
yo: Nigba naa, ti won ba bi omo naa, won maa n topa gbogbo oorun, gbogbo ijeun, gbogbo isele oju aye lori orisirisi ero.

en: And all of these technologies transform the baby's most intimate behavioral and health data into profit by sharing it with others.
yo: Gbogbo awon ero wonyi maa n se ayida iwa ikoko omo ati data ilera re si ere pelu sise atagba re pelu awon miiran.

en: So to give you an idea of how this works, in 2019, the British Medical Journal published research that showed that out of 24 mobile health apps, 19 shared information with third parties.
yo: Lati fun yin ni oye bi eyi se n sise, ni odun 2019, Jona Isegun orile-ede British se atejade iwadi to fi han pe ninu irinse ilera lori ero-ibanisoro alagbeka merin-le-logun, mokan-din-logun maa n se atagba afitoni pelu eniketa.

en: And these third parties shared information with 216 other organizations.
yo: Awon eniketa wonyi maa se atagba ifitonileti naa pelu ile-ise merin-din-lokoo-le-nigba miiran.

en: Of these 216 other fourth parties, only three belonged to the health sector.
yo: Ninu merin-din-lokoo-le-nigba enikerin wonyi, meta pere ni won je ti eka ilera.

en: The other companies that had access to that data were big tech companies like Google, Facebook or Oracle, they were digital advertising companies and there was also a consumer credit reporting agency.
yo: Awon ile-ise miiran ti won ni anfani si data yen ni awon ile-ise imo-ero nla bii Google, Facebook tabi Oracle, ile-ise ti won n se ipolowo oja digita niwon bee si ni awon ajo ti won n jabo eyawo onibara naa wa.

en: So you get it right: ad companies and credit agencies may already have data points on little babies.
yo: Nitori naa e gba a: awon ile-ise ipolowo ati awon ajo ayanilowo le ti ni aaye data nipa awon ikoko tele.

en: But mobile apps, web searches and social media are really just the tip of the iceberg, because children are being tracked by multiple technologies in their everyday lives.
yo: Sugbon kekere lasan ni irinse ori ero-ibanisoro alagbeka, wiwa nkan lori itakun agbaye ati ikani ibanidore, nitori won n topa awon omode lori opolopo imo-ero lojojumo aye won.

en: They're tracked by home technologies and virtual assistants in their homes.
yo: Won n topa won pelu awon ero inu ile ati awon ero arannilowo ninu ile won.

en: They're tracked by educational platforms and educational technologies in their schools.
yo: Won n topa won pelu awon ikani eto-eko ati awon imo-ero eto-eko ni ile-eko won.

en: They're tracked by online records and online portals at their doctor's office.
yo: Won n topa won pelu awon akosile lori ikoni ayelukara ati awon eka ori ero ayelukara ni ofiisi onisegun-oyinbo won.

en: They're tracked by their internet-connected toys, their online games and many, many, many, many other technologies.
yo: Won n topa won pelu awon nkan-isere won ti won sopo pelu ikani ayelukara, awon ayo ori ero ayelukara, ati awon ero to po pupo miiran.

en: "So during my research, a lot of parents came up to me and they were like, ""So what?"
yo: "Lasiko iwadii mi, opolopo awon obi ni won wa bami won si n so pe, ""ki wa ni?"

en: Why does it matter if my children are being tracked?
yo: Ki lo je pataki ti won ba n topa awon omo mi?

en: We've got nothing to hide.
yo: A o ni nkankan lati fi pamo.

en: Well, it matters.
yo: O daa, O se pataki.

en: It matters because today individuals are not only being tracked, they're also being profiled on the basis of their data traces.
yo: O se pataki nitori kii se pe won n topa awon eniyan eni nikan, won n se akosile won pelu itopa data won.

en: Artificial intelligence and predictive analytics are being used to harness as much data as possible of an individual life from different sources: family history, purchasing habits, social media comments.
yo: Imo atowoda ati iyanana asotele ti won n lo lati ko data to po jo nipa igbesiaye eniyan lati orisirisi orisun: itan ebi, baraku oja rira, ariwisi lori ikani ayelukara.

en: And then they bring this data together to make data-driven decisions about the individual.
yo: Won si n ko gbogbo data yii jo lati se ipinnu itoni-data nipa eniyan.

en: And these technologies are used everywhere.
yo: Awon imo-ero wonyi ni won n lo nibi gbogbo.

en: Banks use them to decide loans.
yo: Ile-ifowopamo n lo won lati se ipinnu eyawo.

en: Insurance uses them to decide premiums.
yo: Awon adojutofo n lo won lati se ipinnu owo idojutofo.

en: Recruiters and employers use them to decide whether one is a good fit for a job or not.
yo: Awon to n gba osise ati awon to n gba eniyan sise maa n lo won lati se ipinnu boya eniyan to fun ise kan tabi bee ko.

en: Also the police and courts use them to determine whether one is a potential criminal or is likely to recommit a crime.
yo: Bakan naa awon olopa ati ile-ejo maa n lo won lati mo boya o se e se ki eniyan hu iwa odaran tabi o se e se ki eniyan tun iwa odaran hu.

en: We have no knowledge or control over the ways in which those who buy, sell and process our data are profiling us and our children.
yo: A o nimo kankan tabi akoso lori ona ti awon to n ra, ta ti won si n lo data wa se n se akosile wa ati awon omo wa.

en: But these profiles can come to impact our rights in significant ways.
yo: Sugbon awon akosile yii le nipa lori eto wa ni awon ona to se pataki.

en: "To give you an example, in 2018 the ""New York Times"" published the news that the data that had been gathered through online college-planning services -- that are actually completed by millions of high school kids across the US who are looking for a college program or a scholarship -- had been sold to educational data brokers."
yo: "Lati fun yin ni apeere, ni odun 2018 ""New York Times"" se atejade iroyin pe awon data ti won ti kojo nipase ifetosi ile-eko giga lori ikani ayelukara -- ti milionu awon omo ile-eko giga yika orile-ede US ti won n wa eto eko tabi eko-ofe fi sile -- ni won ti ta fun awon onisowo data."

en: Now, researchers at Fordham who studied educational data brokers revealed that these companies profiled kids as young as two on the basis of different categories: ethnicity, religion, affluence, social awkwardness and many other random categories.
yo: Ni bayii, awon oniwadii ni Fordham ti won sewadii nipa isowo data fi han wi pe awon ile-ise wonyi maa n se akosile nipa awon omode lati bi odun meji ni orisirisi isori: eya, esin, oro, iwa-ibaje lawujo ati awon isori adijumu miiran.

en: And then they sell these profiles together with the name of the kid, their home address and the contact details to different companies, including trade and career institutions, student loans and student credit card companies.
yo: Won si n ta awon akosile wonyi pelu oruko omo naa, adiresi ilee won ati awon ona ikansira-eni fun orisirisi ile-ise, pelu awon ile-ise owo ati ise-ise, awon ile-ise owo-eya fun akekoo ati ike igbawo awon akekoo.

en: To push the boundaries, the researchers at Fordham asked an educational data broker to provide them with a list of 14-to-15-year-old girls who were interested in family planning services.
yo: Lati koja enu ala, awon oniwadii ni Fordham so fun onisowo data eko kan pe ko pese akojopo awon omobinrin labe odun merinla si meedogun ti won nifee siifetosebi fun won.

en: The data broker agreed to provide them the list.
yo: Onisowo data naa si gba lati pese akojopo naa fun won.

en: So imagine how intimate and how intrusive that is for our kids.
yo: E ronu si iru asiri ati ayanjuran ti eyi je fun awon omo wa.

en: But educational data brokers are really just an example.
yo: Sugbon apeere lasan ni awon onisowo data eko je.

en: The truth is that our children are being profiled in ways that we cannot control but that can significantly impact their chances in life.
yo: Otito ibe ni wi pe won n se akosile awon omo wa ni ona ti a o le dari re sugbon ti o le ni ipa pataki lara anfani won nile aye.

en: So we need to ask ourselves: can we trust these technologies when it comes to profiling our children?
yo: A nilo lati birawa: nje a le fokan tan awon imo-ero wonyi to ba kan akosile awon omo wa?

en: Can we?
yo: Nje a le se bee?

en: My answer is no.
yo: Idahun mi ni rara.

en: As an anthropologist, I believe that artificial intelligence and predictive analytics can be great to predict the course of a disease or to fight climate change.
yo: Gege bi onimo nipa ajosepo eniyan lawujo, mo nigbagbo wi pe imo-atowoda ati iyanana asotele le dara looto lati so asotele okunfa aarun kan tabi lati gbogun ti ayipada oju-ojo.

en: But we need to abandon the belief that these technologies can objectively profile humans and that we can rely on them to make data-driven decisions about individual lives.
yo: Sugbon a nilo lati se agbeti igbagbo wi pe awon imo-ero wonyi le se akosile awon eniyan laisegbe ati wi pe a le gbara lewon lati fun wa ni ipinnu nipase data nipa igbesiaye eniyan.

en: Because they can't profile humans.
yo: Nitori won o le se akosile awon eniyan.

en: Data traces are not the mirror of who we are.
yo: Itopa data o ki n se aworan iru eniyan ti a n se.

en: Humans think one thing and say the opposite, feel one way and act differently.
yo: Awon eniyan maa n ro nkan kan ki won si so idakeji re, a sewon bakan won o si hu iwa miran.

en: Algorithmic predictions or our digital practices cannot account for the unpredictability and complexity of human experience.
yo: Awon asotele eto tabi awon asa digita o le jiyin fun aileso-asotele ati amudiju iriri omo eniyan.

en: But on top of that, these technologies are always -- always -- in one way or another, biased.
yo: Sugbon lori iyen, awon imo-ero wonyi maa n segbe -- ni gbogbo igba -- lona kan tabi keji.

en: You see, algorithms are by definition sets of rules or steps that have been designed to achieve a specific result, OK?
yo: Se e ri i, awon eto pelu oriki ni akojopo awon ofin tabi igbese ti won ti seda re lati mu esi kan pato, so ye?

en: But these sets of rules or steps cannot be objective, because they've been designed by human beings within a specific cultural context and are shaped by specific cultural values.
yo: Sugbon awon akojopo ofin wonyi o le je ooto, nitori awon eniyan ni won seda won laarin ogangan ipo asa kan ni pato won si mo

en: So when machines learn, they learn from biased algorithms, and they often learn from biased databases as well.
yo: Nigba ti awon ero ba n kekoo, won maa n kekoo pelu eto asegbe, won si maa n kekoo latara akojopo data asegbe.

en: At the moment, we're seeing the first examples of algorithmic bias.
yo: Lowolowo yii, a n ri awon apeere eto asegbe akoko.

en: And some of these examples are frankly terrifying.
yo: Die ninu awon apere wonyi n deru bani.

en: "This year, the AI Now Institute in New York published a report that revealed that the AI technologies that are being used for predictive policing have been trained on ""dirty"" data."
yo: "Ni odun yii, ile-iwe AI Now ni New York ti se atejade ijabo kan to fi han wi pe imo-ero AI ti won n lo fun asotele olopa ni won ko pelu data ""onidoti."""

en: This is basically data that had been gathered during historical periods of known racial bias and nontransparent police practices.
yo: Eyi je data ti won ti gba lasiko itan ti a mo fun isegbe eleyameya ati awon isesi olopa ti o foju han.

en: Because these technologies are being trained with dirty data, they're not objective, and their outcomes are only amplifying and perpetrating police bias and error.
yo: Nitori data to doti ni won fi ko awon imo-ero wonyi, won o so tooto, abajade won ko n safikun ati atunse isegbe olopa ati asise.

en: So I think we are faced with a fundamental problem in our society.
yo: Mo ro wi pe isoro gidi ni a n koju ni awujo wa.

en: We are starting to trust technologies when it comes to profiling human beings.
yo: A ti bere si gba awon imo-ero gbo to ba kan ki a se akosile nipa awon omo eniyan.

en: We know that in profiling humans, these technologies are always going to be biased and are never really going to be accurate.
yo: A mo wi pe lati se akosile nipa awon omo eniyan, awon imo-ero wonyi maa segbe ni gbogbo igba won o si ni peye to bee.

en: So what we need now is actually political solution.
yo: Nkan ti a nilo bayii ni ona-abayo oselu.

en: We need governments to recognize that our data rights are our human rights.
yo: A fe ki ijoba mo wi pe eto omo eniyan wa ni eto data wa.

en: (Applause and cheers)
yo: (atewo ati ariwo).

en: Until this happens, we cannot hope for a more just future.
yo: Ayafi ti eyi ba sele, a o le nireti ojo-iwaju adogba.

en: I worry that my daughters are going to be exposed to all sorts of algorithmic discrimination and error.
yo: Mo n ronu wi pe awon omobinrin mi maa koju oniruuru eto eleyameya ati asise.

en: You see the difference between me and my daughters is that there's no public record out there of my childhood.
yo: Se e ri iyato to wa laarin emi ati awon omobirin mi ni wi pe ko si akosile ijoba nita nibeyen nipa igba-ewe mi.

en: There's certainly no database of all the stupid things that I've done and thought when I was a teenager.
yo: Dajudaju Ko si akojopo data nipa gbogbo nkan ibaje ti mo ti se ti mo ti ro nigba ti mo wa labe ogun odun.

en: But for my daughters this may be different.
yo: Sugbon fun awon omobinrin mi eyi le yato.

en: The data that is being collected from them today may be used to judge them in the future and can come to prevent their hopes and dreams.
yo: Data ti won n gba lowo won loni le di lilo lati se idajo won lojo iwaju o de le dena ireti ati ala won.

en: I think that's it's time.
yo: Mo ro wi pe asiko ti to.

en: It's time that we all step up.
yo: Asiko ti to funwa lati tesiwaju.

en: It's time that we start working together as individuals, as organizations and as institutions, and that we demand greater data justice for us and for our children before it's too late.
yo: Asiko ti to lati bere si sise po gege bi eniyan, gege bi ajo ati ile-ise, ka si beere fun idajo data to tobi fun awa ati awon omo wako to peju.

en: Thank you.
yo: E seun.
